Take a whole day to explore this impressive place. There are so many different parts you can wander for ages. Kids can run free to their heart's content which is an extra if you are travelling with children. Make sure to see the change of the guards ( a few times a day). Gyeongbokgung palace is located in the center of Seoul and easy to acces. Bukchon Hanok Village, Insadong and Cheonggyecheon are in walking distance.

A must see for anyone in Seoul. Walking through the palace gives an impression of what 14th century high society in Korea was like. If you are not coming with a guide, go on line and read about the history and locations within the palace for a forfilling experience.
The palace is at the end of a long boulevard and located in front of some nice hills. Good for photos and watching the changing of guards.

Beautiful old Palace with both striking buildings as well as gardens and ponds. Try to see changing of the guard (several times daily). There is a free English tour of about 60 minutes which is very worth while. Entrance also includes Folk Museum with lovely exhibits of daily life of the period.

I went there early to avoid the crowds, but there were still too many tourists around the main palace. I recommend you keep walking inside, there would be more peaceful and you can enjoy your time there
Located in the heart o Seoul and easily accessible by subway. You can spend the whole day wandering around the palace. Do catch the Palace Guard Changing Ceremony.
A very lovely and historic place. Full of wonderful images and architecture this is a must as are the other Palaces of Seoul

Gyeongbokgung palace is located in the heart of Seoul. It is super easy to access and there are many things that you can enjoy around the palace. You will see many people wearing hanbok which is a traditional clothing of Korea and it is free to enter the place if you wore hanbok. There are many cafes and restaurant around area. you can walk to Cheonggyecheon, Myeongdong, Insadong or Bukchon Hanok village from the palace.
Rather impressive and you can wander for ages. Would be a great place to let the kids run. Be warned, not much in washroom facilities. Could be improved be have period enactors.
there's 2 different areas and both charge you 3k won each, though it is really worth it, or way better. especially garden and pond area was great, must see place in Seoul

When you visit this palace make sure to be there in the morning to see the change of the guards at 10.00 - then take enoug htime to explore all the different bulidings it has to offer. Crowded place but worth it.

The first time I visited the palace was in 2011 to see the residence of Prince Gian and Prince Troy of Princess Hours. NOw that I'm back with my son, we got to discover more about South Korea through the museum and writings about the palace. We toured on our own and it was a warm day so we spent only a few hours here. It was really wide and we got to cool down while we explored the museums in the area.  If in Korea, it's a must to see this beautiful structure and I'm glad they preserved the old buildings for us tourists to see,

If you’re into history then this place is a must see, if you’re not then you’re better off visiting somewhere else. Tour guides will be provided if you’re keen on knowing more about the history of the place on a timed basis. If you’re visiting on summer, prepare some shades or else you will be fried by the hot summer sun. There are some spots that will only open a few times a day, so if you want to visit a particular area, get your schedule right before visiting.

Firstly, the entrance tickets are very affordable -- W3,000 for adults and W1,500 for children up to 18 years old. These low entrance prices make the visit worthwhile to learn about the place and take photos. And a tourist has to take photos, right? Secondly, anyone can gain free entrance by wearing a traditional Korean costume, which can be rented from stores across the main gate of the palace (free entrance in other palaces too, while wearing the traditional Korean costume). This makes your selfie photos inside the palace even better :). Thirdly, the place was lightly filled when we came in on a Saturday late morning. Stay about 2 hours minimum, about 3 hours maximum.

This was the first, largest and the main royal palace of the Joseon Dynasty. It was destroyed during the Japanese occupation and has taken much time and effort to be rebuilt and restored. The Changing of the Guard happened while I was there at about 9:30am. Free admission to even foreigner seniors. Many of the girls and some boys even wore the hanbok costumes for Instagram photos. From here one can go to the Folk Museum and then on to Bukchon Hanbok Village and then the Chandeokgong Palace which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Expect to spend many hours exploring this whole area as it is well worth it. Moving on from there take in lunch on Insadong Street and browse the shops. This will be such a day well spent in Seoul.
You cannot come to Seoul and not visit here. A must see. Gives you a great history of Seoul and you get to see how Royalty lived centuries ago.

We visited this palace. This is by far the biggest palace so be prepared to walk a reasonable distance to cover most of the area. A lot of the buildings are very similar in style and it is interesting from a historical view. There was a changing of the guard which was colorful. Take a bottle of water as there are only a couple of places in the palace compound to get drinks. Worth the visit.

This was built 6 centuries ago and is a really impressive palace in the centre of Seoul. The place is huge and can get quite sunny with little shade so don’t forget suncream and water. There are guards at the gate to look at and pose for photos with. We joined a free guided tour in English which started at 1:30 (they have some more but unsure on the times). This was really useful to tell us about each palace building and point out things you may have missed otherwise. It was hard to believe this is right in the middle of the city! Huge open space with big lavish palace buildings.
Nice and ancient grand palace of Joseon Dynasty of South Korea. There are more other palace that should be visited.
A MUST visit to Gyeongbokgung Palace. The grounds have been restored. The Changing of the Guard. Highly recommended.

A must go if you are a history addict! The museum offers free english guided tours at selected timings and the guide is very informative and lovely!  Try to go before 9 am to get the tickets and roam around before the first english guided tour at 1030 to avoid the scorching hot sun later in the day during summer. The palace gets rather crowded and becomes difficult to take a good photo without other tourists in it.  The palace is very well maintained and many areas worth exploring after the tour. One of the perks of wearing the Hanbok to the palace is that you get free entrance into all the palaces. Do note that this palace is close on Tuesdays.

My family visited this palace and had a good experience exploring it. The palace covered a big area. Be prepared to walk a bit if you intend to cover every bit of it. Palace is easily accessible as it is located near to a Seoul Metro Station (Gyeongbokgung). You will need to purchase tickets to enter the palace too.

This place was incredible. It was huge and incredibly maintained. We had gone during winter and there weren't too many people and so we were able to really walk around comfortably away from crowd. It was cold in the winter -- just as a precaution. There are nearby stores that rent out traditional Korean clothing for those who want to take pictures; this was very common.

If u wear a hanbok to this place, your entrance fee is waived. Yes, I know the hanbok rental cost more than the entrance fee lol, but it’s the experience that counts. Overall a very beautiful place though some of the renovations were quite obviously of recent make. But it doesn’t detract from the beauty of the place.
Feel very humble inside this place, but it’s crowded and sometime hard to move or take pictures at the same time

We really liked that the Palace provided free guided tours in English which helped us learn and understand the different structures within the complex, and the life of the Korean royals back in the day. This is especially interesting to those who watch K-Dramas.

One of the key cultural attractions of Korea in my opinion! There are many shops around the palace that rent traditional clothing especially to go to the palace, so that's what I did (foreigners are wlecomed to do so!). I loved walking around the castle and taking pictures. There are many tourists inside the main court but of you venture into the gardens behind the castle it gets less crowded.
Feel the pulse of the bustling capital of South Korea. This picturesque palace is the first royal palace built in 1395 during the time of the Joseon dynasty.
Really beautiful palace. Worth visiting while in Seoul.beautiful buildings and gateways. Clothing hire available. Wonderful architecture.Had a lovely walk around the palace grounds

We visited on Memorial Day. So everybody were out in their traditional hanboks, plus the Honour Guard really complemented the traditional pageantry. A must visit when in Seoul. Korean traditional architecture at it’s best, set in beautiful, extensive gardens.
Still one of the places to visit when you are in Seoul. The palace is so intricately made and the mountain at the back is so amazing. However, it is so big but there is only 1 or 2 toilets nearby.

The original palace dates back to the 1300s but various invasions by the Japanese in the 1500s, 1800s and 1910 has meant a lot fo the original palace has been destroyed. Much of the palace is reproductions of the original buildings but the architecture is still very impressive. Be equipped with walking shoes and headwear as the palace is quite expansive and exposed

We visited the palace on the last Wednesday of the month, so the admission was free. However, a fee is charged for the guided tour. The palace area was large. There were many tourists wearing Hanbok at the palace. We saw the changing of guard ceremony. There is also a cafe that sells snacks and souvenirs in the palace area.
only issue was that wehn we there, they were preparing for some sort of conference, so missed the photo with the reflection!
It’s a big place with long heritage and old construction building. But I have been to Beijing Forbidden Palace. The construction heritage and treasures of this palace just can’t compare to that

We had a beautiful and enjoyable experience here. Rented a hanbok from nearby and took photos and videos in this Unesco heritage site. It was a really nice day. Come with a full stomach as food is not allowed inside. Or have snacks outside by the exit before or after. We enjoyed the dumpling shop and CU store, in our hanbok :-) Well kept and beautiful Palace.  Staff in Secret Garden was kind and helped us on our way, especially when we were last in the group. Thank you for the English conversation and encouraging words to us as we walked up and down and climbed the steps.

Saw many local and tourists wearing the traditional costumes and indeed they brightened up the whole place, which was just ancient buildings. And it is amazing to see how the building was built with small caving like holes for firewood so that the whole building could be kept warm during winter time.

Love the architecture and colours on the palace . It wax good to see the guards in traditional dress. There are also a lot of ladies dressed in hanbok. 3000 Won entrance fee. Souvenir shop and cafe off to the side.

this is a huge space with beautifully reconstructed gates, temples, and recreation areas. If one rents a native costume and wears it into the grounds, admission is free. Many tourists do this and it adds a flair to the grounds and they all seem to be enjoying their moment in native dress. It is a fairly large site and one can spend a great deal of time there or one can see the highlights in about an hour plus and move on. I highly recommend visiting.
Nice taking photographs but long walk from station. Many people wearing the Hanbok. Good for children to understand their culture.

I arrived in time to watch the changing of the guard at the entrance. It's long, involved and colourful. It's a busy place but there's lots to see. I joined a guided tour and am glad I did as it is vital to understand the place. There were a lot of tourists wearing hired traditional costumes wandering around adding to the colour.

Very clean area and can get very crowded during weekends. Good for photo shoots.  Entrance is free. If you want to rent the Korean traditional costumes it is readily available near the palace before entry and very cheap as well.

If you are looking to see a bit of history in Seoul the palace is worth a visit. Make sure to be there for the changing of the guard at 2pm. The Palace museum next to the actual palace is also very interesting.

I’ve watch many period dramas, I’ve read quite a few books on Korean History and always enjoyed documentaries in regards to the history of Joseon Dynasty. But to walk through it, to sit within the palace walls and have tea with dessert really made my knowledge come together.

To get the full appreciation of the site one needs to walk through the entire grounds and visit the museum. The Palace really shows a lot of Korean culture. We ran into a few groups of Korean students outside the Palace which put us in the right mood from the beginning.

The entrance, main palace and the palace museum are a must see (KW3000 entrance fee). The changing of the guards is an added bonus if you happen to be on time for the event. Note that the palace is expansive which require a lot of walking on stone path and gravel. There are not much shaded tress and places to rest expect around buildings. So an early morning visit is recommended. I made a reservation for an English guided tour of the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion only be disappointed as the tour guide decided to conduct it in the local vernacular. I did inquire though as she stated that she can give me a 10 minute English guide after she is done with the group but left before she finished.

Visited The Palace on our first day in Seoul. It is a beautiful place to visit, but I was saddened to read it’s history as we walked around. So often I learned about the demolition of Korean historical / sacred buildings being destroyed by enemies throughout the centuries. This Palace had been greatly recreated in recent years. Having said that the grounds are definitely worth a visit, tourists can hire Hangbok ( traditional costume) to wear and visit the palace in and many do and take hundreds of selfies. There is also a Changingof the Guards at certain times. Very colourful.
This palace was very large & a bit hard to finish the tour but it's very good. The palace was informative & interesting stories about the culture & history of Korean!
Worth the visit, easily accessible from train station. Could spend the day here and nearby villages.
Beautiful ancestral place. Having a tour guide to fill you in about all the history is great. Would recommend this to anyone visiting the area.
Must see buildings, water garden, and crowds all dressed in traditional Korean costumes. Enjoy the Folk Museum within.

We went through the palace fairly quickly because there were so many people when we were there. I think school field trip was happening and there were tons of kids everywhere. It would have been nicer if it wasn't so crowded.

Free entry on Wednesday is a bonus but either way the grounds are extensive and beautiful with palace complex, craft shop and museum all in one spot. Great way to spend an afternoon. I shall return in order to see the changing of the guards.

We arrived at about 10am and found out that there is a free english tour at 11am. So, after walking around a bit, enjoying the view, we waited for the tour. There was about 30pax waiting for the tour to start. A lady dressed in a lovely hanbok gave us a tour. We enjoyed the tour a lot because the information provided about the palace were very interesting. You will appreciate the palace structure, architecture and culture better. The walking tour took 1 hr and after that, we were free to roam around the palace. Very enjoyable tour, highly recommended!

My traveling to south korean finally completed by visit palace. A very great experience to enter the palace wearing hanbok, felt like a princess for a day. This palace has a huge areas, hence it might be exhausted to look around yet so fun. So guys if you have chance to come to korea, you must be come here.
Beautiful traditional palace of the last ruling dynasty. The free guided tour was great with explanation on the architecture, history and culture. Recommend doing it at the beginning if your trip.
This place is huge and it's a maze inside. But it's fun to walk around and especially the pavillion on the water looks great. It was really crowded, though.

A wonderful and huge palace to visit, the place is very wide and i guess it will take almost few hours to complete the whole place to visit. This is one of must places to visit. There are Museum, park, lot of unique buildings (palaces), kids zone and many more. You will spend almost half day or even full day here....

Being one of the prominent sites for tourists, Gyeonbokgung can get very busy. Try to time your visit to see the changing of the guard - it's actually quite impressive. There is no charge to watch the changing of the guard, but if you want to go inside the palace there is a small (not unreasonable) fee. Make sure you find a spot in the crowds near to the roped off area so that you can see what's going on. The palace grounds are vast. After visiting the buildings closest to the entrance, keep walking to see all the buildings behind. You'll find you get right away from the bulk of the crowds and can better enjoy the ambience of the place.
A massive complex which was a great experience. Surrounded by lovely grounds and the wonderful guards display. The guards seemed to change on the hour.
wonderful experience seeing all the people in traditional hanboks everywhere at the palace grounds . A place one should not miss.

Beautiful, peaceful!! So amazing to see everyone Dress up and take photos in traditional garb.Adorable, mothers and daughters, girls, boys and young families all done up.. so stunning. It’s a large enclosed palace grounds with loads of history and traditional Korean culture to take in.. cheap to get in and lots of ground to cover, perfect for a long stroll through time and a must if your visiting Seoul!!! Right downtown

Put on traditional costume to get free entry, and be photographed at your best ancient look! Spend at least 3 hours there as we did, and we also had a volunteer guide (a high school English student) showing us around.

Although not the most attractive, Gyeongbokgung palace is the biggest and the main palace in Seoul. So, ot is a must visit tourist attraction. Very crowded all the time, free entrance for visitors wearing traditional korean dress (Hanbok), that can be rented near the palace. Quieter areas are the walls surrounding the palace, with the pillars making the colorful walls and ornate ceiling beams more attractive for photos (instagram). Changing of the guard around 11:00am is also an interesting attraction to watch.

This place is just gorgeous. You have the option of taking a guided tour but I opted to just wander around on my own. Signage is in Korean and English and there are printed guides in several languages. If you want to stick to a set time frame take the guided tour, but note yours in your language are limited to specific times of the day and the tour will typically last an hour to an hour and a half. I personally had fun wandering at my own pace and ended up spending several hours walking, viewing, thanking photos and videos, sitting and people watching, etc. it’s just a beautiful setting and experience.

This is the Forbidden City of Korea. From an architectural perspective, very fascinating! It is quite similar to Chinese royal architecture, but there are plenty of differences to make it distinctly its own. If you like architecture, you will love wondering around this palace, and the tiny doors everywhere are so cute.  Don't pay for a tour! All of the sites in Seoul have free English speaking tours, the trick is to find out the time, and to be on time for them. I found these tours to be fascinating, enjoyable, and full of information, so I highly recommend them.  In the back is a gorgeous garden, with the Bukhansan Mountain as a backdrop, especially during the autumn, breathtaking. Stop by the Blue House (Korean version of the White House). And you have to spend a good hour in the folk museum which had a bunch of traditional and cultural artifacts, an ancient Hanok home, and a ~1960s style shopping street.

A place to learn about the history of Korea in the Joseon Dynasty on the different palaces where the King worked and lived. Scenic cultural place with many stories told by the official guided tour, a great learning experience about old Korea. You may also want to watch the guards changing ceremony at the entrance of the Palace at designated timeslots and engage with a tourguide or audio guide yourself to hear about the tales of the Kings.
I love how clean it is remained and how easy to come here. Just take a train and you'll get it here. Do explore outside gyeongbokgung palace for some street food

For those wanted to explore and to know more the culture of Korea,I highly recommended this place. Everything here is picturesque especially during autumn season. Got to appreciate more the colorful history of Korea.

Where is the best place to see the changing of the guards? It is outside the gate, where you get the closest to the guard. Do not go into the big yard inside the gate. They will pass through it and the actual changing of the guard is in front of the Gate.

Accesible via mrt Gyeongbokgung Palace Station (Seoul Subway Line 3), Exit 5. Do catch-up the "Changing Guards Ceremony" at 10:00, 13:00 or 15:00. Avoid morning in the weekend as it was super crowded and it's hard to get good pictures with the only background of the palace.

Went here mid of May with my wife and friends. The place is so huge and very rich in history. We went early and were very fortunate to see the change of guards ceremony. You will see men in Korean traditional soldier uniforms including their weapons. Inside are structures but for most of them you can only glance from outside. Tips: - Wear appropriate footwear. The place is huge you'll do a lot of walking. - The ceremony starts around 10am. Be there early and go to a good spot to watch. - You can try the soldier uniforms. Area is near the first gate if I'm not mistaken. - May is cold but very sunny so bring umbrella. - Bukchon Hanok Village is like 20-30min walk from here. You may want to consider walking as the streets outside were also nice. The palace wall are great from outside.

A tourist destination for everyone. Large complex and very interesting. The entrance is very colourful with the well dressed guards. Don't miss the change of guards at midday. A bit dusty path on a dry hot day. Ensure to have a hat or umbrella.
Good for travellers who would like to learn much about the Korean traditional matters. The free guides were polite and helpful.

This quite large and well kept palace consists of large wooden ornate buildings in a park like setting. You don't need to go on a tour to visit any of these sort of places. Taxis in Seoul are really inexpensive and will get you to where you want to go for short distances. For longer distances the Metro is fantastic. But I advise you to make good use of Google Maps to get you around the system. But be aware that Maps quotes the stations names in Hangul characters. I ended up with my own special way of recognising parts of the characters!!!  The palace is a hot and dry place so ensure that you have water with you. There are some relatively steep sections in parts so if this presents a problem be careful to allow plenty of time.

I visited Gyeongbokgung Palace few time. As I go free & easy without a guide in Korea. I have realised that it was so easy to move around in Seoul with the metro. I did some research before I arrive Korea. They have all the difference time for changing guide at the main gate. It take about 30 minutes with all the parade in traditional costume. The Palace provide difference timing for free tour with English & Chinese Speaking guide daily. The tour will be guide you through the Palace and gave you the detail explanation of the Palace. Please make use of the free service and you save a lot of money.

If you are looking to be temporarily immersed in Korea culture while in hustling-bustling downtown Seoul, this palace is a must-see destination. The palace grounds are hardly tucked away in some obscure corner of the sprawling metropolis of Seoul, for they extend over several hundred acres, and do offer some quietude compared to outside the gates.  You will find numerous buildings that are splendid in their grandeur, and also old, twisted pines that represent the long-time suffering of the Korean population under colonial rule. One of the most captivating scenes is the grand lake, which begs for photos during cherry blossom season, the colorful autumn, and also during the evening.  In closing, KNTO (Korean National Tourism Office) offers a pass to three palaces all within a few Kms of each other, which is a highly recommended to take in these incredible venues for a taste of tradition in the midst of one of the most modern cities in the world.

Without doubt this was my favourite attraction in Seoul. We arrived just before 1400 meaning w could enjoy the whole change of the guard ceremony. Great fun.  After that we wondered into the palace and genuinely were in awe with how beautiful it was. Of course the clear blue sky and nice weather helped with the atmosphere.  Closed on Tuesday's so plan accordingly. To access use Subway line 3 exit 5, or just wonder through this beautiful city and arrive when you arrive :-)

It was the first royal palace built in the Joseon Dynasty and where the Joseon Dynasty 500 year history began. It is the largest of the 5 grand palaces remaining in Seoul. You should plan to visit it together with the 2 museums in the palace grounds, National Palace Museum and National Folk Museum of Korea. We bought a combined ticket to the palaces which also includes a guided tour of Jongmyo Shrine and the Secret Garden, Changdeokgung Palace as you save money. However be prepared to walk a lot as the different buildings are spread over a large area. Do also make time to see the changing of the guards ceremony on the hour from 10am to 4 pm at the grand main gate, Gwanghwamun. After you have reach the end of the palace grounds, you can catch a glimpse of The Blue Office of the President. The office is situated just across the road with Mt.Bugaksan in the background. The only setback is that there are very few tall trees to give shade, compared to the other three palaces.

If you are a fan of arts history and culture this is definitely the place for you. Very serene palace with a hall exhibiting tea ceremony live. Please find out when is the free guided tour as it is only available at certain time or you will end up not knowing any of the history accurately. Entrance is 3000won(I think) and to the museum is free :) enjoy!

this palace was the biggest than other palace, seem like Forbidden city at Beijing but it's smaller. We visit at rainy days but lucky we are to seen they are beautiful on rain. the Palace including couple buildings for King, and you can buy the maps only for 500 Won at information. Entrance fee is 3.000 won and I think it's cheap.  inside the Palace you will found the King home and many buildings with Korean architecture and cultural. And it will finished at Folk Museum.  For me it's little bit boring since I not a historical person, but the garden ruins it.

- The guard changing ceremony is very fascinating and educational. - Try the guard changing costume. What an experience! - I just love how the staffs of the palace wear traditional clothes. - Easily accessible by subway. Just 10 minutes walk from there.

Don't miss the change of the guards because here there is a commentary for explanation of what is going on. And the colours! I've never seen such splendidly clothed guards. Loved it! Entry is free when you wear a hanbok.  The palace area is huge and you will spend about 2 hours here. There is also the National Korean Folk Museum in which you can learn a lot about Korea, it's culture and historical development. Then, there is a little area to see how the houses on the palace grounds looked throughout the ages. It is right next to the Children's Museum. You see, you can visit a lot of places here and will definitely see a lot of old houses.

We had a guided tour for the morning, if you can get there in time to see the change of guards is a awesome experience. This place is nothing short of amazing. It is VERY big! Take at least 2 hrs to get around it all. Great richness of Korean History. Great value for money.

the palace is sooooo big. You'll need maybe 2 hours if you want to look carefully at the palace or taking picture in every corner of the palace. I think the palace is very photogenic and beautiful. If you come on Sunday, there's a flea market infront of the palace, it's worth to visit.

We took the subway. Long walk coming and going.  Nice buildings. Did not catch the changeing of the guards- I dont know where to find it. Place was huge! We just enjoyed its beauty - I did not get an audio guide. Bring water, lots of sunblock, sunglasses, and wear comfortable shoes.  After, we tried to catch a taxi. Unfortunately no taxi stands that we knew of. So walked back thru subway.

We (me and my husband) came here around 11am on a Monday, so we avoided too much crowd. There were still enough people to keep it exciting, kids too! The ticket is 3000 won per person, which is great value. We did not purchase any audio guide or English guide book, we felt like exploring it ourselves. It was actually quite fun this way, lots to explore and it was a very different palace architecture with lot of open bits inside the palace too. I liked the roofs and doors design. We spent about 3 hours there and we just took a stroll and wandered - not sure if we saw the whole thing. The weather was beautiful and very sunny, although my husband who is white got sun burnt as we were out in the open for most of the time :-) so make sure you apply plenty of sun screen if you don't want to be burnt.  There are boards with information in English too, which helps. Attached photos!

One of the few palaces you shouldn't miss-out during your holiday is Seoul. The buildings were quite magnificent. It opens from 9am till 6pm...but it's great there's free guides tours conducted on English @ 11am, 1:30pm & 3.30pm. The changing of guard was amazing...dress in their traditional regalia with sound of drums. Explore all the different buildings & grounds ...would take me a good few hours. This place captivates me... Ending ...by reaching to a main road right across is the Blue House.

The palace is without doubt a fantastic spectacle. It's gloriously cheap (3000 won for an adult) and can easily fill a morning or afternoon. The main palace, rebuilt in the 19th century, after it was destroyed in previous centuries by the Japanese, is in excellent condition. Further to this the grounds are quite extensive and we were surprised to see more structures, ponds and walkways after every corner. A true highlight is of course the changing of the guard which happens 3 times a day. If you go earlier on each one you can see them practice outside the palace.  Being my first time this Far East, it was a hugely fabulous place to behold and is by far the best of the palaces in the city. Visit!

I've traveled all over Europe and visited my share of castles, but the grand scale of the grounds and buildings included in Gyeonbokgung cast a shadow on everything I've witnessed before. It is massive and a bit daunting. Make sure to wear comfortable walking shoes and grab a guidebook (offered in several languages) or hook up with a tour guide.  The main (most famous) gates of Gyeonbokgung are right off of Gwanghwamun Square, not far from the notable statue of King Sejong (which is another must-see when in Seoul). It's very easy to get here by subway, bus, or taxi; although, I suggest taking the subway - it's super inexpensive, and is possibly the BEST subway system I've ever experienced, EVER. (Very safe. Very clean. Very easy to navigate, even if you don't speak Korean or read Hangual.)  We exited the subway (sorry, can't remember which line or number), and it spit us out right by a museum/gift shop that had a side entrance to the palace. It worked out perfectly! We walked in the gates and were in the main, large open courtyard inside the main gates (that are on street level in Gwanghwamun Square).  The palace is always teeming with tourists from all over the world. It's bustling and dizzying and amazing all at once. Unlike European castles, there isn't just one, central building; but instead, multitudes of buildings with similar architecture scattered throughout the grounds. Some are open to be viewed (like the private rooms of the royal family members or the throne and state rooms) while others are boarded up and can only be viewed from the outside. There are beautiful flowers and water areas in different parts of the complex.  My favorite part was Hyangwonjeong Pavilion - an "island" in the northern grounds of the palace connected by a wooden bridge to the rest of the grounds. You're not allowed to enter the island, but it's magical to look at.  If you want to be extra thorough and make it to the back of the complex (where the servants and guards quarters are), you should probably allow yourself 3 hours or so to meander around. This is not the type of attraction where you are in and out in an hour! There is so much to see, you could easily spend most of a day here or split the grounds up and visit on two different days.  Although built in 1395, the palace was been rebuilt in the late 1800's due to fire (the buildings are nearly all made of wood); but the Koreans took great care to reconstruct the palace as it originally stood.  It's open most days from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. but is closed on Mondays or Tuesdays (can't remember which, but it was closed the first time we tried to visit) and holidays (check the website (http://www.royalpalace.go.kr/html/eng/main/main.jsp) to make sure it will be open when you intend to visit.  An absolute MUST-SEE. You will not regret visiting, and I suggest taking a walk through the nearby gift shop I mentioned. I'm sure the items are more expensive than elsewhere, but I never saw things they had for sale anywhere else but there. Worth it if you're looking for a unique memento of your visit to Seoul/Korea.

You would never believe that you are in the city when you are browsing round these temples. There are many more cute temples in the surround area which your ticket includes. It is a great place to visit.

We went there to check out the palace but then we figure out something else. Every hour, they would have guard changing ceremony. about 10-15 people march out with drumroll. they replace the guard then goes in back. I could remember when is the last change but probably about 4pm. Anyway, if you are interested to try their guard's clothing, do stand infront of an isolated building on the compound 10 min after the guard changing start. they only accept few people but it was open every hour. If you missed once, you still have next hour. do go in 3 person or more. As the person in charge wont help you to take picture. If not, you only can depend on selfie~ I couldnt talk bout the palace as we ran out of it to watch the guard changibg ceceremony. Afterwrd we couldnt go in back. So if you wanted to check the palace, come early and watch the guard changing, then only you should go in. Sharp on time ok?

Gyeongbokgung was within walking distance of my BnB and a great place to walk around. You can complete a decent circuit on your own in about 30-45 minutes. Try to time things so that you can be at the Gwanghwamun gate on the hour between 10am and 4pm. The 10am, 1pm and 3pm times are the extended show while the other hours only show a shortened version. Since the whole reenactment is only about 15 mins long, I'm not sure there is much at all to see with a shortened version! You don't need an extra ticket to see the changing of the guard, you just need to be in the right place at the right time.

We reached the place nearly 3PM local time. It is the right timing where the guard changing ceremony was about to begin. It was awesome!! After the 20min changing ceremony, we were quickly run to the booth where you can try on the guard outfit - for FREE!!! have fun!!
There are a lot of palaces in Seoul, but this one is the biggest and easiest to visit. Nice scenic walks around the grounds, changing of the guard ceremony, nice buildings... ticks all the boxes.

It's cold in the courtyard as the winter wind just sweeps across the open from the mountains. Put on extra during winter time and go with a guide or something because it can get really, really boring looking at the same buildings again and again.

I liked how well arranged this museums decorated. It has a very detail memorabilia about Korean culture. Despite its small building of museum (due to the main attraction is the Palace), you will still be amused. Inside the Palace, you can take a picture (for free) with girls wearing national costumes of South Korea. The toilets need some upgrade and somehow I do amazed to see a woman house cleaning staff simply enter male toilet and Korean male seemed not to be disturbed by that (ithough i felt a bit awkward). My tour guide said this Palace better visited during fall

wear comfortable shoes and maybe an umbrella if you are there during the summer. I have been here twice, on a fall and just this summer. I would say best time to see this place is during the summer when all the leaves are colorful. The area is situated in the middle of the city but it is pretty magical when you are inside. It's like you are transported to a different era. The place is very well kept. Don't forget to bring your camera!

If you're interested in old palace architectures, this is the place for you. The area is not as grand and big as the Forbidden City in Beijing; but still need a good half-day effort to cover the compound. We were there in early Dec 2014. Although the temperature was a bit chilly, there were still many visitors; including a lot of local students. I would image the place must be packed during summer time. The National folk museum of Korea is adjacent to Gyeongbokgung, so you may plan to spend a whole day in the same area to visit both locations. Gyeongbokgund subway (No. 3 line) has a station just outside the palace. Suggest to start the visit early in the day.  A near-by restaurant called Tosokchon that serves ginseng chicken soup is worth the visit for a meal as well; especially in winter. The hot soups will surely warm up your body in no time.

We were there at around 11 in the morning in late autumn. Weather was good but the wind was quite strong.  We walked from the Bukchon Hanok Village, where we stayed for a night. Took us about 20 minutes or so.  If you are a foreigner travelling on own, best thing is to time your visit with the free guided tours. We thought we would go ahead without the tour and this is something we regretted, given the size of this place and lack of signboards to tell you any historical facts and your exact location as well. We found ourselves lost for an hour, ending up at some garden, smaller palaces and the National Folk Museum and had to go one big round to come out to the entrance.  If you are planning to visit more palaces, suggest you take the Combination ticket, which will cover Gyeongbokgung, Chandeukgung, Chanseukgung (if I'm not mistaken) Deoksugung, and Jongmyo shrine which costs KRW10k (I recall it would be cheaper by KRW2k if you bought the tickets separately).  Although we were in Seoul throughout the stay and decided we should visit most, we didn't and only managed to visit this, Chandeukgung and Jongmyo shrine so the Combination ticket was not worth it but could come in handy.  I would prefer Chandeukgung, which is about 20 minutes walk away as it is much more interesting.
The visit there was amazing, and in the winter, it makes for great snow angel-making grounds. And oh! It overlooks the Blue House (the Korean equivalent of the White House)

Lovely grounds and charming with autumnal colours, the largest pond is a highlight. The buildings are beautiful to look at.  Attempted an English tour but this was a challenge to understand (we are English) so we wandered at our own leisure which was great.  The Folk museum is a bizarre addition but worth a look around, particularly the Jean exhibition which will amuse Westerners with it's stylised curation.

Beautiful place. Nice place to take pictures. went in winter(mid november). One of the palace building is closed to public during winter- open from april to sept(i hope my memory is not failing on me)  Must go for the guided tour(available in English, Mandarin, Japanese, Korean). Last about 1 hour, which bring you through the palace and tell you the history of Korean royal family and the korean palace architecture.  The one of the interesting attractions was the guards that stood outside the palace( something like the guards in Windsor castle(london)), but with colorful uniforms and more guards and korean musical and flags.. they did the marching (went at ~130pm so get to observe the change of guard ceremony ~2pm)  Not necessary to buy the palace map if you go for the guided tour. the palace map cost 5000 won.

beautiful place. huge place. there's a coffee shop inside. the cashier is pretty. i took pictures but she told me not to take pictures. it would be great to visit there in autumn - for the trees. this place has an entrance fee.

Being a korean series fanatic, visiting a palace is a must-place-to-visit for me. The palace groound is really really huge. Visiting in the peak of autumn is an added value to the beauty of the place. There are benches that you can sit upon. I like the one that faces the moat. Make sure that you get to see the changing of guards ceremony (http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_2_1.jsp?cid=292853)  Directions: Gyeongbokgung Palace Station (Seoul Subway Line 3), Exit 5 Fee: 3000 won for adults
This is the biggest palace in Seoul. However, it's overcrowded with tourists and tour groups. Highly recommended to visit during less busy period to soak in the atmosphere.

Gyeongbokgung is the largest palace in Seoul, and I did appreciate all the structures and the grand scale of things. However, I think other palaces are much more interesting. Gyeongbokgung feels like a tourist trap and has too many visitors. The landscaping here isn't all that exciting compared to, say, Changdeokgung, which was built in harmony with nature. I would recommend visiting this palace to experience the grandeur and the guard changing ceremony, but also take a look at other palaces around Seoul.

The palace is very accessible by train as a train station leads directly to the palace complex. A good time is visit is at 9 a.m. because you can watch the opening of the gates in the traditional way. We did not take the tour but was able to see the different parts of the palace, taking time to notice the cultural artifacts. We saw many Korean school children visit this palace, a testimony that the palace is important to Koreans.

A very large compound in the middle of Seoul, the contrast between the old palace roofs and the surrounding skyscrapers is impressive. The compound is very large, so be sure to take comfortable shoes along. It's very beautiful, there is lots to see and everything is well-kept. I found it less crowded than I had imagined it to be, it's very easy to reach by metro and the entrance fee is very low, around 3 USD. They have guided tours, although we always prefer to go on our own. You can't go inside any of the rooms or buildings, but it's still impressive to see it from outside. We were able to take millions of lovely pictures, and greatly enjoyed our visit. There is a great little Samgyetong place called "Tosokchon" not far, which is prized with selling the best Ginseng Chicken in Seoul. That's how we rounded off our day there.  If you have time, if you like walking, and if you want to see the largest Palace in Seoul then this is the place to go.
It is a good place to learn more Korean history!! It is very big, you can spend half day to visit there.
Love the guards at the front gate. Free dress up in guard costumes, cheap entry fee. Beautiful sceneries with mountains views behind the palace buildings.

All five palaces are basically identical...you may as well go to this one as it is the biggest.  Try and arrive or leave on the hour and you will get the changing of the guard show.  The palaces are good but they are all the same...same layout, same style, same interiors...just five of them...

Gyeongbokgung Palace is the largest palace in Seoul. It is at the end of the main blvd. We watched the changing of the guard at the palace gate on the way in and on the way out a more elaborate changing of the guard ceremony was being held. The grounds are vast and there is also the Korean Folk Museum included with your admission price. It was a very hot day so going in the museum was very enjoyable. The museum was informative about Korean culture and was very interesting. we probably spent 2 1.5 hours at the palace complex.

It is a sprawling compound which encompasses many halls and living quarters plus 2 museums. Avoid going on weekends as there are many tour groups present! You could spend up to 3 hours walking the palace grounds and museums, all for an affordable fee of 3000won each. Be sure to bring a bottle as there are hardly any shops selling drinks.

Beautiful once you walk through the grounds. Loved the National Folk Museum as it explained Korean life and why Koreans eat kimchi. It is large and it was very hot the day we visited so very tiring to walk around. Watched the guard ceremony. hotel bus too us here-subway home.

This is a nice palace located in central Seoul. The buildings are old and beautiful. You can also watch the changing of guards. We were told that this was at 1pm and 3pm, but when we arrived at 3 pm the ceremony was already finished. I think it began at 2.30 so heads up for that. You can also visit the folk museum of Korea which is just outside the area. The cost is 3000 won pp

Pro : Located in the city area. Accessible via metro. Pretty cheap admissions. Free guided tour available. Large compound. Quite a number of attractions to see. Historical. Learn how royalty lives. Nice garden. Great ambiance. Lovely pavilions.  Con : Most of the buildings are re-built or replica as the original were destroyed/demolished. Huge compound. Lots of walking required. After a while, one building looks like another…

This is our the first attraction we visited in S. Korea. The place is awesome. Surrounded by high rise buildings is a huge and well preserved palace. For just 3000 KWon, you not only see this picturesque palace but you can also see the National Folk Museum. It is worth every KWon. This tourist spot is also accessible, there is a subway connecting the palace. Dont miss the changing of guards ceremony.

The palace is very pretty. Not spectacular at all but very pretty and a nice place to kill some time. Went there today with my mother. It is packed and just empty shells of buildings. The highlight is the free folk art museum.  Never the less enjoyed this palace with what could be a tranquil setting all for the price of $3

This is the definitive sight to see if you are traveling to Seoul. If you have seen other palaces in your life, it might be somewhat underwhelming. If you have never been to anything like this before, you're in for a treat. The palace only costs $3 per person to enter, and it is extensive. Eat in advance, and enjoy the sights.  If you arrive at a certain time, you will be able to see the guard change at the gate ceremony. This is an added benefit but not really necessary. There are English, Chinese and Japanese translations for those interested in a summary of what is happening, though. You can also view the guard change ceremony at other palaces in the Seoul area if you do happen to miss the one at Gyeonbokgung but still are interested in seeing it. As an aside, you do not need to actually pay the palace entrance fee to view the guard change ceremony, which is nice if you're just passing by and want to watch.  About the palace itself: It is the largest of the five great palaces in Seoul, although I'm not sure about how it stands compared to other palaces in Korea. It is located near the northern end of the city, opposite of the N Seoul Tower. There are guided tours given of the palace, and I would definitely recommend coming during tour time, otherwise you will just be looking at buildings and have no idea what you are looking at! Like the gate guard change ceremony, the tours are given in Korean, Japanese, Chinese and English. They are given at different times, and each language tour is given at different frequencies (i.e. the English one is given about three times a day, while the Chinese one is only given once a day).  The tour takes an hour, and you will see the majority of the palace grounds and buildings. I have done the tour twice, and both tour guides were excellent, and they each gave me different information, which was nice. After the tour, you are obviously free to go back and see anything you might have missed or wanted to spend more time doing. During the tour, you will have time for pictures, as well.  After you have seen the palace, I recommend doing two things:  1. The Blue House (Korea's equivalent of the White House) can be seen by leaving through one of the exits (near the northwest, next to the pond). That exit is as close as you can get to the Blue House (unless you schedule a tour, which takes a month or two in advance to schedule), so it is a good place to take pictures and see something you may otherwise never be able to see. As an aside, if you leave the exit, you can re-enter through the same way you left after you have seen the Blue House.  2. There is a Korea folk museum near the back of the palace, towards the east. It is free with your palace entrance. You can spend anywhere between an hour or two (or more, if you so desire) looking at all of the stuff in there. It is extensive, and there are some pretty cool things in it. I recommend going there, taking a load off, grabbing a drink or snack and getting out of the heat (or cold!) for a little bit.  Overall, if you're going to Seoul, you have to see the Gyeongbokgung. It is large, interesting and inexpensive (like most things in Seoul). Come for the free guided tour for an additional bonus.

This is a strange place. First of all it had been completely destroyed by the Japanese (and many times before) and they only started reconstructing it in the 1990s - so the entire thing is only about 20 years old (and they are still adding buildings) and completely empty. Secondly it looks like a small Korean copy of the forbidden city in Beijing. With this in mind it is still an interesting visit as it gives an idea how the original palace might have looked like, if you have only time for one place I would recommend Changdeokgung, which is more authentic and imho more beautiful.

We wanted to tour Changdeokgung Palace on our last day in Seoul, but we learned too late that the only one of the five palaces open on Monday is Gyeongbokgung (which is closed on Tuesdays). So we set out in a steady rain to see what we could see.  We walked from our hotel near N Seoul Tower, maybe a 45 minute stroll. The walk would have been shorter had we known precisely where we were going.  We arrived just as the changing of the guard ceremony was ending, which was pretty cool. Their bright uniforms are impressive, and they replicate the original Josean guards' reds and blues and greens. Their somber countenances are unwavering. They'll permit you to stand close enough to take a photo, but they won't acknowledge you.  Admission is only 3000 won (about $3 US). Though Ggyeongbokgung is older than the other palaces (originally built in 1395), there isn't much left to see because the Japanese intentionally destroyed most of the buildings during the occupation. Restoration only began again in the 1990s. The exterior wall stands, as does the inner courtyard structure and the main palace building, and some smaller outlying buildings.  When it started downpouring rain, we spent some time sitting in the gift shop waiting for it to ease up. They have some really lovely artistic high quality souvenirs for sale, including pottery and inlay jewelry chests and ceramics. They're pretty pricey, but they're not trinkets. You can also buy coffee, hot cocoa, snacks.  Gyeongbokgung is lovely, but it's pretty low key if you've seen palace sites in Bangkok or Beijing. A highlight of our visit was when one of the staff insisted we "come here" to see what he was pointing at. You can only see the golden dragon on the ceiling from one vantage point, and he wanted to make sure we saw it and got a good photo. We'd have missed it otherwise.  We were hoping that most of the tour would be inside due to the rain. It wasn't. Because the rain wouldn't let up and our feet were already wet from traipsing across the muddy grounds, we didn't go to the water or explore the rest of the property.  Hopefully Seoul will continue restoration of this site and eventually return it to its original splendor. I'll come back and revisit it.

The palace grounds are quite large, you could easily spend a half day or whole day exploring. We wandered around for 45 min on our own, but there are almost no signs indicating the history of the building or history. So we decided to take the free English tour. The tour is excellent, the guide takes about an hour and gave us a detailed and heartfelt description of the buildings, cultural significance. The tour is not just about the buildings but explains what was achieved in the buildings such as the creation of the korean language. We felt like we really learned a lot and had a better understanding of the Korean culture and it was Free!  English Tours: 11am, 1.30pm, 3.30pm

Directions: Gyeongbokgung station (exit 5) or Gwanghwamun (exit 2). I went from the Gyeongbokgundg station and once you get out of the exit, you will go in from the side door of the palace.  Admission fee: 3000 won (each person)  If you want to know more about the palace, there are free English Tours at the following timings: 11am, 1.30pm, 3.30pm. The duration of the tour is 1hour.  I did not take the tour and we just walked around the premises. The palace is really big. Thus, although there are loads of tour buses, you will not feel that it is very crowded. The instructions are far and few. Maybe it will be good to go for the guided tour or the audio guide.  Although this palace is bigger and more grand than other palaces, i love Changdeokgung better. It is more tranquil and prettier.  Anyway, the changing guard ceremony is held in front of the main gate every hour from 10:00 to 15:00 (i.e. 10am, 11am etc). You can see it as an experience. You can also take photos with the guards.  Overall, if you only have time to go 1 palace, choose Gyeongbokgung if you like big and more grand palace and also to see the changing guard ceremony. Else, I will recommend going Changdeokgung instead.
Honestly, after seeing so many temples and palaces in Korea, they all start to look the same. The scale of this one sets it apart. The backdrop of mountains makes this one really special too.

When we went to visit the Gyeongbojgung Palace, there was a fee tour. The tourist guide was very informative and it was a great way of understanding how Korea became great. I was amazed how intricate and grand the palaces were as one gate would unveil its beauty and grandiose majestic sights.

This palace is in Seoul and very easy to get to, whether you are driving or taking public transportation. We drove and the parking was 3,500 won, about 500 yards from the entrance. Our family paid a total of 7,500 won for the four of us, and that totals 11,000 won for the trip (maybe $9). We spent a few hours walking, reading, taking pictures, and sightseeing throughout the palace grounds. I couldn't believe how many "buildings" there are throughout the palace, the highlight for me was the building surrounded by the fish pond, very, relaxing and a great place to sit and relax. There are bathrooms throughout the palace, and even a full blown reenactment "outside" (where you don't have to pay yet). We paid and followed the King in through the entrance, the kids loved it. BONUS - You can walk through the palace to the exit opposite of the entrance and see the Presidential Office of the President of Korea, this was pretty cool. Once you've seen enough, you can reenter the palace grounds with your ticket stub. After a few hours at the palace we enjoyed the market across the street. A great day had by the entire family!

This is the main palace and it is right in the middle of Seoul. Tickets are cheap. I think it was only $2 or something like that. Make sure to take the guided tour. Once you go past the place where you need to give your tickets, there is an office to the right. You wait outside for the tour guide. Tour times are posted outside the tour guide office as well as the ticket office. The tour lasts about an hour and takes you throughout the palace, explaining various locations and giving a lot of insight and history. The tour made our visit to the palace wonderful and we learned so much! I still can't believe that it was a free tour!  After leaving the palace we walked to Insadong and back to our hotel in Myeongdong. That's how close the palace is to everything.

This is THE palace in Seoul. If you are there for the culture and history, you have to come here. Also, if you're planning to visit BOTH this palace and Changdeokgung down the street, come here FIRST!! You can get a 2 in 1 ticket deal, but only at the Gyeongbokgung ticket office. Unlike us who went to Changdeokgung first. (Dang it!) The main gate at the front (not where you get your tickets though strangely enough) is very impressive. Although we learned that it was just recently completed as the original was dismantled by the Japanese. The Japanese occupation really did a number on Korean cultural heritage and they're just getting around to finish resurrecting a lot of the structures in the palaces. So, a lot of it is not the original and so not very old at all. Unfortunately, if you go into these palaces without a tour guide it's difficult to get a sense of the history attached to the place even with a pamphlet. This palace is much grander than Changdeokgung. There are also a couple of museums attached to the grounds. Do not miss the Folk Museum!! Excellent!! We didn't have enough time to do a thorough tour of that. Also, found out way too late that we missed a whole section of the palace compound that was used as location for the K-drama "Rooftop Prince". (Dang it, again!!) Well, when it's so hot and you have 2 little children and severe jetlag on top of it all, you tend to run out of steam pretty quickly.

The Gyeongbokgung Royal Palace complex on the north side of downtown Seoul is a marvelous and beautiful site. Meticulously re-built after being destroyed by the Japanese imperial occupation army, the on-going reconstruction is revealing stunning buildings and layers of Korean history. Archeology is on-going, and can be observed during your visit. The gardens and trees are treasures along with the buildings. The small palace at the north-west corner, originally meant to be for the preparation of the dead and a place of mourning, is the best presented of the complex. The restoration is perfect, and being out-of-the-way keeps most visitors far away. It is serene and made for sensitive photography. Even during tourist high season it is not overwhelmed by visitors. he entry fee is so low it is almost free. Be aware that the reason the buildings look so good is that they have largely been re-built since 1989 under a half century plan to restore the entire complex. Almost everything was destroyed by the Japanese imperialists who sought to eradicate Korean history and culture. The fact that most buildings are not original is all that keeps this from being a true five-star attraction. You can walk to the main gate from City Hall.

The palace will give you an interesting insight into the history of Korea, but this isn't what it appears. Firstly, most of what you see is actually a recreation, built from 1990 onwards. Secondly, the thing it is a recreation of was a reconstruction built in 1867. The original palace was destroyed by the Japanese in 1592...  The English language tour we had was informative, but historically extremely naive. It would appear that the Korean Kings were all paragons of honesty and divine perfection. Forgive me for being suspicious, but I suspect (and history shows) that they were as complex and varied as any humans.

This palace is actually a reconstruction of the one that used to stand here. The original dates to the Joseon Dynasty. It is only one of several in Seoul, but it was the only one that I had a chance to visit. The architecture and the decorative art inside the buildings were beautiful. As you enter, you can pick up a very thorough pamphlet which explains the purpose of each of the buildings. This was you can tour yourself around and make sure you know what you are looking for at each of the many courtyards. Pamphlets are available in many languages, including English, and are quite informative. Behind the museum is the National Folklore Museum which was well worth the visit alone. You can enter the museum only from the western palace gate. The museum is free of charge, though there is a fee for the palace. The museum gives an excellent overview of the history of people on the Korean peninsula, dating back to prehistoric times. The signs in Gallery 1 all have good English translations, so it is really easy to understand what you are looking at and make sense of the timeline of Korea's past. Gallery 2 consists mostly of artifacts, which are displayed nicely but do not have as much information in English, so I enjoyed this section of the museum less.

This palace is large and has everything, including impressive buildings and enchanting pavilions. just let your imagination run. excellent with children, who can have breaks (with treats) by the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion pool and at the children museum. No need for a guided tour, and I would skip the unnecessary National Folk Museum of Korea (unless you're aiming for the children museum) and National Palace Museum of Korea. I used the exit through the National Folk Museum, and went up samcheong-ro towards the traditional houses of Hwa-Dong - it's a steep incline that's worth the effort.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is truly the crown jewel. Impressive 14c history and site. The entire site is dedicated to the museum. The most impressive part is the views... to the North, beautiful mountain views and the tops of the palace, same as 600 years ago. To the south, the modern skyline.  Changing of the guards, on the hour, is impressive.  The only downside is that the Palace is all recently rebuilt, so the buildings are 'too good to be true'. The restorations are very well done and still definitely worth the visit.  Only 3 USD to enjoy, an extra 1 USD for electronic tour.  Visited June 2013

This place is beautiful. I would like to have done a tour, but we visited as a last minute decision. So glad we did. I would recommend a guided tour if you can as we saw groups being guided into areas that others were not allowed to go. And I'm sure there are many stories to be told. The changing of the guards was interesting, and their weapons were something else. Seeing the very modern and chaotic Seoul outside of the palace is such a contrast. We were approached by some very friendly Korean locals who were so charming. Lots of walking to be had, so if you are limited with your abilities, you may want to organise a wheelchair, or accept that you may be limited with what you may see. We went on a sunny day (take sunscreen as there is little shade whilst walking around) and it was just beautiful, but I imagine it would be just as pretty in the middle of winter. Great photo opportunities here.  As a side note... outside the palace a man sold me the best pineapple I have ever eaten in my life!!! It was a slice on a stick and was divine. You may need a napkin handy, as it is sooo juicy.

Go there early. It can get very hot in the afternoon. The palaces are not lavish but artistic and beautiful. Wish they had more facilities like drinking water fountain, benches etc. Changing guard ceremony is OK. Try pumpkin candy outside. Try taking the college student guides with you.

what a i love about this place is its location. located strategically in the middle of city, the hustle and bustle city.. so sad to listen their story.. they actually have a hundred building but during the war, it left only 10 building which 2 of the building are still original building. if you need tour guide, just wait in front of the tourist information at 11am for English tour guide. it takes one hour tour around the palace.. please prepare yourself with hat, sunblock, or anything could protect you from the sun.. you can see the changing guard in this palace starts at 10am, it takes 30min..

Five six footer tall Korean guard will greet you at the front gate, faces are straight tough looking and their hands holding five different weapons will make you to expect more, and the huge tall gate with dragon designs gave me an excitement to see what's inside but as the time goes by and gets inside the first palace all I saw is green and it's clean, for me it's like park not a palace, but it's good looking park though. My advice is just don't expect more, I'd rather like the look of the small hanok villages than the big palace with nothing inside.
the grandeur and size make it impressive. you may try traditional clothes for free but you must line up for your turn. well worth it.

Guide books advised us that the gate opening took place at 9am. This is incorrect. The gate opening takes place at 10am. You can catch them warming up at 9.45. It's worth watching though and try to get to the palace early to avoid the crowds. We got there for 9am and we got some lovely photos, tour groups start pouring in from about 9.30am. 11.30am is the first English tour.

The palace was not too big, 2 hour was enough to spend there. The things I like from this palace was, there were Hanbook rent for free, beside the cafeteria. But had to queue, since many local and tourist used this facility.

Just use a jacket, long john, and sneakers, and ... you are ready to enjoy Gyeongbokgung Palace in winter. It may provide a slight different experience when we visited Gyeongbokgung Palace in the thickest snow in Seoul history in 2010. It was a little bit chilly, however, it was wonderful seeing the guards hand over ceremony. Do not forget to take pictures by wearing traditional guard costumes for free - a brilliant opportunity.

Its a very interesting place to visit. Especially if you get there to see the changing of the guards. It shoows you the historical way of the past, and afterwards you are allow to take pictures with the guards once they are in position at their post. I wish I could have seen it in the summer time when the trees and flowers would be at full bloosom.

It was raining heavily as we get out from the metro station. To make it worse the National Palace Museum is closed. As we enter the side entrance from the museum, we saw the ticket counter and information counter all closed. Quite a number of visitors or tourists seems to be upset coz not allowed by the guard to enter the palace. Maybe it's already closing time. So, advisable to visit this place in the morning.

This is indeed a nice palace located at the middle of the busy city. It is accessible by Seoul Metro and the palace itself is big and cool enough! There's no need to purchase the ticket and enter the palace, just take some pictures outside the palace is good enough! Don't forget the be there at 10am then you would see the changing guards ceremony for free! After this palace, you can just walk to Samcheong-dong, Bukchon Village and Insadong by walking! Easy!
I like the decorations and the buildings, it's a very good palace. and the most amazing part is changing the guards which occurs every hour. No way to visit Seoul without visiting it.
Wear your rubber shoes during the tour, take the afternoon english tour so it is not too hot. A bit boring after being to Beijing, Tokyo and Cambodia
A very good place to show Korea hundred years ago, the buildings are preserved well and impressive.  If you like to take photos definitely this is a good place to go.

There is free hanbok wearing at the souvenir shop which was such a memorable experience! Each person has only 10 minutes to wear the hanbok as the line gets pretty much long. I suggest you go and patiently wait in front of the souvenir shop at lunch time (like what we did) so you get to be first in line when they open up. Ask someone to take your photo standing in front of the nearest palace so you have a great background.

Despite all the modern advancement of the towns near Gyeongbokgung Palace, this place will never shed its beautiful history. The palace, though standing for centuries, has retained its beauty - from the 5 colors that symbolized korean culture to the detailed structures it has - all perfect and amazing as of this moment.

I grew up in Korea and was at the Palace about 15 years ago. I remember it to be one boring trip then, since I lived in Seoul.  Two days ago I visited the Palace with a friend from Japan. The Palace was nicely presented, although rather crowded with tourists.  Make sure to check out both new and old museums. Also make sure to visit in the morning around 10am to see traditional Korean music and guards!

The changing of the guards is worth seeing. It takes place in a massive empty square and the guards move around it, so you get good views of the whole thing. It's very colourful and makes for good pictures. Besides that, there is not much else to see besides the buildings, and the main gate.

If I have to compare, I would prefer Deoksugung Palace than Gyeongbokgung palace to visit during holiday. Why? Gyeongbokgung is too crowded since it's the main center of the palace to be visited by the tourists. The main attraction would be the changing of the guards, the history of the palace, the national folk museum and the national museum.  However the last time I came here I can't enjoy it that much since it's very crowded with people. Even the pictures that I took were not as beautiful as ones I took at Deoksugung. Perhaps, one suggestion, come to Gyeongbokgung during weekdays, and not in a spring, winter, or summer break. People are coming not only from Seoul but also China and Japan. I really find it unattractive in a huge commotion like that.  Nevertheless, for 3000won, this area is really worth to visit. This palace area is so huge that even 3 hours will last like a flash. And make sure, you're not coming during holiday. It'll be an awful experience.You can't really enjoy the scenery since it's too noisy and crowded.
A must-visit for first time Seoul visitors. Provides tourists with a glimpse of historical Korea. Get the combined tickets for all the palaces (costs 10000 KRW)

One of the most beautiful palaces in Seoul (Go for this one if you had to visit only one).  The changing of the guards which occurs at 2:00 pm is worth watching.  Take some documentation / map about the palace to understand the history of the place.

We were there around 2pm, and we were able to watch the changing of the guards. It took around 15 minutes, and guests can go up close to take photos or videos. There are no barriers so you can feel free to take photos.  The palace itself is big and beautiful. We feel this is the most beautiful one of the palaces.
Get the schedule for the ceremony from the Korean website and go watch! It is amazing to watch the guards continue to perform this tradition.
Changing of the guards, the history and architecture, the gardens and the surrounding mountains all within the modern city of Seoul

Absolutely stunning and a must see. You can make your way around the palace and the surrounding neighborhood on foot an enjoy the splendor. Reasonably priced at 3,000 won Try the follk museum too it's free

Located in the heart of downtown Seoul, the Gyeonbokgung palace is a must. Not only are tickets dirt cheap, you can also gain access to multiple different sites including the neighboring palace, and the Folk Museum.  Beware though. The palace is closed on Tuesdays. Always check on the website to make sure they are open as they tend to close it down for various reasons.

Join the free guided tour. Guide was very good, speak very good English and share not only about the palace history but also on other Korean tradition and culture. Tried to catch the change of guard. The museum next to the palace cannot be missed. Entrance to museum is included in the palace ticket.

There are many palaces in Seoul,and for most you can't visit all of them. So if you have to visit one of these beautiful palaces, I would say it has to be Gyeongbokgung.  It has its beauty and it is HUGE! You can wonder aroundt the palace enjoy sceneries. I recommend to visit the palace during the changing guard ceremony. Which I find it very entertaining and exciting to watch. This is on 11.00, 14.00 and 15.30. You can visit this place at any day but Monday!  TIPS: I went there two times already. In July, it's very HOT! so you may need to bring umbrella along.

This is one of the palace that you must not miss. Beautifully preserved with rich cultural site. On a sunny day, this place is excellent for taking pictures, very colorful, good view of the mountains. The palace a big place and need a few hours to really enjoy and relax walk to have glimpse of this location. Too bad we missed the changing of guards.

The 1st royal changing ceremony start about 10.30am and the ceremony is about 10minutes only. Then you can take pictures with the guides..but dont be surprised that they will not smile at all. You still can take pictures with them and outside the palace even you dont but the ticket but to get inside, you have to buy ticket at only 3000won. They are more places to explore inside including korean national folk museum.

Went here on a balmy, brisk Sunday afternoon in February. Temp was about 10C and the skies were clear and sunny with no wind. Beautiful day!  This was a great to decompress after a long, anxiety filled week.  I didn't know what to expect and a guide would have been nice but is certainly not necessary. It was relaxing to just stroll the ground, looking at all of the buildings and reading the plaques. The architecture is incredible and being there, you can imagine the 14th Century King holding court or strolling by the pond.  There are many benches and places to just sit and take it all in, which we did. We didn't have time to visit the Folk Museum or Palace Museum and will try to see them next time.  We saw the changing of the guards and snapped a few photos - in its own way, its as momentous and magnificent as Buckingham Palace.  Incredible to contrast this incredibly historic spot against what greets you right outside the gates.

The cultural experience of korea in the heart of Seoul. Easy to get to, v.big, but i wouldnt recommend visiting it in Winter. It gets too cold there and the absence of trees takes away from its beauty.

Be prepared for a good walk as the palace compound is huge. The former kings must have chosen the place due to its good fengshui as it overlooks a mountain. If you want to know more about Korean history, head onto the museum inside the place which is covered by the entrance fee. There is basically information on how Koreans evolved over the years (i.e costumes, food, handwriting, traditions, etc). Also a good place to enjoy the air-condition after the long walk under the hot sun.  Love the trees and intricate architecture.  Be there before 10 am if you want to witness the changing of guards. The palace is closed every Tuesdays to allow it to be used for filming (presumably Korean period dramas).  As you head out of the palace, cross the road and walk straight for about 50-80 metres and you can find the Museum of King Sejong. TYou won't missed it because there is a huge statue of the King in front of the museum. Though small-scale, it's loaded with information and best of all, it's free. Do watch the short 4-D show to learn how the Koreans fought and won against their enemy with only 1/3 of the battleships. It's so surreal.  On your left after you cross the road as you exit the museum, you will find one of the biggest Starbucks in Seoul which is 4-storey high. A nice way to chill and end your trip to the palace.

I went to Gyeongbokgung Palace the day after my arrival as I was informed that the palace was a must see in Seoul. It was certainly that. The entrance is a large open area with the palace in front of a serene mountain backdrop. Although not the original construction (rebuilt in late 19th and early 20th century), the buildings attempt to recreate the original design and appear to have achieved that very well. As you walk into the palace grounds you start to see just how massive the location is and the many different buildings it has to offer. I enjoyed the Geunjeongjeon (throne hall) and Gyeonghoeru (pavilion on the water) the most. The Geunjeongjeon holds the most interesting interior and the Gyeonghoeru offers the best spot for pictures. The many other buildings are interesting to look at and you can enter some of them for additional close ups of what the palace may have looked like. I spent a few hours here and that was just about right, which included viewing the changing of the guards which was pretty interesting as they are in traditional dress. The Korean folk museum is worth the charge of admission (free) for a quick walk through, but only advise visiting if you are staying in Seoul for an extended period. The drawback to the palace is the lack of interior in many of the buildings to give a sense of each buildings purpose and also of the daily life of the palace inhabitants.

I had to do a rush through due to time constraints, but I wish I had a whole afternoon to spend here. This place is HUGE!! When you enter the grounds, you think....this is it. But it just keeps going. Wear comfortable shoes! If you watch historical Korean dramas, you'll really appreciate this place. You'll get a understanding of the whole royal family, servant quarters.
