Perhaps I was underwhelmed as it was our second palace of the day, but I kind of felt like I was at exactly the same place I had visited earlier that day even though it was a different palace and a new entry fee (admittedly very affordable).

Was there last Sunday. Spent about 3 hours there and only did see a part of the whole thing. Have to visit again. A perfect place for photographers, as many people enter the area in old costumes in return for free entry and to be photographed by other tourists. The whole area is very picturesque and with many people in the costumes this is perfect for photographers.
Beautifully restored palaces in the Center of Seoul. Defiantly worth the trip and the about 3$ of entrance fee.

Check out the palace and grounds. Allow about 2 hours and make sure to catch the changing of the guard. Afterwards, it's an easy walk to see the traditional homes of Bukchon Hanok Village. Weave your way down the hill and grab lunch at one of the many cafes.

This wonderful and large complex at the heart of Seoul is a must go for Korean drama enthusiasts, especially donning their own traditional Hanbok costumes. It is a wonderful destination to visit with all the palaces, amenities (both modern and traditional) and structures flanked in lush greens.

A nicely restored/preserved palace of Korea, the location is also quite convenient with easy access from Ankok Metro station. If you wear traditional Hanbok, you will be granted free access to the Palace.

Must stop on your short or long stay in Korea. Beautiful grounds. Colorful palace and building. Amazing photo opportunities. Lots of folks choose to rent local traditional clothing. Dress like a king and get free entry. Makes it very attractive and lots of participants

Visited the palace and managed to get in free as it was the last Wednesday of the month. The guard changing ceremony takes place twice a day (10am and 2pm) in the courtyard. It wasn't crowded and we took a leisure walk through the palace. There's also a little tea place within the palace if you want to drink tea or taste some royal snacks.
One of historic places in Seoul that must be visited...A place where you can learn about the history of South Korean kingdom in the past

I have been to this palace three times so far. Last time I wore Hanbok. (by the way if you wear Hanbok, you can enter the palace for free) It is a beautiful place with a lake and sometimes you can see traditional ceremonies.
A well known historical site for tourists to see in Seoul. The palace located in the center of the city. Easy to find by car bus or subway
Beautiful and very pleasant and interesting, easily accessible and very well maintained. Strongly recommended!

From the National Folk museum, you can walk through the vast land area full of architectural buildings in an old Joseon era set up. One can guess that this is where historical Korean dramas are shot. Free guided tours are available in English. The place is good for photo op's & during our stay, most locals came with their traditional hanbok costume. 💕
Free if you wear a hanbok to the palace. Do check out this place.. big place with peaceful environment.

I don’t want to miss Gyeongbokgung Palace because it is the oldest and largest Seoul’s palace. The entrance fee is only 3,000 won but if you want to experience wearing Hanbok or Traditional dress you can rent for 30,000won + you can get a free entry discount. One more thing, don’t miss to watch the Royal Guard Changing Ceremonies. It is a great opportunity to experience a rare traditional scene in Korea.

Caught the changing of guards. It was very well executed. Fun taking photos with the 'guards'. The palace is big and impressive. There is also a folk museum. It is of high quality. The children folk museum is also fun. The exhibits are interactive and well designed. Really surprised that for such a nice place it is free to visit for all.

The Palace ground is big, There are Korean's who dress in their national costumes who look so beautiful. At the ticket area, you will find some people who want to be a free guide to you to speak english. They will explain to you the history of the Palace. Inside there is also a National Palace Musem of Korea.  Take note that the guard changing ceremony is at 10.00 am & 14.00pm. The guard duty performance is @ 11.00 & 13.00pm .

The palace grounds is very huge, and it is a great place for photo taking. Many tourists and locals, as well as students, visit the palace daily. The palace guards changing ceremony was interesting. It took place at around noon time. A small entrance fee is required to visit the palace.

Suggest to go visit during the morning or later in the afternoon. We went just after lunch and it was a really hot day at 30 degree Celsius. We were so tired and thirsty and have to rest every now and then after 30mins walking or so. Bring a cap/hat, sunglasses and water if you do go during summer or hot day!  Palace is huge and will be even more pretty I believe during the Autumn period. One can spend at least 3 hours covering the whole palace so it will be good to go during a cooler day. We did not wait for the guided tour as we did expect to spend more than 2 hours in the palace which in the end we did due to much walking and resting!

This is a large complex of restored palace buildings that also includes two stand-alone museums, each of which would be a worthwhile attraction in their own right. The combination could easily occupy half a day or more and provides a great combination of history, art, and architecture. The one sight to see even with only a short time in Seoul.  Be aware that there are restoration works going on regularly, so there will be some construction fencing and inaccessible areas.  The changing of the guard "show" takes place in the main courtyard and so does not require admission--handy if you "miss" it due to schedule or weather and want to do it separately.  It is possible to combine it with the two "C" palaces in the area, but that would be a lot of walking and maybe an overload on "restored palace" experience.

The attraction is very well maintained. There are many tourists going around here. You will see many people wearing hanbok. This is quite interesting, and do not forget to watch the ceremony on the changing of the guards.
The palace is worth the visit for its unique oriental buildings and its change of guards which matches that at the Buckingham palace. The rooms are empty so don't expect to see fine interiors.

Must see place to visit allow a couple of hours here to take in the culture, history and wander around exploring. The guards at the front seem to be more a tourist attraction with their stick on beards and more a part time job than others I have seen in London etc. Don't let this put you off thou as once inside you get to see and learn about the history of Gyeongbokgung Palace. Do make sure you take the free tour lasting just over an hour will give you a good insight into its history and best of all it is free, if you dress traditionally thou it is free entry, great to see so many doing it certainly adds to the atmosphere.  Like most places in Seoul it was cheap admission and certainly worth the cost.
It's worth to get up early to watch the live Royal Guard changing ceremony and the free guided tours. The Korean female guides are very professional and patient in their sharing. Worth visiting!

This place is really busy at times, that busy that it is hard to get a good photo, it is pretty big to so make sure you have good walking shoes on and take water, you can not miss the changing of the guards at 11am 1pm and 3pm it good to watch.
Go there in the morning and catch the "Changing of the Royal Guards" which starts at 10 a.m. before exploring the large palace buildings. They are no less than stunning.

Rent a hanbok from any of the hanbok stores nearby and get a ticket for free at the booth from the side. Otherwise you would have to pay a fee. Take pretty pictures with the hanbok though it might be hot wearing it.

a must visit when travelling to Seoul. As Joseon dynasty's main palace, it is one of the most preserved palace, beside Changdeokgung. It is always packed with tourist. you can visit the palace for free if you wear hanbok. To learn more about its history, you are suggested to join the palace guided tour.

Sunny day to walk, lot of visitors with hanbok (Korean traditional clothes) which you can hire from 15000 won for 4 hours, you can find the shops closed by to hire the clothes, inside the palace have a lot of places for photoshoot, it's a nice day out.

If you can try to time your arrival to see the changing of the guard by the main gate. Its easy ti forget yoh are in a busy mordern city as you spend a couple of hours exploring the buildings and gardens in the palace grounds. Its well worth getting a guide to walk you through. Lical residents dress up in traditional costume which adds colour and charm to the experience. my puctures tell a better story than what I can describe. Well worth the visit

I've seen other palaces in Seoul but this one has a different beauty and character. You will imagine how grandeous of this palace in the past. You can see how the rulers lived and how they were served by their attendants. Somehow interesting. The gardens and the view of the mountain made the scenery more beautiful. It is a relaxing place to stop and reflect for a moment. You will consider the garden view as romantic, too.

One of the more popular palaces in Seoul, and it is a short walking to another travellers place known as Bukchon Village. Enter via the main entrance and you can see 'guards' dressed up in ancient times standing still, 'welcoming' you to it.

Wonderful palace to see. Take a guide as you will miss so much without one. Went into the King court and bumped my head on the curved rock for the doorway. Please watch out for the as my head still hurts.

In terms of "Palace Grounds", I think this is the most beautiful.  I have read reviews that this place is nothing special and that there are many people walking around. Simply not true, well, the "not special" part anyway.  There will be lots of people walking around, its a main attraction when visiting Seoul so I'm not sure what why you would not expect this.  This place is great for photography. So many different types of plants and flowers and lots of buildings to walk around and explore.  Yo will see many people walking around in "Hanbok" which is a traditional dress of Korea. Colourful and beautiful imo.  Grab a leaflet at the start which includes a map, its free and will ensure that you don't miss anything. There is also a way to see the "Blue House" which is where the president resides. I missed this first time round.  Entrance is cheap and you can buy a drink and some snacks inside. I recommend taking a packed lunch, find a nice spot in the grounds and relax.  The changing of the guard is a must see.  A great day out for all.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is quite impressive. The area behind the (restored) front gate is public and you're able to watch the very nice Royal Guard Changing Ceremony even for free.  If you wanna enter the actual Palace ground it'll cost you the small entrance fee of about 3$ only. Sure worth it.The palace ground is quite big and impressive. Nice buildings and architecture. Lots of green areas as well. Many visitors are roaming the area in (mostly rented) Hanboks. A nice sight.  Like I said, don't miss out on the guard changing ceremony. The Royal Guards change at least at 2pm and 5pm. Before the ceremony you can watch them train, just outside the walls (eastside). We went on a weekday and got some good spots to watch, not many visitors. It's enough if you show up about 15-20mins before (at least in spring). You also can take some nice pics together with the guards just outside the main gate.  All in all a nice place to visit. A few minutes away only from the Bukchon Hanok Village, don't miss out on that one if you're in the area.  Wanna know more about me and my trips? Check my profile.

We get to see the guard changing shift at 10 am. It was an interesting ceremony ! The palace was big and there were many nice places for taking pictures. A great experience to visit the Palace when in Korea !

The palace gave an idea of life several 100 years ago. The pavilion in the centre of a lake was most attactive and, on the day I was there, was the background for wedding photos. We saw the colourful changing of the guard.

This is a must see if you are interested in some culture while you are in Seoul. I suggest having a tour guide that can give you insight into the history. The changing of the guards is a nice ceremony and the art behind the King's chair are things not to miss.
Very interesting area of kings palace. I visited similar in Tokyo but this has different spirit. I would recommend to visit it.

TIP: Before going check the time of the FREE MULTILINGUAL tours! They provide interesting backstory and add some richness to the experience - highly recommend.  We visited this place on a rainy day but it was still worth it. My mom and I came together because of the overwhelming reviews we read online but when we got here we were totally blown away. The structures were beautiful and in pristine condition, the backstories all interesting.

One of the grand palaces of South Korea. Very good place to visit, especially if you're looking for cultural exposure.  Reminder to either bring umbrellas, or use sunscreen or both. :)  It's also a bit (or a lot) of a walk inside so make sure you're wearing comfortable clothes and shoes. :)  It has a connection to the National Folk Museum so you can come out that end and continue on to Bukchon Hanok village. And, if you're still not tired, you can go ahead and walk to Changdeokgung Palace (it -is- far, but doable). ;)
On tour, interesting to know the history of the palace. Fun to see a lot of people dressed in Korean outfit.

It's an hour+ and brings you to the key areas with stories and explanations, more than what I expected for a free tour. The guides are humorous and very friendly. Visit the palace website for timings.

As the main and biggest palace in Seoul, Gyeongbukgong is a must visit attraction. You can get in free if you're wearing a hanbok.  Got to see the changing of the guards at 10 am. I think it can be skipped, but if you're there anyway, it's still good to catch.  With a map/short guide available, one can go around on their own, but would advise to take a guided tour since they offer it free anyway.  It's a very big complex so it's best to wear comfortable shoes. Inside the complex is the National Folk Museum and you can get it there for free as well.  So many beautiful historical sites in this palace - architecture, design and nature in one. Placed against a lovely mountain background, you will understand why this site was chosen as the main palace.

Today I have visited Gyeongbokghng Palace which is at walking distance from Gyeongbokghng metro station.  The palace is huge is size and you have to walk a lot to cover all the parts of palace.  The Korean architecture is full of colours & they use lot of wood for making building.  The live music show during the visit was treat for the eyes ( girls playing drums).  Also many local people were dressed in Korean colourful traditional dresses, everyone looking great.  A not to miss place ..

This palace is located in the middle of town, surrounded by Seoul city, very interesting. I got here with a tour guide but I did not pay attention to the explanation, just taking some pictures which are beautiful. Well, a historical side in the city, very clean, and beautiful sceneries. But, you have to be ready to take a long walk.

Haven't been to many palaces in my lifetime, but walking through this one certainly made for a nice, informative afternoon! Loads of people in Hanbok (admission is free is you are wearing one?) enjoying themselves. The buildings themselves are georgous inside and out. Heartbreakingly poignant were the residences for Empress Myeongseong. With the mountains looming on the one side and skyscrapers on the other, an overall interesting exploration of Korea's past. Maybe try to visit on off-peak hours, it got quite busy and crowded on our way out.

We took the Airport Express Train from Incheon to Seoul in 50 minutes. Purchased the Express Ticket at the airport, easily followed the orange signs, assigned seats, off in Seoul. Short subway and a short walk and were at the Palace at 10 am in time for changing of the guards ceremony. Not to be missed. Very colorful and ornate. The Palace is huge. A court yard within a court yard within a court yard. Beautiful. Make sure to find the gardens. Gives you an idea of the landscaping of the past. Serene.

This is a great place to learn the Joseon dynasty period of Korea. It is fascinating to see a huge palace complex in the middle of a city. The highlight of this place is the changing of guards ceremony, as if traveling back in time.
Interesting part of history. Changing of the guards was worth a look. The gardens are lovely for a stroll.

Maybe because I've been to the forbidden city in Beijing. This palace seemed a little plain, but is a great location for Korean-themed photoshooting.  There's is an entrance fee of 3,000 Korean wons btw.

An absolute must. I was here for the afternoon and wish that I had allowed a full day. Acres and acres of space and lots to explore. The photographic opportunities are in abundance here. It was extremely busy and a hot sunny day with blossom everywhere. Many, many couples taking photographs in traditional dress which is so stunning. Even though it was busy, you can still lose yourself in the grounds and find some quiet spots to sit with a picnic lunch if you wish. The admission for myself was only 3000 won which is super super cheap and makes English Heritage Admission prices absolutely ludicrous. I came away having had a super day with stacks of wonderful memories and photographs.
I would like to recommend this place to foreigners who visit to Korea. You can learn Korea history and tradition! Also, can feel Korean life style. You can get to there by subway No.3 (Orange line).

Korea Grand Palace "Kyoung Bok Gung" Great place to learn Korea history and tradition. You can get there by subway No.3 (Orange line). I've been to Old Palace in other countries, because, can know their history and tradition. Also, this place is same. Really different architecture and life style. I would like to recommend this place to foreigners who visit to Korea.

If you're visiting Seoul this is a must see! We loved this Palace and we're in awe of its beauty. My mother in law had a broken toe so this was a hard day for her but we did get her a wheelchair. A lot of Walking and uneven ground with some stairs made for a painful day for her but she made it! Stay for the changing of the guard ceremony if possible.

Absolutely a beautiful palace that reflects traditional local culture and history. You may want to visit at the time that free English speaking your guide provided near the entrance- you can get detailed info visitor centers- to get most of the palace.

I had such a great day going around the palace grounds. The grounds were fascinating and the crowds were average. It only cost approx $4 CDN to enter and enjoy the area for as long as you can discover.

A real highlight of my trip. The Palace grounds are amazing and with the mountain ranges in the background, make for some superb photos.  I would suggest getting here early and purchasing the four Palace day pass as it's great value.  Really, a must see.

I appreciate Korean Palaces so much because it shows how much they treasure their history. It was well preserved and strictly kept clean, and thus it has become a highly respected place. I wish the Philippines valued its history as much as Koreans did. :(
Go there for a good morning walk.Nothing much to see. Very empty palace. Lucky the entrance fee is not expensive.

It's a very busy place during weekends, but I do consider it to be worth it. You have to pay a small fee for the entrance but can stay as long as you'd like to. You're able to rent some historical and traditional Korean clothes for enhance the experience.

We visited this palace on a beautiful sunny day and it was great to see the change of guard ceremony. Try to schedule your visit during the change of guard ceremony which happens several times during the day. The staff even lets you wear the traditional outfit for free of cost and it's a great photo opportunity. Overall a great vibe and a must do when you are in Seoul. You will spot a lot of couples wearing traditional hanbok.

This palace has been preserved quite beautifully. Admission is a mere $4USD and quite worth it. We happened to be lucky enough to catch all the cherry blossoms and flowers blooming. Many people choose to rent the traditional Hanboks prior to entering, as it's quite inexpensive and makes a beautiful photograph.
Free entry if you are wearing hanbok. The palace closed every Tuesday. It's a good place to take photo.
What a great place to visit and see! Totally loved our tour of this site. A lot of cool history and a lot to see!

Beautiful palace surrounded by various blooms of the spring. Nice place for a stroll and learn about Korea's culture and history. Exit at Gwanghwamun station Exit 9 and you can see King Sejong and Jung Yu-shin general statue at the Gwanghwamun Square on the way to the palace. If you are interested to know about their history, do drop by the King Sejong and Jung Yu-shin general Museum located just behind King Sejongas statue. There is a secret stairway leading down to the museum right behind the statue.

It's an imense palace, surrounded by a peaceful neighborhood. You can walk around the palaces and trees, and enjoy the tranquility of the place. It's included a ticket to the Folklore Museum, an atraction that should not be missed.

Originally built in 14 century but later restored in 19 century because of fire, Gyeongbokgung Palace is the largest remaining palace in Seoul from the old Joseon Dynasty. It houses many old palace buildings that are still standing today, some are national treasures. However, Hyangwonjeong Pond is closed to visitors for unknown reason. The National Palace Museum of Korea is located south of Heungnyemun Gate but is currently being renovated, and the National Folk Museum is located on the eastern side which is highly recommended.  The best entrance is through Gwanghwamun gate. There are performances of guards changing ceremony taking place every day. Please find out their timing before you go. Please remember the palace is closed to visitors every Tuesday. Do not be caught unaware.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a wonderful place to visit and a must when in Seoul. Truly magnificent. The view is spectacular and one should try to put on the traditional garb and enjoy relieving Korea's glorious past.

When the KDramas were in bloom in 2000's, I was dreaming Korea as my home. I never expected that it became a reality. I love all the places especially where these historical destinations. I was really amazed when I got in the gate, there are 4 palaces to visit. This was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty. Best visited during Cherry Blossom seasons (in my opinion).

As you can see from the title, yes, free entrance is possible if you rent a hanbok (Korean traditional clothes). There's shops near Gyeongbokgong that rent out the hanboks. You can do some research first before going. And if you're like me, you've been there and just want to walk around taking pictures as well as seeing the shift changing of the gate guards, arrive there around 1:00pm or 1:20pm. If not mistaken, the ceremony starts at 1:30pm. For me, I've been there like 4 times and I've already know how the palace looks like, so I just walk around Gwanghwamun without paying a cent to enter the palace. Besides, there's a museum near the subway exit near Gyeongbokgong which is FREE OF CHARGE.
One of the tourists spot that you must not missed. A lot of foreigners wearing Korean costumes and have pictorial in the place. It's a vast place to walk so wear a comfortable shoes.
Great place to learn history. You should take the tour because you get to know more about the place. You also get to see the blue house where the current president lives.

3 TIPS TO ENJOY THE GYEONGBOKGUNG PALACE  1. Rent a traditional costume.  You can get stunning photos while wearing a traditional costume within the palace grounds. Search online for where to rent a hanbok.  2. Get a map.  Plan your route, evade the huge crowd of tourists and still cover all the spots of the palace. Maps are available before entering the gates.  3. Wear comfortable shoes.  You won’t want to be limping through your time travel or be distracted by a painful blister.

My mom is not a fan of museums and she was totally blown away by the structures and the interesting backstory. It is beautiful there and if you arrive in time you can join one of the free multi lingual tours! Highly recommend it.

We went to this beautiful landmark early in the morning to avoid the crowd. We only have a little time left in Seoul so we did our tour inside quickly. Many tourist in groups often stop near the entrance taking pics etc blocking your way lol so to skip this, keep on walking inside as the palace is huge. Not much description written on each room in the palace, or maybe we just had to take the guide book or something at the entrance. We did the whole palace in 1 hour by keep on walking and taking pics quickly.

Originally built in 1395, this complex was the seat of the Joseon Dynasty until destroyed by the Japanese in the 1590’s. Instead of rebuilding, the royal family moved to another palace site. In 1867-68, the Prince Regent sponsored a reconstruction. Unfortunately, it again was almost totally destroyed during the second Japanese occupation prior to World War II, and the events of the Korean War. Restoration work began again in 1989, but according to our guide, only about 50% of the buildings have been completed. Nonetheless it is a fascinating place to visit and easily accessible. Inevitably, one will compare it to The Forbidden City because of similar design, but on a smaller scale. Make sure that you see Gyeonghoeru Pavilion (on the lake), one of the structures that dates from the 1867 restoration. It was used for entertainment when important foreign visitors visited the palace. Another point of interest is the video that deals with the assassination of Empress Myeongseong by Japanese agents in 1895 (and her quarters). One thing that added charm to our visit was the large number of young folks wearing traditional dress. Evidently, the clothes are available for rental and this has become a “thing to do” on a date, or just a lark.

There's a metro station just beside the palace so it's very easy to go to. On the front gate, you may take your pictures with the royal palace guards. And every hour, there's a performance where the guards change their duty shift. Apparently, there's a little ceremony for that!  Once the performance is done (roughly after ten minutes), the application for the use of guards costume opens. But you have to very quick because they only accommodate max of 10 pax per time slot. We were just lucky enough to be included!!! You may choose from the 4 costumes you want to try. Once you're on it, you can only wander along the ground but not too far! So it's just good for taking pictures. :)  Entrance to the palace is 3000 won for adults. Palace ground is huge and very picturesque so it's worth your while to roam around. :)

The palace was very designed and harmonised with the beauty of the surrounding nature. You could appreciate the creativity of the designers of the palace. At the end of the tour, I was most touched by the sad story of the Queen who was assassinated by the Japanese soldiers. Visitors are allowed to watch a video of the story, visit her rooms and imagine the atrocities happened in the past. Highly recommended.

Lovely place to visit. Shame the original palace was destroyed. But great that koreans are rebuilding it (as best as possible) to preserve their history. I guess in the summer it's even more beautiful. We we lucky that a high school student, Mary, offered to guide us. We got lots of information about Korean traditions, old customs and history.. And lots of information about the palaces history.  We spend several hours there before heading to the Folk Museum in the area.

The Admission: 3,000 won.  The Palace: One of the biggest palace in Seoul. Beautiful architecture!! This palace was the first royal palace built in the Joseon Dynasty.  Sumunjang changing of the guard ceremony(twice a day) 10am & 2pm.  Gwanghwamum changing of the guard ceremony (twice a day) 11am & 1pm.  They also offer English, Japanes and Chinese guided tour.  The Location: Subway Line 3, Gyeongbokgung Station, Exit 5

The place is beautiful, the mountains on one side and the modern buildings on the other makes this a unique sight! Combine a tour at the palace and it's surrounding buildings with a visit to the National Museum of Korean Contemporary History, just across the street.

Nice palace. Well maintained attraction. Very inexpensive to get in. The grounds are large, so on a nice day, this is a very nice walk. Would've been nice to see on of the buildings furnished as it would've looked during the period. So after looking at many buildings, we got kinda bored.
i arrived around 10 am and at the same time with changing guard ceremony in the place. The view of nature was very beautiful with the snow was falling that day.
bring food 🥘 and hot drinks, other than that we like this historic place, to get free entrance wear a hanbuk, confirm free, rent it or buy it just outside the palace

Gyeongbok Palace is the largest in Seoul, completed in1395. King Taejo also built Changdeok Palace completed in 1405. Yi Seonggye an army general that overthrew the government and took the name King Taejo. Yi started the Joseoy Dynasty which ruled from 1392 to 1910. ending with the defeat in the first Sino-Japanese War. He moved the Capital from Gaegyeong to Hanyang (later became Seoul). Gyeongbok Palace is not only beautiful, its history where all the social attitudes formed, powerful etiquette, and the cultural norms..

Gyeongbokgung Palace is the biggest palace in Seoul. It shows a very important part of Korean history, reflecting how people used to live. The gardens are pretty large, with many buildings in the area. As the palace is in a very historical area, there are many "hanbok" renters around, and tourists may dress in Hanbok for authentic experience. As for me, watching people around in Hanbok was very interesting. A not-to-miss is "the change of guards ceremony" - takes place at 10:00 and 14:00. This is a reenactment of the original ceremony from 1400's, takes about 20 minutes and they announce the actions in Korean and English. Also, you can dress-up as guards for authentic photos. The Gyeonghoeru Pavilion on Hyangwonjeong Pond the biggest pavillon in Korea, and it is a beautiful view with the mountains at the back. Strolling in the gardens of this palace and viewing the mountains, trees and ponds, I felt like in a movie from the old times.

It's easy to access there. 1. Line no 3 - orange line - get off Kyong Bok Palace. gate no 5 to the palace. it consist of several palace building. the most beautiful and greatest palace. 2. you can also walk to there from Kwang Hua Moon or City hall. 3. in the palace, there is a museum. it's quite good place to go. 4. on it's right side, there is Sam Chung Dong. now it becomes a famous place Korean Traditional style houses(Han Oak) village. it's good place of walking.

Out of all the places I visited on my 6-day trip to Seoul, this is my favorite. Went there during winter and it was amazing. Wasn't able to cover the whole palace during my 2-hour visit. Would visit again if I come back to Seoul.
Love the architecture and the fact that they make sure that the palace grounds are kept clean and restored! Popular place to see a glimpse of history.

A good place to know about Korea Palace and the history by joining the tour provided by the palace. Do visit the muzium nearby. Should try their hanbok dress cheapest is ₩13k rent for 2hrs and free entrance to the palace. Lovely experienced.

This palace i believe is the more popular one among the 5 nearby. It is huge and due to the hectic schedule we are unable to explore the place. Probably need like half a day to properly explore the area. There is a museum inside.

Be sure to join Gyeongbokgung Palace's free guided tour to better appreciate the place. It will only take one hour for you to learn more about Korea's rich history. If you plan to go to Bukchon Hanok Village, better ask information which gate you should exit. You might also want to check out the Blue House while you're in the Palace. They have an exit that will allow you to see the front of the Blue House. We weren't able to see the Changing of the Guards, but you might want to fix your schedule so you can see it.

The palace is extremely picturesque. I took some amazing shots here in the Autumn. The old architecture combines beautifully with fall colors. I think it's a fantastic place to go if you're looking for amazing photographs.

This is my second visit and i really enjoyed being a princess in one day, where you can rent a hanbook (tradisional uniform) across the road.  Rented fees is 30,000 won for 2 hours and we entered the palace with free of charge because im wearing it.  Beside that, u can try the men traditional cloth for free at main gate.  If this is your first time, you can join with others tourist as they provide English tour guide.  I went there by subway,

A must go place! You may find it is a good to place to go in different seasons, go with a big group or good to go alone! A place where you can sit to enjoy the scenery, take pictures and to find out more the Korean Royal life. Go connection with Metro!

Don't miss this if you are visiting Seoul. The guard changing ceremonies are the highlight and performing daily in short and long sessions. Do at least stay for the short one if your schedule allowed. There are also free guided tours available in different languages. Head to the right from the main gate for the information center once you purchase the entrance ticket. The staff was very helpful!  The palace was indeed amazing in winter. Many girls - tourists and locals alike dressed up in hanbok. It was such a beautiful scene. I've been to Seoul countless times but this was the first to the palace. I would totally come back again the next time to learn more about its history, and hopefully the weather won't be too cold so I can dress up in hanbok to take a stroll in the palace.

We spent an hour to get to 'Jongro-3road' station, because we wanted to go to "Gyeongbokgung". Before we go inside of it, we could see a large door called "Gwanghwamun". We could see quite a lot of people wearing "Hanbok" when we get through the gate. The palace was absolutely astonishing. We couldn't see the end because it's vast compound. Also when we looked inside of the Hanok(Korean traditional house), we could see beautiful colored ceiling. We could feel that this palace is the history of the place. It was almost hard to take in. We felt overwhelming. Also there is a wonderful lake. This lake was surrounded by large trees. In the middle of the lake there is a small island. We were honestly, completely blown away by this. Because we saw this place, we become aware of the sheer wealth and power of the Joseon dynasty. Absolutely incredible place. I highly recommend to visit here. Visiting this place is just the same with seeing a little piece of a picture in the past. Tip : It spends more than 3 hours to look this palace. Also even if you are foreigner, you can go inside the palace for free if you wear a Korean traditional clothes. You can rent it $20. You can get a great picture with it.

We went here during winter but it was still busy! We bought tickets on arrival then decided to hire some Hanbok (traditional Korean dresses) which were all located outside the palace on the main roads. We didn't know that if you are wearing traditional clothes you get to enter the palace for free! The ticket lady at the door told us to go get a refund for our tickets. It was simply amazing! All the intricate little details of the design was mesmerizing! Definitely a must see!

I love palaces and castles. I enjoy history so I like such palaces. But my brother thinks they are all the same and boring. So, to each his own. This is the biggest palace, so it's a must-see. But it's a nice place for photos, get a feel of Korean culture. Fun to see many people walking around in Korean hanbok clothes too. Feel like they came from another age into the modern world. There's guided tours provided in various languages. Be sure to check which one you want to join from the website timing before you go, so you can plan your day better. Wait at the front of the information office for the tour. I would suggest going for the tour so you can get more structured information about the palace. The national folk museum and palace museum are on the same grounds. Both are free but the palace is not. If you enjoy palaces, buy the combination ticket as its 4 palaces + 1 shrine (total ₩14000) but with the combi ticket it costs only ₩10000. Value for money if you will visit most of it. Good to spend a day wondering around the palace and museums. Recommended!

It's not the best palace which I've bee and it's nothing compared to some other palaces. Yet, it's definitely worth a visit. Also great to take pictures with other visitors who dressed up as the emperors and empresses!

The first attraction we visited upon arrival to Seoul. It was winter so it was not crowded at all (though, I've never been there during the other seasons) so you can take time in taking photos and just walk. Just as the other tourist attractions in South Korea, the palace is well maintained, toilets and surroundings are clean, tourist information areas are present, and English tourist maps and guides are provided.  Admission fee is KRW3000 but you can get a discount if you're visiting in group of at least 10. Good thing is, if you have enough time, there is an integrated ticket which you can purchase for KRW10,000 and entitles you to visit the other major palaces and temples in Seoul.  The best thing about the attractions in Seoul is the location. The attractions are pretty much close to each other, hence they are easy to find, especially if your using the subway. The National Folk Museum is located just next to Gyeongbokgung, and you can visit the place for free. You can visit other nearby Museums after, head to Bukchon Hanok Village and stroll at Insadong and Samcheongdong afterwards. Then you can take pictures at the Gwanghwamun gate as you head off to the subway on your way home (what we did, since we entered the Gwanghwamun Subway Station as we got back home).  **If you don't mind long walks, it's better to walk from one attraction to next. **Just make sure to wear your winter clothes to keep you warm as it gets really cold especially when it's windy. Bet you don't wanna spoil your tour when you're busy keeping yourself warm. :)  If you plan to visit Changdeokgung, I suggest you alot another day for that to appreciate, then you can go to Jongmyo Shrine after. You can also exchange Changdeokgung and Gyeongbokgung. Both are near Bukchon Hanok and Insadong-Samcheongdong

Went there about 4 times in summer, winter and spring. winter visit isn't giving the palace any charm as it is cold and not colorful. When spring arrive, the palace take it's color and is much more welcoming

Did a solo trip to the palace, which is conveniently located near a subway station.  There is a change of traditional palace guard parade that had explanations in English, Mandarin and Japanese; very interesting to watch and understand.  The palace itself is quite a big compound and well preserved and restored. I would have preferred that there were more directional signages and explanations of the various locations of the palace. I did not see any maps for visitors to take along (maybe I missed it), hence, some places that I walked had nothing much to view. The lack of explanation boards at the various locations made my visit a purely sightseeing trip, so for those who want some history, either get a guide book or a guided tour.

visited some palace around seoul, me personally is not a fan of history but went there to accompany my family. I bring them to some other palace and it look a like, I suggested to come to one of them is enough.

The surrounding area of the palace is quite vast so you could just walk around anywhere and imagine what it was like for the past kings and queens. Entrance is ₩8000 but there's an integrated ticket (₩10000) if you want to get to all palaces. Check this place out and explore it! Witness the guard changing at 10AM and 2PM. Try the guard costumes for free (first come first serve basis!).

A few of my korean friends went to Gyeongbokgung to show a few friends from overseas. None of us had been there but we just walked around by ourselves casually. It's mostly all seen from the outside so was a bit cold in winter but still a good stroll on a fine day. Allow around 2 hours to have a wander and appreciate the architecture and korean culture here (we didn't go to the museum). One end faces the president's blue house and the other end faces gwanghwamoon. There will be people walking around in the korean traditional attire as there are places to hire them around the palace and the entrance to the palace is free if you come dressed so. But the entrance fee is cheap anyway

There are free tours of the palace grounds at certain times of the day (in English, Mandarin, and other languages). Make sure you join one of these - it will say in the information pamphlet what time and where the guide will be waiting. We found the experience to be much more enriching with the tour.

This is a very typical Korean Traditional palace which is built in ancient Korea, and it is very impressive how well it is preserved. A perfect spot to experience Korean style architecture, a must go place if this is your first time to come to Korea.

Plan your visit to see the "Change of Guards" but even if you can't be there during the event you will not be disappointed. I spent about 3 hours exploring all that I could but one can be there for a whole day as there are so many rooms and details! A Must see!

The palace itself is absolutely stunning even if it was a bit small. The changing of the guards is a must, as there is a little audio thing that plays during it to explain things. Overall a very interesting and lovely trip.

Once you've seen 1 palace, you've seen it all (in my opinion). The only difference here is that you get to watch the changing of the guards. Good thing it was winter time when I visited. The weather, though cold was bearable. I can't imagine walking around this place during summer. I might literally melt :)

Highly recommended to join the free tour at the palace, you may check the timings of the tour on their website. There is no need to sign up for the tour in advance, you can just turn up near the main gate of the palace. The tour guide will explain to you the various living quarters of the palace.  I waited for the changing guards ceremony at 3pm but it did not happen, not sure if there was a change in their schedule?  There are many people wearing hanbok in the palace. I've checked with the information centre that they do not provide renting of hanbok. You will have to rent it at one of the shops outside the palace.  The palace is huge and requires a lot of walking. Hence, it is recommended to wear good walking shoes.

Gyeongbokgung Palace has to be one of the most budget friendly tourist attractions I've ever been to - at 3000krw it is a bargain.  One piece of advice I have is to arrive about 15 mins to the hour - this way it will give you enough time to buy tickets and watch the guards changing (happens on the hour) which will then give you ample time to roam the very spacious palatial grounds. This way you don't have to rush to the entrance if you are somewhere else in the compound to watch the change of guards.  I very much enjoyed the palace - we went in the morning and would recommend you do this to avoid the crowds as this is a tourist hot spot. This way you can get lots of photos without people in the way. Having said that the Gyeongbokgung Palace is HUGE - we just avoided the crowds by walking around the outside first where you can admire all the foyer and ceiling art followed by walks next to the water gardens which are a lovely place to admire the wildlife among the water lilies.  If you can allocate at least two hours to walk around the grounds - it's very scenic and clean - if I lived in Seoul I would come here for the peace and quiet alone, not to mention it is a great workout if you visit every part of the compound.  A must-see and notable attraction if you have time on your trip - it's easily accessible by Subway and not far from other hot spots in the city.
Spend half a day at this lovely palace. So many things to explore, great park and scenic and tranquil. Don't miss it.

This was the first palace I visited, and was the one I enjoyed the most. It was beautiful. My recommendation is that you book a tour as it is more interesting to see the place and know the history. I would think it will be quite boring just to visit and take picture. You can book the free tour provided by VisitKorea, if you are in tight budget.

Not a must visit tourist attraction. It was just a normal palace with a lot of tourists. Not as grand as I hope for. The guard changing was interesting. Seeing them wearing their traditional costume. You can get free trial of the costume. Just go straight to a small hut behind the main gate after the guard changing ceremony.
A wonderful palace with lots of historical perspective. Great to walk the grounds for an hour or so to better understand how royalty lived during Korea's Chosun Dynasty.
Took the City Tour bus and alighted at this palace. Nice place for photo taking and impressive buildings in thia palace. Like it alot
The compound of the palace is very big so be prepared to do a lot of walking. Do not miss the changing of the guards ceremony.

A great place to learn on Korean culture and early imperial history. Very easy to go- take direct train to Gyeongbokgung palace and follow signage. Entry is 3000 won I think and you can rent an audio guide for 3000 won at the counter next to ticket office. 4 language choices- japanese, mandarin, english and Korean  We rented hanbok (Korean traditional costume) at a shop near by for 18000 won per set (males hat for additional 1000 won) and it allows free entry to the palace. The package is 4 hours for picture taking. The shop we went to is not the one opposite the ticketing office. In my opinion, the one opposite ticketing office doesn't really have costume.

Love the overall look and feel of the palace grounds. The buildings and parks inside truly provides for an immersive experience. You must make it for the changing of the guard, which is conducted daily. I feel as if that made the visit more special. The park inside the palace compound was gorgeous. I visited in Autumn, so the falling leaves/cool breeze may have played a role. I totally recommend visiting

If you have a limited time, this is the biggest palace to go. Palace design is influenced by Ming and Qing dynasties. The palace ground is still being reconstructed as a lot of the buildings were destroyed or damaged during the two Japanese invasions. According to locals, the palace is about one third completed and is slated to be fully reconstructed by 2020 or 2030.  Best photo spots are during spring and autumn. In winter, no leaves. You must go for the Change of Guard Ceremony at 10 am and 2 pm.

I visited the palace both during the day and also for the night tours, the night tour was definitely my favourite. The pavilion was lit up and there were performances.They only do night tours during the autumn months.

If you have only short stay and want to see Korean palaces, this is it: located in central Seoul and you will be able to see beauty of Korean palace with beautiful landscapes surrounding the palace! Sometimes they open during the night hopefully this Christmas. Inside, Korean folks museum is another place to learn about Korean culture and custom. Winter time you need a heavy coat since most walking is outside to appreciate the palace!

It was in 1395, 3years after the Joseon Gyeongbokgung palace was at the heart of seoul and front of Gwanghwamun Gate  Free Guided Tour 11:00 / 13:30 / 15:30  한 여름밤의 야간개장 경복궁 운치있고 아름다워요 마지막주 수요일 문화가 있는 날은 무료관람가능 혹은 한복입어도 무료관람~ 고궁 :)

This huge place was the bomb. When we arrived there was a guard changing ceremony in front and it was totally cool. Tickets are only KRW3000. The architecture was just so beautiful. One of the lake was frozen when we arrived but we can still see fishes inside. Simply beautiful.

We spend time in Seoul for 4 nights , first day we visited here with my family and my friend We purchased the tickets and walk around to the palace. It's like in the Korean series that I like very much. Felt like being shown on the series lol. Palace pretty much a source of this country. And I can even walk to the back of the palace as well.I really fall in love this county . The people are very help full

An area much larger than you imagine on walking towards it. In winter closes at 4pm. Lots of buildings and a pond to look at as you walk about. Some steps but it is an easy relaxing walk and central to the city so you can walk on Metro there easily. A popular attraction in the peak season so look at getting in early in the high season.

We enjoyed walking around the palace grounds and watching the changing of the guards. What we initially thought was a canon being shot off nearby was actually a massive drum being struck as part of the guard changing performance. Was also only 3,000 won to enter so very cheap. Highly recommended
One of 5 palaces, biggest and most popular one. Guard changing ceremony a little theatrical but makes for nice pictures

This palace even though it's mostly been recreated due to destruction it's been completed Ina truly gorgeous manner. You can wander around the whole complex using just the provided map. There is lots of signage in English explaining what the various buildings originally used for. Talk a lunch and sit in the open spaces for a relaxing experience

Good tourist attractions... a huge amd spacious palace,before you enter the palace you need to watch the exhibition of the guards first at the main gate then you can now go inside and explore a lot of things..

You're dazzled the moment you step into the main gates from the street. Locals dressed in the local dress add a priceless touch to the place. The blend of the old architecture with the modern cityscape in the background is something not to miss. It is quite a long walk to the palace itself, but well worth it. A lot of greenery and running waters add a peaceful touch to the place. Be ready to get a lot of photos and don't worry about the food or drink as there are small stalls with snacks and drinks spread throughout the place.  Usually, musical shows and concerts are held there at around 7 pm with separate tickets but the settings are usually bewildering. If you get the chance to go, don't think twice.
A must visit for first time to Seoul. It's a place of history and reflection of the Imperial culture. Nice maintained buildings and garden.

Love the peace and tranquility this palace offers. The vastness provided me enough space to just chill at a quiet corner and rest my mind without the crowd buzzing around.  The autumn Colours at some parts of the palace and garden areas were amazing and I have managed to captured some great moments.  Do spend some time at this palace when you are in Seoul. The shopping can wait.

Although there is no like the majestic palace of Beijing the imperial palace, also have no gorgeous color. But to South Korea will go to scenic spots, is one of the historical features of Seoul, the former imperial palace, a historic place, listening to the history to follow, will definitely have to deepen the understanding, and there are a lot of tourist information provided to the tourists from country to country. This is a great building, regardless of appearance or palace to a person very elegant feeling, with very distinctive features of the south Korean historical buildings. Maintenance, both inside and outside place clean and tidy. And has a performance, or there will be a change in noon soldier performance (martial arts), there are large in army demonstration, cooperate with diet language between China and Japan, to take care of the needs of different nationality. Garden scenery good, in a quiet place, worth a visit.

I went during Chuseok, which I recommend to everyone because of the broad array of events which were planned for the holiday. Gyeongbokgung Palace is just beautiful and a nice sunny day made the whole experience that much better.
its realy big The complex really big. Worth a walk all of it. There is a lovely lake There are also guides in English Two hours trip
Away from the busy street and embraced the ample space and astonishing ancient architecture. I would recommend my family and friends to visit when they visit Seoul.
We enjoyed watching the changing of the guards and our tour of the palace was really good. The architecture and colors of the buildings were amazing.
Gorgeous... wear the traditional hanbok costumes here and relive your korean dramas! Hahahaha! Beautiful..

We were disappointed with the Gyeongbokgung Palace. So many guide books put it as one of the top ten sites to visit in Seoul. The palace is not very well maintained, many rooms have no exhibits or furniture there. The only scenic spot is near the small ornamental lake.

It was a Saturday when we visited and the palace was a bit crowded. Many locals in their traditional hanbok allow tourists to pose with them for pictures. The palace ground is huge with several structures on it. It costs $3 to enter the main palace but free for seniors if you show your passport. Be prepared to do a lot of walking, but definitely a must see. The changing of the guards is an added attraction.

I did not visit the other palaces around Seoul but this is definitely worth a visit. The palace grounds are quite large and it would take at least 2 hours to cover the entire area. We had a surprise visit from the 'Emperor' himself, as he walked through the grounds with his "Emperess' and 'guards'! Lots of local Koreans in their traditional costumes.
The place with many surprises.. It a very big place and I was there for 3hours .Make sure you go with a tour or hire the audio guide at the entrance which is very helpful.
This is a must-see in Seoul. A huge place, very interesting buildings and lovely gardens. Great for people-watching too, especially on Sundays when lots of locals wear traditional Korean dress.

We booked a complimentary tour through Visit Korea's website and met at the ticket office at 10am on the day of visit. Our guide was a lovely lady who was a volunteer. It's impressive that locals would volunteer their time and energy to introduce their city to foreigners. She was very enthusiastic and spoke decent English. We started at the main entrance and walked our way through the whole palace. Extremely beautiful place with lots of history and unique architecture. Our wonderful guide explained the architectural aspects, history of the structures, and even some present day local affairs! We wouldn't have been able to understand so much without her. Time well spent and a must-visit in Seoul!

Entering this palace is like we walk in the history.  Trying to imagine what the live in the year of 1300 looks like.  It's definitely a grand palace, huge complex with lot of green sceneery inside.  Love the roof architecture.  I personally like Hyangwon-Jeong pavilion, a royal residence of Emperor Gojong. Surrounded by lotus pond, makes this place so beautiful and serene.  Direction to this attraction : stop at Gyeongbokgung Palace Station (Seoul Subway Line 3), Exit 5.  Instagram : @adjimantoro

I have been to Gyeongdong Palace a number of times.I also am from the US. This time I brought a visitor from the U.S.. We are both cabinet makers, so in visualizing the construction of the palace and other buildings on the grounds, we were impressed. That's not to say that there isn't an air of falsity about the restoration/renovations/reconstruction of the compound. The buildings are not that old. The grounds are not maintained as if they were still a living quarters. One is left wandering about without having a true grasp of the daily life of the palace grounds. There needs to be more visual and written placards  What is important is with an imagination a person can picture how people moved about and how the city was laid.  There is room for improvement. Drop your iPods, cell phone and other tech devices. Imagine 100 years ago. 200 years ago.

The palace is very easy to get to by Metro and the exit takes you right to the main courtyard of the palace. It gets quite busy although doesn't feel too crowded as the grounds are quite big. It seemed that a relatively popular activity was to dress up in local traditional attire which was available for rental. I didn't go for that personally but there were many families, school groups and also couples that did so and this somewhat added to the atmosphere of the palace.  A striking contrast was the backdrop to the palace grounds where on one side you had the mountains and on the other side you had the tall modern buildings of the city. Aside from the main preserved buildings the gardens themselves provide nice photo opportunities particularly around the pond areas. There are also replica buildings that have been constructed that you can wander in to.  The palace also has changing of the guards which I unfortunately missed so worthwhile checking the times and getting there to catch the ceremony.  Note that the vast majority of the visit is outdoors and walking around the grounds so do be prepared.

You can go there by train or bus and just a few walk to the palace. Entrance fee is 3,000 KRW and you should visit there since morning because it's very large. For women who would like to wear Hanbok (traditional dress), you can rent from shop near the palace before and go inside. If you buy ticket and go inside, it cannot re-entry to rent the dress later.

The Temple was very large but had nothing to do. It was however really pretty and there was a nice museum. The small giftshop was awfully expensive. The museum had a large variety of items but the signs with descriptiones were only simply and shortly translated into english, so I'd suggest that you get an audio guide.

It's a good day's fun, there are small streets with lots of small shops and places you can rent Hanbok (the traditional clothing) immediately to the East of the palace. We rented Hanbok and entered the palace as the admission is free if you're wearing Hanbok. It is also a trend among young people and couples nowadays to do it and take pictures while touring the palace, kinda like cosplaying in a way I guess? It was interesting seeing the changing of the guard, different architectures and other people walking around with Hanbok too.

Our visit was so interesting, no doubt because of an excellent English-speaking guide. She gave a good overview of Confucian traditions and the Joseun Dynasty. The grounds are quite lovely, plus there are two museums on the premises that are worth seeing.
My second time to visit the palace and it's still amazing.  The changing of the guards is a must see. Try to schedule a visit during one.

Very economical experience! The entry fee was very reasonable. Think it worked out to be about US$3. The grounds provide free tours in 3 languages at different times of the day. We took the English speaking one at 1:30 pm. A rich piece of Korean history and a lovely way to spend a couple of hours. Note the palace is closed on Tuesdays.

We visited this palace, the largest of the 5 palaces within Seoul, in the morning and it was already teeming with tourists. There is so much history to absorb both in visual and audible form. The details on the decor, roof structure & building design are awe inspiring. Each detail, whether it be the shape of the roof, the colour combination of the ceiling beams, the setting of rooms (with heating options), is so meaningful. Like the other palaces, this is meticulously restored. You can almost feel the presence of royals and the troops within the palace. The place however seems squeezed by the sprawling metropolis though once within its perimeter, one can enjoy the peaceful and serene atmosphere. One thing notable is that unlike Changdeokgung Palace, which is of Korean architecture (entrance walkway is crooked), this palace is of Chinese design (entrance walkway is straight).

Gyeongbokgung is also one of the places to visit in Seoul. Not only is it beautiful to see, it is also easy to find and free of entrance! If you exit from City Hall (blue line) subway exit 2, walk down the road up until the end. It is aproximately a 15minute walk. On the way there you will find the statue of King Sejong (3rd king and supporter of Hangul) and Yi Sun-Sin (famous naval commander). You can also take the purple line to Gwanghwamun which is closer but does not go from Seoul station.

I like this place. Walking around, exploring. Take a rest when feeling tired. Entrance ticket is KRW 3K, free if you wear hanbok. They also have free guided tour on certain time. Be sure to check out their website.

A place where it tells you the history of the Korean Dynasty and how the palace was burn down. Do join the free guided tour to fully appreciate the palace. Do not walk on your own. They in the process of rebuilding the entire palace which is schedule to complete in 2045. Beautiful place to walk around and with many Korean in Hanbok. It's worth coming.
The Palace is nice but your visit gets better when you see the gardens. I was so lucky I went during Fall/autumn, so I could see the different colour of the trees.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a must-visit when you are in Seoul! Do note that the palace is closed on Tuesdays so avoid going on that day. It is extremely accessible via the metro (alight at Gyeongbokgung Palace station itself, Line 3, Exit 5). You can even walk to Bukchon Hanok Village from there. If you're in Hanbok, admission to the palace is FREE!

The palace itself is not so much to see. On a sunny weekend, you can find citizens/tourists wearing Hanbok in it, as if it is a movie studio. It's great to get some Korean vibe. Also, do visit the palace at night! The palace is glowing with some lights on. There are some beautiful pine trees besides the park.

The palace is open for public visits. And as with most of the palace worldwide, there is guard changing ceremony. If i'm not mistaken, it is carried out twice a day. Its an interesting ceremony and tourist should grab the chance to watch it. The entrance fee is quite cheap and inside, you can take pictures and learn many Korean's history. There is also some place inside where you need to pay extra if you want to enter. Fir me, i just pay the initial entrance fee and spent around 2 hour visiting the palace. To go there, its quite easy using the subway.

This was a great temple to visit and you could easily spend a few hours wandering the grounds. It's especially nice to see lots of people in Korean traditional dress as it allows them free entry, but also adds to the atmosphere.

A must visit when in Seoul. Stunning and well-preserved architectures. Love the vast gardens, walkways and ponds. During my visit, there was a stage performance going on. It was interesting to see people in Hanboks walking around.

We are lucky to visit on a special festive day where entrance to the palace is free. We spent an hour or so walk around the palace and it was so chilly during autumn month. Beautiful gardens and clean environment, well maintained architecture & there are free tour around the garden (English speaking). Overall, this is a must-visit place if you are a first timer to Seoul, Korea.

Really interesting and huge palace compound. Try to see the small parade which is at 11 am and possibly 2 PM. There are so many building to walk around and see, and there is an English speaking tour twice a day at noon and possibly one later. Found it interesting but tour, at 1 hour, was too long for our Elem. age kids.

Large estate where you can wander around or take a detailed audio tour Interesting to see the ancient dynasties. Lots of young girls in the traditional folk costumes also made for good people watching.  There's also a number of art galleries nearby so check out modern Seoul as well as heritage sites.

The palace is huge and gives a good insight into Korean culture and dynastic lifestyle. don't miss the evening light and sound show encompassing several cultural events.( only foreigners allowed). make sure you carry your passports
Definitely a must-visit when you travel to Seoul. This palace is very well-preserved and they are continuing with the restoration work.
Good attraction, large palace, different structures, Korean heritage. Went on a day when there was a cultural festival going on. Lot of youngsters wearing traditional and colourful dresses

Nice place to explore. It's a huge complex so there are lots to see. The changing of the Palace Guards takes place at 11am.  What I didn't like was the large number of tourists during the peak hours. Some of them, especially those bus load of visitors from China tend to get really noisy and aggressive when taking selfies. I saw a bunch of them man handle the Palace Guard so that they can have that perfect selfies. So the best time to visit is early in the morning or at night.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is part of the itinerary of all the day tours in Seoul, which tells you that it is worth seeing, but as my husband and I discovered, it is an easy 20 minute walk from the City Hall neighbourhood where our hotel was located. In other words, it is possible to see come of the city's rich history even if you don't have much time to spare. The palace is an commanding structure and gives a real sense of the wealth and sophistication of Korea at the time when Europe was still emerging from the Middle Ages. But, the thing that we found most impressive was the pride and patriotism shown by the Korean people, many of whom were dressed in colourful, traditional costume. Gyeongbokgung Palace is the perfect solution if you are in Seoul on business and don't have much time but still want a taste of the country's history.
Since the culture is somehow similar, I'm not really interested in the palaces, but this one is nice, and if I must choose to go to 1 palace, it should be this one
They have this activity every day except Monday.The costumes of the guards are fantastic and then we took a tour of the palace
The palaces all begin to look similar after a while. My advice would be to go to the museum first (especially if it's a hot day) and then try to figure out which palace you would like to see.

This place is really historical, will every single things you had seen on Korean Drama. The most impressive thing is when we worn hanbok we didn't have to buy entrance tickets. It's the way Korea brings their culture to the tourists.

Lovely palace to visit but not a lot of information in English. If you visit this palace, make sure you watch the guard ceremony. They explain it in Korean then translate to English. It was great to watch.

Definitely worth a visit. The terrain and architecture, buildings and gardens are all well maintained and beautiful. The admission is very inexpensive...great way to promote your city and draw in tourist.

This place is breathing with history, which contrasts so much with tall modern buildings in the background. Met lots of local girls in traditional costumes here. In hot weather you'll feel like being barbecued here;)
Strongly recommended from me - love the palace and the morning Guards changing. Take me back to the old days...
Really bring you to the past. Changing guard ceremonial is always interesting. The guards wear the traditional costume where guests would love to take pictures with them.

It's a grand palace with huge open space. Well preserved architecture. It's now free admission in conjunction with Korea sale Festa. Good for sightsee and photo taking. To experience it fully, suit up in their traditional costumes first! After this palace, do go to Changdeokgung's secret garden for 5000won per entry. 10-15 mins walk east of Gyeongbokgung.

Too beautiful place and all the place look like a picture too cause the tree and the lake 😍 If you are korean drama fans you will be crazy haha ;D cause you will see all the scenes in your eyes and you will know how big in gyeongbokgung palace It's very fun and beautiful place Full of Korea historical place and look :) Must do and come list in Korea!!!!

I had been to the palace in the day some years ago. Last week, I had the chance to go in for the night tour last week. Please go there at about 6:30 pm, to queue up for the foreigners' tickets, for entry at 7 pm (although they let the people in before then). The palace looked beautiful at night, because they lit it really well. It had a dance and a light show (every hour, I think). The reflections of the buildings and the trees in the lake were particularly impressive. Allow about an hour for the night tour and it was worth a visit. Pictures:

this is one place you should not miss when visiting seoul even for the first time. it has a lot to offer and don't forget to bring an umbrella or a hat to protect you from the scorching heat. too bad there was no personal tour guide to explain to us the different features of the palace.

Only seen palaces in kdramas but visiting and seeing first hand is awesome. i was literally in awe. the designs and architecture is definitely 👌🏼. Aside from the shopping, you need to set aside time to visit this

This is typically a king palace during old time. When you experience Seoul in the first place, give a chance to come here and spend aprox. 2 hours to stroll around to the palace and national museum. If you happens to like history and place to photos then you might be spend more time there.  For me, it is good to go and take a look of changing guard ceremony at their official site or any blogger site available.

This is a must see if you are visiting Seoul. It's beautiful and full of history. Very inexpensive stop and you can take endless photos. You will also see many people dressed in traditional outfits walking around. I loved it.

I give this 4 ratings because objectively, it is an amazing place though, honesty, it is not my favorite. Why? this place is crowded (like really crowded) and way too large (it takes hours to go round and check out the castle area). If you are really interested and eager to visit this place, plus you are a history geek, go ahead. But if you only want to take a beautiful picture in a typical Korean castle so you are able to post it on your social media, you'd better check other castle (e.g. Changdeokgung Palace). Other castle is just as beautiful and way less crowded. But, the thing is, this palace is like a must-visit-place when you are in Seoul, so it's all up to you. Once again, it's nice place but not my personal favorite.

Quite a cool place for pictures, palace is quite big so some substantial walking is needed. Has heritage and convenient mountains at the background while taking pictures. Good that there were no high rise buildings on that side of the city

The area is very big and alot to see. But it's hard to take a good picture at the gate because it's always full of people. The sightseeing inside much more tranquil. I was in there at 11a.m and got a chance to see the guard changing. They only walked a few feet long so if you want to take picture, you have to be very quick

This is my second time visiting. This palace is the biggest, oldest & main of the 5 palaces. This palace is huge so it takes a couple of hours at least that you need to wear comfortable shoes! It's located the center of seoul & surrounded by high buildings. You would enjoy relaxing & seeing the gorgeous palace!!
Just a beautiful historical i am amazed by the culture also keeping the palace well maintain i would love to come back !!!!
First royal palace that you have to visit if you come to Seoul. Do not forget to take selfies with its guardians!

As the main palace complex, Gyeongbokgung stands as the biggest. There are a lot of things to see in this complex; thus, a guided tour is recommended if you have time to spare. As my friends and I were pressed for time, we just spent around an hour walking around the palace grounds while waiting for the Gate Guard Change Ceremony. Avoid visiting this place on sunny summer days, as the heat may be too unbearable. The complex also houses the National Palace Museum of Korea which has interesting exhibits and a quirky gift shop/cafe where you can stay in to cool down from the heat.

Needs ability to walk and climb stairs huge property . Lovely grounds I went there during choseok and we were not charged a fee or else you have to pay a nominal amount to get in. Next to the palace is a Museum which is worth a visit. The Korean people are very gracious and helpful.

Hanbok is Korean traditional costume and you can rent it around the palace and Insadong. I rent it at Insadong. The reason I mentioned it is I strongly recommend to visit THIS palace in Hanbok if you want to life long valuable picture in Korea! Also entrance fee is free when you are in Hanbok. Go to the ticket box and ask the tickets. Then you will get free tickets. It's very special experience walking in the historical site in tradtional costume. It was very exciting! The building was very great and felt that I was back in the days during Joseon Dynasty! Oh also this place is huge! Keep in mind !

Gyeongbokgung Palace kept my attention for several hours when I visited. Its grounds are large and the palaces are beautiful! The entrance fee was $3 which enables a visit to their museum as well. It was well worth the time and $3.

I went there in the weekend it was busy and full of people. it was very large that you could enjoy taking pictures of different spots. three different performances are presented a day, attending one of them is enough they all seem the same and very simple. I would command the large changing ceremony. the palace is recommended for people who are interested in history and architect.

I was taken here as part of an organised business tour. The palace is well worth a visit, covering extensive grounds. We arrived in time to see the staged changing of the guard, which was a great spectacle. I most enjoyed the lake and gardens.

Great for a visit during the day - take in the changing of the guard. Even better if you can visit in the evening - the Pavilion lit up with the sunset over the mountains was magical. We managed an evening visit when there was a musical evening. Very atmospheric with many visitors dressed in traditional costume.

The grounds here are beautiful and the structures are as well. The insides, the ceilings particularly are very intricate and colorful but nothing is original because 90% of it was torn down during Japanese occupation which is a shame. The restoration and rebuilding of the structures is very nice, so it is nice to imagine how it would have looked. There are also plaques all around that explain the buildings and it is worth looking up online before you go, but I wouldn't pay for a tour. I was teaching in Seoul and took my family (who was visiting) here in July of 2015 and they enjoyed it but once you have seen one palace in Korea you have seen them all. Doing the hop-on-hop-off bus tour is your best bet! Then you can spend as much time as you would like and move on.
Please join the free guided tour so that you know the history of the palace. The place is quite big, you can spend the whole day inside. You get free entry if you are in hanbok.
It's big, it's beautiful but if you shall get the most of the visit you should be there before 2pm and get a good spot to watch the change of the guards.

Eat. Sunblock. Comfy Shoes. The place is huge. Starts at 0900. You can try on the traditional dress and roam around the palace for free- just the dress. Entrance cost around 3500won. Afterwards, chill inside the national museum. If your lucky, you can watch the marching of guards. And so you know, tourist swarms all over the area.

This is definitely the must visit palace when you are in Seoul. This place is huge so be prepared to walk a lot. Entry is free if you are wearing Hanbok. If not, 6,000krw per pax. Hanbok can be rented from shops near the palace. We rented our Hanbok for 4 hours for 15,000krw per pax from a shop nearby.  Be sure to take lots of photo of the palace.

I like this place very much. Learned about Korean history. It was very pretty and well kept. It was huge and exactly what we expected to see since I have watch lots of Korean movies and see the palace on screen before
The Changing of the Guard was a great photo opportunity. The palace itself is interesting and a nice contrast with modern Seoul right outside the walls.

This is one of the Seoul "Top 10" attractions, but the reviews on Trip Advisor are not unanimously good - so I went wondering if it would be enjoyable, or a bit of a let-down. Well I'm pleased to be able to report that I thoroughly enjoyed it. I had a good walk around Gyeongbokgung Palace and also popped in to the Korean Museum of Folk Culture next door.  I found the Palace very interesting and rather impressive (I did not do a guided tour, I just walked round by myself). Entry is 3000 Won (around US$3, GBP£2) which is absolutely excellent value for money. There were quite a lot of locals there in traditional and very colorful dress, which really brightened the experience.  It took me 2 hours to have a really good look around and take my photos. The Folk Museum I mentioned earlier I do not recommend. I spent just 5-10 minutes in there and it will certainly be of much more interest to Koreans than to visitors. Nevertheless, entry was free so I'm not complaining... just advising!  I notice more than one review comparing Gyeongbokgung Palace with the Forbidden City in Beijing. Gyeongbokgung Palace is much smaller (although still occupying quite a large area) but quite similar in its layout and appearance. Please don't go to Gyeongbokgung Palace hoping or expecting to find an equal of the Forbidden City, but I think you will find something equally as interesting although rather less dramatic in scale.  The day I visited the weather was sunny. I would not advise going on a rainy day, I think that would totally spoil your visit.  Overall, very highly recommended.
A very nice place to visit, be with the historical atmosphere, go through Korean history with English translation device. outside there is a folklore singers with old tradition dresses.
