Having seen the palace in China, the Gyeongbokgung Palace is really nothing in comparison. But it is still a history of Korea.

It's quite a large place with lots of buildings but not a hell of a lot else. There's not a lot of information about the place historically or otherwise which is a real shame and some of the information is only in Korean. Definitely not a place to keep kids occupied.

Sept-2016) Great palace. It was a little too much walking for our my 8-yr old in addition to taking subway both ways...but he loved it.  We got the audio guide for 3,000 won.  The subway exit off line 5 (purple line) is gorgeous. You exit by Admiral Yi's statuei (?)...lots of photo ops.

Huge grounds, interesting history and stunning architecture. We did not take the guided tour, but wandered the grounds on our own, it is the oldest palace in Seoul. Expect to spend at least half a day here as this place cannot be properly seen in an hour. Insadong shopping neighborhood is about a 10 minute walk from the palace and is a must see in its own right as well.

I think the Royal Palace really is a must-see during your visit to Seoul, since this is a most spectacular building complex. I admire the wood-paintings, the structures of the roofs and the pavilions as such, since the inner decoration & the furniture has been destroyed wuring the war. The restoration of the building is done very well and it is nice to walk through the estate. The entrance ticket is not expensive - paying around 15 € for a family of 5. If you rent a hanbok you are entitled to free access. On a hot day it is quite tiresome to walk and make sure to bring some water.

This is really an incredible palace that is set right in the middle of the city. It's crazy how the palace just keeps going and going, much more than it appears from the outside. It's pretty cool to see the changing of the guard as well.

We visited this palace mainly to see the changing of the guard ceremony, but were pleasantly surprised by the beautiful architecture. It is the largest of the five (5) palaces and was built in 1395. It was destroyed by fire during the Japanese invasions in the 1500's, but rebuilt in 1867. In 1915 the Japanese returned to destroy most of the palace buildings, and built their colonial headquarters here. Many of the building and gates have been recently restored.  It was very peaceful at 9am and there were no crowds, so we were able to view the architecture at our own pace. The most impressive building was the Geunjeongjeon (Throne Hall) which had twelve pairs of stone markers outside and a huge throne to the rear of the building.  It will take approximately an hour to view the palace. The National Palace Museum is located outside the palace walls, but was closed (on Monday) when we visited. The Folk Museum is to the North East of the palace complex and admission here is free.  After viewing the palace grounds and visiting the folk museum, we got in position to view the changing of the guard ceremony which began at 10:30am. It was well choreographed, and we were able to take videos and photos of the entire ceremony. It is advised to get to the roped area as early as possible, as there was a huge crowd. The ceremony is done daily, except on Tuesday.  Admission was W3,000 for adults and W1,500 for children. It may be easily reached by taking subway line 3 to Gyeongbokgung Station, and using exit # 5.

Huge grounds and lots of walking. Beautiful architecture and preserved or rebuilt buildings. We had the advantage of our own tour guide and that made the experience ever so better as there are very little explanations for self travellers.  We learned a good understanding of Korean architecture and engineering.  Also the garden at the back is beautiful with the lily pad filled Lake... Certainly worth a visit

This is the biggest of the palaces in Seoul. Be prepared to spend 3 to 4 hours to see most of the area. They provide free tours for foreigners and locals on site so if you want to learn a bit about the history it's a great way to do so.

One of the most iconic sights in all of Korea. Tips: 1. Reach Gyeongbokgung Palace before 10am 2. Do catch the Palace Gate Opening Ceremony & the Guards Changing 3. Try out the traditional costume experience! 4. Take a lot of beautiful pictures!

We followed a private tour around the palace, which was great! Oh, and rent a Hanbok and walk around the palace - the admission is free, and heaps of people will want to take photos with you - see what it's like to be a mini celebrity for a day!

It is very accessible from our hotel since it was a few blocks away. And we were able to have a quick tour of the palace in between our business meetings. At least plan half of your day when going here. Because the palace is very wide. You will appreciate the beauty of their structures and also their garden. You will be lucky to have a photograp with gilrs wearing their traditional dress costume without a cost. And also before going inside avoid touching the palace guards because it is prohibited.

Great Stuff, do not miss the Changing of Guard Ceremony 2 timer per day ( Selected ) Another great place visit and also another building located inside the palace ( National Folk Museum of Korea ), please go in and feel the history. Huge place that must be go .....
Fantastic spectacle. Watching the guards march to and from the courtyard took me bak in time. Ladies in local dress in evidence too.

Ok, so this is a nice place to visit and is really interesting to see such history in the middle of the city. There are very many people walking around, but I never felt too crowded as the ground are really large. The buildings are all very similar (as was the theme of the other palaces we visited), same architecture, colors, etc. there were so many little rooms which had no explanation. The grounds of the palace were mostly gravel, with the exception of the building in the middle of the water, but we could not figure out how to enter it. Nice experience, but I would not spend too much time there.

One of the most beautiful palaces I have been to. The secret garden was worth the extra fee. I felt transported back into a time of princes and princesses. Vast courtyards and beautiful gardens where the royalty once escaped to find peace from the outside world. Cherry blossoms were in bloom to make this experience even more magical.

I have visited Gyeongbokgung four times in the last few years, the latest was this spring. The area is massive and I would highly recommend taking a tour if it is your first time to get the most out of the experience. The workers are very friendly and the changing of the guards is always fun to watch. Also make sure to check out the free National Folk Museum in the northeastern section of the complex.

This is a very nice palace, and I am glad I visited it, although you have to adjust your expectations if you visited similar ones in China. For example, there is no comparison with the Forbidden City! Having said so, I think you should visit it while in Seoul, and from there walk to the Bukchon Hanok Village to continue a day tour of the city.

Our hosts took us to this lovely palace when we first visited Seoul (in May 2012). We enjoyed the historic buildings, the beautiful gardens, and the changing of the guard ceremony. We also visited the National Folk Museum nearby and really enjoyed that as well. (Note: The folk museum has a good gift shop where we were able to buy some lovely gifts to take home to our family.)

Vast area. Majestic main entrance. Beautiful compound. Very good for pictures.  You can see tourists / locals wearing traditional emperor era clothing when they visited this attraction. They actually make the whole experience even better because it gives you that "feel".  Be sure to walk all the way to the end and to also go into the museum. You get to learn a lot about the Korean culture and way of life from those days (way back). Enjoy!

Three generations enjoyed the 2 hour tour of Gyeongbok Palace in sweltering heat. A group of English speaking enthusiastic teens met us as we emerged from the Metro with an offer to show us around for free, and we really appreciated their tour! Their historic stories helped us to see more than just just a collection of old beautiful buildings. At 2 PM plan to be in the big entry courtyard for the changing of the guard reenactment ceremony.

Its a palace inside a city. You see buildings surrounding the palace. You have to pay to get further in the palace but outside is good enough to take nice photos. Location is very good with a train station just beside it!

We rented hanboks from OneDay Hanbok and it was pretty affordable. This grants you free entry and you get to take nice photos in the palace grounds. Many people will wear their hanboks there as well and you can take photos together in all your pretty outfits. Do note that if it's summer, youre probably going to sweat a whole lot.

Walkable from train station. Just before the stairs up from station you can get dressed in royal robes for free, was a fun activity. You can walk through the palace leisurely in your own pace. Good architecture in display, preserved well. You see lot of young couples walking around dressed in traditional costumes, lovely. Plenty of open park space inside. The food shop sells a cold rice sweet drink (non-alcoholic) that was tasty.

Must see when in Seoul! Unfortunately it was a sunny sunny day when we visited so husband got tired of walking in the sun and stayed hiding in café. I walked around and took many nice pictures. Amazing feeling to walk around in this peaceful getaway and imagine how it used to be. You have a lovely mountain view in background and other sides surrounded by modern buildings outside the walls.. Inside walls pure pleasure and there is a café inside, and near museum. Not adjusted to walk with stroller or wheelchair from what we could see. Easy to reach by sub and taxi. Recommend it!
Join the free tour if possible. Detailed explanation. Don't miss the changing guard ceremony! It's a nice watch. Enjoyed the walk overall
This is a very big place, we spent 3-4 hours there and it was a lovely long walk. If you're wearing hanbok (Korean outfits), you can just go to ticket office and get the tickets for free.

It's beautiful palace, nice garden, we have learned lots of history. It has been took by China before. They had build the dragon inside to believe that China never got the Korea before. It's beautiful garden, lake and surrounding. It's totally the center, it's not far away from the Mydeong distric by train 15 mins.

Went to Korea for a Rotary International Convention in 2016. Took an extension tour after and this palace was included on the tour. Fascinating place. The water you see in the cover picture would freeze in the winter and the locals used to ice skate on it!

These grounds have over 50 buildings, but you only get detail of about 10-12 during this tour, which is more than enough. It took about 70min to see the buildings we did. Lots of detail and interesting history.

First of all, this place should be called 'Gyeongbokgung' not 'Gyeongbokgung Palace'. 'gung' means palace in Korea.  I think that Gyeongbokgung is must-see place if someone never had an experience to visit. It's a full package of Korean traditional culture. The palace is beautifully designed and technically built. If you can borrow audio service device, try one. You won't regret it. It's much more interesting when you know the background. Its admission fee is reasonable like KRW 3000(= USD $2), but it's free if you wear Korean traditional custom. There are many rental shop near the palace. Don't miss it. There are few shade to hide from sun outside. If it's hot outside, visit this place some other time.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a must go in Seoul. It's one of the main palace. The grounds are beautifully kept and the buildings are characteristic. Try to join the guided tour and spend time appreciating the settings, history and culture of Korean.

I would recommend entering at the front gate during the changing of the guards. I can't remember exact time it happens. But was a great experience to see the whole ceremony. Once inside, there is so much to see. So be prepared to walk a lot and take lots of pictures. Really beautiful palace.

The palace complex is huge, with a myriad of buildings and acres of grounds to explore.  Firstly don't make the rookie mistake we did - visiting on a Tuesday, when the palace is closed! On returning on Wednesday we were pleasantly surprised to be told that entry on that day was free (not sure that this applies to every Wednesday). In fact, anyone wearing traditional dress gains free entry, but tickets are not expensive at 3000krwon per person over 18, with a small discount for children and teenagers.  This is a restoration / reconstruction project on a massive scale, which is being done sensitively and artistically. Photo opportunities abound, particularly changing the guard and the traditional tea ceremony and, of course, the people (mostly very pretty young ladies) wearing traditional Hanok dress, who are only too happy to pose.  There is a sparsity of shade, so do take this slowly in the heat. There are cafes and toilets around, but a few bottles of water per person is a must as the heat and humidity can become overwhelming.  Allow two to three hours and do try to make your way to the back of the complex, where there are ornamental lakes with pagoda.

OK, where to start. Allow min half day or more. Come bright and early for the changing of the guards ceremony. Bring plenty of food and water, don't forget to charge your camera and good shoes. Not much refreshments available on the premises so come prepared. If you want to wear a hanbok dress, there are plenty of shops where you can hire them for 1.5hrs - 2 hrs outside the palace. I believe the prices start on 15000 KWR for 1.5hrs. It's a great opportunity to take your pictures in this wonderful setting and "IN style" throughout the complex. Definitely worth a visit is also the Folklore Museum with its wonderful restorations of Korean past. The Korean Folklore village's reconstruction is very illustrative and worth a visit for every foreigner. The museum is within a complex and the entry is free. If you need to wind down, there is a small garden towards the north of the complext where you can e.g. let the kids to let some steam out. It's very tranquil there and with offers lovely views. Free 1hr long guided tours are offered on the hour at the entrance. We left the palace by one of the side entrances and enjoyed a well deserved meal in a small restaurant in Bukchon. Great day out.

I had literally just been to the Forbidden City in Beijing so this did feel a bit small. It's beautiful and worth visiting along with the Folk Museum which is on the same sight. From here you can also walk to nearby Buk Chon village. If you combine all these activities then I'd rate this five star. If you're keen on trying traditional Korean cultural dress you can hire costumes near to the palace - then wear your costume and get free entry. You'll also get lots of tourists asking to have photos with you.

If you are a big fan of Korean dramas (especially if you've watched "Rooftop Prince") you might come and visit this gigantic palace! Come to the place earlier in the morning or around 2p.m. then you might be able to watch the soldiers changing their duty. If you are luck, you might get to see some performance through out the day! Remember, Tuesday is closed and the admission fee is $3000 won/person.

We visited without a tour guide. I would recommend getting one to help explain what you are seeing. Get ready to do some walking. The grounds are mainly covered with course sand. The National Palace Museum is nearby withing the grounds and a good place to cool off on a hot humid day and get a drink. Beautifully restored structures are well worth the time.
Th building is beautiful and has a lot of history - not very much liked by the Japanese because of the way they treated the koreans in the past.
Amazing place, the architecture, granduer, history. English is on each explanation board. Enjoyed myself, i am a History buff.

One of the major attraction in Seoul. Probably not as big as China's Gu Gong Palace but since you're in seoul, why not. Most impressive is probably at the front as you enter from the main Gate. As you walk further in, palace gets smaller and more smaller living quarters and they are all look similar. Entry fee is very reasonable ($3,000 WON) and it's pretty easy to get to via subway station. Overall it was a good experience to see the real thing compare to korean drama on TV. :)

The site, the palace structures and the gardens were beautiful. However, I would say there wasn't much to see. Most of the palace housings were locked and those that were open had few or no exhibits within. Going free and easy without a guide will not give you much insight into the Korean traditions or palace life.  However, if you wear a hanbok to the palace, you will be granted free entry. There is a hanbok rental a few minutes walk from the train station. If the weather permits, wearing a hanbok would be a really good idea as you can be assured that your pictures will turn out fabulous. There is no need to feel embarassed as well as many visitors do that :)

Nice palace, lots to walk around, very nice gardens, easy to reach, and very nice to see young Koreans there visiting on their weekend and wearing their beautiful traditional cloths. Recommended to visit.

A very nice place for people who are interested in the history of Koreas monarchy. The place offers beautiful temples and quite a bit of beautiful nature, in form of secret garden for example. All in all a place to visit when you want to learn a little bit of Koreas history
They are not really set up for tourism just yet, but if you are visiting South Korea, make the effort to visit ALL the cultural sites; you will be gob-struck at the history. Just stunning!

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a beautiful palace with lots of history and is sure not a place to miss. It must be on top of your things to do while in Seoul. Be especially mindful of when the ceremony of the changing of the guard occurs as it is a sight to see. It is easy to find and take some walking shoes as there will be a lot of walking.

Went to palace and viewed a lot the museums as not bad it's inside the palace there is a lot to see things to do the changing of the guards and people wearing traditional close people from all over come to See one of the many palaces In Korea it's a sight to see

a must see in seoul. walk thru the huge complex and imagine life as the emperor. the locals get in free if they wear the traditional korean wear so we, as tourists, get to see young men/women inside the palace, enhancing the authentic experience.

This is the bigger of the 2 imperial palaces. Personally, I like the other one. Go see this one just because that's what you do; just like one visits the Statue of Liberty in nyc because that's what you do when you are in nyc. Just a bunch of buildings that very much resemble Chinese palaces. One cannot go in the building, just stand outside and look in through the openings. They do try to make up for it by having re enactments and "changing of the guard" type ceremony.

Booked a free Seoul walking tour for this palace. There were a lot of people over the weekend. However the palace is beautiful. The tour enhanced the palace experience adding much depth to the visual experience of this place. Although this palace was restored it doesn't diminish its importance to Korea and how crucial it has been to the existence of this nation.  The changing of guard ceremony is something not to be missed. It provides an experiential bridge to its glorious past and is one of the highlights of this palace visit.
Gyeongbokgung Palace was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty. The architectural principles of ancient Korea were incorporated into the tradition and appearance of the Joseon royal court.

We joined a free English guided tour of the Gyeonbokgung palace and enjoyed learning about the history of Korea as well as lovely views of the palace. At the end we also had access to the museum and we took the time to look at the exhibits as well.

I had visited the Palace when I lived in Seoul nearly 20 years ago and the opportunity to return was worth the wait. Numerous and ongoing restorations have been taking place since 1990, the latest having been completed in 2010. The serene beauty of the Palace is in start contrast to the surroundings of bustling Seoul. A breathtaking experience.

There are a few palaces, we decided to just see 1 and chose this one. Easy to walk to from myeongdong, 3000 entrance fee per person and you can join a free tour in English (as at the info office) it's also nice to see the changing of the guard. If you don;t want to take a tour pick up a map at the info office just after the entrance and follow it to visit all the main buildings, we were there for a couple of hours - take a break for coffee in the library (i think it was building number 9 on the map). I think it is worth a visit. We went on a Thursday at 12:00 and it was not at all crowded.
Lovely scenery. It is very well kept, entrance fee is low, free for elderly. I really enjoyed the walk, relaxing and beautiful. The museum was very interesting too.

Our visit to the palace was perfect. There was an event (Royal Culture Festival) being held that time and we were able to see and experience the re-enactment of the Royal Feast of 1892. Locals dressed up in traditional outfits complete with props. The event lasted for about an hour, it includes a Korean, English, and Chinese narrative of the event. A very colorful and lively place, it's a must-see!

This is a great palace to visit for site seeing and photo taking. However, the day I went with family, was Korea Culture Day and it was overcrowded with locals and tourists. Also, without a guided english tour guide, we were quite lost in the palace. I prefer the Changdeokgung Palace over Gyeongbokgung Palace.

Went there on a weekend and it was extremely crowded. A lot of your groups all around.  But it is still worth visiting to have a look and feel of KoreA's history. A few locals (I assume) wear their traditional clothing to walk around which made our visit a little more fun when we spot them.  Managed to catch the guard changing ceremony and they are really very professional considering that these people are doing it to 'showcase' the history and not the 'real guards' from the past.

Second time to see the palace. Absolutely love it. I don't know much about Korean history but it is still well worth the visit. Admission is cheap. Very picturesque. Not grand and awe inspiring like Beijing's forbidden city but certainly more picturesque. Museum within the grounds worth a look as well.

We came to Seoul from Japan so have seen plenty of shrines/temples, especially around Kyoto.  I have to admit the palaces in Seoul aren't as wow in comparison. Additionally I thought Changdeokgung Palace was actually better to visit as it was considerably less crowded and looks remarkable the same as Gyeongbokgung except smaller.

We were approached by a free English speaking guide group at the train station who offered to take us through the palace and the grounds, we were hesitant at first but went ahead and found it very helpful and informative.  The palace and private buildings of the royal family and officials were amazing and the palace grounds are massive, definitely a must see if ever in Seoul. Make sure you go on a clear day so you can get the best view of the palace.

I wasn't expecting much because I had been there before on a tour package (too rushed). But this time I went free&easy with friends and had time to explore the palace grounds. There was such a beautiful calm as I took in the sights of the palace architecture, the trees, ponds, mountains...that my heart was moved. I will recommend a leisurely pace to explore the place, then walk to tosokchon for some good ginseng chicken soup.

After visiting Japan, we visited koreas main attraction. We were met by rude staff at the ticketing box as well as upon entry (not surprised after experience with the locals there). You payabout $3 usd to get in and you are unable to actually enter the palace, you can only see from the outside. The other surrounds are mainly restored buildings that were equally as unimpressive. The grounds are all rubble upon entry so expect your shoes to get dirty. Overrated!

Be sure to catch the changing of the guards. I was there during the weekend so lots of people and school children. Buildings are beautiful to look at and some parts are so tranquil. I was lucky to catch the tail end of the cherry blossoms.
Loved this palace especially as we timed it for the very colourful changing of the guard at 10.am . If over 65 bring your passport for free entry
Really nice architecture and color. It's interesting to see this ancient building with the backdrop of modern Seoul. Cool visit.

This is my first time visiting Seoul, and most of friends and relatives told me the Gyeongbokgung Palace is super tiny and simple, comparing to Chinese or Japanese ones, and not worth a visit. We visited it anyway, and it's totally worth it.  PROs: It's easy access from the subway station "Gyeongbokgung," about 5-10 minutes walk. We joined a free English tour, and I highly recommended. (The English tour is offered at 11:00, 13:30, and 15:30.)Yes, the palace is small, comparing to even an ancient Chinese nobleman's house, but it is still a beautiful palace full of Korean history and culture for the visitors to learn. The tour guide spoke good English and was very informative about the traditions, architecture, and the history of the palace and the royal families. There is a beautiful garden at the back of the palace with a small pond.  CONS: It could get quite noisy and crowded with lots of tourists and students on field trips.
Was an enjoyable experience. Changing of the guard is a must see. Enjoyable gardens, water, palace, and great views. Close enough to everything like N Seoul Tower. Well worth it to go.

I went at the start of April where the Sakura flowers were in full bloom,it was absolutely beautiful in the palace filled with ancient architecture and plenty of flowers around,just that it is pretty packed with tourists,do search for the change of guard duties timings to go,that's when it gets abit more interesting,they have little tours to explain to you about the palace,if you are not interested,that's okay,just walk around ,feel like royalty and take in the pretty views.another side note,if you wear the traditional hanbok in,u get free entrance and great pictures,you can rent it at nearby stores,the last I have heard,it was 15k won for four hours rental,pretty much a good deal.have fun!
Its not too far to reach this place from N Seoul tower.. We can find a an ancient culture of korea right here. I recommend you to visit this place by local guide to tell you more about this place..
beautiful architect.. beautiful location.. it has it all. make sure to get pictures clicked in their traditional attire

Also known as Palace of Shinning Happiness, the largest palace of the five grand palaces built by the Joseon Dynasty.  Please remember, palaces closed on every Tuesday. Not free admission.  A must stop: Heungnyemun Compound - witness the 15 minute long Changing of the Royal Guard ceremony  Gyeonghoeru pavilion - visitors can dress up in a traditional gatekeeper’s uniform or in royal court attire and take photographs in front of Gyeonghoeru (free but be there early to get your Q number)  Geunjeongjeon Hall - The throne hall, important state functions once held here  Hyangwonji Pond - looking over the Hyangwonjeong Pavilion  The National Folk Museum of Korea - admission free if you purchased Gyeongbokgung Palace ticket (keep the ticket to show the ticket officer)  Gwanghwamun - a short changing guard ceremony held here too.
A national pride for the South Koreans. For me just a miniature version of the Chinese palaces. So in Seoul a must visit.

Beautiful palace grounds , lots of interesting spots. You need to allow yourself more time at this place as it is huge. There is a cafe and souvenir shop inside. Also check out the museum there. Definitely worth a visit.

This is a great historical site. One can easily spend a whole day here. Things to notice. Make sure to pack food and drinks as there is no food stand available here. There is only a small snack bar that ONLY offers coffee and a few child drinks.

Vast palace with many buildings. Just when you think you've seen it all you find more. The ceremonial changing of the guard is worth seeing too. It was about 10am.  Fantastic place to wander around and see some beautiful buildings and cherry blossom.  The national folk museum of Korea is next door and worth a visit.

If you are in Seoul, that's the Nr. 1 not to be missed part of the city. Fanastic experience, felt myself in the ancient time. Perfect if you are on business trip and just have a few hours till your transfer to the airport. Main entrance is recommended to use for entry - but for exit, it is much more better to use the side one which takes you to the Bukchon Hanok Village which has been a traditional residential area for 600 years. Full of traditional and modern small houses, cafes, shops, unforgettable epxerience walking on the small streets of it!
This is a large complex with many buildings and interesting history. It's centrally located and a definite must see site for Korean culture and history

I went there a week ago. It was a large palace complex, reachable by metro station, just follow the brown line and exit at gyeongbokgung station. there were 3 guards at the gate and you can take selfie with them, although they have stiff faces. the admission ticket is quite cheap about 3,000 won or US$ 0.23. The palace complex is not as large as Forbidden city but the architecture is superb. the throne room is quite impressive, but i notice that some of the walls and ceiling just recently painted. overall its a must do whne you visit seoul. the sejong statue at the sejonh square is located in front of the gyeongbokgung gate.
3 bucks to walk around this amazing place for a couple hours. Had a great time. Highly recommended. Museum was nice.
It is a gorgeous area to escape the hustle and bustle of the city. A small oasis in the middle of Seoul. Don't visit the city without stopping here.

On select days out of the year, the Gyeongbok Palace (Gyeongbokgung) in Seoul, South Korea opens its doors for night-time tours. Tickets are limited, but I was lucky to snag a ticket in March 2016, to experience the nocturnal event.  The ticket itself was cheap (just 3,000 Korean Won, or $2.50 USD), and the experience was really outstanding. I'd highly recommend it if you ever get a chance to go, especially if you can bring a loved one with you. The experience is really quite romantic.

I had lived in Korea for 6 months before I finally saw Gyeongbokgung Palace. I took my family - including my 4 year old sister - here and everyone loved it! Plenty of space for kids to run around, and there is even a children's museum and a small playground on the northern edge of the palace. The place just keeps going and going and it's all so beautiful. Time your visit so you can see the ceremony in front of the gate-it's very colorful and mesmerizing, something that even little kids will love.

Of the four major Palaces in Seoul, I think this was my favourite. To a certain extent, they are look the same - the architectural styles, roof lines, colours and materials are all pretty similar to the eyes of a westerner like me. They're pretty, but pretty similar. Two of them have spectacular changing of the guards ceremonies - not to be missed if you can time it - this Palace, Gyeongbokgung ("gung" means palace anyway), and Deoksugung. So by visiting this Palace. you'll see Palace guards and maybe the changing thereof. It is big - with water bodies, lots of out buildings, and pretty vistas. There's clean free toilets, benches to sit on, and a café serving coffee (take -out as you walk around the grounds or sit down) and sweets. Young Koreans (mainly girls but some young men too), can get into Palaces for free if in traditional costume, and there are outlets which hire these costumes (but not shoes - they all seem to be wearing trainers!). So the Palace was full of them, on a fine sunny Sunday afternoon, all taking their selfies. And they are happy to have their pictures taking by or with foreign tourists. Sometimes the gaggle of girls in their pretty dresses couldn't get away from the queues of tourists lining up to have their photos taken with them in front of the Palace buildings. Gyeongbokgung had the most to offer in terms of beautiful views and the changing of the guards.
Ancient Korean architecture representing the countries formal dynastic periods preserved to show off the wonderful Korean culture.

At only $3,000 Korean Won approximately $2.80 you can't beat the price. It also includes admission to the museum on premise. The restoration of the buildings is exquisite. You can feel the skill that many artisans used in creating such a lovely palace. It is large and can easily last all day, so come early.

Firstly this isn't as huge as Beijing's Forbidden City which was my initial worry. Try your best to get a guided tour and listen to the history of this place and its past occupants. Also try to catch the changing of the guards show and take photos with the guys in traditional uniform and halberds. This palace is also a short walk to Bukchon village area and Insadong.
I thought the palace won't be that big. But the truth is it tremendously big. Two hour won't be enough to look around read the information and take photos.

If you don't have a tour simply Wikipedia this palace and you can find brief explanations on each part of the palace. The museum near the north side was very interesting and put together well.  This is definitely a must place to go if your visiting for the first time.  Only about $3000 Won per adult. No student discounts.
As we only had one day off in Seoul it was not easy to choose the best attraction to visit. But this palace was a good choice. I learnt a lot about Korean history and enjoyed beautiful architecture.
It was good to see the palace. We would recommend this if you are into architecture and history. We enjoyed it.

This place is looks like small version of China Forbidden City, Which is a lot of Chinese touch inside. If you want to walk all around the palace it will take around 1-2 hours. And I recomend you to visit around 10.00; 13.00 and 15.00 since they have guard changing ceremony. The ticket fare is KRW 3000 to enter only the Palace and they have offer bundle ticket with the museum.

There are free English tours during the morning and afternoon which are very informative and very well explained. I highly recommend going on them.  It is a lovely day out. The palace in spring is noisy lovely due to the flowers but it is equally as interesting in winter.

I went there first thing in the morning and to my surprise, was a tour in Japanese. So, I joined them, although I had no clue what the guide was talking about. But a couple of Japanese tourists, after realizing I speak no Japanese, they were so nice and translated me lots of things the guide was telling them. Plus, I had a nice brochure with English text that was very useful. Lots of things to see there. From beautiful old buildings and amazing decorations to beautiful landscaped and spacious gardens. Highly recommended.

My husband and I braved the cold over the weekend to take an hour tour (in English!), and we are so glad we did! Our guide was knowledgeable, and it was exceedingly helpful to have the sites pointed out and the history and significance explained.

Seoul has 5 palaces. This is the biggest and most important one, so if you want to see a Palace then this is the one to visit. Its pretty large with lots of beautiful buildings. I don't know what more to say about this place..  We did pop into the adjacent Folk Museum which is included in the ticket price. This had some interesting things and worth an hour of your time.  We bought some street food outside on the road after leaving the folk Museum. One type was like a round bread that is hollow in the center and the others were small round cakes with a jam inside. Both really tasty and cheap. This may have been the highlight of the Palace visit.

Large territorial palace grounds with many gates to enter. I enjoyed walking around, though, I did not have enough time to see it all as it it huge. For that reason, I would recommend having around 3-4 hours designated for the palace and its ground. The palace consists of many courts, pavilions, bridges, gardens and walkways. It also houses the National Folk Museum and the National Palace Museum of Korea which I would recommend to visit as well.This Palace is very historical as it is main palace of the Joseon Dynasty. As the grounds are large, it requires a lot of walking; however there are benches and cafes around. It is wheelchair accessible.

This palace is a must during any visit to Seoul. Friendly staff and very informative signboards help you navigate your way around the beautiful grounds.  Make sure you exit out the back gate and take a look at the presidential residence.

I have an opportunity to visit this place on my trip to south korea. This place is so amazing! As a fan of some korean dramas like Jang Geum and Ju Mong, I really enjoyed the place. Like ive been in some history book or something. Admission is free during lunar new year, so i expected it to be full of tourists.

While it is possible to roam through the grounds on your own, I would suggest joining one of their free tour if possible to get the most out of the visit.  Timing of the tours can be found at English website royalpalace.go.kr/html/eng/guide  Maybe because this palace is pretty accessible, it is crowded with tour groups and visitors even though it is not a UNESCO site. So between Changdeokgung & Gyeongbokgung, I actually prefer Changdeokgung though Gyeongbokgung is more majestic for those structures which are completed (our tour guide says that it is only about 30% restored after being damaged during war times)  You can get a combined ticket for 10,000won to visit 5 of Seoul's major cultural sites (Jongmyo, Changdeokgung, Gyeongbokgung, Gyeonghuigung, Deoksugung) which is more economical. Just remember to ask for it when you make your purchase at the ticket booth or the attendant will just dish out the single standard ticket. Alternatively, if you happen to be in Seoul during the last week of the month, you can gain entry to all cultural sites for free on Wed as the last Wed of each month is designated as their cultural day.
this palace located in the heart of Seoul,try to visit this Palace in the morning to avoid crowd. total time required to go around the complex will be around 45 minutes
Its worth a visit to see the well preserved historic palace and to hear about its history. great wall painting on the ceilings.
The palace grounds were very expansive and maintained really well. You would need at least half a day to cover everything. We visited during winter so it wasn't too crowded.

This is the biggest palace in South Korea, if you really wanna explore everything and learn its history you could take up to half a day. I was lucky to be able to witness the guard changing process while also exploring the beauty of this palace. Going there in Winter also allowed me to slowly explore it without having to worry about the heat. If you're into history and culture, this place is for you

Gyeongbokgung is a huge place, and has a ton of buildings across it. The ones that can be seen into have gorgeous floors and some have authentic furniture to show how the residents lived. I just wish you could go into more of them, because there's only a handful you can even look into, so for the most part, you're just walking around inside the huge maze of buildings. When the flowers bloom, it's absolutely beautiful though. We have been several times and it never gets old.

As my wife likes history and has been watching some Korean dramas relating to this period in time, we had to come and visit when we visited Korea. We watched the changing of the guards and spent an afternoon looking around. It was okay, pity you can't actually go inside the buildings (which are empty). It would be nice to visit here in the summer months.

First time to Seoul and first time to their Gyeongbokgung place to let me have a better understanding about their Korea culture. This palace was a huge place, how the lifestyle of being a royal family. If you have not been Seoul before, visiting the palace is quite a good experience besides shopping. You can spend at least 2 hours or more there. To see their engraved geomancy rooftops, warehouses to store their stuff, traditional dances and their culture.
nice to spend 2hrs walking around. Do plan to time your visit along with the change of guards. it's on the hour. There's also free trying of guard costumes.
The palace is beautiful, try to see the guard change it is really impressive and beautiful, colors everywhere.
There is a shop outside palace to rent Korean clothes for an hour to take pictures in palace which is worth and fun with great memories.

This was my second visit and it still takes my breath away,truly beautiful.There is a wonderful museum on the grounds and it is worth making sure to see the guard changing ceremony which occurs at 10am 1pm and 3pm. Closed on Tuesdays and entrance fee is only W3000 and museum is free,allow plenty of time as we were there most of the day as it's so big. Subway to Gyeongbok station Line 3 Exit 5 which takes you right outside.If you only visit one palace this should be the one.

So glad we were able to see this amazing palace in the center of Seoul with its fascinating history and beauty. Free English guided tour provided at different times of the day that last about an hour (last one was at 1430 the day we went) and covers the important points/areas in the palace. Go prepared to do some walking - large palace grounds - and early to avoid the afternoon crowds too!!!

We were visiting rainy day. It is beautiful and i really like palace's small lake and boat. Also palace ´s buildings are like a korean drama. It is so interesting. Myengdong street and king's (i don't remember king's name )square are very closer from here.

My second visit to Gyeongbokgung palace in Dec 2015. I was initially planning to visit Changdeokgung to see the secret garden but missed the guided tour for 2 days. Hence I took my friend to Gyeongbokgung - since it's the first palace built. Magnificient as ever and that again explains why I love korea. A mix of traditional within a modern city with lots of history and rich culture in it. This visit to Gyeongbokgung really got me so interested that I found myself reading up on the palaces, history till present day, traditions and culture about the charming city! ( It's the first time I got so interested in history).

We got lucky and visited on a Saturday when there were volunteer tour guides available (and they spoke English). It was amazing! We learned so much while we were there and the palace itself, even though it had to be reconstructed (that is a very sad part of their history) is absolutely stunning! It is amazing they were able to build such a place.

This palace is the most famous in Seoul. One is really after not how the palaces look like but the fantastic ceremonies and shows which come with the palace. There are schedules for the changing of the guards and sword exhibitions in the morning and afternoon. Check their website for the exact time. We came in at 2pm and was just in time for the ceremony. Full costumes, parade of colors, and the use of rituals depict a lot of authenticity and appreciation for Korea's colorful culture. This is a really must-visit for history buffs, families, Korea drama afficionados, and those who are interested in Korea's interesting culture.

A nice palace, and also the change of guard duty are interesting. Also, you can try on to be the guard duty by trying their uniform! It's cool! But wearing the uniform in cold weather made me shivers so much. The palace is huge and has nice interior and exterior for photo taking.

The Palace is big and takes some time to walk around. While it is popular the really isn't a great deal to look at. An audio guide is available to hire or you can pay to dress up in traditional clothing. Pictures are available for free with the Sentry's standing at the front gate

I've been spoilt. Having lived and travelled in China for a few years, I have been fortunate enough to see a range of magnificent and quirky palaces and temples. This one is interesting enough, but not to the same degree (sorry, S. Korea). It has all been nicely restored and there is some interesting architecture but it appears to be a collection of similar buildings in a big dirt courtyard. Perhaps it was the time of year or because we didn't take a guide, but most of the buildings were shut and the open ones had little inside. No nice lakes, gardens, peculiar buildings or shrines and we felt we'd seen enough after about thirty minutes. HOWEVER, we were then trapped inside by the changing of the guard. The front of the Palace is guarded and the costumes are amazing. If you are that way inclined, you can get selfies standing right next to them. The changing involves many more soldiers than just the seven out front, all led by a traditional band that includes someone blowing a conch shell. Explanations are in English too so you can follow what it going on. One of the highlights of my trip.  Note that it was free on the day I visited but I'm not sure why. Ticket booths were closed.
Big and beautiful palace. Would be good to participate in the guided tours which would make your visit more meaningful

if you like traditional architecture and photography,this is the place for it. make sure you are wearing good walking shoes and bring some water with you and take your time. you can either follow a tour or go on your own.

Came there as it's a tourist attraction. Although it's quite small, it's possible to know more about Korean culture. Anyway, it's a good place to take some photos for your vacation. In addition, you can get free entrance if you wear the Han-bok when visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace.

Came to watch the Changing Of The Guards Ceremony but was quite disappointed at how boring it was, considering the hype and other reviews. Felt cheated that I queued and bought the entrance tickets when so many others simply walked in without showing theirs due to how crowded it was. Beautiful place rich in history but not that great an experience.

Don't miss the guard changing ceremony at 11am, 2pm and 4pm.  Take pictures with the guards at the main gate.  It is also easily accessed via mrt line 3 to Gyeongbokgung Exit 5.  And enjoy the palace.

This was a great place to visit but I was expecting just a bit more. Maybe more luxury or Artistry than other places I've been. Don't get me wrong, this place is great to admire. I was banking is spending at least 3 hours and I was done by 1 1/2 and that's included the change of guards. Bring your comfortable shoes and don't worry about the collection of dirt and dust

A beautiful serene and tranquil place to get away from the city though surrounded by buildings. The place is decorated with a beautiful past of the Joseon Era and superb place for phototaking. Don't forget to watch the guards changing ceremony at 1pm at the main square.  Conveniently located near a subway station. There are other museums nearby if you have of plenty time to walk around.

Easily accessible by subway at Gyeongbokgung station. Grand palace and huge area to walk around. You can go to the National museum next to it and there's a cafe next to the museum for you to fill your stomach.

The Royal Palace is a must see when in Seoul but give yourself plenty of time because there's a lot to see. Upon arrival, don't be discouraged if there are a lot of people out front. Once inside, you won't notice them because the Palace sits on a sizable amount of land. It's also incredibly quiet inside, which was amazing because there is much traffic and noise right outside. There a many buildings to see when inside the gate and try to see the pavilion in the moat off to the left. This is a beautiful area. Make sure you look up while looking inside the buildings as well and outside the buildings. There are many detailed carvings and paintings all around. The grounds are beautifully manicured as well and very clean. We didn't receive a map when we arrived so you may want to get some info off the internet before you go. I believe there are several hundred buildings to see. There is a gift shop and museum. There are also live soldiers posing out front as statues.
It's my third visit and this place never fail to impress me. I was here during Spring, Summer, Autumn. Avoid the main stretches as it will be filled with tourist crowd.

Interesting tradition displayed. You must know the specific time of the guard exchange ceremony. Otherwise, you will have to wait for a long time. Visiting the palace is considered incomplete without seeing the unique ceremony. A good thing is that the announcements made are in 3 languages - korean, japanese and english language. Don't forget to bring your sunglasses...

Gyeongbokgung is an excellent place to visit not because it is the oldest, grandest, prettiest or historically most relevant. It is an excellent visit because you are allowed to roam around to explore the palace without many "keep out", "do not enter" signs. You can see how the whole palace is put together by looking at it from different angles. You must also make sure to book your guided tour to the Secret Garden. We were there during the Fall and the color of the leaves brought out the best of the garden. If you have time to read a little about the Korean history, it will definitely add to the experience.

Well, there is really nothing much to rave about in this palace. Maybe because I have been to other asian palaces and therefore have high expectation. Though I must say that the free tour guide provided at the information centre is very good. It gives an insight to the palace and gives understanding to some of the building structures, such as chimney towers that are not noticeable. Heating under the building provided via tunnels.  To its defence, I supposed because the palace was burnt down during the early Japanese/Korean war, much of the original details in the palace was missing. There is not much grandeur that you would expect from a royal palace.  It is still a good place to visit to understand the historical way of life of the monarch during that time.  Check out the free tour time table to ensure that you do not wait too long.

we went there with my husband during summer time.i wouldnt recommend going there summer time as it is super hot,dry and humid. You'll be walking so much. I love seeing the palace and walk around but i wish they had more stuff inside the big palace for us to see and we could go inside. But this place is a must! Just go one time.

Our First tour of Korea is the visit of the Gyeongbokgung Palace. This historic palace was once the home of the Kings has several small palaces scattered in a large area and secured by high fortresses. Our Tour Specialist, Kris, of This is KOREA, told us that the main palace was destroyed by fire and was rebuilt to its original grandeur. The interiors made of big planks of hard wood of the main palace is very simple but the roofs have very intricate carvings and paintings. I'm fascinated with the in-house heating system located beneath the palace floors. They burn wood to create fire that will provide the heat. Don't miss also the Queen's garden located at the back of the Queen's quarters.  The palace is located with a picturesque landscape. There's a mountain at the back and the moat around one of its palaces add to its beauty.  If you're lucky (just like us) you can witness the exchange of guards ceremony held during the specific time of the day. It was almost lunchtime when we saw this ceremony. You can take pictures with the guards after the ceremony.  Near the palace is the presidential mansion of Korea. Also called the "Blue house" because of the color of its roof. You are just permitted to a certain area where you can take pictures. The mansion is highly guarded.  The Palace has enough space for parking small vehicles. However, I saw Tourist Buses parked outside along the side street. There's also money changer inside the premises beside the Ticket station.

It is autumn season when i visited, lot of beautiful leaf and plant.. breath taking garden and building.  Tips: It will be free entry if you are wearing Hanbok. So dont be shy, try to wear Hanbok and visit this place. it will be a lot more interesting.

I think 95% tourists visiting Korea will go to this place! The palace is very beautiful and it's really close to another attractions such as Gwanghwamun Square, Insadong, Bukchon Hanok Village etc.  Make sure you check the ceremony schedule for royal guard changing in front of this palace, it's really exciting to see tho.

I love this place . Tuesday are off so better come other day . Entry fee is 3000 KRW. Amazing palace I like the environment here surround by tree and u can see the magpie and squirrel. U can rent the hanbok there and take pic .

So much fun, what a great piece of history! Do the guided tour to learn more about the culture and how Korea became. There is also a area where you can dress up as a guard right when you walk in on the left... Must do!! Find the falic garden.... Great place for pictures!
+ easily reachable by subway within 1-2 minutes walk + even though there were lots of tourists bus loads of them, it felt quite uncrowded inside the palace due to it being huge

This is one of the most famous palace in Seoul that played important roles during the era of the Korean royalty.  There are so many activities to be done here. One can enjoy the stroll along the well cared and manicured gardens or appreciate the history and beautiful Korean architecture. There is also a children and folk museum that displays exhibits relating to the Korean traditional folk culture. My husband and I visited during the autumn season and the whole complex looked stunningly beautiful. There were also not that many people when we visited during the weekdays and slightly later in the afternoon.  Do not miss the colourful guards changing ceremony prior to entering the complex. You can check the palace's website on the processions timetable. There are also English guided tours conducted daily which are worth joining. You can enquire about these tours when buying the entrance ticket.  Overall, this place is a must visit for anyone who visits Seoul and I recommend it for everyone.

This palace was huge and amazing. The buildings had such intricate detail to them. I have never seen anything like this before. [This was my first and only trip to Korea, and Asia for that matter, as well.] The palace was built in the year 1395, and apparently was fully restored in 2010. You will not believe how intricate the details are on the walls and ceilings - it rivals anything I have seen anywhere. If you go to Seoul, this palace is a must-see.

Viewed the change of guard ceremony twice. Many peole wear Hanbok in the palace. They are very friendly & allow tourist to take photo with them. After the entrance, at the left entrance, there is free guard dress service for tourist to try on. 4 types of garment to choose from.

The changing of the guard ceremony is three times per day and about 15 minutes long. It is an impressive sight of color and music. We enjoyed it. To enter the second gate to the palace you need to buy tickets. It is beautiful and quite large. It could easily take an hour + to see it all.
Recommended for visiting ,know more about Korean culture and history ,spend times to walk and see each beautiful building

I've been to this palace twice--first time was in October 2012 and the second time was just recently, October 2015. I didn't enter the palace ground anymore on my second trip because it's going to be the same. I just wanted to see the "Changing of the Guards Ceremony" again. This time, at around 4PM. The ceremony I witness before was the one in the morning--the complete/full version. Although the one in the afternoon was much shorter, it didn't really take away from the experience of seeing these men all dressed up in their soldier/warrior attires. If you've been to the inner palace once, you don't really have to spend money on another ticket to see it again. It still the same palace building and, architecturally, looks very similar to the other palaces. Most definitely a good place to visit for first-timers in Seoul. A good stop the second time around; however, I don't see myself going back here on my third trip to Korea. I'm giving it a 4 out of 5,nonetheless. Still a very beautiful place to view.

Spent couple of hours here, enjoys the historical architecture, ambience, dressing up with old costume.  I have a good times here and liking the army performance. Ensure you comes with a pair of walking shoe, sitting under the trees, enjoys the fall season.

A vast area with a lot of very pretty but closed buildings. There were some you could look into, but most of the buildings seemed like empty shells. Very beautiful buildings though. Not many places to get something to eat, and not really much to see. Maybe a guided tour would have been more informative, but I really loathe guided tours - so that's not an option for me. It didn't feel like totally wasted time, but I will never visit again.

We visit 3 palace in seoul during our trip, I found this palace is worth to go. Direction: stop at Gyeongbokgung station (line 3) exit 5 Admission 9am-7pm weekend; 9am-6pm weekday (closed on TUESDAY) Ticket: KRW3,000 for adult or combine ticket KRW10,000 (Free entry for those who wear Korean costume) There are free guided tour in English/ Chinese/ Korean/ Japanese you can check the time on their website Free Gate Guard costume experience starting from: 10.15am, 11:10am, 13.15pm, 14.10pm, 15.10pm, 16.10pm Guard changing Ceremony at 11am, I am not sure about other timing. (if you don't feel like going into the palace you can still watch the guard changing ceremony that is free at the main gate before the ticketing counter. Try to go earlier before it get too crowded.
Palace is gorgeous to see at night. Beautiful reflection of the palace from the lagoon that will give double effect which is very picturesque.

The palace grounds is on a large piece of land in the middle of town but the buildings were rather disappointing. They looked to be refurbished in a rather rough way although the main building had an interesting ceiling and roof. We were there during the changing of the guards which was an interesting cultural experience but it does not enough to make a visit there worth while unless you really have spare time on your hands.

This spot is accessible to public by Metro and it is at the Seoul city center where major activities take place just opposite of it. Oct 9 street performance and may art activities make the surrounding lively. One who visit Seoul the first time should not miss this tourist spot.

If you had to pick just one palace to visit in Seoul this should be it. It is a wonderful place with grand sweeping views. At night (while closed) the front is lit up wonderfully and perfect for night photography. If you're going during the day do so by noon and avoid the weekends if possible because of the crowds.

This is a fantastic place to visit on your first trip to Korea. You can see how royalty lived in ancient times. This is one of the most well known palaces along with Changdeokgung. There were 5 royal palaces during the Joseon Dynasty. There is a museum that shares the same location as the palace. It would be best to visit the museum first. When you exit the museum you can purchase a ticket booklet that will allow you to go to all 5 of the royal palaces and a nearby shrine.

It fell a bit short of my expectation - unlike the palaces in Europe where you get to see the interior. But if you appreciate architecture, this palace won't fail you! The gardens of this palace was gorgeous though, maybe except for the Empress' garden. It looked unkempt. Free guided tours in few foreign languages are available throughout the day which is great. Our guide was cute :)

I like Gyeongbokgung Palace the best of all the palaces in Seoul because it has the most history and it is the original (and first) palace of the Joeson Dynasty. There is a very good free English Tour that starts @ 11am every day (subject to change) (and 2 more in the afternoon) and I like that it is where the King lived most of the time and met with his military and civilian leaders there.

Living 5mn away, I went multiple times there, during snowy winter, chilly fall, warm summer and beautiful spring. Year around, the place is nice. Don't expect to see anything similar to Forbidden city in Beijing, this is different, this is much smaller, but very enjoyable. Do the Folks Museum, this is very under rated, and quite nice to learn about Korea. I enjoyed nearby the Queen Palace very much, best in WINTER to see the white landscape. Enjoy your time there and forget/relax from the busy city around.

This is one of five grand palaces in Seoul. You have the option to purchase the tickets by the entrance. There's a package that cost 10,000 won for admission to all 5 palaces including the secret garden. If you generally want to visit Gyeongbokgung, then it cost 3,000 won for an adult ticket. This place is open everyday from 9am to 5/6pm depending on the time of year and closed on Tuesdays. You can join a tour and follow a tour guide through the palace or you can simply roam freely.

There is a small fee to get into the palace complex but it's well worth the money. We were lucky enough to arrive just before the changing of the guard. It is worth watching this exercise, both very colourful (Costumes and flags) and very precise, which takes around 5 minutes to complete. It attracts the crowds every hour on the hour. From the large esplanade, you proceed to a collection of buildings, one after the other. it was the largest of Seoul's palaces and built during the Joseon dynasty and where their history unfolded over the next 500 years. Allow a couple of hours for your visit.

Gyeongbokgung is a must-see for a visit to Seoul. The palace is rather large and has a couple of museums as well as an area for children. Depending on your level of interest and how long you spend walking around, you can easily spend an afternoon there.

My parents and i visited this Palace on the last Wednesday of the month and entrance fee was waived! We also enjoyed free traditional music performance at the National Palace Museum (which was also free entrance) and had an interesting time at the Folk Museum within the compound (which was also free entrance). You can easily spend a whole afternoon here if you enjoy photography of outdoor architecture and korean culture, or if the weather is good. I visited in September when the weather was turning from hot (with occasional rain) to cool (with sunny days) so if I could visit again I would prefer to go in early Oct. The palace is more beautiful than Deoksugung and much larger as well. You should also visit Jongmyo Shrine for a complete historical learning experience. Wear comfortable shoes (some of the paths are uneven and difficult to walk on); advisable to visit the toilet when you come across one as you are exploring the palace grounds, because toilets are not very conveniently located (only 2, one at the entrance and one at the exit, as well as at the 2 co-located museums which have cleaner toilets). You may wish to bring along a bottle of drinking water; if you need a refill, there are free drinking water fountains within the compound near the toilets and even in resting areas.

The palace is renovated and offers a glimpse into the life of the royal family in the old days. The guard ceremony is spectacular and worth the while. For those who purchase tickets you get free guided tours at 11, 13:30 and 3pm in english. Highly recommended

The palace is set on beautiful grounds, with some water and old trees. The colors of the buildings are beautiful, and you're able to peek inside the buildings. There is a map that tells you about each place.

We had a nice visit here - got there just in time for the ceremonial changing of the guards which was fun to see. (Happens a few times a day out front). The palace area is quite similar to the Forbidden Palace, lots of hallow structures with open space - wear comfy shoes! At the back there's a very nice garden. In addition, your ticket gets you free entry to the Folk Museum, so hold on to your ticket!
Nice museum and beautiful palace grounds! Reminiscent of the forbidden city in Beijing. Good for a half day adventure!
A very nice place! It reminds of the Forbidden City in Beijing, China. But this place has a much more beautiful architecture.

This place is expansive! I had imagined it would be one or two buildings, but it's practically a town in an of itself. And inside each room, the details are incredible!  The entrance is off of a downtown hub, so it's quite a transformation going from tall, modern city buildings to ancient walls, bricks, and tile. The part that I found most interesting was that looking north you only saw history with a mountain as your backdrop. You could get lost in time, but if you turned around it was so striking to see the juxtaposition of towering urban buildings just beyond ancient wall.
If you are in Seoul its a must see. I suggest doing a palace tour day which might include a stop in Insadong. Take the subway as its cheap and easy to navigate.

Gyeongbokgung is a huge palace in the city center. I took subway there. Unfortunately I cannot wait for the guided tour so I just look around, quite not fun and uninformed. There is a photo spot for you who want to wear palace guide uniform. They also have the Guard Ceremony several times a day which is, for me, is the highlight of this place.  Suggestion: make sure you come in the right time for guided tour (depends on your language) because it makes huge difference for your visit. Moreover, the museum next to the palace is said to be good but unfortunately I did not have the chance to visit.

The Gyeongbok Palace show us the respect and importance Koreans gave to their King, the palace had lots of space combined in elegance and grandure, the rite of Changing the Guards was equally a sight to see.. It showed us the discipline instilled among Koreans.. But i really admired the spacious grounds that made up for the beauty of the place..

Have been twice to Gyeongbokgung Palace. It's a very cheap attraction--around 3 dollars. You can easily spend over an hour exploring the palace and the grounds. Definitely a great place for photos.  It's very refreshing to spend time here away from the hustle and bustle of Seoul. This is easily on my "must do" list for Seoul every time I come to the city.

The Palace (in the centre of Seoul) is huge and worth doing with a guide, if you can. It's a replica, as previous versions were destroyed during the many invasions. As previously mentioned by another reviewer, the rooms within each building can become repetitive without the benefit of a guide explaining the rooms and how they were used.  Still, it's worth seeing checking out some of the rooms and then watching the changing of the guards in traditional Korean attire. There's a museum deep inside the grounds of the Palace, which offer a great reprieve from the humidity on a hot day.
Definitely a must see attraction if you've travelled once in Seoul. Combines the harmony of nature and the orientalist architecture. Take your time to walk around. Sit down at the pond and relax.
The palace is big but nothing much to see except building structure. Almost nothing to see in the palace as well. Perhaps a guide tag along to explain the historical would be better

The grounds are well maintained and extensive, you can spend hours walking around and exploring. As we were walking through, we were trying to read up on the history and find out a little more. My impressions were just that everything was very bare...although it was a nice quiet walk, I found it to be rather uninteresting as a palace. Walls and nothing more but nice scenery.

Suitable for many types of visitors as it is park-like and relaxing as well as chock full of amazing history. It's a beautiful place that's romantic for couples or interesting for families. Well worth the visit! Anyone going for the first time would benefit by reading up on it's history first.

Although its a 1990s reconstruction of the 14th century palace, it is well worth a visit. Very reminiscent of the Forbidden City in Beijing in a better location with mountain views and surrounding parks
It's very neat; however, since the Korean War destroyed nearly all the original buildings, it didn't have the same effects.
Just back in time after they completed the hardwork on the main gate. This place was offering me romantic and gigantic at the same time. If you are big fan of Korean series, don't miss this spot.

We went there free of charge since there's a summer promotion in July 2015. My first time being in a huge magnificent palace and there were so much to explore! We were there by 1pm and witnessed the royal changing of guard! The guards could stand so still despite the hot weather! We were deeply impressed!  The palace is huge and it requires good stamina and great deal of time if you wanna explore the whole site. Furthermore, it's connected to the National Folks Museum, and there are also small little houses for you to enter! Try to enter all of them, some even provide free photo taking services and you will be surprised! Haha.

Very similar to the Forbidden City in Beijing in terms of structure and designs. Grand and resplendent. Saw the changing of guards in the morning and beating of the traditional Korean gong. I could have spent a day exploring the grounds. National Folk Museum is located here as well.
The palace was so clean and the staff are very polite. They have museum as well before we walk ard the whole palace i suggest you can visit the museum.

This palace is so big and aroubd every corner there is a hidden teasure. It's rich in history and stunning to strole through.  Little kids can run around but will get bored after a little while since there isn't much that will facinate their brains.  If you visit keep in mind that Jul/Aug is Monsoon time so it might start raining whilst you're there. Take an umbrella incase and go enjoy.  You could also have a small picnic there i think.
If you've been to other grand imperial palaces, like the Versailles or the Beijing Imperial Palace, this was ok. It was well kept, but it could use more contextual explanations.
Magnificent palace. Very large grounds. Was free in july when I visited. There is a folk palace on the grounds as well. Good way to learn of Korean history.

I was so lucky to have the opportunity to visit this palace and also able to joint tour guide inside the palace ground. I was also lucky to watched the Royal Guards Exchanging at 14:00. Of course this take place 3 times per day.  I would recommend anyone that visiting Seoul to come here and take this guided tour. It was a really interesting and educational to learn about the Korean history.

The biggest and historically most important of the many palaces in Seoul. Watch a changing of the gate guards and take a guided tour -- much to see and appreciate. Prepare to cringe a few times if you're Japanese -- the history includes some serious unpleasantness, like the occasion when Japan sent 60 guys to assassinate the empress. But you'll still enjoy the tour -- I think! The guides are friendly and knowledgeable. As an American with almost no knowledge of the Korean language, I certainly liked the tour.

More than the palace itself, the grounds were beautiful. Since we visited in spring, there were flowers everywhere and the weather was perfect. I would also recommend taking the free tour to get an idea of the palace's history. There is a lot of walking, so make sure to wear comfortable shoes.

We went with two kids 9&10 and we limited our visit to 1-2 hours max. Really warm (36*C) and afterwards we went to the DDP that was designed by Zaha Hadid. Great contrast to see traditional vs modern. But of course we love modern art...

Our family traveled to Seoul in June, 2015, at the height of the MERS scare, so our experience is pretty atypical. That said, even if you didn't have this magnificent palace basically all to yourself, it would definitely be worth a visit. After a quick look around the museum, we headed outside with our tour guide to explore the compound. The buildings are all gorgeous, with colorful painted details and airy, furnished rooms to peek into. The buildings are so large and imposing, it really evokes a sense of grandeur. This is a great place to get a historical perspective on the hyper-modern city of Seoul.

Gyeongbokgung is the largest royal palace in Seoul and was the main royal palace for much of the Joseon (Choson) dynasty; that alone may or may not be enough to appeal to potential visitors. There are two really great things to see here, though: the changing of the guard with Joseon dynasty-costumed guards and the National Palace Museum, which is really worth an hour or two, filled as it is with interesting and beautiful art and artifacts. After you see Gyeongbokgung, make sure to see Toksegung (Daeksogung or Duksoo) Palace & the Secret Garden (Piwon) of Changdaekgung Palace as well. But just outside Gyeongbokgung's gate, Gwanghwamun, is a huge plaza with statues of King Sejong and Admiral Yi Sunshin, Korea's two greatest heroes; there's a small museum focusing on them located below the plaza that's worth an hour. And you should go back to Gyeongbokgung at sunset see Gwanghwamun at dusk, when it is at its most beguiling and photogenic.
Palaces are always worth visiting, try to plan your visit around the ceremonies that are held to experience the culture.
Liked how they keep it looking the way it look over 500 years ago. I liked the English tour, very informative.

Real great palace that you cannot miss even short time visit in Seoul. Be sure to go on the Secret Garden tour as well. Also walk autside and around this Palace because you can find small but nice places where to eat with really nice local people.
Its a very big place.. if you walk alone make sure you have your guide book or internet,so you will know what is the palace all about and you will not lost.. ^^

The Palace had massive grounds. There were many different parts to the different aspects of palatial life in ancient Korea. Be prepared to walk. There was a beautiful pavilion, Gyeonghoru Pavilion, located in the middle of a large pond. Although I couldn't go onto the floating pavilion, I believe you can apply online to go onto the floating pavilion. The palace officials had a list of names who were permitted to enter. At the entrance of the palace, I was fortunate to catch the reenactment of the changing of the palace guards. So, check the performance times so you can make it there. There are also English speaking guides available free of charge to guide you around the palace.
Could not get in, all closed up with construction inside. Disappointing although some good traditional Korean restaurants around the area.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is absolutely huge, but after a while all of the buildings start to look very similar. The first part of the palace is the most interesting: Gwanghwamun Gate, the large paved courtyards and the throne room are truly impressive. After the first 3 or 4 buildings I got bored very quickly and found that the rest of the palace consisted of nothing more than empty rooms in near identical buildings. The only features of interest past the initial cluster of buildings were the small lake with the garden island (behind the main palace) and the large pavilion for official entertaining on a large lake to the west of the main section of palace buildings. A lack of clear signage made it hard to find where to go next. I spent an hour and a half wandering around until I lost interest but you could easily spend much more time here if you wanted to. I was a bit disappointed that the palace is largely just empty buildings you can only see from the outside - it is hard to appreciate the rich history of Korea when one buildings looks the same as the one you just saw. Changdeokgung Palace had more character and was much prettier. The Changing of the Guard happens regularly and is a good show, but not as interesting as the one at Deoksugung Palace.

Great palace. We bought the booklet ticket to see all 5 palaces plus the Secret Garden & Jomyo Shrine. But after the 3 palace, it just feels like we're revisiting the same place over n over.  Secret garden is great but requires a lot of walking (slopes & steps) continuously for about 1hr. Very beautiful though.  If you don't have a lot of time (or stamina), just pick 2 palaces and maybe the Secret Garden. Check schedules for change of guards.  I recommend Gyeongbokgung & Changdeokgung plus Secret Garden.

Gyeongbokgung is SUCH an incredible piece of history-and I totally reccommend taking the English audio tour. I've been there twice now and I really feel that I find something new to admire each time. Plus, the museums on the grounds are very interesting in and of themselves.  Highly recommend bringing some snacks and water and just walking around the grounds in the back of the palace, especially during spring/summer. The view of the mountain is nice and it's very relaxing/peaceful.

I've been to this palace in all the seasons and like all the palaces in Korea it is best in Autumn. It's easy to get lost here but it doesn't feel like you're in the centre of a city at all. It is so peaceful.
Not to be missed. If you are in Seoul, try coming here even if you only have a few hours to spare. Beautiful buildings and architecture..

The whole area where the palace stands is wide and the buildings are quite similar in architecture and design. It is just awesomely handsome. If you have a guide tell her/him not to hurry the tour. You 'll miss some places inside the perimeter if you're in a hurry. Take your time and take pictures as many as you can. Tour guides have the habit of telling the history of the place longer than it may seems eating away your time for an extensive tour of the place. Instead of listening, go your own way for taking photos as fast as your group can but be sure to follow your eyes where your group goes. There's the possibility that you'll loose them because there are plenty of tourists. The history of the place can be gathered from the internet so, don't bother listening to your guide the history of the place. Go, take pictures. It's your only chance.
