My husband and I had a 12 hour overlay at the ICN airport. This is a great way to spend the time and get a chance to visit Seoul. We signed up for the free 5 hour city tour. Apparently this is the most popular tour of all, I made reservation online (ICN airport website) 6 weeks prior departure and I was lucky I got the last 2 seats. The tour includes a simple Korean lunch which is $10 (mandatory). Transportation/bus is free, courtesy of Korean government. Tour guide is a volunteer and very funny. Nice to walk around the city after a 15 hour flight. The only thing I dislike is the lunch. We were given 2 options: bibimbap (rice) or beef stew. We ordered 1 each, the stew was too sweet to eat for me. Tour was great. I will try other tours next time.
The gardens inside the palace are really beautiful, reminded me a little bit the forbidden city because of the roofs. But it truly reflects korean philosophy of respecting an caring nature.

Overall, the Palace is well-maintained. It's easy to navigate your way around, even without a map since there are signs leading you where to go next. There are also descriptions of each structure, in English, Chinese, and Japanese, so it's easy to get to know the place even without a tour guide. However, there are also maps available at the information area, but for a fee. Don't forget to wear your rubber shoes since you will be doing a lot of walking. Before you start touring the palace grounds, be sure to catch the changing of the guards ceremony just outside the main palace grounds. Ticket area is also nearby. If you love nature photography, this is a must-go place in Korea, especially in spring and autumn since there are a variety of flowers in the area. Plus, don't forget to have your photos taken in the iconic parts of the compound (the structure with a pond, the rows of traditional houses or building around, the entrance) since these are commonly shown in Korean dramas :). You haven't gone to Korea without those photos! After your tour around the palace, you may also want to visit the museum behind it and also have your photos taken with the other statues/structures outside (i.e. the zodiac characters, the tikis (guards of villages), and traditional houses of commoners). I will never get tired of visiting this palace!

Such great history that sits here. I have heard wonderful stories of this place, and being able to put those stories to comparison of what I have seen is so beautiful. Enjoyed the walk around the culture.

The palace is decent & all the block looks similar.The palaces are devoid of many rich artwork found normally in palaces( at least not visible form visitors gallery).  Only some chambers have beautiful designs & color work. The layout is same for all palaces in Seoul.  Be prepared to walk a lot

Gyeongbokgung is a great place, right in the centre of Seoul where you can spent hours walking, exploring and taking pictures. Make sure you have comfortable shoes. Don't miss the change of guards. Guards are dressed in traditional attire and the ceremony is narrated - it is a great experience. If you arrive right before the ceremony you will see the training beforehand. This is a must when is Seoul.

Gyeongbokgung is a great place, right in the centre of Seoul, to spend an hour or so wandering around and taking photos. The halls, pavilions and courtyards are really pretty, and it's an interesting juxtaposition between them and the modern city that surrounds them.

This was our first stop on a sight-seeing tour. We arrived just as the changing of the palace guards was taking place which was very nice to see. This is a ceremonial event that takes place twice per day. Guards are dressed in traditional attire and the ceremony is narrated through a public address system in different languages including English. This is an expansive property and a lot of walking should be expected (including some stairs which are fairly steep). Palace dates back to the 13th century and has been well maintained (and restored numerous times over the decades). The palace includes 4 gates and a number of buildings. At the far end of the palace, (and across the street) is the "Blue House" which is the current residence and government buildings of the Republic of Korea. This is an excellent attraction and would recommend visit by tour guide for explanation of the history of the palace. This attraction can be done over several hours or a full day could be spent here. Definitely a must see in South Korea.
Glorious palace surrounded by a mirroring lake in a beautiful garden, this is what it is. Everything is so pristinely clean. Would not mind going back.
Easy to get around and the actors and costumes were a nice surprise addition to our visit. (These are not the original buildings but cool to imagine them as if they were.)

look to your left and you see a skyline of skyscrapers, look to your right and you see an ancient palace. We were luck to catch the changing of guards ceremony at 10am. We also had a free walking tour (you can book this on Korea tourism sites) he showed us all the different parts to the palace and explained the history to us for nearly 3 hours! We walked from our hotel in City Hall to the Palace and it took 20mins- very centrally located. Also theres a station right outside if you need it

If you love to visit castles , you would love it.  Very huge area to cover, hence get ready to spend 5 hours if you visit it completely. Other than structure , you may enjoy festivals there (if they are scheduled), museum is also next to it which is very well maintained.  Points to be noted : 1) Not a fun for young children 2) Have good energy to walk for long distances 3) Combo ticket is available for all palaces but if you are visiting this one only , specify while purchasing 4) Good cafes in museum 5) Do not miss traditional parade

I had a long layover at ICN, so took the train and a cab over to see the palace and surrounding neighborhood. It will take about 5 to 6 hours to do this including train time.  The first thing to understand is that this palace has been burned down (not completely) and re-built over history. Many if not most of the structures are faithful recreations of earlier versions.  The layout of the grounds is remarkably similare to the Forbidden City in Beijing if you have been there, reflecting similar culture and heirarchy.  With that pre-amble, I had a great visit and would recommend this as a worthwhile excursion. Between the palace grounds and the adjacent folk museum (which is free) I learned a great deal about Korean culture and history.  Across the street, there are two art museums and a wonderful walking neighborhood with a number of quick restaurants.

If you visit only one temple this should be it. It's part of a larger complex but this was the center of power in its day. Here you see how the royal family lived and discover the power of the King's mother. She chose the next King. We were there to see a procession of the King and his entourage walk down the path from the temple to the gate. The King approaches in a sedan chair carried by eight husky men and then alights and strolls with the group for a short distance. Everyone is in red. This event is held periodically, so visitors should check with a guard to find the schedule.
I come here with my parents in winter season have a lot of tours.here have good view for take a photo with couples and family.
Try to go at 1pm to experience the changing of the gate warriors - so colourful! Took an English speaking tour which was very informative.
Interesting, but arrive early to avoid the heat. The changing of guards was interesting. However the sand at the forecourts was uncomfortable when the wind blows.

it reminded me of the Forbidden city in Beijing, just amazing, big in scale. it takes some work walking around it, lots of stairs. to really understand the history some additional background might be helpful, a tour book, or printed content from internet research. the gardens around it were nice too, especially since we visited in the Spring, during the flower bloom season.
Must watch the changing of Guard...superb experience...10 am everyday except Tuesday...close on Tuesday...walk the huge ground and do not forget the garden around the perimeter....
One of the places worth a visit if you want to know the history of Korea. The tour guide is very good in speaking English.
The way the emperors lives was pretty cool. Take the walking tour, it is very helpful. Lots of stairs and walking but it is very beautiful, The guards do not move, just like the UK.

If there is one place that you can visit when in a long over in Seoul... Its Gyeongbokgung Palace. My daughter and I took the ARES train to Seoul Station and just follow the train map we downloaded to find the next train going to the palace. When we were there, its was a free entrance day too. Not much tourist so we got to take awesome pics.  We did not stay too long, but was able to see the Changing of the Guard and went inside for some pics. No complains, its enough to feel the Korean soul.  Don't miss going to Gyeongbokgung Palace!
we got to watch the changing of the guard at 10 am . there are some rooms you can enter, which is unusual in these palaces. also, there are some gardens and a beautiful pond area.
Kinda waste of time and money for visit.. probably i duno how to appreciate wide "empty" palace. Simply nothing for me to see. Less than 10mins, am outta of this place

If you would want to see only one Palace. This is the place to go. I have seen the Changdeokgung Palace but still prefer this one. Bigger and more attractions. Only downside side is the Chinese hordes of tourist who push and shove and it is hard to get a photo with the family with a lot of photo bombs. Very easy to get to by subway.

My friends and I were lucky that we arrived just when the changing of guards ceremony was about to start. The ceremony was impressive, though it was pretty funny how the guards had way too obvious fake beards. The free tour was really good, very informative.
The buildings are superb .The gardens are outstanding, and although there are lots of tourists there is plenty of areas of peace and quiet to be able to contemplate the serenity of the Palace

We visited this palace as part of a group tour. The changing of the guard occurs daily at 10:00, 13:00; and 15:00 (**double check these times before going as they may change!!) Huge crowd at the 10:00 ceremony but still able to see and enjoy the program. There are numerous "outbuildings" scattered throughout the grounds. You can probably cover everything in an hour. Also, the "Folk Museum" is co-located with the palace and admission was included with admission to the palace grounds. The museum has a decent sized collection and is definitely worth seeing. It can be accessed once inside the palace complex (as well as from the street). Plan for a good 2.5 hours total to see both the palace and the museum; 3 hours if you want to soak in the museum exhibits.
The palace was worth for visit to understand the emperor history of Seoul. The building design reflected the emperor living style.

For the equivalent of US$3.00, you get to view a restored palace district that is spectacular. From palaces, to summer houses to lakes and gardens - this is a refreshing change from the modernity of Seoul. I had taken 100 photos before I knew it. It is an absolute must on any Seoul itinerary!
Just a walking distance from King Sejong and General Yi Sun Shin statue. The place are massive and really enjoyed the ambiance. Just 3000 for the entrance fee and it worth to visit.

First time visiting a palace. Amazing view, the palace was so big. We checked out the king and queen staying area. There is one house that was like in the middle of a small pond or something. Many people there, talk to some local school kids also on school trip. The scenery is super nice as theres mountains and trees (I went during the spring time). Great Visit, will be visiting again. Got many photos and videos there. Youtube - lolsia2000

If you visit Seoul, you can see the King's palace, Gyeongbokgung Palace. It is located near the city governent centers. Walk slowly just like a queen(or a King) and feel the calm beauty. See the beautiful curve lines of the Korean traditional roof tiles.  If you should visit just one place because of the short time, just go and see the real unique beauty of the old treasure.

Everyone who goes to Korea must visit Gyeongbokgung Palace. It's right at the heart of Seoul and the current city government centers are still around the area.  The 3 pillar entrance and animal statues that "guard" the Palace offer a starting tease at what lies inside. Once you enter the complex, the intricate ancient walls, wide spaces, and stone paths all draw your attention to magnificent palace buildings where the monarch of Korea used to hold office and receive guests. The best building to see is the banquet hall. It lies on top of a pristine pond and with mountains at the backdrop. Truly spectacular!  Make sure to bring comfortable shoes since you will definitely want to walk around. A camera is a must to capture the beauty of the place. It can get sunny so bring sunblock/moisturiser if you want. My family went there on a weekend it was really full of people. Try to visit on a weekday perhaps so there are less tourists. We spent around 1 hour going around but it wasn't enough for me. I think you should spend at least 1 hour and 30 mins - 2 hours or so. Other attractions are close to the area such as the National Museum, Blue House, and the Cheonggyecheon stream.

This place is so amazing for a history lovers, tourists or even if you want to spend some time close to the nature. The scenery is great! The organization inside and outside the palace is good! I really enjoyed. They even have some self-managed mini-cars (looked alike the ones for golf) for the elderly people. That is so cool! So everyone can go to the place and have fun!

It is huge and wonderful. The best time to visit is in May, because they open it at night, and there will be Royal Court Festival, so you feel like really thrown back into Joseon dynasty. And the have free tours in English, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, so you better check the time. Otherwise it would be difficult to know which building was what. If you missed the tour, I suggest to buy the handbook for only $0,5.
Visited the palace twice over the past few years. it's the largest of all the palaces in Korea, and where some well-known dramas get their locations filmed.  Nice walk with a pretty view.
Was a fun place to walk around and look at the housing that the king lived in . There is a museum on site as well that is worth walking thru!

My first visit was after 3.00 pm. I entered from Sinmumun Gate and couldn't cover the whole area of the palace. By 5.00 pm, I only managed to visit the northern part of the palace and the National Folk Museum ( a very quick walk inside, and grabbed a cup of latte at the cafe).  It's just amazing that beautiful palaces like Gyeongbok and Changdeok are right the middle of this huge metropolitan city. Upon entering, I felt like I was walking into a different era.  My next visit was in the morning a few days after my first visit, and I entered from Gwanghamun gate. The majestic palace, the gates, the whole area, the landscape were just breathtaking.The garden, the architecture of the pavillions - you'll have to go there yourself to see how beautiful the palace and its area are. I hope you will find a time to visit this place if you plan to go to Seoul and be ready to fall in love with this palace.
A "must do" while in Seoul. If you're really into history you could easily spend hours here, but you can also breeze right through and snap a couple pictures. Very affordable.
Nothing much interesting to view at palace. too touristy place. don't really feel the culture when stepped inside.

(Pro-tip ~ all cultural attractions are free every last Wednesday of the month in Korea!). I highly recommend spending a good hour or two here, getting lost in the beautiful, intricate architecture and painted eaves. There are some informative plaques scattered about, and the 500 won guidebook is very interesting.
Nice clean grounds and some beautiful buildings. Palace is well kept. Very busy, long queue to get tickets.
Were lucky and got a personal guidance by a guide trainee. Made us stay much longer then planned but well worth the extra time. Had to skip the Secret garden but will come back soon.
So many school kids were there when we went so it was packed along with the tourists. Very interesting but remember that this is not the original which burned down.

We were lucky to be there to see the changing of the Guard although I believe it happens hourly. Beautifully kept, a really stunning place with gardens teeming with cherry blossoms in springtime . An absolute delight!
Time your visit to coincide with the changing of the guard, Korean style and the English language guided tour. At the end went to Korean folklore museum which is at the far end and was a nice ending.

You can easily spend a few hours roaming through the buildings. Very impressive, especially the maze of walls, courts and small buildings in the northern part of the complex. Free entrance to National Folk Museum is a bonus. And all for a mere 3$.

Make sure that you arrive before 10.00 am. ( 1.00 pm / 3.00 pm ). That's when the Changing of the Guards takes place. Try to bag a vantage point near the big drum ( near the ticket kiosks ). This is where the guards will enter the palace grounds. This is no ordinary changing of the guards. It is a vista in Korean traditional military uniform, traditional instruments, traditional weapons and flags. Plus the whole pomp and ceremony of it all. Note: You can watch the arrival of the relieving guards or you can position yourself in front of Gwunghwamun to witness the end of the ceremony. Then you can wander around the inner palace, after which you can opt for a free guided tour ( English ) at 11.00 am. After this, if you still have the energy, the Palace Museum is just next door and definitely worth a visit. ( Look out for the royal placenta jars !)

Really not much to see, except the changing of the guards ceremony. Should have English explanation of each area and building of the palace. The ground was dry and not much shrubs or flowers. I have been here a few times and it is about the same. A disappointment.
This palace has so many story i heard. This is not huge mega palace but you can read it what is the palace.

I guess if you are in Seoul you will almost certainly go to this famous palace complex. It is apparently the biggest and seems to be the busiest and most popular with tourists and Koreans alike. There is also a regular 'changing of the guard' ceremony, which is fun. Entrance to the enclosure is primarily from the south west or south east, although the ticket office is at the south east. Entrance is cheap (free for 65 year old or over) and an excellent English (or other language) small guide book will cost you just 500 Won. The extent of restoration testifies to the turbulent history of Korea but the extensive site and many buildings are well worth a visit and will keep keen photographers busy. Access to the National Palace Museum is at the south west and the National Folk Museum is at the north east (you get your hand stamped if you want to visit the museum and re-enter the palace). One of the 'essential' sights!

I came here just thinking to take some photos and have a look around. C'mon, what much can you see in a castle compound? Wrong. There's a lot to see here. And plus, the place is so huge and buildings are placed quite far apart, so there were lots of walking. Ended up I spent about 4 hours, barely covering the few main buildings and the garden with the lake in the middle. Lots of photospots, either the Maingate, guards, main courtyard, inner gate and the list goes on.. it just never ends. I went on a warm and bright autumn day, so it was good. All the time spent here will be outdoor, so if you're going in the winter of in the colder days of spring and autumn, then better be prepared.
This, I think, is the best and most well-known palace in Seoul. Changing of the Guard is cool here. Photo ops are awesome, to include the background of the 10,000 won bill.

The main palace in the Joseon Dynasty! Be sure to visit all places within the complex!  If you are lucky, come around 1300hrs for guard changing ceremony. It is one of the three times daily they change the guards.

We arrived rather early and could tour the palace and ground before having a free guided tour in English. Both approaches helped us to get an extensive view of that central monument in the history of (not so) ancient Korea. If you can, do not miss the changing of the guard!

We visited the palace and found ourselves walking around the place to view the many interesting architectural details and design. We spent about 75 minutes walking around until the rain pushed us onward to our next tour. Worth the visit.

We planned to join an English speaking tour (two or three are conducted during the week and note that the Palace is closed on Tuesday's) This is the only way to see the grounds, to enjoy its splendor and beauty. The tour was a quick one hour, but sufficient to give one a firm overview of the palace and history. It is the largest palace in Seoul and if you can only see one, then this is the one to see. Also adjacent to the palace is the Korean Folk Museum and there are other sites nearby. We went on a Saturday so it was crowded, but not overly so.
If you are into political and historical sites, i recommend to see this place. It will bring back how the culture was formed and shaped years ago.

Headed here on an organised tour. The palace is huge while you could happily wander through here alone although a tour guide adds so much more to the history and way the place was constructed and operates, I would recommend it.  The changing of the gate guard ceremony is at 10am, worthwhile seeing, lots of flags music and colors. The palace gets a bit crowded after this time as all the tour groups start to go through. It wasn't that crowded though.  We visited, at the end of March, the cherry blossoms were starting to come out, though will in full bloom in a week or two  Defiantly worth seeing.

This Palace was so much larger than expected. Saturdays you can see changing of the guards in traditional Korean uniforms from Joseon Dynasty Period. For cost of admission (1.50 US) you get access to Palace Museum. This is a primarily outdoor walk through of the grounds- be prepared to walk quite a bit but plenty of areas to rest. Beautiful parklike setting in center and Folk Museum close enough to visit as well (separate admission).

Definitely recommend getting the guide book and really taking your time to read about the incredible stories and history of each hall/temple. And see the changing of the guards - very cool fashion statements!

Gyeongbok Palcae is the rebuilt (circa late 1800s) palace of one of Korea's kings prior to Japan's first invasion of the country. It is large, with a variety of buildings from the homes of the queen and the crown prince, to the dwellings of lesser staff and a government work building. It isa good look at Korean history and a remembrance of the Japanese war atrocities that required the reconstruction of buildings like this throughout Korea.

If you're going to see any of the many palaces in Seoul, I would recommend this one - only because it's the biggest, most popular, easily located, and around a lot of other landmarks/monuments. Honestly, if you've seen one of the palaces, you've seen them all. Nonetheless, it's a worthwhile visit.

We had joined a free guided tour in English. All very well organised. It was a very crowded day as it was the last Wednesday of the month and entrance was free for that day. Beautiful grounds, historical and very Korean. Be on time for the changing of the guards.

A definite MUST for all Seoul travellers. Wonderful views into Korean history and mindset. Kids love it, adults love it... what's not to love? Palace area is accessible even with wheelchairs and prams so everyone is available (though there are some steps).

A lot of things to see and visit. Be prepared to do a lot of walking because the grounds are very vast. Our kids were interested in the first few buildings but after seeing the rest they were bored. We ended up letting them run around in the open fields outside to tire them out. The palace is well intact and gives you a good idea of how life was back then. Definitely recommend seeing the palace if you're visiting.
Beautiful place! Easy to get there. Have some information in English too. Impressive buildings and vivid very artistic decorations.

Due to the history with Japan, much of this does not date back to the 1300's but instead the 18/1900's. Regardless it is very cheap to tour and the grounds are beautiful/massive. Worth the 2-3 hours to do it justice. Try to catch the changing of the guards.
It was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty. Today, it is the most beautiful and grandest palace of all. Must see during visit to South Korea.

If you're a tourist visiting Seoul, the palaces are a go to attraction. I was only able to visit one palace and I was glad it was this one. The place is also next to a museum which would make it convenient for people who are interested in history. This place is huge! Their is a lot of walking involved. If you're there at the right time, you can also view a changing of the guard ceremony at the main entrance.

It's a must-go spot for tourists and that means you have to share the beautiful palace with thousands of people. It is really an astounding structure of building and the lake and trees are pretty as well.

Many palace has been greatly preserved. This palace on the other hand has been abandoned, damaged and destroyed systematically. Currently, many of the building within the palace is planned to be restored to original condition. The palace is very popular with tourist so it is quite crowded but the garden area is quiet. The palace have north and south entrance gate. North Gate also shows the current President' s building.

If you read my other reviews on the palaces in Korea, then you will know that it is a good first step if you have never visited other Asian palaces in Japan or China. If you have, you may feel disappointed because Korean palaces lacks the grandeur of their Asian neighbours. I never got the "awe" factor.

Tours in English run at set times. Definitely worth doing it as there isn't much signage and what would seem like a whole bunch of buildings would be unappreciated without the history and stories.  Not ideal destination in the rain as there's not much shelter.

Absolutely breathtaking with the presidential palace in the background of the south gate. The palace is a lot less crowded at the south gate which is quite nice. During the new year there were tons of extra activities going on within the gates with many people in traditional dress. The foliage isn't in bloom but it was not too crowded so traveling here in the wintertime definitely has its bonuses.

Fantastic palace; This place is very similar to the forbidden city in Beijing, it goes on and on, with each section opening new insights into the life of its inhabitants. Great architectural detail, and perfect place for some great photos.
Period attire along with very well preserved site signage in Korean and english, Tour guides are there to help and explain

My 3rd time visiting this famous palace. I never get tired of coming here as there are so many areas to see and explore. Be there early as by late morning, hoards of tour buses arrived and it really didn't help that the tourists who arrived in bus crowds were all talking or shouting at their loudest. If with friends, can arrange a picnic and enjoy a splendid time exploring the palace. It is especially beautiful during the spring or autumm season. totally recommended.

This is easily accessible and full of culture. During the changing of the guards and on special days it can be crowded, but at other times it is peaceful.  (I visited around 2012, but the questionnaire doesn't allow for dates from that long ago.)

I had a good time at Gyeongbokgung, but I had my camera with me and was having fun shooting flowers and birds and walking through the museums. The changing of the guards was a fun experience too, and there were some groups of younger folks playing some old traditional music as well. But I don't know that it would hold the attention of the young un's very long. the monument itself is a real short visit and the rest is walking around the grounds, so I think it just needs to be your cup of tea. It's in a good area to branch out and do other things too. Don't miss the little statues on all the corners and pedestals around the palace, I found them particularly intricate and interesting.
I loved visiting here. It's directly off the Myeongdong/Dongdaemun subway--very easy to get to. It's also very cheap to visit. I had a great time walking around the temples here.

I went alone exploring Gyeongbokgung Palace because I want to see the changing of the guards. So I went around lunchtime and waited an hour. There's not much to see unlike the other bigger palaces so I sat and read for a while. The place is rather peaceful and there was less tour groups.

If you a DiY, the palace is within walking distance from Insadong across the boulevard. The palace ground is humongus and you will need good pair of walking shoes. Though less comparable with the great palaces of Beijing, Tokyo and Osaka, nevertheless they have much to offer in terms of the nation's history.  Toilets are not abound so make you attend to your needs before wandering around. I love the ornate roofs and the well preserve timber frames but again will not be drawn into comparison with the Forbidden City of Beijing.  The other dampener you will face is this place seems to be a must visit for every tourist to Seoul. The result is this could get overcrowding including the q for the women's toilets. I did not see the changing of the guards as we were on a free transit tour but that would be somewhat colourful as with when they are filming costume/period Korean dramas.

The place is huge, but of course not China's Forbidden City's huge.  This is the place where you'll have a glimpse of what the Emperors of Korea used to lived.  Great place for photographs.  You'll find people dressed in the traditional korean outfits outside of the maingate.  Easily accessible via Subway.

I visited this Palace in late November 2014 after a day exploring Seoul at the end of a Korean business trip... Entrance fee is very cheap at KWon 3,000 (about GB£1.80) and there is plenty to see.  The imposing Southern Gate ('Gwanghwamun') is a major Seoul landmark and over the years has been destroyed and rebuilt several times. The current gate was unveiled in 2010 after a 4 year reconstruction project!! Once through the gate you enter the Front Courtyard where you purchase your Palace entry tickets and there is often some form of traditional music and dance taking place.  From the Front Courtyard you climb some steps and enter into the Palace complex where you see the huge two-tiered former throne room 'Geunjeongjeon Hall'... Look for the beautiful folding screen behind the wooden Joseon throne. From here, going North, you will see the 'Gangnyeongjeon Hall' which dates back to 1395 (reconstructed in 1995) which used to be the bed chamber of Joseon Kings.  For me though the best part of my visit was the beautiful 'Gyeonghoeru', a Pavilion built in 1412 by King Taejong as a place to host banquets and State meetings. Set in the middle of a man-made lake it was a vision of tranquillity when I was there bathed in golden Autumn late afternoon sunlight. Take a walk around the lake and head north to the top of the Palace complex where you will find another lake with a very picturesque (and photogenic, see my images) two-storied octagonal structure called the 'Parujeong' which was built in 1888 and used as a library by King Gojong.  All in all this is a Palace well worth a visit but it can get very busy... I would recommend going in the later part of the afternoon (I arrived at 15:30) when the crowds are a bit less and when the late afternoon light brings out the best of this special Seoul attraction.
10am is the time you must be there for the main event of changing of the guards, they do it every hour but 10am has the most number of guards who participates.
go with a volunteer tour guide. you will learn a bit of korean history esp on the joeson dynasty. It takes about 2 hours and the tour ends at the Blue House .

This is such a pretty place to visit while in Seoul! Do spend the time to walk around the area, snap some photos and enjoy the lovely stroll! I was lucky to be there while they had the guard changing ceremony, try to catch that if you can :) There is a small fee (about KRW 3,000) to enter.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is a must see in Seoul. You can learn a lot about the history and culture of South Korea. The architecture and artwork are superb! It is also a lot of fun to see the guards in front of the palace. It's a very photogenic place with the mountains as a backdrop.

Had our reservations when deciding whether to visit Gyengbokgung or not. Having visited the Forbidden City and having heard this was the Korean equivalent, we thought we would end up seeing pretty much the same thing. Given we did not enjoy or like the Forbidden City all that much, that was worrisome.  Luckily, despite similar styles (due to Korean history) we thoroughly enjoyed the visit to the palace. It is extremely accessible and it does not feel like you are seeing the same building or pavilion over and over again. It also did not feel particularly crowded at all and it was very easy to navigate. The grounds of the palace were also extremely nice to stroll in and it was definitely an added bonus to have the National Folk Museum adjoining to the palace. Even extra added bonus, the entrance/exit closest to the National Folk Museum is a stone throw away from the Bukchon area.  Definitely recommended and would suggest to take half a day to visit the palace itself, the grounds and the National Folk Museum.

Also liked this palace. It was a couple of subway stops from Bukchon. A guard showed me where they were putting on a play. Enjoyed the buildings and the guards dressed up in traditional clothes. There in 4/13

Impressive complex of beautiful buildings. Very busy with lots of tourists and Koreans (or especially because of?) on Christmas Day. Be sure and wait/plan for a tour in English as the tour guides are impressively informed and give you all kinds of history/cultural lessons that are unforgettable.

this palace is one of the palaces worth visiting...you can see the fine architecture in each of the pillars, colors of the palace..if you can catch the guided tour so much better to have a deeper understanding of the Palace's history...

This palace is just an empty palace. To know more about the palace, please get a tour. Otherwise, you can buy the palace brochure for 500 won. Audio guides are available as well.  Nothing much to see except for the huge area use to construct the palace, many are reconstructed back as it was damaged and of cause the guard changing ceremony for the first timers.  Nevertheless, an eye opener for first timers.  I went there during December, as the place is covered with mud and melted snow, it gets quite dirty for your shoes as well as for your legs (jeans).  Please also take note that as the roof are constructed like in the olden days, they have a down slope roof, therefore melted snow (ice) will slide and drop down, please be careful when you are touring the palace especially if you have kids.
It's not an old building, you can take some time to visit, but no need to stay for hours.

The compound area is huge but the palace itself is empty. Nothing. Few pieces of furniture. Artwork? It's not even 100 years old. I was told 90% of the buildings was demolished during Japanese occupation during 1911, it so frustrating. Nevertheless, I was awed with the Change of Guard Ceremony. I think people does not care much about history as long as they can brag about it and take many as many pics around this palace. Compared to many palaces & castles I've been, this doesn't left much impression on me.
Nice big place to learn about Korea's history. Do see the changing of guards ceremony and do consider the free guided tour provided.

We visited this beautiful palace last week (13/Dec) and it was absolutely beautiful.  As it was just starting to get very cold, we happen to see the lake freezing up.  No words can describe the beauty of this place so make it a place to visit if you are in Seoul.  The price of entry is also very very cheap.. kids are free as well... and the palace is located next to its own subway station..  So there is no reason to not visit this wonderful and beautiful palace...

You must see Gyeongbokgung when you are in Seoul. Admission fee is not much. Personally, I felt that a guide wasn't required; if you do your own basic research you'll still be able to appreciate it. You can easily spend 2-4h just walking around and admiring the palace.

I have visited here twice. It is much better in summer than in winter since in the winter, it is too cold to linger and take in the atmosphere and the historic plaques. It is rather extensive with a lot to see. You can spend a whole day there since on the grounds are the National Folk Museum and the National Palace Museum. It is also quite close to the Blue House, the residence of the President of South Korea.Down the road in front of the main entrance is the American Embassy and a long promenade where protesters gather.

The palace is really easy to get to. You could take the subway line, and there is a stop directly next to the palace. I would recommend to come early as there are many tourist groups coming to this location at the later hours.  Also, make sure to see the changing of the guards.

A vast collection of ancient Korean buildings, representing the culture of royalty in former days, with countless examples of historical architecture. Although surrounded by a very active city, once you step inside you feel transported to the way life was several hundred years ago. Much history can be learned, and at least a half day is needed to do justice to this ancient palace.
Sort of reminded me of the Forbidden City in Beijing on a smaller scale. Looks very vibrant beautiful. I understand that much of it burned at one point & had to be restored. They did a great job!

We visited this place though it was snowing. We went to the virtual images on the 2nd floor and had a virtual inter action with the present president of Korea. We shook hands and took pictures that were e mailed to us. Nice concept!

Like - Grandness, the authenticity of the place, the awesome ceremonial spectacle,free costumes (of ancient guards), coffee shop inside the palace square, iconic red pillars, and great architecture. For me, you've never really seen it, unless you've been here.  Dislikes - too many tourists at times! Good thing, the place is huge so you could veer away as far as possible! The whole place closes by 5-6pm though. Not a perfect spot for sunsets, twilight, and all... Not too many signposts to indicate what you're looking at (guess I need to find a tour guide for this part, LOL).

Palace tour is one of the tour recommended in seoul as there is few of them , I have visit all I can say that they are all look same for me same style and design not much different , you can access them all by subway if you have free tour and if you use city tour then this palace is one of bus stop plan to visit at midday as frequently at midday they have some activity to watch there from that palace u can wake to the city center seoul station hope you enjoy the trip and this place there is entrance fees

We see the changing of the guards from the inside and had a tour here, we joined the english tour and the tour guide is good. Im a fan of some koreanovelas and i was able to learn the simple detail and their meaning.

Gyeongbokgung Palace Built in 1394 as the main palace of the Joseon Dynasty(1392-1910)by its founder King Taejo, it is the most comprehensive and grandest of the five palace of the period. Gyeongbokgung, the oldest palace of the Joseon Dynasty, is located at the northern end of Seojong-ro Street. On its grounds stands the National Folk Museum of Korea, where visitors can brower the unique cultural and historical traits of Korea and the lifestyle of bygone days.  Cheongwadae (The Blue House) This is the presidential residence of the Republic of Korea. Tours of Cheongwadae have been conducted since 1998.  National Folk Museum of Korea. As the only national museum on folklore, it displays about 4,000 items on Korea’s traditional way of life. There are three permanent exhibition halls, two special exhibition halls, a shop and a reference room.
It's gigantic. It is closed on Tuesday- so take note. Oddly, there were quite a few places closed on Tuesdays.

It seems as though the tourist guides and hotel concierge have a limited list of suggested destinations in Seoul. However, Gyeongbokgung Palace is rightfully found on everyone's list. The historical lessons are very important and you will learn a great deal by visiting this site. But if relaxing in a beautiful park is what you really want to do, this is a great place for that as well. There is also a very nice folk museum. Try to plan your visit around the changing of the guards. This is really special experience.

The palace is a fantastic place. I understand it was rebuild after the Japanese destroyed the original but it is hard to tell. It looks fairy-tale like in its setting (esp. if you look towards the mountains). In the middle of a busy city, an oasis of tranquility. There are daily performances too. You have to do a lot of walking.

The main and biggest royal palace in Seoul. It's nice, but don't expect anything spectacular. After a while you understand it's a series of similar looking courtyards and traditional palace buildings, that at least for the average tourist look similar (only differ in sizes). It's not a palace where you visit the interior of the rooms. The highlights there (for me) where: The changing of guard ceremony - the main ceremony is nice to watch once. The guards are dressed in different colors, carry different flags and weapons. They shout orders, the drum beats. But you quickly get the idea, and the ceremony is a bit long... And also there is a nice pond inside (you need to pass through several courtyards), near a building, and a picturesque view in the background. A good place to take pictures. About wheelchair accessibility: there are ramps there to enter from one courtyard to another. In some places they have stone paths at the perimeter of the yards. But I would advise to have assistance, as the middle of the yard is uneven and has stones or gravel. You can't climb to the palace buildings (steps). The stone path at the perimeter sometimes is occupied by people, sometimes you need to climb a step or the passage is narrow. So it's not easy there unless you have help.
a palace with beautiful surroundings. we went there in autumn and really enjoyed the colourful trees

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the key attraction in Seoul, its easily accessible via the seoul subway station "Chungmuro Station" and its just a 10 mins walk via the underpass. As we went there quite late around 4 PM We took the option of buying the 1 palace ticket.  And we took the chance to explore the different parts of the astounding palace, unfortunately we didn't get to see the change of guard.  As the Palace close around 6pm, if you are considering to explore the other palace as well, its advisable to get there early, as the entire compound of the palace might took abit of your time to explore.
one of the palace you can see in the compound. there is a pond in front where you can see fish. we dont know if we can see inside.. but most of the palace was for outside viewing only
Changing guards is daebak (Amazing!). I went during winter it was very cold but worth it. I didn't take any guide I suggest to just purchase the map and take your time to explore the huge palace.

The palace and the whole scenario is just beautiful. I visit it during autumn, it was a sunny day, so it was gorgeous to see the yellow and red foliage among the palace constructions. From the palace you can see a beautiful mountain full of colorful trees too. The change of guards is also a interesting thing to see.

Like the other royal palaces in Seoul, this palace is actually a palace campus. It is the premier palace for the Joseon kings. It was destroyed in 1600s by the Japanese and rebuilt in 1800s. There were around 500 buildings inside the campus at that time. But the Japanese invaded Korea once again in early 20th century and almost all the buildings were destroyed. After the WW2 some of the most important parts were once again rebuilt. Nowadays it looks quite good. If you don't have much time, you should see this palace as the representative of the 4 royal palaces in Seoul. By the way, the palace offers free guided tours in Korean, English, Japanese and Chinese a few times a day. I strongly recommend you to join one of those tours. After the visit, I recommend you a walk towards the Gwanghwamun Square.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is the most famous palace in Korea and is well worth spending an hour or two wandering around the complex.  Admission is cheap at only $3,000KW ($3) and has a few pretty buildings and traditional Hanok type houses inside.  There is a Changing of the Guard ceremony which is fun to watch for a few minutes. The children section, which has mock-ups of traditional Korean shops and houses is fun for kids and there are a few galleries if you like this sort of thing.  Definitely a fun day if you combine wandering around the Insadong area and Bukchon Hanok Village.
Wonderful place! This was truly a journey back in time. Be prepared to take 1.5 hours because the area is huge! I recommend checking out the surrounding area as well if you can still walk. ;)
English Tour:  Gyeongbokgung Palace @ 10.30 am  Secret Garden @ 11.30 am  Do buy a combo or combined ticket for 10 000 won.

The palace has been restored to some of it's former glory. The 48 - columned pavilion, Gyeonghoero, is outstanding. Do not miss the imposing Genjeongjeong with its spacious courtyard and surrounding corridors, illustrating the splendour of the dynasty. Check out the attractive lily pond, the island pavilion of Hyangwonjeon, the rock garden and the residential quarters.

We did not go inside the palace but seeing the 'Changing of the Guards' was cool. Be there by 930am to witness this ceremony. However, kindly ensure to respect their rules. You cannot have pictures taken near the guards... Just keep your distance. The palace ground is very spacious so take time to enjoy the place.  The subway leading to the side entrance of the Palace has cool artsy stuff so take time to explore. Don't forget to also stand in front of the palace and just observe the city.
You will not regret visit this place.. enjoy everything about it! Love to see the nice traditional building, and they maintain them nicely and super clean!

Relatively new for a palace. Only 200 years old. They have kept it well preserved. Easy and quick to go through. There are some features in this palace that is unique to Korea compared to other palaces in Asia.
The Palace is well worth a visit. Although the lines for the ticket booth were long, they moved fast. Tickets cost 3000 Won for one museum. There is a nice park on the right hand side of the Palace.

there are many beautiful things to see here and with the mountains in the background it makes it even better. The audio guide is worth it, it tells you many things that you might have otherwise missed. The colours are so rich and clean. If you enjoy palaces you should go. The grounds are beautiful as well with flowers and ponds everywhere.

Nice reconstruction. We went at 10am for the change of the guards as we were told that was the most spectacular. It was nice that everyone had a good spot to take photos and nice backgrounds. English speaking tour did not have enough detail though.

Very near to the Museum and Cheongwadae (The Blue House). It was rather packed for it was a public holiday. The palace was well maintained and we managed to catch the changing of the guards....a colourful event. Near to subway station.

We visit the palace during the cultural week in Seoul, so there was an interesting exhibition in the front court of the palace of virtual and augmented reality where a traditional book comes to live, it was really nice. Also the traditional dance made with little robots was really nice. As part of this cultural festival, there was at night a light and sound free show displayed in the outer wall of the palace. The palace is huge and is worth visiting to get a glimpse of the cultural heritage of Korea.

If you are interested in seeing the cultural soul in Seoul, then pay a visit to the Palace. Changing of the guard, beautiful gardens, intricate building designs and a whole lot of beauty all add for a fun visit - takes about 2 hours to see everything. It is easily accessible from the subway and there is a lot to see in the area. Also close by is the Blue House, where the Korean President resides.

This palace is the most important one in Seoul, so a must-visit! The area is vast, access is cheap (KRW 3000, just over EUR 2) and has interesting buildings and history. The buildings and the area and park are nice, but it is a bit hard to get the information. I would recommend to take a tour with a guide. The buildings have rather sober interiors. I recommend to visit the National Palace Museum which is directly beside the Gyeonbokgung palace. There you will get some more tangible and visible details of Korea's history.

This palace is huge and is very similar to the Changdeokgung palace. Although this palace does not have a secret garden like Changdeokgung, it has the change of guard ceremony, a two story feast building where the emperor entertained, and a pagoda(not accessible, but visible) in the background. Since the palace ground is vast, be prepared to spend at least 2 hours here if you want to see every inch, longer if you also want to visit the museum within. The palace is very well maintained, so well that the vibrantly painted colours robbed it of its authenticity. Because of that, I think Changdeokgung is more authentic, but the architecture is very similar. Come here for the grand palace experience, but be prepared to walk lots out in the open sun. In any case, I think it's a worthwhile experience in Seoul. :-)
The place is big but not much to see inside. Not recommend to go if the trip is short. You can just take a picture at the front door.
Allow at minimum a half-day to explore the palace. It took me a full day, including the museums. Wear comfortable shoes and expect to walk a lot! It was a great introduction to Korean history.
located in the center of seoul, just near american embassy. the palace is majestic and, unlike the other great palace in the capital, you can have the chance to admire the guard exchange. recommend

I was fortunate to visit the Palace in January, with snow on the ground and on a wonderful clear day.  Firstly, there are the guards outside, in traditional uniforms - make sure you see the 'changing of the guard'.  Then the palace itself, which has been lovingly restored (having been ford down by the Japanese when they occupied Korea). It is a lovely place just to walk around - and an incredible space within the middle of a modern city.  Go to the national museum (adjoining the Palace grounds) after - to get an excellent picture of the history and culture of South Korea.
Really beautiful place, you can take good photos and enjoy the view. It's a must see in Korea, for sure.
There is a National Folk Museum inside where you can learn about history and culture about Korea. The Palace architecture is unique.

The palace ground is really big and it is a great place for you to slow down your pace and walk around. I have been here a couple of time and no matter what season it is, it is a comfortable place. Once you get away from the bustling main entrance, the rest of the palace is very comfortable to explore on your own. The toilets are unexpectedly extremely clean.
It is one of the museums that shows Korean traditional palace. I heard that the actual palace was burnt by Japanese and it was rebuilt by Koreans.

I visited the palace with a Korean friend of mine. He told that the palace has been destroyed and resurrected many times during Japanese and North Korean attacks. Seeing the quality of the buildings inside the campus was unbelievable considering the attacks. The repair work certainly has been fantastic. The palace is a typical of Medieval age Korean Architecture. Its huge, beautiful and elegant. I clicked a lot of pictures there. There is a small museum inside, which has a very interesting display of Korean civilisation starting from pre-historic period to medieval age. A must visit if you are in Seoul.

We did Gyeongbokgung as a day trip/walk around several palace sites. We started at Deoksugung and walked up Gwanghwamun Square (currently filled with protesters which made it interesting).  I think the actual Palace at Gyeongbokgung was closed when we visited. Or maybe we simple missed something. Enjoyed the museum though.

I've been here with friends and Korean teacher for several years. That was so amazing Palace with large land and complex systems of King's Palace. You can come here by bus, underground or taxi quite advantage.

This is a popular tourist destination and it is also very central to Seoul.  A few things you need to do here.  They have parade on changing the guard once every hour so it is well worth watching.  The buildings are nice and you can take beautiful photos. One particular spot was the building situated at the north western corner. It was built to entertain guests and it is surrounded by lake and trees. Beautiful.  And also have a look at the important painting in the central building where the King administered. It is called the sun moon 5 mountains. It is directly behind the throne of the King and it has great significance as the holder of power. You can also find the painting on one of the Korean Won notes.  So a place not to be missed plus it is so central to sejongdae ro. where you can see the great Admiral Yee statue and also King Sejong statue.

I made it for a guided tour in English on time (1.30pm), so it really helped a lot. The tour took about 1hr 30mins. People with interests in architecture or photography will have a blast. You can hop into the museum next door and come back in for free with your ticket stub.  The downside is that the palace and museum are filled with tourists and screaming kids, and its quite hard to get shots that you want without people in the background.

... they all look the same. however this one has a massive scale, lots of palaces within palaces, and nice park area and museum around it. however if you've been to the palaces and temples in japan and china, the ones in seoul can't compare
This is the best of all the palaces in Korea. I strongly recommend a visit. Spend some time to explore the surroundings. You can easily walk to Insadong (another touristy spot in seoul), city hall...

Mainly just a big palace and cheap to gain entry.. A few little events going on soldiers marching about in traditional garb.. Not a bad spot to see but very little in the way of historical information that I could see.. Maybe I missed a booklet somewhere.

Expansive palace based on Chinese architecture. Not a spectacular building but some parts looked quite nice. Most buildings do look the same and even though restored you cannot go in the buildings. Limited information on the boards outside with barely any context given.  Changing of the guard takes place on the hour.  Closed on Tuesdays.  If you want to find out about the palace then get a guide, the visit Korea website has the times of tours.

The grounds are truly amazing and you can get a real feel for how life was in the past. Definitely recommend going and getting a tour if at all possible. Might be better to go in the warmer months, but was okay in the winter just dress warm. Easy enough access from the subway.
This palace was absolutely amazing, and was the most lovely sight during my trip to Japan and Korea last year. Definitely worth the trip.

The Best Palace to visit in my opinion!! I love K-Dramas and K-Movies and you know, just the feelings of walking in the same place, being there and seeing everything with my own eyes is best to discribe as breathtaking and exciting. Worth to see for yourself!

The biggest palace in Seoul. Very interesting architecture - something totally different from Europe. All the palaces in Seoul have almost the same style but never think that all the palaces there look the same. Gyeongbokgung is a palace with a multitude of small buildings that had different functions. Gyeongbokgung has the typical complex used by the king, other by the queen, but also a complex of building were the dead body of the royals were held until the burial, and other complex used to hold the tables of the dead royals for the mourning period (2 years) etc. I recommend to save an entire day for this palace because the Korean Folk Museum is within the grounds of this palace, and when you buy the ticket for Gyeongbokgung the museum is included in the price. Furthermore, I also recommend to join a guided tour, you will find more interesting things about the palace, the kings and queens, the rules and habits. However, if you enjoy more the freedom of looking around without someone calling you all the time, and want to take your time to take some good shuts, try to look for the metal panels that are in front of or near each building, in order to get some information about the use of specific building, when it was build, by orders of who and if there happened something important (at the ticket box you will not get a brochure with information about the buildings, you only get a map of the palace) Keep in mind, the ground of this palace is very extended! Also, you will walk on dusty soil, so use proper shoes. Don't use sandals or flip- flops if it is summer and you have sensitive feet. TIP: visit it on Monday because on Monday the other palaces are closed.

We visited Gyeongbokgung palace on a very hot and crowded day on Chuseok (the largest Korean national holiday, similar to thanksgiving). It was extremely busy with many tourists and Koreans alike. The size of the grounds themselves were the most impressive to me. I loved the big pond/lake and the parks around the palace. There's not much to see of the palace itself but its still a good experience. We saw the changing of the guards in their traditional colourful uniforms.

If you're in Seoul this is certainly worth a visit. It's amazing to see something so huge right in Central Seoul. I'd recommend a tour - it helps get a real appreciation for the site and it's history. Don't miss the changing of the guard - what a hoot! Some great photo opportunities here with the dramatic hills in the background.

Seems like a must go place if you happen to be in Seoul but don't get your hopes high. Most of the buildings were reconstructed only 15 years ago so don't expect to see 1000 year old ancient palaces and the reconstructed buildings were modern and artificial looking.  As we were about to leave, we just happened to catch the changing of guards ceremony, and it was pretty cool.

You really dont have to go in to see the throne. The infrastructure is the same as from the outside. Catch the guard changing ceremony at the entrance. That's good. after the ceremony, remember to stay outside so that you can get a picture with the guards. After that, head back to the main area where you can get to dress up as a guard for free! Head there early as the booth closes quite fast after the ceremony.

We went specially to see the guard change ceremony. The guard change happens at 11am, 2pm and 4pm. Quite nice to view the ceremony and quite an experience taking photos with the guards.  It is very easy to get to it. Just beside the MTR. The palace is very unlike what I had seen in Forbidden City in Beijing. It is less lavish, however, loved the huge architecture and the huge amount of space in the palace. With the mountain as backdrop, it was quite a tranquil and awesome sight to behold.  Audio guide is available. It is running via GPS, thus, once you reached a certain area of the palace compound, the audio guide will start speaking. Found it to be brilliant as in some other countries, some audio guides work on number of steps or you will have to key in a certain code for it to explain.  Good experience for the family.

Yes, its touristy and crowded (the most tourists I saw in my 10 days in seoul) but its still a beautiful place to see, if you can catch the changing of the guards it will be all the better... i think its only twice a day  Its good to take a book with you or an audio guide so you know the history behind the buildings and the sections of this complex  TICKETS - if you want to go to the other 5 main temples get the package deal for 10,000won
Take a tour in between your shopping to see this palace and it is worth going. Not as grand as the China one but somehow good to understand the Korean culture.

This place is one of my favorite memories of Korea. I first came here in winter and it was such an experience to see the frozen over lake and pavilion. Recently I returned in the spring time and found the whole feel of the palace grounds changed, with the greens of spring. I'm sure it must be beautiful to see in autumn as well, with the changing colors of the leaves.  If you enjoy experiencing history and olden-day culture, you will have good time here. I personally found that 3 hours was not enough to fully explore the extensive palace grounds and the folk museum. Sure, you can complete a walk-thru under 1 hour, but that is just like a stop-and-go kind of tour. Every palace is different and has its own story to tell. You may enjoy the palace a bit more with the help of a tour guide who is knowledgeable about the history of the palace - either the free timed tours or with a youth volunteer.  I plan to return to Gyeongbukgung again, hopefully in the winter, to experience its understated grandeur and beauty again.

The palace itself is interesting that it has a lot of influence from Chinese architectural design - the Emperors seat is much better kept than the Forbidden city - clean n tranquil for relaxing walks n picture taking- nothing much to see except the changing of guards that is very interesting to take pictures with them :-)
love the atmosphere here relaxing and traditional. museum located inside is also worth visiting. reasonable price

We visited the palace on May Day so it was quite busy but the liveliness was also welcoming. The palace is in great condition with a few rooms you can see in and is in pretty good shape. I wish there was more information throughout of the history or tours that you can sync with your cell phones so you can learn the great history that happened there. With such a technologically advanced society, I think they could do more with that but otherwise, it was great. There were a lot of rock sculptures which were wonderful for pictures!!

My second time to this attraction and it takes my breath away each time. Grounds are clean and well cared for, free torus are in a variety of languages and the changing of the guard is so much fun with the music, movement and yelling! This is also one of the few attractions in Seoul that is open on Mondays.

One of the main reasons for visiting Seoul is for its rich history, dating back centuries to the Joseon Dynasty. There are fortresses, memorials, imposing city gates from ancient times, and grand palaces scattered around the city. I have visited each of the main palaces in Seoul on multiple occasions. I enjoyed all of them, although I do have a particular predilection for Gyeongbokgung Palace.  Gyeongbokgung Palace was the largest and most important of the five grand palaces built, way back in 1395, although it has since been destroyed by Imperial Japan and then restored to something resembling its former glories. Nowadays it serves as one of Seoul’s main tourist attractions and as well as hosting the National Folk Museum of Korea inside its grounds, there are captivating ‘changing of the guard’ ceremonies held a few times each day, which is a great event to capture on video. Gyeongbokgung is located close to another of my favourite places in Seoul, namely Bukchon Hanok Village (a traditional Korean village of old). It is also located within easy walking distance from both the Cheonggyecheon area of downtown Seoul and the Myeongdong shopping district.

Was rather cold when I visited in early April. Very large grounds. Even with guided English tour, it was very tiring to walk around. The architecture and cherry blossoms were beautiful. Definitely worth a visit. Comes with free visit to the folk museum.

We took the English guided tour at 11.00 sharp. Lasted for just over 1 hour. Beautiful pictures within the Palace, with the cherry blossom trees in full bloom in the second week of April. The Korean guide, dressed in the traditional Korean costume, with her American accent and cute mannerisms kept you entertained with her well rehearsed structured presentation. Certainly, in terms of sheer opulence and beauty, the Palaces in Korea do not compare with the Maharaja Palaces in India or those in Europe, but a must for the Seoul visitor. You can purchase a combination ticket for 10,000 KRW ($10) to visit all 4 Palaces valid for 30 days. Dont miss the Changing of the Guard at 10.00am, 1.00pm, and 3.00pm sharp. Photo Op with the guards in their period attire at all times opposite the Main Gate.

2nd time that I have been to this palace. This time, we took my parents. It is one of the palaces that I recommend if you are in Seoul. It was a clear day so you could see the mountains making a great back drop along with some flowering cherry trees. They do a changing of the guard ceremony at various times so check the schedule. It is located so that if you have time you can go to multiple locations from the palace such as the National Folk Museum, Insadong, Bukchon Hanok Village, and other palaces. There is a fee of 3,000w for adults less for kids and you can also get a pass for other palaces. There was a restaurant near the subway exit in the palace, but you can walk to restaurants outside the palace as well. We took the subway.

it is best to navigate the place with a tour guide so you can appreciate the history around it but going here by yourself is ok. i think there is a fee but our tour guide paid for it as part of the tour so i am not sure about the charges. the place is huge and as per the tour guide, it will take you 4 hours to tour the entire palace. the place was restored as it was damaged by the war but still looks ancient so i think that is a good thing as it still gives that old era vibe. there is a museum inside that explains the history of korea. there is also a changing of guard ceremony every 3pm except tuesdays. the guards have this nice traditional soldier attire that really gives that old korea look. you can also have your pictures taken with the guards. i particularly liked the roof. very artistic. the place is near bukchon and insa-dong area so if you are nearby that place, you can take a walk or a 5-10 minute cab ride.

I greatly enjoyed my visit to Gyeongbokgung - I'd recommend taking the (free!) English tour (I believe Korean, Chinese and Japanese are also offered if any of those happen to be your preferred langauge), as I feel that was the best way to learn all the little quirks of the palace and its history. They run twice a day, so check beforehand. Our guide was very knowledgable and dressed in traditional costume, which was a cute touch! I've seen a few reviews comparing this palace with the Forbidden City in Beijing - I've been to both, and I believe Gyeongbokgung is definitely different enough to warrant a visit (besides, comparing anything to the Forbidden City seems a little unfair!).  Some of the buildings are only open from April onwards, and since I visited in March they were obviously closed - that was a little disappointing, but it didn't really take anything away from the experience. Make sure you see the changing of the guards - it happens every hour on the hour, so it's pretty easy to catch. The palace costs 3000W to visit, or you can by the combined ticket for 10000W (which I recommend, as it gets you into 5 locations across Seoul). Overall, I quite enjoyed myself!
An interesting place, amazing that it's been completely rebuilt. Join the free guided tour, you'll notice a lot of details that you would have otherwise missed.

About similar in structure to Changdeokgung palace, but Gyeongbokgung palace appears to me to be bigger in size, more vast. It's a beautiful palace, worth a visit and do make it in time for the change of guard ceremony as i did not see it at the other palace.

The ground are huge, the buildings very attractive although not original (those were destroyed in multiple wars). Fun to see but not very impressive, there is also very little written explanation on site Go to Seoul History Museum first (15 min walk from palace), that helps a lot in understanding what you see

Only 300 yen entrance fee. Conveniently there's a money exchange place/ tourist info place right inside the palace next to the ticket booth. Although the palace itself is quite simple, the land area is massive. I like how right behind the palace there's a majestic mountain behind it. It's very picturesque from afar. And the contrast between nature & city makes it all that more interesting. The changing of the guard was sort of neat I suppose.  They have 3 English tours available per day...but I'm so glad I didn't join it. It would have been unbearable in my opinion...especially if you're pressed for time.  I just wish they had "MORE" English descriptions around the place for us to understand what different places were used for. They had a few captions here and there....but it was few and far between.

This is a nice historic place to visit. Small entree fee, big area to see how the King lived here for some hundreds years ago. Museum is included. After visit you can have a great walk to downtown Seoul.

My family and I were only able to go around half of the whole place but everything was so picturesque! Made me feel like I was part of the numerous history dramas Koreans would do. Haha!  I suggest you check the schedules of their tours or make sure to get a map or just try your best not to get lost because it's a really big place. A bit disappointed because we weren't able to cover the whole thing but it was nice! They have a small museum inside so you better check that out as well!

Brings back memories of the Forbidden City in Beijing. Catch the changing of the guard on the hour, but make sure you don't get in their way because the route is not obvious. An interesting Palace, with lots of buildings. However, you do need a guide as there is very little explanation on the way round. Covers a big area in the centre of Seoul.

We have 4 major royal palaces of Chosun dynasty? and actually other ones are bigger than this one. So someone can think, other ones are better. But if you study our history, than you can notice the importance of this one. When my buddies stop by Seoul, I always come to this one, rather than other palaces.(1~2day is not enough for you to see every palace, so if you are going to stay just one or two days, you have to choose the palace to see) This one is a major palace and it was burned during the Japanese colonial, so very important historic site. I recommend you to come here. I came here with my British friend just a few days ago, and he said it was great.

The palace was huge and very crowded with locals and tourists. You should catch the guard changing ceremony, which was held several times a day. Luckily when we came, it was sunny thus we could take some pictures with the mountains background. Make sure to visit the lake near the back, as it was very gorgeous.

The palace itself is very nice but I liked the lake area much more! It was frozen when we were there and quite a lit if tourist. The ticket price was not that expensive. The changing of guards was interesting fur the kids.

I was excited to see the Gyeongbokgung Palace but ended up getting disappointed. The place was nice and vast however there is nothing much to see inside. There's a lot of buildings that look the same.

The most extensive palace in Seoul. Relative to the others this one charges 3000 vs. 1000 to get in, just a relative measure of the expectations.  The changing of the guards was nice but we found the changing at Deoksugung was more elaborate but the site is there is less impressive.  If you only go to one palace this is the one to go to.

The main attraction here is the changing of guards which happens every hour. Do wear comfortably as the palace area is quite huge with many small buildings and you need to walk a lot. This is the largest palace among all the palaces in Seoul. Admission fee is 3000 Won for adult. If you brought the Integrated pass (10000 Won), this palace admission fee is included.

It is recommended that you take a tour to fully understand the history of the palace. The architectures are great and well maintained. It is a very big place to explore, and do remember to put on anti slip shoes when visiting in winter as the place can get quite muddy and slippery when the ice melts.
Stupendously magestic! Took a lot of pictures! When you get here be ready with your cameras. There's an entrance fee of 3K won.

The architecture of the palace is beautiful and very clean area. It is said by the ticketing officer that Gyeongbokgung is one part the other palace which is located at the north. Nice palace in the heart of the city .

I think it takes like full day if you want to see every bit of Gyeongbokgung. It tells you once we(Korea) have Dynasty that a period of peace and prosperity...yes we do have some dark era in that history as well. If you want to know about Korea, it's like the top of the MUST SEE list. Don't miss it.

Gyeongbokgung Palace complex housed some of the most amazing and beautiful architectural design I've ever seen. The main palace building and the pavilion behind it. A visit here during winter when the artificial lake and fields are covered white with snow would be breath-taking.

Yes it's very pretty and it has changing of the guards show, which is really cool. But once inside there is a couple of nice buildings and a beautiful temple near the back. You can't go inside anything. And there isn't anything inside when you can peek inside. So you're basically walking around the outside. Go if you have time, or just stop to see the changing of the guard and heard to the other palace.

Unfortunately when I went to see Gyeongbokgung it was raining, however it's beauty still left me in awe. Make sure to see this place when the weather is good as there's a lot of walking outdoors! and getting your feet soaked is not ideal. A great place to come to to learn more about the history of Korea and see some beautiful traditional architecture which I've found hard to find in Korea - but I may be looking in the wrong places. Definitely a highlight in Seoul, don't miss it.

This was a breath-taking place. There was beauty everywhere you looked. The grand structures of the palace and surrounding buildings were fascinating. A terrific place for photos! The museum inside was very modern and had multi-media displays along with models, samples and preserved treasures from the past. It was interesting to be in a palace right inside a busting metropolis.

This is a nice place to be in, especially if you have a tour guide to explain to you about the history and whatever that took place in the palace many years ago. I was freezing when I was there (about 2 degrees?) and the scenery was pretty because the pond froze :D
I enjoyed the feng shui influencing the palace's design...coupled with other intelligent building design features..
there are some free areas - where you can take pics with guards ... but that is enough for the family to handle

The main palace, really beautifull. Don't miss the gards at the entrence and try to catch the changing of guards. Around you also have the National Folk Museum which is also nice. Any trip in Seoul should include this palace.

It was fun to walk around Gyongbokgung and adjacent areas talking pictures and observing locals. Although I was not familiar with the historical aspect of the place, it was interesting enough to just stop and contemplate.

I visited this palace on last Sunday and i trust me it is amazing. It is situated in the heart of city but still so calm and peaceful. Anyone visitng korea should visit this palace. To go there you can take subway. Either you should get down at Anguk or Gyeongbokgung station. It is at walk-able distance from both stations. About Palace : If you are visiting this palace, you should take out atleast 2-3 hours of your busy schedule.Entry fee for palace is 3500 KRW for one palace and for all three palace it is 9000 KRW. It is situated on large area. Following things you must do: - Please check English guide tour. It is free and very much informative. - Please check guard changing ceremony timing. It is must see thing at palace. - Visit party area of the palace which is situated inside lake. Take a picture with it. - Take a picture with guard. - Enjoy beautiful greenery at palace. Specially in autumn.  To Eat : - There is some roadside food is available outside palace. You can try that on your own risk. It is good.
Very impressive from outside but I was a bit disappointed with the interiors of the buildings. The small lake and trees within the vicinity are quite nice.

This largest of the five grand palaces of the Joseon Dynasty has been lovingly restored since it was first destroyed by fire and then the Japanese during the occupation of the early 20th Century. A wonderful example of great feng shui, this beautiful palace illustrates "paesanimsu"... mountains behind and streams in front. Protected by the Bukhan Mountains to the north and fed by the Han River in front of the palace, this is an ideal setting for a royal palace. This huge complex is fun to explore, wandering from building to building and imagining the lives of royals and the commoners who served them some 600 years ago. We were told that Gyeongbokgung Palace is more influenced by Chinese architectural principles (more of a grid style), while Changdeokgung Palace is designed more from a traditional Korean layout. As a visitor, the changing of the guards is interesting and can make for good photos -- I would recommend a good telephoto lens to really capture the colorful outfits and facial expressions.
