The gate is most beautiful at night. I understand the Palace is open at night during the summer, this was not the case during our October visit. The Pavillion was interesting, though the lack of an English speaking guide during the "reservations only" tour limited some of the power of this part of the experience. Because of its location in the city, this site can become quite crowded... be patient and learn to go where the groups don't go. This may lead to little discoveries. Of the palaces in Seoul, Gyeongbokgung Palace is the largest and most impressive by sheer size. We personally thought that the Changdeokgung Palace was the most elegant and beautiful. I am glad we saw both.
a completely different world here right in the heart of the city. Easy to get to and also have the museum nearby. Architectural wonder. A MUST if you're in Seoul.

Wonderful place to visit. Very quite towards the evening. During the day, the large amount of people is diluted is the vey big area of the park. It is from far the better maintained one and the garden is gorgeous.

Easy to get to as it is located in the metro station that bears its name. It is the largest palace grounds as well as one of the most beautiful. Has guided tours in korean, mandarin chinese, english & japanese. Looks out for the palaces within the palace grounds especially the one located in the middle of the lake, and also the pagoda with the bridge on the water lily pond. Those will be your highlights. The palace is also located near the Blue House (or Cheongwadae) which is the presidential palace, and also a few museums and the Gwanghwamun Square.
If you have watched all those Korean period dramas, you will enjoy this place. Try to join the tour, there's english, japanese and chinese tour.
This palace is very beautiful. The rooftop is colourful and the painting is nice. The different buildings are beautifl. A good place to visit.

I think this palace has the beauty of its kind though it could have been kept better. Lots of nice scenery here and there and there are hourly royal guard changing ceremony from 9am-3pm. It's the most famous and biggest palace in Korea. Here, other than visiting, the palace, you can meet tourists that can speak English, Korean ppl and students who actually visit the palace ( in which normally ppl in other countries won't be doing that) and you can get the feel of being a kind in such palace. However, I don't understand what is wrong with Koreans especially those from Seoul. Most of them are very unfriendly especially young pretty girls, couples and man in business suits. You try to speak to them even in Hangul, they will ignore you. Plus, it's surprising that their English are very poor. Even they themselves don't really speak to other Koreans they don't know. Usually it's couples speaking themselves which are abundant or girls in groups speaking themselves. That really annoyed me a lot and changed my impression of Koreans through drama. This is where you meets the reality of Koreans instead of those fantasies in drama. However, don't give up trying to ask for help if you need it because it's like striking a lottery where out of 50 people, there might be 1 who are willing to try to basically help you. I was a bit lucky to meet 2 Koreans who helped me to find my way to my hotel from the Gimpo Airport(terribly bad for tourist). Seriously, if S. Korea aims to earn travellers' money, please be more friendly and improve your English as it's the globally spoken language. Prepare for lots of walking if you are not joining a tour group though. No offence though. Tips when looking for help: target for older uncle and auntie, and also not so cool and friendly looking ppl. I would say it's easier to approach guys in younger ppl.

Everything about this place is amazing: the beauty, the location, the history, the technologies. My advice: take a guide. They will give you precious stories about the life in the kingdom and within the palace. Stay also for the staged ceremonies: it is very interesting for the kids. If you have time, walk all around the palace: there are plenty of art galleries, or just watch people passing by. Seoulites are always interesting to watch!

Great complex. A guard changing ceremony happens during the day, definitely should be seen. I believe this place should be visited with a guide so every stone and building detail would make more sense.

Alight at Gyeongbokgung Station where the 5 largest grand palaces are in Seoul. We dropped by National Palace Museum's cafe to have brunch before braving through the cold. We managed to witness the guards march when we were there too. We bought the entrance tickets at the info counter for our English Tour which cost 3000KW each and it will last for about an hour. The tour guide will bring you through the whole of Gyeongbokgung and explain to you in details what each of these palaces means.  Managed to catch a glimpse of the fluffy cherry blossoms during the period when we were there. Overall, it's really a magnificent place rich in history in Korea. Worth visiting! For more on my trip to Gyeongbokgung, http://jacqsowhat.blogspot.sg/2013/06/seoul-korea-day-2.html

I was pleasantly surprised with the Gyeongbokgung palace complex. True, I had read that this was a place not to be missed, and so I was expecting something rather grand. What I did not expect was how expansive the grounds of this palace really are, especially the gardens and peripheral structures to the rear (north). In fact, the gardens and ornamental lakes were where I spent most of my time, and I thoroughly recommend that you get away from the main palace buildings and to lose yourself in this green and peaceful gardenscape if you can.  A few practicalities: I visited the palace on a Saturday afternoon, and to be honest the crowds weren't nearly as bad as I had expected (try doing the same thing at Beijing's Forbidden Palace, for instance). Still, a week day or early morning would definitely better for more solitude. The entrance fee of about US$3 is a real bargain, and you can get tickets valid for one month for about US$10 if you are staying in Seoul for a longer time. Try to arrive at the palace on foot and walk north on Gwanghwamun Plaza to get a really good idea of the grandeur of this magnificent palace, with the sharp granite mountains in the background.  If you only get to see one thing in Seoul, make sure it's the Gyeongbokgung palace. You won't be disappointed!

watched too much of k-drama and decided to visit this place. love it because have always wanted to visit the palace and get a feel of it. whole palace was very big and took us an hour plus to finish walking the entire palace. basically nothing inside and more of sightseeing.

With only a day to spend in Seoul and my original plan to visit the DMZ area scrapped because of military exercises, I spent a few hours at this beautiful national treasure. Great for walking amidst beautiful trees, and simple but ornate buildings. The roof-lines and eaves of the structures were really impressive. Definitely suggest this be on the itinerary of a visitor to Seoul.

Though it is a recently restored palace, you can still feel the history and grandness of the place. Perhaps I managed to catch the changing of the guard and saw people in period costumes so I was able to visualize Gyeongbokgung during its heyday. It is expansive and from the layout, it's like a smaller version of Beijing's Forbidden City.  I also made a mistake of visiting Changdeokgung first and regretted it when I saw the 2 for 1 ticket. Don't listen to the Lonely Planet advice of visiting only Changdeokgung if you only have one palace to visit. For me, Gyeongbokgung is grander and more evocative of the past despite its newly-restored surroundings. Plus, there are other attractions around the area like the Folk Museum and the Innsadong shopping street.

This is a must-see in Seoul but be prepared to spend a lot of time there (a few hours)-it is really big so put on your walking shoes. I took a self-guided tour which allowed me to see the palace at my own pace but if I had to do it over again, I would have taken a guided tour (there are three English speaking tours per day-11am, 1:30pm, 2:30pm). Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the “Five Grand Palaces” in Seoul and is the largest and most visited. It was the main palace in Seoul for 500 years and the kings and queens of the Joseon Dynasty would live here. Like the other Seoul palaces, this one was heavily damaged during the Japanese occupation and the Korean War so most of what you see is reconstructed but that doesn’t take away from the grandeur of the Korean architecture. The Royal Changing of the Guard ceremony (reenacted since 1996) is a must-see and happens three times a day (10am, 1pm, 3pm) inside the front gate.  After you pay the admission fee, you can get a pamphlet which details each building you see. The highlights for me were the Gwanghwamun Gate (main gate), the Geunjeongjeon (main throne hall), Hyangwonjeong Pavilion, Geoncheongung, and the trio of Parujeong, Jibokjae, and Hyeopgildang. There were also two pleasant surprises for me. The National Folk Museum of Korea is located on the grounds of the palace and although I didn’t plan to visit the museum, I did a quick tour to get a taste of it. If you make it all the way to the far side of the palace by Sinmumun Gate (North Gate) and walk outside, you will see a heavily guarded blue building. This is the Blue House and is where the President of South Korea lives and works.  I was able to visit three of the “Five Grand Palaces” in Seoul but if you only have time to visit one, Gyeongbokgung is the one to visit.
Mostly reconstructed but you get a sense of what it was like originally. Watch out for the tour groups!

Gyeongbokgung is a palace which is beautiful, well-maintained and very clean. It's large and was once reconstructed. The entry fee is W3000, which is for me reasonable. While walking around this place, I felt like I was in a journey to the past haha. For people who love historical things, this is a must go when you come to Seoul.
This palace is very beautiful, well-maintained. The rooftop is colourful and the painting is nice. The different buildings are beautiful. The lake is beautiful as well. A good place to visit.
It was really exciting to visit the royal place. I especially liked the Gate Guard Change ceremonies. I actually felt like i was in ancient times watching the royal guards perform so gracefully.
It is a very good place to visit. Highly recommended. It is massive, so make sure you wear a good pair of walking shoes.
Beautiful palace! Especially enjoyed the changing of the guards ceremony. It's so unique. Very well-maintained area. Convenient location (right at MRT station). Highly recommended.
I love how Korean preserve their historical values and bring it to show the world. From here, I can really visualize how the changing guards ceremony truly was many hundred years ago!

I visit this palace around 11.30am. Since at Korea it is very hard to find HALAL food, so I bring my own food and eat before I enter to this palace.  There will be a changing guard ceremony at 1.30pm, so you don't miss it.  You also able to try Korean Traditional costume, and during the time that I went there, the costume was Guard Costume.  This is the biggest palace in Seoul. The fee is 3000 won per entry.  In front of this palace, there is 3 monument. You can just cross the road and take pictures with it. And if you go straight, you can see famous stream in Seoul
The grounds are enormous, so I recommend taking one of the guided tours to focus on the most important parts and be able to appreciate it more fully. Visit the Palace Museum on the premises.

Very well maintained and lots of nice photo opportunities all over the place. Lots of quaint views of small temples and trees and little nooks and cranies showing Korean houses and pathways. The museum is nice to visit as well, very informative and clean :)

This place has been thoroughly restored and looks a bit too new, but it is quite spectacular, as is the surrounding scenery. Don't miss the changing of the guards ceremony, which seems to take place quite regularly.

My friend and I actually only planned 2 hours for Gyeongbokgung but turned out there wasn't enough time because the palace was HUGE!xD there were lots of buildings to visit and i don't think we finished walking the entire area because our feet were already sore from all the walking..haha. We walked around the palace without a guide but if you would like to know more about the palace and its history, it would be good to get one..they have Korean, Japanese, Chinese and English guides during certain time slots. If you're a fan of places with rich history and culture, then this place must not be missed!:)
Royal Guard Changing Ceremony that takes place only twice a day was fantiastic. The 3 museums in the palace were the among the best in the world and they were free.

This is a huge complex (probably the biggest of all palaces), with palace buildings, gardens, huge entry gate and guard parade. Very interesting and the view of the entry gate with the mountain in the background is good. The national folk museum is also situated in the grounds and is worth a look and was free at the time I went. Also if you go south of the gate along the central promenade of Sejongno Road, you will see Statues of the King and Admiral Yi. There is a free underground museum (entry at King's statue). Definitely worth visiting, especially the Admiral Yi exhibit.

This old palace complex was quite huge and it was located right in the city. The wooden arches and buildings were beautifully carved and decorated. They were simply magnificent. Our tour guide Jenny gave us a superb history of the old Korean royalty and how they lived. So if you are interested in Korean royalty and cultural history, this place is a must
A must visit. Just go for a walk around the lakes! Fish can be seen everywhere.... Many places to go through

This palace teaches you a little more about Korean cultural in the early day. We were on a tour but it was hard to hear the tour guide and too many people to see some of the attractions there. I did enjoy learning more about Korea.

At first I cant believe that such traditional and serene palace is exist in the middle of the busy Seoul. Inside this Palace complex there is a lot of other traditional building to see. If you love photography you would love this place. The palace building is huge with an authentic decoration. Also there is a lot of garden with beautiful scenery. Overall the palace complex is good and very attractive.

We were fortunate enough to visit the Palace when they lit up the place and allow visitors to come at night, so we spent half a day and the evening there. It was quite an experience as the Palace was packed with people. The Palace area is huge and the buildings are pretty however some may find the palace rather 'empty' and I do prefer Changdeokgung. The changing guards was quite fun to watch. For a good walk, go to Gwanghwamun Square and walk towards the Palace.

In the entire leadup to our Korea trip, Gyeongbokgung seemed like it would be THE palace to visit. Strangely enough, I feel like it may have been the one that we least explored. That may be due to the enormous size of the palace grounds. I also wasted too much time photographing the front areas of the palace and underestimated how much time was left in the day. You can really spend hours at Gyeongbokgung just relaxing in the various areas the palace has to offer.  While we were in front by Gwanghwamun gate, we saw some sort of guard ceremony. At the time, I thought it was their "changing of the guard," but now that I'm seeing Youtube videos of the full ceremony, it can't have been it. Luckily, we caught the full "changing of the guard" at Deoksugung, so I'm good on that.  Based on my limited anecdotal knowledge, it seems like Gyeongbokgung is the most popular palace to visit. It's right off the main city square and it has the impressive Gwanghwamun gate to mark the main entrance. If you can only visit one palace, I'd probably recommend Changdeokgung with its beautiful Secret Garden and slightly smaller crowds. However, Gyeongbokgung is enormous and impressive. You can't go wrong either way. Go see them both!
A must see in Seoul. A great insight in Korean past with monumental building in combination with small more intimate locations.

We didn't do all the palaces of Seoul, but if you are going to do one of them it should be this one. Not on the scale of Forbidden City in Beijing, but still very impressive.  Again very cheap entry fee, free 1 hour tour guides in different languages which was very informative, and the changing of the guard which is definitely worth the wait (many of these throughout the day) and great for photo ops with historical dressed soldiers.  Next to this are 2 museums (Folk and the Palace museum). Both are interesting and depends if you have time in your schedule. Folk is included in Palace ticket.
Very interesting place with many things to see. To hire a guide would not be a bad idea, otherwise one can read all in the travel guide.
Superb architecture. Very interesting mix of buildings, gardens and temples. It has a good restaurant and is just besides a metro station.

It was supposed to be grand but despite the vastness and a couple of displays of the old settings of the palace, I came away without feeling impressed. It did cross my mind what a big place for the workers to get from place to place in the compound.
The area is immaculately preserved. They also make it so tourist friendly with the free Hanbok wearing and the changing of the guards ceremony for show.

If you are just going to Seoul for shopping, I'll say you may not like going to these historical places which can be a little dry.  But it's highly recommended especially for 1st time visitors to take some time off to read, see and learn how is the history like and how much hv been destroyed after the war. Take your time to stroll the gardens to take the city stress away. Try on the guards uniform for a fun photo taking at no costs.  Every country's historical buildings are to be respected for what they have been through with time. So we think its not a fair comparison to compare the different palaces. Just have an open mind to learn more of what was recorded during that era.

Make sure you do not miss the exchange of guards which start around 10am. It is almost an hour show and worth watching. Take note that this takes place outside Gyeongbokgung and you need not purchase a ticket to watch this!

This palace is a "must see" for any trip to Seoul. The surroundings are absolutely beautiful with mountains in the background, manicured gardens and fish ponds. You can experience how the royal family used to live hundreds of years ago and then step out the gate into downtoen Seoul. Walking shoes a good idea due to the large area to be covered and the uneven surface area (ancient paving stones, not concrete). The changing of the guard ceremony also interesting as well as the exhibits of life in ancient Korea.
There are a couple of palaces in Seoul. Both are different enough to enjoy separately, but you must see at least one.

Gyungbok Palace was used as a King's place during Joseon dynasty. You can feel Korean royal family's life and there living standard. Also, you can enjoy beautiful nature in Gyungbok Palace. Don't forget other palaces around Gyungbok Palace like Changduk Palace or Changgyung Palace.
plenty of phoyo opportunities with guards changing and the buildings and you can try on a uniform and watz around its very funny and worth doing and as always everyone is friendly
Prepare for a long walk if we want to explore the whole areas. The whole were very clean and well-maintained. The palaces have colorful detail and interesting pattern on many parts of them.

We visited the palace as a family on a Sunday morning and spent appr 2 hours here. As has been mentioned in many reviews, a lot of parts of this palace are rebuilt due to destruction suffered during Japanese occupation. Nevertheless, it remains very impressive. Since we had our two children with us (10 and 15) we didn't opt for any tours (they tend to get bored easily) but just wandered around the grounds. There were plenty of information tablets near all major sites and all were available in English so no language barrier there. We arrived at appr. 10.50 and were able to take some shots of the kids with the colourful guards in front of the palace. The changing of the guards on the hour made for a lovely video shot. Once inside the gate the ticket booths were located towards the right hand side. When we went in there were only 2-3 people queuing in front of us so no delays in purchasing tickets. The grounds are huge so you can easily spend some hours just wandering about, taking scenic shots (and have them taken by Koreans of you as well!). We had a coffee outside the cafe in the sun which was lovely and priced similarly to the rest of Seoul. Overall a great place to start your sightseeing. Very easy to do and beautiful shots to get. I would make sure you go in good weather though since virtually all of it is outside (you will only be able to look inside the buildings from windows).

Wow ... What a great piece of architecture ad restoration. This palace is the largest and one of 5 palaces in Seoul. I joined a tour and this was one of the inclusions.  It was good to have someone explain all the history and show me through. Wonderful colors and history.  Look out for the changing of the guards - a parade of wonderful costumes, sounds and pagentary. Lots of people scrambling to get photos but wait until the end and you will get shots of guards leaving .  I wish I had more time as tour only allocated an hour which also include the national folk museum. This is a must see if you have limited time. The other palace I saw was very similar ad I don't think it's worth doing two palaces.

It was amazing to see how totality lived... And there day to day habits. The architecture is a sight to behold. I was amazing to see how Japan and chime ha influence in the way they developed there land and also to know that korea has been invaded by both but still in the end Korea fought through. Even if your not big into history the views, plant life, and entertainment is enough to take up your whole day. Don't forget to see the changing of the guards. And for 3,000 won you can't beat that... Plus free admittance to the national folk museum right next door.

I liked the fact that this complex was restored very well. Though it suffered a lot of damages due to the war and the Japanese occupation, I found this royal palace to be a more sober and enjoyable example compared to Beijing's Forbiddne City. More information available in english, less crowded, and very clean

Well kept, vibrant and well preserved. You will enjoy an afternoon stroll here and definitely enjoy visiting the museums. Nice souvenirs and reasonably priced. They have great views to take pictures of and is one of the palaces that you would think of revising.

This is the #1 palace to see if you can only see one. Highly recommend the tour. Only a few english tours a day, so check your guide book or the website for schedule. If you can't make the tour, pick up a pamphlet at the information office, there isn't any signage on the grounds explaining what anything is. Changing of the guard happens every hour on the hour, that's worth seeing. Also recommend the integrated palaces ticket if you plan to visit a lot of palaces. It's a good value and saves the standing in line at every palace to buy tickets.

Although most of the buildings are rebuilt in recent years, there are various guard changing ceremonies held throughout the day. at 11am 1pm and 3pm there is a procession with drums and music and at 2pm and 4pm is a simpler guard changing ceremony.

this is the also one of the "must see" place when you go on city tour, at front of Sejong King Statue, go on there at 10.00 then you will see the guard changing ceremony, and after that you can taken your picture with them, it was great,,,

Too bad that we went here in the afternoon that is why we missed the changing of guards. What I really like the most is the big landscape of the palace and the mountain views in the palace. When we where there the small room in the middle of the lake reminds me of Moon embraces the sun. I really want to go there but it is restricted to visitors. We were already tired at the time when we visited this palace so we spent a little time in here.

The name translates as the Palace of Shining Happiness. This palace has survived a lot of wars and rulers making is historical site a representation of how strong korea is as a nation and it's citizenry. The interesting folk museum and palace museum is housed here including beautiful traditional korean gardens. When in gyeongbogkung you must witness the royal changing of the guards that happens every hour from 10am - 3pm and of course have photos with the korean guards as well

The main attraction of going to Gyeongbokgung is to watch the changing of the guards. They say it is historically accurate, complete with exchange of passwords and stuff. It’s best to time your visit to watch the changing of the guards, and then go on the free guided tour which I think runs every hour. The tour guide gave lots of interesting information about the architectural features of the palace, like why there are three “lanes” going into the palace from the gates, or how the palace is heated during the winter months. She also gave told us a bit of history of Korea, the palace and the kings that occupied it. Overall it was 2 hours well spent.  If you’re into walking a lot, Gyeongbokgung is walking distance from Insadong, Jongmyeo Shrine, Changdeokgung Palace, Gwanghwamun Square and Cheonggyecheon Stream. So from Gyeongbokgung there are quite a number of choices of places you can go to.

Visited Gyeongbokgung late November so it was starting to get chilly. It is easily accessed via the Gyeongbokgung Palace station on Seoul Subway line 3. We were able to catch the Changing of the Guards. Don't forget to take tons of photos with the guards and the lovely red and yellow foliage.

Easy access from subway. The exit/entrance from subway was decorated to have a feel of the historic palace. A palace with cluster dwellings for the palace workers. Beautiful architecture and carvings made for good photography. They have a procession of guards at certain time of the day. They have FREE guides done by students in English! You can see them in their bright orange jacket. A few other museum around the palace grounds. This place is huge! Take us a few hours to cover the whole ground. Only our hunger for lunch stop us from covering the whole ground. There's a cafe in the museum building to have hot coffee. We head to Insadong for lunch which is nearby across the street. Visited in December 2012.

Imagine large palace with interesting stories behind them.... hence, it'll be good if you manage to catch a guide that gives free tour at regular interval.  Be sure to get there before 4pm or so (please check closing timing as it differs time to time) as ticketing close an hour before closing time... we missed it by ten minutes during our first trip there :(  There's a National Palace Museum at the side with some interesting displays, taking about an hour or less to finish viewing, a good side visit if you have some time on hand,... or happened to missed the ticketing time (like us)

The palace offers free guided tour (first one for English starts 11am) but unfortunately the timing was not right for us. We were told that there are uni students giving free tours of the palace as well but we could not locate them. That was why we decided to rent an audio guide for 3,000won. The content was informative but if you don't mind reading, I recommend that you skip the audio guide and go for the free guide book that you can find once you enter the ticketed entrance. The written guide comes with illustration & pictures, to give you a better idea on what to look out for.  The palace is very accessible. We took the metro to Gyeongbukgong metro stop. One of the exits will lead you straight to the palace. The palace wasn't very crowded when we first got there at 9am, but the crowds started to stream in by the time we left at 1pm.  The buildings in the palace are small but the palace grounds is quite large. Note that many of the buildings are restored works rather than originals. The landscaping looked nice and left me desiring ti want to see it in spring & autumn.

With so many palace around, we decided to just go to this one. The entrance fees is pretty cheap. Took and audio guide too, but found it not necessary as there is a free English guided tour. Remember to go see the guard changing ceremony.
The in-house guide was great and informative! She was also passionate about what she was telling us. I now understand the Koreans grief over losing their royalty because of the deeds of the Japanese.

It's quite an experience to really step into a historic Palace where most people only view them in dramas. Kind of crowded in the morning. They have a ceremony at specific timings where there's music and guards "marching".  It's a huge palace. When we are there, some little parts are undergoing construction. But we still enjoy our trip there.

We enjoyed the beauty of this. Unfortunately, when we went it was cold and I don't think we gave the palace due justice. There isn't much to do, but we also had our son and were not able to spend a good amount of time taking a tour or audio tour. I am certainly glad we saw this beautiful palace though.

This was the first site we visited in Seoul. We joined the English tour, which took a little more than an hour. The palace gave tremendous insight into the prevailing culture and principles of the Joseon dynasty. I was impressed that, unlike other palaces, there was no emphasis on excess and luxury. Instead, they had a stream for purifying the mind, simple dwelling places for the royal family, and even a quiet place for the king to reflect. The buildings were big, but relatively austere.  After the tour, we watched the changing of the guard ceremony at the Gwanghamun Gate. This happens hourly from 10am to 3pm, so you can catch it before or after the tour. Entrance to the palace costs KRW3000 (less than UD$3), tours are free.

Where do i start? I kinda got lost inside the palace, I was walking somewhere I think is suppose to be the servant's area and I have no idea where i am by the time i notice i was lost. It is really nice place to have a look. and Just a tip, bring along a water bottle and a cap if you are going around noon, you would need that :)

Visiting the Palace during Chuseok just added to the experience. There were people dressed in traditional costumes, dancers, and special events going on in the children's section, including traditional games. The Palace wasn't crowded, we were able to roam around and take lots of pictures. The Palace is easy to get to, and there is a money exchange inside which is very helpful. Be sure to give yourself enough time to walk to all the different sections. One of my favorites was the replication of a village from the 1940's, including the comic book shop. I would recommend that you either eat before going to the Palace, or take some snacks with you. It is so big that it takes several hours to see everything. There are places to fill your water bottle and the bathrooms were clean.

Gyeongbok Palace has to be the number one attraction in Seoul. I never get tired of watching the changing of the guard, the changing of the leaves, or the changing faces of the tourists from all aover the world who flock to its grounds. A vast expense of land in the center of Seoul yours for exploring at your own leasure without too much interference from low key museum staff. Take a camera of course and be prepared to walk away with hundreds of wonderful compositions from magnificant architectural roofs to detailed close-ups of ancient fixtures and doors. Well worth spending a half a day exploring preceded by and with a follow on late lunch or early dinner. High noon is the spectacle of spectacles with the changing of the guards, so don;t miss it. One of many palaces in and around Seoul but in my humble opinion the best preserved and most professionaly presented and maintained.

Went here during the obligatory tourist day of a business trip to Seoul.  We watched the changing of the guard shortly after arriving at 10. A few people brightly dressed as traditional korean warriors marched around a bit but didn't really do much else.  Pretty impressive overall though and a fairly large complex to explore. We had a group tour guide who was full of interesting information about the place, which brought it to life a bit more.  Some of it is original but much has been extensively restored, but done in a sympathetic manor.  I guess it depends how much you like this sort of place but we took about 1.5 hours to see all the major bits of the complex and I thought that was enough.

i was here on a sunday in October,the weather was quite warm for me but the sun are real big.remember to bring your sunglasses or you won't be able to open your eyes to see the historical building which are still colourful and well maintained.please be prepare that you will need to walk quite a lot,plus taking photo,watch the shift changing of the palace guard.the palace closed on Monday so take note if you are planning to go there.

The sheer enormity of Gyeongbokgung Palace can be a bit daunting, but I do encourage anyone visiting Seoul to take a few hours to wander through the grounds of this amazing palace.  After passing through Gwanghwamun Gate (the main gate of the palace, which is itself enormous and visually stunning, especially as it is lit up at night), there are many structures to walk through within the temple's vast walls, along with amazing courtyards, pavilions, statues and traditional Korean gardens. Each gate and doorway passed through provides new and wonderful sights to take in. The temple's vibrant color scheme of teal, red, purple and orange -- seemingly standard throughout most if not all of Korea's temples and palaces -- is a delight to behold.  The National Folk Museum of Korea, as well as the National Palace Museum of Korea, are also located within its walls, and tours are available for both.  The palace is very easy to get to, with close access to the subway and bus routes, and seems surprising and almost out of place in the middle of such a busy city. But once inside its impressive walls, one can quickly forget that you're in a bustling, modern city and allow yourself to be transported to a different and distant time.  Although it attracts a lot of tourists, I highly recommend spending a few hours visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace -- you won't be disappointed. And if you can visit on a weekday the crowds will be far fewer.

I'm in awe with the size and scale of this palace. I'm also so very happy I dropped the 3000 Won for the audio guide. It was highly informative and provided me with a much richer experience than if I'd just bumbled through the place. For a moment I stopped to listen to the free tour and it seemed quite worthwhile, too, providing even more color than the audio guide. I would recommended it if you're into a slightly more structured walk. My favorite part? Hyangwonejong in the back - a phenomenally beautiful pagoda and pond. I could have spent hours there.

This is the meaning of the word Gyeongbokgung and it fits the palace so well. I arranged for a two day stopover in Seoul and checked online for places of interest. This was on the top of my list. I arrived in Seoul and stayed at the Sky Hotel which had free shuttle service and was two blocks from the metro for downtown Seoul. Excellent location!!! Took the metro to the Palace and arrived just in time for the changing of the guards which was absolutely beautiful and very entertaining with music, costumes, drums, marching bands, etc. I enjoyed it so much that after I toured the palace and grounds, I stayed for the next guard change which is on the hour. The Seoul metro makes it very easy to get around the city and it is very reasonable also. Two days was enough time to see most of the important sights of the city. Food was delicious esp. the area called the Samcheongdong with its wonderful street food. Also went to the Jeongdong theatre for the "Miso" showing (full house). You can take a city bus tour (hop on, hop off) for only ten US dollars, I real bargain!!!

Very conveniently located with its own subway stop this is a great place to walk around in the fall or spring when the weather is comfortable. Lots to see and plenty of space to switch your legs while admiring the amazing architecture,

the garden and compound is so huge the lines for the entrance ticket were long great architecture  wear covered or rubber shoes as there will be a lot of walking from one palace/room to another its quite dusty in spring (i visited them in spring)
Typical palaces as in similarities to the ones in other cities like Beijing. It has a very big compound so walking end to end is quite a distance so prepare to have good walking shoes.

Went there on a biz trip in Jan 11. Client organized local tour which of cuz, couldn't missed out the magnificent palace. Maybe it was my first encounter with winter weather and it was freezingly cold to walk on the snow (lots and lots of walking) and I didn't get to enjoy the scenery due to the coldness. Hence, be prepared to put on heat pack and extremely thick socks with boots before going there!
I strolled through this palace. It was interesting. Well kept. Changing of the guard was very enjoyable.

Went to the Palace to get a feel of Seoul. By chance just got there as the guard was changing - it's quite a spectacle with falgs, banners and unusual uniforms - it was quite fascinating. The paalce complex is ok, a bit like a small Forbidden City and it certainly gives you the feeling of how grand it must have been

A much more compact place than the Changdeogung Palace but main buidlings-wise, more or less comparable. But what sets it apart is the secret garden area which gives you a good impression of what it was like hundereds of years ago. Most buildings here are original and not rebuild as in the other places. Do take the English tour because it gives so much inside info on this attraction. A plus !
The palace is super big.... I couldn't finish exploring the palace during my one hour visit. Was too tired and had to back...

Wear comfortable walking shoes and bring a bottle of water. Be prepared for the often dusty areas paved with gravel. There are many steps to climb without handrails in order to see inside many of the palace rooms. Allow time to do a guided walking tour with English speaking tour guides. There's a sign at the gathering place inside the palace grounds for the scheduled tours, which are free.  Please read the other reviews of this palace. I agree with most of them, and don't want to repeat.

We arrived at Gyeongbokgung Palace around lunch time, it was very hot and too much glare from the sun. Maybe its better to go in the afternoon and in time for the English-speaking tour guide but there are free English booklets that you can read while walking around the palace.  There is also the Gogungddurak museum shop and cafe where we had our lunch.

The palace itself and surrounding are beautiful, but in my opinion the park behind is beautiful, with artifitial lake and great deep green. Try to get on late afternoon, when sun starts to set down and enjoy great play of colors

Impressive architecture with the National Palace Museum of Korea and the National Folk Museum on the grounds as well. Time your visit to witness the changing of the guard and be sure to see the gardens in the rear of the palace, especially the lovely Hyangwonjeong pavilion. The combination ticket for all the palaces in Seoul, including the Secret Garden and Jongmyo Shrine is well worth it if you plan on seeing more than 3 of the sites.

This is the one of the place you need to visit when your holidays in South Korea.You can explore by yourself and it take 2 to 3 hrs to complete this area. The entrance fees is around 2,400 Won.You can bring along bottle of drinks and cap if you visit summer season as the place is big for your to explore where you can snap beautiful view either the traditional palaces or lake.You also can try their traditional dress for snap photos with free fees. The best is when you arrive in you can see the changing guard with some of traditional music. We also can snap photos with the guard when they are on duty.Please don't miss this place in your holidays itinarary.
Beautiful and very nicely programmed in the summer. Took out of town guests there on the weekend and the museum was free. It was a delight to see all the extra performances.

All visitors to Seoul should stop by this palace. Very amazed by the grandeur of the structures and the beauty of the architecture. Be sure to come on a cooler day as we visited during a heat wave and found ourselves dripping with sweat. Also do not make the mistake of spending too much time at the main gate and the first palace building as it is only a small part of the overall complex.
The palace is completely rebuilt and it is worth a visit to understand Seoul's past. There is a great guards ceremony every our in the main entrance

Loved the palace and worth visiting. definitely go there and its not far from the city centre. I took tons of pictures here which i enjoy doing. At the entrance the guards are all dressed up in traditional old uniforms which was nice to see.

Been here twice and still think that's this is the most interesting attraction in Seoul, other then the shopping. The place will take u back to the olden days in Korea. It would be great if u can get a guide to explain the features within this palace to get a better understanding.
One sparsely adorned pavilion after another. No tree cover at all; it is scorching hot under the summer sun. If you don't want to expand the energy or have limited time, skip this tourist trap.
The famous palace here... A must see for every tourist! Vast area inside... I wonder how many servants the King has inside the palace grounds!?!?!

The Palace is very big, and nice to walk around. While you can find the performance schedule of 'changing soldiers' every day. Very impressive performance - you will see the soldiers wearing Korean traditional costumes marching with Korean music, and at the end of the performance, you can take photos with the soldiers!!
the changing of the guards is what makes this palace different from other palaces. very colourful

This is my favorite of all the palaces in Seoul! The buildings are beautiful...there is so much to see. The changing of the guard ceremony is something not to be missed. My favorite spot is the small pond in the way back of the grounds.(Hyangwon-jeong) The day we were there, there we lilly pads in the pod. The pictures we took of the pond, gazebo and mountain in the background were breathtaking!

This palace, and its neighbor to the East, is beautifully restored and well worth visiting. You can enter some of the buildings.  Recommended: Take a free, guided tour, either from the Palace (times posted upon entry) or by reserving one at the Korean Tourist Agency (http://www.visitseoul.net/).  Hidden treat: National Folk Museum of Korea is at the NE corner of the palace, and is excellent, with free guided tours.

The palace is pretty big, though once you have visited one palace, the rest looks pretty much similiar. Though they tell a different story. And so a guided tour helps or the guide booklet that is made available at the palance entrance. There are various activites that happens within the grounds of the palace. Depending on the time of the day, you will be able to experience the changing of guards at the entrance of the palace. There are some family oriented activities available within the palace vicinity as well.  The amazing thing about the palace is that it sits beautifully against Mount Namsan and the Han River.

Nice touch of Korean history walking the grounds. Nestled in the heart of Seoul, this is very accessible. But it is not on the scale of the Forbidden City - and definitely worth visiting. There were the colourful guards marching around and they even wandered off into the business district outside the palace walls. Nice sight.
This place is larger than I had imagined, but it is quite the place to see. The museum is also attached to the grounds. The changing of the guards is quite th scene.
This is the biggest of all the palaces and the most well-preserved.
The changing of the guard was enjoyable. The museum is also worth taking in and walking around the ground, is a nice way of spending an afternoon.
touristy guard change during the guard but well worth getting a photo of

Yes, this palace has been reconstructed but the innovative South Koreans had no alternative if they wanted to rightly showcase their proud history.  The guards at the main gate were incredibly still as tourists posed beside them.  The 1100 changing of the guard was impressive: much music amid solemn ceremony and marching.  The Palace's reconstructed buildings occupy a large area. Reconstruction is ongoing with some traditional cottages being built.  The entrance fee (KRW3000 was particularly good value). One can combine this with a visit to the free National Folk Museum.  Don't come on Tuesdays: it is closed.

One of several major palaces in downtown Seoul; once you've had a guided tour of one you will recognize the main features of the others. I'd avoid the audio tour for this one, though; the equipment is very temperamental and the sound keeps cutting out.

Easy to get to by the subway - Gwanghwamun Station on Line 5. You walk out the station and there is a statue of King Sejong- past the statue is the Palace with the guards in uniform. Worth visiting for a look at a bygone era and existence.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is close to the city center is thus the most frequented by tour groups. Visit early in the morning to avoid the crowds. The National Folk Museum of Korea is connected to the complex, so visit this as well when you're in the area.
Loved the changing of the guards! Afterwards we were invited to take pictures with the guards who were very patient with the many tourists.
Great view into Korean history. Do the self guided audio tour or join a live tour. Well worth it.

Compared to the palaces in Beijing, Gyeongbokgung Palace are not that impressive as a whole. But there are some interesting parts in the palace that are awe-inspiring. Its big moat in the middle of the palace & the changing of the guards are just a few of it.

the palace is intersting to visit if you would like to see one of the Korean palaces. However, the palace is not original and has been rebuilt recently, which explains the good quality and freshness of the painting.

Gyeongbokgung Palace (景福宮)... the most Beautiful Palace ever !! Myself and with 6 other of my girl-friends are first time visit palace. We manage watching the colourful changing of the guards on time at around 10am and walked around for about 2 hours.  Admission Fees : Adults 3000 won (Closed on Tuesday)  getting there by subway : 1. Use exit #5 of Gyeongbokgung Station (Subway Line #3), 2. From Exit #2 of Ganghwamun Station (Subway Line #5), walk 400 meters

One of five palaces in Seoul, it has been fully restored. It's a large fenced complex with many different buildings. Most of the buildings cannot be entered, but some, including the throne room, have the doors open so you can see inside. Do take the video tour, it has a built in GPS so the narration automatically starts as you approach each viewing point. The changing of the guards, every hour on the hour, is colourful and worth seeing. My favourite parts were the stone animal statues and the large pavilion set in the water.  Probably not interesting to small children as there's a lot of walking and not much to do.
It seems like they have a lot of students going there for field trips

It is a huge palace complex that you can wander around. It's a great way to spend a nice afternoon outside. If you are visiting, to see some well maintained or restored traditional palace buildings. I would say it is a definite must to see at least one of the palaces if you are visiting South Korea. For those that live here, you should have been to one by now.

I'm not a history or culture enthusiast, but visiting Seoul is not complete if you dont visit all those palaces. It's nice because it was my first timer, what you expect will be the colourful unique designs. Excellent for photo taking and memorable photo of Seoul trip. nothing much to see and expect on the changing of guard , just a procession with colourful guard marching and playing traditional musical instruments. easily accessible by subways (Gwanghamon or Geongbukgung st).
great for learning about korean culture, architecture is nice too. it is massive, so recommend visiting when youve got some energy!

Good for learning Korean culture for those who is very curious and interested but to some it will be boring and tiring. When I went there, a ceremonial parade was taken place where there are Koreans who wear hanbok so we took a lot of pictures, you'll see different kind of old building of Korean Monarchy.

This palace is a great place to visit to get a glimpse of Korea's history. Definitely get an audio guide if you do not take a guided tour. Without the background information, you are likely to miss out on a lot of key facts.
This was a great half day trip. The history was interesting, the grounds are nice and inside is the folk museum. If the weather is nice, take a picnic.

If you have seen any European, Chinese, or Japanese palaces/temples, this will be a bit of a let down. The architecture is nice enough, but there very little interest-holding power here. Nicest thing about the place is the mountains in the background.  Thronging with tourists as well, not a MUST SEE if I'm honest.

Ponds, nooks, crannies, pavillions, surprises, ....its all here. The changing of the guard is quite a ceremony so don't miss it. Check with tourist office(s) to find out the daily schedule (depends on time of year of visit).

If you are short on time, and only have one palace to visit while you are in Seoul. I really recommend Gyeongbokgung Palace to be your pick. It has an extensive ground. They layout is great and easy to navigate through and the buildings are so beautiful. I was just in time to see the cherry blossoms still in bloom. It is a beautiful and serene place. A must see on my list of things to see while you are in Korea.

Visited this and CheongDuk Gung. We liked this one better--more spacious, more impressive. Terrific gift shop at the adjacent Folk Museum. Didn't stop to take a photo in traditional costume but it looked fun.

The grounds of this palace was just stunning and huge. Free guided tours are provided in several languages. A children's museum and an art museum are also here. I was expecting to be here for about an hour, but ended up spending 3-4 hours here.

If you only have time to visit one palace in Seoul make sure it is this one. It is absolutely spectacular and you could easily spend a whole day there. The first day I went it poured with rain so went back a week or so later on a sunny day with blossom starting to appear. Just spectacular in a large city.

The big palace in Capital city of Choseon dinasty were devided by the political reason in early 1900's. Gyeingokgung is the main core place of that big palace and there is the historical spot where Korean last Empress got assasinated by Japanese Yakuja during the termoil era...

I think that one visiting Korea should not miss this place. It is in the heart of the city and very near other must see places like Gwanghamun park and the Blue Mansion. We got to see the changing of the Palace guards which is another good experience. The place covers a vast area and considerable time is needed to go around it. There was also free admission in the National Folk Museum which was also very educational. It might be very helpful though if they placed some historical description on each palace and not only on the entrances. Still, it is a must see for me.
history + scenery = awesome. u'll regret if u dont visit this palace.. a very huge palace.. u can see guard ceremony every hours :)

A beautifully preserved traditional architecture in the center of modern Seoul. Its gardens and lakes are picturesque spots that will provide perfect shooting locations for photography enthusiasts. Take advantage of the free hanbok wearing at the souvenir shop!
Very nice place. Apart from the Palace it is also a park with a great view of mountains.

love the tour guide...she explained everything in detail..do check out the time for the free tour guide...we managed to get more than 10 people to save 600won for the entrance fee..it will be great if you can get more than 10 people and the ticket will be 2400 won ;)

With or without the cherry blossoms, the palace site is one beautiful place you must visit when you are in Korea. Colorful palace guard clothes and flags compliment the intricate design of the roofs of their halls and gates. The vast space makes it good for strolling/roaming around while holding the hands of the one you love and occasionally sneak a kiss or two. :) There are many tourists here but with how huge the site is, you definitely can find a private place where you can sit down and have a heart-to-heart conversation amid the pavilions, lake, and the beautiful backdrop of the Bugak Mountain.

If you only have time to visit one palace in Seoul, visit this one. It's big, elegant, and fun to walk around. You can also visit the national folk museum from there. Plan to spend about 2 hrs there... It's the nicest one in that area thrust me.

Part of planning our itinerary for the day is looking up the different attractions clustered in one area, say Hongdae area. My friend and I decided to dedicate one day to do a 'cultural' tour. We planned on going to a couple of the palaces in Seoul, as well as a museum or two.  Gyeongbokgung Palace comes highly recommended in different Korean travel sites. It is the main palace in the Joseon dynasty. Anyway, we chose to get there before 1:30 PM so we can join the English guided tour of the palace.  The place was already packed with tourists and locals alike. There were different tour groups as well, but the place was big enough that it didn't feel crowded. We paid 3,000 Won each for admission into the palace.  The tour guide spoke English but with a very distinct Korean accent. Being exposed to the Korean English a lot more than my friend, I found it easier to 'understand' compared to my friend. The guide was very knowledgeable and inserted some anecdotes into her tour.  The tour lasted for one hour, but we weren't able to cover everything, so we were left to explore the rest of the compound.  There was also a Royal Changing of the Guards (I think) ceremony as we were leaving.  The reason why I suggest you start your Cultural tour here is that you won't need a tour guide for the other palaces since they are basically set up in a similar fashion.  Restorations are currently being done on some other part of the compound.

This is a must see in Seoul! There are about 5 or 6 palaces... this is by far the best one! There is also a free tour in English everyday. I believe the tour is around 2p.m. Check their website to make sure though. Have a great time!

I think this is the main palace out of all the palaces you can visit in Seoul. The architecture is impressive and well-preserved. We walked around the huge ground for an hour and a half and visited the different halls.

I have been there a few times already and it never gets boring! A great place to visit for a day, also for a picnic. Very well maintained . Don't miss the show at the entrance of the palace, it feels like going back in time! There is one part of the palace that you need to book at least a day before you visit, if you don't you cannot get in. Absolutely loved it!
Was a nice 3 hours looking around this relatively new copy of this 600 year old Palace.

I would not make a special visit to this palace. Both the architecture and the palace ground is uninteresting. The National Folklore Museum is equally dry. (I personally found the exhibits very creepy. May because I am Chinese and a bit superstitious.} However if you are in the area you should not miss the interesting local designer shops, cafes and creative houses in the intricate lane ways east of Samcheongdonggil. If you were here around dinner time there are also numerous restaurants to choose from along this picturesque road.

The guided tour was great. If you miss the schedule, they do have audio guide equipment for loan. It also offers free Korean clothing try-on service, so make sure your ask for the location before heading in.

Gyeongbokgung Palace has been under a restoration process for some years and so far a lot of the buildings have now been outwardly restored. The contents of some are still to be placed. The site is huge so good walking shoes a must, and it does get hot here so plenty of water.... Not many places to get food or drink on-site. The Palace certainly opens your eyes to how things used to be

Highly tourist-ed but a great and easy see in the center of Seoul. Enjoy the walk around the Palace grounds (not a huge amount to see) then be sure to enjoy a bit the plethora of restaurants and drinking establishments (Hofs) around the area. When the smoke drives you coughing from one restaurant or bar (or every one), a walk along the canal is nice!
Vast grounds and beautiful foliage, this place will give you a historical lesson of Seoul in the past

You can spend a good few hours here if you really looked at everything in detail and walk to every section of the palace.  There's a free guided tour (different languages at varying times) available but this is after you buy your entry ticket into the palace (3000 won).  You can't go into any of the buildings but there's some that you can look inside with a description in front.  The changing of the guard is definitely worth seeing as well and occurs every hour.  You really need to walk around the palace to appreciate why some people who worked in the palace in the olden days never even saw the king once the entire time!!

It's the biggest and most well known palace in Korea. How long you stay there is up to you. You could blow through it in an hour, with the pamphlet and a camera or you could stay there for hours with a guided tour. My biggest complaint about any palace in Korea is that they are INCREDIBLY well maintained, so they sometimes lose that feeling of history and age with every coat of fresh paint they slap on, but I have lived here 3 years and they are still pretty amazing sites. They are huge complexes in the center of one of the worlds largest cities and they really give you an idea of what life was like in Korea ages ago. Fall is the most beautiful time to go because it is not too hot and the fall colors actually make it even more gorgeous than in spring (aIs surprising as it sounds). It also gives you really beautiful views of the mountains, the Blue House where the President lives and it is quite large. It might be difficult for kids that are too small because you just look at things, you cant really interact or enter buildings, but kids above the age of 7 I'm sure would find a way to enjoy it. It's perfect if you are taking family visiting Korea, if you are a family visiting Korea, teens, friends or couples.

The Korean government is currently reconstructing the buildings of this palace. Before the Japanese ocupation the palace had 800 buildings; during the occupation all but 10 buildings were torn down. The project to restore Gyeongbokgung is a fifty year project; half the project has already been completed. The reconstruction has been made difficult by urban expansion. The work done so far is very impressive and I look forward to seeing Gyeongbokgung in all its glory in the future.
Though buildings are extensively reconstructed, it is enjoyable to wander around and immerse oneself in the historic architecture of a bygone Korea.
we were only in Seoul for 27 hours, but we managed to visit this palace. It was definitely worth the visit, it is very easy to get to, picturesque, and the changing of the guards is very cool!

This became one of the highlights of our tour, not only because of the Palace and grounds, but also we got to try on a traditional Korean costume!  First, the Palace and grounds ... the area was bigger than I expected and had a bit of a tiring walk to explore, but I didn't mind because this meant it didn't seem to be as crowded. The Palace and other buildings were majestic and I liked the feeling of history it brought for me. We arrived there at around 3PM, which was perfect timing because we witnessed the "guard" show. Not sure if it was meant to be a changing of the guards, or a reenactment of a historical event (I wasn't paying attention when they announced it) but I did enjoy the show.  Then there's the traditional Korean costume. As we explored, we noticed a sign beside the coffee shop showing some traditional costumes. Turns out that they allow you to try on a traditional Korean costume! And it's for free! But when we got there, they already had quite a long waiting list and couldn't accommodate us anymore. So my friends and I went back early the next morning, just so we could experience this. The costume place opens at 10AM, and they allow you to have it on for about 15 minutes, in which time you can explore around in costume in nearby areas to give you the perfect photo opp. :-)
Bring a camera. You'll find lots of beautiful pictures. It is large, so be prepared for a lot of walking. You can buy a little box that describes what you are seeing in several languages. Enjoy!
Its really nice. It reminded me of the Korean soap operas. When you're inside you will imagine how life was like in the old times. The place is very clean and well kept.

Visit one and you got the idea of how it look like all. Pretty bland and less ornaments compare to palaces in Japan. But its Korean humbleness who win peoples heart. Humble, pure and tradition above all.
The palace is clean and there is a wonderful performance on changing of guards at certain time of the day. However, there are a lot of tourists in the palace and it is therefore very crowded.
Very nice palace. Unfortunately the interior is shown only on small maps and not with open windows to let you look inside. Palace guards are very helpful with foreigners

Between Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung, i prefer Gyeongbokgung, as there is more to see and the secenary was much better.  There is also the guard changing ceremony that happens every hours in front of the palace and if u want have some good food. At Gyeongbokgung station exit 2 there is Tosokchon (토속촌) the famous Samgyetang shop which even the president of korea patronises.  So all in all a good all round place to visit.

was having a high hope when coming over to checkout the palace. When we arrive it is a bit of disappointing as it look bit barren / empty.  if you're visiting here on summer i suggest to visit here in the evening as the sun is too hot to move around.  there is a museum nearby which the access is free of charge :)
Take the free tour. Really worth the 1 hour time. You will be given time to take photos.

I am quite surprise when I reached this palace. I don't have much expectation as I thought this is just a palace with buildings and garden. What surprise me is the surrounding scenery. What a beautiful place! I went there during autumn, and the leaves are so beautiful, especially the scenery near the lake. The ticket is quite cheap. Worth visiting!

Gyeongbukgung is the crown jewel of Seoul's collection of royal palaces, with complete access at no more than a few US dollars. You could honestly spend all day wandering its huge expanse, there's just so much history there and so many different styles of architecture to appreciate as well. Besides the main pavilions, I recommend seeing the Hyangwonjeong Pavilion towards the north gate and the Gyeonghoeru (Royal Banquet Hall), set on water. But honestly, its worth it to just take your time and wander through the whole thing leisurely and read the posted information along the way. I loved Gyeongbukgung so much I went twice during my trip! On a side note, do not miss either the National Palace Museum (separate 1,000W admission) or National Folk Museum attached to Gyeongbukgung.
good museums within. but you can tell it is just too touristy. not ORIGINAL

Very cheap admission (KRW2,000) for what you get. There was some sort of changing of the guard type thing around 11am. Unsure if it's hourly or at a certain time of the day. Over crowded with tour groups in the front main buildings. There's plenty of ground to cover in the back and fewer people.

We went to Gyeongbokgong palace only to watch the Opening of Royal Guard Changing Ceremony at 10 am in the morning at the main entrance. This is a great opportunity to experience the rare traditional scene just in front of us. We were so excited and took photos with the traditional costume of the Guards after the ceremony. While waiting for the ceremony to be started, we took the opportunity to visit National Palace Museum located on the left of Gyeongbokgong main entrance which is free admission.

I have one day to visit the sites of Seoul while on a recent business trip. This was a must see and the changing of the guards ceremony made it especially nice. It helped that I had an excellent tour guide, but all in all the beauty of the grounds spoke for themselves. The museum on the grounds was a bit hokey. Then again, I'm not a big museum person so probably not fair to criticize! I recommend this on the list of things to see -- if you go here, I would skip other temple sites. This was clearly the best.

I'd like to start off by saying that I'm a history buff - especially the dynasties of East Asian countries. Having read so much good reviews, I made this palace my top priority during my visit. To say that I was disappointed would have been an understatement. It was like a palace on a budget. Don't go expecting the splendor of a bygone era. The sprawling grounds are filled with identical buildings with little to differentiate from one to another. Even my poor hard-working tour guide was hard put to infuse much enthusiasm into the group which had gone there with so much anticipation.

When in Seoul as a tourist this is the #1 attraction. When on business and having 1-2 hours spare time during the day or weekend, visit this place. Although reconstructed after much destruction by the Japanese colonists and relatively simple for a palace, the overall experience is great and the grounds make for a nice walk. Entry WRN 3,000. Be prepared for herds of tourists though during weekends & holidays, so probably during the week is a better experience. When I was there in August it was quite warm but above all very humid, so prepare for some serious sweating while walking the grounds. The National Folk museum in the back on the right is OK, if you have another hour and to cool off, but more interesting for locals than for foreigners. Entry for the museum is free. Showing your palace ticket will let you enter the palace grounds again.

Make sure you bring your walking shoes, the facility is huge! We saw a lot of people with bad shoes on. This is an amazing opportunity to see history. What a treat! The museum is also quite good. It is well worth the money and your time. Great for kids and adults. It may be difficult to bring someone in a wheelchair.

The low cost of the palace makes it worth it to just walk in and take a look around. I believe a majority of it is all reconstructed, so you aren't looking at centuries old buildings. You can still be impressed with the grounds and the effort to protect the culture and history.

It's 3000 Won to enter, which isn't bad. This palace is really intact and you can tell that they keep it preserved very well. The architecture is amazing! You can't fully go inside, but you can take a peek inside, to see how the other half lived back in the day.

Entering the Palace grounds is deceptive - it is really a large complex and you could spend a good deal of time exploring the buildings (re-creations). There are ceremonies near the entrance with folks in period costumes. The architectural details are beautiful. There is a good museum across the street. We did the palace grounds - then had lunch (bibimbop) nearby and then went to the museum. You can also walk to the Blue House from here - that's the Korean White House where their President lives.

Having seen so many palaces and temples in Asia, we inititally thought this would be an hour long, in and out, type of attraction. To my amazement, between the palace, the changing of the guard and the two museums on the grounds of the palace, we spent the better part of the day here.  The Palace grounds themselves, house many different buildings in more than once style, so it is worth it to wander and see all the areas and the gardens that connect them. Everything is well kept and protected. Some buildings have rooms furnished and set up to give one a glimpse of how daily life was conducted in this palace. Although the changing of the gaurd is an obvious tourist catch with university age guards with glued on beards, it is still a fun and colourful display. There are two free museums on the grounds that are most definitely worth a visit as well. The Royal museum contains a restaurant, that while not cheap, offers high quality food that is very tasty.

I think the many many other reviews have said it all. Just want to share some info that visitors may need. There are free (?) guided tours in various languages. And on weekends, there are free guided tours by volunteer organizations, which is what we took. Our guide was a 13 year old high school student. While we were there, we could try on Korean traditional costumes for free and for a very good laugh. ;) The palace is closed every Tuesday.  While Gyeongbok Palace is definitely worth a visit, we heard that Changdeokgung Palace and its gardens were even better. Unfortunately, did not get to see Changdeokgung as we went on a Monday when it was closed ;( so do plan your trips!

Gyeongbokgung palace, the obvious seat of government in older times, is a showpiece for the city, staring down at the city's main avenue through the reconstructed Gwanghwamun gate, giving it the proper sightlines so important in eastern palace layouts. Seen from the outside from the newly built pedestrian center area of that avenue, the gate and palace grounds are nicely framed by a backdrop of green mountains. Being the main palace in Seoul, it features a number of displays, including performers in traditional dress showing various aspect of court pageantry. Also worth visiting is the folk museum within. The buildings are predictable large and ornate, and more geometrically laid out than at other palaces. The detailing and shape of the roofs are unique, and the large number of carved stone figures, some of them unfortunately encased in transparent boxes due to unruly visitors, interesting indeed. As usual in such palaces, the women's sleeping quarters have a more livable look to them. Maintenance and upkeep are very good, reflective of the country's current prosperity.

Impressive and interesting palace though we preferred nearby Changdeokgung Palace, which has a more scenic setting. Gyeongbokgung is more out in the open. In addition to the palace buildings, the main things we liked about Gyeongbokgung were the changing of the guard ceremony and nearby location to the Blue House and Bukchon Hanok Village, which were both worth visiting.
This was a beautiful area to walk around and learn some Korean history. The ticket price was very reasonable. Very nice gift shop/cafe.
It is good place to visit if you walk lovers and would like to knownsome history. I went with kids . We enjoyed but avoid to visit in hot day.

Visit the palace with Korean traditional costume (you could book it at shops nearby) allows you to enter the palace free of charged. Most authentic ancient feel in Korea! So beautiful with a mountain view behind the palace.
The palace is pretty big and nice, you can buy your ticket at the counter specially for foreigners. Also if you wear a hanbok you can enter for free
I wasn't expecting much, but the history and details of this place impressed me. It is a large complex with many buildings. Each building has a unique and interesting purpose. Go with a guide.
I had the chance to visit the site after a business meeting nearby, this is very impressive and gives an idea about history of Korea
Infrastructure takes us to experience ancient times. A lot of diversified people & travelers you can see over there
You must get a ticket to get in the palace. Its totally worth to visit. Try to spend 1 to 2 hours here to discover this beautiful palace.
Great for those who want to know more about the history and culture, and no you don’t really need a tour guide if you just want to take pretty photos and they had traditional wear for rental as well
We rented those traditional Korean clothes, Hanbok, and took many picturesque photos. Worth doing. There is a cafe in the palace and so you can relax there in between taking photos.
Took a tour of the palace. Got some great photos, saw the changing of the guard ceremony and learned some history. It's definitely a must see if you visit Seoul
They also have free guided tours at few intervals of day. Local wear traditional attire while visiting this place.
Super awesome place! I really love everything from here . Would like to go back again here! Super worth it
Rent a hanbok and you can enter the palace free of charge. Hanbook rental can be found nearby the palace (to the right of the palace entrance).
Easy to reach Gyeongbokgung palace with public transportation and many small restaurants not too far from the palace.
such an amazing place to visit. we got a chance to wear a hanbok and moved around the palace..like we transfered back to Joseon Dynasty..love the feeling so much.
Beautiful and historic spot in central Seoul. A must visit if you visit South Korea. Make sure to catch the guard change too!
Beautiful grounds. Historical and informative. We especially enjoyed seeing all the folks wearing the traditional folk dress.
Make sure you take in the changing of the guard, we did the 1030hrs. Also do not miss visiting the museums, both are well worth it; best to set aside most of the day to do the museums justice.
This place is huge, elegant and historical. There are a few guards changing event, but the main event happen @ 11am.

Gyeongbokgung Palace was the first and largest of the royal palaces built during the Joseon Dynasty. Built in 1395, Gyeongbokgung Palace was located at the heart of newly appointed capital of Seoul (then known as Hanyang) and represented the sovereignty of the Joseon Dynasty.  Beautiful architecture and they restore the building quiet well after the first palace was invaded by the Japanese back in 1945 - 1948 where Korea was attack, much of the building in the palace was run down and destroyed, they were moved to the second palace in Cheongdeokgung Palace.  There were beautiful matching presentation to shows how the army and General March during the dynasty and how they serve the king during Joseon Dynasty. Lovely wonderful place ☺️☺️☺️

This is one of the main sights in Seoul. It looked like most was modern reconstruction, but it was still very impressive. The place was clean and quite large too. There are so many museums and galleries close by too.
Very beautiful grounds and buildings. Most fun was visitors dressing up period costume (guess they are available for rent) and taking photos, etc.

An essential part of any visit to Seoul. Unsurprisingly, the palace is a smaller version of the Forbidden City in Beijing. If you are wearing traditional Korean costume (hanbok) you get in for free, so when we were there about a third of the visitors were wearing traditional Korean garb, which gave the whole experience the feel of being at a masquerade. Do not miss the changing of the guard at 10:00 AM. There is an adequate English tour at 11:00, at no extra change.
If you're visiting Seoul just for a day, do not miss Gyeongbukgung Palace. Also wearing a hanbok allows you free entrance on most attractions in Seoul.
Very inexpensive and gorgeous grounds to explore. Don't miss seeing the changing off the guards. My teenagers loved it!

Beautiful architecture, it is somehow like a scaled down version of the Forbidden Palace in Beijing. Missed the change-of-guards though. If you are one to look at details, you can spend a whole day here. Entrance to palaces in Seoul are considered cheap. This palace entrance fee is KRW3,000 but I opted to purchase the package that include few more palaces as well for only KRW10,000. Weather was pleasantly cool in November, and the autumn leaves are stunning

It has some semblance to the Forbidden City but on a smaller scale. Dont miss changing of the guards that takes place at intervals.  Two types of tickets: palace only at W3k and a 4-Palaces combi ticket at W10k. We went for the cheaper one.  The main throne hall sits majestically in the centre with other buildings behind, linked by covered walkway. Behind the complex is a garden (I imagine it would be beautiful in summer) and a stream. There is a souvenir shop and toilet. There dont seem to be a place where we are allowed inside so we only take a peep through the window.  An experience to immerse yourself in the imperial Korean times.
Visited this place 2x last month since i didn't know you can't go deeper inside into the palace. In case, if anyone wants to see their guard changing time, 10AM and 2PM

This is a very large open area. The buildings can only be viewed from the outside. I find it amazing that the colors seem so fresh while being exposed to the weather. It was interesting to see so many tourists dressed in traditional hanbok costumes, especially when they are taking photos of each other. Didn't know that was a "thing" until later. The changing of the guard is an interesting ceremony to watch.

This is a large expansive complex that really requires at least three hours to experience. And with the ridiculously cheap admission rates, you will definitely get your money's worth. A lot of people (locals and tourists alike) enjoy renting traditional Korean clothes (hanbuk) and often mill around throughout. Photos are accepted; just politely ask first. It really is a 5 star attraction; I am just not into this type of thing and would rather spend my time in a local neighbourhood hanging out which is why I gave it 4 stars.

The palace with its vast grounds is more than 600 years old and reflects Korean traditional architecture. Don't miss the changing of the guards ceremony at the Gwanghwamun gate at 10 am and 2 pm. It is quite elaborate and different. You get to pose with the guards for photos, after the cermony. Entry fee is 3000 won per person.
