This is the most popular palace by far. It's central location and the importance of its gate is very clear. The grounds are well-kept and vast. There are many interesting things to see here and even a museum inside (that's totally worth a visit), but I have to say that having visited all of the palaces in Seoul, this one is not the best in my opinion. I would advise visiting Changdeokgoong and getting a tour of the Secret Royal Gardens. It's a stunning place, and the quiet nature of the gardens is surprising. There is no city noise at all.
One palace that you should not miss during your trip to seoul. A lot of walking as the palace area is quite huge but it is worth it.
Beautiful place. There's a museum on the grounds too. Don't miss the ceremony of the change of guards. Impressive!
I spent a morning with a group here. Great way to spend half a day exploring and learning. Cost was low and grounds were spectacular. A must see.
The palace " compound " is quite large... looks deceptively small from the outside but once inside is a treasure trove of history and beautiful architecture... a must see if visiting S Korea

This is so far the best Palace in Seoul as this is very big and there's a Korean National Museum inside which is free of charge. There are also palace guards demonstration and you can wear traditional Korean attire. This is also very near to many tourist spots which you can only walk to enjoy the city view along the way.

Gyeongbokgung palace is the largest palace in Seoul. Within its compound, you would find other museums too. There are guard changing ceremonies and English guided tours at various timings of the day. It would be wise to plan in advance. Do note that it's closed on Tuesdays. If you are planning to visit the secret garden at Changdeokgung Palace, you would be better off getting the combi ticket at 10,000 won and this valid for 1 month.  If you are visiting in January, make sure you have sufficient winter clothings as the palace tours can get fairly chilly at times.  Also, make sure you have a good breakfast too as you are likely to spend more than half a day here.
One of the most popular tourist destination in South Korea. Highly recommended for first time visitors.
We went to the palace and it was such an wonderfull day. I never thought that this place is so big! There is also a museum for free. Next time I will also go there!

If you're going to see one palace, choose this palace. Changing of the guards was nice, and they let you take pictures with the guards after (like London), and same rules apply, don't touch them. More than the changing of the Guards, what I liked more was just being able to roam around the palace and take many pictures on their grounds, it is so surreal, so many historical K-dramas floated through my mind. The trees on this property are so gorgeous, my eyes kept floating from the plants to the architectures and back. Once I visited this palace, I didn't feel the need to see any other. They also have a cute and very clean café to purchase snacks and drinks. My only regret was not knowing to rent a traditional hanbok (Korean dress), before going to this Palace. There were other tourist there that thought ahead, and went to places to rent a hanbok and headdress, and they looked really good taking pictures at the palace. I'm planning on visiting this place again, and this time I will rent a hanbok ;)
Easy to get to using public transport and worth seeing while in Seoul! If you only have time to visit one palace, this is it.

We walked around the palace. The palace is not huge but beautiful. Not much we can enjoy due to a limited time. Most of the time we use to take photos. We were lucky to come when the weather is sunny in the winter.

I was expecting a rather huge Palace before I headed over to Korea but my group of 10 only stayed in the Palace for 1.5hr before we got really bored and left.  It's worth a visit but don't bother spending too much time there. Not much to see as compared to the different castles or palaces around the world.

I'm a fan of historic drama series and one in particular was set in this palace so it was exciting to visit the place and see it for myself. Beautifully maintained, with informative signage, it's a "must see" stop in Seoul.

Went here with my girlfriend and it was nice to see some historical architecture. The buildings have AC and the palace grounds are incredibly wide and long, will require 1 or 2 hours to see the entire place.
This place is in downtown Seoul. Great place to see some Korean architecture and history. This place has guided tours in english and specific times . Please make sure to check these times.

I love strolling the compound with beautiful tree and flowers, well maintained and preserved palace. Surrounded by modern and tall building makes it special. A lot of walking but the landscape is very nice and picturesque. Rebuilt architecture but still a great place to visit. Beautiful maple and ginkgo tree in the compound. Love it!
It was interesting to visit the palace and get to know more about the history of korean. Recommended for families.
Reached just nice at a time they were having the change of guards ceremony.. huge place, wonderful architecture...

It was very fun to visit the palace and I must say a must go for the trip to Korea. If you wanna experience wearing hanbok, there are some shops that rent out hanbok nearby but just make sure you do some comparison first as there are definitely gonna be some differences, regardless in terms of price or the hours of rental.  Furthermore, if you were to wear hanbok to enter the palace, you get a waiver of the entrance fee so it's a hit on 2 birds with 1 stone isn't it?  Enjoy your trip at gyeongbokgong palace as I did.

I haven't been to KyeongBok Palace during this trip but this is The Glimpse into the old palace of Korea representing how it was back in those days, rather last centuries and not that old. It's pretty but not as big as the Forbidden city in Beijing of course. Not much as left except for the building in both palaces of course but it's nice to have some remnants of old times.
Beautiful palace peaceful very well presented Worth a visit we did not get to see all there were heaps to see

We ran into changing of the guards and it had narrations in 4 different languages so most travellers would be able to understand. Great buildings and architecture for understanding the history of Korean royalty. Just hope there were some guidebooks for us to follow. It was a bit boring because there wasn't enough guide of the purpose the the buildings. At the end, it ended up with quite a lot of similar buildings.

This area is very huge so I would suggest a pair of comfortable shoes when you visit this place. There is free wifi and tours. Also, one can dress up in traditional korean clothing while strolling inside the palace. Don't miss out on the change of guards ceremony in front of the palace gate (facing Gwanghamun Square).

Recently featured in several UK tv documentaries which prompted the visit. An outstanding, quite large palace comprising a number of well maintained and beautifully decorated buildings. Time your visit to include the changing of the guard - a rare experience!

The photo spot at the corner angle view spot is the better point to aim your back ground photo shoot especially with mountain as a back drop  Just stand still... hahaha...  the history about this palace surely can mean something to any tourist if they feel related to the object..hard for me to tell more  Scenery enjoyment ... yeah you will get that...

A pretty well reserved place, beautiful! You can really get a pick of Korea's history here. Not much of an.exhibition inside the constructions but plenty of places to walk around and get amazing photos. Kind of hard during winter considering the amount of time spent outside.

You will recognise many locations appearing in Korean dramas. A very beautiful place to take a slow and romantic walk. Alas I was with my young children. Seems that you get free entrance if you are wearing the hanbok which we didn't try. But seeing many people in hanbok set a very nice atmosphere. It is also in walking distance to the famous ginseng chicken restaurant so plan to visit before or after your lunch :)

Recommended to buy the Combination ticket that costs W10,000 and gives admission to 5 sites plus the Secret Garden. Advisable to look for the schedule for the guided tours and the changing of guards which are listed online for easier planning. This is easily the most crowded of all Palaces in Seoul. There are also 2 good museums onsite - the National Palace Museum and National Folklore Museum Museum. The Gwanghwamun, Bukchon Hanok Village are also around so this visit can easily take up the entire day. Nearby the excellent Tosokchon Samgyetang restaurant is a must visit for ginseng chicken soup.

Make sure you go for the changing of the guards and also in time for the guided tours which are free and very informative. Lots of teenage couples walking around with traditional clothing and they don't mind having their pictures taken.
This is a notable Seoul attraction. As such, it gets huge lines. Plan accordingly. Have visited twice now.

A great place to wander as well as to look into Korean culture. A great place to just take your time.  Try to catch the changing of the guards.  Great for people who love taking photos. So many spots and things to capture.  Does require a bit of walking, though an easy walk.

Basically only myselg and mom (no other selection can be done). In this gigantic palace and also a main palace which later rebuilt in years, the Josean dynasty has been using other palaces as their main palace.  It was to my surprise of the beauty of the palace and a must visit museum to understand the entire historical era of S.Korea kings dynasty. Again, our private tour guide, Juno was like a walking history book explaining to me what was that all about.  You can see the water clock, the astrology of the olden days with truly brilliant creation and characters that they have used. The sun dial really beautiful and so do the map of the stars.  Gwanghwamun also together in this itin and fascinating by looking at it. The palace is so huge to be true with different set of furnitures, walk way, crafted stones and auspicious animals of ancient belief.  Don't forget to see the guards changing time and take a shot with them. That is cool!!  Well, check out yourself if you truly indulge into some olden cultures history frel like me besides K-pop! You can even drop by the nearer eating place to raste the beef soup rice to give you warm feeling in a cold winter! No regrets!

We paid a small admission fee to enter the palace grounds. There were many beautiful buildings to look at. We had visited Changdeokgung Palace just prior to this one, and the buildings in both were somewhat similar.
A nice place to visit, small entry fee, but if you really want to learn something go to the Palace museum that are just inside the grounds. Good descriptions in English.
It was really beautiful and quiet. We went during the MERS scare, so it was very empty. The people working there were very friendly.
Very Interesting worthwhile site to visit. No/minimal entrance fee. (Free during our trip) Accessible by subway. Not so crowded and wonderful photo opportunities.

Probably the grandest of the palaces in Seoul, I really enjoyed walking around the gardens and the peaceful scenery with the mountains in the background. Come early before the hoards of tour buses arrive!

Had a good understand on the palace layout during the Joseon dynasty. Met many Korean visitors wearing Hanbok and taking pictures with loved ones around this serene place. A must visit place if one wishes to get a glimpse into the glamour of Joseon dynasty and the life of the royal family as well as the government officials.

This palace has a lot of history about Korea and its kings' lives. The free guided tours (in English, Mandarin, and Japanese) are very informative and gives quite a lot of information about the past. Worth checking the change of guard that happens twice a day. Don't miss the free guided tour which lasts for about 1.5 hours.

This is the largest and arguably the most beautiful of the palaces in Seoul and a must see, with many splendid sights, including several national treasures and the originally conserved Gyeonghoeru Pavilion and Hyangwonjeong Pond. You'll want to reserve 2-3 hours to savour everything there is to see here.
We got to hire humboks and we got in to this for free and walked around in costume while seeing this place. We got to see the changing of the guards display also.

We had visited the Palace and watched the Guard Changing Ceremony which happens daily here and is a must watch. They have a band and guards in colorful uniform carrying flags and marching towards the gate. Many people gather around to watch this ceremony. Once you enter the palace, there is the Main Entry, where you get best WIFI connection but do not waste your time sitting in there and move ahead, you will be surprised at how vast this palace is although it seems small from the outside. Also one can see the architecture, museum (inside premises), relax in the garden area and learn a lot about Korean culture and influence.

I guess a visit to a palace is a "must" for any visit to Seoul, unless you have zero interest in history or photography. If you only have time for 1, make Gyeongbokgung the place to go. Coming here is pretty easy via the Metro (at the very imaginative "Gyeongbokgung station"). Once you exit the station, there are numerous signs to tell you where to go, and you come out at the National Palace Museum. It is easy to spend an entire day here esp. if you visit both museums (the other is the Folk Museum), wait for the guard-changing ceremony, plus taking pictures of the palaces.

If you are into historic place, this is a must go and we had the chance to see the change of the palace guards but my kids were a little scared of the fierce looking guards though they were just standing and everyone was taking turns to take photos with them. It was Cultural Day when visited so it was free entry. Plenty of young ladies and gentlemen dressed in Korean traditional costumes in the cold winter. Some of the area in the palace was covered with snow. Very pristine. A short walk a way from the palace was the National Palace Museum and then across the Museum was the area for Bukchon Hanok. A must go for tourists. The Palace grounds wasn't very stroller friendly as the steps was not even but they had ramp everywhere that had stairs to ease the way for those with strollers and wheelchairs.

It's a nice palace with Korean architecture. We can go around the outer part of the building - not the inside one.  Please go inside the National Forklore Museum to learn about the culture. Worth knowing. * TK
It is a typical beautiful,well conserved palace in Seoul and you can see the change of guards outside!
This place is not worth a visit. I have visited many palaces around the world and this is really a minimalist palace. Can skip.

This is such a beautiful place! We went in early october at night when there was a light show as well, many people dressed up in traditional outfits (which can be rented in the surrounding town area). Very grand, clean, and very worth the visit.

It is our second time visiting the palace, and this time the feeling is different, which educated us to use a simple and humble angle to appreciate how the ancient Korean Royal families were also very humble and not excessive, and appeared in matching role and status.

Easy to get there via subway. However, it's a long walk for old people who cannot walk fast and long especially during the winter and windy days. Muzeum is informative. The restaurant serves good food and prices are reasonable compared to those outside. Should provide English speaking staff to explain things to visitors though. The change of guard is nothing much and not worth waiting for. Go during last Wednesday of the month and you get free entrance.

they have the guided tours a couple of times a day, some in chinese and mostly in english. the lady guide we had was informative and courteous. other than seeing all the interesting structures there, one could wander just a bit to the presidential palace next door for a photo.

The palace ground was immense so be prepared to walk for an hour or more. There are a lot of people wearing hanbok so it was quite a sight. It was like being time warped to the earlier days of Seoul. Be sure to catch the changing of the palace guards. We were here last autumn and the trees were colorful and dramatic. Perfect place to practice your photography skills and do pictorials.

This palace just keeps on giving.  After nearly every gate, there was another amazing gate. Behind which was another beautiful and ornate structure. The architecture and design of the grounds gives you an insight into the power that was concentrated here.  A word of advice. In the winter, be prepared. There is no heated building in the palace. We arrived early in the morning and froze our toes. Our only saving grace was the nearby and semi attached museum at the back of the palace grounds.  In fact, even though the entrance fee for the palace was minimal at roughly 3$, I found it odd that if entering from the back side palace entrance to go to the museum, you can essentially enter both the museum and the palace for free.  The museum was amazing, but i will review it on its own.

This is a huge place so be prepared for a lot of walking. There are some buildings that have some furniture but most are empty. There are informative signs which are helpful and they are in English. This is where they have a very colorful changing of the guards.. if you don't get the pictures you want, they will stand out in front of the palace so you can get your picture taken with them. There is a small building where you can try on their outfits and heve your picture taken. Thereare beautiful grounds with a lake. bring a picinic.

While there are three other palaces in Seoul, I don't think you can go wrong with this one. Like almost everything historical in Korea, it's been reconstructed after being destroyed during the Japanese colonial period. The job has been done well, though. Walking through the huge park is wonderful, and a stop for traditional treats is worth the extra 10,000 won, especially considering the cheap price of admission. Throw in the free folk museum, which is big enough itself to spend a few hours, and the whole complex is one not to miss while in Seoul.

Gyeongbokgung is a beautiful tourist spot where you can learn more about Korea. Aside from that, it's a nice place for a walk because it's a huuuugggeee place.  Good thing about it is it's also walking distance Changdeokgung Palace, Bukchon Hanok Village, and the famous monuments.  You can also watch the guard changing ceremonies (if you find it interesting)

If you have a short time visiting South Korea, you don't have to go to every palace in Seoul but just go here. You can already experience the vibe of Joseon Dynasty by going to Gyeongbokgung. If you don't want to pay the entrance fee, try wearing hanbok and take pictures like the old days! It's a good place during autumn when most of the trees turn brown, red and yellow.

A palace not that different from the forbidden city in Bejing! Entry is about 3 dollars and it's definetly worth a visit!  Make sure to take to the left after the palace and then walk straight up by the little pond to have a great view of the national folklore museum.
Everything is ok with this palace. The only truth is all buildings are max 50 years old. Here is no historical or authentic brick at all. Guard changing is intresting to watch.
I like the place. Our host brought us to this place to experience Korean culture and history. It's clean and enjoyable. I've learned a lot about their culture. Great experience.👍

Can't complete your must-see list if you don't see the Changing of the Guards. It's like a parade of colors. I loved the outfits and the movements. It's outdoor and it lasts for less than 10 minutes, so don't be late. The whole place is grand and abounds with history and culture. Roam at leisure. Tickets are for going inside towards palace and not necessary for watching the Changing, but it's for a minimal fee and worth going around. Quite accesible by train because station is near. You can plan to walk to Bukchon Village to complete your itinerary.

Remember to spare some time here as this place is big and pretty time consuming to visit. This is a must see place to all the tourists. The view and atmosphere there was pretty nice. They are lots of girls that dress up with hangbok. It's a very nice place to take pictures and for long walking. Remember to catch the changing of guard at Gwanghwamun.
In this place you can see the biggest castle or south korea and its history, you cAn rent a traditional costume too

A humungous palace with lots of walking to do and much to learn on. So allow yourself at least half a day to take your time to go through this whole complex. It's a paid entry. If you want a free entry, you may go to the museum that is to the side of this palace. To get to see imperial Korean history, this is the place to be if you have limited time in Seoul. Other palaces are typically similar to this one. It's usually filled with tourists, especially in warmer months, so expect to have other people in your photos of the scenery and selfies.

The palace is spread over a huge area. It's really nice to have a stroll around and explore the different part. The only thing is, after a while everything starts looking the same, especially if you have visited other palaces and temples in Korea. You will see the same motifs and architecture everywhere.
If you love culture and history I'm recommend this place for you since there are many places near it you will need a full day to visit them.

We came on a day which was free admission. The grounds are really serene with a bridge over a large pond with lily pads. We saw a many in hanboks from school kids visiting on field trips to tourists renting there's nearby. This was the first palace we visited and it was the better of the 3 in Seoul. The trees were turning already and looked very nice with the building and pond areas. It was a cool, overcast day. We spent only 1hr total here. This is because the buildings are completely empty. This one was rebuilt after being burned down completely by the Japanese. There are no furnishings, items from daily life, or anything you'd see in European palaces or even American grand estates in any of the palaces in Seoul, so it is disappointing in that respect. Maybe all these antiquities are hidden away in museums instead because in we didn't see any of it here or at the other 2.

It is near to several train stations so it won't be hard to visit. They are closed during Tuesdays. But you may opt to go to the National Museum instead, try renting a hanbok too, for the ultimate experience

We went here as one of the last few stops before our flight back that evening. Lovely sights and buildings, very peaceful too. Got the chance to witness the changing of guards ceremony. The guards are kind of the korean version of the London Royal Guard, you can take pictures with them (in their very elaborate garments), but they never smile lol. The ceremony was definitely worth watching! I'm unsure of other schedules, but the one we witnessed was at 11am, so make sure to do some research if you'd like to watch the ceremony!

Bright colors and details with the mountains and city in the background made this place pretty breathtaking. I was only able to go for a short time while on a layover, I'll definitely return to see the guards.
The narratives in the palace give you an idea of history of conflict between Japan and Korea .... in particular Japan's aggression.

One of the palace to see in Seoul. The grounds are huge and eye opening to the structure of the palace in the ancient days. Seeing in person is "wow" as compared to watching in TV drama. I can imagine how one need to walk from one end of the palace to another to talk to someone.

This was the first stop during our half-day guided tour in Seoul. We spent just under an hour touring the castle and grounds. I'm glad we had a guide, because I feel we learned much more about the cite. There are two good clean restrooms, plenty english plaques, and many photo spots. We went in December, which was still beautiful, but seeing this in Spring or Summer with the gardens in bloom would have been even better.
If you go to one place in Seoul, go here. Beautiful buildings to see and lots of walking in the gates.

First visited in the 90s and the experience has much improved since then.  The colorful, authentic replication of the post classical history guards and their ceremonies are a must see. And the idea of being able to wear traditional Korean garb while visiting adds a nice extra touch.  The opening of more exhibits in other parts of the castle depicting more accurate representations of life back then would enhance the experience more.

The palace has plenty of things to see (we eneded up going back later in the week). Try one of the tours there, they are full of information. My family thought some of my photos of the palace were postcards, they were so pretty.
Nothing special about this palace as a lot of the places got " Do not enter" signs on it. But if you like looking at how the king used to live then go visit the place.

The palaces inside all look very similar. And once you go up the steps, you can only look from the outside. I enjoy some of the history but was not interested enough to stay for long. The grounds would be very difficult for strollers to maneuver.

We missed the free guided tour so I think it wasn't as engaging by walking on our own. In comparison with the palaces in China, this wasn't as good. It could do with more explanatory notes/signages for tourists to read about the history / culture. The souvenir shop had really lovely items though. We managed to catch the changing of guards which were interesting.

A very nice place to visit either solo, as a couple or with friends. Easily accessible through the subway and they have free tours with guides in three languages including English. My guide was very friendly and had a good sense of humour. I recommend to visit this place at least once if you visit Seoul

Excellent site. It only cost about 6 dollars to enter the palace grounds. I was surprised how large the attraction was. We only had a couple of hours to tour the palace, so we had to rush through it. It includes a museum that has a lot of history to cover. Access is easy either via cab or metro. We use a cab and it was inexpensive.

Visited the palace with a friend and it is a pleasant stroll with a lot to see. I've been before, and frankly it's better to go in the spring or summer when the flowers are blooming, but it's still worthwhile in the less colorful weather. Lots of people dressed in traditional clothes - you get a discount if you dress in hanbok. Changing of the guard is quite a nice thing to see. (My friend from Korea tells me that the guards are actually young men doing their military service, so they are in fact REAL guards).  The gift shop is lovely also.  The palace is right near a number of other tourist attractions and well worth spending a few hours to see how the royalty of years ago lived.

This is a place to visit if you want a peek into Korean history. The stories about the Kings, and their way of living is intriguing. Make sure you get the audio guide it is only 3000won and give great context to your visit.

A large area need to cover. Quite interesting and beautiful buildings. Only if miss out tge guided tour one won't be able to understand the details of the history. But if follow the guided tour will miss out the Royal Guards Changing Ceremony. Means need to stay in the Palace longer .

Surrounded by the bustling city of Seoul is this wonderfully maintained priceless cultural gem. Take your time to marvel at the architecture and the amazing artwork on the roofs and ceilings. Well worth a stop.

Visited the palace with the free shuttle from Hotel Ibis.  The palace is grand and huge. It was rebuild and it is still in the process of rebuilding as it was destroy during the war. I took the free guided tour and it gives us a good history lesson.  A good place to visit for at least 4 hours and there is also the changing of guards that you should not miss.  A must visit place while you are in Seoul.

From our hotel its just a 20min subway ride, however we have to change to a different line to reach it. The best is to get the guards changing duty time in advance in order to catch it first hand.  It is more of a growth up place, kid really feel bore in this.

Many of my friends been to South Korea and Gyeongbokgung Palace and didn't know that they have Change of Guard. Our private tour guide parked the car right under the palace and we walked up, and ta-da, right inside the palace, and we didn't waste any time waiting, and saw the change of guard ceremony. It is a nice palace, and look like the Forbidden Palace in Beijing in many aspects. Saw it in tour info that if you wear the traditional hanbok, you can enter this place for free, plus few other places in Seoul. We went in July and its too hot to wear hanbok, so not sure if its true.

It is indeed a Must See when in Seoul! The guards changing ceremony is an event to watch by itself! The palace is tremendously huge & majestic! U can spend half a day there & be mesmerized by the scenic view of the palace! Gem of Korea!

This palace was gorgeous! The colours were amazing, unlike any other palace I have visited. It's very big, so you don't feel too crowded with people! Involves a lot of walking because it's so big. Definitely a must see in Seoul!

We sign up the free tour guide to tour the palace. You can sign up thru their visit Seoul website.. it needs a local Seoul contact number in order to do the booking, just choose the language tour that you prefer. The is the largest palace in Seoul. You will need a good 1.5 hours there to really going thru all the attraction in there. There are a few tourist attraction nearby the palace, do plan to spend half a day for this area.
A fantastic Korean heritage place to visit, make you back to ancient and feel the King life. Korean good in maintained and keep that all history to future.

If you are into history, architecture and learning more of the culture of the previous centuries then this visit to the palace is well worth the time spent. If you are not into history, architecture and learning more of the culture of the previous centuries then if you seen one palace, you have seen this palace already since they all are pretty much alike to me during this period in history and in this geographic area. It is huge and you will get your exercise walking the grounds.

After a no show of tour guide which I signed up for half day tour, I decided to go on my own. It is easy to find and the palace provides English speaking tour guide at 3 intervals. She is funny, dramatic and yet very professional. Excellent stories which made this visit very interesting. After the guided tour, you may walk around the palace but two hours should be sufficient as it is rather cold now. Tip: Suggest you stop at the information station to get a map and more info on places to visit at the right hand side at the entrance.

There's a lot of visitor wearing hanbok, which is amazing. You should definetely use hanbok too, there's a lot of places where you can rent the hanbok near anguk station or insadong. They're wearing the hanbok to gyeongbokgung and bukchon hanok village, since the location are kind of near and you can reach one another just by walking.
Very beautiful place with many place to take very nice photos.You can go across the street to rent the Hanbok.

Its a huge palace, right in the middle of the city, made in traditional Korean style. Go early in the day to witness the changing of guards, at 11 am. There is also the museum and presidential palace (blue palace) behind it.

If you visit Seoul, you must see this place because it's very central, and it's also very famous. You'll see a lot of Koreans wearing their traditional clothes there, which is very cute. The street that faces/goes to the palace is very wide and beautiful. There are some statues there in the middle so you'll know it when you see it. Highly recommended.

Toured this palace and was awed with the architecture. The palace complex was huge. There were also 3 museums nearby which were very informative. I especially enjoyed the Folk Museum. Also enjoyed the changing of the guards ceremony which was intricate and colorful.

Din expect it would be so big and din catered sufficient time to cover the whole area. In a way, wasn't with the right crowd as well since I was the only one who watched Kdrama and enjoy scenic walks. Peaceful and pleasant place to have a stroll.  Would recommend to at least visit it once when in Korea

Loved it. Go early to avoid tourist crowd - and also if you want to take photos of the palace buildings without the crowds. There are two museums - National Folk Museum which is a very good introduction to how Koreans used to live up till now (cultures, beliefs, way of life). There's also the National Palace of Museum too.  I opted for MMCA or MOCA which is on the right side of the palace (if u r facing the entrance) - there's a cluster of private galleries too; Hyundai is worth a visit. If you walk further in, there's where the Bukchon Hanok village is located.  On the left of the palace is where all the cafes, eateries and hanbok rentals are. The infamous Tosokchon is there too. Ganghwamun Square is located directly in front of the entrance of the palace too (after the main road).  Just alight at Gyeongbokgung palace and there are clear directions leading you directly to the entrance.
Enjoyed walking around the grounds to this beautiful large palace.Of particular interest was the Folklore museum right next door.

I visited this Palace on my layover stay and i am glad i took up a transit tour package and got the opportunity to witness this magnificent Palace with so much rich history. It's very beautiful and i recommend everyone to visit.

I visited three palaces during my visit and enjoyed this one the most. It is a huge complex and takes time. The Changing of the Guard is a must see--I think they do it at 11 and 2 pm--but check before making plans. If you have been to the large palaces in China, this will seem familiar but still worth it. Cost is only 3000 won--so under $3 US.

As this palace was destroyed by Japanese troops in the late 1500's and as it has been redone in the 1800's and as then the builders changed it to look like a chinese palace, we do not really know how it was originally. Anyway the colours are more peaceful than in China and Japan and the motives of the ceiling designs are very beautiful. Worth visiting.
Definitely a must see palace . Changing guards ceremony is interesting. Beautiful architecture building. Important chapter of Korean history.Beautiful cherry blossoms in Spring Apr16.

You can combine folk museum, insadong, bukchon, seoul contemporary art museum with gyeongbokgung.  Perfect place to chk the architecture of korean last dynasty Chosun. Perfect place to take walk with children or friend or date even.  My favorite spot in Seoul

Luckily, I and my friends visited Gyeongbokgung Palace while the Royal Guard Changing Ceremony was performed. We find traditional and contemporary atmosphere in the palace. I think this is the most beautiful palace among others palace in Seoul.

Took a taxi to outside the gate and purchased admission ticket. Once inside the gate, we explored inside the walls and saw some amazing structures. We saw some signage with a brief English version explaining the structures. Wandering throughout, the sight has a folklore museum and temple and alongside a simulated village constructed to show life several centuries back. Also found ancient artifacts of sculptures used in early religious beliefs and practices. This was worth the admission and few hours spent wandering the grounds

There's a lot of places to explore in this palace. I love the Hyangwonjeong area, the pond is like what you see in a painting but real. You can also witness the changing of the royal guards. Being here is a nice way to be familiar of their history.  This palace is accessible from the train station.

I went there with my husband. it took us 3 hours to walk not even half of the palace. It is HUGE. And it is covered with ginkgo tree which their leaves has all turned into red and yellow. VERY BEAUTIFUL.

I was a bit disappointed by the palace as it is a rebuilt palace with almost no interiors. The imperial palaces in Japan or China are much bigger, nicer and more interesting.  It is still worthwhile to visit, but do not expect too much. I like the museum next to the palace though and would recommend to visit that one too when you already there.
We joined the free English tour guided programme which was insightful. There were Mandarin guided tours too It closes on Tuesday.
It is huge and located in the heart of Seoul so that it makes the city more attractive and interesting. Hyundai National Gallery and Samchungdong are very close to the site. Try this area.

It is not my favorite place, but it is so nice to see when the leaves are about to fall. Colors are awesome. People also enjoy it in spring, with the colorful flowers. I have a couple of times, and I always think that the most beautiful part is when I see it from the outside, the main entrance with the mountains behind.

A lovely historic site to visit; easy ride on the Metro and you are there to stroll and imagine what life was like for those who lived in and worked at the palace. The area near the back with the pond and pavilions is particularly beautiful and restful.  It is a bit surreal as skyscrapers surround this human sized place, but that makes it feel locked in time and very special. The museum has a quiet place to enjoy some tea either before or after you see the collection but for my money, the fun is wandering around the palace complex outside. Great place for families because kids can run.
If you have the opportunity to travel to South Korea you need to visit gyeongbokgung palace, you don't disappoint

We travelled as a family of 4 with 2 children (aged 7 and 9) in the month of November 2016. We planned our visit to Gyeongbokgung around the timing of the free guided tours as we wanted to get a better understanding of the palace. The schedule for the tours can be found on the Visit Korea website. According to the website, you do not need to make advance reservation unless you are in a group with more than 10 people.  Eventually, we joined the 4pm Chinese language tour (last tour of the day; main gate closes at 4pm when we were there). The tour lasted 40 minutes and as we were the only family in the group, we could ask the guide many questions, which she patiently explained. We learnt a lot during the tour, including the significance of the animal statues surrounding the main hall, why there are wooden bars at the front doors of some buildings; how the heating system worked, why the emperor created the hangul language etc. Totally recommend joining the tour to get the most out of the Gyeongbokgung visit.

This palace was huge but it didnt really awe me. It was beautiful and we thought we would purchase the whole package of 3 places for like 10bucks. We ended up not even going to the other 2 because this one wasnt all that. I did not regret checking it out because thats what traveling is all about but i did regret purchasing the bundle since we didnt go to any other palaces. If you are trying to save money i would opt out of purchasing tickets. They let u into the entrance where the guards are for free so i would do a photo opt there and go spend ur money eating some tasty foods instead. But if you have money, go check it out.

Very nice place, entrance is only 2,5 euro including a free english tour lasting over a hour. The place is huge and for sure worth the visit. The gardens are very nice. The area around as well us interesting, and watch the change of the guards which is actualy in front and outside of the palace ground.
Understood from the guide that this place was burnt down twice in the past, left 30% for people to see. With the guide's explanation, could understand the architectural and historical part

visited the place during early november 2016  happened to see the changing parade of ancient guards ceremony at the main entrance. according to online article, you will see it happening at every 11am, 12pm, 1pm, 2pm, 3pm..  after which, they will stand stationary at the gate facing the main road for a short while and this is the best time to take a photo with them! after i took a picture with them, suddenly a command was shouted and they left! the whole process for photo taking with them was less than 2 minutes! so fast! everyone was surprised that they left so fast, not sure if this is the norm..  visiting the palace during autumn period was great.. the trees are changing colours and there were many people wearing the traditional korean outfit taking OOTD near the maple trees, the view was marvelous  the palace was huge.. we were there for 1hr plus and have yet to complete the entire area. so do allocate some time to comb the entire place

Super easy to get there, just take subway and get off at Gyeong bok gung station. Entry fee is 3,000w per person, price is quite reasonable and they provide free touring as well.  Went there in late Nov and it was freezing, and therefore we couldn't stay there for long, only went there for around 1.5 hours and we have missed a lot of nice places inside the palace. I would suggest to go in spring or summer time, because it opens for longer hours and provide night visiting with all the lighting at night time, for sure it will look more beautiful than visiting during winter with all the fallen leaves.

So I really enjoyed this historical site as it was extremely well preserved and great efforts have been put forth to ensure that the authenticity of as much of the past was preserved as possible. Some may disagree, but lest they forget, much has happened in the last hundred plus years in Korea that in some countries would not have allowed for such a rich piece of history to be put on display or refurbished good enough to make it a tourist must see spot. Having been to quite a few different historical sites in Korea, this is in my opinion one of the best ones to visit if you are into history. The only negative thing I would say is that this may not necessarily be a fun and action packed location that would inspire too much excitement from younger kids.

You can go to the Gyeongbokgung station and ascend directly yo the gate of the site. It's a massive complex and quite good to explore. People always flock at the center gates but there'd be lots of space to take nice photos inside the complex and garden. We visited during winter and very manageable number of visitors. The photos are a bit foggy though and while we get to have a glimpse of the mountain backdrop, I can only imagine how beautiful it is during summer or spring.

We went there during autumn and it was a very lovely place with a lot of areas that are picture perfect. We went there twice because we felt during our first visit that it's a must to experience wearing Hanbok and so we did during our 2nd visit! Our pictures were great!
Much larger than expected, the grounds are huge. There isn't much to do except walk around and imagine what life must've been like centuries ago at the palace

No visit to Seoul is complete without a trip to the Gyeongbokgung Palace. If you have time to visit only one palace, make it this one.  Start trip with a picturesque stop at the Gwanghwamun with the traditional guards and move on the massive palace grounds, soaking in the ancient Korean architecture and have a feel of what it was like during the Joseon Dynasty.

Being here brought back so many memories of K-dramas. Loved it. My wife and I had this palace as one 1 hour stop of a city tour. This was definitely too short as we were rushed through by our tour guide in order to get to our next location. Definitely will be going back for a slower pace tour offered by the palace in English. Would not recommend self tour as you would miss out on the rich history. Comfortable shoes are a must.
This is a must see. Check with locals or the concierge for days when they are having events in the park. Bring a good camera.
Such a really large largeeee place to walk... But really a great place to understanding korea history.....

Finally, a beautiful and serene place in Seoul! Beautiful grounds, well worth your time. We came early in the morning a cold November day, and had some areas completely to ourselves, but I would guess it is crowded in the high season.

Out of the many palaces in Seoul, this is the one you must visit! As this place is huge, I recommend setting aside more time to spend here. Do catch the Royal Guard Changing Ceremony (10am-3pm) every hour at Gwanghwamun Square and join a free guided tour as it makes the whole place comes alive.

I came here and i got lucky i was in time for one of their marching of the guard routine. Really cool to witness so make sure you stick around for that. Also the placae itself is huge and so much to see, can spend like hours here. Worth visiting if you're in Seoul

Being on a business trip, I managed to get a one day quick tour of Seoul. Through viator, I managed to visit this beautiful palace. As you pass through the various sections, you get closer to the main palace and to the old banqueting area. It gives you a real touch of Korea and if you visit the adjacent museum, there is a very good pictorial display of the Korea s history.

A must see in Seoul, beautiful, typical Korean architecture - wood and ceramic, brightly painted and immaculately clean. I understand that the palace has been completely rebuilt within the last 50 years after it was razed to the ground during an occupation. The tour guides speak an excellent level of English; if you enter at the main entrance, and exit at the back you can see the Blue House past its gates and guards (home of the president).
Fascinating to see the royal guard parade. Close to myeongdong but with a lot of activities to do...

One of the must place to come while you in South korea. When Autumn season the scenery very beautiful and the leaves color is yellow and red. The atmosphere of traditional and modern that mixed into one. The park very spacious, suitable as a place to sit relax and take pictures there. When I get there, I use hanbok and many foreign tourists request to take photos. Free entry ticket if you use hanbok.
... But not as much as Changdeokgung Palace. So if you only have time for one, pick the smaller, more intricate Unesco World Heritage Site.
Beautiful and so well maintained. Not only for the Palace, but also for the museums you can visit there. It is a complete visit to know more about Korea and Koreans. A must see.

It's a freezing cold day. Made it just in time to join the 11am English-speaking guide. Why does the tour always clash with the changing of Guards? Grrrrrr.  I suspect this palace will be prettier during other Seasons. It looks pretty dried up in winter.  The guide's stories were good but it's just too cold today........when she pointed out the National Folk Museum of Korea at the east gate, that was a Super informative museum.  Overall, the Korean architecture of this palace is interesting !!
The palace was a very photogenic place in the Fall, with lots of colorful leaves. It was interesting, and a nice place to stroll and enjoy the trees in the foreground and modern city rising above.

Before going, check the time for the change of the guard (in period costumes). Get off at Anguk Stn. Entrance fee is cheap. Watching all the buildings can take easily several hours. This is the largest palaces. Only the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion remains as original. All the rest has been reconstructed 100 to 150 years ago. There are two museums at the back. The National Palace Museum is the place to go. The National Folk Museum is unimpressive. There is also an area that reconstructs a village about 50 years ago.
The Museum is a must see attraction if you are visiting Seoul, South Korea. The Museum is one of the oldest palaces that remains in the country.

The site is close to Anguk metro station and has several courtyards and temples/palaces. Just keep walking north through each courtyard until one gets to the Royal Palace to see the King's throne. Your 3000 won ticket also gives you access to see the temple across the road to the right at the end of the palace and there is a free cultural museum there too. Takes half a day to see all.

Coming here during the summer is definitely a harsh time, as the ground of the palace is mostly soil/sand, and it would be terribly hot, should a sudden shower comes, there are not much places to go to. Night tour would be nicer I think, with all lit up.

This is the biggest palace out of the 5 palaces in Seoul. I went in November & the changing of the guard took place at 10am, not sure if changes so make sure to change. It was definitely worth watching. The palace is quite big but you can walk through the whole palace within 1-1.5hour. You get free entrance to the museum with your ticket but I didn't spend any time there because I was part of a tour.

This is not that palace that comes to your mind when you think of any palace. This is a wide spread area with center located prayer hall and small rooms around the area. Entrace and buildings inside are of typical Korean construction in their early stages. You may feel relaxed as if you were in Korea before 70 to 100 years
Nice view especially during Autumn. Nice weather. You can get in free when you are wearing korena traditional wear - Hanbook.
The palace grounds are huge and expansive - the sheer size of the atrium will surprise you - but the palace in itself lacks luster and nothing magnificent.
Beautiful royal castle and residence. Wonderful park grounds with lots to see and plenty of room for leisurely walks. Love it!

An extensive ground with many beautiful buildings and scenes. Spent 1-2 hours here walking around and taking photos. Perfect for a sunny day. The palace is closed on Tuesday's, and there's also free entry for those wearing traditional dress

The Palace showcases the extravagance of the monarchy in their time. It is a showcase of culture, fauna and architecture etc. if one wishes to learn Korean history etc. It is best to join an English tour guide who has knowledge of its history and significance. Try to catch the changing of guards ritual at 10:00 a.m. and then tour the palace. There is an entrance fee ... but if you are a US military personnel, this is one of the choices offered in a package.
Great palace to visit to experience a bit of korean history. It is definitely a main tourist attraction that is worth the time to visit. Guard changing at 10am and another one in the afternoon.
We were able to take a tour which was extremely informative. The guide was well educated about the grounds and history of the site. We also took the secret garden tour

The grounds and buildings of the palace are interesting but not spectacular. What is quite exceptional is changing of the guard at the main gate that was the highlight. A surprise that it was very reminiscent of the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace and other places in Europe. Colourful and apparently historic according to our guide. It was very crowded so arrive early for a front row view. It is very close to a subway stop so should be very to access if you are staying close to the transit system.

We came here on the first day of our trip and what a beautiful place to start. This place is huge and there is lots to look around and see. The entrance price is more then reasonable. Just be warned if you leave through a certain gate you'll have to pay to get back in.

What a fun time. The grounds are lovely and there is a lot going on. The leaves were changing and so the fall colors were super pretty. There was a changing of the guards sort of ceremony and that was really fun to watch. There were lots of folks in their traditional dress and we just had a lovely time. There is also a really great shopping area nearby and that was nice too. I am not sure what the shopping area was called.
This is interesting, but nothing too out of the ordinary. The changing of the guard was the highlight of the visit.
The temples have been renovated . Allow yourself sufficient time to visit this site, there is a lot to see.

I was lucky because I got to see the changing guard ceremony when I was there. Two times this palace got destroyed by fire but now it stood so majestic in the northern part of Seoul. The palace itself represents traditional culture mixture with contemporary architecture. The palace has a huge compound with beautiful scenery that allows visitors to take endless photos especially if you are wearing hanbok. Inside the compound there are two museums, too bad I didnt get the chance to visit it.
Beautiful traditional palace in the nature. The tickets are reasonable and there is a free guide that takes you all around telling you abouy history.

This was the main royal palace of Joseon dynasty. The first one was build more than six centuries ago, but was then destroyed and rebuilt a few times. The last one has been in the past century and is now meticulously rebuilt following the original project. The whole area offers several buildings to visit including huge gates, palaces, small and bigger buildings. Expect to spend at least a couple of hours to visit this area. This was the most beautiful tourist site that we visited in Seoul.

The palace is huge so just keep in mind that you will have to walk the whole palace. We watched the changing of the guards, took pictures with the guards outside. If you're going in the summer, dress comfortable because is was too darn hot! Not much shade unless you're near the palace and the other buildings. There is so much history there which was very interesting. Beautiful palace, a must see if you're a first timer.

The most famous palace in Seoul. Entrance fee is 3000 won. Combi tickets is 10,000won altogether. Free entree for those who are wearing Hanbok. There's free guided tour around the palace at certain timing. Visitors should check the schedule for changing of guards ceremony before going to this palace.

When I planed to go Seoul, South Korea, the one itinerary must put in my schedule that was Gyeongbokgung Palace. I had visited Seoul fifth times, but I had also went with different people in these fifth times which meaned I visited Gyeongbokgung Palace fifth times. It was because that I would like to explain my experience to them such as the feeling which was comfortable to me walk into Gyeongbokgung Palace and I wanted to share with them. In the recent time of I visited Seoul that was on June 2016 with my friend. As I said, I wanted to bring her to Gyeongbokgung Palace, she wasn't understand why we will go an old and non-shopping viewpoint. But she finally accepted this itinerary. On that day, we woke up early and went to Gyeongbokgung Palace. There provided many kinds languages of guided tour to introduce the Gyeongbokgung Palace, and we also joined one guided tour. When the guider started to explain, introduced and we was walking around the Gyeongbokgung Palace slowly. She changed her mind and told me that thanks my recommend. I was happy that she agreed with me it had a strong historical atmosphere in Gyeongbokgung Palace. In my opinion, I will suggest you walk slowly to see and visit that non-commercial, silence environment.

It was a good place to explore and understand the history and culture of the korean during old days. I would suggest for travelers who interested of knowing more about culture and history, shall spend at least 3 hours to complete the whole palace. A free guided tour in English, Chinese, Japanese and other language are available at selected time slot (may get this information from the website). The tour takes about 1 hour to 1 and half hour with a guide to explain and story-telling about the history and what are the building for. However, the free guided tour was a targeted tour on selected spots, therefore to cover the full palace, you may need to explore on your own after that and there is also a museum which you can visit for free admission. To make your money worth if you are a fans of understanding the history and culture, you may get the Royal Palaces Ticket which come along with secret garden entrance at 10,000 won instead of paying one palace for 3,000 won per pax.

A must visit place. Subway station is connected to the monument. Follow the directions and markings in the subway station.  Last entry in the Palace is 1600 HRS. Try to be there before 3:00 PM. The Museum next to Palace is free. Museum is open until 6 pm. There is a good souvenir shop in the basement of the museum.
This place is good for the one who like to discover the Korean culture. It's large. Should go with tour guide to get fully knowledge.

Be prepared to travel back in time in Korea. Brilliant architecture (if that's what they call the palace artwork), intricate and delicate designs. Went here expecting nothing but just a palace but left with so much admiration with Korean history. Don't miss the changing of the guards, check the website for the times. you can take selfies with guards but they will never smile for you. When i went here, there were heaps of Korean kids in their traditional costumes which as beyond amazing! Very pretty and very traditional. It felt like I was in a Korean village from way back then. It gets very busy so goodluck with the crowd.
Plenty of marvelous historical strolling. Right downtown. Near Insadong arts street and near the main performing arts Sejong Center. Relax and get out of traffic.
An awesome place to visit and see some of the history of such a great country. The Changing of the Guard Ceremony should not be missed. If you visit this palace you will not be disappointed.
It's a sprawling complex so comfy shoes are essential. We used an audio guide which was very helpful in explaning the background of the palace.
At first, I thought that Gyeongbokgung is quite small, but then it is totally big which took me around 2 hours going around. This palace also provides night tour which should be bought in advance.
Nice palace located in the centre of Seoul. Come when they have guard changing ceremony, really great
Very nice Palace.. but you must have a tourist guide in order to understand the function of the selective buildings

It's the main Palace of Seoul. It's interesting to visit since it gives the possibility to learn some Korean history. I would suggest to take part to a guided tour, it takes about 60minutes and gives the possibility to understand the most important information about the history of the Palace.

With quite a few different palaces to visit, we decided on this one by pure luck. It's super easy to get to with a subway station nearby. We decided to wait for the English guided tour and it was definitely worth it! The museum that's onsite is also good. Plan on spending at least 2 hours there and wear comfortable shoes for all the walking required.

Lovely place just beautiful and traditional thing to see one of the most famous tour spot and it starts to open at night time with beautiful night lights you should plan your schedule for night visit if you like cultural sights and calm atmosphere.

It was a cultural experience for us. The palace compound was huge and it could easily take a whole day trip. They have nice sites inside and my friends and I were anle to take wonderful photos. It was like a throwback to ancient Seoul and it was a nice experience. We were even able to catch the changing of the guards which was a good exeperience. Bring water when you go here as stores and vending machines are far in between. Try to go early as it gets very crowded easily.

Located right across city hall station, you will have to pay an admission to get in to see the sights and sounds of the palace. Great views and nice walks inside. At the entrance, there is a performance done every 2 hours or so by the palace performers and after, you could take pictures with them.
Absolutely cool. I could imagine King's movement at this place. Interesting walls, building shapes, especially the roofs. very interested.

This palace has quiet wide area. But you won't feel too tired to explore the whole building, because it offers a very beautiful scenery. If you like to explore the historical areas, this place is recommended!

The biggest of the 5 Palaces. Once stepped in, feel like you are transported back to the hundreds years ago. If you are wearing the traditional korean costumes, entrance is free, and your photo with the palace will look like you are in Historical Korean Drama. The inside of each building is very minimally decorated & furnished, big contrast with lavish style in Chinese Palace or European castle. Anyway, keep going to the back & towards the garden & you will see more tourist here than the palace itself. Snap a photo at the pond with the tower in the middle, & the mountain as the background. The view is simply stunning.

Palace is nice and big. Good photo opportunities as we came early November. The leaves are still turning brown. The change guards ceremony is recommended. If u arent interested in history or pictures and prefer shopping then skip this otherwise this will be a good sightseeing place. Entrance fees is cheap. 3000 won for adults. Children below 7 is free

As Palaces go it is rather standard and the changing of the guard...Well there are other impressive places around the World to see the same sort of thing. However, it is worth a visit. The Changing of the Guard is at 1000hrs and at 1400hrs.  The costumes of the guards are very interesting and colourful but probably not very practical! As In London, you are allowed to pose with the gate guards!

I was lucky to visit it on the country's National Culture Day, which they allowed the entrance for free! It's an amazing place to discover the history of South Korea, great for photography too, a bit crowded with tourists, at the time I went (1pm) the guards were there with their cool ancient uniforms and weapons which cool to see, also a lot of people like to pay to dress up on the traditional costumes and wonder around the palace, which I find quite cool to have that opportunity.

This Palace,is the residence of the Emperor during the Seong dynasty. It offers a great insight into the living style and architecture of the era. In terms of magnificence, it matches the Forbidden City in Beijing.
It's in Seoul but when you are there you feel miles away from the city, mountains in the background, a lake with a fab pavillion to look at - absolutely brilliant to look at and spend some time there
Nice palace with great view, great culture and great history. You will require at least 2-4 hours to spend time and roam around. Must see if you are tourist.

A visit to Gyeongbokgung Palace with a guide will give you a glimpse of imperial life during the Chosun dynasty. Total visit will probably take only about an hour at the most starting with the public areas and continuing to the private chambers of the king and the queen. The palace is located in the heart of the city and is quite accessible. In terms of grandeur, it cannot compare to the Imperial Palace in Beijing but we were told that this was intentional given the political situation at that time in history.
I visited other 2 palaces before comming here, and found it's big, and I was very tired and hungry at that time, so I ended the visiting within 1 hour. exactly, 2-2.5 hours would be better.
The main palace in Seoul and also attracts the most tourists. However, we didn't go in the palace since it has empty spaces only and most of the rooms were closed.
There's quite a walk from the start to finish. We're on a tour in Oct and the weather was perfect for this site visit even though the temp climbed to 20 degree Celsius.

I had to cross the main road (traffic lights road) to the main gate of this palace. Luckily we got experienced to see the morning " morning guard ceremony" with the traditional/ancient musics. And also there is Interpretation Services Offered Tours depart in front of the information center at Heungnyemun Gate.Duration: About 1 hr - 1 hr 30 min. If not mistaken, This palace were once destroyed by fire during the Imjin War but then all of the palace buildings were later restored during the King Gojong (overheard the explanation by interpretator). 3000₩ / enterance and closed every tuesday.. the opening hours is depends on the seasons. ~plan your trip peeps..hv a nice travel here in s.korea~

I stumbled to this place after walking through the insa-dong street neighborhoods.  There is an entrance fee of 3000 KRW, about $3 u.s. dollars and it's worth the price. I did not join any tour groups, I explored and wandered on my own. The place can get dusty as the interior of the palace grounds are all light gravel. I visited this place on a weekday during the morning hours and it was somewhat crowded with mostly young kids on a field trip.  The place could be toured with in 60-90 minutes
Visited the palace and garden on 30 th October 2016. Beautiful autumn colours. Don't miss live changing guard ceremony. Rich with Korean culture. Must see palace.
I learned a lot about architecture from visiting this palace. Also a lot about Korean history. It is well worth a visit.
The palace is huge but it's relaxing to walk around the area. Great place to understand a little of the history of Korea. Good place for photography.
Visited the palace and garden on a busy Sunday. Beautiful and well maintained palace, beautiful colors, clean facilities and nice shop. Certainly worth the visit!

It's a great place and it's well preserved. It remains intact and is situated in front of the Blue House, and behind the statue of King Sejong. If you want to know more about South Korea's history, this is the way to go.  It only took us a 3-5 min. Walk from our guesthouse, (Guesthouse Korea). There was a performance for like every 20 mins or so? Where performers dress up as the way that people dressed before and did the rituals etc. To depict the old times. At the end of the ceremony, some performers stand outside the palace and station there where you can take a picture with them (Proper manners and gestures should be observed. They'll feel violated if you get touchy with them.)  Inside, I can say that the overall palace is well-maintained. The comfort rooms are also great. Once you get out, you will see the front of the Blue House, you can also take a stroll in the side walks to enjoy the streets of Korea while enjoying the views of the falling leaves of the tree's

This is a good tour to learn historical Korea. You will find a couple of grand palaces in that big compound. If you come in before 10 am, there you'll see a live marching guard like in Buckingham Palace in Korean version. It will run for about 30 minutes. If you come in wearing a hanbok or traditional costume of Korea, your admission fee is free! To my surprise, quite a number of locals came wearing their hanbok..Those who wore them became instant Hollywood stars...why? They look cute & blend well with the palaces on the background so those tourists took advantages of those nice shots as souvenir! By the way, if you're interested, few hanbok rentals is just near outside the palace itself. Go for it!!

I'll admit I was lucky. I was there on the one(?) day of the year that those who wear traditional Korean outfits got in free. The site was abundant with traditional attire. That enhanced the tour. It's a non-rush tour. It was enjoyable, pleasant, had hidden places to sit and relax. A tour guide would be helpful to learn more, but wandering alone was fine. Go near all the way to the north to see the pond. Sit, relax and enjoy. Once you finish, visit the free museum just to the west, by the subway entrance. If you're a history buff, you'll enjoy.

Very nice place to take photos with traditional hanbok, did I mention you get free admissions too while wearing hanbok to palaces! You can see the change of guards ceremony, check out music performances. We went during the autumn season, so the trees were all turning red and it was very pretty.
One of the largest and oldest palaces in the region. Nice architecture. Very well maintained. Beautiful symmetry to the place.

This place is a must go when visiting Seiul for the first time. The weather was nice and cool so it was very relaxing to walk and enjoy the beautiful scenery of the palace and nature. Bring a camera and take lots of pictures so you can remember how beautiful this place is. 😀
A fantastic walk through history with some great photo opportunities. Lots of atmosphere. Much better on a sunny day.
Huge palace. Ancient buildings in the middle of very modern ones. This is funny and a great symbol of all the contrast that happen in this great city.

It was cultural day when we went to the palace. Hence, there was free admission and it was crowded with students. Nevertheless, some of the spots in the palace were very scenic with mountain backdrop. There was performance on the guards changing ceremony before we enter the palace and we also saw the fake king and queen doing their stroll in the palace with their guards. If you follow them, they will lead you to this pavilion with gorgeous backdrop for photo-taking. The architectural was beautiful and I love the lake especially. It was a good photo taking spot.
Went there during day time. It was crowded but still okay. I saw a lot of people wearing hanbok and it feels like I was in the ancient time. Nice garden. The place is well maintained and clean.

Visited last October 16, 2016 Gyeongbokgung Palace is the main palace. This is the only palace we visited during our trip. We toured the place and it was huge and beautiful. The walls and designs are lovely. Please dont miss the changing of the guards ceremony. It's a very interesting show.  Try wearing hanbok so you can enter the palace free of charge.

Visited Seoul twice and finally made a visit to the Palace. The night tour was simply amazing and they only have 500 tickets allocated for foreign visitors each night. 3,00 won per entry and it is worth every penny. Check out their performances as well.

Didn't get to see the inside of the palace because we didn't realise it closed at 4pm. Was in the courtyard and the views were lovely. A mix of old and new as the buildings are nestled among the skyscrapers and mountains. We visited the museum exhibits instead which were well laid out and had some excellent animations for clearer explanations. The reading room has a booth with ports to charge your phone. Very useful.

The visit was during summer. It was hot and humid. Bring over umbrella to protect you from direct sun. The palace is very huge so expect to spend 3 hours to complete whole course. The guard march is at the courtyard before the palace entrance and make sure you find a spot near by the palace entrance to get clear view.

The palace is centrally located and directly link with subway. The entrance fee is 3000won per adult. In compare with the palace in China and Thailand, this palace seems not as luxury as others. There was not much decorations can be seen and just similar to a large park. There are lot of local people dressing in their native clothing and taking photos in the palace. The palace is a nice place to have leisure walks during holiday.
Interesting place to visit! See guard changing is a must! Opened every day from 9am to 6pm unless Tuesday!
Best time to go, I would say is during autumn. The palace has a small garden somewhere in the outskirts, the autumn leaves make it that much more worth the scenary.
Make sure to watch the changing of the guards in the morning. You may want to visit during a weekday, too.
This is one of the places which we have visited many times in different seasons. There's a Hanbok rental shop which you just need to register and you can wear Hanbok for 15mins

Awed by the grandeur of the palace. The biggest and the grandest of all the 5 palaces. There were a lot of people from different nationalities. Saw the 3 buddhas. It has the King’s office, A huge kitchen, king’s hall where he entertains his visitors. I even posed with the palace guards. Truly beautiful!

Great stop in downtown Seoul. I stumbled across this as i had a couple of hours to spare u til hotel checkout time. It was a quick walk from my hotel, and I arrived just in time to see the changing of the guard. The compound is so big that the mass that had gathered to watch the changing of the guard quickly dispersed as we entered the compound. The fee was under $3 USA to enter--totally worth the proce. Fun total see the architecture and layout. I wish I had spent more time here!

How many times does one get to see a palace built in 1395? The grounds are vast and the dirt base can be uneven. It's a pleasure to walk around and see the history and beautiful architecture. I strongly recommend you let one of the High School students give you a free tour. They are perfecting their English (and other languages) while sharing their history. Very interesting.

Small, pretty, well-preserved. Worth visiting in Seoul. However, if you've seen the Forbidden City, then there is nothing particularly spectacular or grand about this place. I enjoyed it because I love Asian architecture, and enjoyed the animal sculptures throughout the place which are a bit different from the ones I've seen in China. Can get crowded with school groups visiting. Wear your hanbok for free admission.

The biggest palace in Seoul. A lot of beautiful buildings to see. Its strongly recommended to buy combined ticket for all the palaces (5) - 10 000 W and try the guided tour. Its free, all guides speak fluent english and explain all that you can see.
Love their free tour guide service. She explained well on the history of almost each building and kept it lively. however, we miss the guard changing ceremony

We had a wonderful time there. We rent hanbok/traditional korean clothes at a store outside nearby the palace to get free entrance inside the palace.  It wasnt that crowded when i visited, so i managed to take quite a few good photos

Went by day and by night and preferred the night experience especially the light and dance shows which were very uplifting - left with a nice happy warm feeling!!  Fascinated by all the locals dressing up to get their photos taken - was even tempted but too tight to pay the $50 charge!

Very popular with tourists. A lot of people but still very nice to walk around. I would take a whole day as the place very big.  Around 2pm, there is a changing guards in front.  Bring your drinks and foods to sit inside and have break. It would be a nice place to have some drink and food.

This is a small place to take a stroll.... I visited here ten years ago and this time it was packed with Chinese tourists...shockingly many of them. And some crazy boys running here and there I simply couldn't enjoy this place.. Visit here on week days..  주중에 방문하실 것을 권해드립니다 주말에는 중국인 관광객을 비롯하여 떠들고 설치고 분위기를 해치는 요소들이 너무 많았답니다
This is another gem in Seoul. Make sure to travel around the entire property, there numerous little spots that have to be searched for. Go early in the morning.
If you like temples and have the time, a wander through the gardens and temples is very relaxing. Autumn colors added to the interest this visit and I would visit again.

This palace is very impressive, however, it is the most popular one in tourists and therefore very crowded. This does not add to its atmosphere. If you leave the central parts of the palace and wander around in the park, it becomes much more solitary. If you like quieter spots, visit the other palaces in Seoul (which are impressive as well!).
Very nice and interesting. Highly recommend the free English speaking tour which is daily 3 times a day. Only need to pay the entry ticket. Absolutely must see while in Seoul.
My second time here but this time during much better weather. It's a beautiful palace and we got in for free for wearing hanboks!

Join the English guide and learn to appreciate the history and architecture of this beautiful Palace. If you are a historical K-drama fan you will now be able to see and experience the beautiful architecture, the Throne Hall and the Pavilion you see so often in the dramas.  If you are in a Hanok you get in free of charge, saving 3,000 won.  I visited the Palace after Bukchon Hanok Village and Samcheong-dong. All are within walking distance
Nice palace and greenery around. There were lots of people though so its hard to get a good picture with no one behind you. Also saw lots of youngsters dressed in their traditional costume.
Well maintain historical building and museum. We can find lots of Korean teenager wearing hanbok (traditional Korean costum), we can ask them to take a picture for free.
Fun palace, but the best part to me was the views of the mountains against the old buildings as well as the wonderful park/gardens around the perimeter.

Only $3 for tourists, must bring passports. This place normally closes at 5 so seeing it in the dark is cool. There was also a light show and traditional dance at the end around 9:30PM. Highly recommended as it doesn't occur often.

So apparently they do this night viewing only for a couple of weeks, dont miss it.  They only give 500 tickets to foriegners so line up early if you want to get in, around 6PM is best.  The place ia filled with young beautiful Koreans dressed in the traditional Hanboek, and the detail of the buildings are very clear in the splash of lights upon them surrounded by darkness of the evening  But the best part was light and traditional dance Show at the King's Pavilion.  When you step through the main gates it is as if you have been transported back in time lost in a beautiful ancient world of kings and beautiful people surround by the works of great craftsmen.  The light show was an amazing display of Korean Technology mixed with their ancient dance and art.  I was just wowed!!!  I love Korea!!!!

Very lovely palace complex but there is not a huge amount to see apart from the buildings. It would be better if there were some exhibitions in it. I did take the audio guide but again would be good to have more detail etc on the guide.  There was one very nice lake at the back but it just needs a little something more.

We arrived at 2:00PM just in time for the changing of the guards. I highly recommend seeing this ceremony as it helps one imagine what it must have been like hundreds of years ago at the palace. It is not abundantly clear but you need a ticket to enter the inner courtyard and you can purchase them on the far right of the outer courtyard. Once inside you can peer into throne rooms and walk around the grounds.
