We were treated to a concert of traditional instruments out in front of the coffee shop (note: every Korean tourist attraction will have at least one coffee shop). One other treat was the high percentage of people walking around in Hanbok (the traditional Korean garb). Wear your walking shoes. This place is not very wheelchair accessible.
We took the Free Korea Transit Tour to Seoul that included the Gyeongbokgung Palace. Interesting way to spend a morning. Nice introduction to Korea history.

I was proposed at this palace so this place holds a dear memory in my heart. This is a beautiful palace with lots of history! I recommend getting a tour guide to get a better understand about this place. The architecture and the colors are beautiful! It's a great place to wear hanbock and go on a tour. The admission fee is cheap and it's worth a visit!

This is a year round good, must see palace when in Seoul. Beautiful grounds, even better when you coincide your visits with the guard changing ceremony. We were lucky to see the guard inspection ceremony reanactment and display of martial arts. Entrance is free if you rent a hanbok costume. Plenty of rental shop in the vicinity as well in Buchon Hanok village which is just a short stroll away. Or you can buy a booklet of combo tickets to all the palaces and jongmo shrine for 10,000 won. Don't miss the floating Pavillion on the left.

I think gyeongbokgung palace one of must visit in korea. But not suitable when you want "healing situation". When I visit, there a fan meeting or shooting program. Oh, so crowded with fans screaming everywhere
the palace has its history and is well maintained. good for first time visitor to visit... however, do try to go on weekday... it was super crowded on weekend.
Very nice park, rather large. Relaxing place for a walk. Some beautiful buildings. Shows a glimp of how korea used to be. Very touristic.
Beautiful place. You can go for a long walk - learn a lot and try the old tradition te. Very close to centrum.

I've been here several times before but this is the first time I visited at night. We were lucky that on this trip there was a special night session for autumn. It's still the same admission price and it's open from 6-10pm but lines start forming at 5pm. There are limited stilts for both tourists and locals so be sure to come early. There were exhibits and a traditional Korean dance and program showcasing their culture and the story of King Sejong (?). It was held in one of the pavilions on the lake and with the full moon it was just breathtaking! There were a lot of young people dressed in the traditional hanbok because they get to come in free :-)

First thing we did when arrived in Korea was visiting Gyeongbok palace. Good spot to start your visit in Seoul, where you can learn about history. Ticket is not expensive, and you can buy a special pass to visit all the temples and palaces in the area with a discount.

This is a must for any visitor to Seoul, the grounds are massive! Many visitors every day but as the are is so large it is not overcrowded. Many teenagers and young adults dress up in traditional costume for photo sessions, pretty entertaining.
Visited the palace and gardens with my wife and 14m old son. Great place to stroll around and to take some beautiful pictures.

This huge palace complex is stunning, comparable to the best in the world. Every courtyard or space reveals new treasures and, despite being crowded, peace can be found around many a corner. An absolute must-see if in Korea!
The palace is closed on Tuesday though. It's crowded inside. We managed to take better photos from the National Museum outside.

If you are a history buff and plan to visit any of the palaces, and if you have only a very limited time, I would suggest that you visit Gyeongbokgung.It is close to Insadong and Bukchon hanok village. You can sort of do all there in one day. Mind you, there is a lot of walking to do, so be prepared.I was not very impressed by the changing of the palace guard, but if you have the time go for it.Check out the timing for this, as they do this only twice a day, depending on the weather. However, do not avoid the palace visit just because you missed the changing of the guard.

As I rode the bus from Incheon Airport to my hotel in Jongno, I got my first glimpse of Gyeongbokgung Palace. It was way after midnight and the lights from the outer gate and just the presence of seeing a palace for the first time blew me away. I visited the palace and it was such a wonder to see.

During our time in South Korea, being the history buffs we are, we purchased the Integrated Pass for Palaces, which basically gave us tickets and access for all five major palaces for 10,000 won, as compared to 14,000 won if purchased individually instead. From our visits, we could safely say that out of the five, Gyeongbokgung Palace seemed to be the most well known, and perhaps unfortunately, the most crowded too.  We happened to visit during the Golden Week holiday period in China, and that meant hordes of Chinese tourists swarming the Geunjeongjeon, or Throne Hall. It would have been a little more ideal if I had been able to secure a slot for the night tour, where the crowd is much lesser and it is more beautiful for night photography. Luckily, it seems that most tour groups bring their tourists to the Geunjeongjeon area only. Beyond that, if you are willing to walk more and more further, you will be rewarded with less crowds.  The architectural style of the palace is somewhat closer to the Ming Dynasty style, such as the Forbidden Palace for example. This is in contrast to the other palaces such as Changdeokgung Palace, which has a more traditional Korean style. It might look similar at first glance, but on closer inspection, some differences can be seen. The Gyeongbokgung Palace that is seen standing today is actually a reconstruction and restoration, as the original one was sadly demolished during the Japanese colonial era in 1915. Still, the amount and scale that has been restored so far is astonishing and must be seen first hand to understand the very soul of Korea better.  The National Folk Museum of Korea happens to be inside Gyeongbokgung Palace and it can provide a respite from the heat with the building itself being air-conditioned. The exterior of the museum is quite beautiful and is worthy of some great shots. There is also the Hyangwonjeong Pavilion that is worth walking far enough for a great shot.  You should not miss the royal guard changing ceremonies done by reenactors that take place at Gwanghwamun, the main gate of Gyeongbokgung Palace at 10 am and 2 pm. The ceremony takes about 20 minutes and it is an experience you should not miss. You can even take photos with the royal guards after the ceremony too!  Do take note that Gyeongbokgung Palace is closed on Tuesdays and sometimes it may close if it gets too crowded, so do plan accordingly. A night tour would be even better if you are able to get a slot. This is an excellent place to see both the locals and tourists in Hanbok, the Korean national costume, since those in Hanbok get in for free. If you want less crowds however, I would strongly suggest Changdeokgung Palace instead if you only have time for one palace to visit.

Great place for pictures, go on a weekday if you can because weekends can get overcrowded with tourist buses. It was amazing to walk around and sight see. Very beautiful and it was very memorable. It is not very friendly to strollers, especially in the entrance areas. It will not be a smooth ride. I recommend baby wearing if possible.

This is right across from my office and have been staring at it through the window every business trip. Decided to check it out. The palace is ok not very elaborate like others around the world. A guided tour may have been interesting. The change of guards is good.

There are several things you need to do it in the palace or else you will regret in your visit 1) Bring a good camera so you can take some magnificient picture of the Palace 2) After pay the ticket, go right of the palace to check out the tea serving ceremony or rice cake ceremony so you can taste and learn some , as the class or ceremony is depended on the timing 3) Have pictures with the soldiers there 4) Have pictures with the pretty korean with hanok ( korean costume ) 5) Have fun jumping and running as it is really huge!  The last thing is, visit every single corner of the palace and it is sweet enough if you can take some nice pictures with the nice scenery with your love one!

You should visit this place during chuseok, although is a bit crowded, but many cultural activities, free hanbok experiences happening during this time!  香远亭就是所谓的宫内后院，也是我最喜欢的地方。。 醉香桥，景如其名。。 令人陶醉的独木桥与充满香气的莲花池左右作伴！ 那个朝代，这里应该是最让人舒缓压力的地方了！

Was here, there is some kind of park around the palaces, but nothing "wow", just a traditional-style buildings. Worth visiting once when it's your first time in Seoul, but I wouldn't recommend it as some great attraction

beautiful vast grounds & well preserved structures. Very thankful for our Goodwill Volunteer Tour guide whose stories brought us back to the past amazing life of the royals and its people in the palaces.
It was so great when Harry was teaching us about the history here in Gyeongbukgung Palace. I was amazed by how they maintain the structure of this place and the cleanliness too.

The palace is a must-go site if you are first time traveler to Seoul. We spen around 2-3 hour in this palace. However, minus point is that it always crowded. Small bonus point is you can rent a traditional clothes nearby and go into the palace to take picture

This park had many interesting buildings and highlights. At only $1, it was worth it to walk through and look around. I wish there was more information about it that we could have read. Perhaps we should have rented the headphones.
We really enjoyed visiting this palace. Its the best we saw during our stay in Seoul. Do not miss the ceremony when the guards change.
This palace is located in the city and its just enormous. On the back it goes all the way back in to the mountains with a nice lake and park. The buildings are superb, its the highlight of Seoul.

I would say a must if you're visiting Seoul. Or only is admission cheap but you get to go into the palace. I like going to historical places and they do have people dressed up as guards that you could take pictures with, also gives you access to the national museum.

We chose to visit Gyeongbok Palace over other palaces due to time constraint and it was a very worthwhile visit. We were marveled at the architecture in a very distinct Korean way and the detailed danchung painting of the roof overhang. In addition, Goenghoeru Pavillion in the pond was an outstanding idea to have a royal reception or celebration among noble people. Walking northbound, we were able to see a part of neighboring Chungwadae which is the residence of the Korean President in the backdrop of a mountain and it was absolutely beautiful. For the entertainment, there are changing guard procedure and military drill as the King watching. This can't be compared to the changing guard performance of Buckingnam Palace in London in quality, but it adds to understanding of the Joseon Dynasty. I highly recommend to visit the palace and the surrounding area. One can finish touring in as little as 1 hour or all day long.
Went there with the tour from the US , and this Palace was one of the attraction, we love the visit ,See all Palaces the learn Korean culture and History and shoots lot of pic . it was just great.

Come early morning as soon as it opens for a peaceful walk around and good photo opportunities. Gets crazy crowded and noisy as it gets closer to lunch. Also a good idea to set aside time to do the National Folk Museum here as it's just to the side of the palace. Must see if you have not been to Seoul before.

We were in Seoul for 5 days but only chose to visit one Palace, and after research it was obvious to me this was the one to go to. My reason? It's the birthplace of the Joseon Dynasty. When the capital was moved to Seoul, this was the first Palace, and the entire walled city of Seoul at the time was designed around this Palace. We went less for the architecture and more for the history and layout- specifically, with the mountain as a backdrop and the pond in the rear. Walking thru and spending time in the adjacent dongs, all which had their own purpose serving this Palace, made their history all the more interesting as well.  You can reasonably do the Palace in one hour, and there are free English guided tours available 3 times each day- check the times on their website to plan your visit.

There are multiple palaces in Seoul so I would recommend to only visit Gyeongbokgung if there is any time constraint. Tip: admission fee is waived if you visit in Korean traditional clothing. There is a shop opposite the palace that you can rent from but I would recommend to rent them at Insadong as it is MUCH cheaper (40k vs 14k for 4 hours) :)

It might be boring to many people but it's amazing for history lover. It's very huge and needs time to walk there. Especially that there is also museum. I will recommend any one want to visit it 6 hours. يمكن ان يكون هذا المكان ممل للعديدين ولكنه سيكون وجهة تشد المهتمين بالتاريخ. المكان كبير جدا ويحتاج وقت للتنقل مشيا على الأقدام وخصوصا ان هنالك متخف بجانبه. انصح بتخصيص ٦ ساعات على الأقل لهذه الفعالية.
A nice palace with lot of history. Easily reachable via the metro. Just follow instructions when you reach the metro station and you will never get lost.

The palace is huge, with a lot of buildings. Walking is easy though, as it's mostly flat. The palace features the mountains as its backdrop, enhancing its picturesque quality. The ponds are beautiful, and we're built to reflect the mountains' beauty.  Make sure to see the changing of the guard ceremony at 10am or 2pm. Go a bit before then as they also have a short parade outside the side gate with the guards making in formation.

Majestic palace which offers a glance to the splendour past. Several palaces with its history plus a leisure park and lake dotted the landscape. Be sure to watch guard changing ceremony. A refuge from busy city just a step away
The palace, the views -everything is gorgeous. I would definitely recommend people to spend some time here.
we took hop-on hop-off tour bus and with various stops you can get off and get on, the route was pretty good and inexpensive..

Nice garden outside the museum and palace . The palace look nice but the facades and even interior looked so freshly painted and lacked historic feel but nice to see pretty ladies in traditional hanbok.

The palace is impressive in itself. Also impressive is the way it is taken care of, including keeping its background view of mountains, in center Seoul with all the high rises around it. A real monument to Korea's past.
Catch the changing of the guard ceremony, dress up in Hanbok, join a free tour, visit the museum afterwards.. you could spend the best part of a day just on this one location alone :)

The palace complex was actually hugh! The palace itself was really beautiful and grand. The architecture of all the buildings in the palace complex the really mesmerizing. I was particularly impressed with the Royal Guards manning the entrance. They were awesome.

Visited at the end of the day and it was superb. No large groups so the place was quiet, almost serene, the surroundings are lovely and the buildings interesting. Can easily find a quiet spot to read a book. I didn't go with a guide and later regretted as I believe it would have made the visit even more enjoyable.

As one of the most popular tourist spot in Seoul. Prepare for huge crowd of tourists and buses in the area.  Very nice place to visit and add knowledge of korean history.  There is a show at the gate once in a an hour (might change) where guards will perform a war march.
There are site with nice views but didn't offer much to see since most rooms are barred from entrance. Only peeking from windows are allowed. But quite a place to visit anyway. Love the lakes though.

Gyeongbukgung, or known as Gyeongbuk Palace. It was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty built in 1395. I never expected that I can be so fascinated by visiting palace, guess the details and the richness of the beautiful architectures drew me into it.

As with all my reviews to sights in Seoul I will preface this by advising visitors to carefully check opening days and times and whether timed entry tickets are needed to access certain parts of the attraction and also the times for booking guided tours in their language of preference – bearing in mind that numbers can be limited  The palace and grounds occupy a large open space and although the attraction gets very busy (especially with school parties) there are quiet places that can be found to enjoy the architecture and the scale of the palace. Most of the buildings are highly decorative and have been heavily restored and in some cases recreated. If staying in Seoul for some time I would suggest buying the "all in " ticket giving access to all the main palaces in the city

I've been to Gyeongbokgung a few times. My first was in the middle of winter, and not all of the ponds had water, no leaves on the trees.... It was all pretty bleak. I went another time in fall with my sister. We got there in time for the changing of the guard ceremony which is worth scheduling around if you can. My third visit was on a special evening opening. I had to book a ticket online. I went, like most others, with a tripod and my DSLR to try and get some sweet pictures. There was a full moon that night, so we weren't disappointed.
A half day well spent surrounded by friendly and smiling local visitors. Monuments descriptions could be more detailed though if you have any interest in the actual historical facts
I went at 9am before the crowds. A delightful way to spend and an hour or two wandering around beautiful palaces and even some wildlife to see!

Geongbokgung Palace is majestic! This is a must visit if you're visiting Seoul. If you can visit during night time (only open few months of the year), it's absolutely beautiful. With a view of the mountain in the background, it's a paradise for photography enthusiasts. Lots of history behind this palace and if you time do checkout the museum to learn about the history. They have free guided tours in English.

It's a one of THE places to visit if you only have a limited time in Seoul. Huge palace grounds and gardens to explore. It can get really crowded at times so avoid the weekend crowds or school holidays.
Scenery is good. But, it will be pressed against the historical recognition. Good things will be on the bad. I will not revisit absolutely.

There are quite a few palaces in Seoul. The sheer size and scenic location within the city with the mountains in the background, as well it's historical significance make it a must-see in my opinion. It's located fairly centrally and easily accessible via the metro. There are also quite a few other museums located nearby. Our ticket allowed us free entry into the Folk Museum (or Children's Folk Museum? or both, I can't remember). You can spend hours walking around here. You can't enter the chambers or rooms but you can walk through the main structures and there are a lot of them! Wear good walking shoes.  There are many ramps around so it's also very wheelchair and stroller accessible. Clean bathrooms with toilet paper, soap and water are also on site. In order to visit the pavilion, I believe you need to make an advance reservation online. A visit to this palace can be as short or long as you want, but if you want to see most of it (at a leisurely walking pace), you should allot at least 2 hours.  It's felt smaller than the Forbidden City in Beijing China, and the restorations seemed more apparent. Still, the buildings and layout were beautiful.

This palace is quite massive, when I first saw the image in TripAdvisor, I thought it was just one building and that was it. I was quite surprised by how huge this palace is. Most of the tourist are just in the front area of the building and probably left thereafter. If you want to see the entire palace, be prepared to walk quite a bit and spend at least 2 hours there. The palace is quite beautiful and well maintained. I highly recommended to visit this place. We were there on Oct 2. which was a Korean holiday, lots of people dress up in traditional clothing and take pictures in the palace, quite interesting to see. Looks like some tourist also dress up and take pictures against the palace. We arrived around 2 pm and there were so many tourists there, I wish we arrived earlier, it would probably be nicer and less crowded.

Beautiful grounds to explore filled with heritage and history and pride for nationality.  Photographers paradise.  Beautiful gardens, seemed to be a popular place for children and teens to go dressed in traditional clothing to take photos - which I was told would be as gifts for family. As a young western woman a lot of the young girls asked for selfies with me which I was happy to oblige and I returned the favour they looked stunning in their traditional dress.  In places it did feel a little busy- lots of people around. But at no point did it feel overwhelming. I got used to the fact that Seoul as a place was densely populated so figured everywhere you went would be people in large numbers.  I loved the juxtaposition of the placement of the place cradled between modern buildings all around was this nugget of history within the city.  Make sure you go with a full battery on your camera or phone. Much needed.  You can enjoy a traditional tea ceremony too. Plenty of literature also to inform all those niggling questions.  A great day out. A lot is in the direct sunlight so if there in summer bring suncream and some coverage but once you get to the gardens there is plenty of cover in the shade.
I like the reduced design compared with chinese palaces, even it is quite similar this one is worth visiting

Kingdom in the middle of the city. Tourist crowds at this attraction because of its beautiful structure and interesting facts about Korean history. The palace does really get crowded with different tour groups so it's really hard to find a good spot for beautiful shots without tourists around. Overall it's interesting and worth the visit!

Gyeongbokgung Palace is very historical. Our tourist guide said that it was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty built in 1395. I was so amazed when i knew about it that this palace was so old yet the structure is firm.
we only spend a short time to see a couple of palaces and this one had a nice changing of the guards
its was really interesting to see the Gyeongbokkgung Place. Whit the Metro its just to easy to find it.

This Palace is very renowned for the Kings of Ancient Korean Dynasty, its a Must Visit Place to know the Korean Dynasty History and Their Culture. The Ticket Prices are very Low and make sure you go on a Weekday, weekends are usually over Crowded.

The Gyeongbokgung palace is nestled slightly north of Seoul and is walkable if you are staying in there myeongdong neighborhood of Seoul. The palace has several layers and houses multiple palaces.  If you continue to walk in, you will enter the folk museum. Great place to hang out and enjoy history.
It was a very nice palace to be around in seoul,with absolutely gorgeous nature and history of korea.. Its must see if some one visit seoul.

Not to be missed in your itinerary when you go to Seoul. You should go early to witness the first changing of guards which is really amazing. They have a free fit of guards costume. Affordable 3000krw for entry.

OH MY GOD! This is a huge area with lots of palaces all connected to each other that makes the whole place feel like a maze! The biuldings are beautiful and the architecture is superb. The decorations are really nice! Just one problem though, there wasn't enouh info about the places in this palace. We didn't want to walk with a tour and wanted to look around on our own pace so we didb't get much info. There's a good resting place with food and drinks and souvenir shop at the entrance. you can get a hanbok and wear it while you go around.

The guard-changing ceremony in the first courtyard (with the ticket sale counters) would be quite worthwhile watching.  The entrance to the palace grounds from Gwanghwamun gate looks quite ordinary, but once you get past all the initial buildings and explore the grounds, it's very beautiful with all the trees and lakes. There are very signboards explaining the buildings' histories or usages. If I had gone with the free tour (set times), I'd probably have been more interested in the buildings!
Beautiful place, great to visit on a sunny day. Free English tour is available. There are also nice performances, so you will enjoy your walk.
We visited the palace during the Thanksgiving period. Free entrance was a bonus, but would willingly have paid the admittance fee. What a beautiful, relaxing, serene place. Wonderful!!!
You should go and see this place. It is like movies. nice and good for walking. It is really big as well !
Lovely palace to walk round on a beautiful day.There are many buildings and a secret garden.Very cheap entrance fee.

A good place to hang around. You need to buy tickets to enter. Currency exchange also available near the tickets counter. This palace is large and to see everything you need to do a lot walking. You can try out the traditional costumes of the palace FOC. They'll dress you. You can find costume changing location is in your left side after passing the main entrance.

We spent a few hours here this week. Its a truly massive place and its quite busy with tourists. Head through the main gate, watch the changing of the guard (though this is not official - just actors) then spend some time in the museum to get a good overview of the place. Then my suggestion is go further back to get away from the people. You'll enjoy your time here!

The palace complex is so huge~~ only walking around, it took 2hours to finish! But the palace was really beautiful and could see Korean's art and culture! I loved the pond and the small library at the back of it. It was Hyangwon or something. It was really beautiful! Highly recommend to visit here! Go~~!

Well, this palace area is really big, a lot of similar looking palaces and houses and a lot of tourists too, because it's the most famous palace in Seoul. Nevertheless, I think it's mandatory to see this when visiting Seoul. Plus, you get free entrance to a nice museum, to escape the heat like we did when we visitied.
We had a Seoul pass which meant we could see all 5, we saw this one third after spending alot of time walking around the other two, which we felt we could've skipped and just go to this one.

The palace is located at the centre of the city and accessible by subway. The opening hour is 9:00am. It would be better if you could get there in early hours, as tons of people visit there and it gets quite crowded. It is very interesting to see a bit of old times and culture. There is a big building near the water that you can go inside and take a look, but it requires a reservation at least one day prior. If you would like to see that building, I would recommend that you should check the information in advance.

remember to wear shoe to visit this place, as u need to hv long walk and the floor is not flat. sometimes u might need to climb abit and downhill walking. alot of scenery that u might want to take picture, standby ur camera n memory cards. hehe. If you want to see some palace activity like changing shift, make sure to be there before 10am.

The first of Seoul's palaces we visited, and by far the most impressive. Incredible architecture & fantastic English guide, who explained so much in so little time. The changing of the guards ceremony was also worth staying to see. Really worth visiting.

The place is just marvelous. This is where no-filter IG-worthy pictures are made of. You can join the tours and watch the changing of guards. The entry fee is cheap like around 2,000 won only and there's a lot to see here.
It's been there over a thousand years in spite of the Japanese burning it down twice. There is a free tour with an English speaking docent that I highly recommend.
We got the audio guides and walked around by ourselves on a sunny Saturday. It was fabulous - definitely a must see.
This was very informative about Korean culture and how they lived and suffered from the Japanese. What a major historical reconstruction effort for the Korean people. This is worth a visit.

Geongbok palace reminded me Korean Historical Dramas, I was walking in the palace in Hanbok which is a traditional costume which is so beautiful, and you know what? If you are in Hanbok then no entrance fee :) 3000krw though Highly recommend to visit in Hannok

We had a private guided tour and this of course was extremely helpful. It is a large complex with a museum - good written explanation as you go with some interactive displays. Very informative and interesting for a European with little knowledge of Korea and its history.

Visited last September 17, 2016. If you are a sucker for history and architecture, then this shouldn't be missed when touring Korea! All the palaces are instagram-worthy! The palace is so huge that an hour is not enough! It's like a Mini "Forbidden City in Beijing" STUNNINGLY BEAUTIFUL!

Nice photos to take, but if without a guide its boring, however i guess you can read about it beforehand so that you can enjoy more. Takes around 1 hour to 2 hours depending on how much photos you take :)  There is an option of a combo ticket for 4 palaces and a temple, but although i bought it i do not recommend you do it unless you really enjoy this repetetive rooms and buildings :)  May be just one palace and one temple would be ebough, so no need to pay for the combo ticket  Try not to miss the guard changing ceremony and take photos witg the guards. So do go early (not after 1:30 pm) to be able to attend one of them (held each 15 minutes i guess)

It is one of the most important places in Seoul! If you are intersted in history and Korean culture in general dont miss it! They do English tours for free to explain the hlights of this great plalace! You will see many Koreans wearing traditional clothes which is super cool!

Its really easy to reach this palace. You can take subway then stop at Gyeongbok gung palace station. The interesting thing is you can rent Hanbook and you can feel as korean woman/man. Don't forget to watch replacement of bodyguard of this palace in the morning and also noon. Really recommended.

This place is great for all types of travelers. It allows those who like history to be able to read and see about a Korean Dynasty. For those who like architecture and cool structures, it gives you a ton to see and lots of detail to explore. And those who like to just go and walk for a little while, it gives you freedom to explore to your liking. Our favorite part was seeing the changing of the guards and the guard performance at the front gate. And not to mention all the children dressed in authentic Korean clothing while on their school field trips....just adorable! We would totally visit here again.
Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the five (5) major palaces in Seoul. If you can, avoid the visit on a weekend as the place becomes very crowded.

We visited the palace as it's a must for tourists. The palace wasn't huge so it only took around 45 minutes. (Disclaimer: we didn't have a guide or book tour so it was just purely browsing)  The guards at the front gate were interesting and the shift swap process was entertaining. I would recommend a visit.

The buildings are amazing and gorgeous. The place is ginormous, so be prepared to walk if you want to stay a while and venture around. There is also a free museum that doesn't require a ticket to get in, unlike The Palace. It would have been nice if there were placards or even a recording in English to understand what each building was used for. Either way, the grounds are beautiful. We went on the wrong day, it was during the holiday and it was packed! We probably would have spent more time there if not for all the people.

There are a few palaces in Seoul and i believe this is the most significant. There is a museum outside of the palace and it is a good way to relax in the museum after wandering around in the palace under the sun.

It's amazing being able to visit this palace thanks to major restorations and rebuilding. It is a small version of the Forbidden City in Beijing which reminds us of China's historical and cultural influence over Asia. The admission was free because of Korean Thanksgiving when we visited but I would say it's worth it. There is not many historical sites inside Seoul so this one is a must.  The metro stops right at the entrance.

We arrived just in time to watch the guard change over. Three mins in it chucks it down leading them to canceling the change over. Don't want to get their costumes and props wet I guess. Still worth getting a ticket as the palace is huge and the foreign escort place surrounded by water was pretty. The folk museum was good too.

Looked very lovely - but should be open all days . I arroved in Seoul on a Sunday, but was wrecked. So was all geared up on Monday for a day of sight seeing - Nothing open. Plan ahead. Not too disappointed as this was a business trip and so sightseeing was not the primary reason for visit!
The guards at the entrance very interesting. There is not much things to see inside. It was not crowded and probably you need 15 minutes to view the whole palace.

I'm not sure if its because I went on a slightly rainy day or if I didn't get to see the changing of the palace guards, but I didn't find Gyeongbukgung as spectacular as I'd hoped. Don't get me wrong, it's absolutely beautiful, larger than life, and really takes you back to what life was like back then for anyone living in the palace, but besides looking around and getting that blast from the past, it was just a [beautiful] building.  However, it's worth a visit if you've never been to a Korean palace! It's always great learning about origins of great nations.
The fee is about 1,000 won =$1 USD. There a English tour in the palace but schedule time. Nice places to take pictures and nice ponds.

Though smaller than the Forbidden City in Beijing, there is quite a bit of the same sense of Asian greatness of this palace. On a quiet morning visit, it is easy to imagine how this place was once the pinnacle of a civllisation now transformed. The palace is located smack-bang in the middle of bustling Seoul, and although the megacity outside the walls is ever active, noisy and effeciently moving on, time somehow slows when inside. The noises of everyday-life are muffled, and a sense of awe is ever present.

The guard changing ceremony happens 4 times a day and I was lucky to watch it the moment I arrived. The place is huge but the buildings are quite similar. I can't enter any of the buildings except for the one in the picture. But that one visitors have to reserve entry a day before. There are a few explanation stands on what the building are but make sure to get the brochure from information counter so you get more understanding of the buildings from the visit.
Who knew that the Korean dynasty was so old or that the 4th king created to Korean language or that it died out because the 27th king was infertile?
Be sure to rent all a costume at a street leftside the palace. Ask the info for directions and get a 10k won discount coupon

I attended a group tour with Koridoor tours to Gyeongbokgung and several other historic sites around Seoul recently. Gyeongbokgung was by far my husband's and my favorite place on the tour. We enjoyed the changing of the guard ceremony when we first arrived, though it was crowded and a bit hard to see the action. After the ceremony, we toured around the palace grounds and were blown away by their beauty. This is a great place to take photos, relax, picnic, and get a history lesson. We plan to return to see the palace in more depth. It is a serene sanctuary right in the middle of Seoul!

You can spend 1 hour or half a day here. It's really up to you. It is very large and on the premise are also the Palace Museum and the National Folk Museum. The palace is beautiful. There are a lot of people wearing the traditional Korean clothes around and it is really nice. At two o'clock, there is a "guards changing" ceremony. If you happen to be there, I recommend it, but if you miss it, I don't think you should be sad. The two story structure shown requires Internet reservation a day in advance, so I was kind of bummed that I did not get to go in. I just walked around and took my time and worked up a good appetite for the yummy Korean food I had later.

The oldest and largest of all 5 palaces in Seoul. We signed up with the Seoul Tourism Board free walking tour and we had an English speaking guide. The guide gave us a detailed introduction of the whole palace. It is highly recommended that you visit the palace early as it got hotter during the late morning and there was no shade.

The actual palace can only be observed through a wide opening. One cannot actually enter the palace buildings, one can just walk around them and get an impression how the royalty functioned in ancient times. The Koreans do their best to keep up old traditions and it is fun to see the guards dressed up in traditional attire and to see the Changing of the Guards ceremony. In the area there were many patriotic young Koreans walking around being photographed in traditional costumes that it is possible to rent for a few hours at the Hanok Center nearby. The colorful costumes and the Changing of the Guards make the place more interesting. When we were there it was very hot and there is very little shade. Take big hats/sunshades...

This is the number one place to visit for all first timers. Guaranteed you with lots of group tours and people with kids learning about the history. Huge place that takes up to 2 hours for a visit! Get the palace and jongmo shrine pass for easy/quick/best value access!

We visited five palace areas in Seoul, and liked them all. Gyeongbokgung palace is huge, and the scenery behind it is beautiful (mountains look gorgeous)! We ended up sitting by the pond with my friends for hours, just chatting and laughing. At one point the park guard had to come tell us to leave, because the park had closed. The atmosphere was very relaxed.  Make sure to get the palace pass which gets you into all the five main palace areas in Seoul. It costs 10,000 won and can be bought at any ticket counter near the entryways.

A sprawling complex with many buildings. Take the tour. That is so helpful. One thing that we found enchanting was the presence of so many young Korean people dressed in native costumes. It was like stepping into the past.

On exiting the metro station, I was approached by a group of Korean youngsters offering tours of the Palace. My guide was a 15 year-old girl speaking perfect English. She was excellent. She refused a tip - said they were not allowed
Nice overview place to begin first visit to Seoul from the US. Good review of the history in many languages. Enjoyed the guard change ceremony. Never saw so many selfie sticks used in one place.

Fascinating and majestic palace - well restored. I love that it has the mountain range as backdrop, beautiful lakes within the compound and located in downtown modern Seoul. Easily accessible by public transport or taxi. We missed the cultural performance but saw the performer in traditional costumes - very colorful and pretty!
A good interesting day and a real feel for ancient Korean culture, the temples look amazing, can get busy and hot depending on time of year but certainly worth a visit if you are in Seoul.
The palace was very popular. The palace is kept in good condition and provides a good perspective on life in the palace when it was inhabited.
I was so looking forward to seeing this palace but ended up feeling underwhelmed. Compared to palaces in Europe, this palace is very Plain and underwhelming, with lack of displays and information.

The palace is situated in middle of the high rises that gives you a sense of the Korean culture and how it has developed over years with skyscrapers on one side and this well preserved Palace in middle.I would suggest to at least take the audio guide but guided tour should be preferred,this helps in providing the context of the history for the palace.Overall this is a highly recommended place to visit in Seoul.
Amazing temple. So big. The statues, the main gate. Everything looks beautiful. Really nice historic place.

If you're looking for something that will introduce you a little bit of Seoul in Joseon Era, this is it. Quite crowded but guard-changing ceremony is worth-watching. very near two museums and accessible by subway or bus
Provides an excellent example of Korean architecture for the period. A wonderful historical experience to see how Joseon royalty lived. Well worth visiting - very unique.
For only $3 CAD can't go wrong to see a massive palace. It is very large with several buildings to see. You also get free admission to the folk museum. Very nice.
Grandious! Historic! Summarizes well the past o S. Korea, a great example of how old meets new in this wonderful city!
The palace is huge. There is museum. You can engage a local guides, he's very good telling you the history of the emperor and the people of Korea.

I went to the royal gardens after reading a New York Times feature on Seoul. The tour guide was good, but the heat made paying attention difficult. The gardens were nice, but I felt like I was in a park and not a royal refuge. I'm not sure what I was expecting, perhaps something more extravagant.

it was a really nice palace, but not as splendid as i expected for the royal palace. Especially after visiting the other palaces, i need to say that it's not really that different. IT's worth going to the palace, but there is no need visiting more than one. I was done with my tour after 1 hour. I was a little bit disappointed that you could hardly see inside the building. It's very easy to get there by bus and you should also visit the Bukcheon Village close-by. By the way renting a Hanbok (in some shops nearby) costs 10.000 (i think for 1 hour), but in summer it can get really hot wearing that.

It covers a large area with lots of buildings that cannot be entered. We did it without a tour as we were too late. So, walking around on our own with scant information did not meet its our expectations.
Very grand and full of history. The palace grounds are well maintained and the architecture preserved. Weather was great and we had a good stroll and introduction to the grounds!
Worth the visit. You can watch the changing of the guard and then do the tour of the palace which is 3000 WON per person. Much to see and takes about 2 to 3 hours.

I visited this palace many times,still I feel good here It has long history of Joseon dynasty. Plus you can see many people in hanbok,which makes the palace more special. I recommend to visit Gyeongbok palace.

Built in 1395-- was the main palace of the Joseon Dynasty. Amazing structure and history. I missed the Changing of the Guards, but wish I had seen it. I went on the free English tour and picked up a brochure with information which added to the experience. The National Folk Museum of Korea is right there and worth visiting as well- no additional admission charged. The museum explains a lot about life for Koreans over time.

We didn't go inside the palace, but watched the 20-minute show of the changing of guards. And of course took the chance of photos next to the guards. We could also wear the Hanbok and had photos too, absolutely free. The staff serving us was very nice in helping us to put on the Hanbok and took nice photos for us.

Of course, it's the biggest of the five palaces in Seoul and the one with the largest parking area for the Chiniese tour buses. So, if that is your thing, come her. Much better alternative is the smaller, more manageable Changdeok Palace, a km up the road

I've visited three palaces in Seoul and this is my most favorite. It's a big place with many beautiful sites so be prepare to walk. We took our three teenage girls and found so many places to take pictures.  Recently, my girls traveled to Korean and decided to go here at night or at dusk. They ended up taking great shots and it was much cooler in July. Summers are a challenge to go sightseeing in Korea because of the heat and humidity. Visit in the fall or spring if you can.

The palace is a good way to start learning about the heritage and culture of korea, it offers tours in different languages including english, chinese and japanese, it also has different museums inside with awesome galleries, some even has an interactive feature, i will definitely come back here! Ps. Make sure to see the changing of guards parade infront of the palace gate!
Very interesting place to see and make sure you don't miss this one. We try to wear Hanbok and taking photos too.
Definitely a nice to see, but not a palace that will be remembered by us forever. Great architecture and good location, but nothing further.

This palace is huge and lots of walking on pebble road. There are some stairs to go up to see interior of the palace. It's recommended to wear the comfortable shoes. The guard exchange ceremony is interesting. Taking photos with the guard is a must!!

Absolutely beautiful wandering the grounds, watching the changing of the guard. We happened to be there on the hottest day of the year which meant we did not wander as far and as much as we wanted. Be sure to see the Folk Museum there.
Visited this palace on a very hot day. make sure you take lots of water! There are some shady places to sit but not many. It's a beautiful palace to visit.

The admission fee is reasonable $3 but my advise to read about the history before you come which will give you sense to what you will see as international tourist. Choose a cloudy day in summer to avoid heat.
Great for a morning walk, especially in the gardens. Read up on the history a little before you go to get context. Also try to see the changing of the guards.
Very nice palace grounds. Tips: Need to pay to go into palace grounds. Changing of guard is free in the front courtyard and so is the palace museum.  Enjoy!

sorry man, you cant visit Seoul without visiting this place, its a great place to taste some of the Korean history- the palace where the king himself set and ruled. if you are not that interested in history- still, it is a beautiful palace with great stories to tell. it also have many nice places to sit and have rest with your date or friends.

This was a beautiful palace but was starting to look a bit run down. It was very spacious and i wish we'd hired a guide to tell us about it as i inagine thete is a fascinating history. Worth visiting.
The most iconic landmark in seoul. U must go here if going to korea. The entry fee is cheap. Nice for backpacker

The Palace is a def must see in Seoul. Although you're not able to visit the inside and it can be extremely hot and crowded, the colorful buildings are beautiful. Don't forget to walk behind the main buildings, but also visit the gardens behind. Used to be the area for the concubines. Peaceful and still with some very pretty sites.

Go in the morning and take time to enjoy as it is huge palace and you may want to join the free guided tour provided. Do check the schedule at the Tourist Information Center after the Gwanghwamun Gate.  Catch the "Changing of Guard" at 10am and "Gate Guard Duty" performance at 11am

I went there with friends but we decided to split in several small groups. I walked around with one friend and it was really calming. But if you go there make sure it's not too hot, I couldn't enjoy it to the fullest because of 37c° and not even a single cloud. You should go there in a Hanbok and take some pics ^-^

. Must visit place . located in the city center so you can see how the history met the future . big palace beautyful park check when the gyeongbokgung palace changing of the guards very beautyful ceremony
I went there just this Monday. Definitely a must-see if you visit Seoul but try not to go here during summer because it's freaking hot here right now.

Overall: - worth going to (spend at most 2 hours) - beautiful  Pros: - cheap entrance (around $3 CAD) - huge area for you to explore in - easy walks and lots of photo opportunity - free tours in many languages to learn about the history  Cons: - you cannot enter any of the buildings as they are blocked off - it is only beautiful for the first while because buildings look similar and since you cannot enter them, it might get boring / repetitive - most buildings are not the original (a re-build) so it's not the most interesting for those who are looking for the "true feeling of emerging in ancient grounds" - Good to know: the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion (building in the middle of the pond) cannot be entered as it requires reservation in advance

The Gyeongbokgung Palace has been well-maintained over the centuries that have passed since the end of the rule of the Joseon Dynasty! The attention to detail, with regard to the the patterns on the roofs of the buildings, is flawless.  If you are lucky enough to visit the Palace during the morning or lunch hours, you may be fortunate enough to watch the changing of the Royal Guards ceremony. There are also ample opportunities to take beautiful photos to preserve the memory of your trip.  My reasoning behind the 4-star rating as opposed to 5-stars, is the signage in and around the palace. The number of signs explaining the significance of all the numerous buildings is very limited. For a tourist hotspot, signs written in English and Chinese were few and far between.  This is, however, a symbol of a very important chapter of Korean History and in my opinion, an absolute must-see in Seoul!
They have change of the guard at 10am Saturdays Much recommended Blue house is right behind the palace and is beautiful
You learn about ancient Korean culture, architecture and history. Having soldiers in costumes also help in describing life in this palace during that time. Very interesting.
This place is huge and there is so much going on. Although I didn't get to see it because there was a bad rain storm and it was still raining a little, I still enjoyed walking around this huge place.

Royal Lee dynasty is the longest regime in the world history: over 650 years. Every buildings is still under reconstruction as many were burnt down during tough period of the Royal Lee dynasty. There is also a National museum which dusplays Royal Lives of Kings, Queens, Princes & Princesses inside of its territory that is free to all the visitors either local or foreign. May others items which shows its detail of lives in the palace.
It's a nice palace, but when compared to the Imperial palace in Beijing, this one seems very small and plain. However, the guard changing ceremony is neat to see.
Quiet and calm, worth a walk around the grounds to take in the structure and the landscape. Nice alternative to the busy city streets.

It was such a hot month that watching the changing of guards (they have my sympathy) and walking around the huge palace grounds sapped all our energy - even with an umbrella. We perspired so profusely that we decided not to visit every part of the palace. It would definitely be much nicer to visit during the cooler months although not too cold. Having said so much, I would still recommend this place highly for a visit.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is their primary palace. Tour guides are for free, you just have to wait for their schedules :) They're great, they explain everything in detail. The palace is not yet done for re-construction coz Japanese armies burnt down the whole palace except for the main hall. Will take them decades to rebuild everything. Approximately has 500 buildings inside the palace.

The palace area is quite large and nicely decorated. The colour scheme and pattern painted on the buildings reminded me of peacocks and I overheard a tour guide saying this to a tour group. The buildings are quite pretty and there's lots to look at. You can take some really stunning photos with the mountains in the background. It's pretty busy most of the time, but it's such a big place, it doesn't really matter.  We went in the summer at around 10.30am, so it was quite hot and there is nowhere to buy drinks within the palace gates, and only one drink fountain. It would be a good idea to bring your own water/drinks and a hat/umbrella to protect from the sun.  Of course, the highlight of the visit is witnessing the guard changing ceremony and taking a selfie with the unnaturally still guards afterwards. It really is something to see. You don't have to be there at 10am to see it, there are smaller ones occurring at each hour as well.  Visiting this palace can also be incorporated with a trip to Bukchon Hanok village, the other nearby palace and then Insadong. They are within reasonable walking distance of each other and makes enough to see for a whole day.
set in a very peaceful park setting great architectural with a mirrored lake you certainly will need your camera has a controlled walk to view all aspects of the Palace

Experience the guards changing ceremony at 2pm. Go early like 11am, end of the palace there is a museum. You will need at least 1 hour inside to explore. Interesting place to go. Come out to the main gate of palace by 1.50pm get ready for more. summer time get ready your umbrella.

It's really huge palace, as far as I remember, it took about 1hour to go from entrance to blue house behind the palace, absolutely walking slowly, hearing some explanation from tour guide, though. So during summer, you may need sunblock or umbrella! Anyway buildings are so beautiful and it become real with history in mind. I can tell anybody ' don't miss this palace '

Beautiful central palace. We visited it once in winter, when it was really cold. We will visit it again for sure. It is very well maintained. Most of holidays the entrance is free. Otherwise the prices is around a couple of dollars.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is definitely worth a trip if you are prepared! It is quite large and gets very hot in the summer months. Comfortable shoes, water bottles, and sun hats are a must. We were lucky enough to catch the changing of the guard, which included a small parade of fresh guards and drummer. We had to buy a ticket to go up and into the upper section of the palace entrance, to be honest, there was not much English around to explain things. Definitely read up on the history of the Palace, maps are available on site. The farther you go into the Palace the more beautiful and lush the surroundings become. We also ventured into the Korean Folk museum on the property, a welcome retreat from the heat and chance to grab a cold drink. At the very end of the property, just outside and behind the palace, The Blue House is located. It is the executive office and official residence of the South Korean head of state, the President of the Republic of Korea. Outside the palace back gate is a wonderful photo opportunity if you have interest in The Blue House. We took the path down between the Palace and The Blue House and came to large intersection which had a beautiful fountain and free museum across the street.

If you're someone who enjoys watching historical dramas (like me hehe), then you will definitely love this palace. However if you're not, fret not. This palace's sights will still take your breath away by it's magnificent architecture, and not to mention how amazing your photos will turn out.  Be sure to catch the royal guards changing ceremony, and try not to miss it as they only have certain timings for it. To add on, it is quite interesting to see how they can manage to play instruments and/or march in sync in those long uniforms of theirs. You can also take pictures with the guards that are standing at the entrance of the palace (if you're lucky, they might even smile for your pictures!).

This palace is amazing but the Secret Garden tour is well worth it! It's very inexpensive and the docent is extremely knowledgeable! It was super hot out (August) but the shade offered along the path makes it bearable.
It's very cheap to access and very quiet and reflective. I liken it to a smaller version of The Forbidden City.
Perfect place to walk around and discover the Korean culture. Don't miss the Korean couples dressed in traditional clothing.

This vast area would give you a good understanding of Korean culture. The colorful parade showcasing the different traditional costumes of their soldiers in the olden time. While the palace is good, the only thing that disappoints me is the buildings built around the palace that for me is an eye sore. Other than that, everything is perfect. :-)
The palace is very beautiful with mountains as the background. We also get to see the changing of the palace guard ceremony at 10:00 am. Very interesting! It was like returning to the past

Def a must while in Seoul. Very beautiful and huge!! You can spend hours wandering around. You get to see lots of buildings and gardens. A few times per day there's a guards change (check website) - recommend! Get an English tour (it's free, btw, and only 1 hour) - there are few per day. And the National Folk Museum of Korea is within! Also nice and not too big.

I went as the palace was in the centre of Seoul - I had already visited the Secret Garden and C'bok Palace earlier in the trip - so didn't expect to be overwhelmed in comparison. To be honest - I think this was my favourite Palace in Seoul. Firstly the scale is immense when one considers it is slap bang in the middle of the city. secondly - when you are expecting to just wander through labyrinths of palace buildings, you stumble across beautiful gardens and pools of water - the gardens themselves are extensive and astonishingly pretty. I found it very peaceful and a refugee from the Seoul summer heat. I would advise any visitor to take themselves off for a visit and at Won 3,000 for an entry ticket, it was incredibly cheap compared to the prices to visit palaces and castles at home in the UK.

If you are in Seoul, you have to go there. This place is amazing. It's HUGE so be ready to walk. The gardens are breath taking. Very beautiful and peaceful.  Can get really HOT in summer, so bring water, sunglasses or a cap.  I learned a lot about Korean History just by visiting this place. I highly recommend it.

This palace have about 15-16 pavilion (i forget about the sum exactly 😆)..... From the gate...if you get the right timing, you can see the little ceremony of guard changing... After passing the gate, prepare your energy to walked around the palace. You also can visit the blue house (just in front the gate) and the museum (free) around there.
Not much signage so, I would recommend taking a tour. Be sure not to go in the heat of the day. There is little shade and the summer heat was brutal.

Much to explore and one of the great many places to understand the history and culture of Korea. It is good to note the different time slots for the guided tours to help plan your trip. There is a 3pm English tour.

Gyeongbokgung Palace was my second favorite palace in the city. Its so huge that you really don't have to go visit any of the other palaces as they are all extremely similar. I probably spent around 2.5 hours walking around and admiring the beautiful architecture and natural areas located within the palace grounds. There was a free show performed by the locals as I entered the palace gate, which was quite interesting to watch as they were demonstrating a scene from the past. The National Folk Museum of Korea is located on the same grounds, which was a nice pit stop along the way. I'll keep my review short by saying that it was worth the visit as the palace is rich in culture and history and it's so big that you can get the full palace experience!

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a great place to see houses of royal family members and to know something about their history and lifestyle. It has a huge beautiful territory, it took us about 2 hours to walk through the palace. It also includes admission free museum and a small cafe/restaurant. There are ceremonies for the Opening and Closing of Palace Gates and Guard Changes. Several times a day there are free guided tours in Korean, English, Chinese and Japanese. Tip: it may be hard to walk through all territory in hot sunny day, better take an umbrella and at least one bottle of water.
Love the free tour, great presentation, nice and expansive gardens on site. Also has traditional concert at night during the summer months. Usually closed on Tuesdays.

Mighty structures from Joseon dynasty. The palace area is really huge and will take time to cover. So must go there with time in hand & it is definitely worthy. Big palaces. signature designs, and so organized. The whole area is highly well maintained. Souvenir shop and food is available inside. The Museum will brief the amazing past of the royals.  This place very near from Changdeokgung Palace and can be visited together. Walking would be the best way from one place to another.
Mosth popular place in seoul, the grand palace. You can learn about the history of korean people. In the morning, there is also change guard ceremony.

We all know if you are in Seoul you will end up there, to make best use of your time 1- Go with a free tour, English tours are scarce but sure its better than walking by yourself, check the time in their website 2- Watch guard changing, the time is about 13:00 ish I guess Enjoy

We went there 9 am and no cue so going in for a visit different palaces and building inside. The museum was nice . It show part of the history of Korean dynasty. Soldiers exchange was 11 am in main entrance.
Get there at least 10 minutes before the times to see the changing of the guards. We liked this Palace the most.
Beautiful architecture and peaceful gardens offer some respite from the madness of Seoul's traffic. Lovely to see so many school children in traditional dress- hanbok.

The Gyeongbokgung palace is definitely worth a look if you are visiting Seoul. Set at the north end of the city against a mountain backdrop, Gyeongbokgung is actually one of three Joseon dynasty palaces that formed a palatial precinct before it was systematically broken up during the Japanese occupation in the early 1900s. Much of it has now been restored or rebuilt. The original throne hall survived the destruction and is a relatively open building so you can usually see inside, even if the palace is crowded. There are some beautiful gardens and quiet courtyards that I found I had to myself despite visiting in the middle of Summer break. There is also a guard in traditional dress at the main south gate. It routinely changes with great ceremony during the day and the accompanying narrative is interesting. You can see most of Gyeongbokgung in about 3 hours but if you have more time, wander a little further and see the nearby palaces of the Queen and Crown Prince.

This palace was massive!!! It goes on and on and on and you have to walk a lot. I suggest getting a tour guide when you go here otherwise you won't know what the several palace buildings are and what's going on. Go at night preferably as the place is lit up.
Old palace, historic site, well serviced for travelers! It is a little bit hot to visit during the day time in summer.
Also called the North Palace, this is a beautiful palace, where the guard changing ceremony is a must-see.
Very nice, in particular in spring, guard change real fun for children. Well maintained and interesting to roam around.
It's a lovely palace and very expansive. For photographers, it is an excellent venue both day and night. I can't remember how much the ticket was, but probably around $2 usd.

This palace is a must visit place in Seoul. Recently it is open for public at night for a certain period of time. I enjoyed the night tour. There is a museum beside this which is also a good place to visit. I recommend to search the website and go there when night tour is open... Late afternoon would be good time to visit.

this palace is one of most interesting places in the world as you can enjoy the feeling of the ancient times and the joy of seeing the amazing costumes of the Korean people. you must see the changing guard cermony.

Enjoyed the walk we did through the amazing gardens and old buildings. Very peaceful setting and interesting part of Korean history. Seoul is a very busy city and this land mark is nice break from all the hustle and bustle
Try to go on weekdays. Crowds can be fierce on weekends. Korean grandmothers are often quite pushy in queues -- no news to Koreas but surprising to westerners.
Accessible, with tourists even the cold season, it helps you realize the history of Seoul and South Korea.
This palace is one of the most amazing places I've visited. The mixture of the great architecture together with its surroundings was just something out of this world.
The place was huge. The whole are is wonderful. It's better to come with a guide so you can hear the history, but there's signs everywhere with the story of each section of the beautiful palace.
It was a great way to look at Korea's past and looking at the way Koreans lived in the past especially the royal Koreans and how the architecture of the palace.
Gyeongbokgung Palace is the historical of korean, this place is so many people but when we walk to hidden garden, I'm feel peacefully and relax.

An extremely interesting place to learn about Korean history, culture and architecture. Quite big so ideally need 2+ hours to see it all, especially if you take the time to stop and photograph each area.

I visited the palace once in 2015 during day and once in July 2016 at night. I have to say, the first time I saw the architecture of the buildings I was impressed. The second time around was not as impressive. I would recommend the palace to first time visitors to get a better feel for Korean style buildings. If I go back to Korea, the palace will not be on my list to do.

It's a miracle this place still exists, considering the unthinkable brutality and genocide Korea had to suffer through during the Japanese colonization. Besides witnessing the pagoda's and old palace's you will come to learn why Koreans take such pride in their heritage. I enjoyed learning about how the Kings used to walk in figure 8, symbolizing wealth since you could afford to feed yourself lavishly. Go check it ou.
One of the places to see for a historic tour in Seoul, Korea. It is a big palace and has nice gardens. You could take a stroll and feel at peace. It is worth going and seeing

This is an ancient palace in the middle of very modern city. The site has been restored quite heavily but remains very interesting. there are two museums on site, we visited one of them the museum of Korean Life. A great little museum.
It was a really big palace. Highly recommend you to go if you haven't been there. It is a place that I think one must go in Seoul.
Much larger than you would expect, so come with adequate time to enjoy yourself. Walking through the gardens was particularly enjoyable.
Is a great cultural site. You can spent a lot of time in the Palace. Good place for the family to visit.
A interesting place to visit. If you like old places full of history this is a must go in Seoul. I liked it!
Unfortunately, there was a lot of tourists visiting gyeongbokgung and it's quite difficult to take a nice picture with all of these people as the background.
Great place to know more about the culture and history. Appreciated the tour guide's stories, but if you want to soak in the entire place, be ready to spend half a day, at least.

Really great place except for the fact that it was reaaaalllyyy hot cos it was summertime. MASSIVE place. Guided tours were available but I didn't think the English would be comprehensible so decided to stick it out on my own. Overall good eye opener to their culture.
It was a really big castle and I have the chance to watch the garde parade, it was a unique show we can only see there I think. It is a really touristic place but a must see in Seoul !

This is a must-see if you go to Seoul, especially to understand something of Korea's cultural history. The palace is actually a huge complex of buildings square in the midst of downtown Seoul's business district, so it's accessible by car, bus, or metro. Parking is at a premium,however, so use public transport if at all possible. Be advised that this tour requires lots of walking due to the size of the complex, numerous buildings & gardens, etc. If you're there in summer, except it to be HOT, so be prepared. An umbrella is a good idea, both in case of rain & for shade if it doesn't rain. The buildings are serene & beautiful outside & surprisingly plain inside. On our visit there were numerous Koea-American, Koean-Canadian,& Korean-Australian young women there in full traditional dress, which is beautiful & adds to the charm of the place. It's kind of a pilgrimage for them, apparently. Don't miss the excellent museum adjacent to the complex. Nice & cool in there, & the exhibits are interesting & help you understand what you're seeing outside. (I suggest doing the museum first, then the complex.) The restaurant adjacent to the museum offers a limited Korean cuisine. If that doesn't appeal to you, there are numerous food outlets in the near downtown area, but that will involve more walking. You should allow at least 3 hours to tour the museum & palace complex, more if you intend to stop for a meal. But this is a great place to visit, highly recommended.

A very nice experience, also accessable with a stroller (once you manage the metro). The guards with their plastic toys look funny at its best (artificial would probably be a better description). If you are there, try to make use of the free app provided (free wifi everywhere) or the english guided tour. The adjoint folk museum is interesting and provides aircondition to cool down during high season.
Small but beautiful palace! Cheap and easy to go by subway with a direct access to the Palace. The moment we left, there was a ritual ceremony at the gate, it was beautiful, a must visit place.

Great place to take your time and walk around the palace grounds. If you can time it just right, watch the ceremonial changing of the guard first. This will last about 15 minutes and then you should explore the grounds.

This is the best palace (of the 3) in Seoul. Strongly recommend to take the free language tour (check times on their website) or book one with Seoul walking tours (free as well)...w/o someone to explain the deep history / lifestyle its just a bunch of building. The guard changing ceremony is okay nothing special.

This formed part of a private tour we'd organised, so we didn't need to buy tickets or think on timings... we simply were guided, informed and enjoyed.  The changing of the Royal guard was stunning and brilliantly translated over tannoy :-)  Our guide explained many many interesting facts about the architecture, history, residents and traditions relating to both the palace, residencies and grounds.  In the grounds is also the National Folk Museum... Well worth visiting with its excellent exhibitions and Korean history timeline board... please stop to read it, rather than just walk past, or you'll miss out on knowing so much!!  There is also a children's museum, so all ages catered for.

It was my first time to be there and it is a really a comfortable place to walk around and get to know about the history of Korea. Highly recommend you to go if you haven't been there. It is a place that I think one must go in Seoul.

The first time i went to Gyeongbukgung Palace it was raining. But even if it's raining, you can still explore the palace with umbrella and don't be afraid because the ground won't be slippery, the ground designed with rough sands and rough steppingstones deliberately so that people can't walk fast in dynasty era.
Very nice if the weather is good. Lovely surroundings and plenty to look at. Good for all types of travellers to see Korean history.

No visit to Seoul would be complete without seeing the most important palace in the country. Expect huge crowds during the summer. We had a private guide and learned about how the rulers lived, etc. Easy to access as its right in the middle of town.

A brilliant set of palaces and gardens. Really essential if you're in Seoul, the complex is well preserved and full of Korean old skool flava. You can wonder and wander for hours through the gardens. With a little bit of effort you can escape the crowds and find some serenity.

This is the largest palace of all Seoul. Too big and hot on summer days. If you would like to see a very big palace with great expansion this is it. If you would like a more manageable place with more trees and vegetation I would recommend going to the Changdeokgung palace.

I wish I had more time to spend here by myself. My 80 yr old mother and I visited here and she couldn't walk the grounds all day. (suggestion - provide benches for people to sit). We were lucky to be there at the change of guards in the morning. It is only 3000 won (about $3 US). Not a bad picture to be taken. Our hotel was in the area and personally I think the best time to visit is early morning and late at night (the gates are closed but it is less crowded and lit up at night)

It was the first monument we visited while travelling in Korea. It was gorgeous from the beginning to the end.  We took the subway to get there and we appeared inside the palace. Fantastic!  The entrance fee is very cheap and you can walk all over the huge palace. With this fee it is also included a visit in the National Museum, inside the palace area.  A great visit to do in Korea, watching the contrast of the traditional buildings and the brand new ones coexisting in the same city.
The grandest of palaces in Seoul. I arrived when they were doing a traditional guard ceremony demonstration which was great to watch. Not much to see there but nice to wander around the buildings.

There are tour groups available, but we decided to take our time to stroll around ourselves. The pavilion in the pond is a must see, and walk deeper in to find secluded/ less crowded parts of the palace it truly is beautiful. And you can't leave without watching the changing of guards march. I don't know how they stand so still even through the Korean winds (brrr....)
It let you know more about the old days in Korea. Spacious palace with beautiful pool and garden. If you wear the Korean Traditional clothing, the entrance fee is free.

Very beautiful place. Palace grounds are huge therefore allocate at least 2 hours when visiting. My favourite part of the palace is the Hwangwonjeong or the pavilion in the middle of a pond and Jibokjae which is the library/cafe on the far end. I recommend people to buy the combination tickets to save money.
i had the opportunity to go on a night tour of this palace with a Korean friend and i can highly recommend it. the lighting of the structures and the overall atmosphere was something special.

We walked the whole are of Gyeongbukgung. There is a small forest trail right at the end, overlooking a beautiful and serene lotus pond. Entrance to the folk museum inside the palace is free and is a good visit.
Worth a visit. The grounds are huge so be prepared to walk and bring a map. We did not have a tour guide. It's a fantastic place to take photos.

Really enjoyed wondering around the palace grounds. My family split up and agreed to meet back after 2 hours. Even still, my son (15 y.o.) said it wasn't enough time and he had to rush back shortly after discovering another area. Very beautiful place.

It was nice but the only reason for me to go back there would be to exercise since its got huge grounds.  A lot of the buildings were renovated (basically all of them)so there was no feeling of deeper history.

I went with a group of people in a bus, Tour guide was Korean lady fluent in English. After arriving there was too much walk and talk, we were not allowed to enter some places so we only sneak peek from outside
Very interesting place to visit and great area to walk around after the visit. A must when we visit seoul

We got a chance to visit the Korean palace. Plan on staying at least 2 hours. It is one of the best places in the city to take your family and to take pictures. It is pretty inspiring. We were lucky to have a guide explain the whole place. It is well worth the investment.
There is a lot of history to be seen and learned of at this palace. I would highly recommend it for those visiting Korea who want to learn more about the country's rich history.
My wife and my son enjoyed our visit here. The place is quite crowded when we were there.  Architecture was superb and magnificent.  A place that should not be missed when visiting Seoul.
This place is very beautiful in autumn. Its close to the city, easy to use public transportation. Free entrance fee if you wear traditional Hanbok.

If you visit Seoul then you must visit this palace! It is a very vast assortment of old buildings and gardens so be prepared for a hike! Some of the visitors are as interesting as the buildings! The juxtaposition of old against modern is striking.
I have visited the Palace a few times with my South Korean students. There is so much history there! It is amazing and all South Koreans know a lot about it.

Personally, I prefer Changdeok palace than Kyungbok palace, eventhough both of them are really beautiful korean royal palace, Kyungbok palace was distroyed by japanese people during 18-19c when japan colonized korea.  Anyway, It was really nice to travel this place with my german friend. We can get in the palace for free(even my german friend), cuz it was a cultural day! (It's the last Wed of every month). Usually, it cost around 3$. I recommend to make a reservation for the pavilion in the palace, You can make a reservation for that free through the internet website and it's free. It was the best expirence for me and my friend to go inside of the pavilion called 경회루 where used to held big party during the summertime. And of course, Most of the buildings in the palace was really good and they has free museums, one is korean palace museum, and another one is a korean folk museum.

An Amazing place. A little gem nestled between the skyscraper of Seoul. Excellent value for money especially when one buys the combination ticket for all the palaces even if one only visits a few as I did.

This is our second visit to the palace but our first time at night, it is very different from the day view, it feels very mysterious and the entrance looks so magnificent across the road. It's a good place to learn about korea's history and culture if you join the guided tours.

It is truly THE palace to visit and marvel at the beauty presented to you! For an adult you only pay 3000 won and get an overwhelming display of the past. Although, yes, there are a lot of tourists, but considering the size of the place you don't mind them.
