Wandering around the grounds there will be many couples and singles in hanbok taking a lot of pictures. It is a nice addition to the whole experience. I suggest to go there when it opens so you have some quiet moments there as well!!

This is my 2nd time to Gyeongbukgung and the palace has never failed to impress me with its palace structure and scenery.  Arrive around 10:30am before the changing guards ceremony at 11am. The entrance fee is 3,000 won per adult and if you want free entrance, wear a hanbok.  The changing guard ceremony takes about 30 minutes and you can consider having lunch at Insadong as it's merely 5 - 10 minutes walk from Gyeongbukgong.

Excellent palace, worth the 3000 Won ticket. I visited this on Saturday and many young Koreans were dressed in the national customs and happy to have their photos taken. The gardens also good to visit and good photography opportunities of Seoul skyline.

This was the first Korean palace we visited - it is a 5-minute walk from the Gwanghwamun subway stop. The admission fee is minimal ($3.00 I believe), which is appropriate. It was hot as blazes - be sure to dress for heat and bring an umbrella - not for rain - but for shade! You can look in to the palace, but visitors are not allowed inside - you have to peer-in. The palaces are interesting, though after you see one or two, they begin to look very much the same. I would recommend choosing two to visit and then move on to something else.
A grand palace with impressive architecture. The palace ground is large and the trees give it a cool ambience. You can visit the museum, the traditional house and take lots of pictures.

Gyeongbokgung Palace did not disappoint. There was a lot to admire and the size of the palace grounds was very impressive. There is also a shop within the grounds which had beautiful handicrafts and served amazing drinks.

With a beautiful backdrop of green mountains, the palace is an exquisitely restored (and partially reconstructed) monument. It's history, with successive destructions and recontructions, speaks to the resilience of the Korean people and is a testament to their coming of age as a unified people. The grounds offer a serene walk through compound after compound of simple and delicate architecture, decorated internally with vivid colors and patterns. I also highly recommend the museum!

While this is definitely nowhere as pretty or interesting as similar places in China and Japan, it's still a nice place and you should definitely visit as part of your trip to Seoul. Its a cultural attraction and it's important to learn about the history of the country

I visited Gyeongbokgung with a group of friends, it was beautiful weather in March, so I thought it would be very busy....but because the palace grounds are so expansive, even with a lot of visitors it is still quite serene and easy to find some peace and quiet. We didn't visit the museum that is within the grounds, but there was still plenty to fill in a number of hours. I would highly recommend this to anyone visiting Seoul. It's easily accessible and breathtakingly lovely.
It is one of the only realy cultural things you can do if you ask me so you have to visit it. But i wasnt that impressed, all the buildings looked the same. The pound is nice though.
very interesting palace of the kings + queens changing of the guards in full ceremonial clothes colourful site .
Mostly watched from outside, we were very impressed changing of the guard ceremony accompanied by a military-style drumming, Especially exemplary order and discipline.

Such a nice place. Im so into historical sites so this is definitely my most favourite attraction in Seoul. The lake inside the palace looks serene and the breeze is so refreshing esp when you visit in summer. Be prepared to do a lot of walking and photos. Before Gyeongbokgung, I went to several palaces. The buildings kinda look the same. Only this palace has more things to see like the lake, the pavilion, the folk museum. They have the combination ticket ( 10000won for 5 palaces or so) but nvm if you dont have enough time to take a look at all 5 as i think gyeongbokgung is enough! In case you wanna have a nice photoshoot with hanbok, probably visit other palaces. They are not as crowded as this place so people will not ruin your perfect photos.
Very reasonable costs and regular changing of the guard. The gardens were good with lots of seating in the shade. Great views of the mountains

Rich in culture. Magnificent view. We could see many koreans (and non koreans) wearing traditional korean clothing. Informative and helpful guide. Guide was available at certain timings and in different languages. This is the most famous out of the other palaces.
This is a great attraction and you can get a free guide that will make the tour much more enjoyable.

This was a wonderful visit as it somewhat shows you how the Korean people used to live and you can imagine what day to day life was like back in those times. It takes you out of the city even though you are literally in the center. A must-visit when in Seoul. Do be aware, it can get very crowded during busy times.

I went there with my family and we only walked into the front yard. We did not enter to the palace because we think there isn't much to see and they are not as nice as the Summer Palace in Beijing. However, if you are interested in these kind of places, you got to visit this Palace.
A good place to relax and enjoy the nature. Come to see how the korean royal lived in the past and the architect of korean palace. A place should visit when come to Seoul

I was walking down Samcheong-dong and found the entrance to the palace and decided to go in. It was pouring rain that day and really should've gone into the National Folk Museum but I wanted to see this palace and it would be closed the following day. The people were still there despite the rain! This palace was huge with so many grounds and so many buildings, I kept walking and walking and walking. I have to find my pics because my favorite area was this small lake with a small wooden octagon shaped building on an island in the middle. It was so beautiful and since I did not join a tour, unsure fully the history of it or what the purpose was. But, thought that would be a lovely place to go relax in if I had lived in that palace!
very beautiful palace, interesting historical building, nice to visit around spring.we came just in time for guard changing ceremony.
Huge, beautiful, grand, cheap to visit, very korean experience, next to metro, can spend 1.5-3 hours.
I enjoyed visiting the palace complex. It is worthwhile to time your visit to coincide with the changing of the guards. The re-enactment added a great depth to the tour.

The day we went it was sweltering, humid and hot...so it took away from the experience a bit but the Palace is truly awesome in it's size and beauty. It was a popular destination for groups of girls and young women to take shots of themselves in their full hanbok (traditional Korean dress) But they do have a small coffee shop where one can at least get a cool refreshing beverage. Lots of green space which is missing at most of the temples that sport the same beautiful architecture.

We especially enjoyed the architecture and the changing of the guard ceremony. When we visited (on a Sunday), there were so many people, that the photos we took were not as nice as the ones already posted. If we were to visit again, we would visit on a weekday when it most likely will be less crowded. If you benefited from this rating, please click the helpful button.
This beautiful palace was a beautiful trip through history The English speaking tour guide was great. We learned a lot and enjoyed our experience.
Good architecture of past korean building, there is free guide for every hour that will explained the for every building in this palace, in english.
This place and the changing of the guard is not to be missed. Choose a good sunny day to visit this spot. Feel the pulse of past korean History

The English tour is a must! the guide was so passionate about the topic and so informative. The palace its self is very breathtaking and has copious amounts of history behind it, a must when in Seoul!

Travelling to Seoul will never be complete without visiting this grandest palace. Going to Gyeongbokgung Palace is really very educative and enriching, indeed an eye opener to Korean culture especially in their way of life and government in the past.Every nook and corner of it is rich in history and breathtaking. However, be prepared to wear comfy shoes as you are expected to climb steep stairs.

The costumes are real, the place have a fresh paint job, a lot of history in the place. We went for an afternoon visit and was worth the walk. Everything is new and fresh. We were able to watch the changing of the guard which was colourful and energetic. Many tourists wearing traditional costumes added to the place and the realism. Go for a visit.
It should be for free because nothing special there except the guards ceremony ,but you can walk along to city stars surrounded by great buildings and ...
This is a Main Palace at Seoul area. Very Big area, with many rooms and variety usefulness. We should go arround this palace for minimum 1-2 hour. Take Picture in several Big Building.

We entered the palace through, I think, the Southern Gate and watched the changing of the guard ceremony. The grounds initially are pretty stark, though once we walked close to and past the palace, the grounds were filled with colorful flowers, gardens, trees and life. Worth seeing!

There are quite many people visiting this palace as it is the largest one in the area. Some of the buildings have furniture in them so you can see from the door how the people used to live. I personally preferred the Changdeokgung palace as it has more trees and flowers in the palace area and is more peaceful. But why not visit both?

What started as a hot and humid June day while we were visiting the palace, turned into a monster storm in no time that stranded us midway round this palace. After some 40 minutes of solid rain, we extricated ourselves at the expense of wading through deep puddles as we swung around the various buildings of historical interest. Be careful crossing the courtyards between buildings as we found the stone paths quite slippery on our way out. Viewing was restricted from outside looking in to dark halls and rooms, so it was a shame not to really be able to embrace everything our enthusiastic Korean guide was telling us about the palace history. Bound to be better on a dry day there.

The highlight of the visit was the flag changing ceremony with the soldiers wearing traditional Korean dress. The surrounding and palace is beautiful with lot of historically important details. It will take around 1 hour to see the palace fully...
It is a very beautiful place to visit. A must see in Seoul. Near the public transport. Multi language tours several times per day.

Most of the palace is packed with tour groups, but luckily it seems the tours only see certain parts of the palace. I was able to find a beautiful area where I was completely alone, and it was very peaceful to sit and think, or just admire the architecture.
A good place to visit at any time. Shop and cafe available. Interesting displays inside and attractive walks outside.

For what this is advertised to be, I must be honest and say I left feeling quite underwhelmed.  Let's get one thing clear: The palace grounds are beautiful. No denying that. But as I was looking for a more informative destination, this wasn't the place for me.  Sure, there are english tours, but few and far between. And there is an app that provides an audio guide, but the initial app had me downloading another app, which then asked me to download another service, at which point I gave up.  I personally found the Korean Folk museum on the other end of the palace MUCH more interesting and informative (and it's free).  And even for nature folk: Changdeokgung Palace seems to be the better option than this.
Very beautiful place & lots of place to take picture. But it closed at 6pm.  Ticket fee for adult 3000/person  Very recommended for tourist when visit seoul

I was informed that there are 5 most famous palaces in Korea and Gyeongbukgong Palace is one of them. Located in the middle of Seoul, it is definitely easily reachable by the subway. The entrance fee was really cheap and you can enter for free if you wear the Korean's traditional clothes called Hanbok. It was definitely worth a visit to the palace.

Went to Gyeongbokgung Palace the very first day of my trip. It is very beautiful and large cultural spot. There are a lot of nice places in the Palace to photograph. Really liked walking in Gyeongbokgung.

Everyone says that because it's true. Go for the long version and get there early enough to get a front-row stance. The music, the pageant, the colorful uniforms are a real visual and auditory treat. The rest of the palace is very interesting and clean, neat and tidy. I have visited way too many Asian palaces, shrines, temples and Buddhas and so I can't be trusted to do it justice.

We visited the place at the end of May and it was a little hot and sunny but it was a beautiful place to visit and take photos. You see young girls and guys dressed in hanbok taking photos around the palace which adds a nice touch to the place and the gift shop is also a nice place to visit but it could be a little on the expensive side.

This is our very first place to visit in Seoul. It was really nice to walk around in the palace and there were also other museums nearby the palace such as the Children Museum.  Free admission fro the Children Museum.Children can watch the Korean animation of the folklore story of Moon and Sun.This is one of the museums located inside the Gyeongbokgung Palace.But you have to pay for the entrance fees at Gyeongbokgung, the rest of the museums inside are with free admission.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a nice and big enough cultural area to explore and photographed. Rent 24 hours package of hanbok and wear it when u come to this palace. It is placed in one area with Bukchon Village and only few steps away in front of Insa-dong market.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace was the first place we went to. If you're a tourist, this is definitely a must go. Correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe that the K-drama "Princess Hours" was shot at the Gyeongbokgung Palace. You'll see the "changing of guards".

This old palace and the gates are very impressive (built late 1300s) and it is absolutely amazing that the admission is only about $1USD. The palace grounds are quite extensive, so you can easily spend a few hours here if you want to see it all, or just a short time if you only want to walk through the gates and up to the palace. I recommend good walking shoes as the paving stones are a bit uneven in places, and bring water and a hat, as the grounds are quite open with lots of sun.

If you are a huge fan of Korean historical drama, there's no better place than this one where you can enjoy every little details about Korea's past. Try rent a Hanbok, a traditional costume, so you can enter the palace for free! Guide book and audio guide are available for purchase and rent. Free guide tour is also available.

It is really amazing place. Very cheap too (only 3.000 won and you get a free tour of 1:30h). The place is huge so wear confortable clothes and shoes. If you are coming in a sunny day do not forget to wear sunscreen and caps because except for the gardens, there are not much shadow or trees to hide from the sun. You will probably spend more than 2 hours walking. You can also rent an audio tour if you do not want to wait for the next free tour. Beautiful buildings and story of Joseun Dinasty.

This is the first Royal palace built in the Joeson Dynasty 500 years ago. The is largest of the five grand palaces remaining in Seoul. It provides a glimpse into Joeson's Royal culture and architecture. Great place to go back in time and know Korean history and how they evolved over the years to a modern county while deeply rooted with their traditions too. You can take pics with girls dressed in traditional Korean dresses too. Best time to visit is around 4pm as after you can enjoy the evening in Gwanghwamun Square. Admission is 3000 won.
Large palace to explore. Very nice to walk around and admire the structures and the ground. You can spend hours here.
Make sure you have time, It takes about a two hours to see the whole thing. It is worth it though! Must go. Go to the museum prior to your entrance too!

Gyeongbokgung palace it is good tourists attraction in Seoul because it is the largest palace built by Jason dynasty. The royal family who ruled Korea kingdom in 1392. I don't recommend to stay long time because the heat of summers. The best activities is the ceremony of change the guard who wears historic dressed.

We went on the last Wednesday of the month which was designated as a culture day, so the entrance to the palace was free. We grabbed a guidebook for KRW500 from the ticket counter as soon as we entered. There're various pavilions, halls and gates in this huge palace compound, so plan your route and time accordingly so that you can maximize the time.  We managed to view the Hyangwonjeong Pavilion with its reflection in the pond. However, this reflection disappeared over time. If you wish to snap a picture with the reflection, it is best to head to this pavilion as soon as you enter the palace ground early in the morning. Do check out the schedule of the changing of the guard ceremony. This is a must watch if you've not watched it in Deoksugung.  The paint of the the buildings looks new and well maintained. Exploring this huge area brings you back to a different era. It is rich in history so it'll be good to do some reading before visiting. The landscape should offer different kinds of beauty in different seasons.  Spend at least half a day because there are 2 museums here. If you plan to tour a little more in depth, you might need a full day. We did not visit the museums since we continued our visit to Cheongwadae (Blue House) in the afternoon.

It must be have a lot of history here. So large, amazing and hot weather this month. But its amazing to come here. See a king palace. See some girl and boy use a traditional korean clothes. Good, must visit place in seoul

Although each palace has unique features this was by far my favorite palace in Seoul. The architecture is wonderful and being able to see the Blue House was neat. It will take a long time to explore, so make sure to take your time.

The place is so extensive. When you step foot on the grounds, it immediately transports you to a different era. The area is full of ancient looking buildings and a lots of history and stories embedded in the architecture. The highlight for me was the beautiful pond within the vicinity which was covered in lotus plants! There is also a free museum within the compound which apart from its historical value, also is fully air conditioned and comes with a cafe. A great place to take breather.

I highly recommend booking a hanbok rental around the area (about 25-30usd for whole day) before coming here and entrance will be free. I believe they provide tours but I went on my own so I could take my time. This is a great palace to come if you have time to spare. I had a wonderful time and my pictures looked lovely with the palace back ground.
gyeongbokbong Palace is a nice place to have a day long excursion. You can easily access it by subway. There are many great restaurants nearby. The kids will enjoy this place!

You have to arrive about 15 minutes before 10 am to get a good place to see the changing of the guards. It is worth the shirt wait before entering tha grounds which are nicely kept. The place was rebuilt in the 90's so it does not have the same character as the other palaces. The gardens are worth the visit with great opportunities for photos with the family.
Visited the palace and it is a nice area to walk around and see the korean style buildings and parks. Relaxing enviroment in the middle of a buzy city.
A fine display of Korean history. Huge complex of ancient relics preserved nicely. Two relevant museums are there just next to it. But the facility is not wheel chair friendly.

To truly appreciate the Korean people and their history a visit to the Gyeonbokgung Palace is essential. It is a huge site easily accessible by the Seoul Metro. There is a very nominal entry fee equivalent to about $3 that goes towards restoration and upkeep. Seniors are free. There is a free English guided tour that commences at 10 am and well is worth it. The palace is really a group of several separate residences and gives a feel for life in the Chosun Dynasty. Many sections have been restored and it lacks the opulence of other palaces, but does depict the reality of life in a bygone era, at very beautiful location in Seoul.

I personally prefer visiting other palaces as Gyeongbokgung can get very crowded and very touristy.  Huge area, free tour guide available (u can make reservation frm their official website). Spare at least 2-3hr if u wanna cover all areas thoroughly.  ChangingGuard ceremony musnt be missed.  Hanbok rental available just in front of the palace entrance. Wearing hanbok lets u enter palaces (this one n others) for FREE ! :-)

This place is huge and you must expect to spend 4 to 5 hours appreciating the historical significance of the place. Take your time and walk leisurely at your own pace. There are English speaking guides available if you want a fast pace around the area. There are many restrooms available.
One of the must visit place when you are in Seoul. In this place you will learn the korean culture. Never miss the Guards changing ceremony when you visit.

rainy gloomy day which took away the colours of the photos, but not the grandeur of the place. Majestic and pretty, it was really a fulfilling of real life witnessing of drama scenes. Joined the free guided tour and it was an informative 1.5hours. IMHO, better changdeokgung

This tour is absolutely nice !!! We loved everything, especially the greated tour options. Thanks for all of your good suggestions. I also appreciate your guiding me as I really appreciate Seoul and Korean culture so much now! Thank you for everything.

There are few exhibits but the size, grandeur and history is apparent over the extensive grounds. The buildings are a mix of old and many authentic reconstructions, as apparently Japanese colonial occupiers burnt them down several times of the millenia. Definitely worth a visit and English-speaking yours are free.

This is my favorite site in Seoul. It is the largest palace and grounds, with many buildings. 1. Do watch the changing of the guards at the front gate. It happens in the entry courtyard so you don't need to buy tickets to see it. They say it is done hourly, but I read elsewhere they do larger "shows" at 10 am and 2pm. We saw the 10am and it was very cool. They explain things in Korean, so we missed some of what was going on. However they did have some explanations in English. I could understand how they checked the new guards credentials, handed over the keys, etc. 2. Do the tour. Most of the buildings do not have furniture, so you are mostly looking at the outside and seeing the interiors from the outside. The tour really added to understanding the palace, it's history, how it was used and its significance to the Korean people. It is only 1 hour long, and worth it. Plus, it's free! English tours at 11am 1:30 and 3:30. 3 I recommend getting there for the 10am changing of the guards and then doing the 11 tour. It is likely to be a bit cooler and maybe less crowded. 4. At the back of the grounds are the buildings where Queen Min was murdered by Japanese assassins in 1895. These buildings are not brightly colored like the others and I could feel the sadness King Gojung must have felt. 5. Also at the back you can catch a glimpse of the Blue House compound, the home of Korea's President.

Visually, this is an overwhelming experience because of the sheer size and variety of structures and landscapes. Some of them make for some of the best photo ops in Asia. There are also museums on the ground. But what I think is most rewarding -- and important -- is the history that you can learn and the perspective you can gain. As an American who has lived in Asia since 2004, I find the ignorance of my fellow countrymen about the world -- especially Asia -- to be embarrassing. The story of this place takes you through the history of Asia from a Korean perspective: subject first to China, then the various brutal invasions by Japan. Koreans feel an enormous sense of pride in their culture and their strength. As a tiny country surrounded by giants, you really appreciate both when you visit here. Take your time when you come.
A nice place to visit, large open area with historical architect and palaces, don't miss the guards shift change at the front gate.. I think its in each one or two hours..

I was almost expecting a life changing experience because of all the ratings. It was ok. We saw the changing of the guards and walked inside the palace... Meh. It looked like many of the other palaces we've seen in Korea. If this was there first one we had seen, maybe I would be more enthused.  We also walked into the museum and ate at the cafe. The food was great and reasonably priced.

This is a popular destination especially on weekends. Would try and go on a weekday to avoid larger crowds or early morning. There is English guided tour at 11am which usually attracts a crowd but is worth it to get an overview of the highlights. There's a peaceful tea shop in the back corner behind the lake. Also the museum cafe has nice teas and deserts and a nice ambience. Changing of the guard at 1pm and larger performance at 2pm but don't disrupt your day for this. The folk museum has lots to see but is s bit repetitious after visiting the national museum. Metro drops you right at the front on the orange line. Seniors over 65 are free.
Loved all the people in traditional dress & watching the changing of the guard. Maybe the gardens are beautiful in spring, but not so well attended in June. Does anyone pick the apricots?.
If You Got Koren Land already; You Must To Go This Place For Pray To The King Of Korea for Pray for Good ucky In korea Alive !

One of the important places in Seoul must be visited .. too much big and too much beautiful .. you feel there you are one of the old Korean people .. full of history .. I like it and want to visit again

A very beautiful and big palace. We spent one whole morning walking around the palace and taking photographs. We were not able to cover the whole area. There is also a museum there but we did not go in. We also saw the guards changing ceremony. This place can be reach by taking the subway to Angguk.
Its a nice and big palace. Needs time to visit. Completely korean culture show. ok-ok place. Enviourment is Nice

Go early so you will enjoy the guided tour in a smaller group. The place would get crowded at a later time. Spend at least 3 hours or up to half a day there to tour around the palace, the National Museum (near the palace entry) and also the Folk Museum inside the palace. Consider getting an integrated ticket for foreigners at krw10,000 to access other palaces and Jongmyo Shrine as well, which certainly save u some entry fee if you are planning to visit most of them.

This is a beautiful palace which you must visit at least once when in Seoul. Do watch out for the guard changing ceremonies and free guided tours. Worth the trip to understand the history of the palace. Palace is also very near to Bukchon Village area and the famous Tosokchon chicken soup restaurant (same station). Must visit.

We are in Seoul for a conference but whenever we travel we love to do museums/palaces/temples. This was wonderful - calm, beautiful, historic. It seemingly goes on forever but definitely as a respite in the chaos of city life in Seoul!

Live in person. Its stands at the end of the square over looking all this modern Seoul and its a site that cannot be missed. I went with a guide and he told me more details I wouldn't have known otherwise. Just watch out for the busloads of tourists who don't care that you would like a picture with the giant drum too.

Make sure to get a tour guide to take you through this amazing Palace. You get so much more out of exploring this sprawling complex with someone giving you context. The changing of the guard is colorful and filled with drums and music. Very cool.

It was easy to get to by metro to gyeongbokgung station, and was a pretty good place to spend an hour or two. It's actually really big and I'm not sure if we managed to see the whole place as we weren't given any maps, but the buildings were pretty repetitive after a while. It's probably a good idea to go in hanbok (that you can rent in lots of shops in the area) so you get in for free (although it's pretty cheap anyways), and take cool photos. We went during midday in summer so that wasn't really an option, but in milder weather I definitely would have done that.

Great to check out the changing of Guards before entering the palace. Entrance fees are very economical at 3000 won for adult. If the main palace is too crowded , it would also be interesting to move to the side palaces or gardens. You could witness the kitchen where servants cook or royals have their meals. Gardens and lakes are so beautiful. The entrance fees also entitle you to enter the folks museum which is worth a trip as well ! Overall, we spent about 3 very enjoyable hours here just strolling on the grounds. Highly recommended !
Beautiful palace of the Emperor, there's a free guide that will take you around in 2 different times of the day, very interesting!
Enjoyable visited to Gyeongbokgung Palace, one of famous tourist spot to go if you are planning to going to Seoul.

Nice Heritage Site. The Changing of the Guard Ceremony is worth a trip. Watching the young Koreans in their traditional clothing (they can enter for free if they are dressed traditionally) was interesting.
This palace reminded me of The Moon Embraces The Sun! The water is so calm that the reflection of the palace looks stunning in the water! I like that the back gate is accessible to the Blue House.

Very easy to find from several metro stations, and at only £/$ a ticket it's incredible value for money.  You can also get a small guide book for pennies which is a good help as you walk around.  Can easily spend a few hours there or blast around in an hour without stopping in the museums (Palace museum being the more interesting and informative).  Only real criticism (and not the Koreans fault really) but as it was torn down by the Japanese during the occupation, it's only been recently restored (started in 2001) and so there's a lot of concrete in places where there would not have been hundreds of years ago.  However, despite this, beautiful gardens and a worthwhile way to spend a morning/afternoon!
This is a huge palace, and worth a visit. But it is very popular by many tourists, so be prepared for a crowd.
is is excellent that middle in a modern city, suddenly you reach a part of tradition in best condition . when ever you have a travel to Seoul, donot miss this place

I'm not a big palace visitor, I need to be dragged along most of the time, but Gyeongbokgung is really worth a visit, and if it's just to take a stroll in its vast gardens at the back. Many people take the free tour, we opted to just read what was in the brochure and on the signs. A lot of Koreans visit this site dressed in costumes of the era, which makes it a really more authentic and colorful experience.  Worth taking a morning or afternoon of your time in Seoul to explore.
Beautiful palace, a must-see in Seoul! You can rent a traditional hanbok near the entrance, which many tourists do to take pictures.
The palace is a very well organized and it is close to the museum. We can visit the real Korean's traditional performance there.

I visited four palaces in Seoul and this was the best one to visit. It was the largest one and our guide was friendly and very good in explaining things. The great thing about the palaces in Seoul is that they have tours in Korean, Mandarin, English and Japanese. If you go early, you can watch the changing of the guard ceremony and even take pictures with them. In addition to the palace, the National Palace Museum of Korea and the National Folk Museum of Korea are conveniently close and free (you can't beat that!). Even the Blue House where the President of South Korea lives is within walking distance but I didn't go there. The Gyeongbokgung subway station is by the palace but it's also within walking distance from Anguk and Gwanghwamun Stations.
It's big so be ready to walk. You can tell the palace was renovated...probably due to the war. But still very beautiful and serene. It's a MUST SEE if you're in Seoul!
My family and I highly enjoyed this palace. My 9 year old son thought it was very fun and educational, and we all enjoyed the attached museum. It had beautiful grounds and we learned a lot!

You could spend all day here but we took about 2hrs to scroll through. We took lots of pics and listened in to a couple tours but we didn't take one. It cost less than $3 to enter per adult. Not good for a rainy day as everything is outside but you can see inside through windows and doors.

had a wonderful 4-5 hours here and joined the free English Speaking Guided Tour. Our guide was great, good clear diction, a sense of humour and history information which was important. Tour can be booked inside Main Wall and is free for Seniors

ive been a fan of korean drama but seeing the palaces brings happiness to me. though not a magnificent as i previously pictured in my brain but it is so spacious. the pavilions were intricately designed. how i wish i lived in those kind of era. Nice seeing tourists wearing national costumes and have their photos taken

I visited this place on May at 1PM and it was very hot outside. You can take picture with the palace guard but please be careful not to disturb or touch him or they could be mad. This palace consists of many buildings inside. Make sure your feet are ok and your stomach is full before coming here bacuse this palace is soo biiigg. I got very tired eventhough i were not explore all of the buildings inside.

A little disappointing as we expected majestic architecture and beautiful gardens since it was the touted as the most beautiful of all the 5 palaces. We gave the other palaces a miss because of this reason. It took us less than an hour to view the grounds that were opened to public. The guards at the front entrance were however very obliging so we have some good memorable shots.
As seen in the korean movies: nice place to visit, to see korean culture and tradition. A lot of korean pines around.
You can't go to Seoul without taking in the historic atmosphere with relaxed strolls around Seoul's Palaces!
Wonderful day not a fan of guided tours but this is a place that needs to be explained a must see 'Holiday Tours and Travel Korea' run an excellent tour and thanks to David for his guidance
Come see the guard change, stay to walk around the palace. We had a hard time finding a tour but it was good for a quick (< 1 hour) visit.

I had just a couple of hours at the end of a business trip and ended up here by serendipity. For a mere $1 above the price of the $3 basic entry to Changdeokgung Palace, it combined a lovely walk in the park, the historically interesting palace and the beautiful wildflower garden. I did not have time to explore the palace closely or to even enter the Great Greenhouse so I hope I get a chance to go back.

An interesting recreation of the palace. It would have been better if more of the original structure still existed. As it stands, it is still a decent place to visit. You can sometimes see traditional costumes and ceremonies.
Not much to say since we didnt go into the Details. Nice place to take some photos. Everything was clean and the place itself was worth seing.
get there early. Seniors are free! lovely grounds and palaces are beautiful. MUst see the colorful changing of guards. YOu are allowed to take pics with the guards at the front gate .

Interesting attraction, with a lots of locals visiting the place, wearing the traditional clothings. The place was huge and need to walk quite abit. Beautiful place to take photos with the flowers in the background.

The palaces, quarters, ponds and gardens are beautiful. And it's interesting to learn the parallel historical timelines. While the Renaissance started in Florence, Italy in 1350, Gyeongbokgung Palace was built in 1395 during the Joseon Dynasty.

Beautiful site and visit! We took the english tour. We loved our visit. Take all the time necessary to do a complete visit of the site and the gardens and as well make sure not to miss the changing of the guard show. We took such beautiful pictures and made memories we will forever cherish. A must see during your visit to Seoul!
We liked it quite much. Beautiful place, worth the visit. It closes at 5pm we were there at 4pm, still enough time to wander around :)

We stumbled upon the palace while wandering around Seoul. It was a great experience, we got to see a traditional Korean performance and wander around the grounds. We saw a lot of museum static displays and a ton of art.

Just check the time of free guided tours and guard changing ceremonies before you reach the palace. With the guided tour it was quite lovely. View is nice, the palaces are similar to Chinese architecture but a bit different as they are based on Confucius' teachings.

I highly recommend a visit in this palace and join the tour with your language.  Our tour guide was truly wonderful because she was able to explain to us well about the history of every corners of the palace, her sense of humor was a bonus because we never had a boring moment especially talking about history.  A fantastic experience with the tour.
Nice palace to walk around on a sunny day. Just by the blue house. Take your time and just wander and then check out the neighborhoods nearby for cool trinkets
We were fortunate to arrive just before the changing of the guard so there were no crowds. It was avery colourful event and fun to watch as it was also fairly short.

visited this palace during our recent trip to seoul. we watched the change of guards ceremony which is scheduled on every hour. after which, we had fun wearing the general / commander / guards costumes for photo taking etc - this is FOC. all these activities are at the outer court only. if you want to visit the inner court, you need to pay the entrance fees.
Truly a wonderful place, it was a step back in Korea's past but I would advise you to visit early as you will encounter thousands of local school trips.
Palace is really well maintained... had a nice lovely walk through the palace. Caught the guard exchange ceremony which should not be missed.
We. I sited the palace in Dec 2015 and again in June 2016. Our June trip was with an English speaking tour guide which made a huge impact on our enjoyment of the tour.
Enjoyed watching the historical changing of the guard and the fastidious work that has gone into developing the Palace.
The Koreans have worked hard to rebuild this culturally significant complex of buildings after the destruction of the 20th Century. Its a kind of forbidden city on a smaller scale.
The free show showcasing the ancient guard changing ceremony is worth visiting. It is near the Metro station, we strolled by another 150m near this palace for the Gingsen Chicken Rice.

Don't know if they are always there, or if it was a special occasion, but the palace grounds were crawling with locals dressed in traditional Korean attire. It made visiting each house on the grounds more authentic. The grounds are massive, so give yourself a few hours, and there is a political museum on site that we barely peaked at since we arrived to close to closing time. Take your camera!

Once a complex of 500 buildings destroyed by the Japanese, and though not as large as the Forbidden City in Beijing, Gyeongbokgung reconstructed still manages to awe visitors. It is full of Koreans and tourists in traditional Korean Hanbok dress (free entry!).  Be sure to come for the Changing of the Guard ceremony at 1000 hrs and 1400 hrs because even the guards are in ancient costume. There are other ceremonial performances, the times of which can be found at the Visit Korea website.  There are free tours in different languages, and two museums attached to the palace complex. We went for a tour in English (only 3 a day) and it was most informative and helpful. Our guide explained the underfloor heating, the tiered Queen's garden and showed us where Japanese assassins murdered Empress Myeongseong in 1895 and burned her body. I was quite shocked to learn of this barbaric act. But that's the thing about this palace - it immerses you in Korean history.  Write in for permission in advance if you want to visit the banquet pavillion, which is otherwise closed to visitors.

Start off your trip in Seoul with a visit to this palace. While it was summer for locals, weather was still pretty good for us. Reco to rent Hanboks (traditional Korean wear) so that you'll have free entrance to this place.

We could have spent a lot more time here, especially with the Folk Museum attached. The weather for us during our visit was very hot, so we looked around and took pictures and appreciated the beautiful buildings.
Visiting the palace as part of an organised tour and quite enjoyed it. To fully take in the place suggest 2-4 hours.
Very accessible and near a city station, The palace is a great place to immerse yourself in Korean culture and architecture. :)

One of the few major monuments open on a Monday, which coincided with my first day in town. It is a relatively large site, with extensive gardens as you move through. Exit on the north end to catch great views of the presidential complex and you can soak in the government district on your walk back to the metro.

I took a subway to this palace and the train system in Seoul is very convenient as the instruction and announcement is in English, Mandarin and Korean. Even the ticket vending machine is on 3 languages so it's pretty easy to get around and you won't get lost. Ok I really enjoyed the beautiful scenery at Gyeongbakgung but it was freezing cold in Dec. There are English and Mandarin guided tour around the palace at certain time. It's pretty interesting to learn about the culture and some ancient beliefs. For people who can't tolerate with extremely cold weather, I would advise you not to visit the palace during winter. Strong wind and the cold could dampen your spirit to walk and explore further 😉

Before we went to the palace, we found out that if you wear the traditional costumes you will be able to enter for free so we rented our Hanbok from a nearby shop. The rental fee was about 30,000 won and we can return to them by 5pm. What a fun experience wearing Hanbok and walking around the palace and taking photographs. The palace was a really beautiful place and I am sure it will be better if you follow the guided tour. It is quite a big place and can get quite crowded from early morning to afternoon so be sure to go eariler and please put on sunblock and bring your umbrella along, most part of the pathway are not sheltered. Keep in mind that there is only 1 cafe inside the palace so you may want to bring some food and drinks along while walking around.

The buildings are nicely maintained. The place is spacious with trees around. A lot of chairs for people to take a rest when visiting. Yet the side gate bear Gyeongbokgung Station does not allow exit so we have to walk back all the way the the front gate to get to that area, which is a bit inconvenient.
Large Temple set in the center of Seoul, small fee to enter, is somewhat accessible for people with physical disabilities
Beautiful, historic palace and grounds in the middle of the city. I was surprised at just how big the property is. Plan on spending at least a few hours
Nice Walk, and photogenic! Be sure you go with a guide, so you will receive very important information.

The visit at night is very different from day time. There's no guided tour and no guards-changing ceremony at night but it gives you a feeling of tranquility. Besides some buildings being lit, there was also a play with various lighting effects and musicians playing live music. We spent nearly 2 hours there.  The place opens at night on dates 29/4-1/6, 16/7-19/8, 24/9-28/10 and between 7 and 10pm.  The 3,000 won entrance fee would be waived if you go in traditional Korean clothes.  We loved the locker facility provided. We left our bags in the lockers available on the left hand side right after passing the admission gate and traveled the palace light. The 100 won coin deposited would be returned to you when you open the locker.
We loved this place, it's amazing! Tips: Go to this in morning, could have many beautiful pictures. There are many people wearing hanbook, you can take many shoot with them.
Very interesting and beautiful palace. Near the "Blue House"--residence of the current president. English tours are available.
Very very very good. I like the historical castle. It's very huge. If you're lucky you can catch some wonderful and remarkable festivals.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is one place you have to visit when holidaying in Seoul. It is wonderful to see a historic place in the middle of the city. Getting there is easy too. We took the train there on our own and the palace is within a minute's walk.  You can catch the change of guards ceremony at a few timings during the day and you can dress up in beautiful traditional Korean costumes to take nice photo shots too. There are guided tours available at certain timings and I recommend you follow the tour if you want to learn and understand more about the place. As I walked and explored the palace on my own, I missed out alot of stories behind the many halls in the palace.
The Gyeongbokgung Palace is conveniently located in central Seoul - just down the main road from City Hall. Its a beautiful palace and worth visiting!

Make sure you wear comfortable shoes when you will visit this palace. Its really wide spread and you will need to walk quiet a bit to see everything. Please keep at least a few hours in hand to see everything. There are a few guided tours available that you tickets for.

Great place to visit when in Seoul. Hard to think that this can be found in the city with sky scrappers on one side and and mountains in the back ground on the other side. Not very big and can probably only want to spend an hour there but definitely worth a visit.
I enjoy visiting the palaces. I was fortunate enough to visit on Memorial day and had the opportunity to see a lot of young coup les in traditional dress.

Huge palace lots of crowds and girls in national dress all having their photos taken little information provided but some hints of history in the queens death at the hands of the japanese. Many of the bildings the same but the large hall and thrown immpressive.
Magnificent place, lots of history in this place. Recommend to get the free guide to walk around. Having the understanding will make the trip more meaningful
Recommend going for changing of the guard and then doing a guided tour. The grounds are really big so allow a couple of hours and bring a lot of water.
just skip it if u are not into palace. it required entrance fee but you can easily sneak in during peak hours. for me just taking a photo at the entrance of the palace is more than enough of my time.

Well maintained building. Entry ticket is 3000Won per person. During certain hours, you can see the changing guard ceremony. Can reach here by subway using the Gyeongbukgung station which will bring you out near the National Palace Musuem.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is huge historical beauty. Nice place to go around for pics. U can time urself for free guide available in English as well. Even without Guide its worth a tour. Give min 2 to 2 1/2 hr for complete tour of palace. Its in heart of city and easily accessd by subway.
Very interesting palace dating from 1392. Beautiful buildings and very well maintained. We had a free guide.
Huge place to visit. Allow for at least 1.5 hours to go through the whole place. the library was a nice place to stop for a cup of tea as well.

Being a Palace it shows the grandness of the royalty of the past with the touch of frugality. The structure has signs of Chinese architectural influence. From Gyeongbokgung Palace, you are a short walk to Insa-dong.where you can experience artique art, book stores and craft shops.

A stop at the palace is well worth the cost of admission, as is the audio guide. Budget about one to 1.5 hours here, and enjoy wandering through.  There are not many shaded areas, so if you come during the hot months, plan your stop for the morning or for the last entries of the day, otherwise it can be tiring.
Great tour that you can do on your own or with a guide. You can easily spend a half day just touring the grounds. Be sure to visit the guest room in the Blue House. Very good history lesson.
Well-maintained palace where the highlight for us was the 10am changing of the guard which our kids were enthralled with.

Visiting the palace is a great way of partly knowing the history of Korean dynasties. It is easily accessible and few minutes walk from the train station. I took advantage of the free tour guide services being offered by students. Their desk can be found just before you get out of the train station.

The place can be extremely crowded during weekends where you have to squeeze to get around. Outside of the main palace it is still pretty quiet where you can sit and truly enjoy the beauty of the palace.  If you want to understand the palace, a tour is a must as there arent many informations shown in the booklets.
If you are someone who loves history, this place is worth visiting. Otherwise, going there is also worth the trip if you are looking for places to take pictures with buildings on the yesteryears.
Gyeongbokgung Palace is good for those who are interested in the history.Those going to this place must visit Insadong market (very near,just outside the palace) , known as "Art Street" of Seoul.

The palace was interesting to walk around and take in, and gave a good amount of information about the lives of the past royal family, even without the free guided tour. Easy enough to spend at least a couple of hours here as the grounds are huge and the various buildings spread out. The highlight for me was one of the pavilions in the centre of a moat which was incredibly picturesque and peaceful, against the backdrop of mountains. The only problem was it was very very busy, but likely due to it being a great value, essential attraction for visitors o Seoul.
A very good place to spend a weekend morning, looking the beautiful palaces and gardens, with good oportunities to take a lot of beautiful shots..

We went twice. It was too hot in the day. But in the evening it was beautiful. Even more so due to the large number of people wearing traditional clothes. A limited number of evening tickets are made available for foreigners each day and only become available at 7:00 in the evening, so head there at 7:00 and grab some evening tickets! We were lucky enough to go on a Saturday and a great show was on from 8:00. This was my favourite event in Seoul. It is also definitely worth catching the changing of the guard ceremony. Watch from inside the main gate.
Just a beautiful palace where you can sit down and appreciate the history and architecture at the same time. Definitely worth a visit!

Spent hours here with my mother and grandmother.  There are many different types of traditional Korean palaces you can visit along with a museum that houses old Korean artifacts.  Take your time her and go at your own pace. That's the beauty of this site.  Don't forget to visit the section on the east that have models of an old school Korean village.  Admission was free when I went but I think there is a fee normally.

been here for 2nd time and still impressed with the size of the place and its historical stories. Found out more history from local guide and every little detail in these buildings holds a lot of interesting meaning. Would suggest to get local guide to bring you around in private tour to understand and explore more about Korean culture and historical infos.
Anyone who is interested in the countries history must visit this place and escape from the noise streets of the city

This palace was interesting not only for it's historical value but because it was also in the middle of the city. You could literally take a picture of the palace with Seoul's myriad skyscrapers as a backdrop. Reminded us of some of the palaces in China.
it was very nice to see gyeongbokgung ceremonial on that autumn, they have a beautiful view and huge building
ensuring the traditional palace is maintained is good that too in the middle of the city. At one end you see the palace and the opposite side you see all the modern sky scrapers. good visit

You can spend 2-3 hours here pretty easily. Take a leisurely stroll, and check out all the buildings within the palace ground. You can also get access to the National Folk Museum as well from here with the same ticket.
the place is too big to walk around.. lots of big and small palace plus ancient stuff.. the palaces were amazing! ancient korea!
This palace has been completely restored to its original, even though it has been destructed twice in the Japanese attacks on Seoul. It is of great beauty and should not be missed!

Easily one of the prettiest sights of Seoul with the mountains as the backdrop. On a Saturday evening I saw many Hanbok wearing local girls which gave traditional feel. The palace reminds me of the forbidden palace in Beijing. With large and nested courtyards. There is an entrance fee to this place and the ticket counter closes at 5 PM. Easy to get to on the metro. There are many nice places to visit after a tour around the palace.

It was a hot sunny day n there was a guard changing shift ceremony when we arrived at the Palace's main gate (b4 entrance). Some tourists made the effort to rent hanbok n wearing it to the palace to have photos, which was really nice. There is a Pavillion on the waters which tourists can reserve 1 day in advance (pic attached) to get access to go in n have photos. There r certain guided slots which r in different languages acc to the ticket counters.

A grand and big palace. Lots of walking but worth it. Don't miss the changing guard ceremony and check their new schedules before visiting. Now, they only have two shows at 10:00 and 12:00. They have a big show running when we visited there. Because it was their Golden week in the first week of May, free entrance for all visitors to all palaces on that weekend. Also, if anyone wearing their traditional Korean clothes, free entrance are granted. After visiting the palace, you can take this opportunity and enjoy their famous Ginseng chicken soup. That most famous restaurant is 10 minutes away from the palace, but don't go there during lunch hour, you will find at least 200 people waiting before you. We wait until 3pm, no waiting is required.

one of the palace in Seoul, we purchase royal palace ticket which we can use it for different palace, however the palace was really crowded, and little bit dusty, u can find museum at the back of the palace, well we did not stay long....
Visiting this primary palace when visiting Seoul is a must. Take the guided tour given at 11:00, 1:30 & 3:00 to get the most of your visit.

It is a beautiful palace and nice to go for a walk. However, in terms of architecture and beauty, there are other places in the same region that may be more beautiful. It was nice to see guard changing ceremony in the front of the building.

It is a worth place for the price.  We got the 10000 won tickets to visit the 4 palace and the garden. This palace was the only one with free show. There's 3 kind of so you should check the time.  For us it was at 13h to 13h30.
This historical Palace is worth the trip. It's so huge and splendid. It's a must to visit the palace when going to Korea.

Historical place and it is spectacular. Free tour guide provided and there is performance in the middle of palace. The palace is connected to the front area of Cheong Wa Dae. Love the view so much. There is a museum with the coffee counter, you may get a rest here with free wifi. It is worth to spend 2-3 hours here and then go to eat ginseng chicken soup after this.

This palace is so large that you feel like you will never be able to see it all. The buildings are beautiful and very well maintained. It is amazing how extensive the complex is and the different buildings you see throughout the grounds. We highly recommend visiting this palace if you are coming to Seoul.
The Korean palaces are really really simple and peaceful. Beautiful gardens and halls, but nothing too ornate. Should visit at least one of the palaces if you are in Seoul

It was fantastic to visit this palace. It is made out of wood mostly and amazing how it is not damaged after 100s of years. We did not go inside the main part which needs ticket but we're able to see a lot in free ticket zone.

Nice place to visit in Seoul. for people from Europe this is a relatively young historical place, but for US and other citizens - it is old enough to be amazing. in very good condition, full of young people, nice and calm place in the middle of a 10 million-citizens town. great architecture
It was pretty much a muchnes although changing of the guard really good. Inside was sparse and for me just ok. The museum however far more interesting as it depicted life to the present
Since traveled a lot in Asia i wasnt blown off my feet. but it is a nice place to visit. spend there 2 hours MAX
A most interesting location. I was impressed with Korea's maintaining their history, yet at the same time, staying up to date in their new architecture. Place it on top of your places to visit.
This palace is massive. We were lucky enough to be here on a day that featured a Korean song and dance group. It felt as though we went back 200 years.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is an interesting place to visit especially if you are interested in Korean history and the way of life of royalty during that era. I cannot say that I could identify with much of what I saw as it was not an area of the world that I know very much about and so did not appreciate a lot of what I was seeing and was being told about.

Visit this place if you've been to Changdeokgung Palace and only if you've no other place to visit.  Changdeokgung is far more beautiful of a palace than Gyeongbokgung. However, Gyeongbokgung has it's charmed as well. Visit during children day and you'll get free entrance for a day
Marvelous palace in the heart of Seoul.The changing of the guard ceremony is interesting and it was lovely to see young people in their traditional dress.

This is a must visit while you're in Seoul. I would say this is one of the major highlights when visiting. You have to pay a small entrance fee of 2,000-3,000 won (roughly about 2-3 dollars US) and once you get in, you are free to roam around. Theres actually a lot of areas to explore in the Palace. Gardens, pond, areas of hanoks and temples.  It can get pretty busy and might be difficult to take pictures, so I recommend going early morning. You can also wear hanboks and walk around the Palace as well. Theres also an art gallery close by (outside the palace gates) with lots of traditional Korean restaurants, cafes, shops, etc.

Its huge!!!!! i needed more tan 3 hours to do the Speedy gonzalez style tour, (walk fast, few pictures and keep going), dont miss it, just try to go early morning and weekends to avoid large groups and school trips groups

Interesting enough to spend time to visit. My sister & I rent Hanbok for 4 hours (cost less than 15,000 won/person) and had free entrance tickets. Changing the guard parade is really interesting. I considered we were lucky to see the march!

Having a day tour around Seoul, this palace is the first and maybe the most important place to visit. A big complex of palace that reminds me of Forbidden City in Beijing, not only show the richness and uniqueness of Korean architecture and history in the past but also offered the visitors with some attractions from Korean kingdom (which unfortunately I did not have enough time to enjoy).
A great day to spend the day. The museum is worth visiting and the have free performance to enjoy and the comfort of A/C. Stroll around the grounds and enjoy!

We had an opportunity to watch the ceremony before leaving. The place is quite big and we only stayed for only a few minutes since it was winter and we went there on our last day. But it is definitely a place to visit when going to South Korea.

This place is very nice. The palace is very spacious. You can imagine walking along the path where kings and queens have and marvelling at the gardens and scenery.  When you have bought your ticket for the palace you can go to the National Folk Museum for free when you show your ticket on the same day.

A good place to visit to learn about the history of Korea. There's a guard changing at 1pm and u can take photos with the guards. There is also a museum nearby to understand more about korea's history

This largest palace in Seoul (or Korea?) is conserved extremely well, though the narrative signs can be a bit more lively and in-depth. I visited on a Saturday morning and the place saw huge crowds - tourists, kid groups and girls wearing Hanbok!
Nice walk, plenty of photo ops. Servant quarters are cool. A lot of people come dressed in costume. Only 3,000 W.

Like all the other palaces i have visited during this travel , you can feel the history of this nice country the architecture is splendid . Don"t forget to borrow the local national dress from the reception and walk around wearing it , you will feel like you are one of the soldiers or guard of the palace . All facilities are also in , like coffee shops , toilets , museum ... . it is really a nice place to visit in Seoul .

Beautiful Palace architecture but then stripped of all its goods and wealth,.. feel bad about colonial rule which korea also suffered.. and the damage that Japan did to the history of this clean, strong economy ....  This country needs to get back its history by collecting all its artifacts from various collectors and restore its history ... because with out ones heritage one cant build his future...  Well kept and simple... building ... well feel it less only because I am comparing it with the Palaces of India...but its different here....

Located in the northern part of Seoul city, this palace has many beautiful buildings and nicely landscape garden. Ideal place to make many photos. If you are visiting Seoul, It's better to combine the visit to Palace with other tourists attractions in the area like Folks museum, Samchongdong, Insadong, Jogysa temple etc.

You can only admire everything from the outside. Buildings and surrounding areas are perfectly maintained. Even if you are on a tight budget and /or a tight schedule you should take an extra ticket to visit the gardens. Try to visit this place early morning when there are not too many students about. They sometimes make such a racket that it's impossible to understand the guide. It happened to me this time whilst on an afternoon tour . When you are at the palace, don't miss the next famous landmark worth a visit : the old traditional Hankok Village which starts a couple of streets from it. I highly recommend Changdeokgung Palace. If you can visit only one palace, visit this one .. with a guide. Some guided tours are free. Enjoy!

Its a historic walk in to the ancient and rich history and heritage of Korea. One can't help but marvel at the architectural genus of this palace and respect the cultural heritage of this great country.

Timing our visit to the Royal Palace with their free English guided tour made this very enjoyable. If you want to do it on your own, bear in mind it's huge with very little English explaination. Wear good walking shoes and bring lots of water.
Another one of those spots on the Soeul "must see" list. Worth the entrance fee, lots to see inside.

Take the free English guide at 13:00 and don't miss the guard change ceremony. Also visit National Folk Museum. Amazing place to relax and drink your sweet potato latte or green tea latte both are amazing.

The place to visit in soeul. Where you can see how the olden age tradition of the soldiers how they communicate and changing the shifts. The music and slogans was impressive. The big drum was highlight.  The ticket price to get in to the palace is 3₩. Its in the middle of the city. The scenic from the palace is astonishing. The must visit place and know about the kirean traditions.

If it is your first visit to Seoul, make sure to visit Gyeongbokgung. Just this will do, no need to visit others. Ticket price reasonably at krw3,000 per adult, if you wear hanbok, it will be free entry. If time allows, join one of the free tour guided by English, Mandarin or Japanese speaking Korean lady, they provide good insights and some history for your easy understanding. Thereafter, you can explore more on your own. Do note that the palace closed on every Tuesday.
We did this free transit tour by the city of Seoul and while the place itself is amazing, there is nothing much to see especially if you have no background on korean history like i did.
The palace is very beautiful but you must wear rubber shoes since the palace is very big. There are lot of photo ops in Gyeongbokgung Palace.

Went on winter time . On a clear blue day. The palace is really beautiful . Walked all the way in to the quiet lake - the scenery is good. enjoy the quiet grounds, far from the grp tour. lots of small palaces / "departments" within the palace ground . Visit the National Folk / palace museum at the same time if you got time . opp the palace (back gate) is the president blue house.

Studied this during architectural history class so it's fun to walk around. I arrived around 3:30 and was just about to catch "changing guards". There are local students who would like some "language exchange" experience that would give free tours. I was told by the local that if you want to, you can get to try on the traditional korean costume for free in the information center. I didn't have to time to do so, but you could go and see if you are interested. There are quite some girls wearing and walking around and a few guys too.

The main reason I wanted to visit this palace is because they filmed Rooftop Prince and other periodic Korean dramas here. This place is beautiful. The architectures are amazing and the beans to hold the roof have very intricate drawings on them. Some of the doors were locked but I was still happy to visit this place. Kings and queens walked the paths I walked. History and laws were created and made here. Its amazing to see that, most part of the walkways around the palace were just dirt. Amazed me that the kings and queens were frugal. Paintworks were beautifully preserved and same goes to the building. Love the scenery because since its spring, the palace flowers blooms and highlighted the beauty of the place even more. If you have a toddler, be sure to wear walking shoes because you will mostly be walking on dirt, just like the royalty who used to lived there. Beautiful...
Visited this palace as part of a tour. It was also a school holiday so there were so many children and teenagers there. It was very beautiful but I wish we had more time there.

Been here 3 times - 8 years ago first time. Awesome place. However, I have taken the English tour and found it great. Not so this time. The palace grounds were extremely crowded. There were so many people on the tour that many times you could not hear the guide or she started talking before everyone could actually get to her location.So many people that it was hard to look inside some of the structures. There were huge tour bus parked outside the palace - so hundreds of people are swarming in at once. I was told by a local that evening when I remarked on the difference experience I had that there is a big uptick in Chinese tourists and these tour buses are everywhere. So just note that the English tour may not be that great. But the tour is free with palace admission so just try to stick close to the guide and return to explore the buildings when the tour is done. The place is amazing and worth it.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is the palace all first time visitors should see. Plan to spend some time there, a visit to the National Palace Museum which is on site is very interesting and can take up a good part of your time. Keep track of your time as you would want to see the changing of the guards ceremony.

When we visited we saw the change of the guard at the main gates. I'm not sure how frequently this occurs but it's worth checking out to see if you cancoincide your visit. The uniforms of the guards are colourful and flamboyant and you can take photos with them much the same way as you can with the guards in London. There was also a lot of young Koreans visiting in traditional dress when we were there. The grounds, lake and palace are nice - you need to set aside a couple of hours

We spent about three hours at this lovely palace, which we thought was the nicest in Seoul. It was very good value to get in, and guided tours in English were included in the price. The gardens were beautiful and the old traditional buildings full of character. We loved the way a lot of Koreans dress up in national costumes to visit the palaces, adding to the atmosphere. We got some lovely photos while here and thoroughly enjoyed our visit.

Have been to Gyeongbokgung Palace 4 times. It is an interesting place that you are allowed to explore without a tour guide. There are many buildings on the large grounds that you can walk into and take pictures. Most of the signs are in Korean as well as English. At certain times there are performances done by Koreans in costumes that date back to when the Palace was occupied. It is very interesting!

A stunning reconstructed palace in the heart of Seol. ₩3000 to get in and a further ₩3000 for an audio guide and definitely worth it.  Not a whole lot of information to read so I recommend the audio guide.  Take some time to sit and take it all in and then hit up the nearby shopping district afterwards.

Just go there to relealise this. I had been here more than once. Roam around or just sit. The serene environment and the peace and tranquility will embrace you. If you like History, you will enjoy the years this palace has stood by. If you dont, you will enjoy the Nature here that will help you to be with yourself.

Our first tourist site visit on the trip. It is right at the station that bears the same name. Best exit to use is #5 and then you are right there. We were able to see the changing of the guard. The palace was built in 1394. It is from the Joseon Dynasty. Good for wandering and taking pictures.

Enjoyable tour of the palace given, free of charge, by students of the local language college wanting to improve their English. If asked do say yes to this service. It really is free and you'll get much more out of your visit. Lovely kids.
Great place to go for a little cultural and historical experience. Some of the locals came dressed in the traditional hanbok cloting.

This was my third visit and I love it everytime. If it is warm and humid then prepare to sweat as you will be walking a lot.  If you plan it right you can also get in for free as we did this time (by chance), but the downside is having far bigger crowds than usual.  Make sure you also see the Blue House which is at the back if the park.  The palace is beautiful, very traditional korean. The ponds and park also make this a great outing. For a better experience try to come during the change of guards or other special events to be fully immersed in korean traditions.  If you are in Seoul and you only have time for one palace then this is the best!
Awesome palace...just like in the kdramas I've watched. Great sight and for picture taking as well. A myst see change if royal guards.

I happened in Seoul a bit out of accident, but have loved this city. It's important to mix a bit of culture into a trip and the central location of this palace did make it an easy visit. Admission is also quite cheap. The guards dress very vibrantly and ate stationed on the front gate. Have your picture with them, just no touching. Time spent here is dependant on the individual, I grew restless after a few similar looking buildings and some nice gardens and completely missed that there was even a gift shop, the place is quite vast so if you want to see every nook and cranny than budget a couple of hours. Also be prepared for the school tours and a fair number of people.
its a big palace, you can imagine how to lived that dynasty, how they communicate without gadget cause this palace is very big and quite far from other place to the other

The place is very big and beautiful. Take the map on the information centre and walk around. I haven't got a guidedd tour but it was ok as I had my Lonely Planet guide in hands. Go there with sun otherwise it might be a bit boring.

A short review for a huge place! I cannot imagine how amazing it would have been when it was built. As this is a replica, there is a little let down. Still beautiful grounds & buildings from the 1800's

I read a few strongly negative reviews, so that sort of inspired me to write a less nasty one - for balance... I do not know if I was just lucky, and went there at the right time of the right day, but there was virtually NOBODY else around, outside of my immediate party. Of course, that could possibly have had something to do with the company that I was in, as my friends' father was a high ranking Korean military hero? He was sort of leading us around this venue, and I suppose that may have been the reason why nobody else was around at that time, but I think it was a neat place, and I'm glad I got the chance to see it. It was a splendid photo-op, to mark of my checklist.

Beautifully restored after a tumultuous history that left large parts destroyed, the palace is a monument to the resilience of Koreans and the importance of their history. More understated and elegant than the Forbidden City, the palace can be enjoyed as a stroll in an hour or as a full half days' exploration activity. For future visitors: there is not much shade (particularly in the central parade ground area where the changing of the guard may be viewed) and it can be very hot in the summer months.

The most impressive and very large palace in Seoul that you have to visit if you have a day time. For me it was the first stop. At the end of the visit I enjoyed the changing of the guard ceremony. Must go!

Cant help but give this one top marks. It was nice and peaceful in the palace grounds which was great away from the hustle and bustle of the city. But we really lucked out...to celebrate the 94th anniversary of childrens day entrance was free so seeing as we didnt even have to pay i cant not give it top marks.
It's definitely a must see when you're in Seoul. The entrance ticket is cheap and its more cheaper when you get the combo tickets for the 4 Palace.

It was crowded with both local and tourists when we visited. It was difficult to see all the sites in the rain as it was muddy between sites. Nevertheless, it was grand. It was however not my favourite. I prefer to walk around the secret garden at Changdeokgung.

The first day we went there was not actually a good experience because we were not aware that the palace was close on Tuesdays. It was disappointing but they let us visit the Palace Museum instead. The next day my sister and I still went positively hoping we could get in. And finally we did and for free! I was about to pay at the ticket booth when the lady told us that they were holding their National Culture Day and that admission was for free. Visiting Gyeongbukgung was on top of my list even before we arrived in Seoul. It was spring so the air was cool, cooler than the day before and we were glad about it. We took hundreds of pictures from the gates to the pots and stairs of the temple. It was like remembering all the Korean dramas I had watched before. But what I had realized was, I was setting foot on the same ground where kings and queens of Joseon walked and stood. It was a very happy experience!

Totally unintentionally we came to Seoul during the lantern festival. As a result we received full entry and were also offered an English tour by a group of school children (as part of a club activity). We took them up on their offer and were extremely glad we did. They took us around the palace, explaining to us a great deal about its history and cultural significance.  The palace itself is very similar to many others and is still being reconstructed back to its former glory. However, the reconstruction is very realistic and it is possible to still gain a feel for its original significance. The gardens at the back allow strolls into the quieter regions of the palace providing a welcome break from the inevitable crowds.

Visiting the Palace is definitely a step back in time but the destruction wrought on it by Japanese forces at the time meant that little of the original structure remains. Still, the restoration work is excellent and walking the vast grounds is one of the most pleasant things to do in Seoul. Admission is about $3.00 however I strongly recommend you hire the audio guide for an additional $3.00. If you see Koreans wearing traditional dress walking around the Palace, many do so because they get free entry. I did note that there is good wheelchair access throughout the site but be prepared for a bumpy ride across the central courtyard.

great palace which has been rebuilt for may times. When I was there no so crowded so I was able to explore more, took some nice spot pictures. Affordable entrance fee with lot thing that can we expect

Loved this palace. It is right smack in the middle of seoul, so it is very charming to see a traditional palace, surrounded by the modern technologies of high rise buildings and cars. If you are visiting, don't forget to stop by tosokchon which serves the best samgyetang. Go inbetween lunch and dinner times or you'll be in for a long wait.

Visited Gyeongbokgung Palace during winter, summer and spring. Different season different feel. Entrance is free if you're using hanbok. Every side of the palace is worth for a memorable picture. Good for a romantic walk among couple, an educational trip for families and great for group of friends to enjoy pictorial scenery. Dont forget to watch guard changing ceremony. A unique event.

Had wonderful time there, the place is very well-maintained. It is quite big so I recommend to reserve at least 2 hours to enjoy all the little bits there. I also really liked almost one hour traditional music show there, no idea whether it is part of their normal schedule
