Make sure you go on a tour. There are free tours, you just need to register online. I was on a tour with 3 other girls. Having a tour guide gives you a lot of information about their history. Its not boring nor purely political. They gave us insight on how the royalty lived, even their personal lives, and some tragedies that happened in that palace. It was interesting. Long walk, but the place is really amazing.

I have visited this palace before. I did not realize the ground was so huge until I had to enter via the National Folk Museum entrance. I was wearing hanbok and I got in for free. This palace is on the must-see list of all tours. It can get crowded especially shortly before and after the changing of the guards. Come early to avoid bus loads of tourists.

The palace is simply mesmerizing. Whenever you step in, you'll automatically grab your camera to capture the beauty.  Tip: 1) be there on 10 am to watch the guardian-changing ceremony. 2) take a photo with hanbok-wearing local. 3) don't waste too much time here, there are other palaces around.
One of the Main Korean Palaces that must be visited during your stay in Seoul. There is a free English Tour guide and you should catch the changing or guards ceremony.
I recommend to visit this place which is very interesting for you to discover South Korean history. Enjoy it.
Very beautiful exterior and the areas are big too... we had a guide so he explained a lot on the history and which houses belongs to who... you start with the palace and ends with the museum
Attractive palace with enormous well kept grounds. Particularly impressive is the Temple of Fragence. Changing of the Guard ceremony is, to western eyes, unusual

This is a must see if you are in Seoul. The building is not accessible to the public on most days and is used for official functions. It is a beautiful example of traditional Korean architecture and stunningly beautiful. I was very impressed.

Visited the palace as part of the free Incheon transit tour. The place was huge and offers a glimpse on Korea's past.  spent around an hour here, would suggest a longer stay to fully appreciate the place.

I have visited this Palace during the Lantern Festival so it was free thus I cannot comment on the ticket pricex. It has the nicest localisation of the all Palaces as you can see beautiful green mountains in the backgroun. I'd say that if you have time to see only one, see this one.

Up until recently there was a night time openning event. Normally it is operated from 9a.m to 5p.m.  So when you grab a chance of night time opening, it will be great. You can enjoy the traditional architecture style of Chosun Dynasty through from 14th to 17th century. You can't imagine there still stands a beautiful palace by the downtown of Seoul.  It's the symbolic scenery of Seoul to get along well with tall buildings and historic palace. Those complexcities are the feature of Korea.

Nice for a wander around on a nice sunny day. Not at all expensive for how much of the palace and the grounds you get to walk around. Can easily spend a few hours walking around the palace and the gardens. Definitely worth a visit, an absolute gem in amongst the high rise buildings of central Seoul

A huge park of old palaces right next to modern buildings. In a way it symbolizes both the old and new Korea.  I recommend taking a guided tour. Our guide was excellent and provided background and perspective to the palace grounds. Specifically how the Kings/Queens lived during the Joeson Dynasty. Especially when you compare this to today's modern sensibilities.  There is also an audio guide, but I did not use. Perhaps the next visit.

I wouldn't be expecting that the palace is wide and with two museums that can be visited after. Got amazed with places surrounded with almost blooming lotuses. The tranquility and the fresh air ease away the problems and anxieties. Truly educational and relaxing at the same time.
There was lovely parade, nice atmosphere there, a place you must see if visit Seoul!!! The palace is big, there is an interesting museum which just opened. Great to learn their history.

This entire place is awesome! Its a very beautiful and nice place to go but be warned, it can get a little tiring to walk around as it is extremely big. You can rent a hanbok (Korean traditional costume) and walk around to get the experience of the olden days. If you are lucky and are on the right time, you might even get a chance to see the guards changing 'shift'. It is highly recommended to visit this place!

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the most famous and largest palatial complex available in Seoul. It is well located above the Gwanghwamun Square and close to Line 3 Metro station. It is fairly well preserved and reconstituted, while some areas are not accessible, some others clearly showcase the way of living during the Joseon Dynasty with different rooms spanning each building serving as quarters for either the King, the Queen, the Court and Guests at the Palace. It gets a little repetitive as the buildings were duplicated in different sizes but the overall ground is magical and includes performances, the National Palace Museum, the Folk Museum, etc. Get patient as not everything is well indicated and perhaps a group tour would be better. Note that you'll get free admission if you dress in the traditional costume, which seems to appeal the young generation!

This palace and grounds are kept immaculate, you will not be going around saying "that looks shabby, they should fix that up", nay! You will be impressed by their upkeep and slight modernisation (the electric light!). Lots of good looking young ladies walk around in traditional dress (some men too, but it's a minority), peacefully enjoying the gardens and place, making you think upon olden day times whilst they are taking selfies and posing in duck face... Must see.

For best view, avoid dust storm periods in Spring. It can ruin your day. Also, winter may not be best. There are restaurants inside but they are only good for light meals. Also, try their tea shops. These are fairly good. There is underground parking but you must arrive very early. The spaces are quickly gone. Also watch out for so many tour buses. One good thing is that it is very close to downtown.

It's a beautiful place, you can almost see the grandiosity of Korean nobility of old. Confucian kings ruled for more than 500 years until the beginning of 20th century. There are two museums in the complex. Palace museum is great and folk museum's shop is worth a look. It's quite a long walk though, and not for rainy days, because inside there are no pavements. You shogun check the time for guided tours in English, when I went it was 11:00. And you should plan to go there at the time of presentations usually held at the afternoon, it was 14:00 When I went so I missed them. There are presentations of royal guard exchange, martial arts and others, at different times.

My cousins and I did visit the place first before going to other nearby palaces in town but because of too hot weather we never stayed long actually.. The best time to visit this place is when the sun sets.. We went to this place at noon time and we never had our hats and umbrellas and so the scorching heat was not fine for us..But never, never miss going to this place when you go to Seoul..

This is the largest of all the Seoul palaces, though not the most charming (Changdeokgung is). What makes it the best single choice is the fact that it also contains the National Folk and Palace Museums (both free).
One of historical place that must visit while in Korea. Try to rent Korean traditional dress and walk around with it. Better come in the morning as at noon too crowded

Not too special! Only a big famous place for a walk. Many korean girls wear traditional hanbok for selfie or go along with professional photographer. But it is good to go once if you haven't been to there.

I'm a fan of history, art, and architecture, and the Palace was a wonderful way to experience all three. We went during December, so it was rather chilly. The Palace tour takes about an hour if you go with a guide (and read reviews of tour guides before going to an attraction - ours was rather pushy and made us feel like schoolchildren), and we would've enjoyed this more had we done it ourselves with perhaps a guide book. However, the history of the palace is very interesting and a lot of the centuries-old work is still intact. You will definitely enjoy the daily Changing of the Guard (at noon)!

The palace was not open for public to go inside and roam the halls, but the site was well-kept. Traffic was pretty tough heading towards this area but thats only because its a tourist attraction. What we did was have the van we came in, drop us from a distance and pick us up at an agreed location when we were done touring.
Nice place but kinda bored as only sight seeing and have to walk a lot as the place really big. Not able to catch the ceremony, coz my frenx told me is an interesting show. :) overall nice place :)
It is much smaller than Beijing's Palace but similar set-up. Many Korean came here with traditional costumes on that day and friendly enough to take photo with us. Thank you!
A must see if you are in Seoul. Beautiful landscape and architecture. Similar to the palaces in China but it is worth visiting!

Gyeongbukgong palace is in the middle of the city hall district in Seoul. It's the biggest palace (if im not mistaken) in Korea and was once home to the Royal Family. The buildings and environment are preserved so well that you actually can't help but think that you have managed to time travel and wound up back into the Joseon Era. Overall a Wonderful and beautiful place. A must see for any tourist!

A must visit place when you are in Seoul. Walk around and experience the atmosphere and the actual buildings within the palace walls in the city. If you have the chance, see the guard rotation at the main gate as well. Recommend you to buy the combination ticket, even though you don't need to see all the 4 palaces.
Was lucky enough to see the changing of the guards ceremony, very colorful! This place is Amazing, so much to see. Make sure you read all of the information plaques. Very highly recommend
A must see. It is better to go with the tour. They have a microphone so easy to listen to. They have tour in Korean, English and in Japanese.
It is similar to some palaces in China. But as the most beautiful palace in Korea, it is still worth of visiting. I personal think you need a tour guide to tell you the history of this palace.

Beautiful palace in middle of Seoul. We hired han-bok at a near by store and walked around, taking photos, which was a lot of fun Some beautiful sights. However my memory is rather faint (after about a month) what the differences are between Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung other than the latter was bigger and had a big garden (Secret Garden-Biwon) - so if you are pressed for time, you could do either one of them rather than both.

A tremendous place to see a real palace inside a metro city. Entering the front gate you will be welcomed by a majestic palace gate. You will ejoy the old building with great maintanance effort make sure you explore the whole complex with a tour guide which will helps you understand each building function and how a royal lived on that era, including technology on those days which affect modern korean people

This is my 2nd visit but its much different as compared to winter period. Do not miss the change of guards and be all out and rent a hanbok for great photo around the palace. Of course take a tour if you are interested in the history as this is the grandest palaces in Seoul.

You haven't been to Seoul if you haven't visited this palace.  Glad to have visited this place on my first day in Seoul. It somehow enlightened me in an intuitive way of the present way of life of the people. It's something I can't put into words but just felt and understood.  Sense of pride for their heritage,history and culture is very evident in the Koreans.  I'm glad to have patiently waited for the English guided tour. It gave me a deeper appreciation of Korea's culture and tradition.  Highly recommended for history buffs and even better when touring with a guide.

A nice place to visit and you could spend a whole day here as it is a vast site.  Many authentic buildings and alot of open space with ponds and lakes. There is plenty of information to explain the original site.  A nice experience when visiting Seoul. It only cost about £2. For the ticket so is good value.

Beautiful palace, check the times for the different tours in different languages. You can purchase combination tickets to three palaces and a shrine and the tickets last three months so they are a good deal. I was able to use all he tickets in the combination during my two week stay.

Be sure and time your visit for Changing of the guard. Very colourful and ceremonial pomp. Beautiful ponds and grounds - worth a walk about. Understandably busy and popular as one of Seouls top attractions. Cheap to get in & take an escorted tour in the language of your choice, if your time allows. There were cultural music presentations as well.

Main attraction of Seoul, you can easily spend half a day there around the gardens and looking inside the buildings. It's worth it to join a free guided tour, make sure you check out the schedule in advance.
Went on the free English speaking tour (you have to pay for entry though), which was very interesting and made it a worthwhile visit. Nice looking palace and gardens.
Crowded with locals and tourist but this and Changdeokgung Palace are the ones that you really must visit if you are interested at all and your time is limited.

The sheer size of the place is impressive and one can easily spend 2-3 hours exploring the grounds. The place is very very popular and when I visited it was full of guided school and tourist groups.  Unfortunately the crowds detract from the serenity of the experience, so it might be worth visiting at opening time to stay ahead of the flood of tourists...
A good way to experience the traditional culture of korea Saw some girls renting hanbok and wear it to visit the palace But as usual the palace is flooded with loud tourist group
Most of the precincts of this palace looked dry and dusty. Compared to the Indian palaces I have seen, this palace looked too basic. The best parts were the ponds that we saw.
Lovely palace but very crowded , most of the time,but worth going as we get to see the old charm of Korean history , the garden are just amazing
Magical night walking around the palace after dark. The concert at the Pavillon showcased classical Korean music and dance. I enjoyed it even more than wondering around in the day.

We visited during peak festival time as a family of three, with a 2 year old in a stroller. Overall, this is a great place to visit. We would have enjoyed it more if it hadn't been so busy, but obviously as we visited during a festival it was to be expected. Good: Huge. Seriously. You could probably spend two full days here if you saw every inch of this place. Very interesting. Lots of signs in English. They also have audio tours available in English (and other languages) if you like that sort of thing. Lots of other things are connected to this, including a children's museum. If you like museums, you could spend several days going through all the ones surrounding this Palace.  Bad: Since this hasn't been much restored, the ground is very uneven. It is very difficult to push a stroller or wheelchair over it. The staff do their best to help by putting ramps over doorways, up stairways, etc, but it is still difficult. Not necessarily bad, but be careful about going here on a windy day. The sand/dirt on the ground is very loose and will blow into eyes and noses.  Definitely a must-see if you enjoy/are interested in Korean history.
The 3.30pm tour is quite good. Lady spoke English well. We could comprehend what she said. Thats a lot in Korea  Ticket full price is 3k Won. Thats it worth.

Gyeongbokgung was the first palace I visited and I was awed by the sheer size of it. Set aside about two hours to fully enjoy the sights and catch the changing of the guards ceremony if you can. It gets really crowded at certain parts because of tour groups. Closed on Tuesdays and costs ₩3,000 for admission for adults.

We arrived the Palace early as there is guided tour of the substantial palace grounds in different languages: English, Mandarin (and possibly French?)  The guide has done a great job in showing us bits of history, and even teased us with couple of questions to keep up the interest.  A most enjoyable experience but prepared to walk for an hour of so, and some of the grounds were a bit uneven. If you're concerned, then bring a walking pole to be on the safe side.
Enjoyed seeing the palace complex, I was glad I was with an organized tour group since I learned a lot of history that made it much more interesting

Personally, I like visiting places of historical and cultural value, especially palaces. Gyeongbok Palace is conveniently located from Metro Station and it gives an insight to the Imperial Korea in the past. I am quite surprised with how well maintained this palace is, given the fact that it was set up in the 14th century. For those of you who like taking pictures, this palace offers many spots to capture 'those' moments.  Even though Gyeongbok Palace was the main palace of the Korean Emperor, I find that it somehow lacks the grandeur of other palaces that I visited.

Watched changing of guard practice then the full works. There is English, Japanese, Mandarin audio explanations broadcasted so it's easy to follow. It's open in evenings without enaction. Beside it is the museum which is free. Also it's best location to walk towards Blue House and Buckhon Hanok Village.

If you're first time in Korea, I suggest you start exploring the history & culture first, (shopping and entertainment can come later), because Seoul is rich with it. They presevered their culture well. I personally love the palaces. I went straight here after I check in my luggage, just in time for the changing of guard ceremony at 1pm.  To go here, I use metro line 5 to Gwanghwamun station and used exit 2. I started at Gwanghwamun square, where Statues of King Sejong and Admiral Yi are and walk up to the palace. it doesn't take long. Tips: at the ticket counter we bought a combination ticket for the palaces + Jongmyo Shrine for 10,000₩. These include The Secret Garden at Changdeokgung Palace. If you buy separate tickets, entrance fee to each palaces can be up to 3000₩ (and The Secret Garden had an additional fee of 5000₩)

If you ever go to Seoul, you have to go to Gyeongbokgung Palace. It's great with friends or as a solo traveler. Easily accessible from the subway. Makes for great tourist photos. Truly a piece of Seoul you can't miss!
good place to learn about the olden days of Korea. was expecting more exhibits though. the guard changing ceremony was pretty awesome. take pictures with the guards too!

I love visiting historical places but not this one. The look and style of this palace is very similar to the Chinese one, so, you can still take some good pictures here. But this palace is kind of empty and there is not even a single sign to explain the history.
It's like you went back in time! For me it's like I've been to my favorite Korean period dramas. The Changing of the Guards Ceremony is a must see. Lots of photo opps for, I guarantee you!
We spend about 1/2 day here exploring the castle and its lovely grounds.  Don't forget -- It's closed every Tuesday!
The palace offers some great photo opportunities and lets you wander freely and explore at your leisure!

The best of the old palaces here. While it will greatly underwhelm those who have been to the Forbidden City in Beijing, Gyeongbokgung is still a pleasant place for a tourist to visit for an afternoon. Definitely check out the changing of the guard ceremony. Also, you can get a photo with the presidential palace in the back.
I've been here before and it is great to see. Take into account that it's closed on Tuesdays. The palace has been rebuilt several times.

THE GYEONGBOKGUNG PALACE AT SEOUL, KOREA The Gyeongbokgung Palace was set up in 1394, and was the very first palace of the Joseon Dynasty (1392 to 1910). The four other royal palaces in Seoul are Gyeonghuigung, Changdeokgung, Changgyeonggung and the Deoksugung. These palaces are UNESCO World Cultural Heritage sites Gyeongbokgung was built by King Taejo, founder of the Joseon Dynasty, and is the grandest and most exquisite of all the palaces in Seoul. It is one of the finest examples of Korean architecture. Entry to the palace is via the main gate known as Gwanghwamun. It is made almost entirely of granite and is surmounted by a Korean-style twin roof. The palace buildings, on the other hand, are made almost entirely of wood, and are aesthetically painted with Korean motifs. Many of the royal family’s possessions have been transferred to the National Palace Museum of Korea, on the same grounds, where they continue to be on display. Thus, the main palace building is virtually unfurnished. The main palace building was the former residence of the Korean royal family. Alongside is the beautiful Gyeonghoeru pavilion and the well-manicured palace gardens, both of which retain their original charm. At the entrance are guards, as well as palace “officials” dressed n various colourful period costumes – primarily reds or greens. Tourists love to have themselves photographed by their side – such pictures having high souvenir value. However, the icing on the cake is the very elaborate ceremony of the Changing of the Royal Guards, performed three times a day. It is a journey back in time, to an era of pomp, glory and grandeur. The National Folk Museum of Korea,covered in a previous item, is also on the palace grounds. Hormuz P. Mama

Loved seeing this beautiful place nestled in the heart of such a cosmopolitain city. The architecture was breathtaking, with so much to see for a really affordable entrance fee. There were so many hidden areas to take photos without tourists all over. Had a great time.
Our visit was timed perfectly... not a huge crowd and pleasant weather. We enjoyed venturing on our own and seeing the beautiful gardens.

The palace is huge and it takes time to go around it. There is a museum located inside, where you can see the history of the nation and what the ancient Korea looked like. Make sure you do not miss the shift changing of the guards at the gate of the palace. You can take photo with the guards as well, they wear the traditional clothing. Do not use selfie stick though, the guards will forbid you.
Although largely reconstructed after the second world war, Gyeongbokgung Palace is an impressive example of Korean classical architecture. Must-see for any Seoul visitor with a few hours to spare.

Take an English-language tour, which is included in the purchase of the entrance ticket. This ticket is free to people 65 and older. Allow at least two hours to enjoy this magnificent and historic palace. Read about it before going and find out the times of the English--language tour.
So amazing place and too many travelers on there not special for foreign, it's including Korean as well. If you wear hunbok, the entrance price is free.

It takes about 1 and a half hour to look around the palace. If you are into architecture, it is worth of visiting. The ticket is cheap and it is even free if you are wearing the Korean traditional clothes. (Hanbok)
Joseon dynasty palace in seoul. If you enter the palce,you can see not only palace but beautiful garden and so on.

This is a must see if you're in Seoul. And do join the free walking tours for the explanation on the palace(about 60 mins). The guides are friendly and knowledgeable. After the guided tour, wait around and witness the changing of the guard. There are 2 types, one just the guard changeovers. Then there's another with major ceremony and a band. not sure which times, but stick around for the major one. There's toilets and a cafe inside the palace grounds near the gift shop. Good photo opportunity near the pagoda facing the mountains at the north side of the palace

I really enjoyed the palace and especially the guard changing ceremony. This is definitely a must-see when you are in Seoul. As I have been there on a Sunday it was very crowded. I you have the time and option to go on another day, than do this...especially when you want to take beautiful pictures.

We took the free english guided tour included in ticket and she was very good. The tour lasts about an hour and visits all the key building. The guide will explain how the king and queen lived in their quarters, how the buildings were heated and designed. The palace is beautifully reconstructed and we will return as the work is ongoing to restore more buildings. From the palace it is a short walk to Bukchon and Insadong.

The costumes...the history...the beautiful garden inside are a must when in seoul...it represents the best of the korean history...one of the most beautiful attractions in seoul...inside you'll find lots of tourists wearing the traditional costume...it will be fun to take a photo with some...
So excited visit this place,bcoz im wearing Hanbok (traditional costume of korea) so it looks special when you taking picture wif hanbok infront of the Gyeongbokgung Palace

This palace represented the determination of the pple's desire to keep and maintain their history. Rebuilt many times I don't think any of the Kings had lived or used this palace before. So this place is more like a record of what it was like in the past. It is still interesting enough although I wished there were more signage to explain the history.
This palace is apsolutly beautiful. An added feature included in the very reasonable entry fee is the most colourful changing of the guard. Well worth a visit, highly recommended.

The place is huge so prepare to walk. Since it's Spring, the place was filled with spring flowers and cherry blossoms. A lot of people were roaming around the palace premises in Hanbok which made the scenery even beautiful. The palace architecture especially in the Throne room is so detailed and magnificent. A must visit place in Seoul.

Reconstructed palaces but historically accurate. Wear comfortable shoes and bring an extra battery to take lots of pictures. Make sure to read so you'll know their past and present. There is a perfect spot in this place where you can literally look at the past on your left and the present on your right. It has coffee and souvenir shops too.

We were really fascinated about the scale of this palace. It was huge and magnificent. The pavilions are all lovely and all of this is right in the middle of urban Seoul. You can't get any contradictory than that.

Gyeongbokgung is the largest of the 5 grand palaces and worth the stop. It can be overrun with lots of kids on class field trips but once you get away from the first few entrance rooms, there is lots of space within the walls to find areas that are very secluded and peaceful too. The grounds are impeccable and stunning with the Bukhansan mountain backdrop. In April, the flowers are blooming, even some cherry blossoms left. The changing of the guards ceremony at the main entrance is charming and well worth the 15 minute stop to catch it. The free Folk Museum within the Palace grounds is also well worth the visit.

Entering the compound, like taking a time machine back to the ancient time of Korea, where the emperor still have the Vito power. It also feels like entering a scene in the korean drama. See how the king lived, the life in a grade palace.  At the same time, we can feel that no matter how great a king was, finally it back to the earth, ash to ash, soil to soil.  Then the democracy hit, slowly Seoul becomes the Seoul today, modern, fast pace, developed.  It worth to take a walk to this historical place, but suggestd to do it during spring or autumn, particularly the festival of cherry blossom.

I may be wrong, but I think this is the largest and main palace in Seoul. Yes it is huge and could take you about 2-3 hours of you wanted to go to every single area in the palace grounds. A must-visit to see a slice of history.
We visited at a time when the cherry blossoms and other blooms made this an especially enjoyable place.

Our guide advised us that the Palace has been destroyed repeatedly over the centuries, yet the S Koreans have refused to forget their rich heritage. The Palace is immense and very impressive and has been lovingly restored. The place is immaculate and well cared for, and is a must see for all travellers
The biggest palace on Seoul..catch the changing of guard ceremony and be taken back to time...The feeling is surreal.Take a stroll at this majestic palace with great view!!

The Palace is a lovely recreation of the palace from long ago. Much of Seoul's old buildings were destroyed during the wars, but they did a great job rebuilding and preserving this cultural heritage. I liked walking around the smaller courtyards where there were fewer people and more undisturbed family picture taking opportunities.
I loved visiting the Palace. Walked around the palace, explored it fully and enjoying getting to know the beautiful designs, culture, traditions and architecture!
This is a beautiful palace -- the largest of the major palaces. The grounds were lovely. Great photo ops!
Grandest palace in Seoul set against mountain backdrop. Many pavilions & halls spread out on sprawling grounds, prepare to walk! Closed on tues. Daily changing of guards 10am-3pm.

When we arrived there , it had been snowing and the palace gave us a wonderful sight. Just on time for the parade. It was quite thrilling to see these men in costumes and the sound of the gong.... We then entered the complex and visited this huge place. The atmosphere was quite eerie with the snow covering the ground and the roofs. We had a great time.

Oldest and biggest palace in Seoul. You'll need time to explore it, since it is so vast. Mostly palace buildings, though it does have a very charming back garden and a shrine as well. Don't miss out on the throne room, I found that to the most impressive building.

One of the cultural/historical places to visit in Seoul. The grounds is not as big as Beijing's Forbidden Palace, but it's worth a visit. A good place to go to take a break from all the endless shopping.

We thoroughly enjoyed touring through this palace and also indulging in the architecture and history of this amazing location. The ceremony of the guards and people in traditional dress was an added highlight to this visit
Nice place worth a visit for anyone who has not been to Seoul. Changing of the guard is worth to witness. Need about 1-2 hours to complete the tour.

It is huge there's no other words to describe it. I would have loved to either read more about the background prior or either attended palace tours that they have. I went a couple of days before April so there weren't many cherry blossoms - only a few trees had started blossoming. The scale of the palace complex was huge and I could spend a whole day in it. The huge scale of tourists and students made taking pictures impossible. In addition there weren't any signs at each building providing more information and any furniture to indicate how it would have looked in the past.

Grand palace would be an understatement to describe the whole compound of the palace. We gave the self-guided tour 2-3 hours but to tour the whole palace for its entirety, a traveler may need at least 4 hours, take minimal pictures, and a lot of energy to complete the entire tour of this palace.

Be sure to witness the "Changing of the guard" performed hourly 11 - 3, as a spectacle. The collection of buildings within the palace are interesting but basically not a great deal there. Entry is reasonably cheap.
Great first impression at the front gate(gwanghwamun) but there is very few too see or explore inside. at least there are frequent guard show at the gate.

the march was at 10am sharp, so be there on time, it was an experience but i am not a historical person, so seeing it from the outside and watching the guard shifts was good enough. but definitely a possible site to go and experience korea! and listen to historical stories from a tour guide ;)

One of the icon when you come to seoul. This is enough interesting place that you have to visit. Many of tourist come here not only international but domestic too. Few people come here with tranditional clothes and mostly young people. You can ask them for photo. Dont forget to see the schedule of changing guard ceremony and explore the palace. You can find museum at back of the palace.

This palace is huge and would probably take a good part of the day to explore. I personally did not venture into the palace quarters (seems like you had a pay an entry fee?) but remained outside taking photographs. Some lovely views guaranteed, what with the mountains some distance from the palace in the North. I actually much preferred Changdeok and Deoksu Palaces though. I found the change of guard procession here to be a tad bit disappointing. Also, tourists come here by the bus load and the crowd was overwhelming at just 10:30am in the morning. Needless to say, I left really quickly.

A stunning palace in Seoul. The scale of the palace and its grounds took us by surprise as its in the city centre. Very definitely worth a visit. I would recommend watching the changing of the guard. Whilst it's a reenactment, it's a fabulous colourful spectacle.

We don't usually sign up for group tours but this was a good one since we were the only clients on the tour. The palace and surrounding grounds are very grand. We were able to see the pageantry of the changing of the guard and the lovely architecture of the palace and rooms for the king and his family. It is a must tour since one can see old Korea surrounded by a new, vital and pristine South Korea. Our well informed guide shared and explained interesting historical information.

A wonderful place to visit for everyone. Lots of history here, beautiful architecture and grounds. Visited there on a foggy day, with mountains and the pagoda breaking through, giving everything a very romantic ancient painting appeal.
Great that they preserved this area. Was able to see the changing of the guard and the inside of the palace.
The Palace is a must-see for a first-timer to Seoul. The architecture is beautiful. We didn't do a tour, just walked around and enjoyed the sights.

We visited the palace meanwhile a few times and can recommend you to put this on your list too. There are guided tours available in foreign languages. We did a few in English when friends came over and there's quite a difference in quality among the different guides. My wife followed once the Chinese guided tour which was apparently best of all. The chinese speaking guide carried apparently so much more knowledge of the history than the English speaking guides we followed so far. The season I liked most is autumn. The different colors around the lake and the ginko tree area are magnificent.

We visited this Palace after our visit to the blue house (Cheong Wae Dee). This is the largest Palace in Seoul and it's really huge. The exterior were well maintained. Even though we didn't manage to get an English language tour around the palace, we enjoyed ourselves by taking lots of photos. The cherry blossom trees were so low that we were able to touch and feel them. It was really a beautiful sight to behold with the lake, cherry blossom flowers and the built of the palace.  It's worth the visit. If you don't want to visit all the other palaces, one should visit this one.

You would enjoy this place if you like history - otherwise it would just be a huge place to roam. Quite crowded with lots of tour groups. Located just outside the subway. Do catch the changing of guards "parade" at 10am and 1pm (there's one more later).

I was impressed by how this heritage building could be located beautifully in the city center with huge land allocation. The palace was maintained very well, and of course this is a great place for photo!
the palace is big. u can explore on your own or join a free guided tour. recommend the tour as it is useful to know more about the history and architecture.
as per title, this is the best palace that i have visited in korea (i have visited some in seoul and pusan)

Get a feel of what life was like in the days when kings ruled Korea .. The throne room is pretty amazing and the price of the ticket is 3000won which is 3usd.. So worth it! You can also rent a self guided tour device or download the app. Lots of people and lots of photo opportunities.!

The Palace is awesome and very big. It's fascinate to be part of korean history. However, they should provide more information about history of the Palace for visitor in the leaflet. Got 1 palace I can't remember the palace name, we can go inside but we have to book in advance more than a week to go in. I thought tourist might not know about it until I ask the guard there. I think the palace I mentioned is summer palace. I really want to go in because the tourguide said if we see from inside the palace out at the window, we'll see the view like the painting. That's make me really want to go in!! The Palace close on Tuesday due to korean drama shooting.
A very big and beautiful palace. Give yourself a few hours to slowly explore the beauty of the palace.

big palace, ticket includes the national palace museum & national folk museum. Only manage to cover the folk museum in about 4hrs time so we skipped the palace museum. some parts is still under re-construction, according to the tour guide it will only be fully completed by 2030.
We arrived in time for changing of guard. Such a great experience. And walking though the entire palace compound was amazing. Such great history everywhere.
Beautiful palace with interesting marching parade. Did not go in but the view from outside is significant enough. Near subway!
Large facility with a modern museum, as well. Great photo opportunities everywhere. Just don't miss the changing of the guards presentation!
Love the architecture of this palace, the huge building and amazing built of this place will make you feel like a Korean royal yourself! :)

If you've seen your fair share of palace, you could be a tad underwhelmed. It isn't opulent, it doesnt have the grandeur and scale of Ottoman, Spanish or Indian palaces. Its charming though. And low key. There is the customary staged "Changing of the guards". You'll see the guards soon after out of their outfits in tees resting against the palace walls smoking a cigarette. Its a collection of korean style units spaced across a large piece of land. Its sandy and dusty. There's a temple on one end. If you're into Korean history, yes the wartime facts will be interesting, but otherwise, its a quick 40 min swing by. Combine with Bukchon Village right next to it. There are hordes of tourist buses that will arrive so prepare to jostle.

Love this classics destination in Seoul, not the best palace that I have visited in Asia but defiantly worth a visit to look into Korean history. Insadong and the Hanok Village is nearby as well, they are accessible by foot, don't forget to visit them while you see the palace.

For us the palace was more about the beautiful gardens it is set in. The area is huge and you could easily spend a few hours wandering around admiring the buildings, ongoing restoration and the very well maintained grounds.

This palace offers many beautiful historical structures that look surprisingly Chinese. Even though there were quite a lot of people on this Sunday afternoon. It felt tranquil.  There are also many perfect photo opportunities too.
One thing I love here is the view of the mountain from the entrance and view of modern building in front. We also l0ve the changing of guards.
The views throughout the palace were amazing. Enjoyed our time there. Could have spent 3-4 hours to take it all in.

We spent a day exploring the palace grounds are were not disappointed. The weather was great and really allowed us to maximize our time there. We started out the day by watching the changing of the guard at Gwanghwamun gate (it's worth watching and occurs every few hours around, I think we saw it at 11 am). We did not partake in a guided tour (not sure if they're available) but we did purchase some audio guides which did an adequate job of guiding us around the grounds. In addition to the gate at Gwanghwamun, there are several other gates leading into the main grounds where you can find the main palaces. The entire place is colorful and features an architectural style unique to Korea. Visiting at this time of year is especially good because the cherry blossoms are all blooming, making the palace's numerous gardens very beautiful. There are also royal residences, guest houses, temples and the king's library/study. You can spend many hours in the palace grounds and I would suggest you visit earlier rather than later, as crowds accumulate quickly and the palace closes around 6pm. In all, visiting Gyeongbokgung palace was by far my favorite experience while visiting Seoul and I would highly recommend it to anyone visiting the city and looking for something to do at a relatively low cost (bar minimum was transportation costs plus admission tickets and paying for the audio tour if you want it).

If this is your first time, try to join the in-house tour, or get a map and read the architectural labels to know the historical significance of the things you will see here. It will make you appreciate the place more than just having your pictures taken in here.

The complex is nice and some buildings spectacular. The whole place impress because of its overall size. This being said, there is not much to learn or even to do besides walking outside, along the empty or closed palaces. Certainly worth a visit though

The admission fee is Korean Won 3,000 and you can stay all day. Very scenic and pleasant walk. I visited at the tail end of the Cherry blossom season and there were still quite a few trees.  It being Sunday today, many locals came in their traditional costume, and this added the overall flavour to the palace and gave the visitors many photo opportunities

We visited the palace and the cultural history museum (one price gets both, they are connected inside the walls). Luckily had great weather (required), spring blossoms were out and the coming of age were around in their traditional dresses happy to pose for and with us on pictures.

Very nice place as cherry blossoms all over .. We with kids visited on april 9. So weather was cold and cloudy. Around 13c ..We didnt listen to the guide so we wouldnt be tied up. We got to take our time in looking for good photos to take wc is the most important . there's cafe also where the kids bought hot choco and muffin. .

We went last November . Weather turning cold. The place was awesomely beautiful with many nice nature view... Nice maple leaves all over ..  The buildings are so nostalgic as we see them in Korean drama :) if anyone rem watching roof top prince ..  We went in the period when they have many students coming in hanbok .. Boys wore army uniform . Many tourist requested to take pic with them so as my boys ..  We spent abt 4 hours as we explored almost the entire place while sharing with chn. Very educational .. Love to see the mandarin orange tree..  It's so therapeutic to be Juz sitting near to the pond to enjoy the weather , scenery .
We rent KRW1,000 per one automatic earpiece and it gave us great experience to understand Joseon dynasty history with appreciation on how Art took place in the palace and government administration.

The main palace used by the royals. Not the largest but gives a great picture of the country worked. Used until relatively recently by the last remaining royals. Highly recommended if you are on a time budget.
Nothing to shout of. I find the attraction need more signage to better appreciate the things we seen here. The only thing I find nice is the guard changing ceremony.

Set against the backdrop of mountains on one side, and modern Seoul on the other, the palace is a popular "must visit" attraction in Seoul. Don't miss the colourful changing of the guards at 10 am and 2 pm. You can take photos with the guards as well. The park was huge. Many pretty spots for photos. We visited at the turn of winter to spring, when some of the trees were beginning to bloom. It would be spectacular at the height of cherry blossom season, and during autumn. Loads of tourist busses and tour groups, though, but the grounds are huge enough not to feel over crowded. Our guide showed us the Kings and Queens quarters, the event hall, and even the little building where the king had famously invented the Korean written language characters.

A must visit if you come to Seoul just like Forbidden city is a must visit if you come to Beijing. It is a very large palace complex however mostly are reconstructed one and during my visit also several spot are still under renovation.

Beautiful look into history with many buildings around the palace and a museum. Plan to stay about 1/2 the day there to explore everything. I must have taken 200+ pictures while there. Part of it was free then it was W10,000 ( $10 }

We tour this place for around an hour. We interestingly watch the changing of guards, took some pictures with them, take a tour inside the palace.  A great place to learn the life of the kings in yesteryears - what each room consists of and looked liked.
Interesting to visit to understand the culture of Korea. I joined the one hour free english tour guide provided at the location.
It is a marvel that such a historical place is still standing in the middle of Seoul. The details of the building and the whole place is just grand.
Jinny was very clear with her explanations, and her jokes were funny! Grand and tragic at the same time. A must visit.
Guided tour organized by visit seoul web site provide tours in English, Mandarin or Japanese! Free of charge! However the palace is so large, it took 2-3hours for the tour.

The grounds at the palace are deceivingly large, so what we thought was going to be a 20 min walk through the palace turned into 90 minutes or so. This is another good site to see in order to get a picture of what life was like when... There is nothing extremely thrilling about this attraction, but there is quite a bit to see. Thought this was not a bad site, I would recommend this on a nice weather day.

Great place to visit, lots of interesting buildings and more of an interactive open space you could walk around. Huge complex with lots to see and great photo opportunities.  Only limitations is that there is a shortage of places to eat/drink (only came across one small cafe) and not enough information on the actual sites you are looking at

This palace is still under reconstruction but it's already worth a visit. Guided tours are free if your timing is right and are well worth your time to get a little bit of background. There are some particularly lovely views at the Northern end of the palace grounds.
rich in culture and history. very interesting to listen to the lifestyle of the kings of yesteryears.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is easily reached via the Purple Line 5 Gwanghwamun Station. The prominent huge statue of Emperor Sejong watches you as you stroll past him at the Gwanghwamun Square towards the Gwanghwamun Gate. It is a good 500m walk from the station.  The 3 colourful guards in traditional Korean military outfits stood solemnly at the Gate as tourists posed photos with them. Don't miss the changing of the guards. The entrance fee to the Palace proper is 3,000KRW including free entry to the National Folk Museum at the back. The Palace is nothing spectacular if you compared with those in Beijing, China like the Summer Palace or Forbidden City. It is just wide and big open sandy ground with squarish traditional houses. Nothing colourful or interesting. It would be nicer during the autumn or cherry blossom season. We were there in late March and all trees shed their leaves and look so gloomy.  The National Folk Museum is more interesting as it showcases the history of the Korean culture. You should spend more time in the Museum than walking aimlessly in the big wide Palace ground unless you take the free tour which offers better insight of Palace. We did not take the free tour as we missed the timing. The other highlights are the pagoda and the traditional Korean houses around the Museum vicinity.  We existed through the National Folk Museum road entrance instead of walking back to the Gwanghwamun Gate. We original wanted to have lunch at Tosokchon for the ginseng chicken (nearer to the Gate side) but the Museum Entrance staff showed us a cross arms indicating not worth the walk back to the Gate. Instead, we walked to Insadong, about 15 minutes away.

The guard changing ceremony is really interesting and worth going to see. It happens a couple times a day. There is commentary in mandarin, English and Korean through the ceremony. The guards wear traditional dress which is awesome to see as it is very unique to Korea.
Refreshing to eyeside. Never a dull moment. Lots of beautiful view. Prepare to do real walking. The place is huge. Really not to be miss place.

On a sunny spring day with the cherry trees in full bloom we toured the palace and were in awe of the sprawling magnitude of the palace grounds. I was particularly delighted with the many, many Koreans who dress in traditional clothing to visit the palace. It made it all the more enchanting.

Nice palace for a morning visit. Enter the palace via Gwanghwamun gate and try to time your visit to catch the Royal Guard-Changing Ceremony.  The palace was largely rebuilt and restored and it gives you an insight of the living area of the royal family, Joseon Dynasty.
The Gyeongbokgug is the best temple in Korea, close to central city and can make a nice half day trip to people staying in Center Seoul.
This is a larger park, most people rarely see the deep end of the park. Definitely worth visiting as the national midtown is right next to the castle.

There isn't much too see, but if you're on a date, you don't want the experience to just drag on and on. So in that sense, the palace is perfect. Many people prefer to go to Gangnam for dates, but I think Gyeongbokgung and Gwanghwamun area are much better as it is cleaner and more things to do.  Night-hours at the palace is also a sight to see, however, be warned of big crowd.

This palace need no reservation prior to the visit. Tickets can be purchased outside the palace. English guided tour is highly advisable to thoroughly enjoy the palace and understand the history and story behind what really went on during the earlier days of Korea.

I went there in Feb - in winter time. There is no flower at all BUT i can see the brownish scenery at park behind the palace which is nice to see and also can see the nearby hill (don't know the hill's name).. the cold n3ver bother me anyway..

Was my third trip here in ten years but my first visit in late spring. Simply lovely. Especially enjoy the palace gardens at the back! The free guided tour that we signed up for made the visit even more enjoyable!
Interesting to visit, but after 30mins the kids were bored. There was a ceremony when we were there so it helped to spiced things up.
Must come here to see and be in a moment as king and queen of this palace. Beautiful scenery especially during the spring seasons. Be sure to wear transitional Hanbok so can get free admission here.

Once you cross the great walls that separate the city from the temple, you will feel you are back in the 12th century. There are shows every once in a while. Korean things... it's a great place to visit. Also, it's very close to the old village and to a walking pedestrian street, very famous too, that I don't remember the name now!! But if you have the time: do it!

Most of the palaces have been burnt down several times (being made of wood), so they are mostly replicas, and not very authentic when there is a concrete lintel across the roof...it wouldn't have taken much to hide the lintel under authentic roofing tiles. Also, you can't go inside most of the buildings due to their small size and fragility - 'wallpapered' floors wouldn't take too many feet pounding across them - so it's not like visiting a stately home in the UK!

Excellent for those who love historical spots and this one is given the bonus of having the National Palace Museum right next to it (free entry). From the old map and looking at palace from a distance, one would feel as if it's back to Forbidden City. The stone ground, steps, carved balustrades, bronze urns, painted ceilings and eaves in main hall, etc etc. As a Kdrama fan, I can't help but get dizzy headed ! There are a few restricted areas but overall there's a good feel about exploring the inner grounds where many old trees survived. Particularly like the huge pavilion connected to a manmade lake. If you visit early or mid April, you get to see more blossoms.....I was lucky to catch a couple of plum blossoms. Time and patience is needed to cover the huge grounds.

Spacious palace, cold weather, windy.. That what i feel when i visited this palace. Surrounded by mountains... It so beautiful place to see. An ancient building with the history it self. Make this palace is one of must visit place in seoul.
Beautiful place. You can feel the history the minute you walk in. Make sure you buy tickets ahead of time for the secret garden

Centrally located near Insadong, Bukchon Hannock Village, as well as several museums, this main palace from the Joseon Dynasty is a great place to start your day. There is a subway stop by the same name on line 3 and exit 5 brings you right up into the palace grounds. It's only 3kWon per person for entrance and there are free English speaking tours throughout the day. This is my favorite palace to take guests because there are so many options of places to go from there.

If you coming to Seoul. This is must be in ur itinerary. The palace is huge, it take about 1.5 hour to explore. It also have changing guard ceremony before ur enter the palace. if u want to see inside the palace, have to buy entrance ticket about 3,000won. Since this is my third visit to Korea. So i just watch the Guard Ceremony. it also take about 30 minute. after the ceremony end, we can take picture with the Guard.
A very picturesque palace with a lot of great angles. Make sure to watch the changing of the guard ceremony. It is very colorful and veery photogenic.

Need at least 1.5 hrs to explore. Plenty of places to explore and take photos.  The guard changing ceremony is must see - to get the best view, stand at the top corner of the L shaped path where the procession will take place. You can get to see 2 sides of the ceremony.

If you're going to a palace, make this one your destination. Entrance fee is nominal and the place is huge. Crowds can get busy with all the tour groups. No food inside, and washrooms are hard to find so go prepared.
You could probably walk yourself around this monument with a guide book, but going with a tour guide had us there for the changing of the guard & little nuggets of information as we walked around.
I had an opportunity to visit this palace. It's unfortunate that it was raining but I really enjoyed my stay.

This palace is huge, with loads to see!! The buildings are beautiful and the grounds are well maintained. You can see the "changing of the guards" which was pretty cool as well as being able to try on traditional Korean clothes for pictures. The palace was vey very busy - so i would suggest going early to try and avoid the mass crowds. My friends and I spent around 3 hours walking around this attraction

Be prepared to get lost in the palace without a map. My fiance and i visited the palace without a guide map and we got slightly confused after a while since most of the buildings look quite similar. The palace is picturesque all around and we loved taking a 1hour stroll within the palace.

A beautiful palace giving a glimpse into Korea's past. If you pay for a ticket you can enter and walk around. The trees were bare when we visited but I imagine they are beautiful when in bloom and even in the fall. Couples dressed in traditional clothing walking around make for great photos. If you don't want to pay, you can see some of it and the guard changing for free outside. We saw it at 2:00. They do not do it on Tuesday, and if I remember correctly the whole place is closed on Tuesday. Palace is right outside of an exit of the subway. There is a museum as well with a cafe outside and a cafe inside. A bit pricey for me. The palace is also next to the traditional village which makes for a nice walk and craft shopping - I recommend going to a cafe there afterwards.

Ticket entry is cheap compared to a site in the uk. There are plenty of toilets available and a coffee shop. There's plenty of space to move about although key areas i.e. at photo spots, it can get a bit crowded.  There are free tours in multiple languages available which are very well done and last about an hour, you can just turn up at the meeting spot inside the 2nd courtyard in at available times and join. Be prompt as they do go on time and are only 3x a day in English from what I could see.  You can see the changing of the guard for free but make sure you time it right or you'll miss it (check on website).  The cultural devastation by Japan over various occupations means this entire Palace has had to be rebuilt from scratch and none of it is the original palace from the 1500's. Japan actually shipped the entire crown princes wing of the palace to Japan where it burnt down in an earthquake in 1923, only the foundation stone was returned. Don't go expecting to see the original thing as it's not, only a replica from records. Saying that it's pretty impressive that they've managed to do the restoration they have.  It's a grest site and they are still working on some wings which have yet to be rebuilt. Expect to spend a full hour more exploring even after the tour.  You can exit out (and keep the ticket for re-entry) the rear gate to see the Blue House (the modern day korean presidents residence). Hint when you see loads of secret servicemen you'll know you're there...you can't miss them.

It's good to be back again. I came here on Winter time and this time with my daughter. I love watching "changing guards ceremony" and walking around this palace with Korean Traditional Dress "Hanbok". Just come to the information centre and tell them that you will going to use handbok during your visit here. They will help you. Don't forget to use your comfortable shoes..

This is one of those places that you need to visit because it is one of Seoul's tourist attractions... It looks like a much smaller and less ornate version of the Forbidden Palace in China. If you visit here and want to go to the Bukchon Hanok Hillage, be sure to ask for directions as they are in close proximity... Since you are here, the National Folk Museum was also pretty good to see. That attraction was free...
Nice soothing place... Must watch change of guard act, luckily was there at right time when it happened.... JetPrivilege number 201869242

It is better to visit the palace early morning. Plan to arrive at the palace around 08;45, and watch around the palace and enter the palace premises by 09:00. After 10:30 more visitor will be there and miss the chance to get nice photographs. Dont forget the museum, where you can find more information on Korean Culture.

The palace compound is huge and you can spend a few hours walking slowly around it. There are gardes, a pavilion in the middle of the lake (though I think visitors are not allowed to enter the pavilion), living space of the royal family, etc. My friends and I studied the Korean history so we tried to tie everything to what we studied. One thing I would strongly recommended is to go with someone knowledgeable about this place or go with the tour as without them the buildings will be just another palace. You can always just take pictures of the area but to make the visit worth the trip having someone explaining things would be the better choice. Please check the operating hours too as I believe they close pretty early.

I like this place. You can visit the museum first. It tells history of korea. Then visit the traditional palace and you can watch the traditional parade (i dont know the name) The location is nearby the blue house.

Impressive glimpse into a once private royal residence. I highly recommend the brightly colored and musical changing of the guards. Any place along the rope will afford a good view. Each of the buildings you encounter are unique and the artistry of the beams and roofs are memorable.
One of the must see places of Seoul. All palaces are worth visiting, and this one is no exception. Guaranteed a nice visit!

Went here first thing in the morning. its a huge place so no worries even if there are many visitors. I enjoyed walking around taking in the fresh air and great sight. Was not able to witness the changing of guards but next time.

To me, travel to a new country and city should include a visit or more to the historic and cultural background of the city. We were fortunate to have been accompanied by a knowledgeable English speaking guide which made our two hour walk very meaningful and educational. Since we have visited many similar places in the world, I was impressed by the efficiency of the administration of the Palace.
We were lucky enough to be there when this palace was open at night. That only happens 4 weeks during the year. The palaces were lit up beautifully and people were very respectful of the area.
This is closed on Tuesday but the museum is open. Large and beautiful palace in the heart of downtown. A most see if you are downtown. Take the metro straight to it.

I have been here twice already but I still see the charm. The place is very big and imagining how they lived before then it must be very grand. This place is very accessible riding a bus or a train and around this are other sites as well. History and Architectural lovers would love this.

Sorry to be negative here, but as a tourist visiting Seoul I found this very underwhelming, especially relative to other top cultural sites around the world.  There didn't seem to be any rooms to enter, statues to see, etc. it's just a very large palace spread out on a huge patch of dirt.  I would recommend going on a tour - otherwise i think you'll be quickly bored.

Appreciate the beauty and architecture of the Joseon dynasty. The biggest out of the palaces in Seoul .... the tour nearly killed off my feet. So be sure to wear really really really comfortable shoes.  Don't rush through it, stopover at the museums to know more about the korean culture. There's also cafes there .... if you need a break.  This tour was one of my favourites ....

My first time here was in Sept 2014 before I came back again in Sept 2015. I followed an English complimentary tour guide the first time I was there. Really mesmerized by the scale of the whole palace. The tour was not 100% of the whole area since it was really big but it covered the necessary parts about the history of South Korea Kings. The view was really something to behold. The 2nd time I was there, I went to the National Museum beside the palace which I didn't manage to go the first time round. Given a choice, I won't mind coming again for the 3rd time.
The museum not to big, but have a nice story about Korean Ancestors and culture. We love to visit this places. The Palace somewhat similar China cultural in forbidden city.

it was fairly obvious from the start that the whole guard changing ceremony is performed by 'actors' - even the mustaches were obvious it was makeup. I was not very impressed by the whole ceremony - lots of banging and clanging and yelling. But see it if you are there.  The palace grounds are really spacious, but there's mostly barren since these are tourist places now.
A lot or tourist from around the world, the weather was very cold. Beautiful landscapes and i really love it.

It was closed when we are there on Tues but it look stunning from the outer view itself. Detour to National Palace Museum of Korea just next to palace which is eye opening from knowing the history of Korea.
It was day beautiful when I visited. Perfect weather , nice sun . The palace is big and spacious. They eat time I visited a palace in Korea so a really good experience.

A bargain for the entry price! Be sure to time your visit to see the changing of the guard which was spectacular. Worth walking all the way to the top of the park area to see the pond and other buildings.

Don't just look around the big palace, head up the hill to look around the older, smalller, more human areas. Much more evocative. My children loved the pool and oldest ( newly restored ) rooms. Korea has made her history come to life! Well done! My kids loved it.

This palace site (entry cost less than £3) is being extensively rebuilt, following the Japanese destruction of parts of the original palace during their C20th occupation However, the site is well worth including in your itinerary for Seoul as it is extensive and gives a powerful impression of the development of the Korean historical capital. The attached National Folk Museum is full of detail of historical Korean life and is both free and fascinating.
This place is huge, and in a cool area that's easy to get to by the Seoul Metro. Very historic and lots to do in the area when you are finished here. I would definitely go here if your in Seoul.
Visited in March, 2016. My only complaint, the water in the ponds were drained for the winter. Still a very impressive place to visit.
Been there on 12 March 16 last week, weather was cold but not short of tourist. The view was magnificent, and definitely breathtaking. One thing not to miss is the guard changing parade.

Awesome palace. Very big. Nice architecture. Should go and visit but not recommended to stay the whole day as it's just while day of walking around. The guard exchange ceremony is awesome to stay and watch.
I fell in love with this place. If you plan coming to South Korea, you must visit this place. There's nothing better than historical places in this country.

Great to spend 4 hours learning a bit more about korean culture and history. I found this really interesting. We joined the free walking tour which was probably the best decision as the guide was able to explain the difference between the buildings and piint out clever little things like the symbolic meaning of the number of animals on the roof beams and the innovative way the korean royalty kept their rooms warm in winter.  The palace is large enough that you wont feel crowded much. Bring some snacks or purchase outside so you have a drink while you wander around.

I've been here two times now, and I recommend going in good weather. The grounds are massive so it's really nice to take a few hours to walk around, sit down, look at all the buildings, etc  Watching the guards change is also cool (they do it at specific times)

Without a guide it is a stroll through a very interesting park. I visited as part of a VIP package tour while eating the goodies of Seoul. I would have totally missed this gem of a palace right in the middle of Seoul without expert knowledge guiding the way.  There is very little signage and didn't have an audio tour so without a guide you miss out on a lot of historical details of architecture and trees that literally date back to a different era. I would like to thank Daniel Gray and his company Delectable Travels for for arranging this excursion since I have visited Seoul often to eat and have seen many of the other sites before.
Worth visiting a few times rather than trying to see it all on one day. I loved the smaller palaces and buildings in the back.

Be sure to arrive early in the morning to see the ceremonial change of guards. After that, have the opportunity to take photos with these guards standing straight and stiff - but please be careful not to touch them as it is unallowed. The whole place is big and you can have great photos captured at the different rooms within the palace, including the king's room, queen's, princes and many others!

While you should see this palace, there is little information provided to guests without being in a third party tour group. It would have been nice to know what each of the buildings and structures were for for a glimpse into history and what life was like inside the palace walls.

Very extensive, beautiful and interesting. The only down fall is the 75 other tourists you are required to accompany on the guided Secret Garden portion of the tour (see pic). I would imagine that a small tour is the way to go next time. All in all it is worth a visit, just be prepared for and endless series architecturally stunning and recently painted empty buildings and complexes. It's surprisingly quite culturally bland.

I visited the palace with my partner and got bored too soon. There is not much to do inside the palace. Only a very few spots where you can get yourself clicked. I would not really recommend this site if you are seeking for some fun place and picnic spot to visit. But, if you want to tick one more destination on your checklist then go ahead and have a look at it. You might like it. Oh, and by the way there is a museum also which you can visit. But again, it was a disappointment too. Good luck!!! :) :)

this place used to be the seat of power to the old Korean kings. The entrance is cheap and they offer free English tour guides (check the guide schedule online). The palace is big and take sometime to see it all. also there are paid actors who act like old royal guards along with costumes and weapons and they do guard changing ceremony.

Admission is extremely affordable at only a few thousands won. A nice place to bring visitors who are interested in history if not it can be generally boring as there is no activities or performances around the site.

The Palace and the Museum is a good place to get to see the Ancient Korean Architecture but we must go along with a Guide else we might not understand anything.... Disappointing that entry into any of the Halls are restricted and Tourists can only see the Architecture from the Outside.

The palace is a great visit. A shame that you cannot go into the rooms, but still a great visit to see and experience a little how the royalties lived at that time. I also saw a few families with push chairs, so the facilities are definitely push chair friendly.  Do visit the museum as well, learned a lot about the history of Korea.

it is just architecture, certainly must checkout the time for guides if not you will miss a lot. I went in without a guide. There is a free guided tour in the information counter once in enter the palace one the right hand corner. They also give you free map. If you are not really keen of looking at the building, then maybe you can watch the exchange of guards. Or take pictures around the palace. Only cost 3000 won for tickets to go into the palace though. It will be great if you wear the hangbuk . good for photography. Met a few couples doing pre wedding there with traditional gowns.

Although not the prettiest royal palace in Seoul, it is a must-see because of the size and many other attractions within the palace. If you can do the evening tour, you are in for a very different experience which is also recommended. You cannot be disappointed with a tourist sight like this palace which summarizes the last Korean dynasty which lasted over 600 years.
A grand n beautiful architecture. Free guided tour is provided. Can reach easily by bus and by subway. Worth for visiting!
It makes sense to go here. What you see, why and how you see it helps give backgound toand understanding of Korea and the culture
In Korea ? Go see a palace - pap some pics and soak up some culture.  Nice 2hr stroll, bonus museum with some artefacts to scope out !

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is easily accessible by Metro as there is a stop dedicated to it. When you go up the steps, the vastness of the palace will welcome you. We didn't read up on the time of the changing of the guards but I think this is a nice thing to see. Entrance fee is W10000 I think for foreigners and you can wander about the huge palace grounds the whole day. Was amazed at the intricate design inside and outside the main palace. Also, it's amazing how all of these were preserved. Lots of clean restrooms inside the grounds. There's also a coffee shop where you can rest up. Definitely a must see when in Seoul!
Nice view of the Palace from the hotel . So big to visit, and is a land mark for history lovers and Asian Architect seekers. See pictures .
Never ceases to make me go whoaaaa..I just love how Seoul mixes old and new, modern and ancient so seamlessly.
Great history in Korea represented by this palace. Plenty of space to walk in peace and enjoy the ambience.
Korea is so amazing, you cant leave seoul without coming to the palace. the guard change is worth it too, reminded me of mulan!

Gyeongbokgung palace is a huge palace in the touristic quarter of Seoul. It is really worth it. You can walk through the different parts of the palace and admire the wonderful architecture of the palace. If you plan to do other palace in Seoul I would advice to take a pass (which is available three months after purchase).

I've been to this amazing palace twice now. I can probably safely say I know my way around Gyeongbokgung Palace pretty well. But no matter how many times I see the same buildings or walk the same routes, I'm always amazed. Walking straight from the bustling, central city of Seoul into this amazing historical palace is quite mind-blowing. The atmosphere instantly changes. It really does feel like you've stepped back in time. With beautiful historic buildings, mountain backdrops, and lakes scattered throughout, you are guaranteed to get some of the best photos from your Korean holiday right here! In fact, my photos here were so great and professional looking, it inspired me to take photography seriously on my holidays. If you come here, you will never regret it. It is unique and special, the kind of place that is unique to this amazing country.

Close to the fantastics National Museum (free), while you need to pay a small fee to enter in main complex of Gyeongbokgung (worth the $). Plenty of people wearing traditional dresses, a traditional show, very nice palace, plenty of old style buildings, and even is possible to see a show with Korean guard, old style. Awesome. Just don't try the food on the national museum and go somewhere else for lunch, really bad. Easy to get ther by metro, has got a station 2 minutes from entrance of the palace and the natinal museum. Good choice to spend the whole morning.
Lucky to be present during the ceremony of changing guards. Epic and interesting, very inspiring view in the midst of the capital's skyscrapers.
Great place to walk around and soak in the history and atmosphere. Plenty of people, but also plenty of space to explore too.
A guided tour is absolutely recommended since you could spend around 2 hours just walking around this place. It was amazing to see the vastness of the palace.

Beautiful, restored palace. Very reasonable entry fee that also includes the museum. Because we got there as soon as it opened at 9, we were able to walk the grounds with very few visitors and make it back to the gate for the changing of the guards by 10. So glad we started early because the tour buses started piling in as we made our way out.

There's a entrance fee charges to enter this place. Don't miss chances to tried out free costume before you enter the gate. Take picture for remembrance. Don't forget to take we-fie with guard in front of gate they wearing their traditional costume. There a few small palace located inside, walk and enjoy the beautiful scenery around the palace.
Lots of photo ops. Very large open air sight. Weather will impact your visit. Dress accordingly if very cold. Beautifully re constructed.
Many people flock to this palace and when you see it you realise why. For me it's a mini Forbidden City as far as the layout is concerned. A must see. Afterwards I walked to the Changdekgung Palace.

This palace is easy to reach from central Seoul and it costs only a few dollars to visit. Spend some time wandering around the lovely grounds and eavesdrop on the wisdom of a tour guide speaking your language, if you can find one. Based on the bits and pieces of various tour operators were heard, this place is rich in history, but even if you come uninformed, as we did, you will enjoy it all the same for its beauty.
and amazing value for money. If you just have a couple of hours to spend in Seoul, this is a great option.

Wonderful large palace grounds with excellent access to the buildings. Can get a bit crowded with all the Chinese tour groups because the have 20-50 in each group but the grounds are huge so you can explore the architecture and history without too many folks crowding around. The Korean History Museum is highly recommended and very thorough in presentation of the history of the Korean people.
Very similar to the Forbidden City in Beijing, this site contains a complex of courtyards and different buildings, lakes and places where you can walk.

Visited this palace and couple of time whilst living in Korea. Lovely walk ways around the palace and beautiful views! Wouldn't visit in winter as doesn't look as nice without the pretty flowers and trees. It's right next to a subway station and if you walk out the main entrance there's a lot of bars and restaurants nearby, and also a nice stream. There's an English tour guide which you can walk around with at set times (check on website). I walked around for about an hour with the tour guide and then did my own things.

this was the main residence of the king back in the day, out of the 6 or so palaces in seoul. you can only go in the day time unless its a special season offering night tickets or tours. be sure to catch the change of guard ceremony
The whole area is vast and the palace is well preserved. Very detailed intricate designs on the walls and roof... So enchanting and makes you wonder how it was like to live in those palaces..
This palace is like stepping back in time. You learn so much about Korean history and the architecture of this palace is gorgeous.

Grand spot. Nice visiting. However the palaces are all similar and less nice than the Chinese ones.  Basically yes you have to go and see but don't expect much.  It is quite surprising to see the mix of modernity in a so small space.

There isn't anything inside of this palace -- and the grounds are a bit dirty/muddy so wear appropriate shoes. It's sort of like the forbidden city if you've been to Beijng. There are many nice views as you walk around and the setting with the mountains in the background is really nice.
This place is pretty interesting. It is not a place that you would visit again and again, but it is one that should be visited a least just once if you are in the area.
