A place of serenity in the hustle and bustle of Seoul. There are a couple of museums on site. If you are planning to visit the palace and the museums, you will need to allocate sufficient time.

Very large facility with different palaces of great beauty. Don t miss the Natioal Palace Museum of Korea (just outside the venue) and the National folklore Museum of Korea (you can access it free and then go back to the Palace just showing your entrance ticket). Both museums are worth a visit. The palaces on the venue are quite a stroll one from the other so take your time. The place was crowded on a cold Febrauary weekday, so I imagine it must be worse in the Summer. Many young ladies rent a Korean traditional dress to visit the venue, it is quite colourful. You can buy a combined 10,000 KRW ticket for all Palaces and Jongmyo Shrine.
This is a nice place ... Great and a lot of sad story but the building is nice we spend about 30 mins here , its too rush .I think 1-2 hour is good scenic view
Insight of Korean history, way of living... Definitely take a guide, they will explain a lot of interesting details about this "forbidden city of Korea"
You can't go to Seoul without visiting the palace. Beautiful and the parks are very well designed. So colorful. Totally recommend it

A definitely must see in Seoul. The palace is wonderfully placed in an very modern area which gives it a splendid vibe. My friends and I were lucky to have witnessed the change of guards being in procession. It was an interesting sight to see.
Felt like I have transformed in time and went back to the old times where Korean Emperor, Empress, Princess exist. I want to one day wear the hanbok and take pictures here.

Positive: - huge places - all about Korean history - good place for picture - Flower season (April) - beautiful scenery  Negative: - Crowded with tourist, that will pushing you away from the place and cut queue etc

One can walk around and see the grounds, but the guided tour turns it into an experience. One hour to walk through the palace grounds plus 90 minutes to experience the hidden garden. Spring and fall must be stunning. I went in February when landscape was dormant. Still with the time even though it was chilly out. Dress warm.

Arrived in time to catch the changing of the palace guard ceremony at 10am in the square in front of the ticket booth. Make sure to keep your ticket, as you will need to show it if you exit then re-enter the grounds for the adjacent National Folk museum of Korea. The rear gate leads out to catch a distant view Cheong wa Dae, the presidential Blue House.
Plenty of walking around,clean about there and lots of history. Private guide made this very interesting

Went there late afternoon and watched the change of guards before going into the palace. There were a few tour groups, but not crowded. And once you step away from the centre and wander to the side, you get a really nice feel about this place.  There are many young Korean girls and boys wearing traditional dress and costume and having a great time taking photos. Great place for people watching.

While not as grand as the Forbidden City in Beijing, Gyeongbokgung makes up for it with fewer crowds, clean air, and a beautiful mountain backdrop. My friend and I enjoyed exploring the lesser populated nooks of the palace, as well as the lake surrounded pavilions. Make sure not to miss the changing of the guard at 2PM as it was rather spectacular, with guards dressed in old gear marching heroically along the gate to traditional pipe music. Very cool.

This palace from the Joseon Dynasty was awesome! The price of the ticket was reasonable ($10 US) and it also including the Korean folk museum, which was by far the best museum I went to in Korea! We waited for the English speaking tour at the front. I would highly recommend the free guided tour!! I wouldn't have enjoyed this place as much as I did without the tour guide. She gave some really good insight and background history that was compelling as you walking around the grounds and visited the different areas of the palace grounds. The guided tour is about an hour or so. We also visited the museum which was included in the price. Go there as well. It was awesome!! It has some spectacular displays with life size depictions of Korean traditional ways of life and past history. It also had a Korean food history area as well which was fascinating too. Overall, I am very happy we went to Gyeongbokgung Palace! A highlight of our trip.
Great couple of hours, some good photo opportunities especially the guards on the gates. Close to main centre of town

If you're a fan of sageuk (Korean historical drama), make it a point to visit Gyeongbokgung palace. For just 3000 won for adults and 1500 won for kids, you get to know more about Korean history and bask in the majesty of the palace and the various halls around it.

The view of the mountain at the back of the palace is just stunning. The Gyeongbokgung palace is three minutes walk from the subway station. I spent my two hours going around the palace. They have started the changing of guards by 11am. I walker around the area instead of just seeing the palace itself. Lovely view! there is a museum on the same area which has a free entrance. It's definitely worth a visit!

Of you want to feel like a movie star, wear a hanbok, go to the palace. The traditional dress is beautiful. When my friends and I arrived we were bombarded with requests to take photos with people. It was surreal. The palace itself is beautiful. Lots of information is available about the historical significance of Gyungbukgoong in the Korean capital
Crowded with tourists. There's ticket charge but we were lucky enough because we payed a visit on the day which is not charging for the ticket. I got to see so many pretty korean girls with hanbok.
We spent about 2 hours exploring the grounds. It's a sprawling palace, so go with good walking shoes.

Its a must visit, cos its very much part of Korean history. Location is perfect, near US embassy and busy intersection. Free English tour and you can sit in the park and relax if you must. My son who was an exchange student there took me around, so I knew not to expect much out of this 'palace'. Click a picture with the guards outside if you like and the big statues of the King on the pavilion outside
been here 3 times. each time i came back to visit i still got blown away. i love the architecture, the landscape, everything. would be nice to be come during spring or autumn!

I went on a tour of Gyeongbokgung Palace and it was amazing! I learned about the architecture and culture of Korea while learning about the history of the country. The palace is beautiful and offers a wonderful step back into history while one is completely surrounded by modern buildings.

Make sure you join the 11am free english tour. Very informative and the best part it is free. Get to connect this with the gwahamun square, king sejong statute, admiral yi and the folk arts museum tour which are all interconnected.

If you have a few hours to admire nature and old buildings, do visit the Gyeongbokgung Palace. Be ready to walk though because the place is huge! You may want to come early to witness the changing of the guards at palace grounds at 10am and also play dress up with traditional royal guard costumes.

Hi. I was at this site on October 22, 2015. It's an amazing place which records the history of an important period of Korea history. The empire history. There are a lot of wonderful buildings with its old art and very special coloring and painting. Specially the throne Hal and the Emperor Hal and rooms. Also there are many statues and gargoyles. And many girls wearing the traditional clothes.
Great place to wander around. Lots of great people watching. Easy to get too. Well maintained facilities. Beautiful place to take pictures.
The place is amazing, what happened in the past wasn't so amazing, but the whole building itself is amazing.
This is one of several fantastic palaces around South Korea. It has been well maintained and is beautiful!

Gyeongbok Palace is a historical palace that been used for King in the past time. This palace is very big and consist so many building. Here we can see the Place for held a party, meeting, room for King & Queen and also rooms for King's Concubine. Here we can see so many important building.
One of the 4 Seoul palaces. Absolutely stunning. Located at the end of the big boulevard running from the city hall. Huge place, many buildings, all beautiful.
A place that must be visited in Seoul. You can sense the historical values as you walk in to this palace. Well preserved and interesting historical architecture.

If you wanna get nice pics of you and your friends in Seoul, this is one place to go. Make sure you go there on a good bright day, to get Instagram-worthy shots.  There are always kids wearing traditional garbs, and they'd be more than happy to take pictures with you, which is nice.  There is a big famous square right in front of the palace get, and you can continue the photo sessions there.
The photos speak for themselves. It was an enjoyable experience. A must see for those interested in Korean traditions, history and culture.

Seoul has the most amazing temples. This one was my favourite it was set out with a lake front with its reflection glittering off the surface. The architectural design of the temple was amazing with such detail put into each area of the temples it was truly outstanding.

Entrance fee was 3000 Won for adult, I somehow get a black and white guide book at the admission counter at 500 Won, don't do it, by you can get a briefer colorful version inside the second gate. Also there is a National Palace Museum of Korea which you can enter from the palace. If you want to go inside the museum, and walk around the palace a bit more, make sure you get back into the palace before 16:30 hrs. Otherwise, they won't let you get back into the palace again. The palace close at 17:00 hrs.

I loved all the palaces in Seoul, but this one absolutely exceeded all expectations. Well preserved and stunning architecture - colorful buildings with many interesting details. Beautiful gardens. Need few hours for a visit.

Easily accessible attraction. Short walk from Gyeongbokgung station. There are many photo opportunities in the palace. Move further in there is another Korea Folk Village inside Gyeongbokgung Palace, free admission. I find the Korea Folk Village better than Gyeongbokgung.  There are also free costume rental (5 mins) for you to wear and take photo near the Gyeongbokgung entrance. Limited pax for each time slot.  Do stay for the guard changing ceremony. There are also free guided tour in the palace. Please check their website for more details.

We did the Secret Garden tour which was quite funny ("you have 3 minutes until we move on"!) and pretty interesting. The gardens were covered in a light dusting of snow as we were there in January and the stream was frozen, it was very pretty

Maybe it was the fact that this was a somewhat spontaneous visit without detailed planning and we happened to hit it at the perfect time that the changing of the guard was starting, which was exactly when we arrived. Maybe it was that the weather was bright, sunny and perfect. I think it was more than that. This place felt magical. There was a peaceful presence that can't be explained but we both very much enjoyed it. I found the free English speaking tour also enjoyable and informative helping to bring me up to speed on the Joseon Dynasty. If I had one complaint, it was that the English speaking tour guide had a quiet voice and the sound system didn't help her much. The site is beautiful and historic and not to be missed in Seoul.

It was the first day of the korean new year, hundreds of people flowing out of the underground to the palace- because it is free. The palace suituated right at the stop .There was a traditional dance going on, music with drums and a simple dance with people in hanbok. Then go into the musemun for a walk, it is well organised and worth a look.Insadong is situtated not far away so spent sometime there as well.

This palace basically composes of many temples, pagodas and more standing on sand. It just looks like an abandoned desert. They don't let you go into the palaces, so there's not much to see from the outside. The similar characteristics of different palaces and the lack of background information makes it a tourist site that is not recommended. Remember to follow a guided tour to have a better understanding of the functions of different structures. Or else you will find your visit boring and meaningless.

A beautiful main palace in Seoul. Several attractive shows are : the changing of Guard, the children museum (One of shooting location of Daehan Minguk Manse when they visit palace and Minguk get annoyed by the Train driver :D). The area is huge, so it's better to spare around 2 hours,especially if you bring many friends. The buildings're typical,but pretty. Not forget to mention the small lake located inside.
Very large grounds with various out buildings. Seoul is such a modern city that there is very little that is "old" so it is a nice change of pace.

The palace itself was quite large with many separate sub-palaces. There was not many things to see within each small palace. However, the architecture was quite nice and great setting for photo taking if that is what you are into. There is a huge garden behind the palace. However, we could not afford the time to cover that.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is truly an amazing place. Once you get there, you will definitely picture out in your mind the setting of the King's feast, gatherings, important events and various historic activities that happened hundred years ago. It is such a wonderful and well-preserved tourist spot in Seoul. Though hundreds of people visit the place everyday, the people of Seoul makes a great job keeping the place clean and tourists friendly.

One of the main palaces in Seoul that every tourist should visit. The Changing of Guards, the Main palace and the grounds are a must see. You should wear thou a comfy pair of shoes since the area is wide. Great photos of the place are unlimited. Not recommended on small kids since they may not enjoy the whole experience.
We went to the Palace and the secret garden. It snowed for a short time and it was magical.The tour guide was excellent and we had an amazing time.

A beautiful structure that has been well-preserved and highlights the beauty of the ancient Korean dynasty that shaped the modern society to where it is today. Fascinating folk museum is right beside this palace and it is in reach of Insa-dong (the shopping area), restaurants and other interesting places, too.

I have been living in Korea for a few years now and am not particulary impressed with a lot of the temples in Korea. Most are not original and the result of mass reproduction. However, if you're going to see any temples, i'd suggest this one. Its one of the largest, with beautiful grounds, particularly in the sping and summer . The ticket prices are also very cheap to enter.
A place that you can find traditional korean culture. Hanbok wearing is fee of charge to get in.

Came here during the lunar new year. Entrance fee is free as its a holiday. So maybe if you do not want to pay for he entrance fees then go during holidays time. However no guided tour is conducted. Think it's because of the holidays, there is also stalls set up for both adults and children to make craft, eatery, writing wishes. Went to children's museum- if families travelling with children, it's another place can go and experience some of their games and play.
It was my first time in Korea, I love everything I've seen. Hopefully, I will have a chance to be there again.
Awesome place to go! You can see historic palaces and watch the changing of the guards. You can even rent a hanbok here and imagine you are apart of the history there.

The palace is so big and full of traditionally scenic paintings in its walls, attic, and rooms. From the tour guide, we could hear explanation regarding the reign and fall of the dynasty. We also could understand on how the relationship of the royal family and their warrior as well as their workers. On the palace yards we also could see digital brief explanation on the development of Korean people from the early stages in a museum, and we also could try playing traditional children game i.e. Circling a Top with skin-band, running a thin wheel with its steel guider, pointing steel-head wooden arrow to small steel basket, a swing, see-saw as well as playing a 'Katepok' (shuttle cock like game) with our ankle. This is great to reminding our children of the old fashioned game apparatus. The most interesting is the Palace provide us with traditional Royal Hanbok clothes for taking picture as a King and Queen of the day. We could also see how the traditional meals are cooked and served on the digital explanation in the Culinary museum nearby the Children museum in the Palace yard. By taking boxes of certain kind of meals from the cupboard, screening the barcode on the media, and we could see the meals prepared, cooked and served on the screen in front of us.
It is an outdoor experience so I wouldn't recommend it to families with young kids. It is still amazing to find out about how the history was built in Kore.
Nice to wander around and to check that box. The changing of the guard is the most interesting part.

We arrived here a few minutes before 1 p.m. and were lucky to be in time for a FREE English speaking guided tour with the low price of paid admission. Allow at least 1 hour and wear comfortable shoes. HIGHLIGHT was all the other visitors from other Asian countries who wore special clothing gowned clothing to their tour and we took photos with all of them
Just a short walk from the Gyeongbokgung subway stop on the #3 line. Take exit door 5. You can spend a day touring the palace grounds and enjoying the museum. Seniors can enter without paying a fee.

My friends and I have this in our itinerary and I'm glad we did it. This Palace is so huge that I suggest that you should wear the most comfortable walking shoes you have! The entrance fee for the Palace is 3000 won and there is an additional fee for the secret garden. There's also a coffee shop in the middle of the Palace where you can rest and drink some tea. They also sells some souvenirs.
I whish come here once a time 'cause I love historical places and because of that I love Korea and living there.
If you have a chance to visit this palace, or I think you must visit while you are in Seoul. Guardian Exchange ceremony and Wearing Korean tradional costume are good to have experience.
This is a pretty impressive palace even if it has been reconstructed after centuries of destruction. Great layout and reconstruction but it gets extremely busy so go early

You can spend hours here, walking around, lapping up the grounds and buildings. It is really mesmerising to be immersed into the past, with huge skyscrapers towering over one side of the grounds, and mountains at the other.  There are English speaking tours available at certain points of the day, and you can also watch the changing of the guard, which is pretty cool.  The only reason I gave 4/5 is because if, like me, you have seen many temples in Korea, they all begin to look the same ha! This is definitely one of the very best to visit though - a must see for anyone exploring Seoul!

The area is big. But most of the building is closed. So much to see, only outside of the building. The only building we could see inside is the Throne, but the dragon on the ceiling is nice. There is a museum inside which has a nice display.

As I was born and raised in Seoul for 22 years, I can't be more proud of this beautiful palace of my city. I can surely recommend this place for who you are, where you from, and what you're looking for.

nice palace, to visit, you can see amazing korean architect. at the gate there are dressed up Guards- try to catch the changing of the Guards. there is also small village at the end of the place to see the tradition life of ancient korea
The palace provides visitors with a strong flavour of Korean history and culture. Let the guides take you on an extraordinary history lesson.

Our family really enjoyed the visit to the palace. Glad we joined the free volunteer guided tour which helped us learnt more about the palace, than just touring the surrounding. The palace is really huge, from outer court, to inner court, to every little corner of the palace, it tells us so much about how the royal family lived in the olden days. The tour guide was very patient and explained in great details of how the emperors lived, how the palace was managed, and how the princes/ princesses were brought up outside palace. We learnt a lot through this visit, and fell in love with Korean culture even more :) A must visit place, for someone who loves history - like me :)
Had a really good time here. Do wait and stay for the change of guard parade. Tradiotional korean costumes and drums.

We love to see the palace especially since we watched Korean dramas a lot. The admission fee was not expensive too and we really enjoyed ourselves there to see the rooms, structure, and architecture of the palace.  Awesome place for tourist!
This place would look eerie and sad during winter. I've seen photos of this temple during spring and it was beautiful! I would prolly go back some other time when the flowers and trees are in bloom!
Definitely a must go to if you are a traveler visiting Seoul. Not too much to do though- you just walk around and look at the buildings and cant go inside them.

A large and beautiful palace complex in the heart of the historic district of Seoul. To make the most of the visit you must take your take to absorb the beautity of the place and understand its history. Large enough to spend several hours and be sure to catch the changing of the guards as well!
We came at a very untimely visit. Temp is at -18. Can't feel my hands and my face. But the cafe located near the palace is great. Great souvenir items. You can buy a book if you're a bookworm.

I visited this palace several times during my stay in Seoul actually but in August I had my favorite experience with an exclusive night visit! The park and main buildings are the most beautiful in my opinion and its location makes it the center palace even if Changdeokgung is supposed to be the biggest and most important one. I especially love the building surrounded by a lake next to the main one and in the park behind, the little tea house is just too cute for words. I totally recommend going there at night if you can catch the special events they're doing for this opportunity and coming at different season as well.

We visited on one of the free airport tours. We had a great guide who gave us some great information, but we were a bit exhausted to take it all in. I did enjoy the beautiful buildings (especially the colourful roofs), and the peaceful grounds. Definitely recommend a visit.

I went here because it was #1 on TripAdvisor's list for Seoul. I managed to arrive just as an English language tour was starting.  The guide was knowledgeable and pleasant but she didn't really encourage questions. Of course it was cold and windy outside so that may have affected everyone.  The tour and the overall exhibit are all outside so the weather on a particular day may affect your appreciation.  I felt that I learned a lot of Korean history, especially the story of the invention of the Korean alphabet. Well done!

This place is for those seeking peace and serenity yet has a knack for Culture and History. Magnificent structure, no longer 100% original yet eloquently restored. It speaks a lot of the Korean ancestries' creativity and style. Learned a piece of their history even for a short span of time. Didn't know even the pavements speaks how they protect their royals.
If you are in Korea on vacation, you should definitely visit Gyeongbok Palace. Even if you live in Korea it is a great place to visit in the spring and fall.

I went on the Seoul Historic Tour through Koridoor tours on the weekend. I was going to like traditional Korean places, so it was so much fun.  First, I went to the Jogyesa Buddhist temple, and I could understand of Korean Buddhism. There were also a bunch of great flower-decorations It was nice to see the temple in South Korea, and then we went to gyeong bok palace. Tour guide was explaining to us about Korea Choseon dynasty which was so impressed.  We went to national folklore museum and then we went to the blue house and sa-rang chae.  It was exciting to see all the presidents from the very first and currently one.  I would love to go there again, when my friends visit to Korea next time.  Thanks Koridoor Tours!!!!

Thsi is a great place to learn about korean history if you didnt know.  There is a english tour around the premises for tourists and the tour guide speaks good level amount of english  its quite big but also you can go up close to some palaces and look inside- very interesting! i recommend visits! :)
You must visit. Strongly Recommend. Beautiful sight and palace. No need to explain. Only 3$ closed every tuesday

I'm kind of a nerd for this stuff, but I really enjoyed touring the palace and watching the attendants reenact the guard changes and things. It's easily accessible through the metro, so if you're being a tourist in the city you have no excuse! But really... why would you want to miss this magnificent place for free anyways? The courtyard costs nothing to enter, and that's where the aforementioned reenactment occurred. Next to the palace is also the National Folk Museum of Korea (With FREE entry [which I separately reviewed]), which adds a little depth in exploring the history of this rich culture!

If you can explore it for the day, try, its a lot of rooms. I have gone to China to see palaces, but this one had so many functioning rooms. We laughed as we walked recalling the Korean Dramas and we understood what "living outside the palace" meant. tons of rooms, different levels.. and adorable
A must visit place in Seoul! Amazing architecture and nice walk in the palace! Enjoy the dynasty feel and historic building.

Wintertime is probably not the best time to visit but if it is your only option this palace is recommended. I thought this was the loveliest palace in Seoul. Due to limited time and it being a very cold day we only saw a small portion of the palace grounds. It is recommended that you bring cash to pay for the entrance fees as the credit card machine was not working the day we visited. We visited on New Years Day and there were many visitors. After visiting this palace walk south to visit Gwanghwamun square.

The palace grounds were a sight to see. If ever in Seoul I think it's a must. In a city that is full of innovation it's good to see where all can from. The grounds are vast and you are able to roam freely. The structures and mountains in the distance are ideal for pictures. And anyone of any age would enjoy this visit.

This was my first time to visit Korea, especially its capital city, Seoul. I wanted to explore by myself, but I didn't know where to start. So I looked it up and found good tour called 'Seoul Historic Sights Tour' provided by Koridoor. It was a small group tour with a group of 5. During the tour I have learned a bit of Korean History and the current Korea. Tour included one of buddist temples and the main palace then Blue house. It was great. Thanks to nice tour guide from Koridoor, I spent my time efficiently in seoul.
Highly recommend visiting this stunning palace. Spend hours walking through the living quarters and palace grounds. The changing of the guard is also a must see.

Both of the times I have visited Gyeongbokgung Palace, the guided tours have been wonderful. The tour guides are funny and very well informed, and the traditional outfits they wear are beautiful. The guards out front keep a straight face even when you're taking pictures, and they look great. The palace itself is beautiful, and definitely worth the visit! Definitely wear sunscreen if you visit on a sunny day though!

Gyeongbokgung is a huge palace in Seoul. Do cater for more time time to explore the palace. Join in the complementary tour to gain more insights into the various parts of the palace. Join in a tour of the secret garden in this palace, spaces are limited for this secret garden tours daily.
I love the Changing Guard Ceremony. Very lovely place and tour guides really hard to provide best services. Love it!!

A guided tour early in your visit to Seoul gives a basis and understanding of the history and culture of this proud nation. Easy to access and to move around, I appreciated the explanations of features I was given.

I joined the trip and english tour guide accompanied myself during the trip. From her explanation, i can learn many things about korean histories. They are also on the way to renew and rebuild the building,since some of them destroyed several times based on the history. It is a must have place if you visit seoul.
Loved this place. Beautiful palace. Watch the changing of the guards at 10am if you can. Can easily spend a few hours here. Very peaceful.

Visited this palace just two days ago and had a great experience. When I arrived, I was not allowed inside and quickly realized that I had gotten there just in time for the changing of the guards. It was a great site to see. I wish I had done the tour, but was satisfied that my admission allowed me inside the National Folk Museum.

I joined the Seoul Historic Sites Tour on yesterday, 20, Nov. It was so great time for me to learn about interesting history about Seoul. We went to Jogyesa Buddhist Temple and our tour guide, Haley explained about many concepts about Buddism and the palce as well. Visitng Gyeongbok Palce is one of the best moments for yesterday. Haley explained really well about Korean, especially Seoul histories, legends and even scret stories of each builidings and many things around there. Also, I felt like being in Chosun Dynasty when i was seeing the Royal guard change ceremony. The palaces and whole palace area looked sooooo beautiful it almost looked like a huge beautiful garden in the middle of this big city. So, this tour made my day yesterday and i want to join another tours which i could learn more about Korean culture and history.

There are a number of palaces in Korea, but this is the best of the best. It is the largest and is beautiful. They offer a daily changing of the guard show right inside the gate (free), but there are a lot of great photo ops and it is a wonderfully quiet place to enjoy, away from the noise of Seoul.
You just have to come here. It's one of the most picturesque places I have ever been in... Try to come early to avoid the crowds

Unfortunately most of this palace was destroyed so it's been rebuilt within the last 100 years. Although it's not 'original' it's very interesting and picturesque. We visited in the afternoon and got some amazing pictures at dusk. It's quite spread out so plan to be there for a few hours. There's a free walking tour in various languages at different times, I highly recommend it!! We arrived part way through the changing of the guard which was a bit of a bummer as its really theatrical. If you go look up the times and don't miss it.

The grounds and buildings are very well maintained - especially the gardens and detail paint work on the buildings, making you feel like your stepping back in time. The changing of the guards is a must see ceremony with the traditional uniforms that the guards are wearing.
For history lovers, this place is perfect for you. So many beautiful palace and its scenery. This place is so big, be sure to have a lot time to walk around this area.
Beautiful palace in Northern Seoul. Don't miss the daily changing of the guards ceremony. Entrance to the adjacent folk museum is also free and worth a visit
Gyeongbokgung place is the best attraction for first time visit. It is located in the center of Seoul. Convenience transport and cheap admission fee.
You much visit all palaces in Seoul. Palaces are must watch. The structure and the piece of art is something that you will admire. It is very peaceful place.

Once you've visit Seoul. Do not forget to visit this palace. It's the best. There are some more interesting inside too, eg. National Palace Museum, Korea National Folk Museum, Korea National Children Museum.

Very touristy yes but since this palace was like in the middle of city, it's kind if stepping back to old time. The must seen was the changing guard scene. The palace quite big spend like 2-3 hours there's a lot things to be seen if u into the culture type if not about 1 hour should be enough.

Even in the freezing winter days, this palace is still a worty place to visit. Quite a big ground to cover, its interesting to see inside the museum and when you re lucky enough they will open some of the palace doors to let you see whats inside. Its not much, but still interesting.

Though this palace is worth visiting, I need to remind anyone who wanted to visit the sight should really wear enough clothes. The palace is not surround by any tall buildings so is cold inside.  As for the free tour guide provided by the palace is good. One should go there if interested in Korean culture.  Most important the guards exchange ceremony is something you dont want to miss. If you dont have enough time to enter the palace, do drop by to the exit of the palace and watch the ceremony. Is really traditional!
Very large and well-maintained complex with multiple living areas, temples and garden areas. Worth visiting if only for the lovely large lake and wooded areas !
I love the changing of guards, I'm curious if they put make-up in their face and if their beards were true. And one thing, the guards and the police in Seoul are cute, do you agree with me guys?
If you have free time in Soul you can visit for one hour ..but you should be careful about the weather

The palace devided into many parts. You can start from the main gate or from another entrance. The pavillion and all royal resident are really nice. You can walk arround and relax at some corridor. You can explore the palace within 2 hours or more.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is just amazing and was the definite highlight of our trip. There is a free English tour and our tour guide was really lovely and she talked us through the history of the palace and kept our group of around twenty people interested.
Try to read up a bit before going there because most of the information board/sign was shown in Korean. Overall, worth a try ! 3000 KRW entrance fee for Adult.

I've seen a lot of palaces in my life. This one is nice, nothing special about it. Of course that doesn't mean it's not nice...  The buildings are very nice to look at and you can imagine the work needed to carve and paint it.

a lot of stories happened in this palace, i did the search for my luck , the place needs a Guide , you pay for the entrance also and remember doing the tour in the Palaces in SEOUL, take your Hat with you to kill the sun

Some will tell say that there are other Joseon palaces in Seoul that are prettier than Gyengbukgong, but it is the biggest, grandest, and the archetype fr all others. The grounds with the various buildings are enormous, and we find new nooks and crannies every time we go. Make sure you leave time to visit the palace museum and folk art museum adjacent to the palce grounds.
Be prepared to walk for miles. This place is huge and beautiful. Lots of history in this place. You just have to be patient since they are spread apart. It is like a small city in a city.

It is interesting to see some of the palace building structure was built small and short older days and the interior was very detailed and colorful. The area is huge and do have your lunch before you go as you may need at least 2 hours to cover the whole area.  Do ask the taxi to stop you at the main entrance not the side entrance to save time. There are a few modern buildings near the main gate to explore.

Definitely worthwhile to spend an hour or two visiting and take a break from all that shopping. You should try to sync your visiting time to catch the guards changing performance and follow through with a free guided tour of the palace.
The Gyeongbokgung Palace was so beautiful. My family and I were lucky to be able to visit the palace in the autumn. All the autumn leaves added even more beauty to the scenery.
I really loved the palace! The museum was really great. The show in the front courtyard of Palace was cool! Totally recommend. Very educational and tons of history.

It is an eye opening to see the former Palace for the Joseon dynasty ruler. Though there are not many things to see within the inside those palace buildings, at least we can appreciate how the Korean wanted to preserve part of their heritage . The present day Gyeongbokgung had been rebuilt due to fires during the Imjin Waeran Japanese invasion 1592 -1598 and systematic destruction by the Japanese colonial govt from 1910 to 1945.

We got to the palace just as they began the changing of the guards ceremony. If you have the chance to see that, it's worth a wait. Behind the walls there are a lot of buildings, many of which are similar in design/structure -takes a while to walk around but I enjoyed seeing the traditional Korean buildings set against a beautiful mountainous backdrop on one side and the city skyline of Seoul on the other.

Whether it's your first trip to Seoul or you've been several but have never fit a trip to Gyeongbokgung Palace you have to visit. If you've been but never during the night, go again. The night views are the things postcards are made of. See the shows - we saw a drum exhibition. Excellent!!

There aren't many historical sights in Seoul honestly, but this is the main palace and one worth seeing. The guards staring straight ahead is a cool sight to see, and especially when the guard come out and do their routine. Cheap admission fee and a lot of space to walk around through. Go experience!

This is an excellent place to visit for a good outdoor walk while taking in the sights of the beautiful palace. We loved all its colors and the views of the buildings with the hills in the background. It's only 3000 won per person, including the folk museum, so it's absolutely worth it!

Taking a metro would be the best way to reach Gyeongbokgung Palace, although I had some difficulty checking the right metro , & language is one of the obstacle. But I had a good time watching the parade, & drum performance - it's worth to spend 2-3 hours getting around . It's huge so take your time to take pictures of the Palace & surroundings. Bring some snacks or fast food. I enjoy visiting the Palace.
Fee apply. If you happen to visit, do spend more time here. The place is BIG that require a lot of walking.

There are too few cultural offerings in Seoul. And that is a pity. This is a work in progress and one that should be visited when in Seoul. Guided visits are particularly instructive and educational. This is definitely a beautiful monument that marks the history of the country. Go see it.

Love these historic sites, but the Northern Palace is severely lacking in signage. I suppose this is to help promote their tours and guided visits, but as a visitor who likes to independently wander, this leaves me with a sense of "...huh?" Nonetheless, I love that it's not crowded, and also very inexpensive (3000 KRW only, or about $3 USD). The Folk Museum admission is also included. Note to self....Perhaps I should have opted in for the tour....
Our family enjoyed the beautiful palace. We went on a weekday so it wasn't so busy and to my amazement there's free wifi :) on the property
Stunning relic, beautifully preserved. If visiting in winter, wear rain-appropriate footwear. Allow more time to inspect the exhibits in the Folk Museum, which is situated inside the palace.
If you're interested to know more about traditional Korean culture and experience the 'feel' of the olden Korean times then this is definitely worth a visit.
Nice day out to walk around the palace grounds. I find the explanation a bit lacking. If you did not have a guide, you would not be able to appreciate as much of the history
Very huge palace, so prepare yourself for the next 2.5 hours to go around the palace. Beautiful, and I love the attraction they have for changing guard.

We were late after a long walk from the bus station and could only see the last minute of the changing of guards. Already worn out, we only took some pictures with the guards standing there and walked in a little to get the feel. A place worth to explore more and we shall come again on our next trip to Korea.
do visit for a glimpse of korean palace history. I enjoyed the hour long palace guided tour tremendously. do check for the various timings available.
The palace is so full of history and the Korean culture is so interesting. I spent half of day capturing it through my camera lens and could have spent another day.

The entrance fee is just $3000 Won. Very big had a few toilet which was very convenience for such a big palace. We meet two Korea ladies who also came to take photo in their nice Korea clothing, they are very friendly and we also took some photo with them. We have a fruitful outing to the palace.
They offer free tours several times a day. One might have a little problem understanding the guides English pronnounciation. Otherwise, it is a beautifull palace.

The palace is old and as advised by the tour guide, many areas were destructed in wars and the remains were not as grand as before. The place is not too large and touring can be done in an hour or so. However as the most popular tourist spot in Seoul, seems a must go. Don't miss out the change of guard every hour near the front gate. You can also walk to the Blue House at the back of the palace which is now the president's office.
Beautiful palace. Make sure you you're there for the change of the guard, as it makes the whole thing more special. The National Folk Museum is inside and also worth a visit.

This is the main palace in Seoul. The grounds are vast and it contains multiple rows of buildings and walkways. You can spend several hours strolling through them and taking pictures. The mountains in the backdrop make it for a very picturesque scenery that allows the photographer to experiment with different angles and light. I truly enjoyed the experience, despite the bitter cold and lack of greenery in early December.
Not to be missed when you visit Seoul. We recommend that you do the free guided tour which is very useful to understand the historical background and the architecture.

When visiting the palace, you should definitely time your visit so that you will get to see the changing of the guards. It's on multiple times a day but you better check the current schedule for it. The location of the palace is great, as it's right in the heart of Seoul - easy to find if you can find the statue of Sejong the Great.  The whole area of Gyeongbokgung is huge and there's a lot of place to explore so go early and take your time. At the end of the palace grounds, there's also a museum that's definitely worth a visit. Insadong is within walking distance with it's shops and restaurants, so you can easily spend the entire day around this area.

Exquisite artwork stunning architecture and a great way to learn about Korean history. It's dead center so you can enjoy the historical aspects of Korea and then walk down street and find a really amazing restaurants
Check the timetable for the free guided tours. Although the scale of the palace is rather small, but definitely worth visiting for a quick korean history class.

The train station (line 3 - orange line, exit 5 Gyeongbokgung Station) leads you right to the palace grounds. It was so convenient. If you time your visit, you could witness the changing of the guards. Also, connected to this is the National Museum and outside the gates are the monuments of King Sejong and Admiral Sunshin Yi.

For a small fee you can enter the main complex and you may even catch the free english (or Chinese) tours. There is a the changing of the guard ceremony which occurs a few times a day.  The complex is large and you can easily spend hours wandering around.

We arrived at this palace around 3.00 p.m. We watched changing guard ceremony. We thought our kids will be bored to see that, but they loved it. The palace are so big. If you don't have time to look around, just visit the gate (gwanghwamun), geunjeongjeon, gyenhoeru, hwangwonjeong. There is national folk museum and national palace museum in this palace. You can reach the palace by using metro subway, stop at gyeongbokgung (line 3) exit 5.
The palace is soooooooo big and that we didn't finished it by 3 hours? Omg. Well, it's really a worth place to visit and I enjoyed a lot there especially inside the museum in the palace!
The visit is not free but I feel it's worth visiting. Always nice to know how the people in the past (rich or poor) lived and how they contributed to what we see today.
As a part of your tour to Seoul you have to go to visit the palace . I front of the palace there is an exhibition try to visit it is free of charge and open until 6 pm . The palace is closed at 5 pm

An incredible place that is so peaceful! Definitely a must see when in Seoul! This place is exactly what you think of when you think of Asia, beautiful palaces on a tranquil pond and if you're there during early spring during cherry blossom
Beautiful palace walk and nice photo shoot. This place is easily accessible by the metro, ask your hotel staff for directions.
My sister and I enjoyed visiting the palace. We took a free English walking tour of the place and this helped us to learn about the history.
Not a place for kids for sure but those who love to take photograph, it provide vibrant colour and excellant architectural piece.

Went on a chilly December Saturday. Lots of people there but it's a big place. A volunteer tour guide met us at the subway station and walked with us, explaining in English what we were seeing. She was great, and only 14!  Chinese style palace, so you keep walking through more and more court yards, each dominated by a higher and more important building. Nice, natural setting with mountains in the background. Particular features are the roof decorations and the underfloor heating systems. Thanks to our young guide for pointing them out.  Look out for the pavilions that stand on ornamental ponds. Imagine yourself in the palace's heyday, enjoying the views and relaxation of these pleasure pavilions. Unfortunately, you need to imagine, as only the reconstructed buildings and the mountains are left.  Easy access from the subway station and a couple of museums nearby. Together they can fill most of a day.

This was our first tourist stop in Seoul. Many great photo opportunities and unless you read up ahead of time the guided tour worth it to explain the layout. We went early am to avoid crowds. As we left, the tour buses were beginning to pull up.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is centrally located near the heart of Seoul, is inexpensive, and is a wonderful example of the beautiful historical Korean architecture that epitomizes the ancient Silla Kingdom. A great place to stroll if the weather is good. Try to time your visit to include the changing of the guard.

It's a big palace complex make sure to wear your comfort shoe. Not a lot to say since I compare it with Tiannanmen in Beijing. The feeling more or less the same with slightly diffrent characters of building.

We going for winter vacation on december in Gyeobgbokgung palace korea, wheater 1 - 3 degree celcius. Bring your therma jacket along, hand glove , hat to avoid cold here. Their service is only to 5 PM then close

Well if you like walking around and looking at some nice Buddhist architecture, this is a cool place to go. It wasn't a huge thrill or anything so you have to be into the history and the meaning of the place if you want to get a kick out of it. For me it was a nice place to take pictures.
I was surprised to see that the palace was open for visitors at night. all the buildings were illuminated. I had a very good opportunity for very good night shots of this magnificent place.

It was a cold rainy day on my visit, so it kind of ruin my visit. The guide armed with an umbrella seemed oblivious we are getting wet and cold . So, we tried to keep up with her and wishing for shelter and hot coffee . The structure is beautiful but also sad that a lot of the buildings were destroyed before. ... do come , on a nice sunny day. There is a nice walnut pastry shop from gyeongbokgung stn exit 2 ...cocohodo....its absolutely delicious and you can walk down further to Tongin market for their famous dosirak lunch tray

It's Seoul's Northern Palace and subsequently also the largest palace in Seoul. There isn't much to say about the Palace other than that you need to go if you're traveling in Seoul. The grounds are huge and the buildings are beautiful. Yes, there are quite a lot of people, but that is to be expected. If you really really dislike crowds, I would suggest the Changgyeonggung Palace (just east of Gyeongbokgung) however this palace is not nearly as impressive.
An interesting place to visit, they said that in ancient times the square represents the earth while the circle represent the sky...

Gorgeous views all around at this palace. A lot of people were here, but the grounds are so large that they were spread out pretty well. We went in November so the trees were those wonderful fall colors and made for spectacular pictures. The admission is cheap (3000W) and the tours are free if you wanted to do that. One problem was that there aren't any signs around to explain to you what each building was. Therefore, we were going to do a tour, but as my boyfriend could read the Chinese above the doors, we didn't actually need to do it. The palace is right next to the Bukchon Hanok village, Samcheondong, and Insadong so we visited all of these places in one day. For those of you that count steps, you get a TON of walking doing this haha. So definitely wear comfortable shoes. All in all a really great tourist attraction. I recommend visiting in the Fall.

Guard ceremony at the entrance is definitely something to plan your trip around. The palace grounds are beautiful and we learned a lot about korean royal history. The audio guides are great.  There's a museum inside the palace, which takes around 45 to 60 minutes to walk through.  Highly recommended!!

Large grounds. Tough with a toddler in a stroller over some terrain but lovely buildings. Thought there might be more gardens etc but overall very picturesque and a must see. Audio guide worth doing. Wear comfortable closed in shoes. Can get muddy. Changing of the guard also good to see.

For those who are taking their first trip to Korea should really visit this place. Lots of history, lots of nice preserved architecture and you get to see what's it like back in the days because the staff would wear the traditional outfits as well a small ceremony performance.

This palace was beautiful! As there are so many palaces around in Seoul and we were pressed for time, we only managed to visit this one because we spent a longer time there than expected but no regrets! The grounds are massive and if you can spend the time, don't rush and walk around to discover the gardens and other smaller outbuildings. We spent some time in the Crown Prince's garden (towards the right when you just pass the main building) and it was just beautiful. You can even pack a lunch and have it on the benches under the pretty trees if you like (we saw some locals doing it).
A well maintained temple that offers a glimpse into the history of the country. A large spread out area with many buildings to see, so make sure you allow a decent amount of time to get around

The palace is huge!!! It has interesting architecture and beautiful garden. There are also various cultural and art performance, including the change of guard ceremony that is very delightful to watch.

This place is super cool. It's about $8 to visit. English yours are available and the culture museum is included in the price. The walk around the gardens and grounds is perfect for a warm sunny day. Make sure you stay and watch the changing of the guards and get a pic with one of them.

We visited in early December. It was cold enough that the ice was frozen over on the pond. We arrived just as the actors were coming out and putting on their show. There was no crowd so we got a great view. Walking through the facility was a joy and you can go just about anywhere in the facility. Parking was easy and it was relatively cheap. I don't remember what it cost, but it wasn't even a second though to pay.
This palace is really huge. The architecture is awesome. If you are lucky, you can see live changing guard ceremony. Only pay 3000₩ for entrance fee. Please wear something comfortable.

It's huge, so prepare the most of the day for taking the tours. Make sure to bring water with you. Bring a lot!! Read about the palace in advance so you can enjoy your visit. It's worth all the time and the tickets are cheap. Btw. Buy a group ticket for all the great palaces because it's a money saver. Also bring your Korean friends with you, they can enter for free if they're under 25, and accompany you even on English tours.

i don't know Korean language so i hope that when visiting a historic site, i would have english signs to read, but i don't foun many except name signs. you will have free map and a small guidance to look at, an if you have the patience you can open it, see where you are standing and read about it though. still, many buildings look ...just the same for me and i dont really get the sense of it. but the place is very broad and it were hard for me to do so when one hand is busy holding the umbrella and shopping bags .it was rainy and i found the walk quite exhausted. so i don't recommend shopping before going to the palace.
This is nice place to stroll even on rainy days. Make sure you either get guided tour or audio translation. You will learn history and behind story related to each sights.

We visited the palace when it was snowing. Although the guard changing parade was cancelled due to the snow, we were not disappointed. The snow transformed the palace and its ground to an amazing sight! We joined the English tour and it was very informative.
if you can get a local of hire a guide...would pobably help...my friends knew what was happening and the different buildings ...great day
This place next to the national folk museum of Korea. i didn't really enjoy this place because i came to this place at the end of november and already cold and windy.
great spot for photo opportunity. accessible by subway thru anguk station. i think the entrance fee is about 3,000 kwn per person. not too large but good enough for a brisk walk around.

DATE VISITED: November 18, 2014  PROS: Amazing place in the Heart of Seoul. Beautiful Palace. Wait for the Changing of the Guards at around 3:00/4:00pm. It's worth watching!  CONS: Too many people. Some tourists don't know how to follow order to discontinue from walking in and out of the site where Changing of the Guards took place. Geeez!  LOCATION: 5/5 PRICE: 5/5 HOSPITALITY: 4/5 ATTRACTIONS: 4/5

Elegant little palace in the heart of Seoul. Find tranquility from madness of Seoul in the quiet grounds of Gyeongbukgung Palace. Must remember though, Korea was never as big as China so it's no Forbidden Palace but beautiful and significant all the same.
A place definitely worth a visit if you are in Seoul. It is however a pity that you as a tourist are not allowed to enter any of the buildings.

The palace grounds are huge. Don't try and do this on your own. You need a guide to explain the layout and importance of the architecture and history.  Be warned - the steps can be high and tricky. Wear comfortable shoes and take it at your own pace. Visit the Korean Folk museum to get an overview of life. Also, there's another museum by the main gate that features some of the royal cars.  The changing of the guard is impressive. Don't expect the huge pageantry of Buckingham Palace. This is a much smaller ceremony worth viewing.  If you walk all the way to far back corner, beyond the lagoons, you get a great view of the current Presidential House. Be sure to keep your ticket with you.

Visited the palace in November and the autumn leaves were simply stunning. Also recommend catching the tour - it lasts about an hour and gives you an overview of the various buildings within the grounds.
Really nice place.. If you love the story of Korean Joseon dynasty, here is the must to visit in Seoul.. You can try Korean hanbook for free here..😁😁
This is one of may favorite places to visit in Seoul. It's beautiful and steeped in rich history. The guided tours in English are wonderful. I would definitely recommend going.
A stunning palace experience. It was pure joy, wandering around the grounds and looking into the buildings on the Gyeongbokgung grounds. A must visit for anyone in Seoul.

Close by to our hotel in Jongno-gu. We could have gone by subway or chosen to walk. As we arrived there was a changing of the guards. Make sure to have a photograph taken beside a guard. The inside of the palace grounds is enormous with an attractive lake like area at the rear. Be sure to allow an hour or two to wander around the surrounds. The entry fee is quite reasonable and you will find an appealing cafe/gift shop towards the centre of the grounds.

Had a friend guided us here which is wasn't far from our hotel in Myeongdong. It was a good walk and we just arrived in time for a guard change. We didn't make it around the whole place but it was great to look around a traditional area and landscape. It started to rain so it was cut short and could only spend an hour before close but I would like to visit again. Took some really nice photos.

This is well worth the effort to see while you are in Seoul South Korea. Make sure you go to the front and watch the changing of the guard. A few minutes before the changing of the guard they march in the side yard.
It's a lovely palace located in center of Seoul. To get there you can just use the seoul subway line 3 exit 5. The view is so amazing, and you can see the attraction also if you are lucky.

This is a majestic palace. It basically is the 'heart and soul' of Korea. There is a historical significance to the palace that makes you stop and think about the history that took place in the palace. It was a worthwile half day excursion and I do recommend going when it is nice weather - not too hot or cold.
If you like historical places, try this. A huge place and connected to the Folk Museum of Korea. Very interesting.

We had previously visited the Changdeokgung Palace and felt that this palace was pretty much the same only larger with far more tourists. My conclusion is if you have time for only one palace, go see Changdeokgung instead. It's only about a kilometer or so up the street. Anyway - we did enjoy the visit here and found some spots not completely mobbed by tourists. There were lots of teens in hanbok which leant an old world authenticity to the site.

Conveniently accessed by public transportation and close to a bunch of other attractions like Bukchon Village and Cheonggyecheon Stream, I would suggest to head out early to Bukchon Village, enter Gyeongbokgung Palace and head out to Cheonggyecheon Stream for the evening. The palace is beautiful but can be very full at times, but try to see as much of the buildings as possible, especially the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion and don't forget to see the re-enactments of Korean royal guards in the court yard.

This place were huge. Nothing much to see or do here. Empty buildings, dull ground. There are beautiful lake and small cafe. i went here in spring season . Weather kinda hot. This area will be hotter in summer because the surrounding are plain desert.

This is one of two main palace in Seoul but is more prominent. I would choose this location as it is closer to other sites such as samcheungdong and everything can be done in a day. There's a little confusion to where the entrance is as we were looking for the ticket counter. That is actually inside and there are many ways to get in from the front and southeast and southwest area.
Like the every bit of the view and the palace. What a technology and I liked the way solders shifted their timing.

It's worth to pay a visit here. Quite a big compound with scenic view and historical buildings. Get ready to spend 2-3 hours walking around. Remember to take along the brochure at the ticket counter if you were interested to know the history as there is no notice board that put aside for you to read. Do plan your visit to align with the guard changing ceremony. One thing disappointing is some of the buildings are closed for visit.

Visited on a rainy day so maybe that is part of the disappointment. Other than change of the guard did not see anything too exciting other than the main area. Very little offered in English so had difficulty understanding the context. I you have to choose one, go for the Changdeokgung Palace instead.

South Korea is very much famous of its heritage such that it will always be a good idea when visiting to this country to go to the palaces. Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the famous palaces in South Korea. The place is big and you can explore. It is good to go there in the morning. There is an entrance fee of 3000 KRW.

I love to see history and building structures and all.  However, I am slightly disappointed with Gyeongbokgung Palace as most of it places are close to public.  Noone is allowed to see what it is inside. So for me, it is a turn off.  This trip is more of like a trip to see building, lakes, and park, and nothing about the palace.

This was a palace in the era of Joseon Dynasty which is well maintained. There are two lakes with gazebos: Kyunghoilu and Hyangwonjeong. These two lakes are very beautiful. From time to time, this place is open to the public at night times and you should book at the designated dates if you want to see it. Especially, the night views of these two lakes are the most beautiful. Many photographers gather to take pictures of them.

The palace grounds was very huge but every check point is about the same.the king's chambers, the queen mother's chambers then the concubines' chambers. They all look the same. I was a bit disappointed to find out that almost the entire place is rebuilt, it's not the original palace but it was burnt down during the Japanese invasion. and they're not done adding on new segments of the palace. entrance fee is pretty cheap. the architecture seems pretty normal. probably the more interesting thing to do here is to try on the palace guard uniform for free and witness the guard changing ceremony. give this a miss if you are not into touristy stuff.

We enjoyed the buildings all around Seoul, but what was even better were the grounds of the palace (trees, lakes, etc.) - especially in mid-November as the leaves were all changing to incredible colors of red, yellow, orange. Endless incredible photo opportunities.

Was there in mid September, the weather was just nice for a morning stroll of the palace. Nicely replicated buildings n landscaped gardens filled with rich history. We joined a free guide tour when there. It was an informative tour indeed ... You get to learn not just the history but the clever olden days architecture design of the buildings catering to the different Seasons of the year, and the interesting culture of the palace.  Do go there in the mornings when there's lesser crowd. Do check out their Seoul tourism website on the timings of the free guided tour and the days which the palace is open at night for visits.  After visiting the palace, do pop over to Samcheong dong which is east of Gyeongbokung ... just a short distance from the palace. It's a little quaint Neighbourhood filled with little art galleries, shops, cafe, restaurant. Be prepared to do walk hard as it's road are straight but has many slopes.

I walked to Gyeongbokgung Palace early morning from my Lotte Hotel (Fantastic Hotel by the way, one of the nicest I've stayed in anywhere in the world for a reasonable price). During the week day in early morning in the October there was very few people inside the walls of the palace. Made for a great morning visit of solitude, learning history and photo opportunities. As the morning progressed the palace became more crowded with tourists and school tours. If you are in Seoul the Changdeokgung Palace is a must see.

Suggest to visit this Palace on the first few days of your trip and walk all the way towards the back where the pond is located. The palace is very well maintained. Looks very similar to other Asian Palaces. There is a train station entrance by the museum beside the palace too

While I was looking forward to this trip, I did not have any expectations whatsoever so as not to ruin the mood. This is the second palace I visited, and it lies just in front of two statues, one of the admiral and the other King Sejong, seated in a chair, and founder of the Korean alphabet. The ticket entrance was 5000 won, a bit hefty if you ask me. The tour started and I joined a tour with an English translator, kudos to the translator for really trying to explain the history and details of all the buildings.  The architecture and style can somewhat be likened to those found in Shanghai and Beijing, maybe because of cultural influences. I was a bit disappointed though because of the lack of English descriptions of each of the place. Signages are also scant in the area and be ready to endure long walks!  I suggest going here in the morning or early lunch time so that you can have time to visit the blue house which the guide said was one gate away only from inside this palace. Unfortunately, I didn't see the blue house.  In total, I find this palace, nothing special, an average if you ask me, but I commend the departments involved here for really making sure to preserve the edifices. So, in going to Seoul, choose wisely which among the palaces you'll be visiting. This one would not be in my list again.

Visitors should put this Seoul attraction on their list. For amateur photographers, it's provides a good opportunity to experiment and compose picture perfect shots. Take note of the schedule of the very colorful and ritual-driven Changing of the Guards as this is one activity that visitors to the attraction musn't miss.
This is a very huge complex of buildings, accessible from the Geongbokgung station. Ther is also a folk art museum and a palace museum inside.

It's a very big palace, you need at least an hour to walk inside and see whole area however it's beautiful especially during spring / autumn. It's better to visit in the afternoon so you can see the beautiful mountain view.

This palace was one of the most important during the Joseon Dinasty, from 1392 to 2010. This palace is well preserved and it is possible to see the role of the king over Korea Peninsula. On that time Korea was only one country It was not divided like nowadays. In front of the main entrance it is possible to see the change of the guard, two times a day. If you are in Seul, you must go there.

After all the 5 star reviews, I was anticipating a nice historical museum. However, there are few signs, no description, very little furnishings in any of the buildings. Perhaps six rooms were setup. It was hard to get an idea of what life was like. We got the audio guides but they were not that helpful because there were no artifacts to look at! Not at all comparable to theForbidden Palace which has extensive exhibits
Definitely worth a stroll - beautiful palace and all its buildings, the park in autumn is fabulous. The highlight are the palace guards and the change of guard ceremony.
The palace had recorded many dynasty of Korea. Rent the audio guide if you come by yourself. There is many gates into the palace and how its expended over dynasty. A must for history lover.

We got to Gyeongbokgung Palace on foot from Bukchon in mid afternoon and caught the changing of the guards which is one of the attractions. It was quite fascinating and impressive and worth the visit. We were unable to visit the entire palace.

Went here at the palace with my fiance and my sister November 2o15. It was the perfect time because it was autumn. We arrived at the palace before 1 PM. We waited for the changing of the guards ceremony to start. Watch the whole ceremony which was 15 minutes long approximately. I had fun watching the changing of the guards ceremony, i was looking forward to watching this.

This is 1 of the highlights in Seoul and is really worth a visit. The architecture is awesome and the palace itself is beautiful. Loads of great photo opportunities and if you are into culture and history it really is s must visit
Oustanding place to visit, the palace was pretty and very clean check many other places and was such a good nice trip

It very much reminded me of the Forbidden Palace setup in Beijing, but felt much more extensive. The fall colors on the trees were fabulous. It seems to be more beautifully landscaped in Seoul. It was big enough to feel you could get lost. We did not do a tour, but many people were and you would learn a lot more by taking a tour.
Come at time of change guard ceromony. Huge palace, good if you like history. come earlier to explore close at 5 pm

were here for leisure, 3 of us really enjoy the beautiful scenery, clean place. visited in early morning, this place open at 9 am. All tree change colour of leaf make it refreshing your eyes. Only rainy that stop us to enjoy more, also don't miss the guard palace parade. with those cute guard
This place is must visit when you are in Seoul. It gives you an insight of Joseon dynasty architecture. Once you are here then dont miss the changing of the guards at the main gate.

It is in central city of Seoul. And the palace is Main and First palace of Joseon Kingdom (1392 ~ 1910).  It is comparably new relic, instead Gyeongju city is from BC57 of Silla Kingdom (BC57 ~ AD935).  Anyway it has many merit to visit because it is inside Seoul, easy access.  :)

Located right outside Gyeongbokgung station, entry into the palace costs 3000 won. You can also exchange currency there. Architecture of it all is amazing. Don't forget to bring your camera or you will regret it ! :D

As much as I've enjoyed the forbidden city in Beijing, I had a good time exploring Gyeongbokgung Palace with my camera. historical architecture and beautiful garden walk which I often seen in Korean period drama! It was very very crowded when I was there.

You will love Korean history here and will start to watch Korean historic dramas afterwards. It is so big that you may ramble in its labyrinths for hours, it seems like desert even if there are many visitors. Don't miss the change of the guards: feel the rhythm of the drums.
Such a stunning place, visited late in the afternoon. Park closes at 5 sharp so give yourself plenty of time to venture around the grounds.

A lovely palace to see. Easy to walk around for all ages. It's inexpensive and if you keep your ticket the museum is free too. It was so beautiful on the day I went and the leaves were changing colors.

I went here on a Thursday which I think was good because it was not that many people there as I would expect it to be on a weekend. Very easy to get there by metro and the entrance is only 3000 won, a little less than 3USD. The park is really nice especially in autumn with a lot of different colors and a lot of space. Defiantly worth a visit. There is also a museum of Korean people and history connected to the palace where you get free entrance if you went to the palace. It was also good for those that doesn't know that much about the development of Korea and its people.

I went there during the national holiday when you can visit for free. Very good place to know more about korean culture. If you go to this place, don't lose the opportunity to visit the museum with the history of the country. To know the Gyeongbokgung Palace, walk around and go to the museum you have to spend few hours.
We didn't get to see much of the gyeongbok palace because our tour was in a rush. But they had an interesting architecture & heating system which was explained by our local guide.
The fall is the best time to visit this palace and Seoul. Do not except a fancy place cuz you will see a simple and quite buildings but it has the Korean style which you like👌
A sprawling area with beautiful gardens and trees. The change of gaurds takes place everyday at 11:00, 14:00
This is the best palace amongst all. If you have the time, then you should visit this. Quite nice but this cannot compare to the magnificent Forbidden Palace in Beijing.
Its the best time now ...autumn,cooling but not too cold. You can visit the museum n garden furst n option to enter the palace.

The Gyeongbokgung or imperial palace is a must visit for visitors to Seoul. The main entrance is impressive and visitors can see the parade of the royal guard behind the compound of the gate at fix time interval of the day. Inside the palace compound visitors can appreciate the beauty and majestic setting of the various sections of the palace. The throne chamber is very impressive and visitors can also get to see Korean in traditional dresses. A must stop itenary for any visitor to Seoul.

Very impressive and beautiful structures. Perfect place to walk around and enjoy the scenery for an hour or two. There are local high-school students - "volunteer guides" who will offer to walk you around for a small tip...it is fun but if you have an access to Wikipedia, you would learn more... I suggest against the museums there. They are underwhelming.

This is really a very beautiful place. The only drawback was that they were doing some major building in one area. Lovely autumn colors and a very easy place to navigate on your own. Also very close to some great museums.
I love the huge area of this palace. Love the structures of the buildings. Love the surroundings. Love the scenic views of the nature inside the palace area. This place is damn relaxing!
I just love Korean culture. Visiting this place is a reminiscent of the Korean royalty. It's just sad that they don't exist today :(
I had a great time here, I spent a couple of hours slowly taking in the atmosphere, beautiful buildings and fantastic autumn leaves.

This is one the tourist recommended site so we decided to give it a go. It is situated in quite a large area, we are not allowed into the building so we have to view it from openings that have been built for tourist I reckon. The man building which I supposed is where the King reside is beautiful, looks like the bernal building is handcrafted, with so fine detail and beautiful Colours. There are other buildings but we are not allowed in. With the autumn leaves falling and trees turning brown accompanied by cold weather, it was a pleasant trip. The highlight is probably the changing of the Guards, not as elaborate at the one in Buckingham palace but still pleasant to watch. Overall it's quite nice and I would recommend everyone a visit to the palace,
Spring - Summer - Fall - or Winter, in each season the palace will have its own beauty. If you should choose only a "gung" to visit, this is the one.

The Palace was great. We had a beautiful day to walk around the grounds and enjoy the scenery. When we were there, there was a lot of young girls wearing the traditional dresses. The hanbocks were beautiful with lots of bright and vibrant colors. Nice to see them.

We got lucky with our DIY tour to the G- Palace, as we arrived at the outside palace square we saw Koreans fully dressed in gala uniform only to find out that the changing of the guards was about to happen-3:00 pm. Wonderful ! So the best tip -- be there before 3 pm , long walk to toilets-- it's by the parking lot! The walk between Bukchum to the G Palace had a Redtaurant with the famous chicken with ginseng soup dish - must try at least once in a visit to Seoul. Add Salt &!pepper to taste :-)
Although it is rebuilt from the ruins the Japanese invasion left it is an impressive insight in the historic king's palace and with a 1 hour tour in english you get all the essential information.

We went as a family with an elderly using wheelchair. Firstly, the Palace is good to visit as it is rich in history and the changing of the guards is great to watch. The palace has a beautiful garden on the side and a beautiful lake too. The colors are just wonderful in Autumn. Toilets are available before you go into the palace and there are toilets in the palace too. There are cubicles with sitting toilets. However, I can't say that the palace grounds are exactly wheelchair friendly because the ground is sandy and certain parts are paved with very large slabs with huge edges and not convenient to push a wheelchair. We ended up pushing the wheelchair through the corridors and into the side gardens and lake. Plenty of places for good photo shots. There's really no need to join a tour. You'll manage visiting this place on your own.

It is free for seniors. It was bigger than what we expected with a lot of walking. We were rewarded with a colourful autumn foliage at the other end of the palace ground. The guard changing ceremony was also worth watching.

Went on a lovely sunny day first thing in the morning when the palace opened so it was quiet and pretty. The grounds are huge so lots of photo opportunities. The museum attached is free to enter and also worth a visit.

Its really large for visiting. U should spend at least half of day here. There are many beautiful sights in autumn. And the street around the palace is also nice, too. The ticket included 2 museums also.

This was a MUST SEE for us and should be for you, too.  VERY reasonable admission ticket...about $2.50US. They offer tours in English at 11AM each day they are open....closed Tuesdays. I would also assume they offer tours in other major languages during the day.  WEAR comfortable shoes/sneakers, as there is a lot of standing and walking involved. Some stairs, uneven places. Our guide was very good, a charm, really.  Magnificent buildings, colorful and well versed by our guide. Just walking around on your own might not give the same presentation...TAKE A FREE TOUR, if possible. Allow just over an hour if you take the free tour. Food shop is small but offers the basics and more...water, iced coffee, tea, GREAT ice cream, etc. Tables outside and inside. VERY, VERY reasonable. Then, on your same ticket, you can go right next door to the Folk Museum and see that. A very good deal.  Very memorable and again, a must see while in Seoul.
I love how we seemed to travel in time. We were early so we were able to enjoy the place to ourselves.  Free to the Public on Wednesdays.

Enjoyed it, not as much as the secret garden and other palaces or the shrine, but definitely the largest and most visited temple. Skipped the tour and walked around on my own. Not much to see except the very spartan buildings, all the area around has been cleared sort of, very little vegetation.
