unbelievable what has been built centuries ago, and is still in such a good shape. I believe there is a lot of energy spent on keeping it in good shape, but it makes you feel how it has felt in Korea in the 13th century

It is recommended to spend around 2 to 3 hours . There is a ceremony of changing guards around 10pm which take around 10 to 15 mins . Administration is quite cheap . But the building structure is almost the same , you will lose interests after 2 hours .

The wide courtyards and the architecture of the palace kinda gets you back to thinking how it was 700 years ago. Must have been very regal. What I loved most was the gardens at the back of the palace which were full of autumnal colours. You can easily spend 3-4 hours here and don't miss the food at the Gyeongbokgung café. It was my first Korean meal and the Tteokbokki and Veg Bibimbap was amazing!Not forgetting the Kimchi!

Gyeongbokgung palace was an absolutely stunning place to visit. We went on the last day of Chuseok so it was very busy with school groups and visitors for a festival.  It's very large but there's lots to see with several old buildings open to view and walk around. There isn't too much to say other than it was a truely breath taking place.
The Palace is a lovely place to spend an hour of 4 with nice buildings and a lovely Garden. On site is also the Korean Folk Museum.

If you're looking to learn a little more about Korea's history and enjoy some historic oriental architecture this is a great place to start.  The palace itself is within the city so it is a comfortable find (public transport will get you there easily). Within the palace there's plenty of space to relax - especially if you venture beyond the palace rooms and into the garden area.  Makes for some great photographs and a relaxing break.

This is the only Palace my husband and I visited in Seoul. It's a large complex so prepare to spend 2-3 hours to explore. Admission was free when we got there but rented audio guide cost 3000 won. There is free guided tour (English, Japanese, Chinese) starting at Heungnyemun Gate (2nd Gate), make sure to check the time if you planned to follow. We just missed it. My favourite spots are Hyangwonjeong Pavilion and Gyeonghoeru Pavilion.
We loved visiting this palace! Very well signed for an American tourist. Don't miss the opportunity to see how the ruling class lived.
Ancient place, we can see many historical palaces which is in every palace has a different story. They have a schedule to "changing guard" if you are lucky you can see that.

Visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace is definitely a must if you are in Seoul! Try to visit the palace when the change of guards is happenning, it will be an awesome experience. We also wanted to attend a free English guided tour, but since the group included 50+ people and the guide's voice couldn't be heard, we decided to discover the palace on our own. If you don't attend a tour, it's better to be prepared on what you will see and read descriptions, otherwise after some time the visit can be boring. For us it was a great experince!

Took the train to the stop just in front of the palace also named after the palace. Try to get there by 10 am as teher is a changing of guards parade which is quite fun to watch. you can also take pics with the traditionally garbed guards at the South main gate. Much like the Beefeaters, they cannot talk and will not move. make sure to line up and be orderly!  the palace was well preserved and there is much space to walk about and roam despite the tourist hordes that were everywhere. We went in all the way till we arrived at the back garden sanctuary which feature ponds, trees and small hillocks. this was a gem of a garden in the heart of Seoul and a great place to just sit down on the grass and imbue the tranquillity of the place. The looming hills just beyond the walls were a magnificent backdrop as is the pond to the east where there was a picturesque pagoda on the island in the centre. Many shutterbugs were capturing the beauty of the place. Do take the exit where the National Folk Museum is ..take the EAST gate and from there you can take a leisurely stroll past arty shops to Insadong where u can have a wonderful lunch in one of the traditional eating houses in the side lanes!

We got to watch the ceremony sharp at 3pm everyday. Actually they have 3 times everyday. In morning, 3pm and late evning if i'm not mistaken. The largest palace in Korea it is, with beautiful original hundred years of architecture! Not to forget, do try to don the guards' uniform for free! The place to try the uniform is near the front gate.

Nice palace with colourful guard to take picture. It was raining that day therefore did not take any photo. I prefer Cheongdeokgung.  However it's directly link to metro. Easy to find.  It's also near the museum where it's more informative.
We had a tour guide to show us apround but just going by yourself would be fine too. It was very busy with kindergarten kids everywhere but I think it would have been so busy other than that.

I love this place, you can caugth many things when you walking around the palace. A beautiful natural view, traditional culture touch, guards atraction, try guards costume, and feel like a part of kingdom. Really touching and i promise that i'll be back in autumn.

Nice place worth to visit and walk in Seoul, where one can familiarize himself with the Korean history and culture. It is good to know the schedule of guided tours before you go to visit. Usually the free guided tours in english are available two or three times per day, but you need to know the time. However, even without a guide you can easily understand the meaning of each dwelling by reading the information tablets. Also there are many nice places to take a photo.
Can easily be done in an hour. Only $3USD. Good photo opportunities. Not much history or displays or artifacts. The buildings look the same after you see a few but definitely Wow for a while.

After watching several historical dramas, the palace exceeded my expectations. It is larger and prettier than it appears in the dramas. Several areas were closed and we missed the guided tour, so we most likely didn't have an ideal experience.

This is a beautiful place and is a must-see during a visit to Seoul. It's interesting to watch the changing of the guards and the museum is also worth a visit. My mother and I were able to enjoy the place without a tour.

I only had time to glance into the palace by oh boy it was impressive as nothing I ever seen with the mountains in the background. There was a sense of grandeur and warmth that was unlike anything I ever saw and I didn't even really get to go inside to look properly. It's a must see in Seoul for a reason. I only gave it a four because I didn't have the time to go inside. But I urge you to make time and go see it. Booking a tour is probably a good idea too.

This is a must to see if you are in Seoul.Great to see some Korean heritage. This is a well maintained part of history and a very large palace area. You can get a voice tour which is operated by touching there guide map and it tells you all on the location. After the tour one can relax with a walk around the lovely gardens. It is a very serene and tranquil place in the heart of the hustle and bustle of Korea.  I would recommend to go early in the day as it is extremely popular with coach tours and school parties

My third time at the gyeong bok gung palace - always fun to visit and have a peaceful walk through the palaces. Takes about 1.5 - 2 hours to complete the walk from entrance to the exit. From the exit you can see and take photos of the Cheong Wadae (blue house).  I would also recommend Chang Deok Gung which is pretty scenic too.

This was the number one palace and the ground are large and used four times a day for the changing of the guard ceremony. We went to the 3pm, less people. Times change best to check. The museum outside is worth a visit, bit the exhibits have no English explanations.
High light of Seoul. Great to visit in a beautiful day. you can ask for tour course. Closed on Tuesday.

This is one of those place you have to visit while in Seoul to get a glimpse of days of yore. It can get packed with tour groups so quite difficult to get clean shots without photo bombers. Check out the changing of the guards and have your photos taken with them.
You get to observe the march & changing of guards at the main gate of the palace with a closeup photo allowed standing next to the guard
Went to Gyeongbokgung Palace on a cloudy day which made it not so good for photo shooting. Worth visiting if you want to know about Korean history.

This was a surprising start of our visit to Seoul. Free entrance due to some school holiday, excellent digital guiding system, impressive location ... Close to subway station with the same name, good café at the subway entrance.
Time it so you see the main changing of the guard, allow at least three hours to see all it has to offer
The palace was very big and luckily we went there when it was sunny, so it was a nice day out. Also there is museum inside the complex

Our group of 5 from Europe had our last day in Seoul and we got to the palace to see the grounds. The main palace closes very early at about 5:30pm. We got to the door at 5:30 which is the last ticketing time, and the man would not let us through. Our guests had never been to Korea before. The ticketing man and other man who guards the entrance were both so cold and without feeling. As a local, I led the group there and tried to explain in Korean, and was rebuffed so coldly. There's no ombuds service and no customer service in Korea to help improve this kind of poor service, which is too bad since people come with the expectation to be delighted by their experience here. This is one of the main palaces which most tourist try to see. There is a lovely queen's garden, and a good museum all in once place. The servants quarters is a little like a maze so fun to wander through.

Most probably the most famous palace in Seoul. And also the biggest. Large area, with a lot of beautiful, colourful buildings. Good to visit on Monday, when the other palaces are closed. Free guided tours are available, but you can enjoy it on your own, as well, especially if you have got a basic knowledge about Korean history. If not, read the panels all around the place. Check for evening visits, as well, for a more misterious scenery. Accesible by metro. Visit the museums inside.
Very interesting trip. enjoyed the tour. Invest in the audio unless you are on a tour with a guide. Was interesting to learn some of the history of Korea.

We went during Mid October 2015. Ticket prices 3000 Won per adult which at the time was equivalent of less than £2. Gyeongbokgung is very easy to get to by the MRT on line 3. It is closed on Tuesdays. Recommended time spent in this attraction: 1.5 - 3 hours.  Firstly, before entering the actual Palace, on the left side of the entrance, there is a free service where you can wear the costume/uniform of the ancient imperial soldiers and take pictures for five minutes. There are timed slots where you can queue up and I think they allow up to 10 people per hour to borrow these costumes to take pictures. I didn't note down the times, but it was something like 11:15, 12:10, 13:15 etc till closing. I highly recommend this as it really adds to the overall experience.  At the entrance you will see guards in the ancient soldiers uniform standing guard and patrolling (much like the Queens guards in London) You can take pictures with them (but not if you are wearing the borrowed uniform - it is forbidden, we saw a girl get told off for doing this).  Inside the palace, though it's not as big or as grand as the Forbidden City in Beijing, houses the ancient architecture with the big halls for the Emperor, his Queens and officers which are beautiful and inspiring. The stone sculptures on the stairs and the roofs look amazing and the artwork inside the halls are exquisite. I definitely recommend a visit to Gyeongbokgung for anyone passing through Seoul, if not for the history then at least for the art that is the palace itself.

The palaces are beautiful, but this one is the largest, and is just amazingly beautiful. There is so much to see and the pagoda in the pond I spent hours looking at it. I went here twice, each time I found inner peace. Cheesy yes but true.
You should visit this great ancient Palace. It's located in Seoul and it's very easy to get there. Subway Gyeongbokgung Exit 5.

Very easy to find. We went to a weekend and there were still no queues to speak of and it was not very busy. The palace is so large that you can easily find a space were there are no other people, which makes it feel like a real escape from the city. It is also very interesting and beautiful. I have been to many similar places but because of the size, setting and few clouds I would say this is definitely one of the best, well worth a visit.

Korean traditional palace, flowers and trees are very beautiful in autumn.  Historical palace in the historical district within Seoul City  Catch the changing of the guard ceremonies!  Inexpensive admission fee of 3,000 won  Free English tours are apparently at 11am, 1:30pm and 3:30pm.  World heritage site by UNESCO
gyeongbokgung palace is absolutely beautiful. its a must visit if you are going to seoul. make sure to wear comfy shoes and clothes as the palace is huge.

I've been there in winter days, and enjoying snow.! It's my first time to playing in the middle of snow, and I'm happy that time.! The place are very broad, but there is no restaurant or shop if you want to eat something.!

Bring comfortable shoes because this place is HUGE!!!! Make sure to check the times for the changing of the guards ceremony at the front of the palace. Incredible to see the incredible artwork and detail that went into building the palace. We didn't get to make it to the center to the blue house due to our children being tired but make sure to try and visit.

i've seen many tourists during our brief stay at the Gyeongbokgung Palace, although we didn't stay that long, it's worth the visit, probably we'll go back there if time permits on our next visit in Seoul!
You must try the free palace guard outfit! Its refreshing here. I love the nature. And the history. There is a free english tour guide every 11am. Try it.

It's really worth visiting, the grounds are huge! It houses the National Palace Museum and Folk Museum, worth a visit too.  They provide a quick (1hr, believe me it barely scratched the surface) free guided tour, just be at the meeting point at specified hours. The Palace Guide book can be bought (W500) at the information counter before the entrance.

i went there on OCT 2015 with my sister and my cousin (total 3 people), my sister already pre booked the free tour guide in English for 2 pax, and we add 1 more pax during arrival, we really highly recommended to join this free guide if you are interested in the history or story behind each building. strongly suggest not visiting on OCT since it is picnic season and the place is full with students. the tour using free guide took 2 hours in total.

It is a very huge park. 2 hours are not enough to walk through every corner in this palace. The architecture is unique and colourful. Free to experience the costumes. Limited only 5 mins to take picture for each person. The view is awesome in the palace is awesome. Actually it is quite similar to China Palace.
This is a Magnificent Palace and is a must visit when you are in Seoul.  It has various sub-palaces / theme architecture and you just have to visit them all.

Breathtaking palace, it is in a giant park that is lovely to walk around. Free English tours are apparently at 11am, 1:30pm and 3:30pm. 3000 won admission. You get about 30,000 wons worth of wow factor though :) The folk museum is in same park (free admission). Go go go.
large open area with different palace buildings and nice ponds, very relaxing. easy to get around, signs in english.

Great place to check out for a little taste of the old Korean housing. The area is enormous so your not right on top of other people. There are a lot of big groups coming throughout. Great photo opportunity area, dress warmly. Lots of walking around.

Beautiful scenery surrounded the palace. Colourful autumn leaves was definitely a stunning background photo. It wasn't too crowded during weekdays. Easily reached by public transportation. A must visit place in Seoul.
It's a beautiful place ! It allows to have a taste of Traditional Korea Culture. The national palace museum of Korea inside Gyeongbokgung is worth a visit as well.

I actually enjoyed myself even though the buildings look similar after a while. Place was huge so the guided tour helped a lot. The changing of guards ceremony was nice too. A couple of pretty spots for photo taking too.
If you like history this is a good place to go. There is guards dressed and standing at attention when you enter the Palace. I would suggest going on their tour.
Watching the ceremony is a must. The palace is beautiful. And the surrounding area is so neat & beautiful. Many art galleries & so clean..

The huge size of the palace complex is quite overwhelming, but exploring each quarter was never boring. The buildings are beautifully preserved/restored. The gardens are well maintained and clean. We were there just in time for the guards changing ceremony, which was interesting to see.
Nice place for photography. The best time for picture is around 10 am on a sunny day. There is another pond close by.

The mountains provide a lovely backdrop to Gyeongbokgung (although the city is right behind you too!). It's easy to get to and makes for a nice wander away from the busy city streets. I arrived early and it was so peaceful, but the crowds tend to draw in as the morning goes on. They hold ceremonial changing of the guards at set times through the morning - apparently the guards are military personnel who 'drew the short straw' - some of their faces might give this away :-)

When we arrived, we walked right into the start of the royal guard ceremony. It was indeed rewarding to watch the event. The palace grounds were crowded and we were indeed fortunate to be able to take photos with the young ladies in their hanbok costumes.

I naturally connected to the Gyeongbokgung Palace after watching a Korean Soap back home. The palace is an excellent place to connect to original and traditional Korean culture without living the city centre.  I was able snap pictures with traditional guards who looked like statues, I never knew they were alive until they moved.  While many tour companies do tours of the palace, you can go there yourself, buy the ticket and walk in.

There is no doubt that the palace is grand and it covers a large area. I did get the feeling though that it was a shell and that outside of foreign tourists there was little else going on there. The buildings themselves that surround the main palace are all empty and you can only go inside a couple of buildings that were furnished by the Spartans.  I think if you goto Seoul, you do HAVE to visit but don't expect too much apart from a clean pretty palace with nice gardens.

The name means "Palace Greatly Blessed by Heaven."A nice place to visit. The palace was first built in 1395. The entire complex covers 250,000 square meters. We saw the Presidential Residence at a distance.
This place offers such a breathtaking view... Really nice place for photos too! It's a little like a maze. Best to go when weather is not too cold so you can explore the place better :)
Much of this palace has been recreated following destruction, but it is very much worth seeing. The structures as well as the gardens and grounds make for a wonderful experience.

Very pretty especially if you haven't been to China or Japan. Skip the other palace across the street unless you like walking in a big park.  It's rebuilt recently the architecture and design is quite similar to Chinese palaces. Worth a couple hours if youre in the area.

We didn't get to go this year because it was closed Tuesday, the day we set aside for the 2 palaces near each other. 4 years ago, the 11 of us (grandparents down to youngest 4 years old). We didn't do a guided tour which was great at the other palace this year but it was still beautiful.

This is a charming palace and well worth visiting. I would highly recommend that you take a guided tour to get the full benefit of your visit. Due to the time of our visit we were unable to seen the Secret Garden as you have to take the site guided tour which is offered 4 times a day (in English). Our private guide indicated that it is a place well worth visiting.

I have visited here many times over the years as I enjoy the peaceful strolls through this Korean historical cal site. The many traditional palace structutes, well manicured grounds and the serene location in the heart os Seoul make this a great escape. My favorite part is the lake which is in the center of the palace grounds. It has a beautiful pagoda and is filled with lillies. It is easy to get lost in thought and imagine how beautiful this place was long ago. The entry fee is inexpensive. You can buy a ticket book to access here, three other nearby palaces and a temple for 10,000 Won. That is under 10 US and is a bargain.

The palace is tremendously pretty, colourful and big! Lovely place for pictures and lots of Korean teens in their traditional gowns taking selfie! Very fortunate the day of visit was the only sunny and hot day in the week! Spent about 4 hrs walking around, could have been more had the National Palace Museum offered more English translation of the displayed items.

A huge sprawling complex, recreating the richness of the centuries of Korean royalty. Best with a guide as it is massive and busy! Loved it. Make sure you see the stationing of the guard gates. Terrific.

Visit this palace 2nd time. As the last 2 years autumn there are many people visiting this palace not only tourist but the native koreans as well taking chances to go out and enjoy the sceneries before winter coming. Today im so lucky as there are act perfomances from the past dynasties. And also lots of beautiful koreans high school students are wearing han bok and walk around the palace. This is a must kept historical place at korea.

It is one of the top ten tourist destination in Seoul so don't miss it if you are here for the first time. It is big place and offer free museum entry, although you will need to pay 3000 won to get to see inside the palace but it is worth it absolutely.  Very easy access as it is connected to the Gyeongbokgung station, just walkout of the station as it is right in front of you ! Can spend just one hour there to have a quick tour if you are not into too much history !

Well if you ask us the history and what the guide was talking about , we were actually not much into it, but the beauty is too good. One of the main attraction to be visited when you in Seoul. Change of guard ceremony was interesting we were there I think 3pm or 4pm and we got to see it!

To understand Korea's 5,000 years of history & ties to Confucius theology, one needs to set aside some time & wear comfortable shoes to walk thru these grounds, see the restored beautiful and best of all five palaces - much like going to BJ to see China's Forbidden City. Our escorted group tour took us via the back by way of the Blue House (Presidential compound - like America's White House) onto the vast complexes - once housed over 7,000 rooms in its 500 buildings, ancient & historic designs in harmony with nature, haven & earth - and how once Imperialistic Japan virtually nearly destroyed SK's rich history and artifacts. The performances, special showings and the daily changing of the "costumed" guards are extra bonuses when timed - otherwise, there's plenty of see, visualize and appreciate - of a nation and its people, proud and mindful of its past while steering ahead of its destiny - despite its modern day South-North separation and threats of war.
An ideal place to spend 1/2 the day. I recommending getting the audio guide, it is cheap and a good way to get the details of what you are looking at.
Palace is one of the most traditional thins in Korea. The most important palace for the royalty. Very romantic. Big. There is a museum also which worth a time.

You can see the guard changing ceremony and take a picture with them. Very historical. When I was visit there, there was a place for try their guard clothes. Not hanbok, and it is for a guy. But they are allow women who want to try it too.  If you have only few days in Seoul, you can't miss out this place. Actually there are another palace but in my opinion, this is the most famous palace.

This is one of the must see places here if you are in Seoul. It is one of the most beatiful temples in Korea and it has a great Changing of the Guard ceremony. You must see this if you are in the area, but you have to be there before 12pm or you will miss it.

Either read up,on your history or go with a guide to get the full understanding of this site. The king's quarters, the queen's quarters, the different lanes for walking, the meaning of the colors in the building, all need to be explained etc. The history is very interesting and the grounds are large with many buildings
Go and check it out theres free English tours as well  Make sure you wear comfortable shoes from outside it didn't look that big but you walk abit  Great to take photos
There's changing of royal guard ceremony at the entrance and free tour guide. One of my favourite place to see in Gyeongbokgung palace is Hyangwonjeong! It is so beautiful!

I went to Gyeongbokgun Palace last winter. There's a pond inside and it was frozen, just like a mirror. The palace was so big that I walked around 1 hour. I experienced the buildings there and thought about the drama I saw before. There were so many toursits there, as it is really a must-go place in Seoul.

If you want to know more about Korea's culture this is a good place to visit. You'll see the structures of their Palace and the guards too. It is muddy when it rains so it would be difficult to walk in the place.. It would be helpful if you have a guide with you so that you would learn more about the structures, what the buildings are.. what they where.. etc.
Loved all the lovely colours on the buildings. Culturally rich. Good for business travellers on short stay for a 1/2 day outing.

There were guided tours in the different languages, but you must check the timings before you go, otherwise you might miss it.  Otherwise, everything in the Palace has been reconstructed. It was something I did not expect. I peered into the many buildings and was empty inside. However, as it was autumn and the palace grounds were quite serene, we managed to find a spot on the grass to chill at. The whole scenery of the place is also very peaceful. You might spot Korean girls in their traditional Hanbok, walking around to snap photos in the palace grounds.  If you would like to know more about the history of the place, I would suggest you find a tour guide, otherwise, it might not make any sense to you.
I love these. My Korean friend helped me to visit one of the best sightseeing. At the first time, I had a few time thus I will back here soon.

We bought the package which include the admissions to visit other palaces for ₩10,000, and is valid for 3 months, although we were only in Seoul for four days but we did go to other places on the next day. There is a free guide tour and we joined the English tour at 3.30pm.

A must in our itinerary when visiting Seoul is to visit Gyeongbokgung Palace. Rich in history and culture of the Ancient Kingdom...Each structure inside has a story, and the best time to visit is autumn.
lovely setting - needs a whole day to fully explore all aspects of this stunning, vast inner city temple area....... go on line to view pics

Easily reach by metro station with few mins walk. If you have been to Forbidden City in Beijing, this palace might be a little small and empty. If you have not been there, this is a good place to go. Some comments said its very Korean. I'm not too sure have they been to China's palace? I personally find that they have lots of similarities.  If you are there, just do remember to check out the guard exchange time table which i think this is one of the highlight. They have long exchange ceremony and short exchange ceremony. Besides, they also have a costume booth at the left corner before you heading out. You can put on the exchange guard traditional clothing for picture and they are for free.

The Forbidden City in Beijing covers 12 times the land area of Gyeongbukgung, but I find the latter more beautiful ( I included a few photos). It was burned down by Japan in the late 16th century, and not rebuilt until the 19th. Behind the palace is the mountain, and in front Sejong Daero, a large boulevard with statues of two of Korea's historical heroes. Also right by is a performing arts center, and a Palace Museum. It's at the heart of Seoul.

Let me start at the beginning: Gwanghwamun. It is picturesque and photograph-able from both Sajikno as well as the nearest traffic island on Sejongno.  Try to visit early to avoid the hoards of children on day trips from school and the tour bus crowd.  Once inside, if they are starting the pomp of the changing of the guard, I would use that as an opportunity to get a head start on the above mentioned, unless you're a huge fan of such proceedings.  The complex is quite large and some of the structures imposing but it sits on barren land (which I doubt was the situation when it was in use) which gives you the sense of emptiness.  Since it is a sprawling complex without a lot of reference points, I'd recommend either turning to the left or right once inside and working either clockwise or counter-clockwise, respectively, along the periphery. If you walk up the central path, there's a lot of nooks and crannies that you will miss.  Personal highlights were the Hyang-wonjong Pavilion at the far north of the complex and the view of Gyeonghoeru from across the water. The National Folklore Museum is supposed to be worthwhile but I was too hot and tired by the time I came upon it. It is scenic in its own right, with a 5 story pagoda perched on top.  The entrance fee is not that high, so it provides a good return on your investment.

I signed up for a free tour from the visitkorea.or.kr website and thoroughly enjoyed the place. The guide Jun, a retired South Korean volunteer, was excellent in giving our small group of four the background to the palace and use of different buildings in Gyeongbokgung. I learnt so much about this palace and its inhabitants during the Josen era in the two-hour tour, from why there are three entrance gates and why they have different heights to the different uses of the different kitchens in the palace. It was really intriguing to also see the sun dial invented during that period by one of the scholars and more importantly how it is used. Do I recommend this place? Yes but especially if you have a guide to help you fully appreciate the rich culture and history this palace embodies.
It's very Korean!!! A must see attraction to visit downtown Seoul! Near to a Seoul Metro station very convenient and accessible to visit.

If you visit Korea there are numerous temples available to see, but this is as it states, a palace. The scale and workmanship is impressive and the changing of the guard is a spectacle worth seeing. Very peaceful place in the middle of a hectic city.

If you visit seoul you must go to Gyeojgbokgung. It is very beautiful and very huge so prepare yourself with water and snakes if you have to but my advise is to eat well then go. It is much better to visit it early in the morning or after 11 I'm not sure which times it opens but after 4 pm will be so crowded

This is one of the most visited Palace in Seoul. I would highly recommend visiting specially during the change of guard happens. I went twice during my trip because the first time it was raining and the next day the weather was beautiful so I went back to enjoy the sights and palace.

The biggest of the 3 main palaces in Seoul, it does stand out from the rest. It has late endless compounds . While the palaces seemed clean, they were hardly big or grand in comparison to some of the other countries like those in Thailand or India.  The good thing was that the place was maintained really really clean../"still if you are in Sepul, worth a visit
I preferred the Changdeokgung palace. This one felt more commercial. There was a huge platform constructed for a musical event. The changing of the guard was not waht I expected. Very disapponting

Watch the traditional Palace guards changing ceremony performed at the entrance. The palace grounds were massive, surrounded by situated at the foot of the northern mountains and great to exercise your feet. The buildings were beautifully restored, demonstrating the rich heritage of ancient Korean dynasty.

From far away the palaces felt majestic and remarkable, but going closer to the buildings one could feel that most buildings of the palace are replicates, given that the Japanese and the Korean War have destroyed most of the buildings.  There were tours given and if you did not have time to catch one could walk around the palace compounds and there are signs which give a brief historical summary of the uses of buildings.  Walking to places that were not allowed when guards were not looking was interesting. You could see the empty interiors of certain buildings and how they do not look authentic from the insides. On the other hand, there were some places not refurbished recently that gave the scenery for photography an authentic feel with aged wood and discoloured paint (after all, the original palace was not as colourful as it is today with the advent of modern dyes that were more vibrant).
Is a big place, to really enjoy this place you need a bout 2 hours. If you like to take photos, you may need to allocate more time in this area.
Beautiful palace and a wonderful walk through history. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit there. The changing of the guard is short in timespan, but the colors were beautiful.

I enjoyed this palace. It is a very big area and you could be there for hours. There are some guards at the entrance in traditional dress so that is interesting. If you have been to China, this is very much the same as sites there. I visited quite a few in China, so just this one would have done me. If you have never seen anything like this then you must go.
Good for history buff and also to witness the change of guards. Accessible by train (gyeongbokgung station exit 5) but shouldn't spend too much time here.

We visited the palace during Cheusok. It was fairly busy but the visitors were fairly pleasant. I don't know if it was due to the holiday or not, but there were quite a few young people in their traditional dress wandering the site. Their presence gave an authentic air to the visit that was exciting.

One of the few palaces in Seoul, a favourite amongst tourists.  It is small in size and if one has visit The Forbidden City in Beijing, this palace is much smaller in scale. It does not have the opulence and grandeur as normally seen in a palace.  Must understand the history behind the palace and how it was largely destroyed during the Japanese invasion and the palace was only rebuilt in the 1990s due to shortage of funds. So what we see now is a rather new landmark.  To make it interesting, one can also enjoy the walk around the palace in the traditional costumes i.e. hanbok but the rental shop isn't inside the palace, One has to rent from the shops outside the palace.  In my visit, it was really enjoyable to see a few local girls dressed in colourful hanbok, and they welcome picture moments with you.
its like going back to the old time in Joseon era. like in the drama. the place is sooo good. dont walk too fast. you need to enjoy your time here..

My wife and I really enjoyed the two hours we spent wandering around the palace grounds. The price of admission was low and the grounds are gorgeous. It is a wonderful place to walk around and soak in the beauty of the grounds and the landscapes around the palace area!

I enjoy walking the grounds at my leisure, soaking up the ambiance of the Joseon dynasty. Being on the palace grounds helps brings all those Joseon-era kdramas to life.  I have been to Seoul twice in the last 2 years and I have visited this particular palace both times. 2/2=100%
It was a lovely early autumn visit, the surrounding trees just starts to turning yellow. A beautiful historical place to relax and enjoy.

I strongly recommend a visit to the palace. We visited wirh out 4 years old son and had a lovely time. We started with the National folk museum and visited the palace on the way back to the metro station. I recommend this because you will experience much shorter waiting time to purchase a ticket
Interesting Palace - free to over 65's! Lot of walking as it is very spread out. Worth a visit to aquaint yourself with it's history.

The grounds of this palace are expansive and you can wander around for hours, seeing the gardens, ornamental ponds and many palace buildings .You can also witness the colourful changing of the guards ceremony which is staged at regular intervals, or participate in a free english tour (these depart 3 or4 times a day). It does tend to lack a little character because basically all the buildings are new and there is nothing much inside the buildings to see (it was "restored" after being destroyed in the distant past). It also does get very crowded. However the entrance fee is a modest W3000 (or you can get a combined W10000 ticket and visit 4 sites within 3 months) and it makes for a pleasant diversion. You can also visit the folk museum at the side of the palace (for free) which also has a very interesting open-air section of historic shops, buildings and statues. Certainly worth a visit when in Seoul.

An interesting look at how the King use to live  I went in autumn and the scenery was really beautiful with the different coloured autumn leaves. The nicest view is one where the pavilion is.  They have scheduled tours but if you would like to walk around on your own but still get to know the history of the place, I would recommend to rent their audio tour where you can easily point to what you want to know (on the map) and listen to the historical facts. This is available in several languages.

We managed to catch the first changing of guards ceremony, which was quite interesting. The area is quite big and can get very crowded as well. The interior was alright but the view from the palace was awesome! I was told my the locals that this is not the most beautiful palace in Seoul though.

i don't know where or when but the moment i walked out the train station for this palace, i was in love. i had come just as the changing of the guards happened, it was so amazing. i can honestly say, i enjoyed everything, from the random pots of flower to maps in the floor. i had so much fun just walking around and taking pictures. you were able to view into the palace rooms but they were still in preserve. everything was perfect.

Plan to visit 2 + hours and it is so fun to see the changing of the guards. Displays are good and the grounds are beautiful. We did this palace one day and the West Palace another day. Bothe were great and worth seeing but do it in in separate days to keep it from being overwhelming.

We took a taxi from our hotel to the palace. IIRC it cost about $30 round trip. We arrived in time for the changing of the guard ceremony which was nice. Also took a guided tour. We enjoyed touring the palace.

This is one of the palaces in Korea. It's very big, picturesque, and calming. Getting inside is not a problem at all. We went as part of the Incheon tour in between connecting flights. You can find them at strategic locations at the airport. We only paid around 5-8 USD for food. I highly recommend going via this tour if you ever find yourself at their airport.
Amazing with this Palace, it is very big place, we can see traditional korean palace with background modern korean skycrapper. But too many tourist/visitor as we visit

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is a beautiful place, well preserved and tourist friendly. You can practically take pictures anywhere, and at the same time learn about where the emperors of Korea used to hold their meetings and banquets. Place is huge with lots of touristsand be sure to bring a decent camera, as there are quite a number of things you should take photo of. Families with young children might want to consider bring a stroller as place is really huge and only transport is by foot.

The palace has so much history. It is definitely one of the most famous palaces in Seoul that one has to visit. getting to palace is quite straightforward. Spend more time in the palace and explore all the rooms.

This place is really BIG but it was worth the visit! We joined the free guided tour so as to really understand the buildings in the palace grounds. Be prepared to do a lot of walking and follow the guide closely. Because of the size of the crowd that turn up on the day of the tour, sometimes the guide cannot afford to wait for everyone in the group to catch up since they have to keep the tour within the strict time slot.

In a previous visit, I actually saw the museum and some of the palace, but I went back for a second visit to finally see the whole ace properly, and I'm glad I did. The queues o get into the main palace were very long, but pretty fast, and be sure to have your ID and stuff with you when you go, just in case. The whole place is beautiful, gardens, buildings and everything, with many photo opportunities. I stayed 'til after sun down and saw the lights come up and then it was a different beautiful all over agsin. Definitely recommended.

A beautiful place to walk around and take in the history and gardens. Time your visit for a guard changing ceremony to experience the theatre of the ceremony. Refreshment facilities are available but it's best to be self sufficient. There are plenty of places to stop and rest, but no substantial food to purchase. The gift shop offers some lovely options for souvenirs also.

Information points are in english as well. Take the tram tour when you get there. It follows the wall and allows you to cover more points in a shorter time. There are other guard towers that you can walk to and once you've seen a couple, you've seen them all, but it is a pretty cool experience. Their are random personnel dressed as warriors which makes it cool as well. At the INformation center where the tram drops you off at there is an archery range where you can pay to shoot a recurve type bow and arrows at wood targets. There is also the gift store with the archery range. Pretty cool experience overall.
Huge palace. Beautiful infrastructure. It would've been good if they could place international language boards at each sight.
The palace is nicely preserved.The entrance fee was trivial but it would be good to have a guide to explain the different rooms.
Very amazing Korean architecture that has intricate details and I was very eager to see and understand more! Glad we got a guide for the tour to bring us around!
Interesting history and especially when the King had guards watching when he defecated and smelled and tasted it to make sure he was healthy! THe changing of the guards was fun to watch as well.

Traditional palace located middle of city.  There is performance on certain time. Its free and looks nice.  In front of the 경복궁, there is a 광화문광장. I tried 한복 for free! Its not the traditional way to wearn but enough to get experience of wearing korean traditional clothes. It was really awesome.

If you set aside the history part (which is worth it in itself), it's absolutely beautiful and so big! The colors are unlike palaces in other countries. They also have free guided tours. Definitely worth it!

This is great way to savor the culture of Korea, our group had a local guide who gave us specific details of the architecture and history of the palace.The Palace guards are very accommodating for photos.

It's a must to visit this wonderful place for any one who come to Seoul , here you will find the palace , monuments of the ancient loyal family , the wonderful park behind the palace , it's so good time you take for the family and any tourist who travel

Got there just on changing of the guards so there were bus loads of tourists which made the area very crowded making what should be a peaceful place rather hectic. Had a better experience at other palaces.

Start at the gate and try to catch the changing of the guard..check for times.. we were able to don the uniforms after the change in the courtyard..tons of fun. Then stroll around the massive complex of structures and visit the adjoining museum to get the history of the dynasty. Walking further through the grounds will take you to the folklore art museum which was included in the price. Overwhelming and informative.

We got there just before the changing of the guards, so we were able to see the ceremony. A photo opp.  The palace was interesting. There's a lot of history behind it, so I hope you have a knowledgeable tour guide.
very interesting and stunning introduction to traditional Korean architecture. Definitely good to purchase a printed guide (inexpensive) or take a guided tour.

Well worth a visit while you are in the area Excellently maintained and spotlessly clean We arrived just in time to catch the changing of the guard with this adding to the magic enchantment of this beautiful palace

There's not much of ancient Korean history you can see in Seoul. And this palace is a must see. However it is less well maintained and less impressive than, say, its equivalents in Japan. (I realize that 35 years of Japanese colonial rule may have contributed to the comparatively poor state of Seoul's palaces). I would also replace the thin sand with gravel (grass?) as ground cover. Otherwise it feels a bit dusty.
The palace was overwhelming but I completeley enjoyed the tour. It was very informative in terms of Korean history.
Worth visiting if you want to see beautiful palace grounds but could only look inside the windows. Also, I wish tour guide spoke better english.

This is the biggest and most impressive of the 5 palaces in Seoul. Its also the most visited, and does get pretty busy. Its totally worth getting an audio guide, to learn more about the buildings and the grounds. And make sure that you dont miss the guard changing ceremony. According to my guidebook its happening every hour, but actually its only every second hour, so you may want to check this in advance.

It's a perfect blend of nature and hystorical place. The place and palace it self is a very iconic, it's a must take a selfie spot. Inside, you'll see a beautiful lake and a scenic mountain. For a first timer in Korea, this is a lovely place. Get your camera ready and load it up with lotsa pictures!

A must for anyone's visit to Seoul. Access to the entire Palace grounds is provided so that one can experience at their own pace the lifestyle of Korean royalty. See the conservative nature of the Confucian royalty. From throne room, to living quarters, to the changing of the guard dressed in traditional Korea military garb, the visit to Gyeongbokgung Palace is a pleasant adventure.
1 hour tops. Zip through. Take a few photos. Read a few signsZip out. I love history, but not with thousands of people elbowing me.
Changing guards ceremony was amazing, it's a colourful event with flags, trumpets and a loud drum. definitely a must see attraction, combines the harmony of nature and the orientalist architecture.

This is an awesome palace, not unlike the Forbidden city in Beijing, in terms of its design and magnitude. We were fortunate to get there just in time for the changing of the guards, at the front of the palace. The guards with their uniform fake moustaches and goatee beards were a funny sight to behold. There was an entrance fee involved, but good to know that anyone over the age of 65 gets to enter free. There were 3 main pavilions leading oneself to the back, where the kitchen and living quarters were located. My favourite building would have to be the one standing on v high stilts, surrounded by a moat /pond......absolutely beautiful and tranquil. We were able to appreciate the stark contrast between this complex of ancient buildings and all the futuristic skyscrapers in its backdrop. This palace is very well maintained. And worth a visit.
beautiful palace, with lily ponds, and gorgeous views of the mountains behind, this is a gem, glad we took the time to go visit!

I know that I am in the minority here, but if you have visited other palaces in Asia - for instance in Beijing - then this place will definitely pale in comparison. It is still interesting, and the architecture is beautiful, but it is a style that is found in other palaces. If this is your first trip to Asia, this will be interesting.

The Palace is a very popular spot with Tourist, so it is crowded all day. Take a pair of good walking shoes with you, because the visit takes about 3-4 hours on foot. If possible , try to visit around lunch time, between 12-13:30, when most of the Tour groups would be on lunch break.

Beautiful palace and was lucky enough to catch the changing of guards process. On the general Seoul tourist website, it only mentioned the time was at 10am, but it changes guards 3 times a day. !0 am, 1 pm and 3 pm.

Changing of the guards is at 11:00am , 1:00 pm and 3:00 pm. It’s nice to watch the changing of the guards as it will give you an Idea on the Korean culture. There are scheduled tours around the palace with different languages. Get ready to walk and walk and walk under the sun (it depends on the season as we went there during summer), but it’s definitely worth it.

Free to see the changing of the guard which happens several times a day. Long parade with Korean music and traditional costumes to get the guards in place to make the changing of the guards. Those 65 or older can show passport and get free admission ticket at the ticket booth.

The changing of the guards is worth the visit. It is a large place and wheelchairs are available if needed.  A college student offered us a free folk museum tour in English which was very thorough and interesting.
It is great to visit the palace. The guides are good and it is so large that you can feel the silence everywhere..even when it is very crowdy
Very cheap admission although a bit disappointed that none of the buildings had any furniture in them, unlike when visiting a British stately home for example.

I have seen the Gyeongbokgung Palace several times in Korean dramas, and was really excited to visit this palace. I visited the Palace on a weekday, in the early morning where there were less people. At the ticketing office, a cheap information booklet is sold for 500won that offers a comprehensive walking guide to the palace. I spent the day walking around the palace, admiring the architecture of the palace, including the huge Gyeonghoeru. The Hwangwonjeong was also a very serene place to take a break. The palace was linked to the National Museum of Korea where a huge collection of the Royal History of Korea is housed. Their gift shop also offers a huge selection of Korean history and culture books in English, of which I got a few.
The palace complex is huge, and the entrance fee is relatively inexpensive. Walking through the palace complex allows for one to experience the rich culture and history of Korea.

There's a museum there, and other museums nearby too like the Museum of Contemporary Art within 2 minutes walking distance which you can pair with this trip.  The weather was good when we visited and it was lovely walking the palace grounds. The museum is a 3 level, informative place that brings you back to the olden times with many real artifacts nicely preserved.  Titles and descriptions come in Korean, English and Mandarin and the place is spacious and neat.  Definitely worth the visit here to learn about Korean history.

This is the replica of the palace from the last Joseon dynasty since the original structure was destroyed during the Japanese occupation. It's about 3 dollars to enter and they have free English tours available which takes about an hour . The changing of the guard parade is really colorful and you can take pictures near the guards but you can't really touch or get too close to them. It's really big and in the summer can really get hot so bring provisions. At the back there's a gate where you can pass to get near the Blue Palace for some photo ops.

Worth visiting. Come just before 1pm, as this is when the change of the guards ceremony begins. Then, you can have a guided tour (about one hour, but worth it to get some explanations on the palace and its history.) There's an English tour at 1:30 pm.

Even though the palace is a reconstruction, it has been beautifully recreated in every detail. I arived there early as to avoid the crowds as by the time i left it was started to fill up. The whole palace complex is HUGE! It does take a bit of time to walk around it. There some wonderful buildings here.

The area of the palace is very large, so it takes a lot of walking to visit everything. I used English audio guide, which told me details of every building and gate, what was it's purpose, when it was destroyed and rebuilt, but I missed general history of the palace.  Buildings are very pretty and well preserved, with beautiful paintings on the wooden ceilings and walls. However, they are all very similar to each other. You can't enter them, but you can look through the windows, and they are all almost empty.  The best for me were ponds and garden. You can't even get close to the buildings on the ponds, but even from the distance you can tell it's something different.  It took me over 2 hours, and it was hot day. If you visit on such a day, don't forget to bring a bottle of water.

I used the Free English tour. You learn a little history - get told your ticket gets you into the folk museum next door (which I actually found more interesting).  The Korean psyche has zero time for the Japanese who raped the country and its occupants over a 40 year period until they got nuked.  During this period this Palace which once comprised 550 buildings was reduced to one or two so what you see is a reconstruction in progress.  Something you have to get used to because if the Japanese did not blow it up, tear it down or use it for target practice then fire will have reduced it to cinders at least once and possibly several times.
A great place to walk around, especially in the fall or spring. Large tours visit regularly on weekends, however.
It's so neat to see the historic restored houses/palaces set up in the middle of the city. It's a larger area than I had expected. Good for an afternoon trip.

If you are a Korean history craze or k drama fans, you may not find it interesting. It is clean, well kept but simple and small scale if compare to China. Should visit once but won't go back. It is close to the famous ginseng chicken soup place. Can walk there after your visit.
I was completely in awe of this palace. We spent hours exploring the grounds and taking pictures. The architecture and history in this place are not to be missed!!

I went here first thing in the morning. To beat the crowd but even after every one showed up it was still fantastic. Alot of temples and history. Expect to spend about 3 hours including the museum, which is a must sea as well.

A vast, sprawling and frankly uninspiring estate of allegedly very old palace buildings, of which all were empty inside, and which had been so thoroughly refurbished in and out it looked as though they'd been built last year. There are vast open flagged spaces between each of the buildings, and probably the least unattractive is the one in the picture on Tripadvisor. There is the changing of the guard - a bit of a Disney luridly-coloured 'show'. with the actors not looking as though they're enjoying it much either. What saves it is the intricate tilework, soffits and external dressing of the buildings, which are worth photographing. There are barely any cafes inside so bring plenty of water.

I did my daughter's first birthday photo shoot here. Well maintained. Huge. too much walking and too much to look around. Best to visit in fall or spring. Palace tours available in different languages.

need to relax and free your mind from shopping and eating, this is the place to be for a little peaceful getaway, very romantic and photogenic place, it does require walking as you would in the shopping mall but the difference is, you are actually spending quality time with you loved ones and bonding with your soulmate.

We spent a couple of hours looking around this beautiful palace. I've not seen anything like this before right in the centre of the city. The architecture and the gardens are amazing at every turn. You really get a feel of how things used to be and you forget you are in the biggest city in South Korea!  Highly recommended especially if the weather is good.

Cheap to visit at 3000KRW! The place is huge and a lot of walking is required.  Interesting change of guards every hour from 9am to 3pm.  You get to see the Emperor's court and his throne, concubines' rest quarters, servants area, a beautiful lake and a museum.  Good place for photography.
inside center of the city,you can find such a beautiful place to explorer.good place to relax when you tired of noise and shopping.
a palace that you should see. Very easy to reach, because the subway connected directly to the place.

Definitely the top palace to visit when in Seoul. If you go, the morning changing of the guards is a must see (longer than the rest). A great expansive property to explore and hard to believe it's only 10% of the size it once was!
wonderful place, romantic, great to take pictures, in the middle of the city center, also special night visits possible
Would be better if some description can be put in front of each of the rooms. I asked for digital guide but the staff seems did not understand.

Wow, beautiful palace and so unique. We didn't go inside but we're already so much impressed with the beautiful and immense outside. Watch the nicely dressed guard in their original costumes at the front gate. From you walk in 10 min to Insadong

As a local people in Seoul, I think from time to time what place should I recommend to foreign people visiting Seoul, Korea. Several palaces, and Jongmyo Shrine is the first places to recommend. Korean palaces are relatively small compared with palaces in other countries (for example, the forbidden city in Beijing). So for someone who think size matters, this palace is not an impressive place. I just hope tour guide can properly explain the history, culture, and architecture of this palace.

It is a beautiful palace! With a nice park around the palace. But the other famous palace which is bigger looks exactly the same. I recommend going to one of the palaces if you don't have that much time.
Plan on spending at least a few hours at this extensive and very picturesque location which comprises quite a number of buildings, plus a museum on Korean culture and history.
I would recommend visiting here if you are in the area!! We had a lot of fun and really enjoyed our time here. LOVED IT!!!
Great palace to visit -- Would recommend to more detail in English or English speaking tour guide to get full effect of site -- Beautiful Palace

It is undeniably a must place to visit in Seoul, it is unique because it is an ancient palace surrounded by the skyscrapers out there. You can see a contradictive view. The only downside is that tourists can just have a look at the building but not inside the building. I would like to see how does inside look like for bedroom and kitchen.

There is a reason why this place does not get an excellent review from me but let me tell you about the Pro's first. A great place to be for families who wants to visit and explore the palace and while many think that the place is just touch and go, you are wrong, this place is fairly huge. My cousin and me walked around the area for at least 2 hours before we decided to go. At certain part of the day, there will be some performance by the Korean citizens to portray how the guards used to do during their change of guard ceremony. At certain days, you can even try out their traditional clothing.  The cons is that it is closed on Tuesday and although I have been here for 3 times, the traditional wear area was always close. Not sure if it will get open anytime soon though. This is the only downside but overall, I would recommend anyone who has never visited an ancient palace to come and visit
This building says it all. A traditional palace with a great structure, great architectural concept and great art.
IfFyou travel to seoul dont miss this one. And the ceremony too. Its really large area i think,but its nice

Very traditional palace, with beautiful gardens and constructions. Inside there is an interesting museum about Korean history and culture worth the visit. The guards of the palace dress typically as in Joseon Dynasty.

A must see whilst in Seoul,amazing history and the buildings are stunning.Take your time and see everything,it was very hot while we were there so take a lot of water with you,having a guide was also a must have as the knowledge they give you is something you could not get on your own. We so loved South Korea.
Changing of the guards ceremony was amazing. All the uniforms were so colourful. Don't miss this event. Not sure how often it happens each day.
Went during winter. Its beautiful and amazing. The snow, frozen lake and etc. Would love to go again on other season.
The change of guard procession was interesting. Bring a hat and plenty of water when visiting during those hot days. A must-see when visiting Seoul.

I took the english tour. I think they are open everyday and every 2 hours. It took about 2 hours and it was very informative. The palace ground is very large and beautiful. You can take the tour and ask questions or leave and wander around yourself. It's a good way to meet new people in your group who speak the same language or take pictures for you. Very recommended. I got great photos from it

My perception of Seoul before actually visiting was that is a largely artificial city with no real history or culture relative to places like Hong Kong. Seeing Gyeongbokgung Palace and a some of the other cultural sights during my visit proved me wrong.  I happened to arrive around when an English language tour was about to begin, so I joined up (it was free). I won't give any spoilers, but the guide helped me understand why Seoul might not have quite as much of its pre-modern history on display compared to some other cities.  Further, the on-going work to rebuild Seoul's heritage sites is impressive and uplifting. I'll look forward to future visits to see it unfold.

If you visit Seoul and don't see this palace, you need a doctor. It's like visiting Beijing without seeing the Imperial Palace.  Try to check the times for the changing of the guards. It's a colourful event with flags, trumpets and a loud drum. Kids will love it. The best views are are on the left side or near the front gate.  Guided tours are handy, but it's fun to stroll at your own pace. The palace grounds are greener near the left side at the back, cwhere you'll find a small lake. This area also has more ornate decorations and several gates and doorways.  The palace rents out baby strollers, but the large cobblestones will give your child a serious massage.
It is one of the main attractions of Seoul together with the Seoul tower and other famous neighbourhoods like hongdae, gangnam and itaewon
This is the biggest palace in Korea. So large that it took hours to complete the sightseeing in the inside of the palace.

I recommend a tour because I regret not getting one. It was still interesting and worth seeing. The temples have a lot of beauty and great detail to them. I expected more greenery but I'm assuming that's too much for cost of upkeep

Visited this palace with my aunt. It was big and beautiful and although filled with people it just felt desolate...like just imagine how it was when a dynasty lived there. Just open space. Like all palaces the design is colorful and bright with flowers in the cut outs and trim.  The changing of the palace guards was a big to do...there was this whole official ceremony and everything and that was really amazing to see.

I love Korea culture so i was so happy to visit here. Many places I seen in movies and very large. I spent many hours here. People were friendly and I loved the folk museum. It can be crowded so go day time.

From entering this palace... you are just in awe of its sculptures, scenery and the colourful guards... You will see many building types, including pagodas, a huge museum of korean life, a street village and plenty of gardens for picnics.. Its amazing. Well worth a visit.

A beautiful palace in the middle of Seoul. This place has some amazing photography options. They just opened a new part on the east side which is great for the photo lovers. You could spend all day here if you wanted. And dont forget about the free museum in the back right of the Palace.
This is quiet and neat place  If you want to feel korean culture You should visit here Must visit place
This is a massive complex on the edge of the city centre. It takes a couple of hours to do it justice, so dress appropriately and don't forget the umbrella.
Well maintain palace with a picture perfect view! Need to purchase a ticket to go in and worth every penny. The palace is big and there is a tour in the preference language but please check the time!

A prominent tourist attraction, this palace is on the A list of most tourists. The palace and its surroundings are kept to be pristine so as not to damage or harm its antiquity. Hence, tourists can only observe the palace from outside although they can still wander around the site. The weather is very humid and hot in summer esp. because of the lack of trees around the complex. Still, this palace is worth the while.
This is closed to insa-dong . One can walk this palace before walking around insa -dong, and some of the old ancient looking house. Sovereign is better price here.
i like walking in this palace, ever though sometimes its kind of busy but still a good place for talk a walk, growing the inner peace and taking a photograph esp in the spring and autumn

The palace was really easy to get to if you take the subway. Entrance was 3,000 won. You could purchase a combination book that included tickets to other palaces for 10,000 won. The book is good for 3 months. The grounds definitely involved a lot of walking, so make sure to bring some water! Great tour!
Very interesting to learn a bit about Korean history. It was well worth waiting for the free English tour. The guide spoke English well and was very obliging.
I highly recommend it. All the temples that you can see in Korea are simply great and all of them have English tours for free. It could not be better.

It is not the most beautiful palace of Joseon Dynasty, but it functioned as the main palace. You can feel the Joseon in the palace. Don't forget to dress up as Korean Traditional, Hanbok. Free admission!! Public Transportation recommended.

A wonderful surprise when you first glimpse the palace across the courtyard. Colourful guards defend the front gates. Such a spectacle. Miles of buildings and then out to the park at the rear. Cross to the folk museum for another look at the history of the Korean people. A great day out.

histirical beautifully constructrd koearian palace, nicely dressed soldiers and the gardens sorrounding the complex give you the feeling like you are traveling in time and live with ancient Korean kings.  there are good tour guide who lead the tourists and give information about every single corner of the palace, free of charge.

This is a great place to spend a couple of hours. The history is fascinating about the Japanese occupation and impact on this site. Beautiful lake and a very calming vista over the waterlilies, especially on a hot day. Architecture is interesting to see how the Korean's design their palaces. It is also free to visit on Liberation day, 15 August. The locals love it as well, so it can be a bit crowded on the 15th.

Most of the buildings you see at this palace complex, including the main throne hall and the famous front gate, are recent reconstructions. This palace is in fact one of the least historically authentic ones in Seoul, not to mention crowded. As a Seoul resident, I mainly come for the 2 museums on the palace grounds, the National Palace Museum and the National Folk Museum. The former has a good restaurant and a brilliant shop.
Busy road to cross to get to the palace. Enjoyed seeing the changing of the guards. Large compound which was impressive to walk around but busy and pushy crowds to go into the actual temples.
This is a must visit palace and garden. Really worth it! Middle of the city! For small kids it can be a bit to big as you can walk around for hours.
Worth to see. Not too old. Needs lots of walking to see all the palace areas and many uphill and downhill..

Right in the heart of Seoul, this is a must-do if you are interested in learning about the history of Korea. The palace grounds are beautiful. Be sure to do yourself a favor and hook up with a tour guide so you can learn as much as possible. And bring your camera because the sites are amazing

It was very big and and very empty because I went during the MERS scare. Beautiful architecture. If you want a tour guide, you have to call ahead. I got to go to a small building that is normally off limits.

cultured and heritage always one of the best thing/place to visited especially when they have and related with long great history. the scenery was awesome and the environment was really harmony. as advise, you should have more than 3 hours if you want to finish visit this place or maybe more than that.. its really big and really nice...

This palace was visited as we had 10 days in Seoul. I personally found that when you visited the first couple of temple's everything seemed the same. There were some nice lakes and an interesting museum to look at the history of south Korea however, 2 to 3 hours was enough for me. The war museum is a must. It deserves to be no 1 on trip advisor.

Great place to spend some time imagining how life was like. Excellent museum of the palace as well, just to the left when you come in the main gate. Try to catch the changing of the guard for a ceremonial treat!
This is a very beautiful place to visit and take photos (you do not need a long time there)our tour guide from "Korea private tour" was great

The Korean people lost generations of culture and history though the Japanese occupation so what you see is not original but its also not to be missed. Please visit as it gives a wonderful insight into a Korea in the past. If you are familiar with Chinese or Vietnamese architecture it is worth gettin an informed guide to explain the subtle differences between each culture. They may look the same but they aren't.

Cultural heritage never seized to amaze me everywhere I go to a palace or castle.  Preserve well, and the details is superb. The museum is a breeze and easy to learn.. Need more english explanation though..  Must visit...

A really nice place to go to, when I went there it wasn't to crowded so it was really nice to just walk around and enjoy the scenery, see all the old buildings, see the gardens and the ponds was especially nice and quiet.

If you are into the history of Korea then this is a must see. I am not, but I learned alot on the tour about the history of korea, the living conditions of royalty as well as the servants etc. The architecture was amazing, the amount of detail in the painting was impressive. Glad we went.
Importnat and one of the five palaces in Seoul. Very typical structure for Corea and exciting structure.
Amazing photo opportunities with a wealth of history and culture. Definitely a must see location of South Korea. Interesting architecture and stories of the past.

I was so impressed with Gyeonbokgung Palace. It is very well maintained and very easy to get to. Take a subway ride, come up the stairs and there you are. Truly amazing how they have kept this beautiful piece of history in the middle of skyscrapers and buildings. They offer free guided tours and I really suggest taking one. If you go in the summer months be sure to take lots of water, an umbrella and a hand fan as there is no shade. Pictures will not even do justice of how amazing the palace was.
Very beautiful with lots of history and a lovely garden, located very centrally so other attractions around. Don't miss this if you're in Seoul.

A must see when traveling to Seoul. There is much history in beauty in this palace! The Joseon period is a huge part of Korean history. I highly recommend doing a guided tour; they're free and happen multiple times everyday. The tour guides know a lot about the place and its history, and you see a lot of the palace without getting overwhelmed by its complexity.
Immersed ourselves into this really ancient romantic palace! Wearing the "hanbok" taking photos! The roofs and exterior façade were exquisitely done up! Check out the Pagoda nearby!
Must do visit of a stunning, over 700 year old main Korean royal palace in central Seoul. Closed on Tuesdays.

Basically everything in Seoul is crowded, and this place is no exception. There are some lesser-known palaces around the downtown area that are equally beautiful (if not as huge). I prefer them, actually, over this palace. (Changdeokgung)  Insider tip: if you're visiting in the summer with little kids, let them play in the fountain directly in front of the palace. It's a bit of a hike from the front gate, but a great way to avoid a kid with a case of the grumpies.

This was a great experience, i thought the arhictecture was so interesting, and gives a real feeling of traditional korea. even though it was very rainy, there were still many tourists which is understandable as its an outstanding palace. I would recommend not going during monsoon rainy season though if possible.
Very nice park. Beautiful building, with 2 descriptions: English and Korean. Enter cost 3$, I was on Saturday day and it wasn't full of people.

You can introduce by yourself in Korean History, you can feel in the time of these palaces and close your eyes and to imagine beeing inside the palace some hundreds of years ago, really is phantastic to transport in the time, all you need is imagination and to look slow every passage of korean history and to read and understand the texts of every place in the way.

The visit to Gyeongbok Palace was one of the highlights of my trip. I was able to be there at 10AM for the changing of the guard. I loved seeing the colorful uniforms and hearing the traditional drum being hit. Later I was able to sit near the pond where the King used to entertain and throw parties. The architecture is wonderful, as well. Lots of walking. I recommend bringing an umbrella for shade during the summer months.

well. you're not going to Korea if you're not going to this palace! it's true guys, i'm not kidding. I've seen a lot of korean palace in korean dramas, but never thought the history behind it. lucky me, when i was there, there was a free english tour guide to lead us about this palace, it's really worth my time

On a glorious sunny early summer day, I had the opportunity to enjoy some of the sights of Seoul, that bustling Korean metropolis that is surprisingly (for a Westerner) full of unexplored history. My first stop was the Gyeongbokgung Palace just near the Presidential Palace and the centre of the business district around Jongno-gu. A bit of history from the official guide. The first palace buildings were built in 1395, three years after the Joseon Dynasty was founded by King Taejo (Yi Seong-gye) after the capital of the newly founded dynasty moved from Gaeseong to Seoul (then known as Hanyang). The entrance is a grand courtyard, similar to the classic imperial Chinese design for the Forbidden Palace, it is breathtaking! After then, a range of buildings, temples and garden lakes were constructed and which survived until the Japanese occupation resulted in almost all buildings being dismantled. Now, lovingly rebuilt, they exude peace and harmony with a dose of tranquillity around the gardens and lake. A great place to visit during a free couple of hours and in the heat of early summer, bring plenty of water..

Stunning in size and culture. One of the top two palaces to see while in Seoul. Make sure to get in before too late in the day when they stop letting people in, you need sufficient time to visit around!

The gardens in this palace are very lovely and relaxing place to walk around. We came here on the weekend and although it was a bit crowded, you did not get the crowded feeling while walking in the gardens. The infomation about the history of the palace was a bit limited.

A true icon of korea. To really appreciate this country, you must most definitely need to see the palace! A lovely place. Plan at 3 hours to get around the big place. I love it here. Been 12 plus times!!!!!
Beautiful architecture and a charming man-made pond inside. Perfect place for k-pop fanatics to visit.

We visited the palace and we're lucky to start by watching the guards change performance. The visit was enjoyable. At the end we entered the attached museum which was fascinating. The only problem was the hot weather did not help us to enjoy the palace outdoor.

I visited this place with my host. She told me stories of how she use to come here and played when she was a kid. Then she told me stories of how she brought her kids here. I think hearing her stories and hearing about the history of the palace gave me more of an understanding of what this palace meant to Koreans. It was a really wonderful place. It is the perfect place to see and feel the past, present and future.

The Palace is the largest in the Seoul and dates back to the late 1300's. The grounds are large with many buildings and 2 lakes. It's a marvel to see the work of all artisans that created all the buildings and landscaping. It's like going back in time...
Golden roof of Kings Room is totally amazing. Excellent guide and well described. Number one place to visit.
Definitely worth a visit, nice buildings and if lucky get to see change of the guard in the traditional gear.
The biggest palace resides in the heart of Seoul.Entrance fee: about 5 US$. Free guided tour in English - check the information for details. Fabulous building and history
Please plant more trees for shade. It's quiet beautiful but sometimes it just get's too hot during summer.

Beautiful Palace and Gardens. We also arrived just in time to see to changing of the guards. Very spacious so be prepared for a lot of walking. Museum next door provide very educational historical background of Korea. We went during July when all public tours were free.
