The Palace is very beautiful and worth a visit, it was in my opinion the most beautiful thing I saw in Seoul. At the entrance to the palace you can see the traditional guards and there are various events during the day that you can watch, such as the change of the guards. At the entrance there is a sign with the timetable for these events, it is worth to wait for one of them!

Had the opportunity to see the changing of the guard and English speaking tour of the palace. There was a special tour of the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion - Korean language only. But the guide found me prior to the tour and gave me an overview. This tour is only available for a short period of time - so glad I was able to see this peaceful palace.

Very beautiful. The best out of the 4 palaces in Korea. It is optional to buy a group pass to visit all 4 palaces. I will not recommend it unless you have plenty of time to visit all 4 palaces. Its pretty much the same.

This is a very beautiful palace and is worth the visit. We just arrived at the end of the 10am changing of the guards and you should make a note to arrive to see the whole thing. Apparently the ceremony is conducted several times a day and is full of pomp and noise, but is fun.

From our hotel Biwon, that was not so far to get on this royal great place. It is one of the five Seoul and surely Korean sites,that count as the World Heritage Centres of the world. We headed along the Yulgok Road and got in the front of the main gate of the Royal Palace, that is, Gyeongbokgung Palace. Before we entered inside, or within the great square, stone paved, we witnessed to such great royal ceremony, that was done by the royal guard in the very beautiful red and blue costumes. Many of them carried the spears and royal flags. Took some pictures. Inside we found ourselves entouraged with tipically korean architectural design, presented by the buildings at one or two storeys, the wood fences, the stairways, that led to the doors of these houses of high noble men of old Korean royalty. This palace was built by the Joseon dynasty in 1395, one of the most important dynasties throughout the whole history of Korea.On the site there are five grand palaces. This place have had the turbulent history, the palace was two times demolished. First time it was during the Japanese invasions of Korea (1592 - 1598) and second time, it was in the more recent history, that is, in the years of repeated Japanese occupation of Korea, from 1910 until 1945. Really immense square, with the great blue sky above us, elegant, nice coloured palaces all around and large stone plates under the feet. Here again we saw the Royal Guard, this time in the procedure of changing the posts. The very beginning of our stay in Seoul, and how it was impressive !!

I've been to all the other palaces but don't think I can pick a favorite. What's nice about this one is the size (it's the largest) and even though it tends to be the busiest there's a lot of ground and buildings so the people get spread out. A trip to this palace gives you the opportunity to visit the National Palace Museum or the National Folk Museum. I've been to both museums and don't consider them "must sees" but are nice if you have the time and if you only have time for one I would recommend the Folk museum over the Palace museum.  I've been here twice, once in the Spring and again in the Fall. Both times were beautiful because there was bloomed cherry blossoms in the Spring and colored leaves in the Fall.  9am-6pm, last admission at 5pm Adult 3,000won (about $3) 7-18 1,500won (about $1.50) 6 & under free Other Info: watch changing of the guard ceremony and have your picture taken with one, special night time openings Palace Website: www.royalpalace.go.kr
A must visit place in South Korea to have a glimpse of the country's rich history. Do not miss the royal changing of the guard when you visit.
In chosun's palace is remains now. also there is so clean insid. Many drama is in this palace and maybe half thousand of history. I like this palace

some of buildings are not original due to sad invasion history. there are many signs with good information on most of buildings. there are few museums right next to palace. take your time will take approx. 2~4 hours
So good to see the palace in person. We saw this each time we watch historical Korean Dramas and being here just made it more real for us. So good that they maintained this.
A glimpse of Korea during a different era. Make sure you are there for the changing of the guard ceremony

In retrospect, this place probably requires a tour guide. At least for the front section it's just a series of very open assembly spaces on sandy ground. We missed any gardens to see the changing of the guard (a bit anti-climactic). The price was right, though (thanks MERS). Perhaps a couple more information stations would have brought the place to life.

This is one of the encient place in Korea. I have stepped up to this palace afternoon lazily after my tiredness of visiting Lotte World. But once i arrived there i become refreshes with this historical monument and it made worth of voting there. I would like to recumbent people to visit there once you are there in Seoul.

Our tour to the palace was fantastic. Already a fan of Asian imperial dramas, it was fun walking in the 'footsteps of kings' and imagining life in the past. The near by Museum was educational without being too encompassing and we were able to take in both before lunch.
Nice place. High recommended to visit in Seoul. Be ready to do lots of walk. Many nice photo spots inside.
A must visit, Parade ceremony is a definitely not a miss.. have ample amount of time to visit the palace.

First time that i visited this country and city, and everyone told me "you need to visit this palace". They were not wrong. The palace is huge and is the best way to understand about the culture, the past and the difference between South Korea and the other asian countries. The entrance fee is not high, and also can buy one ticket that includes the visit to other palaces. Use comfortable clothes because you need to walk a lot but the views and buildings are amazing. Inside you can also visit one museum that is really nice. Amazing place for summer or winter!

Other than the huge amount of visitors in the afternoon I have nothing bad to say about this palace. Very large, beautiful buildings and gardens. Especially the area around the pond is beautiful, quite easy to spend an entire afternoon exploring this palace!

Coming from a very young modern country, visiting ancient historic sites like this is an eye opener. It is so enriching to learn about the rich culture of another country.  Gyeongbokgung Palace is a beautiful place to visit , a must see. It is a huge place, so be prepared to do some walking & spend some time here.  But it is worth it. After all, there are no better places to learn about another country's culture than actually visiting their historic sites.

Great palace - try to go so that you can see the changing of the guard. Seemed like Fridays are the day to go if you aren't part of a tour group. We roamed here for 2 1/2 hours and still didn't see everything! There's no food sold here so bring a picnic/snacks if you plan on taking a break towards the back of the palace where there's benches to sit and eat under the trees.

Yes it is one of the best attractions in Seoul. It is a very big palace with huge garden. Don't forget to wear very comfortable shoes to walk in. And if you have a Korean customs to wear this is the best place to take some photos while wearing their beautiful dresses It is very recommend to visit it during the guard change to see it.
Great priority palace to visit in Seoul. Be sure to go on the Secret Garden tour as well, then explore the neighborhood afterwards. Nice small eateries in close proximity.

As you'll read in other reviews, this place is huge! You can easily spend an entire afternoon here which should allow you to see everything. There's quite a bit of walking, but you get a good idea of the architecture and culture.

Went there at april 15 But if u want to see some sakura leafs I suggested u to go somewhere else  The place is huge Inside there are castles, folks houses, museums and also hanbok rental in the front of gate. Plenty of tourist when we went there  In my own opinion, i prefer to go to japan temple's or japan's castle But it still a place to go if you want to sightseeing at seoul

The Palace was rather big, the atmosphere around the palace was very nice despite the large crowd. I think this place would be best visited in spring or autumn when the weather and temperature is just right.

We went to all the palaces in 1 day. This palace was pretty closed to where we were staying. This is considered the second most huge palace in Korea. On the day we went, there were free entrance for all tourists. I guessed this has to do with the recent MERS cases. There were not many people there. Was quite empty. Reached in time to see the changing of guards. Was pretty impressive with it. The changing of guards last around 15minutes. After which we headed inside the palace and it was HUGE!! You can view the beautifully structures of the palaces, the building of the home of the King and Queen. We spent an hour walking around and had our rest at a café in the palace itself.

A pretty big palace. it's not as big as The Forbidden Palace in Beijing but it was nice. It definitely had the Korean architecture and culture. The pavilions were nice but pretty empty. Worth a visit!
I was able to visit during a business trip and loved the beauty and history this provided. I did not get a guided tour which probably only adds to the experience but will loved my visit.
I spent little time there, mostly due to the great heat of the day. The palace seems to be mostly grounds (though I could be wrong about that). There are great local places to eat nearby.
The guided tour helps you understand and know what the palaces were about, the tour guide I had have good English but her voice volume was a bit too low.

Beautiful! I went with an old roommate that I had while studying abroad in Korea. She was able to explain the details of the palace and give me some history. It is really pretty and I highly recommend it.
A nice place to spend a couple of hours just walking around, taking in the lovely gardens and historical buildings. Highly recommend it!

Let us say that if there is only a palace to be seen or if you have little time in Seoul, it is good that one that it is necessary to visit. Attention the palace is closed for the visits on Tuesdays. Opening hours are from 9am to 6pm. Cost approximately 3'000 Won for entry and half for children until 18 year old.  The palace dates from the 14th century, and it extends over 40 hectares, it is a city in the city, count 2-3 hours to see the main buildings. A project of restructuring is in progress for a duration of 20 years reason why all the structures are not accessible.  NB: every hour there is a change of the guarding in the entrance of the palace which deserves to be seen with its traditions.

This palace is huge, you could literally spend all day there. The changing of the royal guard ceremony is fun to watch at the very front. The pond is beautiful! We were able to walk through and take pictures in front of the blue house and see the national folk museum of korea. If you can only see one temple in seoul id highly recommend this be the one!

This amazing old hunting park used to be the King favorite spot to chill. Now the public can visit this place and enjoy their time. The place is massive and tour guide are available. You can see the old Korean building and nice swamps. I highly recommended this place. Please wear sport shoe as it might be a long walking there.

The place is huge! We spent about 30 minutes looking at everything. Absolutely worth seeing as it's convenient and is in the middle of town. We were in a rush so didn't go into the museum but it's definitely worth seeing if you are pressed for time and can only visit one palace.

The palace grounds are huge! Each building is so beautiful and unique, they're similar but completely different to Chinese or Japanese palaces (if that makes sense). There's a museum inside the grounds which you can enter with the palace ticket. There is a changing of the guards display every hour on the hour at the entrance. The palace is so easily accessible by metro, there's no excuse not to visit!

Enjoyed a walk through this palace, partially with the English tour that`s included in the entry fee. The palace is really nice. The guided tour was informative and added to the experience, although the guide did go much in the detail neither followed a chronology.The only real disappointment is that you need to book in advance to enter the palace building on the west side (surrounded by a small pond).

After wandering through all of Seoul's major palace complexes, I've picked Gyeongbokgung as my favorite. It is a huge complex with a number of beautifully designed buildings as well as a wonderful garden at the back. Although the garden at Gyeongbokgung Palace is not as big or as English-garden-like as the one at Changdokgung, it is a very pleasant an beautiful place to stroll through. Make sure to take the free guided tour and then wander around on your own as well because the tour doesn't cover everything (although the tour lasts for about an hour, the complex is just too huge). Try not to miss the guard changing ceremonies because they are a treat. The times are clearly marked at the notice boards as you enter. You can also try out the guard costumes at the building to the left as you enter through the main gate. It is open just before and after the guard changing ceremonies. Spots fill up quickly. Among all the palace complexes, this is the most archetypal, the biggest and perhaps the most majestic. Changgyeonggung has some of the most beautiful clusters of buildings though. There is no entry fee during July 2015.

Being the largest of the five palaces, I would say this is something you definitely should set aside time to see. The National Folk Museum of Korea is also within the premises, so make sure you have a few hours available. We spent 2,5 hours but didnt get around to see all the different buildings.
Much of the palace is reconstruction which lends a feel of in authenticity. Nevertheless, it is a lovely place to wander. A tranquil spot in the heart of Seoul.
this place is awesome! Dont miss the changing of guards program. Everything is well kept, will make you feel like you were transported to a different time.
Great to visit and walk around when you are visiting the city. Beautiful gardens and well manicured grounds as you see all the history inside.

This is the biggest palace in Seoul, and definitely worth a visit if you're in town. It's not the most amazing thing I've ever seen, but it's a very scenic and pretty palace with a massive area to walk around on a nice day.  Also it was free during July 2015 so that's a bonus! Go now if you're here this month.

It was great! We took lots of pictures, because of course the place was beautiful.  There were also free tours on specific times in different languages.  It was a long walk back, because from after the tour, you have to go all the way back. there is no other exit, except from where you came in.  We tried to find one form another way, but there was really none.  It's a HUGE place.

In most places, the historical sites are usually a bit out of the way from the city. But not in Seoul, it's really interesting how the old palaces are intertwined in the very modern architecture. I went during a heavy rainstorm with thundering, so not the best time to go, but also allowed for some quite dramatic photos! Definitely worth checking out!
I visited this historical place during winter. It was a peaceful place and we can see the traditional architecture in this palace.
Definitely worth visiting! Beautiful, historically important location in the heart of a modern city. Tranquil, green, and pleasant.

The largest palace complex in Seoul. It has many buildings and each has its specific history, of course you'll have many photo spots. Don't miss the guard change ceremony at the gate. It is also near to the National Folk Museum. You'll need 1 to 2 hours to cover the whole complex.

Not a great palace but one of the must see. It represents Korean traditional architecture. When you see other palaces around the world you might say this is not that great but definitely worth a visit

One of the best things to do in Seoul. The palace complex is large and reminds me a lot to the Beijing Forbidden city. The good things is that it is not obercrowded like the Beijing one, so you will really enjoy it!

I like visiting historical places, and this one was no exception. I found royal Korean customs interesting when our tour guide narrated the events that transpired in the queen's chambers. Of course the traditional architecture was also something I really marveled at.

Architecture at its best. You will find peace within yourself when you spend at least two hours in this place. Take some fresh air at the park and entertain your eyes with magnificent assets from the past at their National Folk Museum :)

This was our favourite palace in Seoul, it was close to our hotel and we were there in the morning when the guard change happened- don't miss this one (they do it few time a day). The palace is enormous but easily accessible even without a guided tour as we did. We bought a brochure where we bought the entrance tickets and it had a map and all the necessary information about the palace in it.

I went to the palace with a korean friend. The tour lady was very good, and let go a couple of funny jokes to lighten the atmosphere. The tour is 1h long, because the palace is so big. The architecture is beautiful. Simple yet refined, the wooden structures are assembled without any nails or metal and symbolize asian acient design. I think this is a classic visit on the Seoul To-do list.

I happened to be here during July which apparently all the palaces and museums are open for free!!! and also coincidently to have enjoyed the free guided tour provided by the palace, all of which has made the whole experience so much better!

It is a beautiful historical Korean temple. We had just come from Beijing and went to the Forbidden City before arriving in Seoul, so in comparison, it is less impressive. Nonetheless, being Koreans from Los Angeles we were still very glad to have seen it.
A great palace to walk around. It is a part of Korean history. Even it is a replica, the original one was destroyed.

This palace has been destroyed, twice I think, so what you can see today has been entirely rebuilt. The grounds are huge and nice for a stroll around - but there isn't too much to see here in terms of exhibits, etc. The changing of the guard ceremony has interesting music and costumes and my kids really enjoyed seeing it.
This is a palace worth visiting. Main Royal palace of the Joseon Dynasty, this has a lot of architecture and numerous palaces rooms inside. One of the biggest palace in Korea.

Seoul at night is like a teenager who just discovered life after school. All of those who spent hours working, chasing deadlines, staying in on piece after meetings and reunions are the same that cluster bars, restaurants, plazas and more, giving this city an unique sense of dynamism and restlessness. That is why from time to time it is more than necessary to breathe and relax, and believe me, there is no better place in town for this action than the gardens of Gyeongbokgung Palace! Want to contemplate Korean architecture while promenading away from the intense rhythm of town? Well, think no more, this is your place.
Enjoyed a free walking tour. The history and architecture is well worth the visit. Wear good walking shoes.

Today I visited the palace and to my surprise the entrance fee was free. A sign was posted that named the other nearby palaces also as free for the month of July due to MERS. This palace was just as beautiful as the others that I visited on my trip to Korea. I also enjoyed the Korean Folk Museum which is also on the same grounds.

Decided to do a palace tour via the subway. Subway was right next to the palace. You can buy a multi-ticket whilsy there. Gives you access to other palaces in the city. Worth it if you see 2 or more places. Good museum at the entrance too.

Located in the heart of downtown Seoul, Gyeongbokgung is an easy must-see visit. The Changing of the Guards ceremony welcomes most visitors. The first portions may have more visitors, but be sure to wander to the back parts as well. I especially liked the Parujeong building. Pavilions by the waters are particularly beautiful in spring and peaceful after an occasional snowfall. Amisan chimneys are noteworthy. Do visit the free Folk Museum, connected to the palace grounds.
Cheap admission (~ 3 USD) and worth to see the traditional face of Seoul and Korea. However, do not expect anything breathtaking.
Make sure to catch the changing of the guards in the afternoon! Love the ceremony and brightly colored attire.  This is closed on Tuesdays, by the way, so plan your Seoul itinerary accordingly.

A must visit for Seoul. See the changing of the guard and the elaborate show for tourists.  The grounds are nice enough, but not very large. Back then, it seems the Koreans were not that affluent when compared to China or Japan.

The best palace in Seoul. Gyeongbokgung is the largest and so I'd recommend choosing this one over any of the others. You have the addition of the National Folk Museum once you're inside. Tickets are dirt cheap! The palace isn't open on Tuesdays which I thought was a little odd but other than that, we had no problems getting in.

I enjoyed walking around in the palace. It gives me a rough idea of the rich culture of Korea. Nice place to do photo taking and what makes me happy theres a free palace guard uniform wearing. My whole family manage to try the guard's uniform. We were able to watch also the guard changing ceremony. There is the restaurant and souvenir shop at the palace ground. Must see place.

If you are first timer in Seoul, include Gyeongbukgong Palace. Tagged as Palace blessed by the heavens. The largest among palaces in Seoul. One shouldnt miss watching Changing of Guards ceremony.. Relieve olden times and Be amazed looking inside Kings throne. They are just a few things to visit when youre inside the palace.
Beautiful Palace for Korean standards. However, if you have been to China or Japan you will be slightly disappointed. Nevertheless, definitely top of your list if visiting Seoul.

It was quite boring as I not a history lover.The palace was well maintained and the area was quite big.Nice place to take pictures to proof that u had visited Korea.I watched the guard changing ceremony and it was quite nice so I gave this attraction three stars.
hundred years building, is a landmark of seoul, how well the palace is, and very easy to go, follow by train.
Beautiful,the museum is wonderful,if you visit during the autumn it's a bonus it looks wonderful with all the different colours
This complex is huge and expect to wander through here for a day. If you're lucky, you will see reenactment of the palace guards and see it all lit up during the annual lotus lantern festival.

The palace is gorgeous and the ceremony of the change of guards is very entertaining and educational. Closed on Tuesdays but on all the other days the times are 9:00, 1:00 and 3:00.  Would recommend to those who want to see a little bit of the history of Seoul.
must see !! the garden was designed very beautiful. you will feel suprised with the pool, mandarin duck & birds inside the garden. even it's artificial garden but it's still looks natural.

Just like any countries it is best to visit historical places . It is a huge place. The paintings on the wall of the place was intricate . They were able to preserve some of the furniture used in the olden time. However the bad side is that you can only look from the open windows as visitors are not allowed to enter the rooms.  Make sure to visit during the change of Guard! During morning and the one we watched was during the afternoon at around 3 P.M.

Biggest palace I visited in Seoul. Is worth paying the admission tickets and walking through. There is a lot to see. The architecture is amazing, leaning about the culture is fascinating. The changing of the guards is a great show. This place is a must see in Seoul.
This palace captures the glorious history of Korea. This is very close to the Business Centre of the city and business travellers also can visit this place with just 1 hour break.
the palace was the last home of the last remaining korean royal family. a place that has a lot of history and tragedy. its beautifully maintained

It is a very nice palace, and gives an interesting glimpse of the Korea history and culture. But, to me, the most interesting thing was the changing guard ceremony. Complete, with drums, music, everything. Just fantastic, do not miss it. Site has schedules. Beware, it is closed on mondays - not on tuesdays, as site says.

I recalled all the K-dramas I watched set in the early history of Korea. It's a very huge place and it's great to note that reconstruction is currently ongoing at some parts. It's good how they continue to rebuild some of the parts of the palace. It shows how important and how they value the preservation of their culture. Changing of guards is one of the must watch activities when visiting. Tourists can also try to fit in the guard's costumes near the gate.

Visit this palace several times already,watch out for different exit. I always hear something new from tour guide when we visit this place so I always curious of any other story. You will see a palace complex with different usage, size and form. People in the old days really have great passion as you see on the building. This place is big and may be windy so prepare a jacket, March can still freeze you in this place. Take pictures with some buildings and as you walk out some dust may fly so walk slowly. For 1395 built, this palace still look amazing. Never iss this when you are in Seoul.

I and my family members enjoyed visiting this palace. And we had so much fun wearing the guard costumes and having some great photos, too. It was nice to see the moment of of guards changing the shifts.
every hour they change their gate guard and they performed guard changing ceremony, so nice and snappy to see. the palace was great and nice to visit.

This is definitely worth a visit, but you will enjoy exploring the palace more if you read a little about its history first. The lakes and gardens are a good place to take a break and rest a little while contemplating Joseon history.
We were there at sunset and stayed until dark. It was the perfect way to see it , since after dark it has a special magic. This should be on your shortlist if you are in the area.

So I came to visit this palace after visiting Tokyo's Imperial Palace 3 days prior. This one is a lot better and looks more authentic. There are free tours for various languages throughout the day. Make sure you get there on time, but even if you don't you can just search for the tour group and join them midway. They tour guides are very knowledgeable and they teach you a lot about the history of this palace. In my opinion, you need to visit this place with a guide otherwise you won't appreciate it's history and what each building represents.  It's better to go on a weekday. I did and there were plenty of areas where you can take photos without anyone in the background. Bring bottles of water with you because you are outdoors and it gets hot. There are no vendors except inside the museum, as far as I could tell.

The temple isvery nicely located and full of peace the architecture is very beautiful and needs personal attentin The area is fully covered by beautiful old trees The templealso reflect the life style of the king

I went with my mum to visit Seoul and for the pair of us we knew 0 Korean. It was definitely very easy to find the place and getting tickets was as easy as it could be with English and Chinese signs too.  The first thing we saw when we got there was the guard change over - I believe and it was really cool to see. The actual Palace itself was huge and you are free to look at most part. I really like it!

Gyeongbokgung Palace is the biggest palace in Seoul located in the center of the city.  Most of the area in the palace including the Throne Hall has been burnt but rebuilt is 20 century. You need at least 2-3 hours to walk around and to enjoy the great local Korean atmosphere with also group English speaker tour guide provided by the palace and it is free of charge. At every 2 pm the also have the guard patrolling show available at the main gate which worth to see and taking some photos too.  Within the palace, there is 2 museum available one is National Palace Museum and the other one is Korean Folk Museum, if you only have enough time to choose one only, the palace museum is what I would recommend.
Largely reconstructed but still stunning. Do not miss the National Palace Museum, which displays a lot of stuff from this an other royal palaces.
The palace is an interesting place to visit to learn about some of Korea's history. Make sure you arrive for the 'changing of the guard' ceremony.
buy the multi ticket admission for all the palaces to save money on entry. if you go to one palace head to this one.

Magnificent and beautiful architecture. You can simply walk around and experience the beauty but no enter is allowed. Sometimes can get very crowded. Bring a nice camera with wide angle lens and dress with colorful costume are always a good idea.

First visit was done alone and stupidly i covered the first part of the palace and left before exploring the back part of it. It was sooooo amazing to see the lake and different parts of the palace which really brought me to the history of how the palace people lived in the past. Take some time to sit by the lake and absorb the surroundings. You will really feel as if you were brought back into history. Go to the east side of the palace after you end the museum visit. There is a vintage corner which shows a tiny vintage cafe, photo studio and how the commoner lived in the past. Definitely worth that 3000won ticket price and I'm sure it's better with the english language guide to understand the history of the palace.

I have been to palaces in Beijing and so this is not really as interesting as to what I anticipated. I would recommend having a tour guide otherwise it will not be meaningful to walk through this. Guard changing ceremony is worth waiting for and definitely one of the key attractions to watch.
You should have a good camrea with, great for photo-shooting. Don't miss the gate guards changing shifts every hour, it's great.
Be sure to take the English guided tour to get the most out of your visit. It's free of charge (inclusive in the access fee) and very insightful.

Nice way to spend an afternoon wandering around beautiful parks and little pagodas, etc. Get an information pamphlet (like 500 KRW) so you can add some history knowledge to your gazing. They are available next to where you buy the tickets.

This is one of the must sees in Seoul. Easy to reach with public transport (subway station Gyeongbokgung or Anguk from where you can walk through some very nice streets), you can spend half a day walking around the palace grounds. Be aware that most of the buildings aren't original, but are restaurations from 19th and 20th century. The overall setting of this palace within super busy Seoul is amazing.

Do not be fool. This palace is amazingly big! I spent an hour and a half and still.didn't manage to cover all the grounds. Still, the lake area is amazingly peaceful. Pretty much own time own target too.

The natural beauty at the palace, it's manicured lawns, sprawling campus, the beautiful backdrop of hills were truly impressive. Having seen the magnificent palaces and forts of India, I didn't get awed by the palace buildings. Most of the structures had a similar build, simple but beautiful wooden structures. The palace is very well maintained. The most beautiful building was two storied structure built in the middle of a pond on the western part of the campus.  There is a museum with Korean cultural artifacts, nice to spend some time here. There is also a theme park based show casing a Korean village, nice for kids.
Love the place and people in traditional costume were professional. The hourly ceremony is interesting so don't miss it!

Basically it is a old castle with a big open court yard. There will be a lot of tourists getting off of fleets of buses. Lots of large tour groups, some with matching hats and tshirts.  There's not a lot of shade, it will be wise to bring some water, an umbrella, a hat, and some sunscreen. It is close to a lot of bus and metro stops.  Overall, it is something to visit after eating some ginger chicken and taking a breaking from shopping.

Well,maybe because i expected it too much so when i got there i was disapointed. If you wanna go there,it is not far from the station. But i forgot the station's name. It is kinda confusing to reach it,you must really remember the station's names since typical station in Korea are almost same. It costs about 3,000 won.

This place is huge, we spent 3 hours with a guided tour and we visited the buildings and grounds that are very important and have a royal history significance but architecture wise words could not explained how intricate and beautiful the place and the history is amazing. It is must if you visit Seoull very accessible by public transportation or do hop on hop off bus and that is one of the stop.

I was on a 1 day trip in Seoul, Ms. Guide was very nice and funny, she spoke very good English, so there was no problem to understand everything she said. Probably single trip would be more interesting, than in a group of random ppl, but I didn't have time for organizing everything by myslef. The company picked me-up from the hotel, so I didnt have to worry about anything. Unfortunately I dont remember how was the trip called and via what company. I've ordered it from the hotel. Palace is beautiful, very big, a lot of interesting places with museum, where you can learn something about history. The place is amazing but, like all places in this type, very crowdy, so it's very hard to take a good picture without random ppl.
Although the palace is recently restored, it's on a huge site with beautiful parks and lakes between the buildings. The folk museum is also worth a visit

Its good to be here and witness the guard changing ceremony.. we are lucky when we went there is a parade and also flea market held opposite of the palace. Great place for photo taking.. I prefer to came here durong winter. As summer is too hot to handle in an open area..

After a few hours of sleep, and just a tad hungover, we started our adventure to the historic Gyeongbokgung Palace. This palace was on acres upon acres of land. If you visit at the right time you’ll get to witness the guard ceremony at the front gate. We noticed a lot of visitors doing their usual “peace sign” photo ops at the front of the palace and then leaving the grounds which caused us to wonder whether or not we wanted to spend the 8000 Wons to go in further since no one else was going inside. I am so thankful we opt to pay. Once we were inside everything just seem surreal. It was honestly like going back in time, and the architectural details of the reconstruction of the palace and its surrounding buildings were magnificent. And quite frankly, after a long night of partying this was the perfect way to detox.

This is the first stop on the Incheon Airport Seoul City Tour. It is an amazing place but we were only there for about 45 minutes. If we are ever in Seoul for a couple of days, we would likely go back and spend at least a half day there. But if you are at the airport for a long layover, coming here on the 5 hour tour is sorth it

This palace in my personal Seoul palace rating gets well-deserved 2nd place. It doesn't differ much from acrhitecture point of view from other palaces, but nonetheless it's beautiful and impressive. Guard ceremony is interesting. You can check times of ceremony at the gates - there is info sign with schedule and type of ceremony.
An excellent palace with so much to see... the change of guards ceremony is a must see as it reflects the local Korean culture and is colourful...

I ended up going on a day when there weren't any performances going on, but they did have guards that were traditionally dressed at the entrance. It wasn't too crowded, but it was fairly difficult to get a good view of the blue house because a good amount of the tourists congregated at the viewing area. The palace grounds were gorgeous, and getting to go to the Folk Art Museum was also great. The girls I went with and I just kept looking at the museum from afar until we finally worked through the palace grounds and figured out what it was. The mock village that was set up was pretty cool too.

Unfortunately wooden structures tend to burn down over the centuries. This is a neat palace, but it's not that ancient. The free walking tour in Seoul (found at the official Visit Seoul web site) was nice, because they guide explained what we would have otherwise missed.
if you a Saeguk K-drama fan, u should come here to get the feeling. subway station: gyeongbokgung station, anguk station also can

If you only have time to see one palace in Seoul make it this one. There are free tours everyday: Tours depart in front of the Information Center at Heungnyemun Gate (흥례문). Duration: 1 hr - 1 hr 30 min Tour Schedule: English: 11:00, 13:30, 15:30 Japanese: 10:00, 12:30, 14:30 Chinese: 10:30, 13:00, 15:00  The entrance fee to the palace is 3000won. You can also buy a combination ticket for 10 000won. This will give you entrance to the following four Palaces: Changdeokgung Palace (including Huwon, Secret Garden), Changgyeonggung Palace, Deoksugung Palace, Gyeongbokgung Palace and Jongmyo Shrine.  Please note that Gyeongbukgung is closed on Tuesdays.  The changing of the guard is also worth seeing so make sure you time your visit with that. 3 times per day, 10 a.m., 1 p.m., 3 p.m.  After visiting the palace you can walk to Tosokchon restaurant to have its its signature samgyetang (chicken ginseng soup) made with glutinous rice, gingko nuts, ginseng, garlic and jujube, as well as 30 different types of medicinal herbs and grains. The line at the restaurant might be long but it moves fairly quiclyk and it is a must have when visiting Seoul!
Most amazing place for foreigners. Architecture and history combined at one stop. Not to be missed when in Seoul.

Originally visited in July 2011. Had a 12 hour layover in Seoul and took the opportunity to book a half day tour that brought us primarily to the Gyeongbokgung Palace. We were able to witness the changing of the guard ceremony and explore the grounds for quite some time. The colors of the clothing and architecture were memorably vibrant. Following our palace visit we went to the nearby museum to learn more about Korean culture and history.
Gyeongbokgung is the most interesting place in Seoul. You will see Korean traditional architecture in this palace. You can enter the area for free if you wear traditional clothes, Hanbok.

Huge palace with loads of history behind it. Good to have a rent a audio guide which is available at the information counter for a small fee of 3000 won.  The palace is repainted every 30 years. Thus, might look a bit too surreal depending on when you visit  Change of guards ceremony can be viewed at specific time. And need not purchase the entrance tickets if you just want to view this cause it happens outside the main entrance.

It was pretty nice, but a little dull and hard to find a nice path through to see everything. A lot of the buildings look the same. I found the insides more interesting than the outsides, but, of course, you're not allowed to go inside, you can only look through the window. There were a lot of school kids there on field trips, but I didn't find it annoying. We were used as props in pictures for what we figured was some kind of scavenger hunt, which was amusing. Unfortunately, we came on a day when there was a concert, so we didn't get to see the changing of the guard :(

I and my family were so excited to visit to Korea. I got strong impression when I had company trip to Korea several years ago. At that time, I decided to be with my parents. Especially I was comfy with strong security in Korea and Korean were quite kind and warmhearted. Anyway it is very recommendable to visit Korea with your family.... I went to two palaces as my guide's recommendation... actually she preferred 2nd palace named Changdeokgung palace.Gyeongbokgung palace is representative, I was told it is the biggest one... it looks like forbidden city but it was built up around 30 years later than Gyeongbokgung palace. I went to Chankdeokgung palace as well. it is 2nd palace... there are 5palaces in Korea. the second palace was completely different.. it is also recommendable with many interesting history.SEEING IS BELIEVING.My tour guide was very enthusiastic and her story telling was so helpful to understand ,catched our concentration and touched us.. it was one of my strong impressing in Korea until the end day.. My collegue let me know one tour agent in Korea. We stayed for 5days, except for one day, we joined guided tour with her. she was very proud of their company(tour agent).. she was professional. When you travel to Korea, I want you to be with a good tour guide with very forsure agent. The agent name was very unique.. Anneonghaseyo Tour.. haha..It was available to have costomised tour with very reasonable budget...I was told it was handled by family that's why I could trust much more than other contries for trip. If you have any plan to travel to Korea, contact here.. I have business card of that agent.. Everyone will be satisfied with ...

This place is huge! Palace buildings have intricate designs with beautiful surroundings (ponds, trees, etc). The guard changing ceremony is a must-see, an amazing experience indeed. The official English tour provided for free is also very helpful. Highly recommended.

I visited the place with one of my Korean business partner and he made a digestive short history of the palace, king and following Japanese occupation. The palace has been restored to a very original condition and there are plenty to learn if you want to understand Korean pride.

Tried to explore all area of the palace and strolling under huge ginko tree really made my day. No need to hurry if you want to find hidden gems in here. If you visit with hanbok, you don't need to pay admission fee.

The palace is very impressive, especially being in downtown Seoul. The best part was underneath the King Sejong statue in front of the Palace gates. There is a huge museum underneath, with a lot of cool Korean history. There was a good Turtle Ship section with a big 1/3 scale model you could go inside. Overall the palace itself was too packed for me, but the museum under the statue was fun to see.

If you were to go to one of the palaces, i recommend this one. We went on the weekend and there were some students who offered to be free tour guides (to practice their english) . Spent about 3 hours on the palace grounds

Never fails to be impressed by the architecture and history of the place. Going there on a Saturday means jostling lots of people.  Easy to get to the place using the subway. And from the palace there are other attractions nearby, notably the "Stream".
big palace with great architecture... changing guard ceremony, you have to see it.........................

this palace is quite huge and has so many colorful buldings. the details are amazing. gyeongbokgung is the largest palace in korea. if you like history and culture, i suggest you to buy integrated ticket for palaces, including jongmyo shrine and secret garden guided tour, only for KRW10.000

It is the biggest palace out of the 5 palaces in korea. The admission ticket cost around 3000 won per adult and it is easy to walk around even without tour guide.. there will be royal guards changing ceremony and we can either watch it from in front of the entrance or inside..it's quite interesting and quite a sight..nice..

I came here because it is among the top of the list for Seoul attractions. For me Seoul itself is just a hype. Maybe due to k-wave. You don't have to enter the castle. Just stay outside to see the performance around 10am.

It is definatly worth a visit but don't expect too much. Korea is still rebuilding and getting their sites back to their former glory after the Japanese occupation. It was good and it is worth a visit but I would recommend a walk around changdeokgung palace and it's secret garden if you only have time for one
If you've been to the forbidden city I would say skip this palace. Being newly built, It feels more like a movie set than a walk through history. Maybe in a hundred years it will gain some character.
The well-preserved palace is a must-see attraction in Seoul. Be sure to take the time to wander around its extensive grounds.

I had been to the palace before during the day and it was very nice, but this time there was a week where it was open at night time (normally closed at night). It was 3,000 won for a ticket, but was well worth it! Only 300 foreigners were allowed to get tickets.  The palace at night was very different and a different experience. If you are lucky and visit during one of the few times it is open at night, GO.

Took my son's fiance and her dad when they visited last week. Palace is big and will take at least 2-3 hours to see it all, so plan accordingly. If your visiting in the spring or summer have water with you. There are tours in various languages (English 3 times a day) and they are part of the fee. Plenty to see and more is being added as the restore the palace.

One must go for it. It is one of the Korean traditional cultural places. It has a garden as well where you will find various colorful flowers and trees. Very nominal entrance fee.  Visited October 2014
Very well staffed palace and grounds it is worth it to take the tour of both the palace and the secret gardens.

Go and enjoy the traditional Korean cultural sights in the palace! But prepare for the scorching hot weather. Also some steep steps and all to climb. Worth a visit definitely - especially if you are interested to view some traditional and cultural artefacts!
Nice palace, and a big site with extensive gardens and a folk museum (think history of Korea), to visit.  Only cost a couple of quid, definitely worth it.
Gyeongbokgung Palace, the most beautiful and largest of all five palaces. free guided tour provide and well explains the culture and building structure.

I visited the palace in the first week of april 2015..such an amazing traditional korean palace and a must see if you are planning to go to Seoul. You can imagine what stories happend behind those old doors during the royalty days

For people who are patient and have enough time...This beautiful palace has a hidden gem! If you enter the palace and have the folk museum on your right make sure to go to the left ( west) You will enter the garden grounds and tour pick up point. The garden is beautiful with temples in the lake!

I was staying in an apartment right in front of the Palace.  This royal palace is imposing by its size and its majesty. There are tour guides to take you around the palace.  Everyday, at every hour between 10 am and 3 pm, soldiers in costumes of the time when the palace was created (1395) march in musique for the change of guards. It is fun to watch.

We visited the palace whilst attending a family wedding. We had recently seen a program on TV documenting the rebuilding of the palace and to see it in reality was just awesome. At the time of our visit it was during Korea's Labour Day celebrations with various displays taking place. A spectacular none of us will ever forget.

It's a beautiful palace, huge and peaceful compound. If you really want to reap the benefit of the histories behind, grab the free tour guide available near the ticket counter. Walk around, take your time. Visit the place in the morning or later in the evening since it's more comfortable. We went there near noon approaching end of spring, so yeah, the sun was not exactly nice to us :D.
Nice place and very large place, very good for exercise ..There are free guides for foreigner and Korean...Clean and tidy
This is a huge place including a Presidential Museum which is worth seeing. Beautiful grounds and buildings. A good few hours are required to see it all and it's well worth it
Nothing much to see. The guards are unusually dressed in red and blue and are worth a look. The palace is a series of bulidings in a large walled compound with gardens and plenty of gravel.

The palace complex is huge with many beautiful buildings. The grounds are usually quiet which is a rare delight for a location in the middle of Seoul. The history about the palace is well explained and very interesting also.
You should visit during guard change hour. It's quite nice to see the tradition ceremony. The palace is quite big and worth seeing
The palace is located at central Seoul and offers english speaking guide. its easy to go there (metro and taxi).
interesting and indeed a must-visit place but at the same time there's nothing too much to see. the palace complex is huge and beautiful, though.

This palace is amazing. It's absolutely humongous, with a large park around. The buildings are beautiful, and provide a nice insight in past Korean building style. Also, the clash between the palace, The mountains and the 21st century city is entertaining. We went on a Sunday and stumbled upon a Taekwondo demonstration at the Folk museum, great fun!
Having seen a number of Palaces this was by far the best as we were in time for the changing of the Guard ceremony. It is extremely colourful, loud and bewildering but a great experience.
This place is quite large, clean and well managed. Old buildings reflected the royal life of the Korean leader long time ago.
Great history and architecture.Don't miss costume parade. Also see the Folk Museum nearby. Facility accepts credit card, but the entrance fee is very nominal.

This palace is somewhat like a "mini-Forbidden City," and is definitely a must-see. If you do not view the Changing of the Guard ceremony - about an hour, it is most difficult to convince your friends that you have actually been to Seoul.

Beautiful palace of the empower. Very extensive compound of old buildings and relics. I wish we'd had a tour guide to tell us more about the place, but it was still pleasant. Very in expensive to visit. Be sure to go all the way to the back where it is more green and there are beautiful koi ponds.

I thought I was just going to spend a few minutes looking around this place. Well, I didn't realize how large it was until I spend hours trying to just explore it. The place had several buildings (not just the main palace) and it had really nice gardens and bodies of water. Then it was quite a surprise to see a really awesome view of the mountains at the back of the palace. What's just as amazing is how accessible it was. All that you needed to do to get there is to get on to their really convenient train system and hop off at the station right next to the entrance of the palace. Really a must see. If I had to visit only one place in Seoul, this would be it.
Great place....and bring along your handycam... record the changing palace. It did have certain time... and the place is so nice. Especially during spring.

Palace is huge and gives you good idea how kings lived in Korea back in the days. Great historical experience. Guards change is highly recommended - happens only couple of times a day so make sure to visit at the right time.
If you choose just one palace to visit in Seoul, choose this. It's beautiful and in a huge area so be prepared to walk a lot. There is also a beautiful lake with a little island and temple.

On our first day in Seoul, my spouse and I visited this Palace which we came to know as one of the five largest palaces in Korea and was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty. The palace was aptly named Gyeongbokgung Palace - "the Palace Greatly Blessed by Heaven". This palace has a remarkable history as it was destroyed by fire during the Japanese invasion and it took years to rebuilt and restore this palace. We feel blessed too to be able to see this majestic and beautiful palace. We toured the numerous rooms such as the Throne room, Pavillions, the Pond, part of the Queen's residence where the garden of the four chimneys of Amisan are located. The distant Mount Bugaksan and Mount Namsan can also be seen from the Palace grounds.

This is where you can feel the richness of Korean History. The palace is beautiful, ancient and well preserve. You can take a lot of good pictures in this palace, there are many hidden details to catch, like the window locks and wood frames. It was Thursday, 11:30 am when we visited and almost every ground in the palace is already crowded with tourist and kids on excursion. We got lucky to see the changing of the guards in the main gate. It is very interesting ceremony. This is a must see!
it was my first impression when I first saw the palace. It is really hige and grand where it needs a huge effort to maintain its condition!

The changing of guards ceremony is like a scene in a Korean darama series. The experience will bring you back to the past. The architecture of the structures and the huge area will give the tourists a good view of the history and stories from the early dynasty and the King's life.
Spacious, beautiful, worthwhile seeing. Minimal cost as it be seen with 4other palaces for 10,000 won. Great value. Take time to see the museum as well.

My family and I were very lucky to be able to see the Changing of the Guards. It was huge and beautiful! I am so amazed by how they were able to preserve the palaces with minimal modernization (well, minimal from what the eye can see). Should you visit, make sure you're at the palace by 1pm or 3pm. They have the Changing of the Guards and it's such a sight to see.
There is the guard change 2 a day. The museum provided good English guides and labels. There is a museum shop at basement - good prices equal to common shops but better selection.
we went to see this place with my daughter and worth the trip. we are there early morning not much people so we have a good view of the place
Highly recommend it.. Best time to go early AM because much less tourists around. Very good place to see and experience Korean history

This palace is huge! There's a lot of nice grounds around the area. It was more fun to take the English tour in order to find out a little about some of the buildings, etc. It was a free tour, just check for the times. There are a couple of museums in the area that you can go to also, which were well done, but not the most interesting museums, to me. Also the blue house is outside the gate and there's cool areas of Seoul all around the palace.
You get to walk around freely around this well preserved historical palace. Wonderful and mesmerizing.

I thought this was going to be a 15 minute activity, max 30 minutes. See the palace, take a pic and get out. So mistaken! The grounds of this place were huge! Go on a clear day and you get views of the mountain in the background. There's a free folk museum too which is rather interesting (coming from someone who doesn't really like museums...). Get away from the main temple because that's where the tour groups gather.

The complex was great to see and explore. Most things have an english translation, so it is very US tourist friendly. I did the audio tour and there was a good bit of history, but not as much information about how the buildings were used as I would have liked.

This is a very large palace. It is often the most commonly cited palace but make sure that its not the only one you see if you are time-constrained. The Changdeokgung (UNESCO site) is a more balanced better choice. If you intend to see at least these two, save some money by getting the all palace pass.
Attracts many so plan early if you want good photo ops, else enjoy the people. My second visit here and it was only average. I believe I would enjoy it more if I had a historical guided tour.

Although a small amount of buildings are original, most of the buildings on the palace are actually rebuilt after they were destroyed throughout history (fires, japan invasion, war ...). They still accurately show the way of life and style of the times of the emperors.  I advice you to take a guide, otherwise you'll be a bit lost like we were, looking at gorgeous buildings but without knowing exactly what they'r history is.

The place very accessible by metro and very interesting guard changing ceremony (traditional costumes) that performed hourly. Free guided tour in different languages are available, just look out for the time slot. The tour about an hr and the guide was knowledgable. The last stop was at the pavilion which is the shooting scene for Kdrama (Moon embracing the sun). The musuem is free entry with good details of Korea history and culture.
Lots of people from different countries. The place full of history, very beautiful, very colorful, must see! Children will certainly like it.

There are free tour guides on selective hours for selective languages to explain on the building, cultural and also history of Korea. You can feel the atmosphere of being in a palace during the ancient time. It is definitely worth a visit to know more on Korea history and also the beautiful scenery is really great.
We were there at the time of a changing of the guard ceremony and it was very interesting. Definitely a must see part of Seoul.
Stopped by the museum and learned a lot about Korean history and culture. The grounds and very nicely landscaped and the buildings very grand. This is one of the best places for photo opportunities.

You can't possible visit Seoul without making a stop here. The guided tours are free and interesting. And the photo opportunities are endless. Make sure you walk towards the back which includes a pavilion situated in the middle of a lake and accessed by a stone bridge.

On the Seoul tourist board site, you can reserve a free guided tour (in english) of Gyeongbokgung Palace. We met our tour guide in front of the ticket booth and were fortunate to see the changing of the guards at the palace (check times and dates). Through our helpful guide, we learned about the Japanese administration building that was built during the japanese colonial rule symbolically at the main gate of the palace. It was only destroyed and the magnificent gate replaced in the 1980s. As you walk through the imposing buildings which are elaborately painted, we learned the paint was imported from China and at times cost more than the buildings. Don't miss the interesting sun-dial in front of one of the king's main rooms. Nearby Gyeonbokgung Palace is the traditional korean neighborhood (Hanok Bukchon village) with nice small shops, art galleries and restaurants.
Went there during winter and it's quite good for taking pictures. But other than that, there's nothing much you can do there

All of the palaces in Seoul are amazing. We were fortunate enough to enjoy our visit this time during cherry blossom time. The history is very interesting and the place very peaceful and relaxing to just stroll and spend time.

Unique and gives an insight to Korea's history and its architecture. Has a nice museum that contains a lot of interesting information about their culture and their past as well. Wait for the changing of guards at the entrance, grab a brochure while waiting, it will tell you what the guards' attire represent.

The area of the palace is pretty big and very nice to walk in. My "minus" is, that the temple as an attraction itself is not really old, but newly built. In my opinion, there are more beautiful, authentic temples in Asia... Awesome during cherry blossom season (which lasts only for about two weeks ;))

It is a huge palace but basically looks the same after awhile. Interesting to see the guard change ceremony. Probably the only one that worth seeing, the rest would pretty much be smaller scale than this one.

The palace was so beautiful. There were several lovely buildings including one on the water. The roofs and beautiful decorations under the roofs were incredible. The grounds were quite peaceful and I could understand why there were so many visitors.  We were lucky to be there on the weekend when they have guard marching ceremony. Quite colorful and enjoyable.

I went there with a guided tour for a hole day that included this magnificent Palace. Located north of downtown dn near the Cheokbokung Palace. There are so many different beautiful buildings in this áreas de the different trees in Bloom, ( before entering They Tokyo us to de National Folk Miseum which is very nice!), you really need a lot of time to see everything, but we were so walking so fast. At the end is the principal "keep" with the little lake around it that made an idillic pictures! Wonderful! Entrance is 3000 son (2400 for groups of ten or more persons); children 7-17 pay 1500 ( or 1200 for more than 10) under 6 and over 65 are free. Closed on Tuesdays and always open At 9:00 a.m. . Closes between 4-5:30 dependiente on the month. This is a MUST visit while en Seoul!

If you just want to have a sticky beak without paying for a ticket (though they are VERY cheap - 3000 or 4000 won I think), you can go inside the first gates and walk around the courtyard area.  It's quite a lot of walking, and bit rough for the pram/stroller, but doable none the less.
Such a beautiful place of you love history. There's also a resting place where you can drink coffee.  Changing of guards also happens during weekdays.  My fave place is the Museum.

We had a luck to see guard change with all their ancient picturesque costumes,we joined to free English guided tour , there are few such tours each day ,it take about 1.5 hour,and we spent another 1 hour there to make pictures. Thicket cost 3000 won seniors elder 65 years free.

We toured Gyeongbokgung Palace with a guide Who was certain to get us there in time for the colorful changing of the guard! Despite a chilly gray day, we enjoyed the ceremony along with a huge crowd. After wander through of all the buildings/grounds, we also stopped into the Korean folk history museum that lies just beyond the palace grounds. Good way to spend a few hours of your tour-time in Seoul.
During weekend, there are guard changing ceremony. Very cultural sight. We rented audio guide. Great value and we learned a lot (even our 7/8 years old kids)

I ended up spending 5 hours here. It was great. They have the changing of the guard several times a day which is quite dramatic. I took a free English speaking tour at 11, but they have them at various times. Then I went to the Folk Museum at the end of the palace complex, and the National Palace Museum at the front of the complex. Great way to spend the day for only $3. Highly recommend.

I traveled here as part of the Free Seoul City Tour available from the Incheon International Airport tourism department. Our group of 20 was guided by a very well versed and knowledgeable guide. The grounds are absolutely beautiful and very well maintained, as is the palace itself. The backdrop of mountains and cherry blossoms certainly add to the mesmerizing experience here.

The palace was quite huge. However, I didn't feel tired of walking as the surrounding was very captivating. Enjoyed watching the change of soldiers and also the architecture of the entire building. Totally a must-not-miss place of visit

Well maintained and proudly displayed - this palace and its' surroundings are a must do while in Seoul. You can have a sense of the history and pride of the Korean people. You can spend a lovely afternoon on a 'date' or with your entire family. Was only 3000 KRW (3 bucks). Highly recommended
Discover the very first palace in Seoul, explore the different parts of the palace and don't forget to have your photo taken with the door guards.
It is not glittery, rather simple for a king. Yet it was an enjoyable place. Sit around the lake and enjoy the view and cool air especially in spring.

The visit of the Gyeongbokgung Palace is definitely nice with guided Chinese Tour (as my mum is visiting). The guide is FOC as per ticketing but you need to follow the timing if you are visiting. There are four languages namely Korean, English, Chinese and Japanese. The areas inside those palace are forbidden to entry as more Chinese Tourists are visiting such places, they like to touch the historical structure which will damaged them. As the structures are slowly built due to fire and war damages. Overall, the guided tour is good. After the tour, you may exit the back door and you will see the Modern Korea Prime Minister Office and Ministerial Offices. You can go back in to the Palace with the tickets. Right at another corner is the Museum of the old Korea where you see items from the different Dynasties to the old villages of Korea.

Do not forget to catch the changing of the guards. We caught the 4pm one at the main gate, and it was such a colorful treat! There weren't a lot of people when we went there, so we were able to go around and enjoy the serenity of the place, especially the part beside the pond/lake.  Read more about it in my blog: https://jeffer.wordpress.com/2014/03/23/south-korea-pt-2-a-dose-of-royalty/

the large compound of mostly reconstructed buildings is worth a visit and the small admission fee. guided tours in English help visitors understand the historical significance. it's a great spot to take pretty photos of the typical Korean architecture.

Nice place to visit as you can see the old architecture design of Korean palace. From there, you can learn more about their King & Queen buildings. Interesting to see how ancient korean guards warm themselves and how the smokes are channeled to another buildings. Amazing too to see how they maintain their buildings (nets are around the roofs, or sharp small sticks around) to prevent birds droppings on the wooden roof).

Gyeongbokgung is more for sight-seeing as the rooms around the palace are mostly enclosed. The sceneries surrounding the palace is scenic especially when I visited during winter. Don't miss out on the changing of guards ceremony which is the main focal attention of Gyeongbokgung. There is also a booth for you to try on hanboks.  For those of you who are expecting a museum-like setting with artifacts and exhibits, this palace is not really like that. For that, you may want to visit Unhyeongung, located quite nearby to Gyeongbokgung. Unhyeongung's rooms are more open-concept with artifacts and multilingual (Korean, English, Mandarin & Japanese) descriptions of every exhibit.
Since this is the biggest palace in Seoul, of course you should see it. Lots to see and photograph, even though it is much reconstructed.

A vast piece of awesome architecture coupled with unique and authentic South Korean Heritage. Love seeing the Palace up close. Reminds me of the Forbidden City in China. One of the best tourists spots in Korea!

Whether you have 36 hours or a more extended stay in Seoul, you should definitely stop by Gyeongbokgung (gung = palace). There are several palaces in Seoul but this one has the largest compound. If you don't much about Korean history, I would recommend the guided tour (which I think is free) and is offered in several languages and throughout the day. It's interesting hearing about the function of the different buildings and getting a sense of Koreas's imperial history. Definitely must see/do.
Beautiful, impressive and interesting. Be sure to catch the change of guard. This season is great since most of the trees were in blossom.

The palace is of course a must see. It is an awesome sight that shows a lot of the history of Seoul and Korea, However, it doesn't "breath" this history as you would hope. Large parts of the original buildings have been destroyed in the past and are now rebuild. So it feels more like a life size museum or rebuild than like an ancient place. If you set your mind to this, you will still be able to see the beauty of the place.
It was absolutely lovely, entrance fee is only 3,000 won and it is nice to spend half the day there slowly exploring the beautiful architecture!

This palace is pretty crowded, but for a reason. The architecture is stunning and the detail in construction is remarkable. It is big and will easily take up a lot of your time if you wish it to. If you come to Seoul, you have to see Gyeongbokgung.

When visiting this palace, you should join the tour as this will help you understand the story behind the palace and the Royals. Schedule your trip before hand so that you can try the free Hanbok wearing, watch the changing of the royal guards, and tour of the Palace on half day. Visit the palace in the morning as there are more people in the afternoon.

The site is huge, and there are so many aspects of the property that the best thing is to join a free tour so that you can learn as much as possible about life in the palace. Certainly worthy of a visit. Plan at least 2 hours.

Enjoyed a half day visit to this palace. Entrance cost was cheap, but would get more from the visit with a good guide - I recommend one for best experience. Changing of the guard is quite nice and very colorful attire.
There were guided tours in English! The place was huge so even after the tour there were more places to explore. the tours have set time so you can explore and come back to join the tour.
Its a must to visit. This place is full of culture and history. Best to go with a guide so that they are able to explain every details

clearly one of the things not to be missed in SEOUL, if you are into monuments. I have lived 5 years next to the palace to know it quite well under many different seasons, Winter can be quite nice with SUN and SNOW. Expect people but the palace is big, however not as big as the FORBIDDEN City in BEIJING. There is a FOLKS museum inside that is worth visiting (you need 1.5 h) and you can have a lunch there, quite nice to take a break from the busy city. Dont expect to see much furniture into the buildings, Korean Palaces are always very barren...the whole thing makes an enjoyable experience for a half day.

What an amazing experience to see up close many of reconstructed and existing palatial buildings. I was also impressed at my tour guides knowledge of history. I just wish that the Japanese army had not detroyed, desecrated and simply made such a mark on these grounds. The grassy patches near the Queen Dowager's residence really made me feel sad. You must visit these palaces while in Seoul!
The palace consists of many, many buildings. Design, painting and architecture of those buildings are almost the same. The main gate and the place hall are the most beautiful ones.

Seoul and Korea itself has many palaces scattered all around. Gyeongbokgung Palace is unique as it now has a change of guards routine and also reenactment of guards training all about its compound.  You pay a fee to enter the palace compound and you can have a guided tour in various language. If you are not a museum/palace sort of person, just enjoy the attractions outside the paid palace compound.

Enjoyed walking the grounds and seeing the beautiful painted buildings. Some have furnishings you can glimpse from the doorway. If you are 65 or older it is free to enter. There were many tour buses when we arrived but it was not over crowded. You can also watch the colorful changing of the guards. Enjoy!

Very big temple area, try to get there when the guards change. This area is very big and you can easily spent 2-3hours here. Remember to bring good walking shoes and not clip claps. You can buy a guided tour, or just go there yourself, easy to find. If you have the time go visit the folks museum next door.
Take a walking tour to get the most information about these many buildings and how people lived here. Catch the changing of the guards.
Not much info onsite, so I focused on architectural details instead. In this part of the world, there are truly grand examples of this style.

this is 1 of the 2 palaces you can visit in Seoul, it's probably the main one people visit, it's truly magical and picture perfect. it gives you a great sense of how the royalties lived and there's so much history in this place, even though a lot of the buildings were not the original as some of them have been destroyed by fire, but they did a great job of reconstruct them to their initial appearance. I enjoyed it a lot and spent about 2-3 hours there :)

We were amazed at how beautifully presented all the buildings were. They were lacking in information though, even the tour guide didn't tell us much. Great place. Must see. Do some research before so you know more about it.
I really reminds me of the Drama RoofTop Prince, and that's the reason we're here too.  #MickyYooChun #MyInspiration

This is, if not the most beautiful and biggest among the 5 grand palaces in Seoul. Go early as it does get busy around mid-afternoon. You can spend a few hours in here getting lost in the beautiful traditional architecture and the atmosphere. That and you are standing where in the past royalty have been.

Surrounded by the modern city buildings the Temple is a haven of tradition. Close to the Metro it is easy to get too. The Temple is a traditional Asian style of open spaces and exotically roofed buildings. I do always feel that more could be made of the internals of the buildings. With traditional furniture and features. Well worth a visit when you are in Seoul.

Gyeongbok Palace is a must see if in the Seoul area. It's still in process of being restored but well worth the trip. Not overly exciting but nice. If you time it right you can get the tour in English or Japanese.

must visit attraction when you are planning to go on holiday to visit Seoul, you must visit it twice in the morning and at night when they open the light, also during the day you have to watch the ceremony for changing the palace guards

Went to Gyeongbokgung as our first destination during our Korea Trip. It was winter, and was really cold. We saw the changing of guards session. The place is quite huge and it wasn't crowded during the winter
It's a beautiful antique castle. They have people dress up and shows of how they use to dress, and march for war. Definitely a place to visit in Seoul.
It's a large beautiful palace with a mountain as it's backdrop (sorry, I don't remember the name of the mountain). We were lucky there was no entrance fee when we went there!

We were there when it was the peak of autumn, and the beautiful palace garden was filled with bright colours. As many other reviewers would point out, it would be good to come in time for the guard-changing ceremony, where you get to see the different units marching around in the main square. You can plan in advance with the ceremony timings here: http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_2_1.jsp?cid=292853.  The grounds are clean and well-maintained, although I wouldn't wax lyrical about the sights (other than the garden yes). I might have unfairly compared this to Beijing's Forbidden Palace, but if you have been to Beijing, you might get what I mean. Nothing that much to see when you really look into each of the halls or rooms here.  It's a short walk to Samcheongdong (use the eastern exit, and work north for 7-10mins), so you could always plan to have lunch or teatime at one of the cafes or restaurants there.

You really haven't seen a "Changing of the Guard" until you've been to the Gyeongbokgung Palace. Strolling around the grounds gives one a lot of photo ops...but the Guards themselves were the highlight for me!

You've seen one palace, you've seen them all. There are sooo many dam palaces in Korea that I felt I had to go to as many as I could. I'd have to say this is my favorite but they all look the same with little differences... This one is special because they have people in costumes at the front and around the palace. I went during winter so I don't know if the other palaces just didn't have people in costumes because of the weather or because I was there so early or if they just didn't have them. But it was great seeing the customes and wondering how they were keeping warm in the freezing weather.

We got to try on the Korean traditional outfits for free. It was up for grab. We, four of us, put on the outfits, which I forgot the name, and took a photo. The photo seems like we were a fuzzy family, but, all of us were just close friends.

There are several palaces in south korea. I personally prefer this one. I didn't buy the package that includes tours to several palaces. Best time to go is during the change of guards where you can snap photos of the guards in traditional uniforms.
Beautiful Place. It was winter so there wasn't much greenery but it is still very nice. Also got to see the 'Changing of the Guards" ceremony. Very informative. Can't wait to go back in the summer.

The palace and grounds were rebuilt after Japanese occupation ended in 1945. For me this dropped it to a 4. A bonus is the grounds are next to the seat of government and a small museum that is a quick history of 1945 forward.
Very good spot to visit in Seoul. It is very interesting place, changing the guide is a great ceremony, don't miss it!

Entrance fee is not expensive. You can look around limited places in the palace but it's big and there are many places to see. There are some performances in particular time so check it out before you go this place.
Went when the palace was lit up for one night. It was beautiful. Definitely worth taking someone there on a date, or for pictures.

The Palace is spectacular, huge and majestic. Its a good place to learn about the History of Korea. It is also considered as a well maintain historical tourist spot. However, if you are not into historical or culture then it is okay to give it a pass.
Amazing place for some photography skills practices, its vary huge place you might need double battery pack ;)

Join the free guided tours for a more thorough appreciation of the beauty and the magic of this place. It's not just a pretty photogenic palace. It's a well preserved place steeped in Korean culture :)
You can't stop in Seoul and not make a trip here. We came during a changing of the guards ceremony. The colors and action were amazing.
It's a "Must Visit" palace if you come to visit Seoul. Very nice and big. Before going inside the palace, you should visit "National Palace Museum" in the front first.

A big Korean art traditional architecture style; Located in many station exit but i chose exit5 from Gwanghwamun station; As i came early opening 9am time; So wandered around at Cheonggyecheon canal area before heading these place.
