The palace itself very big space area; with many complex building inside; the Korean colorful rooftop style is so delicacy and charming; combined with Korean National Folk village museum; where admidssion fee already plus these 2 places visit with costing 3000 KRW from the palace entrance.

I've been in the palace last 2012 but then I decided to go again as I'm with my friends who are first timers. We went there at a wrong time as it was closed but instead, we stroll around the outer grounds of the palace. It was my first time in that area but I love there! We play under the big tree! It's winter but you can still see orange trees/ leaves around the area!  We came back here the next day. We arrived just in time for the ceremony. It was so colorful and by watching this, you will be amazed of their traditions and culture.We availed the English tour and it lasted for an hour. Very helpful indeed to understand its history and the place itself. How I wish I can turn back time!  In 2012, we went there in Autumn so it was full of color but this time since it was winter, the trees were already bald. But nevertheless, the beauty of the palace is still there.  Big palace, Rich history, Beautiful scenery.. perfect! :D

The palace grounds are huge, but after a while, all the buildings start looking the same. This is not like European palace with lavish decorations. Korean palaces seemed to have been very austere in the same-same sort of way. Or so it seemed after visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace. Plus, most of it has been rebuild not long ago, so it doesn't exactly look ancient.

This place offers the window of the rich culture of this magnificent country or should I say city. Well preserved historical palaces and noticeably clean environment makes this place a must to visit. The place is located inside the city itself so there will be no problem in getting to this place. There's a large parking space for tourist bus and private cars

Visiting Gyeongbukgung Palace is a great way to start off a trip to Seoul. Conveniently located near a train stop or bus stop, you can step through one of the gates from the modern world into the past. With the admission fee being very reasonable (₩3,000) for an adult, you can explore on your own or take advantage of a free guided tour. I recommend taking the tour which lasted about about hour to get more of the history of the palace then take another hour or two to explore and watch the activities of the Palace guards. Additionally, if you want to make a day of it, the National Folk Museum and Palace Museum are next to the Palace and a free attractions to round out your visit.
Nice Palace right in the middle of Seoul. Looks and feels just like a scaled down forbidden city. Take a tour it will help to understand the place better.

I was determined to go to Gyeongbokgung palace (it is closed on Tuesdays). It was a perfect centerpiece for Seoul. I was looking forward to the changing of guards ceremony but was cancelled due to the frosty grounds (it snowed two nights ago). I was a bit disappointed but managed to see the palace complex. I was very careful not to tread on the slippery grounds (partly also I had sneakers that don't grip well with ice). I suggest not going to the palaces at winter time as activities are cancelled. Facing the palace was the modern Seoul. It was a perfect mix of the ancient and the modern Korea which has shaped the country. I ventured the palace by myself and they offer free tour guides on fixed times (usually in the afternoon). The information center which is on the gate going to the main palace was very helpful and I was thankful that. (The information center has staff that speak Korean, Chinese, Japanese, and English).
Other than the palace itself I think the other attraction is the changing guard ceremony. I just coudlnt get enough of it.

It was a very huge place and beautiful too. We were lucky to arrive a few minutes before the Changing of the Guard Ceremony. Unfortunately, due to time constraint, we were not able to explore the place. Make sure to spend at least 2 hours exploring the palace grounds and visiting the National Folk Museum.

A historical place to visit while in Seoul. It is commonly packed with tourists, the area with all nice painted buildings. We strolled around the place roughly for an hour where we had many snap shots of the palace, of the trees and of the pond. Walking around the place might be exhausting but compensating with worthwhile experience. We were fortunate to witness the guard changing ceremony and their parade with all their traditional and colorful costumes and had some photo shots with the guards later. It was a wonderful cultural experience to be at Gyeongbokgung Palace.

This palace doesn't have the grandeur of palaces like the Forbidden City or the intricacies of temples like Angkor Wat. It is very cheap to visit it. But it's only worth visiting if you have nothing better to do.  The temples here aren't as interesting as the ones in Japan or China.

The place to be if you are a tourist and looking for a palace to view. Nicely painted buildings, details, and such. Packed with people. Lots of people. This was the only place that I encountered in Korea where the staff were actually not as polite as usual - don't know why. Must be all the foreigners.  The tops of all the buildings were wrapped in wire mesh to keep the pigeons off, and the grounds have a drainage issue with lots of water on the walkways making in wet and slippery (ice !).  Picturesque from a distance - try the "other" palace just 500 meters up the road if you are looking for pictures - Deoksugung Palace - it has a nicer feel to it and is a lot less busy.
My first snow experience is here. Fascinated to see all the snow beside the palace. Amazing view. It makes me love Korea more.
near the center of seoul. very accesible when you are inside you will feel like you are back to the old korea with the changing of guards and parade

I fancy history and this palace made me fantasize of living during the Joseon Dynasty. I am a fan of the korean TV series "jewel in the palace" and this place was the actual scene location of the said series. unfortunately, the royal kitchen is under restoration during my visit few days ago and this fix is expected to be done by 2016. i suggest if you visit during autumn or spring. it was winter during my visit here and most of the trees and grass are dried/brown. Though the buildings are so colorful, and the changing of guards ceremony is entertaining.  I suggest that you include Bukchon Hanok Village and Changdeokgung Palace tour on the day for this trip since these attraction sites are just located near to each other, esp. if you enjoy walking :)  For tour guide map, visit: http://www.royalpalace.go.kr/html/eng/guide/guide02.jsp?dep1=1&dep2=2  For info about this attraction: http://www.royalpalace.go.kr/html/eng/main/main.jsp  How to get here? - take the subway and alight at "gyeongbokgung stn" (line 3, orange line) - If you want to include a visit in gwanghwamun square, alight at "gwanhwamun stn" (line 5, purple line), enjoy the park while walking towards the palace. - or you may avail of the bus tour packages.  For more info, visit: http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_1_1_1.jsp?cid=264337  Changing of guards ceremony: 10 a.m. - 3 p.m. (3 times per day, 10 a.m., 1 p.m., 3 p.m.); 11 a.m, 2 p.m., 4 p.m. : only the guard exiting ceremony (for more info, visit: http://www.visitseoul.net/en/article/article.do?_method=view&m=0003001006003&p=en&art_id=52624&lang=en)

This place is one of the largest and well known places in Korea. It is interesting to see all the different building and I also saw the changing of the guard. This ceremony is a must see when you go to the palace. I believe it happens around 10 am. You can easily access the Palace off the Seoul subway.

Even though most of the place has been rebuilt- it is still a wonderful cultural experience. Try to come before 3pm and at specific times in the courtyard where you buy tickets you can try on the traditional guard costumes. It is a lot of fun. Plus they have tours in a variety of different languages so make sure to come early if you would like to go on one.

The ceremony starts at 1100 , 1400 , 1530 hrs. After the ceremony, you can take pictures with the guards. There is admission fees into the palace. hence we did not purchase the ticket. We just watched the ceremony which takes about 20 min.

A beautiful history to listen to. Better take pictures first. Then I recommend to attend the guided tours which are available in different languages at a scheduled time. A ground exhibition is also performed by the palace guards. And after that, visitors can take pictures wearing the guard uniforms. By the way, the entrance fee is only charged when you go into the palace. But for the grounds outside it (but still part of the whole compound) where the exhibition takes place, it is free for all.

Make sure you get there by 11am and get a good spot to take pictures of the change of guards. It is a beautiful palace and it looked amazing in winter. The lakes were frozen and the sky was blue....gorgeous!

A large open plan area with a number of interesting buildings that give you the feeling of the architecture. Watch the colourful changing of the guard ceremony and then take in the museum. Here you will get an insight into the social history of the country. Finally, if the folk dancers and drummers are on, this is a must see session in the auditorium. It's really an excellent show. Be prepared to spend a half day there. You won't regret it.

Palace very well upkeep and when compared to China palacce,this is far from it..disvovered that most items are written in Han languages. .so perhaps back then korea had copy from China . winter is ice every where n lakes are frozen..palacces are fantasy n n ever get sick if visiting palacce.
Huge area.. plan on spending at least 2 hours here, if you plan to cover the National Palace Museum and the Folk Museum. Don't miss the changing of guards ceremony.
I suspect even nicer in less cold seasons! We got lucky and saw the guards marching outside the palace entrance. Inexpensive to visit quite a bit to see.

I have been to this Palace twice now, and have still not seen every bit of it. There are many really nice things up towards the front that give you a really nice view of the history of their old kings. But, after that, these palace grounds are large and spread out, so lots to see. Very reasonable price, I think around US $7. It is really well maintaned, and I recommend an optional guided tour, no additional cost, and available in English. The changing of the guard outside the grounds is pretty interesting as well, you can do that without entering the palace.

This is an amazing cultural treasure, and definitely requires a couple of hours of time investment to properly do it justice. Make sure you pay for the entrance to go in (it's ridiculously cheap--maybe $5?) and try to watch the changing of the guard. The colors of the costumes, along with the music is truly a magnificent experience.

5 visits to Seoul, I came here thrice! I specially visit the place again as my previous trip I came in early autumn and mid autumn. Very much wanted a view of the palace in winter! It's lovely, the only thing is it will be more beautiful if it snowed. Simply loved this attraction so much! A great way to spend a morning in Seoul... I'll be back here again in the other seasons.

This place is huge, it’s impossible and pretty unfair to just squeeze an hour trip to this place. There are just so many things that left my curious soul wonders, how it was like hundreds years ago when the palace was first built, with its interesting and magnificent architecture – each with its functions and purposes. The palace then went through tests of time from various wars and attacks and some of what remains had been re-built and preserved impressively.  The buildings after a while would felt the same and boring. So we escaped to the garden with wonderful colours of autumn, and landscape of the Bugak mountain on the background. The view was so beautiful, making a popular spot for wedding photoshoots and photography outings. I’ve been to the palace twice – each to different sides of the compound. During both times it felt like going back through time, and getting lost in the history of Korea.

I visited this palace in the fall and was able to check out some really nice Korean history. The structures are amazing and well kept. And there was even a musical performance with traditional dancing. Located close to Insadong and other museums, it's a must visit for a traveler in South Korea.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is an awesome palace. In terms of scale, it is smaller than the Forbidden City in Beijing but equals it in splendour. One can't help but feel the rich history behind it and the traditions and ceremonies that it once held. Although it is Korean, there is a Chinese influence in the architecture and layout.  While we were there, we were fortunate enough to catch the Changing of the Guard ceremony at 1pm. This takes place a few times a day. The palace is one of the top-rated places we visited in Seoul.
If you want to know the history of this country, you must come here.
The place I most wanted to visit in Seoul. Why Buckingham palace when you have this in Asia? I'd vote Gyeongbokgung any day. Don't miss the change of guard!

This palace is an absolute must see in Seoul, they have a guard change ceremony every day at 1pm except Tuesdays, really impressive. The museum is close by and free of charge, good café over there for a short break and coffee.
The layout is very similar to China's palaces as it is based on China's principles. However it has it's own charateristics especially in the backhouse. Charming.

This is th only palace we've visited in Seoul. Overall, it was okay, nothing spectacular but full of history. I especially enjoyed the museum part and the opening march in the morning coz it showed a brief preview of what is was like during the early days.

It was relatively easy to find the palace by metro. We arrived at 2 pm just in time to watch the changing of the sentries at the gate. The entrance fee is considerably cheap. However, you can only look at the palace from the outside and are not allowed to enter the buildings. This was a disappointment as it is better to walk through the buildings. Because we didn't follow a tour, we were unable to understand the culture or history except by reading the description on the plaques or by looking at the Chinese characters on top of each building. It is a relatively big place with a lovely lake that was frozen when we were there. Before we left, we also saw the changing of the guards at 3pm. It was an interesting visit.

What you see in the Korean dramas are as perfect as this palace. Amazing architecture and landscape. You'll feel like a royalty as you traverse the surroundings. Try finding the secret garden too. Hold her hand and have a nice walk.

Much like the certain areas of the Forbidden City in Beijing, these are sets of buildings once used by emperors/royalty but on a regular day, they are mostly empty halls/rooms. Preserved well, though.

Even that this place is not recognized by UNESCO we found it quite impressive. There are plenty of things to see inside, to relax, think, learn... Definitely is the masterpiece of the Palaces in Seoul. My mouth waters when I think about this place again... The into drawback are the packs of tourist and even we visit with a freezing cold temperatures.

Again the palace had been mutilated by Japanese occupying forces. Infact the main frame of the palace was dismantled and a Japanese administration building was built right in the middle of the palace grounds. This building had just very recently been removed. Then they attempted to re create the original palace. The wood carvings on the ceilings are all gone, substituted with paper walls or just painted a plain green, To see what it had looked like, refer to the Forbidden City. The roofs are also recreated with cement instead of wood carvings and porcelain tiles and porcelain figurines. Very sad really. The Japanese occupying forces really even removed the historical past of Korea.

Certainly not the best palace we have ever gone to, the Forbidden City in Beijing is way better, but this palace is one of the best two that Seoul could offer. Granted, the architecture of the place was nice and grand. However, there were a lack of signs and enough explanations throughout the palace to explain what was in front of us. Try to go early to avoid the large amount of visitors.
This palace was featured in so many K-dramas (e.g. The Moon That Embraces The Sun)! Very pretty palace indeed and there is a lake somewhere in the palace!

First visit to this building But too bad since we were joining a tour package and we dont have enough time to explore the whole area. But I love the detail of the building.. with red and green colour domination. I should go again one day.
Beautiful architecture, managed to view the Guards' performance which was fun for the kids to do. Great photo opportunity. Lots of little shops and restaurants are located nearby too.

nice palace, can see some faint tint of chinese culture, been destroyed before however the stage pavillion is of original , so is the three chimneys located in the queen's garden. went during winter so it's of a calm serene feel but still fabulously grand.
full of tourist.. but like people say, you don't go to Seoul if you not go to this palace :) the palace is nice, even its crowded with tourist.. Nice experience

This review is only somewhat helpful to those reading. I watched the changing of the guard, which was neat, and went inside the museum next door, but did not go inside the Palace (I felt it was a bit over priced and I was pressed for time). The changing of the guard is a popular attraction, so I figured it was worth mentioning here - it was an ok experience. They change approximately every 20 minutes if I recall correctly.

We visited this palace during winter so it was really cold to walk around the palace. Since the palace was burn down by Japanese and during the Korean Civil war, all the structures were rebuild. Some of the parts were not rebuild because no one know what the original structure looks like. There were exchanging guards ceremony everyday which was a highlight for visiting the palace. Other then that, go to China visiting the Chinese Palace seem more educational.
It was a beautiful sight, snow falling and on the ground. Very busy at 10am and 3pm but inbetween a lot quieter. See Korean History.

This has to be seen at least once to understand the grandeur of the palace and the surrounding buildings and grounds. If you see only one palace in Seoul, this may be the best.  Our timing was good and we were able to see a fun reenactment of an ancient changing of the guard. The National Palace Museum and the National Folk Museum are both in the same complex (and these two museums are free; the palace itself has a modest entry fee).

To me, if you've seen one Korean palace you've seen them all, so if you're going to see just one, make it Gyeongbokgung. Check before you go so that you can get a tour. There are only three English language tours a day. The palace is a huge maze of buildings and it's easy to get disoriented if you're going through it on your own. Also, you have to go to the souvenir shop to buy the guide booklet, but it's only 500 won.
They maintain all of the artwork in its place beautifully... it was my first time in South Korea, I really miss the friendly people although the couldn't speak really good english.

Amazing amount of shops in those 4-5 shopping complexes that open until 4.30am! My favourite shopping complex among all these is Migliore. You need keep shopping and learn about the price before buying because you may find another stall selling the same piece of clothing cheaper. High quality Korean clothes and fashion accessories at great prices
It's not as luxury and huge if compared to Beijing Zhi Jing Cheng. Overall just walk around and take come pictures.

My main purpose is to watch the royal guards changing ceremony. I love to see guards wearing colorful clothings, with NO smiling face. Ritual are performed every day between 10am,1pm and 3pm in front of Heungnyemun Gate. Be there 30 minutes before ceremony started. You can enjoy photograph just next with guards, in 10 minutes session.

I really enjoyed visiting this palace and learned a lot about Korean history and culture. Try to come early to avoid to many tourists. Korean museum is very close and you can visit for free and reentry to the palace again.

Pros: Beautiful Palace, well-maintained, and has guides during specific timings. Sadly, I missed it. But it was a sight to see.  Cons: There are many opened areas, I would suggest to bring along an umbrella or visit the Palace at a less sunny timing. The signboards around the Palace are pretty scarce, would help if there are more signboards to help introduce more to the tourists who aren't following the guides around.

It sits on top of the city's main road, on the skirt of the mountain hill, located wisely and strategically,in the heart of the Korean Nation. It is an oasis in the bustling city of Seoul. Once you are inside it feels as if you are somewhere totally different. It has the King's and Queen's premises and several other building compounds. What's interesting is, they are simply and efficiently designed. When you see this and the other historical buildings in the city and compare them with the modern buildings, the architectures of that time were way ahead of this century. The palaces suggest that those people knew how to built so many complex structures beautifully and aesthetically thousands of years ago, but they lost their memories somewhere along the time. I wish this kind of simplicity, efficiency and some of the aesthetics were used more often in their modern government institutions and establishments as well as residential high rises. There is a free guide tour in English every hour or so, you can join her and enjoy the history and the stories of the palace. Also there is a guards' changing ceremony, it is interesting to watch. Sorry that I can't remember the times. The tree leaves' autumn colors are adding more romanticism to the atmosphere if you visit in late October/beginning of November.

Not much explanation in English. We tried getting audio guides but they were not available. Doesn't feel so special especially if you have been to similar but bigger places in Asia like the forbidden city.

When we arrived there, it was just about time of changing the officer of the palace... so watching it feels like we went to joseon dinasty... Love it... But seeing all the trees with no leaves because of the season, so I'm thinking, that this palace will look alot more beautiful in spring or autum.

Nice if you are into history and ancient architecture. Not too nice if walking around with kids due to uneven flooring slabs, plenty of steps. Good place for photography and watching the guards changing ceremony. Tosokchon is a hop and skip away though.

the palace is nothing to rave about, like most historical monuments in Korea, it was rebuilt recently, but the guides , who speak english, are so inventive and polite that they make the visit very pleasant

Great slice of history. Highly recommend to appreciate the extent of Korean documented history. And very well kept--the Koreans are obviously proud of this. The changing of the guard ceremony was fun, too.

Plan ur trip time carefully. Free english guided tour available at certain time(cant recall) pretty much strolling in the castle ground. The guards exchange ceremony is held in front of the castle gate (also at certain time of the day).
Very big place... in here like in a film Korean Dynasty.. There is a museum library inside this place, you need to visit it ...

This is a must if you are in Seoul as there are so much to see and do around the area Recommend that you can start the morning walking around the strip just in front of the palace where there is a museum of sort underground. Then have boiled ginseng chicken lunch at a nearby restaurant (there is a famous one nearby) before heading to the Palace. At the Palace ground, you can witness the changing of guards, and sometimes traditional dance performance, and also a visit to the museum inside. Spend the late afternoon walking along the street at the right of the palace (when you are facing the main entrance) which are lined with boutique shops and restaurants. You can also walk up the hill and look at the traditional houses.

Worth the visit as the place was really grand and it was right on the heart of the city. Get a good idea of how the ancient palace was and how the royals lived. Nice buildings and a nice park right at the back. Too bad most buildings were only rebuilt in the 1990s.

We did not really walk through all details but we admired the setting and space of the complex, the colors of Korea, the culture... Sit there just for the nature, or a walk at the garden and its nearby streets would be nice enough to spend the day.

Well worth a visit and hopefully you will be as lucky as us to get a student guide that will show you around and be informative and all they want in return is to practice their english. These guides were waiting at the exit from the Metro Subway station.
This palace has an extensive garden, beautiful ponds and in November, the leaves in the park were turning yellow, red and gold. A nice quiet place to visit even with lots of people.

Prepare to spend hours in this palace as you proceed from one section to another. You will get to see many different ranks of sections that you saw from K drama. Pretty interesting with various spot to explore.  This palace is huge so be prepare to have a little picnic in between your exploration by the pond to take a break to enjoy the scenery.

Built in 1395, this royal palace of the Joseon Dynasty is also known as Gyeongbok Palace. This is a fantastic palace situated right at the heart of modern Seoul downtown. A must-see for a visitor in Seoul, this palace showcases a medieval ritual of flag/march ceremony by modern soldiers trying to recreate the magic of ancient Korean empire.  A guide is recommended for exploring other various parts of the palace including interesting anecdotes about first writing of Korea, or how medieval Koreans used to keep their palace rooms heated without air-conditioning/gas heating technology.

We reached the Palace around 11plus on a sunny day. It's the perfect timing to take nice shots under the hot sun despite there is cold wind. We tour around the whole palace & wanted to visit the Rose Garden but it was too tiring after walking for so long inside the palace itself.  Each building structure is still in good condition and the beautiful scenary is unforgettable. Do have a heavy breakfast before you visit the palace in case you ended walking for hours without knowing it.  We were so lucky to see the guard parade around 3pm and its magnificent before we decide to come out from the palace.
I was only in Seoul for 3 days but this was the first palace I went to and my favorite out of all the ones I visited. It has the museum in the back which was free and fantastic.
Interesting and a good walk. Also many interesting things to see in the vicinity. I would recommend it.

The day I went was cold and rainy, but we still walked the palace grounds. We didn't have a tour guide, so we didn't have the history behind what we were looking at. I would recommend getting a tour guide if you do go.

I had a great time walking around Gyeongbokgung. It is a massive ground with awesome architecture, courtyards and gardens which make for attractive photo opportunities. The site provides a quick glance into the history of the palace. I had a very peaceful time exploring the entire place and if you are willing, you can leave the hustle and bustle of larger groups by venturing deep into the gardens.

Because the Korean Dram Jewel In The Palace, i went to korea and my tour guide let us visit this palace  This palace has huge area and the scent made me feel i was back to ancient Korea  Dont forget to take a lot of picture there to prove u are already in one of beautifull palace at Joseon Dinasty  U can see at severall time an ancient soldier changes the duty like at Buckingham palace ( i forgot what time)
Great place to take photos. Big enough area so that you can get away from the tourist groups. We went in autumn and the leaves were nice reds and yellows.

The lieu is too picturesque during autumn, the weather is fine, but it's too crowded. It is best to save a half day of your travel itinerary in touring around. If you want to hear and learn more about the Joseon Dynasty and anything related to the Gyeongbokgung Palace, it is recommended that one should be in the area at around 11 AM. There are women in hanbok who will tour you around and explain details of the palace which the internet won't.

Little of the original old palace remains, and the ground houses mostly reconstructed buildings and museums, but it's pleasant for a few hours' of walk and exploration nonetheless. Don't expect anything remotely approaching the grandeur of Beijing's Forbidden City, but what it has is well kept and presented.  Despite the presence of numerous tour groups, the area is big enough that finding a quiet, scenic spot all to yourself is easy, all just a stone's throw from the bustle of city centre. The cultural park area to the east of site is free of charge and many Seoulites happily spend leisurely time there.

This is a reenactment of the changing of the Royal Guards during the Joseon Dynasty. The ceremony itself can be seen from outside the palace on the street. To tour the palace, tickets are required. (I also enjoyed touring the palace.) The traditional costumes and ceremonial aspects of the ceremony were beautiful. I was told that research was done to make it historically accurate. The whole ceremony takes only about 15-20 minutes. For something that is fun to see and no cost, I would certainly recommend it for visitors to Seoul, South Korea!
If you do anything in Seoul, this is it. You can spend hours at Gyeongbok, and you can blow out your camera in the process. Recommend you take it slowly and explore all the nooks and crannies.

Huge courtyards! Beautiful place. You have to come here when it's sunny though.. Nice place to take pictures, i even saw a couple shooting there prewed pics here. The most interesting attractions was the guards that stood still like the guards in england, but with more colorful uniforms and hats..
It is amazing that you will find red leaves inside when travel in Autumn.

Beautiful palace. We would have left much earlier if we didn't jump in with the English tour guide. Probably would have given a lower review if not for the guided tour. Without the tour there wouldnt have been much to see.

A wonderful place to see. I saw some previews of Korean telenovelas but I don't pay much attention to it. Seeing this place, now I appreciate it more. A huge place and lots of history in it. It's worth a visit or 2. Take your time.

At the entrance the change of guard is colorful, and inside is great ; in smaller scale reminding of the forbiden city in Beijing . Going on the left hand-side of the buildings toward the north are gorgeous gardens, even nicer that the secret gardens of the East Palace, then continue clockwise south to the entrance, pass the street, turn left and a few blocks away is Insa-Dong. Seniors entrance is free.
Nice and beautiful especially when we visited because its autumn season. Love the colors and palace. I also enjoyed the watching the changing of Royal guards🍁🍁🍁
Excellent view of ancient history in a city that evolved around it! Grounds are well kept, convenient.

I really love it palace and open something new everytime. You can stay inside, look at palace or wall and see mountain or modern high-rise buildings. It is really lovely, you can take free excursion or go through to see Blue House
Don't miss the chance to visit this lovely palace and walk it's very large grounds. Gives a great perspective of the history in the region.
Change of guard is worth watching. The museum or place inside is small, nothing much to be seen. Ticket for just 1 palace is 3,000Korean Won.
take a good camera much time and enjoy it .....its just soo beautiful .... alone to go around sea the nature and the buildings all those colors
A very nice and easy tour. Please make sure you have an excellent guide who understands the complete history of the palace. Everyday at 10am the changing of the guards ceremony is a visual treat.

Had a very nice time here. The grounds are quite expansive, so put your walking shoes on. The English self guided walking tour was good. They didn't give you a lot of information at each site on the headset, so I would say that if you want more, sign up for a tour.

Yes! A very big one~~ We spend three hours here but still not able to make a round.. Maybe we stop too much. HAHA  My favourite band was here one the same time and day I was there.. But I missed them as the place is too big.. Visit the museum on the outside of the entrance before u left, U can learn lots regarding the palace there..  Two significant in one time.. Yeah! Gwanghwamun and Gyeongbokgung. Save the subway fare.. Plus, u can walk down to the Gwanghwamun Square to visit the King sejong statue and also the Admiral Statue..
Interesting architecture mainly the imposing gates Changingc of the guards, 3 times a day. The pond is interesting too
Great Palace, but tour is enhanced if take the audio guide. Check out the changing of the guard very interesting. Also Cultural museums on property are very interesting
It is a place you have to visit if you are in Korea. History and Korean tradition It is a place you have to visit if you are in Korea.

Visited this palace with my family on amazing autumn day in October. My wife attended the free guided tour and it was rather comprehensive. Connected to the subway and directions are clear. Worth a visit.

Having a trip to Seoul isn't complete if you're not visit Gyeongbokgung Palace. You can see a history of South Korea. Try to explore all the places and you'll find the ancient feeling of South Korea. It's very big complex and you'll find many traditional houses of Korea. They have free guided tour to explore all the places, they provide English, Chinese and Japanese speaking guide. Please pay attention to the schedule, at that time my friend and i missed and we just explored by ourselves and naturally followed the crowd of group. hehehe.. There is a big beautiful pond inside. There are more building inside and some places you need to pay the entrance ticket again.

Come with an open mind and don't expect the palace to blow your mind off. This palace is not the most beautiful, impressive and ornate palace in the world but it has it's own charm. I guess ancient Koreans are not into manicured gardens and jaw dropping architecture.  But there were beautiful gardens and the the palace is very well maintained. I had fun exploring the palace grounds and it was nice to find a spot to sit down, and enjoy the cool breeze and just relax for a bit.  Visitors get to see a glimpse of how the royal family lived in the past. There's even performance on the changing of guards at the palace gates.  And if you have the time, follow the tour. it was very informative and the guide was pretty jovial.
It sounds cliché... but you have not been to Seoul until you visit one of the five grand palaces built by the Joseon Dynasty. Gyeongbokgung Palace is the largest of the five. A must-see.

It was the only palace we visited in our trip and it was really big and gorgeous. We spend nearly half day at this palace and the National Folk Museum just next to the palace.  It was the beginning of autumn and the view around the palace is so gorgeous. We followed a free English tour at 11am for an hour and our tour guide gave a very good explanation around the palace. Very informative indeed.  Totally worth it and i would highly recommend a visit to the palace if you are visiting Seoul.

Learn a lot on the history of Gyeongbokgung Palace with the palace tour guide giving a good historical background of the palace ground. I already visited this place twice, once during a cold, chilly winter in December 2013 and this year in June. Never gotten sick of it. I am looking forward to the palace kitchen being overhauled!

Gyeongbokgung Palace is just a few minutes by foot to where we stayed. We booked for a free guided tour starting at 10am-11:30nn. We were 7 in the group including 2 kids. The guide gave us a very insightful overview of Seoul's history and it's architecture. The area is huge as well as the number of tourists. You can actually get inside and watch the changing of guards ceremony at the big open grounds just before the gate where you need to present the tickets. So if your schedule is really tight and just want some photos of the guard changing ceremony with their colorful outfits, just be there by 10am or 1pm, no need to purchase a ticket. Going out we passed by the Folk Museum and used the side exit that leads us to the Bukchon Hanok Village.

I visited many palace in Korea but this one was best one , when I entered the palace found a place which i could wear Korean dress for free and had 5 min time to take pictures with this beautiful dress . There is timetable for wearing dress so you have to wait in line for specific time , just 20 people each time can wear the dress not more . Don't miss cultural army marching in front of entrance too .
It's easy to get to Gyeongbokgung Palace by metro. The palace is big and has lots to see. I suggested not to go in winter cause it's too cold to explore the palace.
Amazing palace. The architecture and artistry are breathtaking. It is well preserved and well kept. Definitely a must see piece of history in Seoul.

Beautiful and very well maintained. Continue along King Sejong Ave. and see the King's and also Admiral Yi's impressive monuments - against the background of the mountains surrounding Seoul. Amazing, considering that Seoul is a very large city.

Aside from the mesmerizing grandness and vastness of this place, the free shows (re-enactments) outside the palace gates does all the difference. It's not everyday that you get to be in a grandeur palace with ancient-looking guards performing right in front of you.  This place should be visited by everyone who visits South Korea.

This place was well worth the time and walk. It's quite massive and full of history. You will find yourself taking photo after photo. If you have kids that don't like to walk much, make sure you have a stroller, etc. Highly recommend this spot.

When I visited this place in mid of October 2014, the troops parade has been started. I have to run fast to take their pictures. I was so happy to see them, feeling like in Joseon era. The whole building are amazing. I love the architectures of this palace.

ceremonial guards, gorgeous landscaped, well maintained grounds, organized and inexpensive. A lovely way to spend part of your day. Also if you just want to pass through on your way to other locals such as Bukchon and Samcheong. Enjoy

GyeongBokGung is perfectly located, with the packdrop of the BukHanSan mountain on one side, and the modern buildings of JongNo on the other. This makes for stunning pictures and an amazing setting. Also noteworthy is the grand entrance from GwangWhaMun Avenue (with the statues of Admiral Yi Sun-Shin and King Sejong the great), as well as the changing of the guard at the front gate of the palace. The palace itself is very nice, large and extremely well maintained, with a nice natural area (with gardens, lakes) on the North Side. I'm "only" giving it 4 stars because as the "national touristic attraction of Korea" the palace itself doesn't rival in size with similar world renown landmarks in other cities (Forbidden City, Versailles...) and people with very high expectations could get disappointed a bit.
this is where I found a picture perfect view. I feel like I'm one of the Korean novella star. The place is huge. I find it hard to find the exit bec. they don't provide a map

It is a grand palace with major restoration after destroy during the Japanese invasion. There are tourist guides with multi language which you can join at your own interest. The english speaking guide have clear pronunctiation and easily to understand. By standing in the palace, you can imagine and position yourself like you are in the dynasty of Joseon. It is a good experience to feel the ancient noble arts.

This is a very grand palace made of wood with all the pretty engravings. Gyeongbokgung is the place where the King sits in. You will get to see the original seat where the king sit in in Korea.  There are also guards standing outside the door and if you are lucky enough you will get to see them change shift and do some marching along the front door.

Gyeongbokgung palace was awesome! The grounds are beautifully kept and very large - we could have easily spent half the day walking around the paths to check out the gorgeous architecture. The grounds is connected to a museum that boosts some of the nations greatest artifacts. Keep in mind that this place can get very crowded with tourists and children on field trips, so I recommend trying to go during the week day. The cover price is fairly cheap (about $4 USD), but you can also purchase a ticket book that is good for the rest of the month to visit the other nearby Palaces in the area.

The courtyard portion does not require a fee and may be enough for most for the visit. Especially, to watch the changing of the guard. The entry price was reasonable, so probably worth it. A free English tour is available, but did not use it because of time constraints.

We arrived at the palace in time for the changing of the guard - a colourful ceremony that was brief enough for even the most impatient amongst us to enjoy. We then took a walk around the palace which is a shadow of its former self, having been burned down by the Japanese. What has been rebuilt is fine on the whole but there are some real highlights like the pagoda on the lake.

For those who like Korean architecture, this is a treat. I joined an English guided tour hoping to learn more about the historical stuff behind the place. Unfortunately, the group was quite big, and the tour guide was using a tiny loud speaker, and so most of the time I couldn't hear what she said. Which was a shame. They could have use those wireless units or limit the size of the group. What you see here are just buildings, and no artifacts. For those you'll have to go to the museum.
Were lucky to catch glimpse of changing of guards. Was very colourful & interesting. One complaint though: very dusty as palace ground is sandy

Except for a few buildings this is a recreation but what a fabulous recreation. We took one of the English tours and it was really interesting. The building are absolutely amazing. It was crowded in the main areas but the grounds are so vast it was easy to find quiet places to photograph or relax. Don;t miss the changing of the guard ceremony it is picturesque and colourful
Love, love, love the place - nice excursion, touch of the past - magnificent. I went to the place on my last day in KOREA AND WOULD NEVER FORGIVE, IF I WOULD NOT SEE

Lovely place. I especially liked the pond with the coy fish. There were a lot of noisy school kids at the gate that were shouting "Hello, hello" at western tourists which was annoying, but luckily the kids scattered around the large area after the gate so we could enjoy rest of the visit.
Went on a Chinese holiday so it was quite busy, but the grounds were clean and had lots of greenery.
This was such a great place to visit!! The buildings are lovingly and beautifully maintained and there was so much to see!! The history of Korea was fascinating, so much I didn't know!!

Though this Palace is Seoul's grandest, it was certainly not built on a grand nor large scale as BeijingForbidden City.  What i am surprised was that the moment we exited the Metro station, we were met with a strong 'sand storm'! And this had continued throughout the next one hour or so when we toured the Palace!  We were surprised as well as disappointed that the Korean Government did not invest in well paved roads inside their supposed grandest Korean Palace ! Instead, sands were seen everywhere, in between buildings and practically - everywhere!  I would strongly suggest ladies to tie up your hair or at least wear a cap as well as put on your sunglasses!  Maybe it was the time of the year we visited (October)? Anyway, you have been forewarned!
Want to know about Korean history and culture this is the place Lot of character and it portraits the life style of the kings.
Not quite as par- like as the other nice palaces, but grander and very nice. Close to City Center, of course, and an easy walk.

This is the biggest palace in Seoul. In my opinion, it is not the most beautiful one. Changdeokgung palace is better. The layout of the buildings is not as aesthetic as Changdeokgung's. Landscaping is noting to shout about. However it has daily changing of guards display to keep visitors engaged. It is good for a stroll.

As a keen photographer we stopped short of entering. There were literally thousand of people there when we went! Luckily the entrance gate had guards dressed in full regalia and I got some awesome photos of them! (free) and some art shots (close up) in the first courtyard. Worth a look as a photographer if it is very quiet, but there is a better temple (see my other tripadvisor review). Take your choice....

We had a great time here. Our tour guide was a plus as he gave us plenty of historic information as we walked around. I liked that this palace contained traditional furnishings in some of the buildings. We even saw the changing of the guards!!!

the entrance to the palace is just the beginning and is usually crowded. move further at the back where the pond is. its quiet and less busy in the forested area. there's a huge mountain in the background if you move past the pond.  make sure you allot half-a-day to explore this palace to make the most out of it!

The palace is quite huge so we were lucky to have followed a free English tour guide from the visitor center. We avoided the crowds as much as we could while still seeing all the major attraction the palace had to offer. The tour was almost an hour long but it gave us further insight to the history and lives of those living inside the Gyeongbokgung.  The ticket also comes with free admission to the folk museum located within palace grounds.

The change of guards ceremony was not too bad, the palace is huge with lots of turning, prepare to walk alot to explore the whole palace, at the end of the palace, there is a free museum to visit. I highly recommend the museum if you wanna know more about korea history.
A must see while in Seoul...to complete your visit. Take the Seoul City Tour for the day which offers a trip to all palaces in the city.
This is the big one with an entire garden area attached. Lovely. They usually have some sort of show so that the area gets very crowded. At the top of Gwanghwamun street.

We did one of the free tours and found it useful for the history and background, making sure we saw all the highlights, and saving us from crowding around the information boards to read descriptions. Tours start just inside the ticket gate near the information booth on the right. Though the website (which also has the times) says the tour numbers are capped, they aren't in reality. You can see the changing of the guard at the front gate without buying a ticket or entering the palace, as it takes place between the front gate on the main road and in the courtyard before the ticket gate.

There are so many palaces that one can visit in Seoul alone, but Gyeongbokgung Palace should be THE go to palace. It is the largest one in Seoul. If you are not a palace person, going to this one will definitely be satisfactory. Like in most palaces in Seoul, you'll find here the famous pillars, well-manicured gardens, the intricate Joseon Dynasty design, well-restored hanoks and the must-see changing of guards. Walking around here can be very tiring, but it's going to be worth it because there's a lot of beauty to see. You will feel like you are away from the hustle and bustle of the city outside its walls.  This palace is also very near one of many art and culture hubs in Seoul, Samcheongdong.  There is a money changer right beside the ticket counter, but do not have your dollars exchanged here. Last time I was there 1USD=985krw. Have your dollars changed in Namdaemun Market or Myeongdong Shopping District instead.  And again, do not miss the changing of guards ceremony. You can experience this even if you will not pay for the palace entrance (I think), so do not miss it!

Great palace, for reference it is much smaller than the forbidden city, but the gardens and the lake give something else to this palace. In my opinion it would be my first choice when comparing with Changdeokgung, nevertheless both attractions deserve a visit. I would set from 90 min to 2h for a good look around.

This was the first palace that I visited in my trip to Seoul, Korea. I expected the compound to be big, but I just never realized how really big it is. It's such a beautiful place. I was there early this Spring and there are blossoms everywhere. I wish I had more time to just sit down and just admire the beauty at the lake. Make sure you wear a good pair of shoes because there's lots of walking involved.
This place was good but just a little bit fake, everything was tooo perfect. The bricks the structure and the paint. I am not sure if this is a newer building. It was so hot, however it was relaxing.

It was an unintentionally visit for me. Been there since 2013, 13 hrs before my next connecting flight so that was the chance to get around in the city.  The palace has nothing much to see, building style is the combination between Japanese and Chinese. I was not sure about the ticket price but it was worth for paying.  If you wanted to pin this on your travel map that's fine, but for me once is enough. There is something else to see in Seoul.
Very relaxing to wander around and take your time to just look. If you prefer you can go on a guided tour.

Gyeongbokgung palace was the first royal palace built in 1395 during the Joseon Dynasty. But it was devastated by the Japanese Invasion of Korea in 1592 and the restoration began in 1990 and revealed what it is today. The palace consists of official quarters, living quarters and resting places. The most representative structures of the Joseon Dynasty, Gyeonghoe-ru Pavilion and Hyangwonjeong Pond are still relatively intact.I recommend you take a special trip to Gyeonghoe-ru Pavilion. For this tour, you must reserve in advance via internet or phone.

But didn't do tour. Investigate if you can go in without a tour. That would be great if you could. We were lucky to catch a traditional show in front of the palace during a cultural event. Also a laser show on the front wall/gate. Check for events there!

This palace is seriously run down by tours, and it gets super packed for the changing of the guard. It is really just a reconstruction and thus historically it is of limited interest. Changdeokgung is countless times more interesting to be sure to check out that one.

I could only spare a couple of hours for Gyeongbokgung Palace, and I recommend that you allot more time for this. It's a lot like the Forbidden City in Beijing, but I found there were more green areas where you can walk and just sit.  Didn't take a guided tour, so I just figured out my own routte.  To the left side of the main corridor, there's a larger area. One of the pavilions has a man-made lake in front of it, with benches along the edge. You can spend a few minutes sitting there, just taking it all in.  There was also a Janggu exhibit. Janggu are those big jars where they store Korean sauce in. The exhibit was in one of the inner areas, and tells you about how they prepared the Korean sauce.  In one of the inner areas, you might also find painters along one of the ponds. It gave off a very peaceful vibe.  Went there in late September, so the weather was beautiful and I went on a weekday. There were more than a few kids on a field trip there, but it still wasn't crowded.
Nice view of the past. September was a good time of the year to visit - not to crowded. Majestic buildings, lots to see.
We were with a group, so we had a guided tour. Lovely grounds, nice views of the surrounding area. Interesting to see a palace in the middle of a bustling city!
Amazing complex of palace with extraordinary art and architecture. It also has colorful painting. Perfect when in bright day.
Very beautiful palace with a very tranquil feeling. Really worth a visit. So much history. The staff is very helpful.

We lives in modern city, it is very unlikely for us to see such palace. It really nice and spectacular. Lots of tourists visit too. Entrance fee: 8,000won (can only visit 1 palace)The palace book guide cost 500won whereby you buy and bring it with you. If you wanna to visit all the palaces, you can buy from here too (cost more). Recommend for those whom really likes historic buildings and not likely to see in own country.
Definite must see for the cultural aspects. You'll need at least 3 hours here (if you walk fast). Go during a good lighting day there are lots of color & details.

I went to the palace in April 2014. Although it was very busy with lots of us ( turists ) I was able to enjoy the whole visit. You can rent the audioguides for few Won, just need to leave you ID with the officer, but I think it was really cheap, like 2-5 dolars per device. You can actually walk around and enjoy the most amazing historic places inside the place, and if you are K-Drama fan like me you will be transported to Faith ( drama starring Lee- Minho ) the rooms, the gardens, everythign was breathtaking. A recommended visit..You even have access to the front of the Blue House once in there, for not addictional cost ..Back again to K-dramas ( City Hunter starring Lee-Minho) If I ever visit Korea again I will go and make a more paceful visit, slower and take way more photos.Bring your camera along, or you will be missing spectacular picture moments.

We asked the taxi driver for Changdeokgung but he took us here instead. Apparently Changdeokgung is closed on Mondays. This place is huge & simple, not much to see except for the Korean Folk Museum. We missed the National Museum, so make sure not to miss it. We also watched the palace guards marching in traditional costumes. Lots of photo opportunities. Overall a very good visit.
This is by far the best palace Ive been to among the five palaces. Especially the palace in the lake. Allot 2-3 hours when visiting this place as this is really breath taking.

Seoul is a very interesting city in that there are palaces in the middle, while being surrounded by skyscrapers. This particular palace was incredibly majestic, and it seemed that even locals go there just to relax on the palace grounds. You can definitely spend a whole day exploring the different areas, and a guide book is only 50 cents CAD.
I really enjoyed learning the history and culture of South Korea, and this was a nice place to start, incredible workmanship and ingenuity, in a beautiful park like area..

Very big & crouded palace. From my visit, after doing pretty much all the palace section, I've came to realize that it pretty much looked the same.. Therefore, it's up to you guys to decide if it's really worth it. I did enjoyed the guard change !

You don't need more than 1.5 hours to conduct a thorough visit of the Palace grounds. We knew exactly what we wanted to see, and the map we had made it easy to follow along. Looking at the map, you can proceed through each quarter in the numerical order indicated. You'll find yourself eventually graduating from the Southern wing of the Palace to the Northern one as you visit each quarter in that order. My favorite sights were the Hyangwonjeong pavilion and Gyeongheoru pavilion. I would also pay to see this place in the Winter when it's covered by snow. Finally, my understanding is the Palace was built, destroyed, and rebuilt several times over the past several hundreds of years. Keep in mind the quarters are as close a replica as it gets to those in which the King lived/held his meetings/etc... but they're not authentic.

We loved the ease of access to all areas of the palace and temples. It was a lovely warm day and we enjoyed the exercise. The ornate buildings and statues were very cool and good information was available to read at each location. Nothing to dislike here.

I didn't actually go inside the complex (I did this for the other palace Changdeokgung Palace) but the exterior was really nice and I got to see the changing of the guards which was a really cool experience, so I recommend sticking around to see that if you can!

Area was huge, you could probably get lost if your sense of direction is not that good. We had a tour guide so it was easy for us to go to the other buildings. The area was reconstructed because it was damaged during the previous world war and a lot of construction is still ongoing when we went there (kitchen area being built). Very good work on the buildings though and all of the decorations done. You really need to checkout the golden dragon on the ceiling if you are there.
Very well kept & informative. Nice refreshment stop to rest up from alot of walking. Not allowed to enter the buildings but that is probably why they are in such god shape.

Book the secret garden tour as well, and book in advance. Its a long walk about 2.5 hours but easy to do and well worth the effort. The place has been kept in immaculate condition. I would highly recommend this tour while in Seoul.

The palace is old, and surprisingly small. Perhaps I just did not see too much into the history of the place. I noticed though that they have put more significance in places that would not have been significant had it not been for tourism purposes. But the facade of the building is interesting. It is a good place to visit one time. Just to get it out of your system. But not to revisit.

Following the style of the Forbidden City in Beijing, Gyeongbokgung is much less impressive but what's great about it is the pine grove and white sand ground that make it feel so aged and natural. In ancient time, Korea didn't have a big forest to build a large palace as China did. The woods for the palace were delivered from China, to whom it used to submit. Thus the houses are much smaller, especially the doors are low and narrow. Interesting place to learn about the country.
You can pass this place. You could check out the guard changing ceremony if you like that kind of stuff.
A nice palace within the vicinity of the city. A pale comparison to Forbidden Palace in Beijing. But anyhow a nice place to visit when you visit Seoul. The Museum there is also very good.

Lovely grounds but the ratio of strolling to special sights was not ideal, and it was easy to get lost. The best part really was getting there -- walking up the boulevard past two massive statues of war heroes, ideally when dark enough to see the entrance all ablaze.
Very important historical and quiet place I suggest for all travelers of Seoul.

Pretty palace with nice scenery. It is fine to go here just to look at the entrance, try on traditional clothing, take some photos and watch the guards. Don't really know what the tickets were for, all the fun was outside.

This place is really wonderful!! Just hope that it is not so hot like when I went! I would go back here so that is why I'm giving it an Excellent rating. And only $3 to get in - awesome! They have a beverages and gift shop if you need that. I want to go back for the free English tour in the early afternoon. There is quite a bit of walking around here so those with trouble walking should beware. Bring your camera. I walked here from the Folk Museum.

Amazing place to visit to know a bit of more Korean culture while in vibrant Seoul. Very easy to reach, just follow the direction of Palace going out of Gyeongbokgung subway station - the map is described on official website (http://www.royalpalace.go.kr/html/eng/guide/guide03.jsp?dep1=1&dep2=3). On the same website is the information about free tours in English. The ticket costs 3000 wons for the whole site and I advise to take one of those free guided tours, so you learn a bit more about culture, history and architecture. However, it was very difficult to get used to my guide, since she had a very strong Korean accent, it still gave me a small insight into the place. I've been there at around 13h and saw the ending of the traditional guard show, which was fantastic experience!
i work in the city of seoul and having such a great tourist spot is just amazing. the trip was just a walk away from the hotel I am staying at I just joined in some of the tourist

While living in Korea, we traveled to and visited many sights. The palaces located in Seoul make it easy to travel a short distance to be transported back in time when emporers ruled. This one is beautiful in many season and relatively flat for those with physical impairments. And the admission cost is perfect for me as I'm a shoestring-budget tourist, by choice.

Three are not only king's and queen's office and living rooms, but also a large museum with full history of Korea. Beautiful gardens and pond make me feel peaceful and healthy while I and my family walk on unpaved ground
Be prepared to walk and walk and walk. Toilets are strategically located. Impressive maintenance of the gardens! Especially the trees! Keep up the good work!

Gyeokbokgung palace is the biggest among the 5 palaces in Seoul. I recommend that you visit this and wait for the changing of the guards. Entrance fee is cheap, 3,000 won. It takes around 2-3 hours to fully explore the palace complex. Also, do not forget to try hanbok costumes.

I cannot believe the bus loads of tourists I saw at this place. This is the most popular palace in Seoul. The backdrop on the mountain makes it more elegant and it is also close to Gwahamun Square. We paid US$3 to get in.  The grounds is quite large and there are two museums on its premises. I love the ponds with pagodas in them. I also love the structure with no paint on them and even the display of the jars were beautiful. We were able to see the entire place except for the museums although we entered one of them.  I also love the horsemen statue in the platform of the subway station near the palace.

This palace is unbelievably large. You definitely want to have a guide, whether a human guide or an electronic one. We were traveling with our own guide and we learned so much about the Korean people and the buildings in which their royalty lived. The buildings are beautifully painted, with very bright colors. Be sure to look at the ceilings in all the buildings because they are decorated very elaborately (inside and out). This is a "must see" in Seoul!

I suggest you take the guided tour because you would understand why the palace was created as such. Visit is not complete without witnessing the changing of guards. Be aware of the schedules for these two.  The place is big and is full of people.

I took a guided tours to visit the Palace. Gyeongbokgung itself means "the palace blessed by Heaven". This is a complete historic building to let you learn more about Korean people way of life and their historical life. I would recommend to take guided tour because of not so much signage or maps available to allow self guided tour. If you are lucky, you will be able to see the Guard Change ceremony on the main gate. Behind this palace, there is a Presidential House called 'Cheonghwadae' or 'Blue House'. Prepare yourself for a lot of walking, from the main gate to the exit gate.

Good way to spend a couple of hours in Seoul. Guided tours are essential because there is not much in the way of signage or walking maps available to allow you to do a self guided tour. The complex is sprawling so without a tour guide you will have no idea what you're looking at. Be prepared for lots of walking. Interesting look inside the Korean imperial court during the Chosin dynasty.

I had the opportunity to visit this amazing compound during a 14 hour layover in Seoul. Awesome train ride from Incheon Airport into the city and voila! there you are all of the sudden facing this gorgeous monument surrounded by a modern world beyond it's walls.  This 619-year old beauty is a must visit regardless of the length of your visit to Seoul. You will, without a doubt be inspired and in awe. From the ceremoniously dressed guards and the colors of the ceilings to the contrast of the beautiful mountains and modern buildings, this is one of the best preserved historical sites you will ever see.

Actually got the 3 palace day pass and went to gyeongbokgung, cheongdukgong, the shrine and secret garden. Initially it was all pretty interesting with the architexture and all, but quickly got monotonous since all 3 palaces were almost the same. Advise: Go with the tour, you ll learn a lot more and feel more engaged, and skip on the other 2 palaces. One is more than enough. Shrine and secret garden good for taking pictures

This is unique place which a must visit place in Seoul. This is a palace spread over a large area where, you can feel the ancient times of Korea.  I was there with a Korean friend where we managed to join the free guided tour (as I remember starts at 3:30 pm). If you have any interest on history or like to know some info about this palace, I recommend you to join this free tour where a guide English speaking guide takes the group for guided tour almost for a hour. Most of the things that you learn from this tour cannot be grabed by just walking around in this place.  I’m not a big fan of Korean dramas, still I enjoyed this visit. If you are a fan of Korean drams related to historical event, this is a must visit place.  Seoul museum is also located in the same premises, so you can visit there also. If you have some sort of an interest on history and have 1-2 hrs to spare, don’t miss this experience. This will give you a memory to recall that you visited Korea.  If I happen to visit Seoul again, I will repeat this visit.
Not really a person who likes historical buildings but be prepared to walk if you are going to explore the place as the whole place is HUGE!

This was similar to all of the rest of the palaces. However it had one of the buildings on a lake here, which was really pretty. This was extremely busy but worth a look round. It was a lot bigger than Changdeokgung Palace, however once you had seen one of the buildings you had seen them all!

Solemn and dramatic, the guards and the music along with blossoming trees make it beautiful. Check the schedule, come at 10 AM. Inside it's just a nice place to walk, we loved it. At the end take pictures with guards, they don't mind it.
you have to visit this place - it is very beautiful and peaceful. have a time for meditation. you can also find some quite place and have a picnik.
Super good palace and it is quite large. Slow down your pace while you visit this palace. Sit somewhere in the palace and that is really tranquillising. Mesmerising scene!

This is the 1st place i visit when i reach Korea. The palace has so many visitors and majority of them are the Koreans. If you ever watched an old Korean drama series and wish to feel how the era looks like, you have to visit this palace. The area are so big, and the buildings are as it should looks like. Great view.

The palace was very busy when we visited it. There are various tours that take place, and you can get a guided tour if you want. We chose to just stroll through the various buildings and gardens. It's a really well maintained complex, and the gardens around the palace are a great place to relax after you tour. There are information boards all around to read about about the various functions of the buildings you are viewing. It's very centrally located and is close to other attractions in the city. You also have great views of the mountains near Seoul.

We hired through Internet a free guide, from some group of volunteers and it was a very nice old man, Mr.Lee, who spent more than 2 hours explaining us everything about the palace and the buildings that compose the place. A good experience that I recommend everybody to do, cheap and worth it.

This was our first visit to a Korean Palace. Overall a good experience, the place grounds are extensive and there is alot of walking. Did not take a guided tour although that might have been better. The buildings all look the same and you cannot enter most of them. They have a formal changing of the guard every so often, we just happened to arrive when they were conducting it. Also at the end of the day (near 5PM) they have a ceremony with traditional dress and pomp and circumstance where teh guards march around and there is a marching band of sorts. We visited in late July which is quite warm in Korea but this day it was cooler with lower humidity. If you go in summer expect it to be very hot and humid. There is a fee to enter the palace grounds and another fee to be able to go to the pavilion which is in the middle of a small pond/lake. We did not visit the pavilion. The cost to enter for 2 adults and 1 child (11 years old) was around 10,000 Won. This cheap in my opinion.

This is only a small palace compared to others in Asia and not as interesting. The changing of the guard ceremony was very touristy and not the real thing like Buckingham Palace. The museum was only average also. I would only recommend this palace for its history.

I suggest to read a little about Gyeongbokgung before visiting the area. This way you will be able to appreciate the place more.  The palace is huge and each building has it's own story to tell. Go to the large open space compound and you will see small erected rocks. Those are used to separate different ranks for ancient Korean officials.  ”一” = grade one (highest rank) ”二” = grade two "三” = grade three "四” = grade four And lower  If you see the center pathway, you will notice the center walkway is higher than the rest. The center walkway is walked by the king. The side pathways are for generals and scholars separately. You will notice huge ring like object on the floor at each side of the compound. It is used to pitch shelter if it rain. But it's only for Grade 1 to Grade 3 officials only.  Read more and be Wow!
one of my most favorite places we visited while in seoul. absolutely gorgeous palace. would love to visit again.

Saw a guard changing ceremony there. Is a good place for sightseeing and photo ops, LOL. Also, if you like the ancient Korean heritage, this is the place. The information are also clear and they are everywhere, so don't be afraid you've got lost :)  Nearby, there are also a Children's museum (?) that you can also visit by paying some fees. I don't know much since I am just passing by, but I saw the sculpture on their front door. It seems nice.

I visited this place as part of my short Seoul trip.  I loved the amazing view from the statues on Sejong - it looks really great for a European who has never been to this type of Asian culture before. We spend there two hours of incredible walk - having a local friend who gave us some insight on Korean culture. Every part if completely different and worth of visiting - lake, buildings etc.  The only negative aspect was the fact, that inside the buildings there is almost nothing - completely different from the collections inside the European castles.

The guard change adds a historic feel to the place as they really dress up for it. Overall the place is huge and is best seen with a guide, as you get insights into things you wouldn't otherwise pick up on your own (not many signs or explanations) or from your guidebook. Such as - who's the most powerful person in the palace? Hint: It's not the king!

This palace complex is very large. It is also pretty busy. We saw lots and lots of tourists from several countries. The National Folk Museum and Palace Museum are also here. You could probably spend an entire day here if you wanted to. We just spent a couple of hours. It's conveniently right off the subway as well.

This place is large so expect to spend more than an hour inside. Reached there just in time for the first changing of guards ceremony. Should watch if you have not seen it. There are guided tours for English and Chinese. Though it's not UNESCO certified, but it's the first palace build. Worth visiting if you just want to pick one palace to go to out of the many other palace around the area.
coming from a country that nothing much historical monuments were still intact, these kind of places in S.Korea tickles my interest. took a lot of cool pictures here.

There are complimentary lockers for visitors to put the shopping bags. A big place to see, with restored furnishings. Easily accessible by train, with artifacts displayed along the passageway. The change of guards ceremony is very realistic

The palace inside it self has many restoration going on. The place is quite pack with people. The palace it self is colorful and the palace ground is peace and quiet. If your planing just a stroll around. It would be a great place.

I think the restoration has not ended yet, you can only walk on the outsides of the buildings and it has been restored from the ground so it has this feeling of being a little bit like a theme park.  Said that it is still a nice play to walk inside and to compare it with European palaces, it is pretty different in concept.

This palace is a beautiful example of historical Korean architecture. It is wonderfully colorful and the palace grounds are a peaceful respite from the hustle and bustle of the city that surrounds it. Plan to spend at lease a few hours while there. The walkways are coated in small gravel so I recommend closed toed shoes. There are food and drinks available for purchase.
You can watch the changing of the guards free at the main entrance of the palace. It was captivating. Traditional Korean dress and customs on show lovely.

This is a must see place in Seoul! Our tour guide has so many interesting stories during our walk tour. It's a nice feeling of having a chance to glimpse Korea culture. The palace is so grand and there are multiplex structures besides it which is just as interesting to see...  There is also a museum near the palace which you can do a quick tour.
This palace is right beside the Folk Museum of Seoul so you can spend a good half day here seeing both. Recommend if you want to see more then just a palace!

Interesting history, the palace is very well conserve and maintain, lots of rebuilding, since some had been destroyed by Japanese occupation period. Very easy to come by subway, exit virtually inside the palace area. One of the must visit places in Seoul.

When I was in Korea 55 years ago, this location was the previous Japanese Headquarters Building. These grounds are amazing and I especially enjoyed the statues of the inventor of the Korean language and also the only Emperor to defeat the Japanese navy. If you had to choose between this and the Seoul Tower, go here.
Complimentary English guided tours provided- the tour guide was extremely professional and helpful. Most beautiful palace
Love it! Awesome view plus great architecture back in the olden days. We went on Wednesday and the admission was free. Yayyyy lucky us. Haha

3000 KRW to spend the whole day. You can op for a tour, or latch yourself with another tour (seen people doing that some time) pack some water and sandwich. It's hard to find food in the palace itself.
Large sprawling complex somewhat spoilt by mass tourism and careless juxtaposition of modern buildings. Make sure you catch the changing of the guard which is colourful and take a short English tour.
Enjoyed our time here. Only Few train stops from Myeongdong. Very serene. The place is well kept with beautiful gardens with mountain and lake backdrop. Loved the white and pink cherry blossoms

I love Gyeongbukgung,but maybe it's because it's the first palace I visited in Korea. The grounds are huge - the scope of the palace is really surreal.  There is a changing of the guards ceremony with music. You cannot go inside and crawl around the palace, no, but you can look inside some of the rooms.  The palace is also centrally located to the National Folk Museum (free and worth a visit) and Bukchon Hanok Village. Insadong isn't too far away either.

This was quite a nice and interesting place to visit. If you make it to the palace I recommend taking a tour, but it is still fun to explore on your own. when I went they were working on a few buildings but what is open is pretty amazing, especially if you are into history. And while there you might as well pop over into the national museum.

You must never give this place a miss if you want to know more about korean history. Visit both place.... The royal palace itself and not to forget the folklore museum.... You will make your journey complete

The guard changing ceremony (scheduled at certain time of the day) was a pleasure to see. I like it.!. The show takes 10 minutes and then you can go take pictures with them. Go with the guide and listen to history will make the visit more interesting than wandering around aimlessly. After the 30-40 minutes tour, then be free to wonder around. The place is huge, exploring all of the place (alone) took about 3 hours. Nice souvenir shop and cafe as well selling quite expensive items but of very high quality. Locker is provided FOC.

This is the largest (huge) palace in Seoul and definitely everyone should visit the palace on their first visit, or even on the second if your coming in winter the palace is nice to see under snow cover. We got the Multi site tickets here which let us in to a lot of the temples around Seoul and saved some cash. The museum in the back was pretty interesting, not extremely exciting, but let you see a lot of props and artifacts of the time, showing how they lived and worked during the old era. The staff during the winter were nice enough to give out hand warmers on a bitter old day when we first came in January.

Our group went on a short trip to this palace, it was very easy to get to from the metro, even for people who don't speak a bit of Korean. We walked around, enjoyed the palace and gardens. It is close enough by some shopping as restaurants as well, so it is good place to make a day of sightseeing in Seoul.
Love the place. Everything is well maintained. Went there during winter so it was really beautiful looking at the buildings encased in snow.

This temple is extraordinary! It is surrounded by breathtaking, mountainous views, and packed full of information regarding Korean Chosun Dynasty. Hour longTours are available in several languages, including Korean (of course), English, Japanese and more. A must-see!
