Lots to see at this palace! A piece of Korean history that will leave you in awe! Interesting and very peaceful. Ensure you get a chance to see the guards march and the traditional Korean singers and dancers. On top of all this, it was very affordable. Make sure you go:)!
The complex was large and walking was very easy - just make sure you budget enough time to see it all. It takes a bit to get from building to building without feeling like you need to rush.

A very large complex to walk around so for best understanding take advantage of the free English guide who meets you outside the information office for on the hour departures. Her tour took about an hour and her knowledge really did help as she explained the history of the palace from first being built in 1395, later burned and abandoned for almost three centuries, occupied and destroyed by the Japanese and then the start of the rebuilding in 1867. Oh and that clever old way of central heating. The reconstructions did not distract from the visit and overall we came away with a great feel for how Royal Life might have been. Look out for the changing of the guard ceremony - effectively hourly - and combined entrance into the Folk Museum
Architecture. The painting decorations on the wooden beams. I should have spent this day visiting the North and experience the thrill of being close to evil
Take your time to stroll down the Palace and enjoy the beauty of the nature and old Korean architecture. Such a peaceful place.

Got a chance to visit The Secret Garden. It was quite lovely, although a bit of a hike. The Secret Garden area is wider than the Palace grounds itself, so try not to miss the tour there.  The Changing of the Guard Ceremony is of course a must-see. You can take a photo with some of the guards for the short time that they are posted by the gate.
Come here early and plan to stay 3-4 hours. There are so many things to see ... some perfect places to take pictures. Make sure you are there for change of the guards.
It's one of the place to visit as one of the most beautiful palace. There's a lot of things to see and it is a huge area.

This is on my list of must see on my first day in Seoul and it didn't disappoint. True to its description, it's a grand palace with imposing gates, stunning throne hall and large lawns for leisurely walks. The palace is huge and doesn't have much information around so it's advisable to go with a tour guide. Either join the free tour given by the palace or sign-up for free walking tours from visitseoul.net. I think the latter is much better because the group would usually be much smaller than the ones who join the free tour by the palace.  Once you're done touring the palace grounds you may want to check out the Blue House and National Museum which are both strategically located behind the palace. Oh! don't forget to checkout the changing of the guards at the from yard which happens like every hour or two.

Much bigger than I thought it would be. Did the free English tour which is offered several times a day. Would recommend the tour as it told stories behind the buildings. There are no signs describing the buildings if you go on your own.  Changing of the guards was interesting to watch but seemed ingenuous and very fake formality.  Folk museum was very good and would recommend. Also nice place to cool off at the back of the palace complex.
Good place to see in the heart of Seoul. Beautiful palace and lots of people. We got to see the beautiful palace.

My first visit in Seoul was Gyeongbokgung Palace. We traveled there from Pyeongtaek by train and then subway. The subway brought us right to the palace. It was a warm day. We enjoyed watching the changing of the guards. They allowed tourists to pose for pics with the guards. I enjoyed the architecture. There were tours given in English but we did not have time to wait for it but would have liked to have gone. Water was sold for 1000 won which is roughly $1. The admissions was 3000 won per adult which is roughly $3 per person. This is worth a visit.

I lived in Seoul for one year before visiting this palace. I wish I would have visited sooner, this is the largest palace complex I have visited in the Seoul area. The palace, museum, and gardens make for an half day trip. We expected to spend about two hours on the palace grounds but actually stayed around four hours. I didn't get a chance to explore everything in that time. I will go back and visit again. If you want to visit a beautiful Korean cultural site I highly recommend this palace grounds.

I love this place during the winter. It's simply breathtaking. Gyeongbok Palace offers expansive royal grounds. A glimpse into the royal lifestyle during the Joseon Dynasty. They have changing off the guards, queens gardens, beautiful parks and tea houses all on the grounds. The colors and architecture are beautiful and it's really neat to have this piece of ancient history in the middle of the modern, urban, City Hall area, backdropped by glorious mountain peaks.
More than meets the eye. The park and buildings go on forever. I highly recommend going on the free English tour to get the most out of the visit.

Incredible palace! A huge, sprawling complex of various different painted wood & stone buildings, spread over a large area near the middle of Seoul. Me and my sister were lucky, in that we just happened to visit while the changing of the guards ceremony was taking place. Very interesting ceremony with lots of traditional Korean dress and instruments. We also happened on a day where entry to the palace was free, although it is normally not that expensive.  Highly recommended for a nice chilled day out. We didn't visit the museum when we went there, but would like to if we go again.

Great architecture, nice clean parks, very near the presidential palace and the main square /street where the king statue can be seen. Also, you can wear a hanbok ( traditional korean costume ) for free in the middle of the square.
Things to bee seen : guards exchanging places, the palace and the most beautiful thing is the garden behind the palace overlooking the mountain.
Beautiful, picturesque palace against a mountainous backdrop. Loads of history to take in as you stroll the huge palace grounds. The ceremony for the changing of the guards is well-worth a watch.

It's the biggest palace in Seoul and worth a trip. Lots of history on the inside, flanked by high-modernity on the outside. You can wander around for hours. Buy the 50-cent guidebook and take yourself on a nice walking tour of the place. It really helps to understand the Korean culture and its history, and its just a pretty impressive place. At the very back of the palace is a back exit that leads to the front of the Blue House, Korea's equivalent of the White House, where it president lives. You can tell where to go by the guards who search bags at the exit. Walk through and you can walk back in by showing your ticket.

Walking along the pathway leading to the gates of the Palace i notice a tree full of yellow Pears that demand a snapshot.We dont have this kind of fruit trees in Malaysia.After paying for the entrance fee by our guide,we enter into this huge garden with old Korean style buildings,ponds,trees and the National Folk Museum.Especially like the various artificial display of Kimchi dishes.Lots of historical artifacts and a great place for photos.In one of the buildings outside there's a room with a display of traditional Hanbok - Korean Clothings that you can wear and take photos with.Did not see the changing of the guards though.Located in the middle of modern Seoul, its a must visit place.

This historical palace is located right in the middle of modern Seoul and this is so cool to see the contrast of the past and the future.  The palas has a very large area to walk and a lot of old buildings to see. The big building inside the lake is gorgeous.  Do not forget to visit the nice souvenir shop. You may also have a cup of tea inside. If you are in Seoul, you must see this palace.
It is a recommended place to visit, you can enjoy a traditional architecture in the middle of modern city

We went off to view what we thought would be just another palace, and it was a bit more. We arrived as they changed the guard giving a good photo opertunity. The place was buzzing but because of it's size was able to appear less packed. Everything is well maintained and vibrant in colour, spotlessly clean and of great historical value. The extensive grounds are well kept and worthy of a walk around time permitting. Recommended

This place was just breath taking! It is huge and the contrast of this palace against the backdrop of the modern city added to its excitement!  It has been restored over the years and there were still new parts that were being restored (kitchen area in particular). This small part of construction did not take away from the jaw dropping effect of this place. The attention to detail, from the original stone taken back from Japan to the extreme detail in the painting, was simply beautiful!  You need at least a few hours to properly explore this palace - which you can do at your own pace (with or without an audio guide (for an extra fee)) or join a guide for detailed information and history! You can then move straight onto the folk museum which is free of charge if you pay for the palace entry. We were also lucky enough to see the official changing of the guard - which was enriched in culture and more history!  They have even built a train station directly at the palace (you get off and basically walk into the palace) which is great for convenience and makes it very cheap to get to.  If you are struggling to decide on what to do or torn between what to see - you MUST see this!

Majestic palace right in the heart of the city. Fengshui dominates the place... The palace was built on sprawling grounds and to me it is the pulse of the city. As Korea does not have a royal family anymore this palace is not used now. The palace is so well maintained and cleanliness rules the day. Be prepared for a long walk thru the palace and stop to capture the artistic handiwork of yesteryears...

Beautiful palace with rich history. Absolutely loved the place. Stunning back drop. CHEAP entry, should definitely raise the admission price. Free entry to National Folk Museum.  It has a very handy location. A definite must see!
This was the 2nd time I visited this place but it never failed to took my breath away. Everything was so beautiful n stunning!

LOTS of history, lots of amazing Palaces and sight seeing places, and also a home of Kim Nam Jae's Hapkido gym. I highly recommend this place, and the famous chicken restaurants around it. Such as the Korean Chicken soup pass the Popeye's chicken place... ironically speaking.

We reached this palace right a few minutes before the guards changing ceremony at the entrance, so if you can catch this, please do so! We explored this huge palace after that and it took us a lot of time to explore this place. There are free tours available if you are interested to join. One of the must go places in Seoul!

I took the free English tour which was great as you heard a lot more about the place. There are lots of photo opportunities and I would recommend going at a time where you can see the changing of the guard ceremony.

I bought the entrance tickets for 3000KW with English Tour. It has other languages as well but subject to availabilities. The tour guide brought us through most part of Gyeongbokgung Palace and it lasted for about an hour, it could have been longer but partly cause of the rainy weather we skipped some. For photos, do visit http://nkikichua.blogspot.sg/2014/03/wanderlust-seoul-korea-day-2.html :)

Must join the free tour!!! The tour guide was great, she told us about so many things that I otherwise wouldn’t notice. The palace was a bit crowded though and it would be better if the tour could be longer to go through more places. Anyhow, this is a must see location. If you are going to only 1 palace in Seoul, this is the one. Reserves at least half a day for this palace if you are joining the free tour and make sure you check the tour time before you go so that you wouldn’t miss it.

I suppose it's a must do if you are in Seoul but don't get too excited.  There are free English speaking tours throughout the day, we caught the 11 am one. The tour had about 40 people to start with and 25 by the end. I guess some got board.  The site itself is not that old as it was reconstructed in 1995 so don't go expecting ancient wonders. But it is a good place to visit to get some Korean culture.

Another side trip during a business trip in a cool winter season,,, getting around the place is quite challenging specially if one is not used to this kind of weather, great experience anyway specially seeing the traditional "changing of the guards",,,

When you get out from the metro subway you will find yourself stunts by the mega old architecture right in the middle of this seoul metropolitan city.  It feel like you travel the time back to where the King and the glory of Korean history.  One thing that I missed is the brief history or the explanation of the building meaning etc. If you like history means that you'll need a tour guide.  Not far from this palace you will easily find the national palace museum thatbalso beautifully arranged.
Its like visiting a studio! A very interesting place to visit because you can wander around the palace and explore the history of the old and ancient Dynasty!

As said in the title, this palace is beautifully maintained. It's huge, so expect to spend a lot of time there, and although we had a difficult time finding the "entertainment hall in the pond", we were glad we found it. The whole place is like a maze without many signs, so make sure you have a good map or a guide. Most of the items are removed from inside the buildings but there are still things to see. It's worth your time. Parents with young kids, you need strollers for this.
We went with our tour and she tell us the story of the beauty palace at the end we watched the changing of the guards

Me and my mom went there in the morning to walk around the palace and we were surprise that there is also "Changing of Guards" in the front area of Gyeongbokgung Palace (you may ask the ticket vendors for the schedule as this is only appears few times a day). If you are going around, you must be wearing comfy shoes at least and try to bring water because you might be surprised how big the Palace is. If you are fond of watching Korean Soap operas, you might consider yourself living in them because the palace is well preserved that it really looks like you are seeing the past and the traditions. If you get tired just a halfway, please take a good rest then try to finish all the buildings as this might surprise you a beautiful view. We went there last Autumn and seeing the whole Palace amazed me. However, if you want to know more details for every building, it requires a tour guide.

This is a grounds that contains a palace and various affiliated buildings. It was partially rebuilt in 1867. There is a modest 3000 won entrance fee so you are not risking much to go in. We toured the palace and grounds on our own. The replica buildings are magnificent and ornate but there is inadequate description of the history and contextual setting of the buildings. Also you can look into many of the buildings but you cannot actually go inside. We did not engage a tour guide as we wanted the freedom and informality to explore on our own but there is generally inadequate information (plaques, descriptions) to really appreciate the grounds and the replica buildings. If you really want to appreciate the site a tour guide is needed. There are some ramps for handicap access but there are also many steps. This destination is a work in progress as a tourist attraction but at modest cost it is interesting for a short time.

We attempted three times to go to Gyeongbokgung palace. Let me save you time a little bit of headache...IT IS CLOSED ON TUESDAYS! The second time we tried to visit President Obama was there so we couldn't go into the palace.  The third time we finally got to see everything. It's a large compound so wear comfortable shoes and bring a camera. If you have one with a good zoom lens it will come in handy, as you can't actually go into many of the buildings.  You can't miss this if you go to Seoul, the architecture is nothing you've ever seen. Breathtaking to see the details and colors used when everything was built. Buy a guide for 50 cents, it will give you information and a cheap souvenir to take with you. It's only a couple dollars for admission, worth it to walk the grounds. Don't miss the changing of the guard, the ceremony isn't very long but it's entertaining. You can take pictures with the guards on your way out.

This is the signature palace complex in Seoul with a myriad buildings in a range of smaller sections. There are many guided tours and at several specific times you can watch a colourful changing of the guard.  The best by far is the picturesque little pavilion on the lake at the very end of the palatial complex: you may recognise it from many popular photos of Korea. This is the most beautiful and tranquil spot in the whole complex with most sight-seers running out of steam long before they get there, so you can enjoy it almost as if it's your own.

This palace is huge, We entered it from the back door the one facing the President's Blue house. The garden was breathtaking, The museum was so-so. It is well worth the entrance fee, because there are just too much to see. be sure to watch the guard changing ceremony that take place at 10 am at the main entrance. I think it last for about half an hour or so. There are so many palaces in Seoul, but this one is the probably the most visited and most beautiful.

It was the first palace that I visited in korea I went on winter, so everything was covered in snow, was so pretty! I will try to go on spring when the flower blossom! It´s worth going! If you don´t have time you can visit only this palace.

Make sure you have sun protection because most of the areas in eh palace is not covered  We had a free tour guide, one of the Korean high school students so it was great to learn a lot of the history and culture of the palace. There was a big sign outside the train station for free tour guides which we did not regret.  We only spent about 1.5 hours here and that was enough

I will totally want to go back again next time, with a guided tour and 3 hours to spare. The whole palace is huge and not exploring all the corners are a waste imo. I just spent an hour to realise that I am only at one section of the palace! Its a total regret that I did not allocate enough time for this visit. However I learnt a lot during that short hour. The palace is worth visiting! Would advise to hire a guide to learn more about the place.

Nice manicured grounds with plenty if nice photo opportunities. If you come expecting to see anything original, you will be sorely dissapointed. Almost all the buildings were built in 1999 onwards as the originals were destroyed long ago. The buildings outside the palace grounds that house your Macdonalds is likely older.

I visited Gyeongbokgung in November of 2010 and May of 2014. In 2010, I visited the palace as part of a tour and this year I had the opportunity to visit again, but at night (the palace is only opened at night during certain times of the year). Both experiences were great, just completely different. In 2010, the tour was a great opportunity to see so much of the palace grounds, plus the Folk Museum and learn a lot of history along the way. Our time in the palace this year was much shorter (simply based on our schedule), however it was amazing to see the palace transform as the sun set. Whether you have a few hours or maybe just 30 minutues, Gyeongbokgung is definitely worth a visit.

I had a 11 hour stop over in Seoul, South Korea. I took a 5 hours guided tour of Seoul during this time from the airport. This tour just cost $50. This included a traditional lunch in Seoul. I would surely recommend this tour if you are having a stop over.  The Royal Palace of Seoul was part of the tour. For a history buff like me, it was a walk through history. Is is the biggest of the Grand Palaces. First constructed in 1395, later burned and abandoned for almost three centuries, and then reconstructed in 1867. Most of the palace is well preserved. And some parts have been beautifully reconstructed.  It is a huge and beautiful complex in the heart of the city. So if you wish to really understand and enjoy the historical significance of the place you will need a minimum of 2-3 hours.  I suggest you get a guided tour so that someone can explain the significance of each building and architecture there.  Hope you get an opportunity to visit this magnificent and historical site.

I visited this palace as part of a day tour of Seoul so we had our own guide. That was helpful for providing extra information about the different areas of the palace. I am not sure if there is a brochure in english available here like at other palaces. At other places it was 500 won.  This palace is nice. The grounds are well kept. The buildings are in good shape but they are also not very old. This palace was rebuilt after being destroyed by the Japanese. I did not find this palace as interesting as Changdeokgung. I think the buildings are very similar but the secret garden at Changeokgung makes it the more beautiful option.

This palace ( ₩3,000) with the Folk Museum within (free entrance) gives you great insight into the Korean culture. The grounds are big so prepare to walk a bit. It is beautiful and has a scenic view of both the mountains and the downtown of Seoul!

I mean the palace from the drama comes to life :P A heavenly, peaceful place to tour with your friends, loves or families. Its soo huge that you need at least 2-3 hrs to tour every nook and cranny. The view is magnificent, beautiful lakes & temples, huge gardens with nice grass patch to lay on to relax under the cooling weather. Its gives a enchanted feeling of how royals, courts, servants etc used to lived. Guided tour will let you understand the stories of every path you walk, every temples you see. I miss out the museum that shows the history of Koreans back in the traditional era & the joseon dynasty tales so gotta be there early in order to explore all the places.

The Royal Palace is situated in the heart of Seoul, South Korea and it is accessible by subway. It occupies an area of almost 700 thousand square metres and was built in the Joseon Dynasty back in 1395. It was destroyed two times over the years because of foreign invasion and occupation and has been rebuilt and restored by 2010. The Korean name of the Palace means " Palace greatly blessed by Heaven" and it was inhabited by the Royal family. The Palace compound is huge and is composed of many different structures for various purposes. I was most impressed with the Geunjeongjeon (throne hall) near the entrance where officials of different ranks would queue up along two lines of stone markers on the left and right of the open court signifying seniority during ceremonies, declarations and audience with the King. Attraction number 4, Gangnyeongjeon and Gyotaejeon, i.e. King's and Queen's quarter as well as number 12, Gyeonghoeru, a two storey pavilion sitting on a pond for royal banquets and entertainment are also worth checking out. I was extremely lucky because when I arrived at the main gate, there was a change of guards in traditional and brightly coloured uniforms which added a touch of humanity to the solemn structures behind the walls. I was told it was done on the hour during the day. The temperature during my visit was -7 degrees centigrade and as it is a vast span of land with lots of open space, make sure you wear enough warm clothings. It may be a better idea though to visit at warmer times. Please note that the Palace also closes for one day during the week, so check with your hotel before you make your trip.

If you have been to Forbidden City in Beijing, you will see the familiarities of these palaces and I was not in awe with Gyeongbokgung as I have visited some nice palaces in Asia. There is almost no tree in the inner court and it's really hot after a long walk, even though I visited in early May. Unless you are into history or culture, don't expect great scenery such as beautiful Chinese garden there.

If you wanna know more about South Korea's culture, you should go here. It has temples, garden and a lot more about the country's origins. It is very huge that you need at least two hours to explore the place. I think it also has guided tours that could help you understand each location in this palace.

Before going, make sure the palace is open. We were there on a Tuesday but it was closed! The palace is in the midst of the modern Seoul, which makes it more interesting. It covers a large area (I don't know how many acres of land) and consists of a number of palaces. There is even a lake inside which adds to the serenity of the surrounding in spite of lots of visitors. The changing of guards is worth watching. The whole parade is about 10 minutes or a bit more. If you are not with a tour, get on the subway and get off at the palace station, the decoration inside the station is very unique. Besides the palace, there is also the museum where you can see interesting things too.

We visited the palace in the night when it opens up for visitors for two weeks in spring. It was quite a unique experience and very beautiful. Call the tourist helpline to book the tickets for foreigners. The palace walkways are stony so the ride on the stroller would be bumpy for the baby however there are ramps in most places with steps. There is a small cafe in the premises so good place to eat and relax. The complex itself us not very big so easy to cover in two hours at a very relaxed pace. The ticket cost is KRW 3000. Very accessible by public transport

The building is very authentic. Two thumbs up for the maintanance effort. Even it's an old bulding but the cleaness is maintain very well. Try use hanbok in here, you'll love see yourself in Korean traditional clothes. For Korean Drama lovers, don't forget to visit the park behind Gyeongbokgung palace. Drama "Rooftop Prince" took a crucial and popular scene in that park.

Highlight of our visit is the free trial of old Korean costumes and the photo opportunity. Located within the city proper and near a train station so this should be a stop for every visitor. They also have some guards parade at specific periods but they are not really elaborate events. there is a section of the palace where you have to pay but we chose not to enter.

Located on the exact heart of Seoul. You dont have to go inside to fully enjoy the atmosphere. Theres two free museum (palace museum and folk museum) and the sidewalk around the palace is connectec to the presidential bluehouse. Westville and Northville are unique and hip neighborhood adjacent to the palace. On sundays farmers market and flea market opens right in front of thr palace.

We planned our visit around the time of the "Changing of the Guard" ceremony at 10am. We arrived about 15 minutes before to get a good spot. It is very colourful and quite spectacular and lasts about 20mins. Following the ceremony we purchased our ticket to enter to palace grounds. There are free English tours however we walked on our own. The grounds are magical. It is wonderful to see a royal palace over 700 years old. We entered from Gwanghwanun Square and continued up to the The National Folk Museum (which is free to enter). It is possible to exit near the museum and then walk to Bukchon Hanok Village. This palace is a must to see!
Not too bad, the place is huge and packed with lots of tourists. Yet another touristic spots. Nothing special about it. You may want to walk further down to Insadong street.

I visited this palace on a Saturday. If you come early, it is not so crowded. I entered via the east gate from Samcheongdong-gil, after a tour of the cute little area Bukchon, where ticket lines are far shorter and you get a prior glimpse at the National Folklore Museum ;) The gardens are just beautiful, as are the colorful buildings and a little pavillion in the middle of a little pond with a bridge leading to it. Although large parts of the Palace buildings were destroyed it is great to get an impression how the buildings looked in their former glory. Descriptions of various buildings and palace complexes are also in English, so it is very tourist friendly. Overall, a very nice palace, and after having seen both this and Changdeokgung Palace, I would recommend a visit to this palace more. And if you get lucky, you can see the guard change at Gwanghwamun main gate, which is very worth it with their colorful flags and costumes!

Buildings not as intricate or beautiful and grand as those in china. The Gardens blooming in spring were well maintained and enhance the otherwise unspectacular architecture. The guards at the entrance in bright red and blue and yellow were good for colorful photography. As structures have been rebuild and renovated from its original it appears too modern and artificial.

The guard changes at 10, 11, 1,2,3 and 4. There are two different ceremonies. Interesting to see. Buildings were interesting. The country has such history and it is amazing to see this, in the middle of the city. Very easy to access from the Seoul Metro. The directions say 5 mins to walk from subway, but that may be from the platform. Once you get out of the station, you are there. Reasonable cost for admission. The ground can be uneven due to the large stones. Can be difficult with a stroller or wheelchair, if you are planning to go there.
Bring your camera and spend a few hours walking around the different buildings and parks. It can be crowded but worth a visit.

I would first see the Changdeokgung Palace. The palace looks almost similar but this is the main palace and you just must see it. If you've taken the English tour in Changdeokgung Palace, you could skip it here. There are museums inside, which had good reviews. We just didn't have time to visit them.

This is the first place I visited the moment I dropped off my bags at my hotel in Myeongdong. I was here quite early on a Sunday morning and coming out of the subway exit seeing the Palace museum and even just the rooftops of Gyeongbokgung palace with sunrise behind it was already enough to make me feel I am really in Seoul. The gates open at 9am and if you are planning to visit other palaces just buy the palace pack which costs around KW10,000($10) and this includes the tour of the secret garden in Changdeokgung palace which is another UNESCO heritage site. Take note of the scheduled openings because they are closed on Mondays so you have to plan which palace to visit on certain days. As you enter the main gate (Gwanghwamun gate) look up and see the colorful artistry painted on the ceiling of this entry and beyond this gate it is a majestic site. The admission office is located at the right side after you enter the main gate and where you can also get a tourist map of Seoul. They have scheduled tours depending on your language and there are small buidings on each side where you can sign up and garb up in hanbok or guard costumes and have your picture taken. They have posted times for this too so if you get the chance sign up for the block of time and see what you look like in Joseon garb. It took me around 2-3 hours and make sure you take a picture of the Gyeongheoru pavilion its on the west side of the palace where the king supposedly entertained foreign dignitaries and diplomats. It is very picturesque and set in a lake with mountains as your background. There was a lot of people but the gounds are vast that you won't feel claustrophobic. Don't forget to visit the National Folk museum and the childrens museum at the rear of the palace. Entry to the museum is free but I rented an audio guide to get a little bit more information on the displays, which cost me around $1.

If there was only one palace you visit in Seoul, make sure it is Gyeongbokgung. Well maintained and on extensive grounds, you'll also see many other gates, halls and paviions. Time your visit so you can see the Sumunjang (Royal Guard) Changing Ceremony at 10:00, 13:00, 15:00 (20 minutes). If you go at 11:00, 14:00 and 16:00 you'll see a shorter 10 minute 'Gate Guard Duty' ceremony.

All the guidebooks to Seoul will tell you that Gyeongbokgung is a must see, and this is absolutely true. The history of this palace is covered extensively elsewhere, and all the practical information required is in the excellent KTO page http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_1_1_1.jsp?cid=264337  We bought an Integrated Ticket of Palaces which covers Changdeokgung, Changgyeonggung, Deoksugung, Gyeongbokgung and Jongmyo Shrine. This was excellent value at 10,000 won.  It was lovely wandering around Gyeongbokgung by ourselves but our visit would have been enhanced had we joined an English speaking tour, so time your visit for one of these groups. There are seats by the lake in the middle, so it is perfectly possible to bring a picnic and enjoy the visit at a leisurely pace - most of the visitors are either in large tour groups or school children on a history outing. This means that the palace is always busy; however there is no reason, if you are an independent traveller, to rush around and not appreciate the beauty of the whole compound, including the National Folk Museum.  If time permits, it is best to spend the whole day in this area as Insadong and Bukchon are close by, with its art galleries and independent craft shops. This is Seoul at its historical and cultural best and it would be a shame to factor in Gyeongbokgung as simply one more thing to cross off your Seoul 'to do' list.

Quite a mouthful to pronounce, Gyeongbokgung actually means "greatly blessed by heaven palace". Originally built in the 14th century, most of the buildings were destroyed over time but have now been faithfully reconstructed. Apparently some of the original buildings still exist. If you only have a day or two in Seoul make sure you visit this palace. The magnificent Gwanghwamun entrance gate overlooks a major square which is also worth visiting. The buildings take you back in time to the Joseon Dynasty and, if you're really into these kind of palaces, I suggest you take as much time as you like. We felt a couple of hours was enough for us but enjoyed roaming around and taking in the historic atmosphere which contrasted nicely with modern day Seoul. Better to get there as early as possible to avoid the crowds although make sure you see the changing of the guard. This colourful reenactment takes place 3 times a day, between 10 a.m and 3 p.m, and is well worth watching. The guards are dressed in royal uniforms and carry traditional weapons and musical instruments. For a moment you feel you are actually living in the 14th century.

Only know two palaces in Seoul that is popular, Gyeongbokgung and Changdokgeung. When I went over, bumped into a lot of local students who were on study trip, so it's very crowded. Changing guard ceremony is quite a moment to see. After that you can take a photo shoot with the guard in front of the gate Gwanghaemun. It is the top tourist destination too. Easily reach by subway orange color.
Had a nice walk in the palace and also visiting the folk museum just outside the actual palace compound.  Had a great lunch too in a traditional house in the district just east of the compound.
Surround by many visitor mainly from main land, the palace was well maintain and is looks totally Gorgeous to me. All the scene in Korea Historical drama come in live, and the feel just amazing .
All of it is worth to visit, you will experience new cultures and histories of South Korea. It is very unique and beautiful

If you have limited time in Seoul, I would recommend seeing this palace. Once you exit the subway exit, the palace is right in front of you. However, after a couple of minutes, things start looking the same. There are different buildings that you cannot enter. There is a history museum in the middle of the palace that is very well done; like Smithsonian type exhibits.
All of them are well worth the visit Gives some idea of the longevity and uniqueness of the womderful Korean people and culture

Not sure if it will be every Sunday that they have the changing of guards as it will be boring if you goes there without any 'show' or even a tour guide to guide you along. We were greeted by a teacher before we reached the palace. She had offered her student to bring us around the palace for a tour as part of the boy's curriculum. The cute Korean boy was indeed very good and speaks very good English. Entrance to the palace = Won 3000 only.  I enjoyed very much on every corner of this palace and after knowing the history behind it. I happened to be there during the cherry blossom and it was indeed very beautiful seeing the blooming flowers.
This is a huge palace complex where the buildings do tend to look like one another. The changing of the guard ceremony was precision marching at its best. The costumes were very elaborate.

Schedule your visit during the changing of the guards as it makes the trip more worth it. The palace is huge and it gets tiring to look at the royal rooms after quite some time. Still, you should go and be amazed that this piece of tradition is smacked right in the center of a busy metro.

This place was amazing and quite large (area wise). We took the subway from Sangsu Station (Hongdae) to Gyeongbokgung Station which is right near the palace. Make sure you take exit 5 when leaving the subway station. The palace sits right behind Gwanghwamun Square which makes for a great photo op. We arrived the gate, and the first thing we stumbled upon was the changing of the guards which was pretty cool. You can take pictures with the guards to when they are stationary!  Once we stopped posing with the guards, we entered the courtyard and headed toward the ticket counter. The price was really cheap (3,000 KRW = Approx 3 USD). We walked the grounds in it's entirety and was amazed by the detail and the scale of this complex. The cool thing is, if you look toward the mountain, you feel like you're actually in a time warp in the 1300's as their is no modern skyline.  Finally, this is a one/two punch if you were to take advantage of it as the National Folk Museum of Korea is around the back of this complex. All in all, that is one of the few places where it is cool to go multiple times.

Great place to spend 1-2 hours roaming around in this beautiful palace. Do catch the guards changing ceremony (earliest at 10am). This place offers many spots for nice photos! Gyeongbokgung Palace Station (Seoul Subway Line 3), Exit 5.

We didn't do all the palaces of Seoul, but if you are going to do one of them it should be this one. Not on the scale of Forbidden City in Beijing, but still very impressive.  Again very cheap entry fee, free 1 hour tour guides in different languages which was very informative, and the changing of the guard which is definitely worth the wait (many of these throughout the day) and great for photo ops with historical dressed soldiers.  Next to this are 2 museums (Folk and the Palace museum). Both are interesting and depends if you have time in your schedule. Folk is included in Palace ticket.

The grandest of all five palaces in Seoul. Remember to take brochure near the entrance. There is free guided tour (in english, japanese, chinese) but the chinese speaking guide that we followed was too soft speaking, barely could hear what she said even she spoke with amplifier, so i suggest to walk on your own with a brochure. Sad that i was too engrossed walking around taking pictures & forgot to refer back to the brochure for understanding the details of the palace.  Things to do: 1. Try hanbok for free. Need to register & wait for your turn. Closed during lunch hour. Can try posing & taking pictures with the guards wearing hanbok. 2. Watch the guards changing ceremony every hour from 10am-4pm. All the guards are really tall & fit. So funny that my nephew was so intimidated by the guards that he asked me to carry him haha.
Very interesting place with many things to see. To hire a guide would not be a bad idea, otherwise one can read all in the travel guide.

Having just visited Gyeongbokgung while on a short holiday break in Seoul last week, I would say its a worthwhile visit historically.  The entire infrastructure and size is comparable to Beijing's Forbidden Palace, though internally, many of the rooms are similar after a while. I have always have an interest in Korean historical artefacts, so while internally, it is not as elaborate in terms of design and ornaments decoration, the feel of how the royal palace was like in its heydays is still pretty interesting. Like all huge palaces, there are a labyrinth of the walkways, and it is easy to get lost if you are not following a map of the place.  Be prepared for an average of 3 hours exploratory walk, if you are intending to cover the entire area.  While there, be sure to visit the National Arts Museum, and the National Palace Musuem. A visit to both, together with the palace, gives a very good insight to the lifestyle of Korea during the Joseon dynasty period.

The first place I visited during my trip to Korea. Nice palace and definitely a must-visit in Korea. Too bad that I went during rainy day. The weather is so cold and the ground is a little bit muddy and we need to find a shelter inside a coffee shop to warm ourselves up.  We missed out the guards changing ceremony as we were late. Anyway, we still able to see the guards changing their position and marching a little, not too shabby.

If you are a first time visitor in Seoul, then it's a must see. they have guard change every hour. the whole complex is huge so get about 3 hours in there...you can also visit the Korean folk museum, national palace museum, and blue house (presidential office) right next to it.

A true exmple of Korean spirit of persistance, perseverance and art.  Huge wooden structures.....nicely decorated place yet exhibiting simplycity of Korean Emperors.  They keep organising cutural shows there dipicting ancient traditions and stories as well. Which makes it a must go attraction in seoul.  Nicely Managed place.......be ready to walk a long stretch to cover every part of it.

Access to this palace was very easy - just get off at the Gyeongbokgung subway station exit and its big entrance is right there. The palace structures were huge and the grounds were expansive. I particularly liked a spot near a small temple surrounded by water with swans. I can sit there for hours just taking the beauty of the whole place all in.

A must-see if you into history or culture. We visited in the morning and joined one of the few guided tours in English. Come here if you wish to learn about history and view the palace and ancient artifacts  Tips: The English tours are limited to a few timings per day so do plan ahead.  The palace is a 10-15 min walk from the train station. You can't see it from the station but it is not difficult to find your way there.

Gyeongbokgung, the "Palace Greatly Blessed by Heaven" is one of the "must visit" attractions in Seoul. It is centrally located in the heart of Seoul and can be covered in half a day with the nearby Gwanghwamun Square, Admiral Yi Sun Shin Monument, King Sejong Memorial Hall and the Cheonggyecheon Stream.  The nearest subway is the Gyeongbokgung Station at exit 5. We didn't use the subway. We were at Insadong, and we walked for about 10 minutes from Ssamji-gil and arrived at the Gwanghwamun Gate around 2:50 pm.  At the time of our arrival, there is no "Changing of the Guards Ceremony". We were not disappointed because the tall Imperial Guards standing at the arched gateway in their costumes make awesome photos. Admission tickets at 3,000won each are purchased inside the grounds and you can photograph these guards or watch the changing ceremonies at the Gwanghwamun Gate for free without purchasing admission tickets.  Free guided tour starts at the reception office inside Heungnyemun Gate. English tours are at 11.00am, 1.30pm and 3.30pm. Groups of 10 to 30 people require reservation. It is advisable to use a guide otherwise you'll be walking around and snapping pictures without a clue of what you are looking or photographing at.  The Gyeongbokgung Palace has some Chinese architectural influence and it reminded us of the Forbidden City in Beijing. There are some cherry blossoms here and it was said that the Japanese, during their occupation, had planted some of the trees on sacred and offensive locations within the palace ground. After the occupation, these offending trees were destroyed. But today, the remaining cherry blossoms add a softer touch to the Palace and provide a lovely landscape.  Gyeongbokgung Palace is a huge complex consisting of many areas, pavilions, ponds, halls, chambers and gates and will need about 2 to 3 hours of your time. The hexagonal Hyangwonjeong Pavilion looks impressive and it was a pity they barricaded the bridge to prevent entry. It could only be admired from across the pond. Hyangwonjeong Pavilion will look best during autumn.  Lockers are available and smoking is not allowed anywhere in the palace area, except at designated sites.  Date of visit: 19 April, 2013 Season: Spring Temperature: 12°C

We only went to one palace and we chose Gyeongbokgung cos the reviews said that this was the most majestic :) We went early, just before 0900hrs. Taxis will drop you by the side entrance, but do walk to the front (Gwanghwamun Gate) for the changing of guards. There's a few museums within the area, the National Folk Museum which we went to and the palace itself was pretty interesting. For those who like architecture, its pretty great :)

This is one of the bigger palaces in Seoul. One could easily spend 2-3 hours walking around. They have Guided tours every couple of hours till about 3:30pm. If you miss this, definitely get an audio guide, it could get a bit confusing without one. Changing of Guards ceremony happens 10 - 3pm every couple of hours, dont miss it! The National Folk Museum located inside is a must visit if you are interested in knowing a bit more about their History, Culture & Traditions.

This Korean architecture of this expansive palace contrasts markedly with the contemporary Seoul skyscrapers. One highlight is the hourly changing of the guard parade. There's an English tour conducted periodically which is essential if you want to understand what the place is all about. I believe they also have an audio tour available as an alternative. Well worth seeing to get a flavor of Korean history and culture. There were surprisingly few westerners there when we visited.
Superb architecture. Very interesting mix of buildings, gardens and temples. It has a good restaurant and is just besides a metro station.

Very attractive place and of course it's one of the list of a must go in Seoul. Easy to reach and sparkling place to visit. Very helpful staff and nice people too. Don't know why I saw so many Thai people, even wonder if I were in the wrong country. I like the soldiers in the fancy old style clothes just like in the dramas. Good for all generations!

It was supposed to be grand but despite the vastness and a couple of displays of the old settings of the palace, I came away without feeling impressed. It did cross my mind what a big place for the workers to get from place to place in the compound.

Arrived there at 10AM and caught the Changing of the Guards. There is even a small free brochure, in English, about this event. At 11AM there was the English tour. This really added interest with the new perspective on the Palace and its place in Korean history. Well worth the trip.

It was my first time in Seoul so I definitely wanted to see one of the palaces. Gyeongbokgung was beautiful and the weather was superb. We happened upon free entry on May 4th. It was great to walk around and there were actually quite a few girls in traditional costume and they were wonderful to see against the historical backdrop. I also recommend visiting the National Folk Museum next to the palace grounds.
the grandeur and size make it impressive. you may try traditional clothes for free but you must line up for your turn. well worth it.

This was a great spot to visit! The grounds were so beautiful and we really enjoy seeing the old buildings and palace. There is a large pond and even an exhibit of the large jars they would use to ferment food in for feasts. There is not air conditioning in many of the buildings, so summer time can be hot - bring water! If you go at the right time of day you can also see the ceremonial changing of the guard that was really interesting! One of the neatest things is that the entire site is located in the middle of the city so you can see sky scrapers right past the palace!
Time tour visit at main south entrance for one of the 4 daily guard changing inv ceremonies--- fun to see.
The area is immaculately preserved. They also make it so tourist friendly with the free Hanbok wearing and the changing of the guards ceremony for show.

If you are just going to Seoul for shopping, I'll say you may not like going to these historical places which can be a little dry.  But it's highly recommended especially for 1st time visitors to take some time off to read, see and learn how is the history like and how much hv been destroyed after the war. Take your time to stroll the gardens to take the city stress away. Try on the guards uniform for a fun photo taking at no costs.  Every country's historical buildings are to be respected for what they have been through with time. So we think its not a fair comparison to compare the different palaces. Just have an open mind to learn more of what was recorded during that era.
reminder of how imperialism - in this case Japanese tried to destroy the local narrative. Nice walk but ...

Korea is a place deeply entrenched in history. In Seoul, this main royal palace is part of that legacy. For a first time visitor in Seoul, I was awed by the magnificence of this grand place. I witnessed the changing of the guards which is a colorful ceremony and had a guided walk exploring the ceremonial hall, the king and queen quarters, the palace office and the peaceful garden by the lakeside. Upon exiting the palace, you will find the current Presidential Headquarters together with a museum which showcases Korea's culture and history.

I didn't find this as interesting as Changdeokgung palace but it is different. Catch the changing of the guards if you can and on a nice day it is very pleasant to wander around the building complex and the grounds.
The Palace was closed when I went on 30 April (not sure why) but it did look impressive from the outside.

I visited this and Changdeokgung palace. It's different. Although I prefer the Forbidden City in Beijing, palaces in South Korea is different in architecture and layouts. The garden is beautiful.  Only went into Chandgeokgung palace. Skipped the secret garden as it was raining and didn't think I will get to appreciate the beauty of the garden (not that I know) without the sun!
A wonderful experience walking around the palace grounds, the National Palace museum is located right beside the palace representing the majesty of the 500 year history of the Joseon Dynasty.
English tour guide was excellent. The cherry trees had just started to bloom so the visitors from all nations and the native Koreans seemed to be more interested in the trees than the buildings.

Make sure you do not miss the exchange of guards which start around 10am. It is almost an hour show and worth watching. Take note that this takes place outside Gyeongbokgung and you need not purchase a ticket to watch this!
Would have been even prettier if the cherry blossom trees had bloomed :( Very well kept and clean. The paint on the palace roof is still very vibrant.

This palace stands out at a main intersection. If you've already been to another of the big palaces like Changdeokgung, as I had, then it will look familiar. Nevertheless, they have a changing of the guard every 2 hours or so, which is very colourful and makes a good photographic opportunity especially on a bright sunny day. It's worth a look. Take note that it is closed on Tuesdays.
with a very good guide, one can learn a lot from this place. loved the "changing of guards" ceremony with actor-guards in complete costumes.

This palace is a "must see" for any trip to Seoul. The surroundings are absolutely beautiful with mountains in the background, manicured gardens and fish ponds. You can experience how the royal family used to live hundreds of years ago and then step out the gate into downtoen Seoul. Walking shoes a good idea due to the large area to be covered and the uneven surface area (ancient paving stones, not concrete). The changing of the guard ceremony also interesting as well as the exhibits of life in ancient Korea.

Gyeongbokgung is definitely a must visit tourist attraction when you're in Seoul. It's at the heart of Seoul and lets you experience the history of how life was like for South Koreans. The architecture of the buildings are amazingly beautiful. There are performances at the grand entrance, tours in different languages for free and it costs less than $3 to the admission fee. This place is definitely huge so make sure to wear walking shoes.

We were here a few years ago. The palace is really cool! We loved learning about the history and all the detail in the architecture. The guard ceremony was neat also. they have headsets to describe everything you are seeing. However, not long after we got there we met a teenage girl that wanted to practice her english so we let her be our tour guide! Loved this place, a great experience!
There are a couple of palaces in Seoul. Both are different enough to enjoy separately, but you must see at least one.

Gyungbok Palace was used as a King's place during Joseon dynasty. You can feel Korean royal family's life and there living standard. Also, you can enjoy beautiful nature in Gyungbok Palace. Don't forget other palaces around Gyungbok Palace like Changduk Palace or Changgyung Palace.

The changing of the guard that happens at 10am is free and was pretty cool to see. You need to pay 3000 won to get in to see the rest of the site but it is worth it.  The site is very big and you also get access to the folk museum

one of my favourite destinations in seoul, this is a MUST SEE! how beautiful the grounds are here, and so serene and relaxing in the heart of this very very busy city. great for a picnic lunch, be sure to allow yourself a few hours here to just relax, wander around and enjoy this quiet. really really magical!

Guide books advised us that the gate opening took place at 9am. This is incorrect. The gate opening takes place at 10am. You can catch them warming up at 9.45. It's worth watching though and try to get to the palace early to avoid the crowds. We got there for 9am and we got some lovely photos, tour groups start pouring in from about 9.30am. 11.30am is the first English tour.
plenty of phoyo opportunities with guards changing and the buildings and you can try on a uniform and watz around its very funny and worth doing and as always everyone is friendly
Prepare for a long walk if we want to explore the whole areas. The whole were very clean and well-maintained. The palaces have colorful detail and interesting pattern on many parts of them.

We visited the palace as a family on a Sunday morning and spent appr 2 hours here. As has been mentioned in many reviews, a lot of parts of this palace are rebuilt due to destruction suffered during Japanese occupation. Nevertheless, it remains very impressive. Since we had our two children with us (10 and 15) we didn't opt for any tours (they tend to get bored easily) but just wandered around the grounds. There were plenty of information tablets near all major sites and all were available in English so no language barrier there. We arrived at appr. 10.50 and were able to take some shots of the kids with the colourful guards in front of the palace. The changing of the guards on the hour made for a lovely video shot. Once inside the gate the ticket booths were located towards the right hand side. When we went in there were only 2-3 people queuing in front of us so no delays in purchasing tickets. The grounds are huge so you can easily spend some hours just wandering about, taking scenic shots (and have them taken by Koreans of you as well!). We had a coffee outside the cafe in the sun which was lovely and priced similarly to the rest of Seoul. Overall a great place to start your sightseeing. Very easy to do and beautiful shots to get. I would make sure you go in good weather though since virtually all of it is outside (you will only be able to look inside the buildings from windows).

Due to the destruction of much of their heritage during several periods of Japanese occupation, Koreans are in many cases literally rebuilding their history. So many (parts) of their old temples and palaces seem a bit 'new'. Having said that, Gyeongbokgung was a lovely place to visit and see part of their architecture and heritage.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the many attractions in Seoul. The place presents a vivid view of the life of South Korean royalty during the olden days. It is easy to get around the palace grounds because of multi-lingual signage all over the area (English, Korean, Japanese). There is also an audio tour provided to visitors who want to avail of it. The palace grounds is so vast. It has certain similarities with Chinese architecture.  To get to Gyeongbokgung, you can take the subway or the bus. You can also take the Seoul City Tour Bus which has its last stop at Gyeongbokgung.

We visited this Palace on our first day in Seoul. It was the perfect introduction to Korea and antidote to jetlag. We walked for about three hours..you can spend even more time there. Bring water and snacks. Take time to rest and enjoy the beautiful lake .

The palace was not too big, 2 hour was enough to spend there. The things I like from this palace was, there were Hanbook rent for free, beside the cafeteria. But had to queue, since many local and tourist used this facility.

Wow ... What a great piece of architecture ad restoration. This palace is the largest and one of 5 palaces in Seoul. I joined a tour and this was one of the inclusions.  It was good to have someone explain all the history and show me through. Wonderful colors and history.  Look out for the changing of the guards - a parade of wonderful costumes, sounds and pagentary. Lots of people scrambling to get photos but wait until the end and you will get shots of guards leaving .  I wish I had more time as tour only allocated an hour which also include the national folk museum. This is a must see if you have limited time. The other palace I saw was very similar ad I don't think it's worth doing two palaces.

Just use a jacket, long john, and sneakers, and ... you are ready to enjoy Gyeongbokgung Palace in winter. It may provide a slight different experience when we visited Gyeongbokgung Palace in the thickest snow in Seoul history in 2010. It was a little bit chilly, however, it was wonderful seeing the guards hand over ceremony. Do not forget to take pictures by wearing traditional guard costumes for free - a brilliant opportunity.

It was amazing to see how totality lived... And there day to day habits. The architecture is a sight to behold. I was amazing to see how Japan and chime ha influence in the way they developed there land and also to know that korea has been invaded by both but still in the end Korea fought through. Even if your not big into history the views, plant life, and entertainment is enough to take up your whole day. Don't forget to see the changing of the guards. And for 3,000 won you can't beat that... Plus free admittance to the national folk museum right next door.

I liked the fact that this complex was restored very well. Though it suffered a lot of damages due to the war and the Japanese occupation, I found this royal palace to be a more sober and enjoyable example compared to Beijing's Forbiddne City. More information available in english, less crowded, and very clean

This palace is spread over a huge distance.There are lots of buildings are beautiful. This is palace is worth seeing. On buying the entrance ticket we were given a map and an English guide. This was good as it allowed us to walk around the grounds at our leisure. the only problem is that my map reading skills are nil. It was quite cold when I went there but I can imagine this place would be amazing with blossoms.  It ia worth seeing.

Definitely recommend this. See the changing of the guard, and they also do a little performance every hour. Recommend getting a tour. Its much more interesting as you hear about the kings and queens who lived in korea back in the days.

Great Place to be. Wonderful seeing the guards hand over ceremony in the morning. The views inside are great. Guided tours In Englishare even more fascinating. Dont miss the photo spot near the ponds inside.
Nothing exciting.  Its ok but not a match for other parts of Seoul, dont go out your way to go.  Kids were bored inside 5 munutes.

Its a very interesting place to visit. Especially if you get there to see the changing of the guards. It shoows you the historical way of the past, and afterwards you are allow to take pictures with the guards once they are in position at their post. I wish I could have seen it in the summer time when the trees and flowers would be at full bloosom.

A huge and impressive palace complex, which does bear some comparison to both the style and layout of Beijing's Forbidden City. The front gate guards change every hour on the hour, and offer a colourful photo opportunity. Line 3 to Gyeongbokgung, and exit 5 to the front gate.

Well kept, vibrant and well preserved. You will enjoy an afternoon stroll here and definitely enjoy visiting the museums. Nice souvenirs and reasonably priced. They have great views to take pictures of and is one of the palaces that you would think of revising.

My boyfriend and I came here after the one hour tour at Changdeokgung in the huge park east of here. We decided to stop in before lunch as the site is smaller on the map. Poor planning! This place is HUGE and has so much stuff inside! You really need to set aside a lot of time for this area! There are 3 museums in the area you can see (one is hidden under the statue of a man sitting on the street in front). After you check out the changing of the guards, you can check out tons of buildings on the inside. If you bring kids, this is definitely a full day! Luckily there is a variety of things here to do that keep it interesting. A must-see in Seoul!

If you will like to visit only 1 palace, may I suggest this one. English guided tours run 3 times a day, please check for the times. Its especially useful to walk around with an english speaking guide, it breathes life to the place.  The palace grounds is the largest amongst the other palaces in Seoul. The spaces is majestic and grand. Located next to the Gyeongbukgung palace are a few museums, which is included in the ticket price of 3000won.  There are guards dressed in traditional costume at the gates. There is a guard change ceremony which makes the visit interesting.

i have visited this amazing place at my second day in Seoul and it was -6C but still i spent hours around... lucky me i saw the changing guards ceremony in the morning and went around with a local tour guide which helpful to understand every spots inside the palace its a huge complex, silent, clean (even icy everywhere) and brought me back to the past when i walked and sit silent inside the complex.. when i was there, i took many pictures and i just couldn't stop to do it... it a must place to visit when you are in Seoul and spend more time around... for sure i will be back here if i visit Seoul in other season (it was winter)
Our family love to visit museums and historical landmarks. This palace is a really nice place to learn about the traditions of the Koreans. It is well preserved and worth a visit.

Gyeongbokgung is one of the 5 grand palaces of Seoul and very rightly so. It was mostly destroyed by the Japanese after the Korea occupation and so far they have only been able to restore half the buildings! It occupies a large area close to downtown and can be easily reached by subway - just stop at the station with the same name (line3). One of the highlights is the changing of the guards which happens every hour. It also houses the National Folk Museum, a comprehensive guide to the soul of Korean people, including the history of the ever present Kimchi. You should not miss both.

Do drop by this area and view the palace. It's huge and a lot of historic moments that you able to experience. Around it, there are other palaces as well. If you have time, can visit all, else just choose this one and it's good enough to leave good memory :)

This is probably the largest palace in Seoul. The vastness of the grounds is imposing and certain structures are really fascinating. The main attraction, though, would have to be the changing of the guards that happen at 10am. Be sure to see it, as there's nothing quite like it. You can take the guided tour or go around on your own. It's not very difficult to go around, and the maps indicate which are the notable landmarks to visit. I thought it was fascinating, but despite being so large, it somehow pales in comparison to Cheongbukdong. It's still something to see, though.

It was ok, nothing overally special I didn't think, but then I was by myself. I watched the changing of the guard and then looked around the palace, might have been more beneficial if you got a guide.

As a largest palace in South Korea, there are many different palaces within the palace to view and take photographs. There is even a pond right behind the King's concubines' quarters that has a pavilion in the centre.  The only thing I disliked about it was that I spent at least 3 hours exploring the palace, including the 2 museums within the palace.
Fantastic place so much to see and read about ,great help is the Guide book (in various languages ) Great place to spend the day .

It's kind of interesting to walk around the Palace grounds and imagine what live was like, but every building looks the same because they've all be recently rebuilt. It kind of lacks the feel of a historic site. Feel free to just watch the changing of the guard ceremony and take a picture for a guard or two, but don't spend more than an hour here. There better things to see.
A major cultural and tourist attraction. Not to be missed, along with the Palace museum,which houses artifacts and gowns of the royal family .

We arrived at 10am to see the changing of the guard ceremony which was really fun to see. Then we bought our tickets and waited for the start of the English tour. The grounds are massive, so allow enough time here. We only spent 30 minutes in the Folk Museum which was not nearly enough time, but we were in a hurry. I'm still amazed at how reasonable entrance fees are in Seoul--just three dollars US for this place. I highly recommend seeing this palace.

This palace is located at the base of a mountain on one side and the busy city of seoul on the other. It is beautiful to see the traditional Palace surrounded by the modern Seoul of today. This palace is large and takes a while to walk all the way through but the buildings are beautiful and the history is interesting. We missed the tour so we took one of the information booklets and did a self guided tour and it was great. There is a lot of information given in the booklet. The tickets are inexpensive and the changing of the guard is narrated in 3 languages. Definitely a must do in Seoul!
The massiveness of the palace, the kings swimming pool, and the change of guards is also a wonderful sight.

This is the #1 palace to see if you can only see one. Highly recommend the tour. Only a few english tours a day, so check your guide book or the website for schedule. If you can't make the tour, pick up a pamphlet at the information office, there isn't any signage on the grounds explaining what anything is. Changing of the guard happens every hour on the hour, that's worth seeing. Also recommend the integrated palaces ticket if you plan to visit a lot of palaces. It's a good value and saves the standing in line at every palace to buy tickets.

This palace is very beautiful and huge. If you are a kdrama lover, you'll find some parts of the palace that is used to shoot some kdramas. It was winter when we visited Gyeongbokgung, so it was very cold. You can just wander around by yourself or guided by available tour guides there.

The National Folk Museum (in the grounds) is free. For those interested in Korean history and culture, it is a must. $3 to wander around the palace grounds is not bad value but adds little to your knowledge or understanding - it is merely a photo opportunity.
It is old palace of traditional ear in Korea. Pretty beautyful and attractive place.

Definitely worth the visit. Best schedule is 3 pm changing of the guards with music and very choreographed procession, then quickly buy tickets and take the free guided tour in English. Our guide clearly loved that place /the guides are volunteers/ and even though she said it will be an hour, it was 1:40 overall. That gives you still a good hour until the closing time to soak up the atmosphere.it was quite damaged in the Japanese occupation, so they are rebuilding it, but its huge and not too crowded. A wonderful insight into the history of Chosen dynasty.
On a very short visit to Seoul we visited the grounds of this palace and a couple of rooms. I wish we had more time and better guidance to the variety of things to know about this palace.
Going to this palace end of february with a group tour. so we know about the history abaout this palace. What a nice palace.

This is the second time we have visited this Palace just to watch the parade of soldiers who perform the Changing of the Guard. They are wearing colorful costumes and march around some of the area of the huge forecourt. There are many performances on the hour and some are short - 5 minutes or so- and some are 20 minutes in length with photo opportunities available.

It was my second time visiting the palace and I am still fascinated by the beauty of this place. I would always revisit Gyeongbokgung. On a little side note, I was once in October and the other time in February, I would recommend going in fall, because in winter it is freezing cold!!! and the ways are quite muddy.

Although most of the buildings are rebuilt in recent years, there are various guard changing ceremonies held throughout the day. at 11am 1pm and 3pm there is a procession with drums and music and at 2pm and 4pm is a simpler guard changing ceremony.
Very interesting, clean. A great place to see the history of Korea. Very beautiful grounds, well kept, not crowded.

We learned a lot about the history of this palace and the effect that the poor relations with the Japanese has had on this treasure. Most of it has been rebuilt. Go on the hour when there is a changing of the guard.

It was only coincidental that we went during the eve of the Lunar New Year, but it was great that we did because we got to see some traditional performances outside the National Folk Museum just beside the palace grounds. We also got the chance to have a free photo-taking session dressed up in traditional Korean costumes. The palace and its grounds were also amazing, like you were in a Korean historical drama, and everything was covered with snow, so it was such a great scene to take in. We were also lucky enough to see the changing of the palace guards at Gwanghwamun. This is a must place to visit in Seoul!

this is the also one of the "must see" place when you go on city tour, at front of Sejong King Statue, go on there at 10.00 then you will see the guard changing ceremony, and after that you can taken your picture with them, it was great,,,

The Gyeongbokgung Palace or the Palace Greatly Blessed by Heaven was built in 1395 and consists of several buildings including a Throne Hall, residences of the Crown Prince, the Concubines and Court Ladies, a library, a pavilion in the middle of a (frozen) pond, all surrounded by sprawling gardens. The property is beautifully maintained and there is so much history around it. This should be part of every first-time visitor's itinerary. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes as there is a lot of ground to cover. I went in January, at the height of the Korean Winter, but enjoyed the walking tour immensely, despite the cold. Get there early in the morning (I arrived before 10AM) to avoid the queue at the ticket booth and the crowds. Don't miss the colorful Changing of the Guards ceremony that happens daily at 11AM. At the end of the ceremony, there's an opportunity to have your photos taken with the guards. The entrance fee of KRW3000 -- roughly US$2.50 -- is a small price to pay to see this picturesque, historical attraction. From my personal experience, it's not necessary to pay to join a group or package tour to get to this attraction. It's easy to get to this place. I went on my own and didn't have any issues. From my hotel in Myeong-dong District, I took the Seoul Metro (move from Line 4 to Line 3) to get there. Exit 5 takes you right to the doorstep of the Palace Museum, a few steps from which you'll find the ticket booth for the Palace itself. When you get to the Palace, there are free information brochures in all languages and best of all, free guided tours. English tours are scheduled at 11AM and 1:30PM.
It was a lovely, cold day. I was a little underwhelmed by the signage and organization of the Palace, but I loved that the museum attached was free and well-done.

This is my second time visited this place,first time is at 2003.To me it is nothing much different.You can see a lot of tradisional Korea style building all the way.We walked a lot to see all the houses and palaces as the place is very big and spacious except the specific palace which need to buy another ticket.You have to pay more if you want to visit more palaces. We bought ordinary entrance tickets only.The first time I came is during summer time,the scenes are so-so.The second time is during autumn,the views are totally different because we can see very beautiful maple trees.

I saw the guard changing ceremony at 3 pm on a Saturday. There are several free English guided tour per day. I was on the last one of the day at 3:30 pm. The lady was really nice and showed us the most important part of the palace. The explanation gave us a good perspective about the life of palace. The tour lasts about one hour. If the weather was not freezing the day i was there, I am sure I will be more happy about the trip. The only indoor place is the folk museum on the side. Overall, I enjoyed the palace tour.

I've been here several times over the past decade as people have come to visit me in Seoul. My guests aren't usually too excited by the experience. I routinely ask locals if they've been and locals rarely have been more than 1 or 2 times in their lives.

Too bad that we went here in the afternoon that is why we missed the changing of guards. What I really like the most is the big landscape of the palace and the mountain views in the palace. When we where there the small room in the middle of the lake reminds me of Moon embraces the sun. I really want to go there but it is restricted to visitors. We were already tired at the time when we visited this palace so we spent a little time in here.

The name translates as the Palace of Shining Happiness. This palace has survived a lot of wars and rulers making is historical site a representation of how strong korea is as a nation and it's citizenry. The interesting folk museum and palace museum is housed here including beautiful traditional korean gardens. When in gyeongbogkung you must witness the royal changing of the guards that happens every hour from 10am - 3pm and of course have photos with the korean guards as well

The main attraction of going to Gyeongbokgung is to watch the changing of the guards. They say it is historically accurate, complete with exchange of passwords and stuff. It’s best to time your visit to watch the changing of the guards, and then go on the free guided tour which I think runs every hour. The tour guide gave lots of interesting information about the architectural features of the palace, like why there are three “lanes” going into the palace from the gates, or how the palace is heated during the winter months. She also gave told us a bit of history of Korea, the palace and the kings that occupied it. Overall it was 2 hours well spent.  If you’re into walking a lot, Gyeongbokgung is walking distance from Insadong, Jongmyeo Shrine, Changdeokgung Palace, Gwanghwamun Square and Cheonggyecheon Stream. So from Gyeongbokgung there are quite a number of choices of places you can go to.

Visiting a palace is an essential item in your Seoul itinerary. Gyeongbok-gung is one of the top palace and it is worth a visit as it is within easy reach via Subway.  Taking pictures with the guards are free and they are all dressed in traditional Korean Costume, if you time your visit correctly you can see the changing of guards too !

The name translates as the Palace of Shining Happiness. This palace has survived a lot of wars and rulers making is historical site a representation of how strong korea is as a nation and it's citizenry. The interesting folk museum and palace museum is housed here including beautiful traditional korean gardens. When in gyeongbogkung you must witness the royal changing of the guards that happens every hour from 10am - 3pm and of course have photos with the korean guards as well

Worth a visit for a glimpse of historic Seoul. The changing of the guard (a few times a day) is fun to see and hear.  The palace is wonderful to see juxtaposed between the mountain on one side and the modern city on the other.  The place is massive. You could explore for hours easily.

Impressive, huge Korean style royal palace. A must see in Seoul, but beware visiting involves a lot more walking AROUND buildings than inside them, and January in Seoul is usually bitterly cold, so dressing appropriately is essential (i.e. at least skiing-type clothes). I enjoyed the visit in spite of the cold, although I expected it to be a lot more about interior decoration than it proved to be the case.

We went there this Jan and we saw the ceremony of the guards changing. Really nice. The palace is huge and really nice altough not the originsl one - that was distroyed long time ago and they rebuild it after that. It is well preserved and you can feel the days of the dunasty. Also you have access to the national museum and there are lovely exhibitions. Go and visit!

Gyeongbokgung Palace is interesting in the fact that it layed in ruins for over 200 years!
