From the late 16th century until the mid 19th century Gyeongbokgung was abandonded, Changdeokgung Palace was the main palace of the royal family during this time. Therefore, it must be noted there is basically nothing inside the palace that dates before the major rebuilding period of the 1860's.  So while there are a few buildings that are between 100 and 150 years old, sadly much of the palace was destroyed during the Japanese Colonial period. What we see today is a masterful reproduction of the original with a few important authentic Joseon buildings still remaining. Most of the buildings that we see are very recently built, just in the last 20-30 years.  Nevertheless, I always enjoy my time here. For one, the palace has a grand atmosphere, the buildings are large and are built in classic Joseon architecture. My favorite palace is without a doubt Changdeokgung, in large part because it is the best preserved palace and the gardens are exquisite. I do feel however, that the two palaces compliment each other. Changdeokgung is the authentic Joseon palace, which is typically called the most "Korean" of all 5 Joseon palaces. Gyeongbokgung is really a product of the final years of the Joseon Dyansty, and the architecture is built in a style that is supposed to legitimize the Korean King as an Emperor.  For anyone who enjoys history (like myself) you will enjoy Gyeongbokgung. I had plenty of time in Korea, so I was able to visit all 5 royal palaces on more than one occassion. If you only have time to visit one palace, visit Changdeokgung, but if you have more time, by all means enjoy the grand Gyeongbokgung Palace.

Not much to see when you're inside the palace. As the palace was destroyed and burnt before, many parts are still under reconstruction. However, it's worth watching the changing of guards taking place at the entrance of the palace every hour of the day. You don't have to pay to watch this.

After repeated requests from our tour guide for a chance to don the Hanbok ( traditional Korean costume), my daughter and i finally got the opportunity to do so within the confines of the Gyeongbokgung Palace. It meant cutting short the palace tour proper and queuing up for about two hours at a designated place. When noontime came, the attendant advised us that they would be closing for lunch and would be resuming at 1 pm. Since we were already next in line, our Korean guide pleaded that we be allowed a few minutes extension since our bus was no longer capable of waiting for us much longer.They understood our predicament and finally conceded. My daughter and i were given the choice of color and kind of costume we wanted to wear. A costumed Korean "lady-in-waiting" assisted the both of us inside the dressing room. She asked us to remove our rubber shoes and produced two pairs of Korean shoes for us to wear . She then motioned us, one at a time to go up an elevated platform, to spread our arms as she went about fastening the costumes in a wrap-around fashion on top of our shirt and pants. Our guide ably took our souvenir shots wearing these costumes at the palace grounds. We boarded our tourist bus, happy at having completed the Hanbok experience..

This is a must-see if you want to learn and see old Korean style buildings. It is beautiful. Do not miss the change of the guards. Easy to combine with the shopping area (authentc Korean style) Insadong on walking distance.

Considering Korea has lots of these palaces, we aimed to see the best and chose Gyeongbukgong and we were definitely not disappointed. Our visit was like a time travel to the early days of how Korea was like. As a K-drama fanatic myself, it was definitely worth a visit if you go to Korea.
this is a beautiful palace, with traditional guards out front. there are several "changing of the guard" ceremonies throughout the day, make sure you stay for one of these.

Gyeongbokgung is a great palace, a traditional Korean palace open for tourists and citizens. There are several scenic palace and places for tourists, including a banquet place, and beautiful garden and lake with snow on the surface.

Gyeong-bok-gung  The magnificent Gyeongbokgung, which was first built in 1395, had a painful and bitter historical background. The Palace, or the complex, was actually destroyed twice under different circumstances during the period of 600 years. The present spectacular Palace complex was rebuilt to their past glory and splendor only as from 1990.  The Palace complex is very important to the people of Korea, as it is a national symbol of sovereignty to them. Visitors should not just admire the beauty of the well-kept gardens, ponds and lakes, but spend time to appreciate the various structures, some of which were constructed entirely according to Korean architectural designs; others were built under foreign influences. Different palaces were also built to serve different purposes, such as grand halls for ceremonial functions, rooms for discussing affairs of the State with officials, halls for entertainment, rooms for reading and writing for the monarch, private quarters of the royalties, and for their servants.  There are four main gates in the Palace Complex; the most famous gate will be the Gwang-hwa-mun, where traditional ceremonial changing of the guards is performed at fixed intervals. But most important of all, visitors should avail themselves the opportunity to visit the adjoining presidential ground, which was closed for many years for security reason, but opened to the general public only in early 2011.
i have been there for more than 3 times, in different seasons, winter is the best time to pay the visit, especially after the snow

Visited Gyeongbokgung late November so it was starting to get chilly. It is easily accessed via the Gyeongbokgung Palace station on Seoul Subway line 3. We were able to catch the Changing of the Guards. Don't forget to take tons of photos with the guards and the lovely red and yellow foliage.

Easy access from subway. The exit/entrance from subway was decorated to have a feel of the historic palace. A palace with cluster dwellings for the palace workers. Beautiful architecture and carvings made for good photography. They have a procession of guards at certain time of the day. They have FREE guides done by students in English! You can see them in their bright orange jacket. A few other museum around the palace grounds. This place is huge! Take us a few hours to cover the whole ground. Only our hunger for lunch stop us from covering the whole ground. There's a cafe in the museum building to have hot coffee. We head to Insadong for lunch which is nearby across the street. Visited in December 2012.

The palace is a must stop if in the Insadong area. This is a Truly a photogenic stop with a piece of the past in the middle of a shiny modern city, complete with the mountains and trees framed perfectly by the design of the palace and surrounding gardens. It was a very cold outdoor walk for us on X-mas eve but worth it for the history and beauty. Warm up after in any of the nearby coffee or tea shops, there's even a Starbucks located just up the street. ;) I imagine summer and fall are the best walks here for the gardens and Koi ponds that were very frozen over at the time of our visit. A Lovely walk about.. back in time.

Just amazing when it's covered in snow ... we wanted to rent hanboks but was told that it was unavailable due to the weather. Very nice walk outside the palace along Samchongdonggil towards other museums and plenty of cafes to chill along the way ...

The snow doesn't stop anyone from visiting, I think it made the place more beautiful. Wear decent shoes in the winter though, because the paths were not all cleared of the snow and it was deep in a few places.

You may have watched some dramas and well reality is better than on tv. I went to Gyeongbok during fall and it was magical! The trees were turning red and yellow and with the mountains in the background everything seemed like a dream. It is one of the best place to go in Seoul! Very pretty.
Enjoy walking around at this palace, tickets include museums visits. Trees in the garden are very nice during my period of visit. Walking distance to InsaDong. Easy access to this palace

The palace grounds is nice and really big,but I wished they did not run of English guide books though because there are some beautiful structures that I have missed, especially the very photogenic pavillion. I enjoyed the hourly changing of guards ceremony as well.

Imagine large palace with interesting stories behind them.... hence, it'll be good if you manage to catch a guide that gives free tour at regular interval.  Be sure to get there before 4pm or so (please check closing timing as it differs time to time) as ticketing close an hour before closing time... we missed it by ten minutes during our first trip there :(  There's a National Palace Museum at the side with some interesting displays, taking about an hour or less to finish viewing, a good side visit if you have some time on hand,... or happened to missed the ticketing time (like us)
This is part of Gyeongbokgung Palace so I'm not sure why it has it's own post. The palace was beautiful.

Even on December 23rd when it is below 0C/32F it was packed--I have only one photo that does not have 10 other tourists in it. Very large--largest palace I think (at least with half of Changdeokgung being closed). Even though it was packed, there was an odd feeling of vacancy there because of how large it is.

We took the English tour and it certainly gives more information than what is posted on the signs around the palace. The palace is pretty, even in winter, but I think it would be nicer in warmer weather. The changing of the guards was cut short due to extreme cold weather (a little below freezing). The information here really complements the Jongmyo Shrine tour (we did the shrine first, but either order would work).

as it snowed and rained the day before, the staff sprinkled sand everywhere to prevent people from slipping on the frozen water puddles on the ground. shoes became super dirty with mixture of water and sand = mud but still, it's for safety reasons. palace is just like any other regular palace with courtyard etc..

There are many Palaces in Seoul so unless you have a lot of time, you need to limit the ones you do see. I chose two and this is one of them. The reasons are that it has a changing of the guards ceremony and also the beauty of the grounds. This palace has the oldest history of Royalty in Korea (the Joseon Dynasty) and is the largest and once inside and you see the enormity of it you will understand the Royalty that it once stood for. The changing of the guards starts inside the main gate and marches to the front of the entrance, which is also called the Gwanghwamun Gate, so if taking pictures, you need to place yourself inside first. I actually like the changing of the guards ceremony at Deoksugung Palace better, but this one is good also. Once inside, and you need to buy a ticket, the grounds are enormous, and go forever. I like the Kimchi building with the different size kettles, and the large central pond. There are many buildings here. I would suggest doing this tour earlier in the day rather than later, as it will get tiring. Definite visit on your Seoul trip.

My visit to Gyeongbokgung Palace was a definite highlight of my time in Seoul. It is the largest of the five Grand Palaces from the Joseon Dynasty, and it's grandness and majesty have to be seen to be believed. Make sure you get there in time to see the changing of the guard, which happens every hour from 10am to 3pm. The National Folk Museum is also housed in the grounds of the palace, and is well worth a visit. Admission to the Palace is 3,000 won (adults) and 1,500 won (children).

The palace offers free guided tour (first one for English starts 11am) but unfortunately the timing was not right for us. We were told that there are uni students giving free tours of the palace as well but we could not locate them. That was why we decided to rent an audio guide for 3,000won. The content was informative but if you don't mind reading, I recommend that you skip the audio guide and go for the free guide book that you can find once you enter the ticketed entrance. The written guide comes with illustration & pictures, to give you a better idea on what to look out for.  The palace is very accessible. We took the metro to Gyeongbukgong metro stop. One of the exits will lead you straight to the palace. The palace wasn't very crowded when we first got there at 9am, but the crowds started to stream in by the time we left at 1pm.  The buildings in the palace are small but the palace grounds is quite large. Note that many of the buildings are restored works rather than originals. The landscaping looked nice and left me desiring ti want to see it in spring & autumn.

It's a huge place, but a lot of the buildings were actually restored and not its original state. There are also some buildings still under restoration. After a short while of walking, the buildings look kinda similar to me, but that's just me.  The changing of palace guards ceremony was pretty interesting though, so that's something you should check out if you have the chance.

Nice palace. There is a very elaborate changing of the guard ceremony that takes about 15 minutes and start in the center grounds and moves out to the front gate and finishes in the center court. Definitely worth the trip.

Honestly I was inspired to come here because of historical KDramas like Jewel in the Palace, Yi San and Roots. It's truly magnificent and inspiring. I was lucky to witness the changing of the guards so check the times before you go so you don't miss out on that aaand the other ceremony, I think it was crowning the King or him visiting-it was a spectacle to see all his subjects lining up and all the musicians and dancers in celebration. I rented the audio guide and tried to match it with the map. I suggest at least having that if you miss the guided English tour-otherwise the visit may deem boring and meaningless. Come with an open mind to discover the wisdom and experience of a different culture! The tickets are beyond cheap as singles but you can also buy a pack-one for each palace as well. Enjoy!

Feels a little bit too restored, but there is a great juxtaposition between the Japanese and Korean architecture here. The changing of the guard is great to see as well and the complex is huge! Definitely worth a visit in Seoul.

I used to see lively events at the Gyeongbokgung premises five years ago when my family visited the site. There were bult-up rooms with characters and figurines inside as well as Hanbok costumes photos sessions. On 17Dec2012, it was a great dismay as many rooms are boarded up.

Maybe I'm biased because I already visit a gazillion palaces and historic sites in Beijing prior to my Seoul trip, so Gyeongbokgung did not really stand out as a "must see". However, I will say the highlight was watching the changing of the guards ceremony as that was something unique to me. The guards are all really tall and good looking like in the Korean dramas, which is always a plus :) I did not go into the palace, but if you love sightseeing and history, perhaps it's worth it!
We got a free tour by booking online via the Korea Tourism Board. It was interesting and scenic although some parts can be dragging. Entrance ticket is quite cheap too.

With so many palace around, we decided to just go to this one. The entrance fees is pretty cheap. Took and audio guide too, but found it not necessary as there is a free English guided tour. Remember to go see the guard changing ceremony.

I'ts actually my second time to visit gyeongbukgung palace. First time during autumn, this time at the onset of winter. I'd say it looked better during autumn but then there was no snow yet when I came, so...  What facinated was the history that unfolded on its walls. It's a visit, even just to bring home that iconic picture in front of its gate:-)and during the changing of the guards ceremony
Nice to see the changing of the guard. I think they have it each day and definitely worth checking out.
The in-house guide was great and informative! She was also passionate about what she was telling us. I now understand the Koreans grief over losing their royalty because of the deeds of the Japanese.
You can see very beautiful scenery around the Palace especially in Autumn. Colorful trees will take your breath away :)
This place is very neat. It is well kept and beautiful. It does get busy so get there early and see everything before the crowd takes the place over.

What a beautiful palace, and as with all monuments in Korea, so well-looked after ... the changing of the Guard is not to be missed, the soldiers are so impressive in their costumes... also very rewarding visit inside the King's quarters, plus stunning pagoda building of the National Folk Museum ...
All place are very beautiful there althought many people but still cozy, relax and comfortable.. Beautiful and wonderful palace..

Nice place to take photos. Quite a bit smaller than the Forbidden City in Beijing. But, there distinct differences in the Chinease architecture and the Korean one. But, you have to look for it. If you find it, its work the visit. Especially, if you arrive in time for the "Changing of the Guards".

Visited Gyeongbokgung during autumn and had a very pleasant time here. The complex is rather large, with at least 13 points of interest, and spent about 3 hours leisurely strolling the grounds and exploring the buildings. Arrived at 9am (opening time) on a Saturday and found very few people which quickly increased in number by 10am.  Entrance fee is KRW3000 (~USD2.70), and tickets can be bought just past the main gate (called Gwanghwamun), on the right side. The brochure is available after entering the next gate (Heungnyemun), and don't forget to pick one up! This is an excellent brochure and was quite sufficient for exploring the complex. It includes a timeline of Gyeongbokgung, a map, and each major area is described along with diagrams and photos (some with colour). Note that the National Folk Museum (the pagoda building) is a separate free attraction and lies outside of the palace complex (though seemingly part of it). Just be sure to keep your ticket if you end up in this pagoda building as you make your way back to Gyeongbokgung (there is a ticket check between the two).  The highest concentration of visitors are in the main throne hall and main residences but the crowd thins the deeper you go within the complex. While the buildings after sometime become similar, the entire complex is still worth going through, though not as picturesque. For instance the ceiling of the queen dowager's residence (where the ten longevity chimney is also located) appears untouched with worn out colours, and provides a good insight into what these ceilings looked like pre-renovation. Jibokjae had an unusual architecture, and the pond with the pavilion is simply pretty.  The route based on the numbering in the brochure allows one to circle the palace complex, ending at the main throne hall and out the main gate, in time for the hourly changing of the guards. This is a reenactment of the original ceremony from the 15th century and occurs every hour from 10am-3pm, making for an interesting addition to a visit here.  Note Gyeongbokgung is closed on Tuesdays (together with Jongmyo Shrine). If considering visiting the other three palaces and Jongmyo shrine, best to get the combination ticket, which is good for one month. These are all within walking distance but likely difficult to properly appreciate in one full day, and requires greater stamina too. Other nearby attractions are the Folk Art Musem as mentioned, National Palace Museum, and Insadong for traditional shopping and dining.  To get to Gyeongbokgung Palace by metro, take Subway Line 3 to Gyeongbokgung Station (Exit 5).
If you've been the palaces in China, you'd probably be disappointed. The architecture (excuse me for my ignorance) is very Chinese. The palace is not particularly grand or spectacular.

The perfect place to experience to get a real historic palace as seen in Korean drama.If you only have time to visit one palace then make it this one and can easily spend 3 hours around the royal palace.

With the entrance fee is a free tour of the palace and grounds. The tour was great and very worth the time. If we had wandered around the palace on our own, we would have enjoyed, but I think we would have missed large parts (it is much bigger than it looks at the beginning). The tour guide was great, and explained a lot of things about the architecture and features of the buildings that were really interesting.

I visited this historical site in Seoul just over a month ago when I went to South Korea for the first time. I very much enjoyed my time there, the sights, sounds, smells and tastes - I wrote several blog posts about this mega city and made a video. Please go to my blog site for more detailed impressions: http://www.junyingkirk.com/?p=3711, and also a link to my Youtube to see this palace for yourself: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=erwK3xFVOvI&feature=g-upl.

Gyeongbokgung Palace was arguably the most beautiful and remained the grandest of all five palaces, Changdeokgung, Gyeongheegung…It was the central building of the King’s residence. There were 9 rooms , the central room was where the king slept and the surrounding 8 rooms were where the court ladies kept night watch. It was worth seeing and you could spend little to lots of time checking it all out. Opened at 9am and there were just a few people here and there.

The palace is very well built, beautiful lake is there with nice pleasant gardens, the stone and wood carvings are a must see, you may have a chance to see the cultural show near the museum which is worth a see...
Palace grounds are immense! Each building is unique in its purpose though the architecture is pretty much the same. Check out the official travel site for free English guided tours.

My mum and I visited this palace (supposedly the grandest) and combined it with a trip to the National Folk and Palace museum (which are on opposite sides of the palace and both free). The entire experience took about 3.5 hours.  It was beautiful, but parts of it are undergoing restoration. We did not take the free tours, but we did take one at the Changdeokgung Palace and there were many similar features ( I recommend that you take one so you can appreciate the significance of all the little things) like the number of pathways, the colouring, the animal statues on the roofs etc.  Make sure you catch the guard changing ceremony (supposedly every hour), this is at the front of the palace (near the main entry point)
This "palace" is in a park full of other historic replicas and a museum introducing visitors to Korean culture. It was all a bit strange to me.
The palace and grounds give a feeling of serenity in the middle of the city. Gradually being restored to its former glory. Worth a visit to escape the bustle of the city and exceptionally good value

a great architecture histories palace. i like the feeling of pretending myself as one of the general in the ancience years ago who walked from the front to the main hall and stayed there, waiting for the king. this is a place to know historic of korea and refresh of all screen that i seen in korea drama..haha

It's quite an experience to really step into a historic Palace where most people only view them in dramas. Kind of crowded in the morning. They have a ceremony at specific timings where there's music and guards "marching".  It's a huge palace. When we are there, some little parts are undergoing construction. But we still enjoy our trip there.
Wear your walking shoes this place is huge. The Female English tour guide had interesting insights into the role of women in Korean palaces--think concubine verses wife.

We enjoyed the beauty of this. Unfortunately, when we went it was cold and I don't think we gave the palace due justice. There isn't much to do, but we also had our son and were not able to spend a good amount of time taking a tour or audio tour. I am certainly glad we saw this beautiful palace though.
Its an amazing and Historic place where you can learn a lot about South Koreans. Keep your schedule free for most part of the day as the area is huge and could find a lot of things of interest.

It famous of its name " Korea first palace", strategically located at the heart of Seoul. You must visit this place as it is where the history of Korea is born. The royal of Korea is establish here.  Chinese, Japanese and English translate is available here, the chinese translator could speak fluent chinese enable us to understand the story of this Palace. It is a place full of "Feng Shui" arrangement and every single building has it own meanings. Then you could discover that how smart the Korean built it country.  If you come Korea but miss this place then you know Korea nothing better. I would strongly recommend you to visit here and follow the tour guide translate so to help you understand what you are seeing.
You need to know in advance when you would like to visit as this place has weird times for visitors. They seem to favour tour groups.

This is a very cool place right in the middle of the city. It reminds me very much of the forbidden city in China, but apparently is older. It is much smaller scale than China and not as busy. If you are in the downtown area it is well worth the visit. The changing of the guards happens everyday at 11am and is really interesting. The costumes and pageantry are very interesting to see.

Spectacular imperial guards changing shift performance.  Get a feel of the actual shooting spot in the Korean's imperial series. It is amazing that the palace is situated right in the center of bustling city of Seoul.
Similar experience to visiting the forbidden city in Beijing, though a much smaller and lesser extent but still interesting to see the Korean royal palace.

This palace is the grandest of the palaces and enormous! Would be worth waiting for the English walking tour if you have time (otherwise grab a guide from the information booth to the right of the main gate). There is a guard changing ceremony ( at set times, cancelled due to weather at times); we got to see the guards at the gate. I'd also recommend taking the opportunity to dress in traditional costumes at the tea house (free, must sign up).

This was the first site we visited in Seoul. We joined the English tour, which took a little more than an hour. The palace gave tremendous insight into the prevailing culture and principles of the Joseon dynasty. I was impressed that, unlike other palaces, there was no emphasis on excess and luxury. Instead, they had a stream for purifying the mind, simple dwelling places for the royal family, and even a quiet place for the king to reflect. The buildings were big, but relatively austere.  After the tour, we watched the changing of the guard ceremony at the Gwanghamun Gate. This happens hourly from 10am to 3pm, so you can catch it before or after the tour. Entrance to the palace costs KRW3000 (less than UD$3), tours are free.

It was raining heavily as we get out from the metro station. To make it worse the National Palace Museum is closed. As we enter the side entrance from the museum, we saw the ticket counter and information counter all closed. Quite a number of visitors or tourists seems to be upset coz not allowed by the guard to enter the palace. Maybe it's already closing time. So, advisable to visit this place in the morning.
Even though I visited the palace on a weekday, it was full of tourists and Korean schoolchildren on field trips. It's good to remember that the palace is closed on Tuesday.

We were very happy to experience the palace. It's very exotic for us to see this kind of architecture and splendour. You have to go there when the weather is good as you have to walk around the buildings.

The place is very big and so it can take quite a long time to visit the whole palace. You have a guide book provided to help you get around and understand the history of the palace. You can also see the contrast between the palace and the view of some of the main buildings in Seoul.
The Palace is a remarkable reconstruction of the Joseon Dynasty era but it lacks details showing how people lived during that period.

A must visit place, to understand what it was like to be living in palace years back. Take a walk in the grounds, and understand the different parts of the palace, its purpose, occupants and its history. There is also guard change ceremony, which is pretty interesting too. Go on a weekday if you want to avoid the weekend crowds :)

If your visiting Korea, this palace is definitely a must see. The palace area is so large, and the scenery is so beautiful with mountains in the distance. It almost feels like your not even in the city. The palace guards are dressed in the traditional costumes, so don't forget to get a photo with one! I'd also recommend getting a tour, or at least a map (it's easy to get a bit lost here!)  The folk museum, wasn't really worth checking out, in my opinion. I found roaming around the traditional buildings more exciting.  Also I think it only cost 3,000 won to get in. Very cheap! So definitely check this place out!

Large grounds, so be prepared to spend hours there exploring and learning. Try to read about the Palace before visiting and spend time reading the various signs explaining the buildings. Very crowded. Nearby, the National Folk Museum is located. Good place to visit for a historical background of the daily lives of the ordinary Korean people.

Where do i start? I kinda got lost inside the palace, I was walking somewhere I think is suppose to be the servant's area and I have no idea where i am by the time i notice i was lost. It is really nice place to have a look. and Just a tip, bring along a water bottle and a cap if you are going around noon, you would need that :)

We visited the Gyeongbokgung palace to watch the changing of the guard and get a tour of the palace. It's a great experience for young and old. Great look into the history of Korea. Also the free cultural museum accessable from palace is also awesome. Our English tour guide was knowledgeable and funny. Highly recommend it on your visit to Seoul.

It's the grandest of all the palaces in Seoul, South Korea. It majestically dominates the Ganghwamun Square. It's actually a complex of many buildings sprawled in a vast area.Its main daily attraction is the changing of the Royal Guards ceremony in full traditional colorful costumes during certain times and many says its comparable to the changing of the guards in London.

Maybe it was a rainy day, maybe it was when all the trees looked dry, maybe because I had too much expectiation... or maybe it was because we could only see the palace from the outer garden (you cant view the rooms, etc). So it was just an okay experience for me.

We visited the Gyeongbokgung palace complex our last day in Korea. It is a large sprawling area, with views of the current Presidential 'Blue House' which is to the rear of this area. It is unfortunite that most of the structures are recreations since the Japanese destroyed most of the buidling after their 1910 annexation of Korea. Definitely take either the guided tour, or rent the earphone that tells you about the structures. I enjoyed this quite a bit, especially the colorful and musical changing of the Guards. The other nearby palace complex was also good, with its secret gardens.
Architecture to be appreciated. And historical facts learnt. Beautiful vast palace interior to roam around.

Visiting the Palace during Chuseok just added to the experience. There were people dressed in traditional costumes, dancers, and special events going on in the children's section, including traditional games. The Palace wasn't crowded, we were able to roam around and take lots of pictures. The Palace is easy to get to, and there is a money exchange inside which is very helpful. Be sure to give yourself enough time to walk to all the different sections. One of my favorites was the replication of a village from the 1940's, including the comic book shop. I would recommend that you either eat before going to the Palace, or take some snacks with you. It is so big that it takes several hours to see everything. There are places to fill your water bottle and the bathrooms were clean.

Gyeongbok Palace has to be the number one attraction in Seoul. I never get tired of watching the changing of the guard, the changing of the leaves, or the changing faces of the tourists from all aover the world who flock to its grounds. A vast expense of land in the center of Seoul yours for exploring at your own leasure without too much interference from low key museum staff. Take a camera of course and be prepared to walk away with hundreds of wonderful compositions from magnificant architectural roofs to detailed close-ups of ancient fixtures and doors. Well worth spending a half a day exploring preceded by and with a follow on late lunch or early dinner. High noon is the spectacle of spectacles with the changing of the guards, so don;t miss it. One of many palaces in and around Seoul but in my humble opinion the best preserved and most professionaly presented and maintained.
Lovely palace in the centre of Seoul. Gardens are spectacular as are the courtyards - shame about the 'empty' rooms.
Showed us the beauty of the ancient Korean kings and restoration of this magnificent compound. Well worth the time to wander these grounds.

This is indeed a nice palace located at the middle of the busy city. It is accessible by Seoul Metro and the palace itself is big and cool enough! There's no need to purchase the ticket and enter the palace, just take some pictures outside the palace is good enough! Don't forget the be there at 10am then you would see the changing guards ceremony for free! After this palace, you can just walk to Samcheong-dong, Bukchon Village and Insadong by walking! Easy!

here is the perfect location for families and couples..really nice when u like traditional culture its here perfect to see it....u can make many pictures and when u come at morning u can see many many more.....
The guard shift-swapping ceremony was impressive. The building itself was so-so... perhaps i wastoo impressed by the Beijing Palace or the Paris Palace Versille

Went here during the obligatory tourist day of a business trip to Seoul.  We watched the changing of the guard shortly after arriving at 10. A few people brightly dressed as traditional korean warriors marched around a bit but didn't really do much else.  Pretty impressive overall though and a fairly large complex to explore. We had a group tour guide who was full of interesting information about the place, which brought it to life a bit more.  Some of it is original but much has been extensively restored, but done in a sympathetic manor.  I guess it depends how much you like this sort of place but we took about 1.5 hours to see all the major bits of the complex and I thought that was enough.
This was my favorite place in Korea. Everything is gorgeous! Also, they serve sikhye there which is to die for. I cannot wait to go back to Gyeongbokgung.

We went during chuseok and it was perfect timing (also free). There was tons going on. A little crowded but the place is huge. Really did not expect it to be that big. I would suggest taking a picnic along and finding a nice spot to chill. Changing of the guards was pretty cool.

got to see where the emperors used to live and it's an amazing place, everybody should visit it...................helped me to better understand Korea...........................................................
This is worth the time to visit. It shows you what life was like back in the old days. It is also a good picture opportunity.

This palace complex is the largest and totally worth visiting. It has some interesting architecture and great photo opportunities. Be sure to go northeast in the complex to get some tea or coffee for a break. They also have an area where you can wear costumes for fun at no charge, which provides some photo ops. Just past that area is the building that has a nice body of water in front of it - reflection pools, and they are beautiful. Then at the northwest corner towards the pagoda is the folk art musuem, which is totally worth the visit and free.

i initially planned on joining the free english tour of this palace but decided not to when i was there. it's a big place from what i see outside. i managed to catch the changing of guards ceremony. it's still considered outside the palace so you don't have to pay admission fee to watch it. i'm not exactly a fan of places with historical value and all that so i moved on after watching the ceremony.

i was here on a sunday in October,the weather was quite warm for me but the sun are real big.remember to bring your sunglasses or you won't be able to open your eyes to see the historical building which are still colourful and well maintained.please be prepare that you will need to walk quite a lot,plus taking photo,watch the shift changing of the palace guard.the palace closed on Monday so take note if you are planning to go there.

I joined the English tour in the afternoon. Unfortunately, not everything the tour guide said was understandable; her tone was also not too exciting.  Anyway, you get taken around about half of the buildings, and are given some history and explanation of some features. When the tour ends after about an hour, you are free to explore on your own.  What I liked the most are the two small islands, one on the west and one on the north of the complex --- together with the surroundings, these create opportunities for some amazing photos.

if u never been to seoul, this should be a stop on ur trip.  i enjoy the open space within the grounds of the palace.  i gave gyeongbokgung palace average only because i just went to beijing and visited the forbidden palace, which is amazing. gyeongbokgung is not as grand as forbidden palace.  i believe my experience would be better if i have a tour guide or use a english audio guide.

The sheer enormity of Gyeongbokgung Palace can be a bit daunting, but I do encourage anyone visiting Seoul to take a few hours to wander through the grounds of this amazing palace.  After passing through Gwanghwamun Gate (the main gate of the palace, which is itself enormous and visually stunning, especially as it is lit up at night), there are many structures to walk through within the temple's vast walls, along with amazing courtyards, pavilions, statues and traditional Korean gardens. Each gate and doorway passed through provides new and wonderful sights to take in. The temple's vibrant color scheme of teal, red, purple and orange -- seemingly standard throughout most if not all of Korea's temples and palaces -- is a delight to behold.  The National Folk Museum of Korea, as well as the National Palace Museum of Korea, are also located within its walls, and tours are available for both.  The palace is very easy to get to, with close access to the subway and bus routes, and seems surprising and almost out of place in the middle of such a busy city. But once inside its impressive walls, one can quickly forget that you're in a bustling, modern city and allow yourself to be transported to a different and distant time.  Although it attracts a lot of tourists, I highly recommend spending a few hours visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace -- you won't be disappointed. And if you can visit on a weekday the crowds will be far fewer.

The architecture of the buildings and the landscaping of the grounds are simply awe-inspiring. I visited on a very busy Fall Saturday afternoon. Thousands upon thousands of people around. Yet the immense palace grounds afforded many locations to get away from the crowds and watch the birds, look off to the mountains in the distance, or simply sit and enjoy the nice Fall breeze. A drumming team was practicing outside of a building on the grounds with a large pond surrounding it. The gymnastic abilities and rhythms used by the young drumming team were incredible.  The majestic beauty of this site, the incredibly cheap entry fee of 3000KRW, and the availability of programmes and pamphlets in English make this attraction a must-see.
huge palace, well preserved and very2 beautiful parks inside. autumn colors full blown. can have picnic inside
Not much in the way of furnishings as they were all burned or destroyed but be sure to look for times for changing of the guard so you don't miss it.

If we had visited China's Palaces, this palace seems small and quiet. But the entrance fees is only 2400 won! But there is a different culture and life in this palace which also houses a Museum where we could see settings of several events, such as making of kimchi.  But the best thing of all is there are a group of Korean costume-cladded maidens who are there if you want to take pictures with them. They seemed not to speak English, but by using the international language (hand gestures), they were willing to take some beautiful pictures with us.  There are a lot of historical facts which the guide will talk and talk but this historical piece is worth a visit even without the ramblings!

This is a beautiful palace that has loads of buildings to see, excellent grounds for a nice stroll, and even free events and demonstrations on a regular basis. We visit this palace every time we travel to Seoul. Its in the heart of the city, however when you pass through the palace walls, you forget where you are and get lost in the romantics of history and culture!

I suppose that everyone will go for a visit when you are first time in Seoul. Being Chinese, I am not so keen because we do have similar structure in China. Well, the guards were a bit of good experience since you can take photos arounfd them. Other than that, pretty average experience for me. I actually got in there because I got lost on my way to other locations.

I'm in awe with the size and scale of this palace. I'm also so very happy I dropped the 3000 Won for the audio guide. It was highly informative and provided me with a much richer experience than if I'd just bumbled through the place. For a moment I stopped to listen to the free tour and it seemed quite worthwhile, too, providing even more color than the audio guide. I would recommended it if you're into a slightly more structured walk. My favorite part? Hyangwonejong in the back - a phenomenally beautiful pagoda and pond. I could have spent hours there.

We spent about two hours at the palace. There are plaques at each building in English so we were able to learn quite a bit about Korean history, even the part about why coffee and coffee shops are so popular in Korea. An interesting place to visit if you have couple hours free while in Seoul as the admission was very low compared with other historical places around the world.

This is the meaning of the word Gyeongbokgung and it fits the palace so well. I arranged for a two day stopover in Seoul and checked online for places of interest. This was on the top of my list. I arrived in Seoul and stayed at the Sky Hotel which had free shuttle service and was two blocks from the metro for downtown Seoul. Excellent location!!! Took the metro to the Palace and arrived just in time for the changing of the guards which was absolutely beautiful and very entertaining with music, costumes, drums, marching bands, etc. I enjoyed it so much that after I toured the palace and grounds, I stayed for the next guard change which is on the hour. The Seoul metro makes it very easy to get around the city and it is very reasonable also. Two days was enough time to see most of the important sights of the city. Food was delicious esp. the area called the Samcheongdong with its wonderful street food. Also went to the Jeongdong theatre for the "Miso" showing (full house). You can take a city bus tour (hop on, hop off) for only ten US dollars, I real bargain!!!
While the palace was rebuilt after the war, they clearly want to share a bit of Korean history with you. I'd take a tour though, as the outer buildings don't have a lot of information included.
The palaces were briliant, so much history behind them. The cost wasnt so bad either, we paid 9000 korean won for 4!

You can't go to Seoul without visiting this extraordinary palace. You also can't miss it, it's right in the middle of one of the busiest areas of the city, near City Hall and the US Embassy. Fascinating look at the ceremonial side of the Korean royal dynasty, the massive buildings are impressive and the smaller pavilions are beautiful, especially the ones sitting peacefully in the small lakes. And make sure you see the Changing of the Guard ceremony, great pageantry & very colorful. Also, don't miss the Folk Museum which is on the palace grounds (look for the very tall pagoda). Great place to start a visit to wonderful Seoul!

I went during the Korean national holiday and Chinese national holiday so lots of tourists there. The place covers a lot of acres and definitely has a few buildlings that offer fantastic photo spots. The changing of the guards is nice to watch and it's explained in English in addition to Korean and Mandarin. Admission prices in Seoul are generally a bargain compared to European and American sight admissions. If you have to pick one palace to visit in Seoul this would be the one. Deongsukgung would be the other as they also have a changing of the guards.
This is a former royal palace, most of which was destroyed during the Japanese occupation of Korea. Buildings have been restored and are a fascinating insight into times gone by.
It is quite nice. It is similar to other palaces in Seoul, but on a much bigger and grandeur scale. What was really impressive though was seeing the changing of the guards ceremony.

They have done such a wonderful job with the palace and although very touristy wasn't as crowded as some places I have been in both Europe and Asia. Thought the palace was beautiful, the guide books are very informative and there really is so much to see. I LOVED the gardens at the back of the palace leading off the folk museum. They were absolutely stunning.
Good experience to see the building. There are so many tourists but I still enjoy the great walk around here.

I visited this Palace in 2009 when I was in Seoul - I found my way there from Incheon Airport and spent a glorious few hours there. I also happened quite co incidentally to be there when a special event was being held, one that had not been held ever before. It was a re enactment of a feast day and I managed to see much of it before I had to leave.  I did not do a tour, but wandered around by myself and found it an amazing experience and if fortunate enough to return to Seoul, I'd certainly visit it again.

The name "Gyeongbok" translated as "Palace Greatly Blessed by Heaven" seems somewhat of a misnomer given that it was destroyed by fire at least twice and the scene of much murder and mayhem during the Joseon Dynasty.  All visits begin at the rebuilt front entry which leads into a wide, open courtyard. At noon, we saw the colorful changing of the guard ceremony which was accompanied by drums and horns. A not-to-be-missed event!  Along with the admission ticket, you receive a pamphlet showing the palace complex layout and details about the buildings. These should be read carefully, or the place just looks like a bunch of empty buildings, along with bridges and walls decorated with stone mythical beasts. The government has done a magnificent job restoring this treasure, except they really need to install more trash cans!  The complex deserves at least 2-3 hours, although I suspect tour guides do not give their charges that long. I'd advise wearing really comfortable shoes. There is no problem finding a taxi to elsewhere in Seoul from out front of the complex. If you walk a bit, there are many restaurants around.
I didn't do a formal tour but still loved the palace. Lots of history, beautiful grounds. Visit this if you can!

Very conveniently located with its own subway stop this is a great place to walk around in the fall or spring when the weather is comfortable. Lots to see and plenty of space to switch your legs while admiring the amazing architecture,

If it is a nice day, the palace is quite pleasant to walk round. If you like walking try Kings Tomb (closed on Mondays like a lot of attractions in Seoul). Kings Tomb know as Soleung in Korean is just outside of Seoul in Kyongi-do - From Gyeongbokgung it is around 30 minutes by Taxi - around $10.

My friend and I walked there and then turned back around. Way too many tourists and we don't like to be associated with tourists since we like doing things out of the norm. It looked nice but it was rebuilt anyway. Plenty of other things to see and do in Seoul. Go eat some Bosintang. Yum

The palace was good to see and ironically centrally located in the middle of the city, but there is not much there other than a few of the remodeled buildings. Needs more descriptions beyond the book at the ticket counter. The changing of the guard was neat to see with the colorful dress and music.
Manager to catch the changing of the guards. Not grand but provided photo opportunities. Worth visiting along with the nearby markets.

we watched the changing of the guards in front of the palace before exploring the vast grounds of this place. we liked the gazebo on the lake which is found towards the back of the grounds. we also visited two museums (with free entry) which are in the palace grounds - the national folk museum and also the national palace museum (unfortunately, not many English signs here so we did not stay long)

Great half day experiencing aspects of life in 1300s Korea. Lots of restored or original buildings in which lived the Korean royal family.  You can pay for a audio guide which has a GPS to know where you are, which triggers audio recordings with pictures on the little PDA. It didn't work perfectly, but well enough to be very informative. Make sure you check the plug and headphones - one of the ones we had was faulty.  There are men dressed in traditional guard uniforms, who perform a "changing of the guard" ceremony, with flags and Korean marching instruments - well worth seeing with lots of comparisons with the equivalent in London.  There is a museum next door, but the displays are almost completely in Korean, making it hard to figure out what a lot of it is about. But for a cursory overview of Korea's history prior to the Annexation by Japan in 1910, well worth a visit.

We went on a free walking tour of this site, which is huge. We saw the changing of the guard at 10am. There are regular times for the guard changes and these are advertised. It costs 3000 won (approx. $3 AUD/US) to enter. There is a lot of walking, but all flat, except for a few steps up and down to go through each section. We went with "Seoul City Walking Tours' with the 'Seoul Culture & Tourism Volunteer Guides". These tours are free and have to be booked online in advance. The booking procedure is easy and you receive a confirmation email. The tours specialise in specific areas of Seoul and are not general tours. There are 17 to choose from.The guides are paid a small amount from the government and our guide would not accept a tip for his fantastic work. Tommy was our guide for our first tour, we did 3 in all. He was relatively new as a guide. He is such a lovely person. We went to very interesting places with him. Have fun as you walk and learn!

the garden and compound is so huge the lines for the entrance ticket were long great architecture  wear covered or rubber shoes as there will be a lot of walking from one palace/room to another its quite dusty in spring (i visited them in spring)
I like the decorations and the buildings, it's a very good palace. and the most amazing part is changing the guards which occurs every hour. No way to visit Seoul without visiting it.
Typical palaces as in similarities to the ones in other cities like Beijing. It has a very big compound so walking end to end is quite a distance so prepare to have good walking shoes.
Wear your rubber shoes during the tour, take the afternoon english tour so it is not too hot. A bit boring after being to Beijing, Tokyo and Cambodia

Went there on a biz trip in Jan 11. Client organized local tour which of cuz, couldn't missed out the magnificent palace. Maybe it was my first encounter with winter weather and it was freezingly cold to walk on the snow (lots and lots of walking) and I didn't get to enjoy the scenery due to the coldness. Hence, be prepared to put on heat pack and extremely thick socks with boots before going there!
I strolled through this palace. It was interesting. Well kept. Changing of the guard was very enjoyable.

Went to the Palace to get a feel of Seoul. By chance just got there as the guard was changing - it's quite a spectacle with falgs, banners and unusual uniforms - it was quite fascinating. The paalce complex is ok, a bit like a small Forbidden City and it certainly gives you the feeling of how grand it must have been
A lovely place to spend a few hours strolling around, watch the changing of the guard and wander into the folk village. If you are over a hustle and bustle of Seoul this is a great place to come.
Another well preserved palace located in the city centre.  A huge place with beautiful landscapes for photography.  Guided tours are available too at certain hours of the day.
A very good place to show Korea hundred years ago, the buildings are preserved well and impressive.  If you like to take photos definitely this is a good place to go.

A much more compact place than the Changdeogung Palace but main buidlings-wise, more or less comparable. But what sets it apart is the secret garden area which gives you a good impression of what it was like hundereds of years ago. Most buildings here are original and not rebuild as in the other places. Do take the English tour because it gives so much inside info on this attraction. A plus !
The palace is super big.... I couldn't finish exploring the palace during my one hour visit. Was too tired and had to back...

We had a great time here, largely due to an excellent tour guide who had a good sense of humour. (Though, one of the people we met who wasn't a native speaker of English found her accent difficult to understand. We personally found we could understand 90% of what she said, but English is our first language.)

Wear comfortable walking shoes and bring a bottle of water. Be prepared for the often dusty areas paved with gravel. There are many steps to climb without handrails in order to see inside many of the palace rooms. Allow time to do a guided walking tour with English speaking tour guides. There's a sign at the gathering place inside the palace grounds for the scheduled tours, which are free.  Please read the other reviews of this palace. I agree with most of them, and don't want to repeat.

We arrived at Gyeongbokgung Palace around lunch time, it was very hot and too much glare from the sun. Maybe its better to go in the afternoon and in time for the English-speaking tour guide but there are free English booklets that you can read while walking around the palace.  There is also the Gogungddurak museum shop and cafe where we had our lunch.

The palace itself and surrounding are beautiful, but in my opinion the park behind is beautiful, with artifitial lake and great deep green. Try to get on late afternoon, when sun starts to set down and enjoy great play of colors

Impressive architecture with the National Palace Museum of Korea and the National Folk Museum on the grounds as well. Time your visit to witness the changing of the guard and be sure to see the gardens in the rear of the palace, especially the lovely Hyangwonjeong pavilion. The combination ticket for all the palaces in Seoul, including the Secret Garden and Jongmyo Shrine is well worth it if you plan on seeing more than 3 of the sites.

There is free hanbok wearing at the souvenir shop which was such a memorable experience! Each person has only 10 minutes to wear the hanbok as the line gets pretty much long. I suggest you go and patiently wait in front of the souvenir shop at lunch time (like what we did) so you get to be first in line when they open up. Ask someone to take your photo standing in front of the nearest palace so you have a great background.

This is the one of the place you need to visit when your holidays in South Korea.You can explore by yourself and it take 2 to 3 hrs to complete this area. The entrance fees is around 2,400 Won.You can bring along bottle of drinks and cap if you visit summer season as the place is big for your to explore where you can snap beautiful view either the traditional palaces or lake.You also can try their traditional dress for snap photos with free fees. The best is when you arrive in you can see the changing guard with some of traditional music. We also can snap photos with the guard when they are on duty.Please don't miss this place in your holidays itinarary.
Beautiful and very nicely programmed in the summer. Took out of town guests there on the weekend and the museum was free. It was a delight to see all the extra performances.
it's big so wear comfy shoes and a fan may be helpful in the summer as Seoul can get incredibly humid. Though this is one attraction not to miss while in Seoul.

If you are in Seoul, this is a must see. Try to get a guide if possible. You probably need about 1 hour here maybe an hour and a half. You will get some nice photos. Try to time it so you see the changing of the guard. This area is bigger than you think so keep walking and move around or you will end up being here longer than you need to.

A place where you do strolls, sit for a chat, enjoy the scenery, take pictures of the guards and... thats about all. The buildings and structures are not sophiscated and are quite plain. The place is well.. relatively big but there aint many artifacts. There is not much to explore and the history is not as rich. It projects itself more of a location for movie/TV makers rather than a palace with history. Quite disappointed as reviews say this is the best palace in Seoul.

Perhaps we have seen the forbidden city and temple of heaven in Beijing so our expectations may be high. Also it was rebuild so may not have the same feel. However. the translation equipment was great to use. We advise tourist to pay tthe 3000 cos you really can understand the history. The changing guards was also a good thing to watch. We caught this at the right time so it was really good.

All visitors to Seoul should stop by this palace. Very amazed by the grandeur of the structures and the beauty of the architecture. Be sure to come on a cooler day as we visited during a heat wave and found ourselves dripping with sweat. Also do not make the mistake of spending too much time at the main gate and the first palace building as it is only a small part of the overall complex.

I first visited Gyeongbok Palace in 1968 and have gone back periodically since then. It is always more enjoyable with each successive visit. Archaeological excavations are constantly going on, and buildings that had been destroyed are gradually being restored. The military unit that used to occupy the rear part of the palace near the Blue House is gone and now that part of the palace is accessible as well. There are guided tours and self guided options as well. Being interested in history and old buildings, I have found that it is impossible to see all there is to see in one short visit. Be prepared to walk: it's quite an extensive complex. I used to prefer Changdok Palace/Secret Garden as my go-to palace in Seoul. That may still be the case, bu Kyongbok palace is giving it a run for the money.

Wow, just wow..the place is so big, so beautiful, it draws you back in time, come at 12 noon, there are guards exchange ceremony, for those who came for a photo time, the best time to do it is at that convenient hour.
Get amazed with the uniqueness of Seoul - a well preserved ancient palace in the middle of the metropolitan city. It's amazing how these two sentiments blend together.
The palace is completely rebuilt and it is worth a visit to understand Seoul's past. There is a great guards ceremony every our in the main entrance

Loved the palace and worth visiting. definitely go there and its not far from the city centre. I took tons of pictures here which i enjoy doing. At the entrance the guards are all dressed up in traditional old uniforms which was nice to see.

Been here twice and still think that's this is the most interesting attraction in Seoul, other then the shopping. The place will take u back to the olden days in Korea. It would be great if u can get a guide to explain the features within this palace to get a better understanding.

this will likely be the first place you go to as a "sight" in Seoul. In terms of the colours of painting/decoration it is certainly distinctive and different from anything else you will find elsewhere in the world, other than Korea. It is somewhat like the Forbidden City in Beijing in terms of the size of the site (not as big though) and it will take half a day to get around. I happened to catch the palace guard parade thing more or less by accident so worth timing it for that (1pm?).

Great history of the palace but extensive walking to get to each building. We arrived on a hot, humid day and gave up before we say everything. But the free brochure explains each building and the history quite well.
I love visiting palaces. If you like watching korean epic dramas, you could relate on the drama scenes by seeing the palaces. The changing of guards is very colourful too

Despite all the modern advancement of the towns near Gyeongbokgung Palace, this place will never shed its beautiful history. The palace, though standing for centuries, has retained its beauty - from the 5 colors that symbolized korean culture to the detailed structures it has - all perfect and amazing as of this moment.

I grew up in Korea and was at the Palace about 15 years ago. I remember it to be one boring trip then, since I lived in Seoul.  Two days ago I visited the Palace with a friend from Japan. The Palace was nicely presented, although rather crowded with tourists.  Make sure to check out both new and old museums. Also make sure to visit in the morning around 10am to see traditional Korean music and guards!
One sparsely adorned pavilion after another. No tree cover at all; it is scorching hot under the summer sun. If you don't want to expand the energy or have limited time, skip this tourist trap.
The relocation of the water mill grounder, authentic traditional house, totem poles, etc are truly appreciated. There's no better way to visualize the way of life the Korean.
It reminds me of the forbidden city palace in Brijing, but much smaller. The museum inside the palace is very nice.

The changing of the guards is worth seeing. It takes place in a massive empty square and the guards move around it, so you get good views of the whole thing. It's very colourful and makes for good pictures. Besides that, there is not much else to see besides the buildings, and the main gate.

A very interesting Palace that was built more than five hundred years ago, although it was once destroyed by fire that took many years to rebuild near to its original state. A huge Palace with lots of history in it.
it is not to compear the palaces in China, but it is nice. Not much crowed and can be visited easily in half day. Tha guide lady was very nice.
The famous palace here... A must see for every tourist! Vast area inside... I wonder how many servants the King has inside the palace grounds!?!?!
Really beautiful. Not as organized at Changdeokgung, but the architecture is magnificent. Be sure to catch the changing of the guards
Don't miss it, after going here I doubt you'll need to go to another palace in Korea. The place is impeccable and the maintenance is great.

If I have to compare, I would prefer Deoksugung Palace than Gyeongbokgung palace to visit during holiday. Why? Gyeongbokgung is too crowded since it's the main center of the palace to be visited by the tourists. The main attraction would be the changing of the guards, the history of the palace, the national folk museum and the national museum.  However the last time I came here I can't enjoy it that much since it's very crowded with people. Even the pictures that I took were not as beautiful as ones I took at Deoksugung. Perhaps, one suggestion, come to Gyeongbokgung during weekdays, and not in a spring, winter, or summer break. People are coming not only from Seoul but also China and Japan. I really find it unattractive in a huge commotion like that.  Nevertheless, for 3000won, this area is really worth to visit. This palace area is so huge that even 3 hours will last like a flash. And make sure, you're not coming during holiday. It'll be an awful experience.You can't really enjoy the scenery since it's too noisy and crowded.

We went to se the colourful changing of the guard, on the hour from 11 am but check times and days that it happens. We did not pay to go inside the palace, preferring to go nextdoor to the National Folk Museum which is free and very good.

I got here just in time to see one of the changing of the guard ceremonies, which I thought was a hoot. Architecture is my main attraction at such places, so seeing the outside and the courtyard was enough for me, so I didn't pay to go inside.

All I can remember is it was sooooo hot and burning hot it was. Best not to go in the hot hot summer. There is nothing much inside well compare to the Forbbiten city in China. There is free custom photos though and you can go out to the musem for free and get back in. On special days if you wear the triditional clothes you can get in for free. Ticket price 3000 Won
Elaborate palace but sadly the present version is mostly reconstruction after dismantling during the Japanese occupation. Be sure to catch a view of the Blue House by exiting at the rear gate.

This was worth stopping by to see! We had a 10 hour layover in Seoul on our way to Beijing. We didn't have enough time to see every single thing here but it was still worth it! You can get here either by taking a bus or by going via the metro/subway!  Take lots of pictures! Bring comfortable shoes! Take pictures with the "soldiers" up front!
This palace is beautifully restored and a popular attraction for locals and foreigners alike. Well worth the time. Get the audio tour!

We arrived at Gyeongbokgung palace early in the morning as we wanted to get in as it opened and hopefully avoid the big crowds. When the doors opened we were surprised to see a large number of tourists already on the grounds. It turns out there is another set of doors that apparently opened before the front doors. This place gets very busy very quickly, oh well, such is life with major tourist attractions in big cities :)  The architecture of the palace is exquisite. The blossoms were in full bloom so it made for a very picturesque settings. We spent several hours walking around the grounds (some spots are off limits as they reconstruct areas) and we were even able to find a few quiet spots to relax. I highly suggest going to the Folk Museum as it really gives a nice view into ancient Korean life.  On our way out we were fortunate to catch a guard show. The entrances are guarded by actors(?) dressed in traditional Korean attire (they even have fake beards to look the part!) They performed a choreographed march for about 10 minutes. I assume they do this throughout the day so hopefully you happen to be there at the right time.  This isn't the most amazing palace that i've been to but it was definitely worth going to. A must see when visiting Seoul.

Lot's to see here, architecture, culture, history... the grounds are well maintained, and there are lots of areas to sit and relax and soak up the surroundings and history. Definately worth a visit if you are in Seoul. It's a shame the locals in Seoul are so rude, I will never return to Seoul or South Korea.

Not necessarily my type of thing but if you are in S Korea for a couple of days then you shoudl allow time to visit, inexpensive and won't take too long. Make sure you go to the front of the palace and see the soldiers.

Although Gyeongbokgung Palace is rebuilt after the wars, the new comes with its advantages. The whole place is well thought out.  Stepping off the subway, the stone lined Gyeongbokgung subway station bring visitors centeries back preparing them for a palace visit. Steps outside the subway exit, ticketing booths are easy to spot. Remember to keep the ticket stub because you will need this to re-enter the palace after exiting for the Blue House and the Folk Museum.  Upon entrance, information desk is on the right where one can obtain brochuer and map in Korean, English, Chinese, and Japanese. Tours are available in Korean, English, Chinese, and Japanese. Royal guard changing ceremony occure on the hour. English tours at 11AM, 13:30PM, and 15:30PM. I joint the english tour which lasted 65 minutes. The tour ended on the north. After the tour, I exited the north gate and took photo of the Blue House Cheongwadae. Coming back to the palace requires ticket stub. On the way back to the entrance, I exited the east gate to check out the Folk Museum. Again, entering the Folk Museum and coming back to the palace requires ticket stub. After a relaxing walk back to the entrance, just in time for the Royal Guard changing ceremony.  The two hour walk was not very demanding. There are also handicap access throughout the palace. However, most path are pavers which are not heels or slipper friendly. I saw young visitors exhausted so this may not be a very excited place for the very young. Those may need a lift of spirit at the Lotte world.  I strongly recommend the tour and reading up the guidebook. It's a very relaxing tour and the guidebook is short and sweet. The Korean government did a great job and made the palace visit relaxing and stress free.

went to visit Gyeongbokgung palace on 11 July and very amazed. The palace is linked from the subway station. It situated in front of modern roads and buildings. The changing of guards ceremony is a highlight of the attraction. It's very colourful and such an eye-opener to see a traditional ceremony in front of a modern street. The palace is huge and all architecture looks the same inside. Nevertheless it was very worth the visit.
It was nice to visit this place again because they are well managed and was kept very clean. Very similar architecture with china's Forbidden City.

The Palace is very big, and nice to walk around. While you can find the performance schedule of 'changing soldiers' every day. Very impressive performance - you will see the soldiers wearing Korean traditional costumes marching with Korean music, and at the end of the performance, you can take photos with the soldiers!!
the changing of the guards is what makes this palace different from other palaces. very colourful
very huge, so huge that you could get lost, entrance was also very cheap, nice place to learn about korea

This is my favorite of all the palaces in Seoul! The buildings are beautiful...there is so much to see. The changing of the guard ceremony is something not to be missed. My favorite spot is the small pond in the way back of the grounds.(Hyangwon-jeong) The day we were there, there we lilly pads in the pod. The pictures we took of the pond, gazebo and mountain in the background were breathtaking!

It was very interesting to see the palace. It was very spacious with plenty of colour and unique architecture. It was kind of disappointing to hear that the entire palace was burned multiple times during the Japanese Occupation and again during the Korean war. Even though none of the buildings are original, it was nice to see how the palace would have looked during its prime. I would definitely recommend a visit as it is a major attraction in the city.

Although all the palaces in Seoul have been rebuilt after 20th century devastation, they are worth visiting to get a feel for the history of the city. They are cheap to enter and have great free brochures about the buildings and the past.

This place is refurbished, so a lot of buildings aren't original. Is easy to get to the place but if it's a rainy day you could have some difficulties because most of the place is outdoors. This is one of the highlights of the city, so you should go.
Very interesting and beautiful to see the architecture! but also very big

Just seeing and hearing, through the tour guide, how the Korean people lived and were governed during the 16 and 17 hundreds made the trip to the palace worth it. Also the palace is connected to the Korean cultural center which was very interesting.
I used the tour guide recommended by the Hotel. Amazing value for money. Strongly recommend it.
It was my first time there, so it could have been better to have clear path to go around the palace for tourists, but it is nice sight to visit though. I wish i had more time to visit thoroughly.
the buildings are well preserved. and if you are lucky, you get to take photos with the guards of the palace too!

I was blown away by the palace restoration and artwork. It is a prime example of Korea's past. There were palace guard re-enactments to transport you back in time. A must see for any visitor in Seoul.

This place is huge! And it was hot, so I recommend going as early in the day as possible. There is a museum out the back side as well, and they have a special children's section. We saw Korean school children on fieldtrips. It was fun.

This is big suggest you have a guided tour so that everything is explained. Get there so you can enjoy the Changing of the Guard ceremony which is very colourful {11am each morning}. The Folklore museum excellent so just give yourself plenty of time and be prepared for the crowds!
Liked - the history and buildings - very cheap to visit

This Palace lies in the center of Seoul and is surrounded by busy roads. It is very cheap to enter and the buildings are pretty and well maintained. It is a very busy attraction, I cannot stress this enough! You may well have to line-up to see inside a building or take photos. Try and time your visit to coincide with the changing of the guard ceremony.
Went with a local tour guide and enjoye all the explaination of the history of the Palace. So big. Never knew the King had so many wifes ! hihi

This place is LARGE and is getting larger. Its been razed by the Japanese in the past and has been rebuilt (and is still being rebuilt) but its a journey into a significant part of Korea's history. English speaking guides are available and are very helpful in order to appreciate the significance and function of the court dynasty that used this as its central palace for state affairs. Although school kids are here by the hundreds on field trips, the size of the palace grounds is so great that you can find yourself alone in a side courtyard in quiet. The restoration is wonderful with great attention to detail. Some of the recaptured landscaping offers aesthetic perspectives that convey an earlier age and culture worlds away from the frantic pace of Seoul just a few hundred yards away. The walled enclosure really leaves modern Seoul feeling far away. Its an inexpensive ticket and one can easily spend a couple of hours here.

One of three palaces we visited in Seoul. Beautiful architecture, rich history and lots of knowledge imparted whilst touring the palace.  We entered the palace grounds directly from the station. The station walkway to the palace itself was amazing as it was themed as a palace. The palace is enormous with so many different chambers and grounds. My favourite section was the structure surrounded by a mout. We were there on an icy Korean day, so the mout was frozen up. The palace also has a curio shop and oppposite the shop you can dress up in tradional Korean attire and take photos. The curio shop is very good and we found some excellent gifts there at very good prices - this is Seoul after all and stuff is not cheap but this shop was very well priced so say the least. There is also an excellent western restaurant at the palace, which sells slightly different meals and has a nice arty feel about it. The restaurant itself also has a large curio shop and you can find good books, puzzles, fans, cufflinks etc at very good prices there.  Well worth a visit - this is Seoul - a city that promotes arts and culture.

This palace, and its neighbor to the East, is beautifully restored and well worth visiting. You can enter some of the buildings.  Recommended: Take a free, guided tour, either from the Palace (times posted upon entry) or by reserving one at the Korean Tourist Agency (http://www.visitseoul.net/).  Hidden treat: National Folk Museum of Korea is at the NE corner of the palace, and is excellent, with free guided tours.

I guess the palace look quite like a lot of other asian palaces. Most of it is not original, but restored or (more often) rebuilt. It's a place you should visite if you're in Seoul, but don't expect too much. The most charming area is at the back of the garden - a little pond with a hexagonal pavillion.

If you are to take Seoul's subway line number 3 to the Gyeobokgung station, you'll be mesmerized by the artistic subway columns promoting Korea's cultural artcrafts. Taking exit number 5, you will see South Korea's grandest palace. Although it was a rainy day during my tour, I still opted to catch the 11 o'clock English tour and learn the rich history of the country. Perhaps I am indeed a big fan of fairy tales and kingdoms the reason why I was so attentive with what the tour guide says ^_^. The most romantic part of the place was the Hyangwonji Pond and the Hyangwonjeong Pavilion. I did make sure to see and visit the site as this was filming location of the first appearance of Kim Soo Hyun in the famous drama, "The Moon That Embraces the Sun".  After the palace tour, the ticket may still be used if you wish to visit the National Folk Art Museum at the back of the Palace or have a glimpse of the Blue House (Korea's presidential house).  The cold wind that almost blew my umbrella and the pouring rain didn't matter. It was still an amazing tour. Hope to visit again on a fair weather.

The palace is pretty big, though once you have visited one palace, the rest looks pretty much similiar. Though they tell a different story. And so a guided tour helps or the guide booklet that is made available at the palance entrance. There are various activites that happens within the grounds of the palace. Depending on the time of the day, you will be able to experience the changing of guards at the entrance of the palace. There are some family oriented activities available within the palace vicinity as well.  The amazing thing about the palace is that it sits beautifully against Mount Namsan and the Han River.
Wow to think of how this is so magnificent even now. I love the colors. How sad that it was burned down by the Japanese. See the palace where the last queen and king were assassinated.
