This palace is immensely huge, or rather, the grounds are. The buildings are placed around the grounds and signs showing which building belonged to who are easily accessible and clearly marked. You can easily spend half a day here just walking around and taking it all in. The buildings are well preserved, the paint and colours glorious and bright. You can enter one building if you take your shoes off and leave them outside, this gives you the chance to get a closer look at how te Royal Family lived, but the sign with the overview was severly lacking here, sporting titles such as "a lamp"... I would have preferred a brief history or something like that.  Depending on he timing, you can catch the changing of the gard at the entrance, definitely worth it. I caught this by sheer luck and was pleasantly surprised. Very colourful, very "old, Asian film".  The museum is also absolutely worth a look. It shows the history of Korea and the traditions of its people, very educational and entertaining.  Outside the museum is a circle with sculptures of all the animals of the Chinese horoscope, excellent touristy photo opportunity ;-)  The museum has air conditioning, but the rest is outdoors, prepare sun lotion, hats and water if you're going!  Kafeteria and shop is just outside the entrance. Neat tip: if you want to send cards, you can buy both cards and stamps here AND send them from here. The staff will show you.

Nice touch of Korean history walking the grounds. Nestled in the heart of Seoul, this is very accessible. But it is not on the scale of the Forbidden City - and definitely worth visiting. There were the colourful guards marching around and they even wandered off into the business district outside the palace walls. Nice sight.
This place is larger than I had imagined, but it is quite the place to see. The museum is also attached to the grounds. The changing of the guards is quite th scene.
This is the biggest of all the palaces and the most well-preserved.
The changing of the guard was enjoyable. The museum is also worth taking in and walking around the ground, is a nice way of spending an afternoon.

This palace can be covered in much less time, but I spent about 5 hours exploring. Took the free English Tour which leaves from the Information office at designated times. Tour guide was impossibly nice, but a little hard to understand. Still, she tried very hard to make sure we got the gist of what she was trying to say. My tour group at the peak of the day was only about 15 people which was a nice size. The tour took about an hour and she did provide a few minutes here and there for us to linger.  I also bought for 3000 Won, an audio tour (right next to where you buy your tickets). I do recommend this as it provided a good number of additional tidbits that the guidebook and tour did not. It is also on a GPS so the audio/video clips just start playing as soon as you come up to a landmark. So after my guided tour, I doubled back and visited most of the places again with my audio guide. Try to time it for the changing of the guards. Not as spectacular as some I've seen in other countries, but certainly worth checking out.  I ventured out to get a better look at the Blue House (out the back gate, just make sure you have your ticket for re-entry), but did not have time for the Folk Museum which you can also access from the side of Gyeongbokgung. Make sure you have plenty of water and food if you need it, with you if you're visiting in the summer months. There is only one cafe at which to buy food & drink and it is located towards the front. There are large circular drinking fountains if you're not picky, though these are more 'faucet like' so folks do 'wash' in these too. I saw them cleaned frequently though.  I was surprised at how precarious many of the spots were - you have to climb to most of the buildings on rather tall stone steps. The ground is stone paved in many places and the stones are roughly hewn and you can easily trip. Just be aware if you're planning to go with anyone with mobility issues or young children.  I took the subway to get here. Get to Gwanghwamun station and there will be signs and maps that lead you to Gyeongbokgung. It was an easy 5 minute walk straight ahead from the exit that I took.  The only thing to realize is this palace has been completely restored from the ground up after it was razed by war and fire, so it is all a 'replica' if you will, if you are a real stickler for that. That aside, I think it is well worth at least a couple of hours visit.
touristy guard change during the guard but well worth getting a photo of

Yes, this palace has been reconstructed but the innovative South Koreans had no alternative if they wanted to rightly showcase their proud history.  The guards at the main gate were incredibly still as tourists posed beside them.  The 1100 changing of the guard was impressive: much music amid solemn ceremony and marching.  The Palace's reconstructed buildings occupy a large area. Reconstruction is ongoing with some traditional cottages being built.  The entrance fee (KRW3000 was particularly good value). One can combine this with a visit to the free National Folk Museum.  Don't come on Tuesdays: it is closed.

One of several major palaces in downtown Seoul; once you've had a guided tour of one you will recognize the main features of the others. I'd avoid the audio tour for this one, though; the equipment is very temperamental and the sound keeps cutting out.
A must-visit for first time Seoul visitors. Provides tourists with a glimpse of historical Korea. Get the combined tickets for all the palaces (costs 10000 KRW)

Ok, it had been a long flight and I was tired, hot and dehydrated. I'd also taken a wrong turn and gone in the wrong direction for a while, so when I got to the complex I was a bit grumpy. It looks beautiful, a bit like how I imagine the Imperial Palace looks in Beijing, but I then made the mistake of taking a free booklet describing the complex.. although it was first built in 1395 it burned down in 1592 and waited 275 years to be rebuilt only to be largely destroyed by fire again less than a decade later. Rebuilt again, it was pulled down in 1915 and in 1926 the Palace area was severely disfigured by the construction of a colonial building. Rebuilding began in 1990. So that was it - the whole lot was no more than 20 years old. Indeed if you look at the edges you can see the construction ongoing. All well and good, but rather disappointing. I have underwear older than that! I consoled myself by imagining the complex as a model, with me shrunk down to size. (C'mon, how many of you have looked at a really good model and NOT ever hought that?) But even that was little consolation - the reconstruction wan't accurate - the guide booklet admits that three buildings in the inner part originally had a hall joining them - so why rebuild them without it? And an island further along originally had access to the north - so why rebuild it to the south? Mind you it is a moot point, because the complex could more accurately be renamed the Do Not Enter Palace. Wherever there was the danger of actually seeing something interesting, a rope hung in front of you with a Do Not Enter sign and the occasion guard sitting around reading a paper. Why? What 20 year old thing am I going to ruin? And why close 90% of the doors and windows? Are the insides not accurate? Are they just storage for wheelbarrows? Why build a complex at all if not to open it up and show it off? I could understand it if it were 500 years old, but 20, no. The one place I really fancied a look around was a reception hall built on a lake. You could see it from the edge of the lake but the doors in the wall were firmly shut. When, at 10am, I saw 5 people being let in I thought my luck had changed, but I wasn't allowed through. The guard pointed out a sign (in Korean) that had a website on it (sorry, I didn't make a note) and said I had to make a reservation. Again, why? So their 20 year old building wouldn't get visitors? Nowhere did I see any indication that you could book, indeed had to book, in order to get inside, not even in the official booklet. And how frustrating it is to find one of the better areas off limits because my ESP powers were off that day and I hadn't guessed I had to book ahead. Totally frustrating, and frankly, they could do with a weedsprayer for some of the main areas and a gardner to turn the weed patch that is the "beautiful terraced garden" into what it should be. Cute squirrels though..

Easy to get to by the subway - Gwanghwamun Station on Line 5. You walk out the station and there is a statue of King Sejong- past the statue is the Palace with the guards in uniform. Worth visiting for a look at a bygone era and existence.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is close to the city center is thus the most frequented by tour groups. Visit early in the morning to avoid the crowds. The National Folk Museum of Korea is connected to the complex, so visit this as well when you're in the area.
Loved the changing of the guards! Afterwards we were invited to take pictures with the guards who were very patient with the many tourists.
Great view into Korean history. Do the self guided audio tour or join a live tour. Well worth it.

Compared to the palaces in Beijing, Gyeongbokgung Palace are not that impressive as a whole. But there are some interesting parts in the palace that are awe-inspiring. Its big moat in the middle of the palace & the changing of the guards are just a few of it.

the palace is intersting to visit if you would like to see one of the Korean palaces. However, the palace is not original and has been rebuilt recently, which explains the good quality and freshness of the painting.

I've heard people say that if you've been to Beijing, Seoul palaces are not that impressive. Well, I haven't been to Beijing so I don't know if that's true but I really, really loved Gyeongbok Palace. Get the audio guide so you understand what each building was for. It's a pretty emotional experience, knowing the royal family is gone.  You can spend more than half a day here because the National Folk Museum and National Palace Museum are here.  Check out the changing of the guard!

This is the prettiest palace in Seoul, for sure! Go there in the morning, when no one else is around. If there's a snowfall, you'll get beautiful pictures of the rooftops and park. There is also a great folk museum there, for those who don't have time to go to Yongin.

Gyeongbokgung Palace (景福宮)... the most Beautiful Palace ever !! Myself and with 6 other of my girl-friends are first time visit palace. We manage watching the colourful changing of the guards on time at around 10am and walked around for about 2 hours.  Admission Fees : Adults 3000 won (Closed on Tuesday)  getting there by subway : 1. Use exit #5 of Gyeongbokgung Station (Subway Line #3), 2. From Exit #2 of Ganghwamun Station (Subway Line #5), walk 400 meters

The guard changning in front of the palace is scheduled hourly from 10 am to 3 pm. I watched 10 am round and it's enjoyable especially when I was trying to take picture. I also had a chance to watch 3 pm round as well since I was still in the area. The routine is definely different from 10 am round and it's also shorter. My recommend'd be go for the 10 am round. Gyeongbokgung itself is pretty to an eye. It's a great spot to picture (day dreaming in my case) of how people in earlier era live.

Many explanations are written in Korean, and little in English. Toilets are not commonly found within the compound either.  However, exhibits are openly displayed for good viewing. The exhibits are also very well maintained too.

One of the most beautiful palaces in Seoul (Go for this one if you had to visit only one).  The changing of the guards which occurs at 2:00 pm is worth watching.  Take some documentation / map about the palace to understand the history of the place.
Loved the palace, history and culture! We watched the changing of the guards and walked the grounds for a couple of hours. The national folk museum is on the property and has free admission.
Changing of the Guards every hour on the hour, ending at 3PM. It's a must see. Wear comfortable shoes and take lots of pictures.

One of five palaces in Seoul, it has been fully restored. It's a large fenced complex with many different buildings. Most of the buildings cannot be entered, but some, including the throne room, have the doors open so you can see inside. Do take the video tour, it has a built in GPS so the narration automatically starts as you approach each viewing point. The changing of the guards, every hour on the hour, is colourful and worth seeing. My favourite parts were the stone animal statues and the large pavilion set in the water.  Probably not interesting to small children as there's a lot of walking and not much to do.

I made it just in time for the free English tour, and followed our guide around for a couple of hours. I really enjoyed learning about the history of the palace from 1395 all the way to the present. Of course, a tour in this area isn't a tour without a good ten minutes hearing about King Sejong :) but overall, I loved it. And the palace is BIG, so wear your walking shoes. My puppies hurt after running around this place!
The palace is a very tranquil place set amongst a bustling city, it was very interesting and gave a good insight into Korean history
the changing of the guards ceremony was interesting. would have been better if there was some sort of english version so visitors could understand what was going on.
It seems like they have a lot of students going there for field trips

good to visit this palace and with the map and discription, you know the history of korea a lot. i recommend to exist on the west side and go for ginsing chicken for lunch and use the same ticket to resume the visit after. since the famous restaurant is right at the west side exist.

Very Big palace so be prepared to walk. The change of guard ceremony is nice to watch. Only thing that was not so nice is the dust in that place. Either beause of the number of people who visit or since the historic site is historic large area is plain ground. What is beautiful is the various carvings of animals and the one that is breath taking is the throne. Pls plan to first thing in the morning as dust & heat combination in the noon would be difficult to handle
Beautiful. Make sure to walk around the whole area, which has fabulous gardens.

We were there around 2pm, and we were able to watch the changing of the guards. It took around 15 minutes, and guests can go up close to take photos or videos. There are no barriers so you can feel free to take photos.  The palace itself is big and beautiful. We feel this is the most beautiful one of the palaces.

It is a huge palace complex that you can wander around. It's a great way to spend a nice afternoon outside. If you are visiting, to see some well maintained or restored traditional palace buildings. I would say it is a definite must to see at least one of the palaces if you are visiting South Korea. For those that live here, you should have been to one by now.
Get the schedule for the ceremony from the Korean website and go watch! It is amazing to watch the guards continue to perform this tradition.
Changing of the guards, the history and architecture, the gardens and the surrounding mountains all within the modern city of Seoul
amazing. i went to this and i went to the palace in beijin, this one is a lot more pleasent. clean with nice architecture and lake inside.

I had a blast and learned so much on this trip. The buildings are breathtaking and the it was weird because it was smack in the middle of a highly populated area but it was quiet... The colors on and in the building were beautiful. I truly had fun. I love learning about South Korea's culture and history.

I'm not a history or culture enthusiast, but visiting Seoul is not complete if you dont visit all those palaces. It's nice because it was my first timer, what you expect will be the colourful unique designs. Excellent for photo taking and memorable photo of Seoul trip. nothing much to see and expect on the changing of guard , just a procession with colourful guard marching and playing traditional musical instruments. easily accessible by subways (Gwanghamon or Geongbukgung st).

Absolutely stunning and a must see. You can make your way around the palace and the surrounding neighborhood on foot an enjoy the splendor. Reasonably priced at 3,000 won Try the follk museum too it's free
great for learning about korean culture, architecture is nice too. it is massive, so recommend visiting when youve got some energy!

I along with my friend had a nice trip around the Seoul. We enjoyed it very much. For me it was like a dream to observe the Korean Traditions, History and culture, wearing Korean traditional, dress I felt myself a Character of King Sejong, the great.  I personally think we should preserve and promote our history and culture for the upcoming generations and the organizations like Touch Korea Tour are doing this in a remarkable way here in Korea. The visit of the National Museum of Korea introduce us to the culture of Korea, the seasons, bridal, birth and funeral ceremonies, music instruments and all that was very unique to us. It also gives us comparison of various ages of empowerment and emperors in Korea. It also tells a clear story of the downfall and rise of Korea. Our guide Sunny Park while explaining all the history of Gyeongbok palace created such an environment and interest that I felt myself to be a part of that era. She explained us the in detail about the various parts of palace and the ruling situation of various emperor. Indeed she proved herself a kind and competent resource person. It was very interesting and romantic to visit the Historical Street behind the palace. The Combination of modern and ancient culture of Korean Society was awesome. I recommend every visitor to visit Gyeongbok palace if you wana explore the real culture and tradition of Korea.

Good for learning Korean culture for those who is very curious and interested but to some it will be boring and tiring. When I went there, a ceremonial parade was taken place where there are Koreans who wear hanbok so we took a lot of pictures, you'll see different kind of old building of Korean Monarchy.
History of the Royal family during that era.The way they lived in such huge grounds.To cover it 2hours plus was not enough time The high light was the changing of the Royal Guards very spectacular.
Worth a visit, probably good idea to have a guide.
absolutely worth a visit make sure you are there when they have the changing of the guard ceremony in the traditional costumes. very colourfull

Located in the heart of downtown Seoul, the Gyeonbokgung palace is a must. Not only are tickets dirt cheap, you can also gain access to multiple different sites including the neighboring palace, and the Folk Museum.  Beware though. The palace is closed on Tuesdays. Always check on the website to make sure they are open as they tend to close it down for various reasons.
Variety of very good museums and very well restored palace buildings.
Lots of excellent examples of ancient Korean palace architecture and life. Good for a walk around. Definitely worth the money.

This palace is a great place to visit to get a glimpse of Korea's history. Definitely get an audio guide if you do not take a guided tour. Without the background information, you are likely to miss out on a lot of key facts.
This was a great half day trip. The history was interesting, the grounds are nice and inside is the folk museum. If the weather is nice, take a picnic.

If you have seen any European, Chinese, or Japanese palaces/temples, this will be a bit of a let down. The architecture is nice enough, but there very little interest-holding power here. Nicest thing about the place is the mountains in the background.  Thronging with tourists as well, not a MUST SEE if I'm honest.

Ponds, nooks, crannies, pavillions, surprises, ....its all here. The changing of the guard is quite a ceremony so don't miss it. Check with tourist office(s) to find out the daily schedule (depends on time of year of visit).

If you are short on time, and only have one palace to visit while you are in Seoul. I really recommend Gyeongbokgung Palace to be your pick. It has an extensive ground. They layout is great and easy to navigate through and the buildings are so beautiful. I was just in time to see the cherry blossoms still in bloom. It is a beautiful and serene place. A must see on my list of things to see while you are in Korea.

get ready to walk around into the traditional houses and around the little lakes they have in this complex. and all the while, catch a small glimpse of how life is during the Joseon dynasty. love the atmosphere and wonderful view during the spring- and winter too.

The greatest and earliest of the Five Grand Palaces constructed during Joseon Dynasty dated back to the 14th century, Gyeongbokgung Palace is worth a stroll to those who explore Seoul for its culture and history. Being restored after ruins by time and wars, the Chinese-look-alike palace is sizeable enough to hold your stay up to half a day or more by its hordes of halls, courts, pavilions and royal quarters.  Come early around 9 am to witness a royal parade before finding yourself passing through regal passages which lead to 5 outer courts (used to serve administration affairs including the Throne Hall), 3 inner courts (private residences of King, Queen and His Mother) and Donggung (the Palace of the Crowned Prince). Somehow, the most radiant shall be 2 pavilions in the backyard and of which, the Hyangwonjeong pavilion on a small island is the most photographed.  What is more, the environs of the Palace may excite you as well. The next door Museum of free entrance with a recreational exhibition of ancient Korea readies to expose more about the history of the dynamic country. A wee further is a food street packed with restaurants and coffeehouses of all ranges and cuisines. Also, it takes 15 minutes on foot to reach Jogye Temple, one the most important Buddhist temple in Seoul and its nearby shopping street. Or you can tour to Mount Inwang, featuring the Zen Rocks, right in the backdrop of the Gyeongbokgun Palace.
Seen on many travel posters, tourist brochures for a reason. The setting, the water, and the porportions of the main building is pretty close to perfect.

The palace was huge, 2 hours was not enough to walk around everywhere. Lots of excellent places to take pictures and take in the culture of a life that has all but passed.  The temple was nice, the park inside and the palace was great to see. It was hot and open, so bring water and snacks, but you can also buy inside.  There is a free area where you can try to wear traditional clothing, but the wait time is quite long.  The entrance fee is like 3000W each, which is great value and the train station is right beside, as well as ample number of taxi's.  Insadong is right infront of the palace, so great way to also do your shopping.  The palace was one of the highlights of our trip.

Visited this and CheongDuk Gung. We liked this one better--more spacious, more impressive. Terrific gift shop at the adjacent Folk Museum. Didn't stop to take a photo in traditional costume but it looked fun.

The grounds of this palace was just stunning and huge. Free guided tours are provided in several languages. A children's museum and an art museum are also here. I was expecting to be here for about an hour, but ended up spending 3-4 hours here.

Join the free guided tour. Guide was very good, speak very good English and share not only about the palace history but also on other Korean tradition and culture. Tried to catch the change of guard. The museum next to the palace cannot be missed. Entrance to museum is included in the palace ticket.
Managed to see the change of Guards which was some thing different from the British type. It was a good day, as it was raining the whole day. We went to this Palace by MRT line

I liked the location, from the palace courtyard I could see the mountains surrounding the palace, and could almost imagine how it was during the olden days. Awesome. However, if you look the other way, you can see the tall office buildings now surrounding Seoul, so on that end, you can get a feel of the old and new in Korea.  Make sure to catch the changing of the guard (around 3pm). After visiting the palace, have some coffee at the museum cafe just before boarding the subway to your next destination.

There are many palaces in Seoul,and for most you can't visit all of them. So if you have to visit one of these beautiful palaces, I would say it has to be Gyeongbokgung.  It has its beauty and it is HUGE! You can wonder aroundt the palace enjoy sceneries. I recommend to visit the palace during the changing guard ceremony. Which I find it very entertaining and exciting to watch. This is on 11.00, 14.00 and 15.30. You can visit this place at any day but Monday!  TIPS: I went there two times already. In July, it's very HOT! so you may need to bring umbrella along.

If you only have time to visit one palace in Seoul make sure it is this one. It is absolutely spectacular and you could easily spend a whole day there. The first day I went it poured with rain so went back a week or so later on a sunny day with blossom starting to appear. Just spectacular in a large city.

The big palace in Capital city of Choseon dinasty were devided by the political reason in early 1900's. Gyeingokgung is the main core place of that big palace and there is the historical spot where Korean last Empress got assasinated by Japanese Yakuja during the termoil era...
Enough to see and keep you and kids entertained for half a day.

This is one of the palace that you must not miss. Beautifully preserved with rich cultural site. On a sunny day, this place is excellent for taking pictures, very colorful, good view of the mountains. The palace a big place and need a few hours to really enjoy and relax walk to have glimpse of this location. Too bad we missed the changing of guards.

I think that one visiting Korea should not miss this place. It is in the heart of the city and very near other must see places like Gwanghamun park and the Blue Mansion. We got to see the changing of the Palace guards which is another good experience. The place covers a vast area and considerable time is needed to go around it. There was also free admission in the National Folk Museum which was also very educational. It might be very helpful though if they placed some historical description on each palace and not only on the entrances. Still, it is a must see for me.
history + scenery = awesome. u'll regret if u dont visit this palace.. a very huge palace.. u can see guard ceremony every hours :)

While much of the site had to be recreated due to unavoidable outcome of war and occupation, the site is fabulous in detail and grandeur. Our English-language guide was very knowledgeable and provided much more history and information than a self-guided tour could have.  I give it five stars..... well done.

A beautifully preserved traditional architecture in the center of modern Seoul. Its gardens and lakes are picturesque spots that will provide perfect shooting locations for photography enthusiasts. Take advantage of the free hanbok wearing at the souvenir shop!
Very nice place. Apart from the Palace it is also a park with a great view of mountains.

love the tour guide...she explained everything in detail..do check out the time for the free tour guide...we managed to get more than 10 people to save 600won for the entrance fee..it will be great if you can get more than 10 people and the ticket will be 2400 won ;)

The palace is under some construction in East areas at the moment. I recommend going in the early morning or late afternoon to avoid the masses of tourist buses and crowds point-and-clicking doing their 'been there done that' poses in enough time to get back to their bus tours. We arrived in mid-afternoon and spent the rest of the afternoon there until closing time at 6pm. The folk museum is North East of the palace and you need your ticket to re-enter the palace grounds after visiting the museum which is free. There's a lovely little coffee shop at the museum with small alfresco area to laze in the afternoon sun while sipping your coffee, or in my case, eating my softserve! No food is allowed in the palace grounds, so eat up before heading back in. The palace buildings were destroyed during the Japanese invasion and also the Korean war, so it lacks the historical 'feel', however beautifully reconstructed. Many families and couples take time to stroll through the park as it is quite a peaceful place when crowds have gone.

With or without the cherry blossoms, the palace site is one beautiful place you must visit when you are in Korea. Colorful palace guard clothes and flags compliment the intricate design of the roofs of their halls and gates. The vast space makes it good for strolling/roaming around while holding the hands of the one you love and occasionally sneak a kiss or two. :) There are many tourists here but with how huge the site is, you definitely can find a private place where you can sit down and have a heart-to-heart conversation amid the pavilions, lake, and the beautiful backdrop of the Bugak Mountain.

Two hours were barely enough to explore the lovely grounds, gardens and various palace courtyards and buildings. Allot more time if you wish to visit the folklore museum (also part of the complex) or linger to soak in the atmosphere. Northward views are majestic ---- looking at the palace buildings and the backdrop of mountains ---- and help transport you to a long-ago era. But look south and you suddenly see the office blocks of downtown Seoul, which bring you back to present-day reality.

If you only have time to visit one palace in Seoul, visit this one. It's big, elegant, and fun to walk around. You can also visit the national folk museum from there. Plan to spend about 2 hrs there... It's the nicest one in that area thrust me.
I love walking around the grounds and go to the Folk Museum which is on the premises. The little pavilion on the small island is lovely.

I visited in February, it was very cold as it was mostly outside, but it also made the grounds even more beautiful. I felt sorry for the guards having to stand in the cold, but it looked like they had plenty of clothes on under their uniforms! The uniforms are very colourful and are certainly a 'highlight'. Try to catch the changing of the guard. Entry into the grounds is very cheap, especially for Seoul, and you can also visit the cultural museum, which was good for warming up on a cold day!

Part of planning our itinerary for the day is looking up the different attractions clustered in one area, say Hongdae area. My friend and I decided to dedicate one day to do a 'cultural' tour. We planned on going to a couple of the palaces in Seoul, as well as a museum or two.  Gyeongbokgung Palace comes highly recommended in different Korean travel sites. It is the main palace in the Joseon dynasty. Anyway, we chose to get there before 1:30 PM so we can join the English guided tour of the palace.  The place was already packed with tourists and locals alike. There were different tour groups as well, but the place was big enough that it didn't feel crowded. We paid 3,000 Won each for admission into the palace.  The tour guide spoke English but with a very distinct Korean accent. Being exposed to the Korean English a lot more than my friend, I found it easier to 'understand' compared to my friend. The guide was very knowledgeable and inserted some anecdotes into her tour.  The tour lasted for one hour, but we weren't able to cover everything, so we were left to explore the rest of the compound.  There was also a Royal Changing of the Guards (I think) ceremony as we were leaving.  The reason why I suggest you start your Cultural tour here is that you won't need a tour guide for the other palaces since they are basically set up in a similar fashion.  Restorations are currently being done on some other part of the compound.
its big, you can see the imperial life in the palace and the history of it.

This is a must see in Seoul! There are about 5 or 6 palaces... this is by far the best one! There is also a free tour in English everyday. I believe the tour is around 2p.m. Check their website to make sure though. Have a great time!
There are so many things to see. You will appreciate the stillness of Seoul inside. Do not forget to visit.
Easy to get to by subway. Need more scheduled tours.

I went there as part of city Morning Tour, just in time for 10:00am guard change, which, I'm told, happens 5 times a day even on a weekday. It started with a sound of a gong, then soldiers in colorful ancient costumes walked in patterns while playing various curious musical instruments. It’s a huge territory with a Museum with mountains on the backdrop. Beautiful! Lots of memorable pictures. By the way, the Morning Tour gives you a choice of leaving you (for free) at Itaewon – the international district. Take this opportunity! If you choose to get back to the hotel, it would be extra $10, and you’ll miss Itaewon.
Good guide, well organized tour around the immense palace space, learned something!

Great place, definetly worth seeing when in the downtown Seoul area the admission is cheap and it is within walking distance of the subway. Beautiful grounds, most likely better suited for the history loving folks, who are able to imagine how these grounds must have looked and funtioned in the 15th century. Perhaps not so much for kids, teens or adults that require more visual stimulation for enjoyment.  The palace grounds could be enjoyed any time of the year, but probably best enjoyed during the mild weather months when a leisurely stroll through the lush grounds among beautiful flowers and tree blossums is possible.
If you have to pick to see one Palace ,this is it! nice and amazing art with history.. I love it.

I had a Korean Goodwill Guide from the Toruism Board take me to Gyeongbokgung Palace and it was something I'll never forget! My guide Mr.Kim was a fountain of information throughout the palace tour... so much information it was hard to remember everything he told me but I tried! I took hundreds of photos at Gyeongbokgung Palace to remind me of this incredible experience. The palace is a huge complex of several buildings and features a changing of the guard ceremony and lot of people in colorful traditional palace costumes.  Very highly recommended... especially if you can go with a Goodwill Guide.

I've been visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace in late March, which is just a bit eary. Everything is still wintery brown and dry. However, I think it must be a beautiful place when the trees are in full bloom which should be in April I think. The layout reminds me of the Forbidden City in Beijing. I think it's well worth a visit. Try to catch one of the free guided tours and the "changing of the guards".

I think this is the main palace out of all the palaces you can visit in Seoul. The architecture is impressive and well-preserved. We walked around the huge ground for an hour and a half and visited the different halls.

On our way to gyeongbokgong palace we meet group of volunteer students who offer free English tour within gyeongbokgong palace... This made our tour interesting... Special thanks to Alex Kwon, who spent almost the whole day getting us around gyeongbokgong palace and educating us about their rich culture:) Just outside the palace youll see gwanghwanmun square.
we needed many hours to see most of it, don't miss the guard's show.

The 1st royal changing ceremony start about 10.30am and the ceremony is about 10minutes only. Then you can take pictures with the guides..but dont be surprised that they will not smile at all. You still can take pictures with them and outside the palace even you dont but the ticket but to get inside, you have to buy ticket at only 3000won. They are more places to explore inside including korean national folk museum.
It's a scenario of the old times, beautiful place to spend some hours. Plan to be in front around 11AM that they have a ceremonial.

I have been there a few times already and it never gets boring! A great place to visit for a day, also for a picnic. Very well maintained . Don't miss the show at the entrance of the palace, it feels like going back in time! There is one part of the palace that you need to book at least a day before you visit, if you don't you cannot get in. Absolutely loved it!

Enjoyed the trip to the Palace very much as we managed to catch the change of guards. It definitely is a sight to see.  The palace itself also has beautiful architecture and is a huge compound to walk around.  Tips: Check when the times for the change of guards are before you visit, and choose a palace you want to visit because visiting all of them may not be a very wise use of time in Seoul.

There are a number of well-reserved, ancient imperial palaces in Seoul, and visiting at least one of them is probably on the agenda of most visitors, and rightly so. They are held with a degree of reverence by the Korean people, and during our August visit here were many more Korean tourists than foreigners. Gyeongbokgung Palace is well-situated for most tourists, as it is close to the lovely Insadong neighbourhood with its restaurants, shops and art galleries, as well as being a five-minute walk from the interesting Bukchon Hanok Village with its Joseon-dynasty traditional houses.  Try to join one of the guided tour groups: they are informative but not overly talky. The palace is surprisingly large, and well-preserved. I found it amazing to see these huge palace structures dotting Seoul, throwbacks to the 14th and 15th centuries, surrounded primarily by modern buildings less than 30 years old. In Seoul it seems that there's very little that's "old": everything is either "ancient" or "modern", and Gyeongbokgung Palace is an excellent example of the former.  A 1-2 hour visit to Gyeongbokgung Palace would be a core component of a fruitful day in Seoul that included this historic site, some shopping and gallery-hunting in nearby Insadong, and a nice meal at one of the many restaurants in the immediate vicinity. The changing-of-the-guard ceremony doesn't have quite the pomp-and-circumstance of Buckingham Palace, but the colorful costumes are amazing and a photographer's delight! Overall Gyeongbokgung Palace didn't blow me away in the same manner as, for instance, Angkor Wat in Cambodia, but it is a worthwhile visit, and definitely part of what I would call "the Korea experience".
Was a nice 3 hours looking around this relatively new copy of this 600 year old Palace.

The palace complex can be reach from 2 stations nearby - Gwanghwamun and Gyeongbokgung. It's good to start the visit from Gwanghwamun Gate as you can see the Imperial Guard at the entrance. There are souvenir shops in the complex area. During winter, you should go to the lake nearby Hwangwonjeong and get the experience to try their traditional top-spinning on the frozen lake.
If you are in Seoul, shell out and see a palace. This one is fine.
Nice Palace, but nothing grand about it.. Typical tourist stop. Worth taking a couple of pictures i guess :)

Went here on a balmy, brisk Sunday afternoon in February. Temp was about 10C and the skies were clear and sunny with no wind. Beautiful day!  This was a great to decompress after a long, anxiety filled week.  I didn't know what to expect and a guide would have been nice but is certainly not necessary. It was relaxing to just stroll the ground, looking at all of the buildings and reading the plaques. The architecture is incredible and being there, you can imagine the 14th Century King holding court or strolling by the pond.  There are many benches and places to just sit and take it all in, which we did. We didn't have time to visit the Folk Museum or Palace Museum and will try to see them next time.  We saw the changing of the guards and snapped a few photos - in its own way, its as momentous and magnificent as Buckingham Palace.  Incredible to contrast this incredibly historic spot against what greets you right outside the gates.

I seem to find something new every time I visit Gyeongbokgung. The folk museum located inside the palace is great, the changing of the guard is really neat to watch. Just a beautiful area and lots of culture

a day spent wandering around the palace and local museums with lots of free information in lots of languages and free guides who are helpful, if difficult to tell that you don’t want their help. Exploring on my own I find things that they may not show you, but they are there to ask when guiding others.

Went there by Metro , 5min walking and you will be at between 2 main road. You will see Emperor Sejong status. From there you can start your photopgrahy till you enter Geyongbukgung. By the time i arrived , there are some traditional dance show i assume. The building is well preserved but the paint to me is like a modern built one. Walk around and the lake in there are frozen. I like frozen lake. Great view and worth to be there if you visit Seoul!

I would not make a special visit to this palace. Both the architecture and the palace ground is uninteresting. The National Folklore Museum is equally dry. (I personally found the exhibits very creepy. May because I am Chinese and a bit superstitious.} However if you are in the area you should not miss the interesting local designer shops, cafes and creative houses in the intricate lane ways east of Samcheongdonggil. If you were here around dinner time there are also numerous restaurants to choose from along this picturesque road.
Traditional look at Korea as it was in the old days - very interesting and enjoyable

The guided tour was great. If you miss the schedule, they do have audio guide equipment for loan. It also offers free Korean clothing try-on service, so make sure your ask for the location before heading in.

If you have time to kill, then it's worth a visit. But if not, it's not imperative to make a stop here. This place has been rebuilt and is rather sparse and sad to say, lacking character or charisma. We did watch the changing of the guard, albeit a bit of a let down.
great free english tour.... and colorful guard changing ceremony...close to culture museum and Blue House

I'm not going to kid you here folks - historical site tours are not for everyone. For anyone who has seen the Forbidden City, Angkor Wat or the Grand Palace in Bangkok, Gyeongbokgung Palace might not pack much of a tourist punch.  Having said that, if you enjoy Korean history or just the pleasure of exploring culturally significant sites, then Gyeongbokgung is a good choice for a day trip - especially if you visit near-by Insadong-gil (Insadong street) and explore the many wonderful side streets, alleyways, temples and galleries that the surrounding neighborhood has to offer.  I also encourage a quick visit to the very nearby Bukchon Hanok Village. It's a collection of traditional houses and streets that have been protected and restored, and I think it provides an excellent complement to a day of cultural/historical exploration!

Interesting to see the old palace and see how the royalty lived then. They had a much simpler life than I expected. Take the guideded tour. Tour is a definite must-do i you are visiting Seoul. Combine it with a trip to Inadong market - a few blocks away.

The palace is huge. It requires couple of hours to walk through all major sites. It is sad to learn that all major palaces in Seoul were damaged or nearly destroyed in the past. But the remnants of the original palace and the newly reconstructed parts are definitely worth visiting. One can imagine the power those nations in Asia enjoy in their history. It is hard to imagine how large it was if the huge complex with many buildings represent 40% of its original size.

Gyeongbokgung Palace has been under a restoration process for some years and so far a lot of the buildings have now been outwardly restored. The contents of some are still to be placed. The site is huge so good walking shoes a must, and it does get hot here so plenty of water.... Not many places to get food or drink on-site. The Palace certainly opens your eyes to how things used to be
Gyeongbokgung is huge!! I had a great time taking pictures and exploring all the entire place. Unfortunately I didn't have the time to attend the 'palace ceremony' (was rushing to somewhere else) :(

Highly tourist-ed but a great and easy see in the center of Seoul. Enjoy the walk around the Palace grounds (not a huge amount to see) then be sure to enjoy a bit the plethora of restaurants and drinking establishments (Hofs) around the area. When the smoke drives you coughing from one restaurant or bar (or every one), a walk along the canal is nice!
Vast grounds and beautiful foliage, this place will give you a historical lesson of Seoul in the past

The cultural experience of korea in the heart of Seoul. Easy to get to, v.big, but i wouldnt recommend visiting it in Winter. It gets too cold there and the absence of trees takes away from its beauty.

Nothing to cheer about but a historic palace... nothing to do beside walk around, look around and take photo... One thing gonna take note are, just exit from the Gyeongbokgung main exit, walk to your left end and there is a shop street. A shop selling a very tasty chicken and serving fresh draft beer~! It's a great dining experience in winter time~! Please look at the picture for reference~ strongly recommended~!
See what's it like back in those days... Went in Winter and there's ice everywhere..

You can spend a good few hours here if you really looked at everything in detail and walk to every section of the palace.  There's a free guided tour (different languages at varying times) available but this is after you buy your entry ticket into the palace (3000 won).  You can't go into any of the buildings but there's some that you can look inside with a description in front.  The changing of the guard is definitely worth seeing as well and occurs every hour.  You really need to walk around the palace to appreciate why some people who worked in the palace in the olden days never even saw the king once the entire time!!
Probably on of the best preserved ancient palaces. If you take the time to go through all the detail you will be amazed to see the brilliance of ancient times. Plan about two hours.

It's the biggest and most well known palace in Korea. How long you stay there is up to you. You could blow through it in an hour, with the pamphlet and a camera or you could stay there for hours with a guided tour. My biggest complaint about any palace in Korea is that they are INCREDIBLY well maintained, so they sometimes lose that feeling of history and age with every coat of fresh paint they slap on, but I have lived here 3 years and they are still pretty amazing sites. They are huge complexes in the center of one of the worlds largest cities and they really give you an idea of what life was like in Korea ages ago. Fall is the most beautiful time to go because it is not too hot and the fall colors actually make it even more gorgeous than in spring (aIs surprising as it sounds). It also gives you really beautiful views of the mountains, the Blue House where the President lives and it is quite large. It might be difficult for kids that are too small because you just look at things, you cant really interact or enter buildings, but kids above the age of 7 I'm sure would find a way to enjoy it. It's perfect if you are taking family visiting Korea, if you are a family visiting Korea, teens, friends or couples.

The Korean government is currently reconstructing the buildings of this palace. Before the Japanese ocupation the palace had 800 buildings; during the occupation all but 10 buildings were torn down. The project to restore Gyeongbokgung is a fifty year project; half the project has already been completed. The reconstruction has been made difficult by urban expansion. The work done so far is very impressive and I look forward to seeing Gyeongbokgung in all its glory in the future.
Though buildings are extensively reconstructed, it is enjoyable to wander around and immerse oneself in the historic architecture of a bygone Korea.

Worth a visit - it was extremely cold when we did, but the grounds are gorgeous. I'd be interested in seeing the grounds in warmer weather. There was snow on the ground for us. The buildings are lovely and you can pose with the colorfully dressed soldiers at the entrance.
we were only in Seoul for 27 hours, but we managed to visit this palace. It was definitely worth the visit, it is very easy to get to, picturesque, and the changing of the guards is very cool!
pretty much a watered down version of forbidden city of beijing. has some korean influence on some of the elements though. can visit if have time, admission is cheap and not a factor.

A nicely preserved old palace. The changing of the guards is an interesting spectacle. The Korean Folklore museum inside the complex shows a lot of Korean history. The only thing I didn't like was the wheather: it was minus 15°C... brrr
Had good shows of guard exchanges, royal family tour. A smaller version of palaces with chinese roots of zodiac stone statues and rooftops.

This became one of the highlights of our tour, not only because of the Palace and grounds, but also we got to try on a traditional Korean costume!  First, the Palace and grounds ... the area was bigger than I expected and had a bit of a tiring walk to explore, but I didn't mind because this meant it didn't seem to be as crowded. The Palace and other buildings were majestic and I liked the feeling of history it brought for me. We arrived there at around 3PM, which was perfect timing because we witnessed the "guard" show. Not sure if it was meant to be a changing of the guards, or a reenactment of a historical event (I wasn't paying attention when they announced it) but I did enjoy the show.  Then there's the traditional Korean costume. As we explored, we noticed a sign beside the coffee shop showing some traditional costumes. Turns out that they allow you to try on a traditional Korean costume! And it's for free! But when we got there, they already had quite a long waiting list and couldn't accommodate us anymore. So my friends and I went back early the next morning, just so we could experience this. The costume place opens at 10AM, and they allow you to have it on for about 15 minutes, in which time you can explore around in costume in nearby areas to give you the perfect photo opp. :-)
Bring a camera. You'll find lots of beautiful pictures. It is large, so be prepared for a lot of walking. You can buy a little box that describes what you are seeing in several languages. Enjoy!

The palace is pretty new. I assume that the original was destroyed. Lay-out and look similar to Forbidden Palace but on a smaller scale. There are guards and shows by them, and the kids will enjoy them.

My hubby and I went here on our first date, and had lovely time. Check out the folk museum next door (and let me know if you find the boys water jugs!). One thing I love about Korean public attractions is that they are reasonably priced, so you can return again and again. Obviously, as my first date, it has a special place in my heart, but it still has plenty to check out. It's also very convenient and close to many other attractions or places to go (Statue of Lee, biggest foreign language bookstore, Tomatillos). Over all, the palaces are very similar, except one has "Biwon" which is the secret garden (not Gyeongbokgung, though) If you have been to the Forbidden Palace in Beijing, you may be disappointed. It is very similar, but smaller, but has it's own beauty, nevertheless. By comparison, the process of getting in here is much easier. Since my husband and I are leaving after many years in Korea, we recently went back to take photos again. Second time around, it was beautiful and awe inspiring. It has sections designed to draw kids as well... I recommend it!
Its really nice. It reminded me of the Korean soap operas. When you're inside you will imagine how life was like in the old times. The place is very clean and well kept.

Visit one and you got the idea of how it look like all. Pretty bland and less ornaments compare to palaces in Japan. But its Korean humbleness who win peoples heart. Humble, pure and tradition above all.

Make this one of your places to see while visiting Seoul. Very beautiful & intricate remaking of some of these structures. Do some research on the history of this palace or else you'll find yourself just looking at pretty buildings.better yet get a tour guide. you wil be doing a lot of walking so prepare yourself. Visit the National Museum of Korea which is on the grounds. It is located way in the back and is free admission
The palace is clean and there is a wonderful performance on changing of guards at certain time of the day. However, there are a lot of tourists in the palace and it is therefore very crowded.
Changing of guards ceremony and the historical palaces
The Royal family lived in such simplicity and it is a good picture on why Koreans can be so hard on themselves to excel sometimes.
Very nice palace. Unfortunately the interior is shown only on small maps and not with open windows to let you look inside. Palace guards are very helpful with foreigners
Tour guides in every language. Bring walking shoes though. Bring a good camera. The changing of the guards is worth seeing all by itself.

I have forced my korean partner to explain me how to get to this place from one of the suburbs. Took a city bus and got there by 25 min. Easy to find and follow. Difficult to believe that all complex was rebuilt during last five years or something. Gorgeous view on the mountain from one side and on the modern city on other. Unfortunately had not time to visit museum. It seems that Palace wants me to come again. Many people are walking around and a lot of schoolchildren run around.

Between Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung, i prefer Gyeongbokgung, as there is more to see and the secenary was much better.  There is also the guard changing ceremony that happens every hours in front of the palace and if u want have some good food. At Gyeongbokgung station exit 2 there is Tosokchon (토속촌) the famous Samgyetang shop which even the president of korea patronises.  So all in all a good all round place to visit.

was having a high hope when coming over to checkout the palace. When we arrive it is a bit of disappointing as it look bit barren / empty.  if you're visiting here on summer i suggest to visit here in the evening as the sun is too hot to move around.  there is a museum nearby which the access is free of charge :)
Take the free tour. Really worth the 1 hour time. You will be given time to take photos.

Very fortunate to catch the changing of the guard at 9.30am, loved the costumes and music, especially the drums, but buildings empty of furniture or artefacts. Best thing was proximity to Folk museum which was great.

We missed the free English tour which started at 9am (outdated guide book said 9.30am..) and so my husband and I rented 2 gps self-guided tour handsets which was cool. We chose the one-hour course and the sets pointed the way to visit the palace in a meaningful way. Each time you strolled to a location of interest, the handset automatically starts and tells you more. The only downside was that the handset was a tad hard to use (we were told that "to hear more about XXX, press more" and we could not find the "more" button). Would recommend you devote at least 2 hours, and give this priority in your itinerary.
It was one of the must-see sights, so we did and enjoyed it very much... just walking around the grounds.
take a good picture in one of their parks, we the ground is covered with yellow leaves. I love their Autumn, we have none.

We spent a couple of hours wandering around the palace and could have spent more time. A highlight was a young woman being photographed in her hanbok (with flip-flops on underneath!). The wood carvings and painted ceilings were amazing...as were the tiles (and animals) on the roofs.

For anyone who loves palaces, this is one palace you shouldn't miss. It's magnificent ! Since it was autumn, the beautiful falling leaves and colorful trees made the palace all the more beautiful. You have to walk quite a bit to see the whole area but it's so worth it!

I am quite surprise when I reached this palace. I don't have much expectation as I thought this is just a palace with buildings and garden. What surprise me is the surrounding scenery. What a beautiful place! I went there during autumn, and the leaves are so beautiful, especially the scenery near the lake. The ticket is quite cheap. Worth visiting!

This palace was so overcrowded that I had a hard time finding a good photo op, but the Changing of the Guard was really cool and worth the trip. The Banquet Hall was very nice as well. Personally, I preferred some of the other palaces, probably because they were less crowded and there was more time to stroll and enjoy the grounds.

Gyeongbukgung is the crown jewel of Seoul's collection of royal palaces, with complete access at no more than a few US dollars. You could honestly spend all day wandering its huge expanse, there's just so much history there and so many different styles of architecture to appreciate as well. Besides the main pavilions, I recommend seeing the Hyangwonjeong Pavilion towards the north gate and the Gyeonghoeru (Royal Banquet Hall), set on water. But honestly, its worth it to just take your time and wander through the whole thing leisurely and read the posted information along the way. I loved Gyeongbukgung so much I went twice during my trip! On a side note, do not miss either the National Palace Museum (separate 1,000W admission) or National Folk Museum attached to Gyeongbukgung.
good museums within. but you can tell it is just too touristy. not ORIGINAL
Try to go to the palace when they have the traditional guards march. Good picture opportunity.

I walked through the palace areas, but except for a private house at the entrance and the throne room, most of the "appartments" where empty/unfurnished. The palace was renovated in the 1990s and one can often feel that it is not really that old. I watched the change of the guard and the costumes were very well done. Overall a pleasant visit. It can be seen as an afternoon away from the stress.
I went in throught the back entrace and walked all the way up to the main gate. Saw the changing of the guard

The first thing that crosses one's mind when Gyeongbokgung is mentioned is history. That first impression will be reinforced when you set foot in Gyeongbokgung. Not only is there history, there is also culture, colors, architecture and so on.  This place is so fascinating that I spent about 4 hours exploring every corner of the palace ground! When my poor feet complained, I sat myself at one of the many benches under shady trees and did some people watching.  It is amazing how they reconstructed and preserved this place in a very original state. It's definitely worth more than KRW 3,000 (the price of the ticket)!!  The must do's at Gyeongbokgung are: 1. Watch the changing of guards that happens at every hour from 10am to 3pm. When you hear the drums beating, be sure to be at the main entrance area. 2. Snap a photo with the guards at the main door which is facing Gwanghwamun. 3. Take a look at all the (kings, queens and princes') quarters that are opened for public viewing. Only 1 or 2 allows you to actually go into the quarters. But be careful of shoe theft. 4. Stroll along Hyangwonjeong Pavilion. The view around the hexagonal pavilion is just magnificent. 5. Take a walk to behind the palace, where you can get a glimpse of the Blue House (presidential palace). That's also the road to the National Folk Museum, a recommended drop-by where you can see the evolution of Korea.  The only don't is not to visit on a Tuesday as it is closed.  The Palace is quite wheelchair and stroller friendly. At places where there are stairs (except those where you have to climb up high e.g. to the main hall/quarters) there are paths for wheels.  There is a cafe near the Sujeongjeon hall, west of the main courtyard. Inside the cafe, you can also find a souvenir shop.

Very cheap admission (KRW2,000) for what you get. There was some sort of changing of the guard type thing around 11am. Unsure if it's hourly or at a certain time of the day. Over crowded with tour groups in the front main buildings. There's plenty of ground to cover in the back and fewer people.

We went to Gyeongbokgong palace only to watch the Opening of Royal Guard Changing Ceremony at 10 am in the morning at the main entrance. This is a great opportunity to experience the rare traditional scene just in front of us. We were so excited and took photos with the traditional costume of the Guards after the ceremony. While waiting for the ceremony to be started, we took the opportunity to visit National Palace Museum located on the left of Gyeongbokgong main entrance which is free admission.
Nice to walk around and to discover the many hidden corners.

I have one day to visit the sites of Seoul while on a recent business trip. This was a must see and the changing of the guards ceremony made it especially nice. It helped that I had an excellent tour guide, but all in all the beauty of the grounds spoke for themselves. The museum on the grounds was a bit hokey. Then again, I'm not a big museum person so probably not fair to criticize! I recommend this on the list of things to see -- if you go here, I would skip other temple sites. This was clearly the best.

Be prepared for a good walk as the palace compound is huge. The former kings must have chosen the place due to its good fengshui as it overlooks a mountain. If you want to know more about Korean history, head onto the museum inside the place which is covered by the entrance fee. There is basically information on how Koreans evolved over the years (i.e costumes, food, handwriting, traditions, etc). Also a good place to enjoy the air-condition after the long walk under the hot sun.  Love the trees and intricate architecture.  Be there before 10 am if you want to witness the changing of guards. The palace is closed every Tuesdays to allow it to be used for filming (presumably Korean period dramas).  As you head out of the palace, cross the road and walk straight for about 50-80 metres and you can find the Museum of King Sejong. TYou won't missed it because there is a huge statue of the King in front of the museum. Though small-scale, it's loaded with information and best of all, it's free. Do watch the short 4-D show to learn how the Koreans fought and won against their enemy with only 1/3 of the battleships. It's so surreal.  On your left after you cross the road as you exit the museum, you will find one of the biggest Starbucks in Seoul which is 4-storey high. A nice way to chill and end your trip to the palace.
Big place, definitely a must do. You could spend half to a full day self exploring.

I absolutely love this palace. It is breathtakingly gorgeous and ripe for photo opportunities. Free English tours are offered at 11:00, 1:30 and 3:30, which I highly recommend. Be ready for some fascinating information about the palace construction and Korean history.

This is 1 of the Five Grand Palaces and its the biggest located in the north of Seoul. Its a great visit for history buffs or those that love structures and want to see how the Joseon Dynasty lived. It is a huge space so expect to spend more than 4 hours if you want to fully enjoy and absorb the palace. The changing of guards is a nice bonus however some might find it a spectacle meant for tourist. One of my favourite structures is the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion surrounded by a man made lake. There is also the National Folk Museum of Korea which shouldn't be missed as you get a glimpse of how the Koreans lived through time. There are tonnes of photo ops for photography buffs however with the amount of visitors roaming around it can get annoying or tough to get good shots. Nothing a little patience can't fix.  Overall I would say its worth a visit if you are at Seoul. Easily accessible via the subway. Plus how can you go to Seoul and not visit a palace!

I'd like to start off by saying that I'm a history buff - especially the dynasties of East Asian countries. Having read so much good reviews, I made this palace my top priority during my visit. To say that I was disappointed would have been an understatement. It was like a palace on a budget. Don't go expecting the splendor of a bygone era. The sprawling grounds are filled with identical buildings with little to differentiate from one to another. Even my poor hard-working tour guide was hard put to infuse much enthusiasm into the group which had gone there with so much anticipation.

I went to Gyeongbokgung Palace the day after my arrival as I was informed that the palace was a must see in Seoul. It was certainly that. The entrance is a large open area with the palace in front of a serene mountain backdrop. Although not the original construction (rebuilt in late 19th and early 20th century), the buildings attempt to recreate the original design and appear to have achieved that very well. As you walk into the palace grounds you start to see just how massive the location is and the many different buildings it has to offer. I enjoyed the Geunjeongjeon (throne hall) and Gyeonghoeru (pavilion on the water) the most. The Geunjeongjeon holds the most interesting interior and the Gyeonghoeru offers the best spot for pictures. The many other buildings are interesting to look at and you can enter some of them for additional close ups of what the palace may have looked like. I spent a few hours here and that was just about right, which included viewing the changing of the guards which was pretty interesting as they are in traditional dress. The Korean folk museum is worth the charge of admission (free) for a quick walk through, but only advise visiting if you are staying in Seoul for an extended period. The drawback to the palace is the lack of interior in many of the buildings to give a sense of each buildings purpose and also of the daily life of the palace inhabitants.

The palace grounds are only a short distance from the subway station which is next to what is now the National Palace Museum. Gyeongbokgung Palace is in an area of central Seoul known as the Palace District. The grounds of Gyeongbokgung Palace are extensive, yet on first entering them from the nearby subway station you may find yourself (as we did) watching the Changing of the Guard Ceremony - an interesting spectacle if only for the colourful costumes!  After purchasing a ticket for the palace grounds (either W3,000 or W10,000 if you buy a combination ticket which includes other attractions) you enter through the impressive gateway into beautifully kept grounds with a number of elegantly restored and graceful palace buildings set against a backdrop of the mountains of Bukhansan National Park to the north.  As you walk around the extensive grounds, you can admire the architecture and ornate decoration of the different buildings (Gyeonghoe-ru Pavillion and Hyangwon-jeong are set in their own man-made lakes) and marvel at such a peaceful setting in the midst of a bustling city.  You are not able to enter the buildings (there are very few objects inside anyway), but you can see enough of the interior to appreciate the elaborate decoration and beautiful architecture.  Note that the palace is closed every Tuesday.  You can easily spend most of the day here, especially if you visit the National Folk Museum ( and gift shop) in the same grounds (entrance is free), which is interesting to anyone who wants to find out more about Korean history and culture.

When in Seoul as a tourist this is the #1 attraction. When on business and having 1-2 hours spare time during the day or weekend, visit this place. Although reconstructed after much destruction by the Japanese colonists and relatively simple for a palace, the overall experience is great and the grounds make for a nice walk. Entry WRN 3,000. Be prepared for herds of tourists though during weekends & holidays, so probably during the week is a better experience. When I was there in August it was quite warm but above all very humid, so prepare for some serious sweating while walking the grounds. The National Folk museum in the back on the right is OK, if you have another hour and to cool off, but more interesting for locals than for foreigners. Entry for the museum is free. Showing your palace ticket will let you enter the palace grounds again.

Of cause you have to see the royal palace if you are Ib Seoul. But dont put your expectations to high. The palace is surprisingly modest, but of cause its interesting to see how the king lived. Please dont see the change of guards. It seems to be only made for tourists and children and its simply a joke to watch. The guards are clumsy and lazy. In stead try to get access to Gyonghoeru-house in the palace-area. Not lots of tourists have the chance to go there and its interesting

With changing of the guards, wide expansive grounds and its very location in the centre of the city, Gyeongbokgung Palace gives visitors an insightful glimpse of the rich traditions of the Josun dynasty. Although Changdeokgung Palace is a UNESCO heritage site, the limited access to protect the site ironically makes it less of an experience.

I had to do a rush through due to time constraints, but I wish I had a whole afternoon to spend here. This place is HUGE!! When you enter the grounds, you think....this is it. But it just keeps going. Wear comfortable shoes! If you watch historical Korean dramas, you'll really appreciate this place. You'll get a understanding of the whole royal family, servant quarters. Great photo opportunities. Although the kids had no appreciations for it, they loved all the running around they could do.

Make sure you bring your walking shoes, the facility is huge! We saw a lot of people with bad shoes on. This is an amazing opportunity to see history. What a treat! The museum is also quite good. It is well worth the money and your time. Great for kids and adults. It may be difficult to bring someone in a wheelchair.

The low cost of the palace makes it worth it to just walk in and take a look around. I believe a majority of it is all reconstructed, so you aren't looking at centuries old buildings. You can still be impressed with the grounds and the effort to protect the culture and history.

It's 3000 Won to enter, which isn't bad. This palace is really intact and you can tell that they keep it preserved very well. The architecture is amazing! You can't fully go inside, but you can take a peek inside, to see how the other half lived back in the day.

Entering the Palace grounds is deceptive - it is really a large complex and you could spend a good deal of time exploring the buildings (re-creations). There are ceremonies near the entrance with folks in period costumes. The architectural details are beautiful. There is a good museum across the street. We did the palace grounds - then had lunch (bibimbop) nearby and then went to the museum. You can also walk to the Blue House from here - that's the Korean White House where their President lives.

Having seen so many palaces and temples in Asia, we inititally thought this would be an hour long, in and out, type of attraction. To my amazement, between the palace, the changing of the guard and the two museums on the grounds of the palace, we spent the better part of the day here.  The Palace grounds themselves, house many different buildings in more than once style, so it is worth it to wander and see all the areas and the gardens that connect them. Everything is well kept and protected. Some buildings have rooms furnished and set up to give one a glimpse of how daily life was conducted in this palace. Although the changing of the gaurd is an obvious tourist catch with university age guards with glued on beards, it is still a fun and colourful display. There are two free museums on the grounds that are most definitely worth a visit as well. The Royal museum contains a restaurant, that while not cheap, offers high quality food that is very tasty.

We did a three-hour morning tour which included this palace complex. We watched the colourful changing of the guard procession at 10.00am.  The complex contains beautiful ornate buildings set against the majestic mountain backdrop and with a serene man-made lake in the middle.  Unfortunately there wasn’t much to see inside the palace buildings as everything has been removed.  Nevertheless, something not to miss on your Seoul holiday.  Also in the complex is the National Folk Museum of Korea which we were only permitted to pay a fleeting visit to due to time constraints. It looks full of interesting exhibits and will definitely merit a longer visit when we next visit Seoul.

I think the many many other reviews have said it all. Just want to share some info that visitors may need. There are free (?) guided tours in various languages. And on weekends, there are free guided tours by volunteer organizations, which is what we took. Our guide was a 13 year old high school student. While we were there, we could try on Korean traditional costumes for free and for a very good laugh. ;) The palace is closed every Tuesday.  While Gyeongbok Palace is definitely worth a visit, we heard that Changdeokgung Palace and its gardens were even better. Unfortunately, did not get to see Changdeokgung as we went on a Monday when it was closed ;( so do plan your trips!

Gyeongbokgung palace, the obvious seat of government in older times, is a showpiece for the city, staring down at the city's main avenue through the reconstructed Gwanghwamun gate, giving it the proper sightlines so important in eastern palace layouts. Seen from the outside from the newly built pedestrian center area of that avenue, the gate and palace grounds are nicely framed by a backdrop of green mountains. Being the main palace in Seoul, it features a number of displays, including performers in traditional dress showing various aspect of court pageantry. Also worth visiting is the folk museum within. The buildings are predictable large and ornate, and more geometrically laid out than at other palaces. The detailing and shape of the roofs are unique, and the large number of carved stone figures, some of them unfortunately encased in transparent boxes due to unruly visitors, interesting indeed. As usual in such palaces, the women's sleeping quarters have a more livable look to them. Maintenance and upkeep are very good, reflective of the country's current prosperity.

Worth a visit if you have some extra time. There are many palces in Seoul, so pick one and go. This one is one of the biggest ones, another one to consider is the Changdeokgung Palace, also a big one and that one is a cultural heritage site. The Gyongbokgun Palace took us at least an hour to get around and we could have spent longer. Lots of walking here, be prepared and not in a rush.  This palace I believe closes at 6pm, and the last entry is at 5pm, so get there before then or take pictures from the outside only. It is worth going inside to see more.  The subway exit will be obvious once you get to the right one because the walkway sort of looks like a palace would look only a little more modern. Sorry do not remember which exit number, but all the travel maps will probably be able to tell you which one.  There are gift shops inside this one and the other ones.  Anyway worth a visit, lots of walking, need good walking shoes, refreshed camera battery, etc...
A rather colourful palace, certainly more so compared to the Forbidden City in Beijing. Quite enjoyed the pagaentry in front of the palace.

I visited Gyeongbokgung Palace on February 14, 2010, the second day of Seollal – the Lunar New Year celebration, and managed to get inside without paying a ticket. Not sure now if it worked for other visitors but on that day, I was wearing two items belonging to the 'hanbok' suit, a silk shirt and a soft cotton jacket, which I bought in Insadong area, earlier the same day. (Of course, during the wintertime, you will not wear just those two, but some more layers above to make you warm.) Although the Gyeongbokgung palace itself was an interesting experience for me (it was my first visit to a Korean historical site), I particularly liked an internal museum that is located within the site – the National Folk Museum of Korea. The museum provides an insight to the old textile manufacture, the works in the field like harvest & many food descriptions (including their beloved kimchi specialty) and many more things. I specifically enjoyed studying exceptional male and female dresses, including those intended for wearing by royalties or in weddings.  Within the same area of Gyeongbokgung Palace there were several outdoor exhibitions and workshops related to the old skills, like kite making or so. It looked to me that those workshops were established intentionally during the Seollal days because Koreans are likely to practice playing traditional games and folk custom, including wearing their colorful 'hanbok' suits.  Near the area of Gyeongbokgung Palace is a large rectangular square that was populated with hundreds of people, playing with kites flying etc. Although it was freezing cold those days in Seoul, I suppose that the lunar year celebrations are probably the best time to visit Gyeongbokgung Palace (as well as the other similar areas of the Korean capital). It is obvious that most of the locals, who do not plan to travel to the countryside for visiting their families and relatives, spend those days to visit the palaces too. That means it is a good opportunity to mingle with Korean people and learn about that part of their lifestyle.

My 1 of Korean friends told me that the palaces are all build with science and all paintings have great meaning. Even a stone locates with science and even a line in painting means the life. I visited again the palaces and then I touched deeply. Most things what I saw, where I visited are always have meaning of life. Nowadays Korea have been modern like Western but still they have many important traditional things. So I recommend you to visit the place if you want real Korea thing.

With changing of the guards, wide expansive grounds and its very location in the centre of the city, Gyeongbokgung Palace gives visitors an insightful glimpse of the rich traditions of the Josun dynasty. Although Changdeokgung Palace is a UNESCO heritage site, the limited access to protect the site ironically makes it less of an experience.
A rather colourful palace, certainly more so compared to the Forbidden City in Beijing. Quite enjoyed the pagaentry in front of the palace.

I visited Gyeongbokgung Palace on February 14, 2010, the second day of Seollal – the Lunar New Year celebration, and managed to get inside without paying a ticket. Not sure now if it worked for other visitors but on that day, I was wearing two items belonging to the 'hanbok' suit, a silk shirt and a soft cotton jacket, which I bought in Insadong area, earlier the same day. (Of course, during the wintertime, you will not wear just those two, but some more layers above to make you warm.) Although the Gyeongbokgung palace itself was an interesting experience for me (it was my first visit to a Korean historical site), I particularly liked an internal museum that is located within the site – the National Folk Museum of Korea. The museum provides an insight to the old textile manufacture, the works in the field like harvest & many food descriptions (including their beloved kimchi specialty) and many more things. I specifically enjoyed studying exceptional male and female dresses, including those intended for wearing by royalties or in weddings.  Within the same area of Gyeongbokgung Palace there were several outdoor exhibitions and workshops related to the old skills, like kite making or so. It looked to me that those workshops were established intentionally during the Seollal days because Koreans are likely to practice playing traditional games and folk custom, including wearing their colorful 'hanbok' suits.  Near the area of Gyeongbokgung Palace is a large rectangular square that was populated with hundreds of people, playing with kites flying etc. Although it was freezing cold those days in Seoul, I suppose that the lunar year celebrations are probably the best time to visit Gyeongbokgung Palace (as well as the other similar areas of the Korean capital). It is obvious that most of the locals, who do not plan to travel to the countryside for visiting their families and relatives, spend those days to visit the palaces too. That means it is a good opportunity to mingle with Korean people and learn about that part of their lifestyle.

I have to agree with one of the other reviewers who said, "If you've seen one palace, you've seen them all." I lived in Seoul and visited several of them, and, although I believe this is the only one that costs money, it is also the best one. I would highly recommend a visit to anyone who is in town. When I was there, admission cost only 1000 won, so it was a great value.

this palace probably presents the image of Korean history, culture, palaces stuff, but think again to bring teenagers to this place. this was the first place I visited during my visit to Seoul and all I could say is 'errrr.. can we go somewhere else?' this place is fantastic for enthusiastic people who's interested in Korean history, etc. but for teenagers, this place is better avoided. we won't like it.
